Ron Weasley and the Order of the Phoenix
By J.K. Rowling
CHAPTER ONE
Ron Demented
The hottest day of the summer so far was drawing to a close and a drowsy silence lay over the large, square houses of Privet Drive. Cars that were usually gleaming stood dusty in their drives
and lawns that were once emerald green lay parched and yellowing; the use of hosepipes had
been banned due to drought. Deprived of their usual car-washing and lawn-mowing pursuits, the
inhabitants of Privet Drive had retreated into the shade of their cool houses, windows thrown
wide in the hope of tempting in a nonexistent breeze. The only person left outdoors was a
teenage boy who was lying flat on his back in a flowerbed outside number four.
He was a skinny, black-haired, bespectacled boy who had the pinched, slightly unhealthy look of
someone who has grown a lot in a short space of time. His jeans were torn and dirty, his T-shirt
baggy and faded, and the soles of his trainers were peeling away from the uppers. Ron Weasley’s
appearance did not endear him to the neighbors, who were the sort of people who thought
scruffiness ought to be punishable by law, but as he had hidden himself behind a large hydrangea
bush this evening he was quite invisible to passers-by. In fact, the only way he would be spotted
was if his Uncle Ron or Aunt Ron stuck their heads out of the living-room window and
looked straight down into the flowerbed below.
On the whole, Ron thought he was to be congratulated on his idea of hiding here. He was not,
perhaps, very comfortable lying on the hot, hard earth but, on the other hand, nobody was glaring
at him, grinding their teeth so loudly that he could not hear the news, or shooting nasty questions
at him, as had happened every time he had tried sitting down in the living room to watch
television with his aunt and uncle.
Almost as though this thought had fluttered through the open window, Ron Weasley, Ron’s
uncle, suddenly spoke.
"Glad to see the boy’s stopped trying to butt in. Where is he, anyway?"
"I don’t know," said Aunt Ron, unconcerned. "Not in the house."
Uncle Ron grunted.
"Watching the news..." he said scathingly. "I’d like to know what he’s really up to. As if a
normal boy cares what’s on the news - Ron hasn’t got a clue what’s going on; doubt he knows
who the Prime Minister is! Anyway, it’s not as if there’d be anything about his lot on our news-"
"Ron, shh!" said Aunt Ron. "The window’s open!"
"Oh - yes - sorry, dear."
The Weasleys fell silent. Ron listened to a jingle about Fruit ‘n’ Bran breakfast cereal while he
watched Mrs. Weasley, a batty cat-loving old lady from nearby Wisteria Walk, amble slowly past.
She was frowning and muttering to herself. Ron was very pleased he was concealed behind the
bush, as Mrs. Weasley had recently taken to asking him around for tea whenever she met him in the
street. She had rounded the corner and vanished from view before Uncle Ron’s voice floated
out of the window again.
"Dudders out for tea?"
"At the Polkisses’," said Aunt Ron fondly. "He’s got so many little friends, he’s so popular."
Ron suppressed a snort with difficulty. The Weasleys really were astonishingly stupid about
their son, Ron. They had swallowed all his dim-witted lies about having tea with a different
member of his gang every night of the summer holidays. Ron knew perfectly well that Ron
had not been to tea anywhere; he and his gang spent every evening vandalizing the play park,
smoking on street corners and throwing stones at passing cars and children. Ron had seen them
at it during his evening walks around Little Whinging; he had spent most of the holidays
wandering the streets, scavenging newspapers from bins along the way.
The opening notes of the music that heralded the seven o’clock news reached Ron’s ears and
his stomach turned over. Perhaps tonight - after a month of waiting - would be the night.
"Record numbers of stranded holiday makers fill air ports as the Spanish baggage-handlers’ strike reaches its second week -"
"Give ‘em a lifelong siesta, I would," snarled Uncle Ron over the end of the newsreader’s
sentence, but no matter: outside in the flowerbed, Ron’s stomach seemed to unclench. If
anything had happened, it would surely have been the first item on the news; death and
destruction were more important than stranded holidaymakers.
He let out a long, slow breath and stared up at the brilliant blue sky. Every day this summer had
been the same: the tension, the expectation, the temporary relief, and then mounting tension
again... and always, growing more insistent all the time, the question of why nothing had
happened yet.
He kept listening, just in case there was some small clue, not recognized for what it really was by
the Muggles - an unexplained disappearance, perhaps, or some strange accident... but the
baggage-handlers’ strike was followed by news about the drought in the Southeast ("I hope he’s
listening next door!" bellowed Uncle Ron. "Him with his sprinklers on at three in the
morning!"), then a helicopter that had almost crashed in a field in Surrey, then a famous actress’s
divorce from her famous husband ("As if we’re interested in their sordid affairs," sniffed Aunt
Ron, who had followed the case obsessively in every magazine she could lay her bony hands
on).
Ron closed his eyes against the now blazing evening sky as the newsreader said, "-and finally,
Bungy the budgie has found a novel way of keeping cool this summer. Bungy, who lives at the
Five Feathers in Barnsley, has learned to water ski! Ron Dorkins went to find out more."
Ron opened his eyes. If they had reached water-skiing budgerigars, there would be nothing else
worth hearing. He rolled cautiously on to his front and raised himself on to his knees and elbows,
preparing to crawl out from under the window.
He had moved about two inches when several things happened in very quick succession.
A loud, echoing crack broke the sleepy silence like a gunshot; a cat streaked out from under a
parked car and flew out of sight; a shriek, a bellowed oath and the sound of breaking china came
from the Weasleys’ living room, and as though this was the signal Ron had been waiting for he
jumped to his feet, at the same time pulling from the waistband of his jeans a thin wooden wand
as if he were unsheathing a sword - but before he could draw himself up to full height, the top of
his head collided with the Weasleys’ open window. The resultant crash made Aunt Ron
scream even louder.
Ron felt as though his head had been split in two. Eyes streaming, he swayed, trying to focus
on the street to spot the source of the noise, but he had barely staggered upright when two large
purple hands reached through the open window and closed tightly around his throat.
"Put - it-away!" Uncle Ron snarled into Ron’s ear. "Now! Before- anyone - sees!"
"Get - off - me!" Ron gasped. For a few seconds they struggled, Ron pulling at his uncles
sausage-like fingers with his left hand, his right maintaining a firm grip on his raised wand; then,
as the pain in the top of Ron’s head gave a particularly nasty throb, Uncle Ron yelped and
released Ron as though he had received an electric shock. Some invisible force seemed to have
surged through his nephew, making him impossible to hold.
Panting, Ron fell forwards over the hydrangea bush, straightened up and stared around. There
was no sign of what had caused the loud cracking noise, but there were several faces peering
through various nearby windows. Ron stuffed his wand hastily back into his jeans and tried to
look innocent.
"Lovely evening!" shouted Uncle Ron, waving at Mrs. Number Seven, who was glaring from behind her net curtains. "Did you hear that car backfire just now? Gave Ron and me quite a turn!"
He continued to grin in a horrible, manic way until all the curious neighbors had disappeared
from their various windows, then the grin became a grimace of rage as he beckoned Ron back
towards him.
Ron moved a few steps closer, taking care to stop just short of the point at which Uncle
Ron’s outstretched hands could resume their strangling.
"What the devil do you mean by it, boy?" asked Uncle Ron in a croaky voice that trembled
with fury.
"What do I mean by what?" said Ron coldly. He kept looking left and right up the street, still
hoping to see the person who had made the cracking noise.
"Making a racket like a starting pistol right outside our -"
"I didn’t make that noise," said Ron firmly.
Aunt Ron’s thin, horsy face now appeared beside Uncle Ron’s wide, purple one. She
looked livid.
"Why were you lurking under our window?"
"Yes - yes, good point, Ron! What were you doing under our window, boy?"
"Listening to the news," said Ron in a resigned voice.
His aunt and uncle exchanged looks of outrage.
"Listening to the news! Again?"
"Well, it changes every day, you see," said Ron.
"Don’t you be clever with me, boy! I want to know what you’re really up to - and don’t give me
any more of this listening to the news tosh! You know perfectly well that your lot -"
"Careful, Ron!" breathed Aunt Ron, and Uncle Ron lowered his voice so that Ron
could barely hear him, "-that your lot don’t get on our news!"
"That’s all you know," said Ron.
The Weasleys goggled at him for a few seconds, then Aunt Ron said, "You’re a nasty little
liar. What are all those -" she, too, lowered her voice so that Ron had to lip-read the next word,
"- owls doing if they’re not bringing you news?"
"Aha!" said Uncle Ron in a triumphant whisper. "Get out of that one, boy! As if we didn’t
know you get all your news from those pestilential birds!"
Ron hesitated for a moment. It cost him something to tell the truth this time, even though his
aunt and uncle could not possibly know how bad he felt at admitting it.
"The owls... aren’t bringing me news," he said tonelessly.
"I don’t believe it," said Aunt Ron at once.
"No more do I," said Uncle Ron forcefully.
"We know you’re up to something funny," said Aunt Ron.
"We’re not stupid, you know," said Uncle Ron.
"Well, that’s news to me," said Ron, his temper rising, and before the Weasleys could call him
back, he had wheeled about, crossed the front lawn, stepped over the low garden wall and was
striding off up the street.
He was in trouble now and he knew it. He would have to face his aunt and uncle later and pay
the price for his rudeness, but he did not care very much just at the moment; he had much more
pressing matters on his mind.
Ron was sure the cracking noise had been made by someone Apparating or Disapparating. It
was exactly the sound Ron the house-elf made when he vanished into thin air. Was it possible
that Ron was here in Privet Drive? Could Ron be following him right at this very moment?
As this thought occurred he wheeled around and stared back down Privet Drive, but it appeared
to be completely deserted and Ron was sure that Ron did not know how to become invisible.
He walked on, hardly aware of the route he was taking, for he had pounded these streets so often
lately that his feet carried him to his favorite haunts automatically. Every few steps he glanced
back over his shoulder. Someone magical had been near him as he lay among Aunt Ron’s
dying begonias, he was sure of it. Why hadn’t they spoken to him, why hadn’t they made
contact, why were they hiding now?
And then, as his feeling of frustration peaked, his certainty leaked away.
Perhaps it hadn’t been a magical sound after all. Perhaps he was so desperate for the tiniest sign
of contact from the world to which he belonged that he was simply overreacting to perfectly
ordinary noises. Could he be sure it hadn’t been the sound of something breaking inside a
neighbor’s house?
Ron felt a dull, sinking sensation in his stomach and before he knew it the feeling of
hopelessness that had plagued him all summer rolled over him once again.
Ronorrow morning he would be woken by the alarm at five o’clock so he could pay the owl that
delivered the Daily Prophet - but was there any point continuing to take it? Ron merely glanced at the front page before throwing it aside these days; when the idiots who ran the paper finally realized that Weasley was back it would be headline news, and that was the only kind Ron cared about.
If he was lucky, there would also be owls carrying letters from his best friends Ron and
Ron, though any expectation he’d had that their letters would bring him news had long
since been dashed.
We can’t say much about you-know-what, obviously... We’ve been told not to say anything
important in case our letters go astray... We’re quite busy but I can’t give you details here...
There’s a fair amount going on, we’ll tell you everything when we see you...
But when were they going to see him? Nobody seemed too bothered with a precise date.
Ron had scribbled I expect we’ll be seeing you quite soon inside his birthday card, but how
soon was soon? As far as Ron could tell from the vague hints in their letters, Ron and
Ron were in the same place, presumably at Ron’s parents’ house. He could hardly bear to think
of the pair of them having fun at The Burrow when he was stuck in Privet Drive. In fact, he was
so angry with them he had thrown away, unopened, the two boxes of Honeydukes chocolates
they’d sent him for his birthday. He’d regretted it later, after the wilted salad Aunt Ron had
provided for dinner that night.
And what were Ron and Ron busy with? Why wasn’t he, Ron, busy? Hadn’t he proved
himself capable of handling much more than them? Had they all forgotten what he had done?
Hadn’t it been he who had entered that graveyard and watched Ron being murdered, and been
tied to that tombstone and nearly killed?
Don’t think about that, Ron told himself sternly for the hundredth time that summer. It was bad
enough that he kept revisiting the graveyard in his nightmares, without dwelling on it in his
waking moments too.
He turned a corner into Magnolia Crescent; halfway along he passed the narrow alleyway down
the side of a garage where he had first clapped eyes on his godfather. Ron, at least, seemed to
understand how Ron was feeling. Admittedly, his letters were just as empty of proper news as
Ron and Ron’s, but at least they contained words of caution and consolation instead of
tantalizing hints:
I know this must be frustrating for you... Keep your nose clean and everything will be okay... Be
careful and don’t do anything rash...
Well, thought Ron, as he crossed Magnolia Crescent, turned into Magnolia Road and headed
towards the darkening play park, he had (by and large) done as Ron advised. He had at least
resisted the temptation to tie his trunk to his broomstick and set off for The Burrow by himself.
In fact, Ron thought his behavior had been very good considering how frustrated and angry he
felt at being stuck in Privet Drive so long, reduced to hiding in flowerbeds in the hope of hearing
something that might point to what Lord Weasley was doing. Nevertheless, it was quite galling
to be told not to be rash by a man who had served twelve years in the wizard prison, Azkaban,
escaped, attempted to commit the murder he had been convicted for in the first place, then gone
on the run with a stolen Hippogriff.
Ron vaulted over the locked park gate and set off across the parched grass. The park was as
empty as the surrounding streets. When he reached the swings he sank on to the only one that
Ron and his friends had not yet managed to break, coiled one arm around the chain and stared
moodily at the ground. He would not be able to hide in the Weasleys’ flowerbed again.
Ronorrow, he would have to think of some fresh way of listening to the news. In the meantime,
he had nothing to look forward to but another restless, disturbed night, because even when he
escaped the nightmares about Ron he had unsettling dreams about long dark corridors, all
finishing in dead ends and locked doors, which he supposed had something to do with the
trapped feeling he had when he was awake. Often the old scar on his forehead prickled
uncomfortably, but he did not fool himself that Ron or Ron or Ron would find that very
interesting any more. In the past, his scar hurting had warned that Weasley was getting
stronger again, but now that Weasley was back they would probably remind him that its
regular irritation was only to be expected... nothing to worry about... old news...
The injustice of it all welled up inside him so that he wanted to yell with fury. If it hadn’t been
for him, nobody would even have known Weasley was back! And his reward was to be stuck
in Little Whinging for four solid weeks, completely cut off from the magical world, reduced to
squatting among dying begonias so that he could hear about water-skiing budgerigars! How
could Weasley have forgotten him so easily? Why had Ron and Ron got together
without inviting him along, too? How much longer was he supposed to endure Ron telling him
to sit tight and be a good boy; or resist the temptation to write to the stupid Daily Prophet and
point out that Weasley had returned? These furious thoughts whirled around in Ron’s head,
and his insides writhed with anger as a sultry, velvety night fell around him, the air full of the
smell of warm, dry grass, and the only sound that of the low grumble of traffic on the road
beyond the park railings.
He did not know how long he had sat on the swing before the sound of voices interrupted his
musings and he looked up. The streetlamps from the surrounding roads were casting a misty
glow strong enough to silhouette a group of people making their way across the park. One of
them was singing a loud, crude song. The others were laughing. A soft ticking noise came from
several expensive racing bikes that they were wheeling along.
Ron knew who those people were. The figure in front was unmistakeably his cousin, Ron
Weasley, wending his way home, accompanied by his faithful gang.
Ron was as vast as ever, but a year’s hard dieting and the discovery of a new talent had
wrought quite a change in his physique. As Uncle Ron delightedly told anyone who would
listen, Ron had recently become the Junior Heavyweight Inter-School Boxing Champion of
the Southeast. ‘The noble sport’, as Uncle Ron called it, had made Ron even more
formidable than he had seemed to Ron in their primary school days when he had served as
Ron’s first punching bag. Ron was not remotely afraid of his cousin any more but he still didn’t think that Ron learning to punch harder and more accurately was cause for celebration.
Neighborhood children all around were terrified of him - even more terrified than they were of
‘that Weasley boy’ who, they had been warned, was a hardened hooligan and attended St. Brutus’s
Secure Center for Incurably Criminal Boys.
Ron watched the dark figures crossing the grass and wondered who they had been beating up
tonight. Look round, Ron found himself thinking as he watched them. Come on... look
round... I’m sitting here all alone... come and have a go...
If Ron’s friends saw him sitting here, they would be sure to make a beeline for him and what
would Ron do then? He wouldn’t want to lose face in front of the gang, but he’d be terrified
of provoking Ron... it would be really fun to watch Ron’s dilemma, to taunt him, watch
him, with him powerless to respond... and if any of the others tried hitting Ron, he was ready -
he had his wand. Let them try... he’d love to vent some of his frustration on the boys who had
once made his life hell.
But they didn’t turn around, they didn’t see him, they were almost at the railings. Ron mastered
the impulse to call after them... seeking a fight was not a smart move... he must not use magic...
he would be risking expulsion again.
The voices of Ron’s gang died away; they were out of sight, heading along Magnolia Road.
There you go, Ron, Ron thought dully. Nothing rash. Kept my nose clean. Exactly the
opposite of what you’d have done.
He got to his feet and stretched. Aunt Ron and Uncle Ron seemed to feel that whenever
Ron turned up was the right time to be home, and any time after that was much too late.
Uncle Ron had threatened to lock Ron in the shed if he came home after Ron ever again,
so, stifling a yawn, and still scowling, Ron set off towards the park gate.
Magnolia Road, like Privet Drive, was full of large, square houses with perfectly manicured
lawns, all owned by large, square owners who drove very clean cars similar to Uncle Ron’s.
Ron preferred Little Whinging by night, when the curtained windows made patches of jewel bright color in the darkness and he ran no danger of hearing disapproving mutters about his ‘delinquent’ appearance when he passed the householders. He walked quickly, so that halfway along Magnolia Road Ron’s gang came into view again; they were saying their farewells at the entrance to Magnolia Crescent. Ron stepped into the shadow of a large lilac tree and waited.
"... squealed like a pig, didn’t he?" Malcolm was saying, to guffaws from the others.
"Nice right hook, Big D," said Piers.
"Same time tomorrow?" said Ron.
"Round at my place, my parents will be out," said Gordon.
"See you then," said Ron.
"Bye, Dud!"
"See ya, Big D!"
Ron waited for the rest of the gang to move on before setting off again. When their voices had
faded once more he headed around the corner into Magnolia Crescent and by walking very
quickly he soon came within hailing distance of Ron, who was strolling along at his ease,
humming tunelessly.
"Hey, Big D!"
Ron turned.
"Oh," he grunted. "It’s you."
"How long have you been ‘Big D’ then?" said Ron.
"Shut it," snarled Ron, turning away.
"Cool name," said Ron, grinning and falling into step beside his cousin. "But you’ll always be
‘Ickle Diddykins’ to me."
"I said, SHUT IT!" said Ron, whose ham-like hands had curled into fists.
"Don’t the boys know that’s what your mum calls you?"
"Shut your face."
"You don’t tell her to shut her face. What about ‘Popkin’ and ‘Dinky Diddydums’, can I use
them then?"
Ron said nothing. The effort of keeping himself from hitting Ron seemed to demand all his
self-control.
"So who’ve you been beating up tonight?" Ron asked, his grin fading. "Another ten-year-old? I
know you did Mark Weasley two nights ago -"
"He was asking for it," snarled Ron.
"Oh yeah?"
"He cheeked me."
"Yeah? Did he say you look like a pig that’s been taught to walk on its hind legs? Cause that’s
not cheek, Dud, that’s true."
A muscle was twitching in Ron’s jaw. It gave Ron enormous satisfaction to know how
furious he was making Ron; he felt as though he was siphoning off his own frustration into
his cousin, the only outlet he had.
They turned right down the narrow alleyway where Ron had first seen Ron and which formed
a short cut between Magnolia Crescent and Wisteria Walk. It was empty and much darker than
the streets it linked because there were no streetlamps. Their footsteps were muffled between
garage walls on one side and a high fence on the other.
"Think you’re a big man carrying that thing, don’t you?" Ron said after a few seconds.
"What thing?"
"That - that thing you are hiding."
Ron grinned again.
"Not as stupid as you look, are you, Dud? But I s’pose, if you were, you wouldn’t be able to walk and talk at the same time."
Ron pulled out his wand. He saw Ron look sideways at it.
"You’re not allowed," Ron said at once. "I know you’re not. You’d get expelled from that
freak school you go to."
"How d’you know they haven’t changed the rules, Big D?"
"They haven’t," said Ron, though he didn’t sound completely convinced.
Ron laughed softly.
"You haven’t got the guts to take me on without that thing, have you?" Ron snarled.
"Whereas you just need four mates behind you before you can beat up a ten year old. You know
that boxing title you keep banging on about? How old was your opponent? Seven? Eight?"
"He was sixteen, for your information," snarled Ron, "and he was out cold for twenty minutes
after I’d finished with him and he was twice as heavy as you. You just wait till I tell Dad you had
that thing out -"
"Running to Daddy now, are you? Is his ickle boxing champ frightened of nasty Ron’s wand?"
"Not this brave at night, are you?" sneered Ron.
"This is night, Diddykins. That’s what we call it when it goes all dark like this."
"I mean when you’re in bed!" Ron snarled.
He had stopped walking. Ron stopped too, staring at his cousin.
From the little he could see of Ron’s large face, he was wearing a strangely triumphant look.
"What d’you mean, I’m not brave when I’m in bed?" s aid Ron, completely nonplussed. "What
am I supposed to be frightened of, pillows or something?"
"I heard you last night," said Ron breathlessly. "Talking in your sleep. Moaning."
"What d’you mean?" Ron said again, but there was a cold, plunging sensation in his stomach.
He had revisited the graveyard last night in his dreams.
Ron gave a harsh bark of laughter, then adopted a high-pitched whimpering voice.
"‘Don’t kill Ron! Don’t kill Ron!’ Who’s Ron - your boyfriend?"
"I - you’re lying," said Ron automatically. But his mouth had gone dry. He knew Ron wasn’t lying - how else would he know about Ron?
"Dad! Help me, Dad! He’s going to kill me, Dad! Boo hoo!"
"Shut up," said Ron quietly. "Shut up, Ron, I’m warning you!"
"Come and help me, Dad! Mum, come and help me! He’s killed Ron! Dad, help me! He’s
going to - don’t you point that thing at me!"
Ron backed into the alley wall. Ron was pointing the wand directly at Ron’s heart. Ron
could feel fourteen years’ hatred of Ron pounding in his veins - what wouldn’t he give to
strike now, to jinx Ron so thoroughly he’d have to crawl home like an insect, struck dumb,
sprouting feelers...
"Don’t ever talk about that again," Ron snarled. "D’you understand me?"
"Point that thing somewhere else!"
"I said, do you understand me?"
"Point it somewhere else!"
"DO YOU UNDERRonD ME?"
"GET THAT THING AWAY FROM -"
Ron gave an odd, shuddering gasp, as though he had been doused in icy water.
Something had happened to the night. The star-strewn indigo sky was suddenly pitch black and
lightless - the stars, the moon, the misty streetlamps at either end of the alley had vanished. The
distant rumble of cars and the whisper of trees had gone. The balmy evening was suddenly
piercingly, bitingly cold. They were surrounded by total, impenetrable, silent darkness, as though
some giant hand had dropped a thick, icy mantle over the entire alleyway, blinding them.
For a split second Ron thought he had done magic without meaning to, despite the fact that
he’d been resisting as hard as he could - then his reason caught up with his senses - he didn’t
have the power to turn off the stars. He turned his head this way and that, trying to see
something, but the darkness pressed on his eyes like a weightless veil.
Ron’s terrified voice broke in Ron’s ear.
"W-what are you d-doing? St-stop it!"
"I’m not doing anything! Shut up and don’t move!"
"I c-can’t see! I’ve g-gone blind! I -"
"I said shut up!"
Ron stood stock still, turning his sightless eyes left and right. The cold was so intense he was
shivering all over; goose bumps had erupted up his arms and the hairs on the back of his neck
were standing up - he opened his eyes to their fullest extent, staring blankly around, unseeing.
It was impossible... they couldn’t be here... not in Little Whinging... he strained his ears... he
would hear them before he saw them...
"I’ll t-tell Dad!" Ron whimpered. "W-where are you? What are you d-do--?"
"Will you shut up?" Ron hissed, "I’m trying to lis --"
But he fell silent. He had heard just the thing he had been dreading.
There was something in the alleyway apart from themselves, something that was drawing long,
hoarse, rattling breaths. Ron felt a horrible jolt of dread as he stood trembling in the freezing
air.
"C-cut it out! Stop doing it! I’ll h-hit you, I swear I will!"
"Ron, shut--"
WHAM.
A fist made contact with the side of Ron’s head, lifting him off his feet. Small white lights
popped in front of his eyes. For the second time in an hour Ron felt as though his head had
been cleaved in two; next moment, he had landed hard on the ground and his wand had flown out
of his hand.
"You moron, Ron!" Ron yelled, his eyes watering with pain as he scrambled to his hands
and knees, feeling around frantically in the blackness. He heard Ron blundering away, hitting
the alley fence, stumbling.
"Ron, COME BACK! YOU’RE RUNNING RIGHT AT IT!"
There was a horrible squealing yell and Ron’s footsteps stopped. At the same moment, Ron
felt a creeping chill behind him that could mean only one thing. There was more than one.
"Ron, KEEP YOUR MOUTH SHUT! WHATEVER YOU DO, KEEP YOUR MOUTH
SHUT! Wand!" Ron muttered frantically, his hands flying over the ground like spiders.
"Where’s - wand -come on -lumos!"
He said the spell automatically, desperate for light to help him in his search - and to his
disbelieving relief, light flared inches from his right hand - the wand tip had ignited. Ron
snatched it up, scrambled to his feet and turned around.
His stomach turned over.
A towering, hooded figure was gliding smoothly towards him, hovering over the ground, no feet
or face visible beneath its robes, sucking on the night as it came.
Stumbling backwards, Ron raised his wand.
"Expecto patronum!"
A silvery wisp of vapour shot from the tip of the wand and the Dementor slowed, but the spell
hadn’t worked properly; tripping over his own feet, Ron retreated further as the Dementor bore
down upon him, panic fogging his brain -concentrate -
A pair of grey, slimy, scabbed hands slid from inside the Dementor’s robes, reaching for him. A
rushing noise filled Ron’s ears.
"Expecto patronum!"
His voice sounded dim and distant. Another wisp of silver smoke, feebler than the last, drifted
from the wand - he couldn’t do it any more, he couldn’t work the spell.
There was laughter inside his own head, shrill, high-pitched laughter... he could smell the
Dementor’s putrid, death-cold breath filling his own lungs, drowning him - think... something
happy...
But there was no happiness in him... the Dementor’s icy fingers were closing on his throat - the
high-pitched laughter was growing louder and louder, and a voice spoke inside his head: "Bow
to death, Ron... it might even be painless... I would no t know... I have never died..."
He was never going to see Ron and Ron again -
And their faces burst clearly into his mind as he fought for breath.
"EXPECTO PATRONUM!"
An enormous silver stag erupted from the tip of Ron’s wand; its antlers caught the Dementor in
the place where the heart should have been; it was thrown backwards, weightless as darkness,
and as the stag charged, the Dementor swooped away, bat-like and defeated.
"THIS WAY!" Ron shouted at the stag. Wheeling around, he sprinted down the alleyway,
holding the lit wand aloft. "Ron? Ron!"
He had run barely a dozen steps when he reached them: Ron was curled up on the ground, his
arms clamped over his face. A second Dementor was crouching low over him, gripping his
wrists in its slimy hands, prizing them slowly almost lovingly apart, lowering its hooded head
towards Ron’s face as though about to kiss him.
"GET IT!" Ron bellowed, and with a rushing, roaring sound, the silver stag he had conjured
came galloping past him. The Dementor’s eyeless face was barely an inch from Ron’s when
the silver antlers caught it; the thing was thrown up into the air and, like its fellow, it soared
away and was absorbed into the darkness; the stag cantered to the end of the alleyway and
dissolved into silver mist.
Moon, stars and streetlamps burst back into life. A warm breeze swept the alleyway. Trees
rustled in neighboring gardens and the mundane rumble of cars in Magnolia Crescent filled the
air again.
Ron stood quite still, all his senses vibrating, taking in the abrupt return to normality. After a
moment, he became aware that his T-shirt was sticking to him; he was drenched in sweat.
He could not believe what had just happened. Dementors here, in Little Whinging.
Ron lay curled up on the ground, whimpering and shaking. Ron bent down to see whether
he was in a fit state to stand up, but then he heard loud, running footsteps behind him.
Instinctively raising his wand again, he span on his heel to face the newcomer.
Mrs. Weasley, their batty old neighbor, came panting into sight. Her grizzled grey hair was escaping from its hairnet, a clanking string shopping bag was swinging from her wrist and her feet were halfway out of her tartan carpet slippers. Ron made to stow his wand hurriedly out of sight, but-
"Don’t put it away idiot boy!" she shrieked. "What if there are more of them around? Oh, I’m
going to kill Ron Weasley!"
CHAPTER TWO
A Peck of Owls
"He left!" said Mrs. Weasley, wringing her hands. "Left to see someone about a batch of cauldrons
that fell off the back of a broom! I told him I’d flay him alive if he went, and now look!
Dementors! It’s just lucky I put Mr. Tibbies on the case! But we haven’t got time to stand
around! Hurry, now, we’ve got to get you back! Oh, the trouble this is going to cause! I will kill
him!"
"But -" The revelation that his batty old cat-obsessed neighbor knew what Dementors were was
almost as big a shock to Ron as meeting two of them down the alleyway. "You’re - you’re a
witch?"
"I’m a Squib, as Ron knows full well, so how on earth was I supposed to help you fight
off Dementors? He left you completely without cover when I’d warned him -"
"This Ron has been following me? Hang on - it was him! He Disapparated from the front
of my house!"
"Yes, yes, yes, but luckily I’d stationed Mr. Tibbies under a car just in case, and Mr. Tibbies
came and warned me, but by the time I got to your house you’d gone - and now - oh, what’s
Weasley going to say? You!" she shrieked at Ron, still supine on the alley floor. "Get your fat bottom off the ground, quick!"
"You know Weasley?" said Ron, staring at her.
"Of course I know Weasley, who doesn’t know Weasley? But come on - I’ll be no help if
they come back, I’ve never so much as transfigured a teabag."
She stooped down, seized one of Ron’s massive arms in her wizened hands and tugged.
"Get up, you useless lump, get up!"
But Ron either could not or would not move. He remained on the ground, trembling and
ashen-faced, his mouth shut very tight.
"I’ll do it." Ron took hold of Ron’s arm and h heaved. With an enormous effort he managed to hoist him to his feet. Ron seemed to be on the point of fainting. His small eyes were rolling in their sockets and sweat was beading his face; the moment Ron let go of him he swayed
dangerously.
"Hurry up!" said Mrs. Weasley hysterically.
Ron pulled one of Ron’s massive arms around his own shoulders and dragged him towards
the road, sagging slightly under the weight. Mrs. Weasley tottered along in front of them, peering
anxiously around the corner.
"Keep your wand out," she told Ron, as they entered Wisteria Walk. "Never mind the Statute of Secrecy now, there’s going to be hell to pay anyway, we might as well be hanged for a dragon as an egg. Talk about the Reasonable Restriction of Underage Sorcery... this was exactly what
Weasley was afraid of - What’s that at the end of the street? Oh, it’s just Mr. Prentice...
don’t put your wand away, boy, don’t I keep telling you I’m no use?"
It was not easy to hold a wand steady and haul Ron along at the same time. Ron gave his
cousin an impatient dig in the ribs, but Ron seemed to have lost all desire for independent
movement. He was slumped on Ron’s shoulder, his large feet dragging along the ground.
"Why didn’t you tell me you’re a Squib, Mrs. Weasley?" asked Ron, panting with the effort to keep
walking. "All those times I came round your house - why didn’t you say anything?"
"Weasley’s orders. I was to keep an eye on you but not say anything, you were too young.
I’m sorry I gave you such a miserable time, Ron, but the Weasleys would never have let you
come if they’d thought you enjoyed it. It wasn’t easy, you know... but oh my word," she said
tragically, wringing her hands once more, "when Weasley hears about this - how could
Ron have left, he was supposed to be on duty until midnight - where is he? How am I
going to tell Weasley what’s happened? I can’t Apparate."
"I’ve got an owl, you can borrow her." Ron groaned, wondering whether his spine was going to
snap under Rons weight.
"Ron, you don’t understand! Weasley will need to act as quickly as possible, the Ministry
have their own ways of detecting underage magic, they’ll know already, you mark my words."
"But I was getting rid of Dementors, I had to use magic - they’re going to be more worried about
what Dementors were doing floating around Wisteria Walk, surely?"
"Oh, my dear, I wish it were so, but I’m afraid - Ron Weasley, I AM GOING TO
KILL YOU!"
There was a loud crack and a strong smell of drink mingled with stale tobacco filled the air as a
squat, unshaven man in a tattered overcoat materialized right in front of them. He had short,
bandy legs, long straggly ginger hair and bloodshot, baggy eyes that gave him the doleful look of
a basset hound. He was also clutching a silvery bundle that Ron recognized at once as an
Invisibility Cloak.
"S’up, Weasleyy?" he said, staring from Mrs. Weasley to Ron and Ron. "What ‘appened to staying
undercover?"
"I’ll give you undercover!" cried Mrs. Weasley. "Dementors, you useless, skiving sneak thief!"
"Dementors?" repeated Ron, aghast. "Dementors, ‘ere?"
"Yes, here, you worthless pile of bat droppings, here!" shrieked Mrs. Weasley. "Dementors attacking
the boy on your watch!"
"Blimey," said Ron weakly, looking from Mrs. Weasley to Ron, and back again. "Blimey, I
-"
"And you off buying stolen cauldrons! Didn’t I tell you not to go? Didn’t I!"
"I - well, I -" Ron looked deeply uncomfortable. "It -- it was a very good business
opportunity, see -"
Mrs. Weasley raised the arm from which her string bag dangled and whacked Ron around the
face and neck with it; judging by the clanking noise it made it was full of cat food.
"Ouch - gerroff - gerroff, you mad old bat! Someone’s gotta tell Weasley!"
"Yes - they - have!" yelled Mrs. Weasley, swinging the bag of cat food at every bit of Ron
she could reach. "And - it - had - better - be - you - and - you - can - tell - him - why - you -
weren’t - there - to - help!"
"Keep your ‘airnet on!" said Ron, his arms over his head, cowering. "I’m going, I’m
going!"
And with another loud crack, he vanished.
"I hope Weasley murders him!" said Mrs. Weasley furiously. "Now come on, Ron, what are
you waiting for?"
Ron decided not to waste his remaining breath on pointing out that he could barely walk under
Ron’s bulk. He gave the semi-conscious Ron a heave and staggered onwards.
"I’ll take you to the door," said Mrs. Weasley, as they turned into Privet Drive. "Just in case there are
more of them around... oh my word, what a catastrophe... and you had to fight them off
yourself... and Weasley said we were to keep you from doing magic at all costs... well, it’s
no good crying over spilt potion, I suppose... but the cat’s among the pixies now."
"So," Ron panted, "Weasley’s... been having... me followed?"
"Of course he has," said Mrs. Weasley impatiently. "Did you expect him to let you wander around on your own after what happened in June? Good Lord, boy, they told me you were intelligent...
right... get inside and stay there," she said, as they reached number four. "I expect someone will
be in touch with you soon enough."
"What are you going to do?" asked Ron quickly.
"I’m going straight home," said Mrs. Weasley, staring around the dark street and shuddering. "I’ll
need to wait for more instructions. Just stay in the house. Goodnight."
"Hang on, don’t go yet! I want to know -"
But Mrs. Weasley had already set off at a trot, carpet slippers flopping, string bag clanking.
"Wait!" Ron shouted after her. He had a million questions to ask anyone who was in contact
with Weasley; but within seconds Mrs. Weasley was swallowed by the darkness. Scowling,
Ron readjusted Ron on his shoulder and made his slow, painful way up number four’s
garden path.
The hall light was on. Ron stuck his wand back inside the waistband of his jeans, rang the bell
and watched Aunt Ron’s outline grow larger and larger, oddly distorted by the rippling glass
in the front door.
"Diddy! About time too, I was getting quite - quite -Diddy, what’s the matter!"
Ron looked sideways at Ron and ducked out from under his arm just in time. Ron
swayed on the spot for a moment, his face pale green... then he opened his mouth and vomited
all over the doormat.
"DIDDY! Diddy, what’s the matter with you? Ron? Ron!"
Ron’s uncle came galumphing out of the living room, walrus moustache blowing hither and
thither as it always did when he was agitated. He hurried forwards to help Aunt Ron negotiate
a weak-kneed Ron over the threshold while avoiding stepping in the pool of sick.
"He’s ill, Ron!"
"What is it, son? What’s happened? Did Mrs. Polkiss give you something foreign for tea?"
"Why are you all covered in dirt, darling? Have you been lying on the ground?"
"Hang on - you haven’t been mugged, have you, son?"
Aunt Ron screamed.
"Phone the police, Ron! Phone the police! Diddy, darling, speak to Mummy! What did they
do to you?"
In all the kerfuffle nobody seemed to have noticed Ron, which suited him perfectly. He
managed to slip inside just before Uncle Ron slammed the door and, while the Weasleys made
their noisy progress down the hall towards the kitchen, Ron moved carefully and quietly
towards the stairs.
"Who did it, son? Give us names. We’ll get them, don’t worry."
"Shh! He’s trying to say something, Ron! What is it, Diddy? Tell Mummy!"
Ron’s foot was on the bottom-most stair when Ron found his voice.
"Him."
Ron froze, foot on the stair, face screwed up, braced for the explosion.
"BOY! COME HERE!"
With a feeling of mingled dread and anger, Ron removed his foot slowly from the stair and
turned to follow the Weasleys.
The scrupulously clean kitchen had an oddly unreal glitter after the darkness outside. Aunt
Ron was ushering Ron into a chair; he was still very green and clammy-looking. Uncle
Ron standing in front of the draining board, glaring at Ron through tiny, narrowed eyes.
"What have you done to my son?" he said in a menacing growl.
"Nothing," said Ron, knowing perfectly well that Uncle Ron wouldn’t believe him.
"What did he do to you, Diddy?" Aunt Ron said in a quavering voice, now sponging sick from the front of Ron’s leather jacket. "Was it - was it you-know-what, darling? Did he use - his thing?"
Slowly, tremulously, Ron nodded.
"I didn’t!" Ron said sharply, as Aunt Ron let out a wail and Uncle Ron raised his fists. "I didn’t do anything to him, it wasn’t me, it was -"
But at that precise moment a screech owl swooped in through the kitchen window. Narrowly
missing the top of Uncle Ron’s head, it soared across the kitchen, dropped the large
parchment envelope it was carrying in its beak at Ron’s feet, turned gracefully, the tips of its
wings just brushing the top of the fridge, then zoomed outside again and off across the garden.
"OWLS!" bellowed Uncle Ron, the well-worn vein in his temple pulsing angrily as he
slammed the kitchen window shut. "OWLS AGAIN! I WILL NOT HAVE ANY MORE OWLS
IN MY HOUSE!"
But Ron was already ripping open the envelope and pulling out the letter inside, his heart
pounding somewhere in the region of his Adam’s apple.
Dear Mr. Weasley,
We have received intelligence that you performed the Patronus Charm at twenty-three minutes
past nine this evening in a Muggle-inhabited area and in the presence of a Muggle.
The severity of this breach of the Decree for the Reasonable Restriction of Underage Sorcery has
resulted in your expulsion from Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. Ministry
representatives will be calling at your place of residence shortly to destroy your wand.
As you have already received an official warning for a previous offence under Section 13 of the
International Confederation of Warlocks’ Statute of Secrecy, we regret to inform you that your
presence is required at a disciplinary hearing at the Ministry of Magic at 9 a.m. on the twelfth of
August.
Hoping you are well,
Yours sincerely,
Ron Weasley
Improper Use of Magic Office
Ministry of Magic
Ron read the letter through twice. He was only vaguely aware of Uncle Ron and Aunt
Ron talking. Inside his head, all was icy and numb. One fact had penetrated his consciousness
like a paralyzing dart. He was expelled from Hogwarts. It was all over. He was never going back.
He looked up at the Weasleys. Uncle Ron was purple-faced, shouting, his fists still raised;
Aunt Ron had her arms around Ron, who was retching again.
Ron’s temporarily stupefied brain seemed to reawaken. Ministry representatives will be calling
at your place of residence shortly to destroy your wand. There was only one thing for it. He
would have to run - now. Where he was going to go, Ron didn’t know, but he was certain of
one thing: at Hogwarts or outside it, he needed his wand. In an almost dream like state, he pulled
his wand out and turned to leave the kitchen.
"Where d’you think you’re going?" yelled Uncle Ron. When Ron didn’t reply, he pounded
across the kitchen to block the doorway into the hall. "I haven’t finished with you, boy!"
"Get out of the way," said Ron quietly.
"You’re going to stay here and explain how my son-"
"If you don’t get out of the way I’m going to jinx you," said Ron, raising the wand.
"You can’t pull that one on me!" snarled Uncle Ron. "I know you’re not allowed to use it
outside that madhouse you call a school!"
"The madhouse has chucked me out," said Ron. "So I can do whatever I like. You’ve got three
seconds. One - two -"
A resounding CRACK filled the kitchen. Aunt Ron screamed, ‘Hide!’ Uncle Ron yelled
and ducked, but for the third time that night Ron was searching for the source of a disturbance
he had not made. He spotted it at once: a dazed and ruffled-looking barn owl was sitting outside
on the kitchen sill, having just collided with the closed window.
Ignoring Uncle Ron’s anguished yell of ‘OWLS!’ Ron crossed the room at a run and
wrenched the window open. The owl stuck out its leg, to which a small roll of parchment was
tied, shook its leathers, and took off the moment Ron had taken the letter. Hands shaking,
Ron unfurled the second message, which was written very hastily and blotchily in black ink.
Ron --
Weasley’s just arrived at the Ministry and he’s trying to sort it all out. DO NOT LEAVE
YOUR AUNT AND UNCLE’S HOUSE. DO NOT DO ANY MORE MAGIC. DO NOT
SURRENDER YOUR WAND.
Ron Weasley
Weasley was trying to sort it all out... what did that mean? How much power did
Weasley have to override the Ministry of Magic? Was there a chance that he might be
allowed back to Hogwarts, then? A small shoot of hope burgeoned in Ron’s chest, almost
immediately strangled by panic - how was he supposed to refuse to surrender his wand without
doing magic? He’d have to duel with the Ministry representatives, and if he did that, he’d be
lucky to escape Azkaban, let alone expulsion.
His mind was racing... he could run for it and risk being captured by the Ministry, or stay put
and wait for them to find him here. He was much more tempted by the former course, but he
knew Mr. Weasley had his best interests at heart... and after all, Weasley had sorted out
much worse than this before.
"Right," Ron said, "I’ve changed my mind, I’m staying." He flung himself down at the kitchen
table and faced Ron and Aunt Ron. The Weasleys appeared taken aback at his abrupt
change of mind. Aunt Ron glanced despairingly at Uncle Ron. The vein in his purple
temple was throbbing worse than ever.
"Who are all these ruddy owls from?" he growled.
"The first one was from the Ministry of Magic, expelling me," said Ron calmly. He was
straining his ears to catch any noises outside, in case the Ministry representatives were
approaching, and it was easier and quieter to answer Uncle Ron’s questions than to have him
start raging and bellowing. "The second one was from my friend Ron’s dad, who works at the
Ministry."
"Ministry of Magic?" bellowed Uncle Ron. "People like you in government! Oh, this explains everything, everything, no wonder the country’s going to the dogs."
When Ron did not respond, Uncle Ron glared at him, then spat out, "And why have you
been expelled?"
"Because I did magic."
"AHA!" roared Uncle Ron, slamming his fist down on top of the fridge, which sprang open;
several of Ron’s low-fat snacks toppled out and burst on the floor. "So you admit it! What did
you do to Ron?"
"Nothing," said Ron, slightly less calmly. "That wasn’t me -"
"Was," muttered Ron unexpectedly, and Uncle Ron and Aunt Ron instantly made
flapping gestures at Ron to quieten him while they both bent low over Ron.
"Go on, son," said Uncle Ron, "what did he do?"
"Tell us, darling," whispered Aunt Ron.
"Pointed his wand at me," Ron mumbled.
"Yeah, I did, but I didn’t use -" Ron began angrily, but -
"SHUT UP!" roared Uncle Ron and Aunt Ron in unison.
"Go on, son," repeated Uncle Ron, moustache blowing about furiously.
"All went dark," Ron said hoarsely, shuddering. "Everything dark. And then I h-heard...
things. Inside m-my head."
Uncle Ron and Aunt Ron exchanged looks of utter horror. If their least favorite thing in
the world was magic - closely followed by neighbors who cheated more than they did on the
hosepipe ban - people who heard voices were definitely in the bottom ten. They obviously
thought Ron was losing his mind.
"What sort of things did you hear, Popkin?" breathed Aunt Ron, very white-faced and with
tears in her eyes.
But Ron seemed incapable of saying. He shuddered again and shook his large blond head, and
despite the sense of numb dread that had settled on Ron since the arrival of the first owl, he felt
a certain curiosity. Dementors caused a person to relive the worst moments of their life. What
would spoiled, pampered, bullying Ron have been forced to hear?
"How come you fell over, son?" said Uncle Ron, in an unnaturally quiet voice, the kind of
voice he might adopt at the bedside of a very ill person.
"T-tripped," said Ron shakily. "And then -"
He gestured at his massive chest. Ron understood. Ron was remembering the clammy cold
that filled the lungs as hope and happiness were sucked out of you.
"Horrible," croaked Ron. "Cold. Really cold."
"Okay," said Uncle Ron, in a voice of forced calm, while Aunt Ron laid an anxious hand on Ron’s forehead to feel his temperature. "What happened then, Dudders?"
"Felt... felt... felt... as if... as if..."
"As if you’d never be happy again," Ron supplied dully.
"Yes," Ron whispered, still trembling.
"So!" said Uncle Ron, voice restored to full and considerable volume as he straightened up.
"You put some crackpot spell on my son so he’d hear voices and believe he was - was doomed to
misery, or something, did you?"
"How many times do I have to tell you?" said Ron, temper and voice both rising. "It wasn’t me! It was a couple of Dementors!"
"A couple of - what’s this codswallop?"
"De - men - tors," said Ron slowly and clearly. "Two of them."
"And what the ruddy hell are Dementors?"
"They guard the wizard prison, Azkaban," said Aunt Ron.
Two seconds of ringing silence followed these words before Aunt Ron clapped her hand over
her mouth as though she had let slip a disgusting swear word. Uncle Ron was goggling at her.
Ron’s brain reeled. Mrs. Weasley was one thing - but Aunt Ron?
"How d’you know that?" he asked her, astonished.
Aunt Ron looked quite appalled with herself. She glanced at Uncle Ron in fearful apology,
then lowered her hand slightly to reveal her horsy teeth.
"I heard - that awful boy - telling her about them - years ago," she said jerkily.
"If you mean my mum and dad, why don’t you use their names?" said Ron loudly, but Aunt
Ron ignored him. She seemed horribly flustered.
Ron was stunned. Except for one outburst years ago, in the course of which Aunt Ron had
screamed that Ron’s mother had been a freak, he had never heard her mention her sister. He
was astounded that she had remembered this scrap of information about the magical world for so
long, when she usually put all her energies into pretending it didn’t exist.
Uncle Ron opened his mouth, closed it again, opened it once more, shut it, then, apparently
struggling to remember how to talk, opened it for a third time and croaked, "So - so - they - er -
they - er - they actually exist, do they - er - Dementy-whatsits?"
Aunt Ron nodded.
Uncle Ron looked from Aunt Ron to Ron to Ron as if hoping somebody was going to
shout ‘April Fool!’ When nobody did, he opened his mouth yet again, but was spared the
struggle to find more words by the arrival of the third owl of the evening. It zoomed through the

envelope from the owls beak and ripped it open as the owl swooped back out into the night.
"Enough - effing - owls," muttered Uncle Ron distractedly, stomping over to the window and
slamming it shut again.
Dear Mr. Weasley,
Further to our letter of approximately twenty-two minutes ago, the Ministry of Magic has revised
its decision to destroy your wand forthwith. You may retain your wand until your disciplinary
hearing on the twelfth of August, at which time an official decision will be taken.
Following discussions with the Headmaster of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, the
Ministry has agreed that the question of your expulsion will also be decided at that time. You
should therefore consider yourself suspended from school pending further enquiries.
With best wishes,
Yours sincerely,
Ron Weasley
Improper Use of Magic Office
Ministry of Magic
Ron read this letter through three times in quick succession. The miserable knot in his chest
loosened slightly with the relief of Knowing he was not yet definitely expelled, though his fears
were by no means banished. Everything seemed to hang on this hearing on the twelfth of August.
"Well?" said Uncle Ron, recalling Ron to his surroundings. "What now? Have they
sentenced you to anything? Do your lot have the death penalty?" he added as a hopeful
afterthought.
"I’ve got to go to a hearing," said Ron.
"And they’ll sentence you there?"
"I suppose so."
"I won’t give up hope, then," said Uncle Ron nastily.
"Well, if that’s all," said Ron, getting to his feet. He was desperate to be alone, to think, perhaps to send a letter to Ron, Ron or Ron.
"NO, IT RUDDY WELL IS NOT ALL!" bellowed Uncle Ron. "SIT BACK DOWN!"
"What now?" said Ron impatiently.
"Ron!" roared Uncle Ron. "I want to know exactly what happened to my son!"
"FINE!" yelled Ron, and in his temper, red and gold sparks shot out of the end of his wand, still clutched in his hand. All three Weasleys flinched, looking terrified.
"Ron and I were in the alleyway between Magnolia Crescent and Wisteria Walk," said Ron,
speaking fast, fighting to control his temper. "Ron thought he’d be smart with me, I pulled out
my wand but didn’t use it. Then two Dementors turned up --"
"But what ARE Dementoids?" asked Uncle Ron furiously. "What do they DO?"
"I told you - they suck all the happiness out of you," said Ron, "and if they get the chance, they
kiss you -
"Kiss you?" said Uncle Ron, his eyes popping slightly. "Kiss you?"
"It’s what they call it when they suck the soul out of your mouth."
Aunt Ron uttered a soft scream.
"His soul? They didn’t take - he’s still got his -"
She seized Ron by the shoulders and shook him, as though testing to see whether she could
hear his soul rattling around inside him.
"Of course they didn’t get his soul, you’d know if they had," said Ron, exasperated.
"Fought ‘em off, did you, son?" said Uncle Ron loudly, with the appearance of a man
struggling to bring the conversation back on to a plane he understood. "Gave ‘em the old one-two, did you?"
"You can’t give a Dementor the old one-two," said Ron through clenched teeth.
"Why’s he all right, then?" blustered Uncle Ron. "Why isn’t he all empty, then?"
"Because I used the Patronus -"
WHOOSH. With a clattering, a whirring of wings and a soft fall of dust, a fourth owl came
shooting out of the kitchen fireplace.
"FOR GOD’S SAKE!" roared Uncle Ron, pulling great clumps of hair out of his moustache,
something he hadn’t been driven to do in a long time. "I WILL NOT HAVE OWLS HERE, I
WILL NOT TOLERATE THIS, I TELL YOU!"
But Ron was already pulling a roll of parchment from the owl’s leg. He was so convinced that
this letter had to be from Weasley, explaining everything - the Dementors, Mrs. Weasley, what
the Ministry was up to, how he, Weasley, intended to sort everything out - that for the first
time in his life he was disappointed to see Ron’s handwriting. Ignoring Uncle Ron’s
on going rant about owls, and narrowing his eyes against a second cloud of dust as the most
recent owl look off back up the chimney, Ron read Ron’s message.
Ron’s just told us what’s happened. Don’t leave the house again, whatever you do.
Ron found this such an inadequate response to everything that had happened tonight that he
turned the piece of parchment over, looking for the rest of the letter, but there was nothing else.
And now his temper was rising again. Wasn’t anybody going to say ‘well done’ for fighting off
two Dementors single-handed? Both Mr. Weasley and Ron were acting as though he’d
misbehaved, and were saving their tellings-off until they could ascertain how much damage had
been done.
"...A peck, I mean, pack of owls shooting in and out of my house. I won’t have it, boy, I won’t-"
"I can’t stop the owls coming," Ron snapped, crushing Ron’s letter in his fist.
"I want the truth about what happened tonight!" bar ked Uncle Ron. "If it was Demenders who hurt Ron, how come you’ve been expelled? You did you-know-what, you’ve admitted it!"
Ron took a deep, steadying breath. His head was beginning to ache again. He wanted more than
anything to get out of the kitchen, and away from the Weasleys.
"I did the Patronus Charm to get rid of the Dementors," he said, forcing himself to remain calm.
"It’s the only thing that works against them."
"But what were Dementoids doing in Little Whinging?" said Uncle Ron in an outraged tone.
"Couldn’t tell you," said Ron wearily. "No idea."
His head was pounding in the glare of the strip-lighting now. His anger was ebbing away. He felt
drained, exhausted. The Weasleys were all staring at him.
"It’s you," said Uncle Ron forcefully. "It’s go t something to do with you, boy, I know it. Why else would they turn up here? Why else would they be down that alleyway? You’ve got to be the only - the only -" Evidently, he couldn’t bring himself to say the word ‘wizard’ "the only you know-what for miles."
"I don’t know why they were here."
But at Uncle Ron’s words, Ron’s exhausted brain had ground back into action. Why had the
Dementors come to Little Whinging? How could it be coincidence that they had arrived in the
alleyway where Ron was? Had they been sent? Had the Ministry of Magic lost control of the
Dementors? Had they deserted Azkaban and joined Weasley, as Weasley had predicted
they would?
"These Demembers guard some weirdo’s prison?" asked Uncle Ron, lumbering along in the
wake of Ron’s train of thought.
"Yes," said Ron.
If only his head would stop hurting, if only he could just leave the kitchen and get to his dark
bedroom and think...
"Oho! They were coming to arrest you!" said Uncle Ron, with the triumphant air of a man
reaching an unassailable conclusion. "That’s it, isn’t it, boy? You’re on the run from the law!"
"Of course I’m not," said Ron, shaking his head as though to scare off a fly, his mind racing
now.
"Then why -?"
"He must have sent them," said Ron quietly, more to himself than to Uncle Ron.
"What’s that? Who must have sent them?"
"Lord Weasley," said Ron.
He registered dimly how strange it was that the Weasleys, who flinched, winced and squawked if
they heard words like ‘wizard’, ‘magic’ or ‘wand’, could hear the name of the most evil wizard
of all time without the slightest tremor.
"Lord - hang on," said Uncle Ron, his face screwed up, a look of dawning comprehension
coming into his piggy eyes. "I’ve heard that name... that was the one who --"
"Murdered my parents, yes," Ron said dully.
"But he’s gone," said Uncle Ron impatiently, without the slightest sign that the murder of
Ron’s parents might be a painful topic. "That giant bloke said so. He’s gone."
"He’s back," said Ron heavily.
It felt very strange to be standing here in Aunt Ron’s surgically clean kitchen, beside the top of-the-range fridge and the wide-screen television, talking calmly of Lord Weasley to Uncle
Ron. The arrival of the Dementors in Little Whinging seemed to have breached the great,
invisible wall that divided the relentlessly non-magical world of Privet Drive and the world
beyond, Ron’s two lives had somehow become fused and everything had been turned upside-down; the Weasleys were asking for details about the magical world, and Mrs. Weasley knew Ron Weasley; Dementors were soaring around Little Whinging, and he might never return to Hogwarts. Ron’s head throbbed more painfully.
"Back?" whispered Aunt Ron.
She was looking at Ron as she had never looked at him before. And all of a sudden, for the
very first time in his life, Ron fully appreciated that Aunt Ron was his mother’s sister. He
could not have said why this hit him so very powerfully at this moment. All he knew was that he
was not the only person in the room who had an inkling of what Lord Weasley being back
might mean. Aunt Ron had never in her life looked at him like that before. Her large, pale
eyes (so unlike her sister’s) were not narrowed in dislike or anger, they were wide and fearful.
The furious pretence that Aunt Ron had maintained all Ron’s life - that there was no magic
and no world other than the world she inhabited with Uncle Ron - seemed to have fallen
away.
"Yes," Ron said, talking directly to Aunt Ron now. "He came back a month ago. I saw him."
Her hands found Ron’s massive leather-clad shoulders and clutched them.
"Hang on," said Uncle Ron, looking from his wife to Ron and back again, apparently dazed
and confused by the unprecedented understanding that seemed to have sprung up between them.
"Hang on. This Lord Voldything’s back, you say."
"Yes."
"The one who murdered your parents."
"Yes."
"And now he’s sending Dismembers after you?"
"Looks like it," said Ron.
"I see," said Uncle Ron, looking from his white - faced wife to Ron and hitching up his
trousers. He seemed to be swelling, his great purple face stretching before Ron’s eyes. "Well,
that settles it," he said, his shirt front straining as he inflated himself, "you can get out of this
house, boy!"
"What?" said Ron.
"You heard me - OUT!" Uncle Ron bellowed, and even Aunt Ron and Ron jumped.
"OUT! OUT! I should’ve done this years ago! Owls treating the place like a rest home, puddings
exploding, half the lounge destroyed, Ron’s tail, Ron bobbing around on the ceiling and
that flying Ford Anglia - OUT! OUT! You’ve had it! You’re history! You’re not staying here if
some loony’s after you, you’re not endangering my wife and son, you’re not bringing trouble
down on us. If you’re going the same way as your useless parents, I’ve had it! OUT!"
Ron stood rooted to the spot. The letters from the Ministry, Mr. Weasley and Ron were all
crushed in his left hand. Don’t leave the house again, whatever you do. DO NOT LEAVE YOUR AUNT AND UNCLE’S HOUSE.
"You heard me!" said Uncle Ron, bending forward now, his massive purple face coming so
close to Ron’s, he actually felt flecks of spit hit his face. "Get going! You were all keen to leave half an hour ago! I’m right behind you! Get out and never darken our doorstep again! Why we ever kept you in the first place, I don’t know, Ron was right, it should have been the
orphanage. We were too damn soft for our own good, thought we could squash it out of you,
thought we could turn you normal, but you’ve been rotten from the beginning and I’ve had
enough - owls!"
The fifth owl zoomed down the chimney so fast it actually hit the floor before zooming into the
air again with a loud screech. Ron raised his hand to seize the letter, which was in a scarlet
envelope, but it soared straight over his head, flying directly at Aunt Ron, who let out a
scream and ducked, her arms over her face. The owl dropped the red envelope on her head,
turned, and flew straight back up the chimney.
Ron darted forwards to pick up the letter, but Aunt Ron beat him to it.
"You can open it if you like," said Ron, "but I’ll hear what it says anyway. That’s a Howler."
"Let go of it, Ron!" roared Uncle Ron. "Don’t touch it, it could be dangerous!"
"It’s addressed to me," said Aunt Ron in a shaking voice. "It’s addressed to me, Ron, look! Mrs. Ron Weasley, The Kitchen, Number Four, Privet Drive -"
She caught her breath, horrified. The red envelope had begun to smoke.
"Open it!’ Ron urged her. "Get it over with! It’ll happen anyway."
"No."
Aunt Ron’s hand was trembling. She looked wildly around the kitchen as though looking for
an escape route, but too late -the envelope burst into flames. Aunt Ron screamed and dropped
it.
An awful voice filled the kitchen, echoing in the confined space, issuing from the burning letter
on the table.
Remember my last, Ron.
Aunt Ron looked as though she might faint. She sank into the chair beside Ron, her face in
her hands. The remains of the envelope smouldered into ash in the silence.
"What is this?" Uncle Ron said hoarsely. "What - I don’t -Ron?"
Aunt Ron said nothing. Ron was staring stupidly at his mother, his mouth hanging open.
The silence spiraled horribly. Ron was watching his aunt, utterly bewildered, his head
throbbing fit to burst.
"Ron, dear?" said Uncle Ron timidly. "P-Ron?"
She raised her head. She was still trembling. She swallowed.
"The boy - the boy will have to stay, Ron," she said weakly.
"W-what?"
"He stays," she said. She was not looking at Ron. She got to her feet again.
"He... but Ron..."
"If we throw him out, the neighbors will talk," she said. She was rapidly regaining her usual
brisk, snappish manner, though she was still very pale. "They’ll ask awkward questions, they’ll
want to know where he’s gone. We’ll have to keep him."
Uncle Ron was deflating like an old tire.
"But Ron, dear -"
Aunt Ron ignored him. She turned to Ron. "You’re to stay in your room," she said. "You’re
not to leave the house. Now get to bed."
Ron didn’t move.
"Who was that Howler from?"
"Don’t ask questions," Aunt Ron snapped.
"Are you in touch with wizards?"
"I told you to get to bed!"
"What did it mean? Remember the last what?"
"Go to bed!"
"How come -?"
"YOU HEARD YOUR AUNT, NOW GET TO BED!"
CHAPTER THREE
The Advance Guard
I’ve just been attacked by Dementors and I might be expelled from Hogwarts. I want to know
what’s going on and when I’m going to get out of here.
Ron copied these words on to three separate pieces of parchment the moment he reached the
desk in his dark bedroom. He addressed the first to Ron, the second to Ron and the third to
Ron. His owl, Ron, was off hunting; her cage stood empty on the desk. Ron paced the
bedroom waiting for her to come back, his head pounding, his brain too busy for sleep even
though his eyes stung and itched with tiredness. His back ached from hauling Ron home, and
the two lumps on his head where the window and Ron had hit him were throbbing painfully.
Up and down he paced, consumed with anger and frustration, grinding his teeth and clenching
his fists, casting angry looks out at the empty, star-strewn sky every time he passed the window.
Dementors sent to get him, Mrs. Weasley and Ron Weasley tailing him in secret, then
suspension from Hogwarts and a hearing at the Ministry of Magic - and still no one was telling
him what was going on.
And what, what, had that Howler been about? Whose voice had echoed so horribly, so
menacingly, through the kitchen?
Why was he still trapped here without information? Why was everyone treating him like some
naughty kid? Don’t do any more magic, stay in the house...
He kicked his school trunk as he passed it, but far from relieving his anger he felt worse, as he
now had a sharp pain in his toe to deal with in addition to the pain in the rest of his body.
Just as he limped past the window, Ron soared through it with a soft rustle of wings like a
small ghost.
"About time!" Ron snarled, as she landed lightly on top of her cage. "You can put that down,
I’ve got work for you!"
Ron’s large, round, amber eyes gazed at him reproachfully over the dead frog clamped in her
beak.
"Come here," said Ron, picking up the three small rolls of parchment and a leather thong and
tying the scrolls to her scaly leg. "Take these straight to Ron, Ron and Ron and don’t come back here without good long replies. Keep pecking them till they’ve written decent-length
answers if you’ve got to. Understand?"
Ron gave a muffled hooting noise, her beak still full of frog.
"Get going, then," said Ron.
She took off immediately. The moment she’d gone, Ron threw himself down on his bed
without undressing and stared at the dark ceiling. In addition to every other miserable feeling, he
now felt guilty that he’d been irritable with Ron; she was the only friend he had at number
four, Privet Drive. But he’d make it up to her when she came back with the answers from Ron,
Ron and Ron.
They were bound to write back quickly; they couldn’t possibly ignore a Dementor attack. He’d
probably wake up tomorrow to three fat letters full of sympathy and plans for his immediate
removal to The Burrow. And with that comforting idea, sleep rolled over him, stifling all further
thought.
But Ron didn’t return next morning. Ron spent the day in his bedroom, leaving it only to go
to the bathroom. Three times that day Aunt Ron shoved food into his room through the cat flap Uncle Ron had installed three summers ago. Every time Ron heard her approaching he tried to question her about the Howler, but he might as well have interrogated the doorknob for all the answers he got. Otherwise, the Weasleys kept well clear of his bedroom. Ron couldn’t see the point of forcing his company on them; another row would achieve nothing except perhaps make him so angry he’d perform more illegal magic.
So it went on for three whole days. Ron was alternately filled with restless energy that made
him unable to settle to anything, during which time he paced his bedroom, furious at the whole
lot of them for leaving him to stew in this mess; and with a lethargy so complete that he could lie
on his bed for an hour at a time, staring dazedly into space, aching with dread at the thought of
the Ministry hearing.
What if they ruled against him? What if he was expelled and his wand was snapped in half? What would he do, where would he go? He could not return to living full-time with the Weasleys, not now he knew the other world, the one to which he really belonged. Might he be able to move
into Ron’s house, as Ron had suggested a year ago, before he had been forced to flee from the
Ministry? Would Ron be allowed to live there alone, given that he was still underage? Or
would the matter of where he went next be decided for him? Had his breach of the International
Statute of Secrecy been severe enough to land him in a cell in Azkaban? Whenever this thought
occurred, Ron invariably slid off his bed and began pacing again.
On the fourth night after Ron’s departure Ron was lying in one of his apathetic phases,
staring at the ceiling, his exhausted mind quite blank, when his uncle entered his bedroom. Ron
looked slowly around at him. Uncle Ron was wearing his best suit and an expression of
enormous smugness.
"We’re going out," he said.
"Sorry?"
"We - that is to say, your aunt, Ron and I - are going out."
"Fine," said Ron dully, looking back at the ceiling.
"You are not to leave your bedroom while we are away."
"Okay."
"You are not to touch the television, the stereo, or any of our possessions."
"Right."
"You are not to steal food from the fridge."
"Okay."
"I am going to lock your door."
"You do that."
Uncle Ron glared at Ron, clearly suspicious of this lack of argument, then stomped out of
the room and closed the door behind him. Ron heard the key turn in the lock and Uncle
Ron’s footsteps walking heavily down the stairs. A few minutes later he heard the slamming
of car doors, the rumble of an engine, and the unmistakable sound of the car sweeping out of the
drive.
Ron had no particular feeling about the Weasleys leaving. It made no difference to him whether
they were in the house or not. He could not even summon the energy to get up and turn on his
bedroom light. The room grew steadily darker around him as he lay listening to the night sounds
through the window he kept open all the time, waiting for the blessed moment when Ron
returned. The empty house creaked around him. The pipes gurgled. Ron lay there in a kind of
stupor, thinking of nothing, suspended in misery.
Then, quite distinctly, he heard a crash in the kitchen below. He sat bolt upright, listening
intently. The Weasleys couldn’t be back, it was much too soon, and in any case he hadn’t heard
their car.
There was silence for a few seconds, then voices. Burglars, he thought, sliding off the bed on to
his feet - but a split second later it occurred to him that burglars would keep their voices down,
and whoever was moving around in the kitchen was certainly not troubling to do so.
He snatched up his wand from the bedside table and stood facing his bedroom door, listening
with all his might. Next moment, he jumped as the lock gave a loud click and his door swung
open. Ron stood motionless, staring through the open doorway at the dark upstairs landing,
straining his ears for further sounds, but none came. He hesitated for a moment, then moved
swiftly and silently out of his room to the head of the stairs.
His heart shot upwards into his throat. There were people standing in the shadowy hall below,
silhouetted against the streetlight glowing through the glass door; eight or nine of them, all, as far
as he could see, looking up at him.
"Lower your wand, boy, before you take someone’s eye out," said a low, growling voice.
Ron’s heart was thumping uncontrollably. He knew that voice, but he did not lower his wand.
"Professor Weasley?" he said uncertainly.
"I don’t know so much about ‘Professor’," growled the voice, "never got round to much teaching, did I? Get down here, we want to see you properly."
Ron lowered his wand slightly but did not relax his grip on it, nor did he move. He had very
good reason to be suspicious. He had recently spent nine months in what he had thought was
Mad-Eye Weasley’s company only to find out that it wasn’t Weasley at all, but an impostor; an
impostor, moreover, who had tried to kill Ron before being unmasked. But before he could
make a decision about what to do next, a second, slightly hoarse voice floated upstairs.
"It’s all right, Ron. We’ve come to take you away."
Ron’s heart leapt. He knew that voice, too, though he hadn’t heard it for over a year.
"P-Professor Weasley?" he said disbelievingly. "Is that you?"
"Why are we all standing in the dark?" said a third voice, this one completely unfamiliar, a
woman’s. "Lumos."
A wand-tip flared, illuminating the hall with magical light. Ron blinked. The people below
were crowded around the foot of the stairs, gazing up at him intently, some craning their heads
for a better look.
Ron Weasley stood nearest to him. Though still quite young, Weasley looked tired and rather ill; he
had more grey hairs than when Ron had last said goodbye to him and his robes were more
patched and shabbier than ever. Nevertheless, he was smiling broadly at Ron, who tried to
smile back despite his state of shock.
"Oooh, he looks just like I thought he would," said the witch who was holding her lit wand aloft.
She looked the youngest there; she had a pale heart-shaped face, dark twinkling eyes, and short
spiky hair that was a violent shade of violet. "Wotcher, Ron!"
"Yeah, I see what you mean, Ron," said a bald black wizard standing furthest back - he had a
deep, slow voice and wore a single gold hoop in his ear - "he looks exactly like Ron."
"Except the eyes," said a wheezy-voiced, silver-haired wizard at the back. "Ron’s eyes."
Mad-Eye Weasley, who had long grizzled grey hair and a large chunk missing from his nose, was
squinting suspiciously at Ron through his mismatched eyes. One eye was small, dark and
beady, the other large, round and electric blue - the magical eye that could see through walls,
doors and the back of Weasley’s own head. "Are you quite sure it’s him, Weasley?" he growled. "It’d be a nice lookout if we bring back some Death Eater impersonating him. We ought to ask him something only the real Weasley would know. Unless anyone brought any Veritaserum?"
"Ron, what form does your Patronus take?" Weasley asked.
"A stag," said Ron nervously.
"That’s him, Mad-Eye," said Weasley.
Very conscious of everybody still staring at him, Ron descended the stairs, stowing his wand in
the back pocket of his jeans as he came.
"Don’t put your wand there, boy!" roared Weasley. "What if it ignited? Better wizards than you
have lost buttocks, you know!"
"Who d’you know who’s lost a buttock?" the violet-haired woman asked Mad-Eye interestedly.
"Never you mind, you just keep your wand out of your back pocket!" growled Mad-Eye.
"Elementary wand-safety, nobody bothers about it any more." He stumped off towards the
kitchen. "And I saw that," he added irritably, as t he woman rolled her eyes towards the ceiling.
Weasley held out his hand and shook Ron’s.
"How are you?" he asked, looking closely at Ron.
"F-fine..."
Ron could hardly believe this was real. Four weeks with nothing, not the tiniest hint of a plan to
remove him from Privet Drive, and suddenly a whole bunch of wizards was standing matter-of factly in the house as though this was a long-standing arrangement. He glanced at the people
surrounding Weasley; they were still gazing avidly at him. He felt very conscious of the fact that he
had not combed his hair for four days.
"I’m - you’re really lucky the Weasleys are out..." he mumbled.
"Lucky, ha!" said the violet-haired woman. "It was me who lured them out of the way. Sent a
letter by Muggle post telling them they’d been short-listed for the All-England Best Kept
Suburban Lawn Competition. They’re heading off to the prize-giving right now... or they think
they are."
Ron had a fleeting vision of Uncle Ron’s face when he realized there was no All-England
Best Kept Suburban Lawn Competition.
"We are leaving, aren’t we?" he asked. "Soon?"
"Almost at once," said Weasley, "we’re just waiting for the all-clear."
"Where are we going? The Burrow?" Ron asked hopefully.
"Not The Burrow, no," said Weasley, motioning Ron towards the kitchen; the little knot of
wizards followed, all still eyeing Ron curiously. "Too risky. We’ve set up Headquarters
somewhere undetectable. It’s taken a while..."
