Mad-Eye Weasley was now sitting at the kitchen table swigging from a hip flask, his magical eye
spinning in all directions, taking in the Weasleys’ many labor-saving appliances.
"This is Ron Weasley, Ron" Weasley continued, pointing towards Weasley.
"Yeah, I know," said Ron uncomfortably. It felt odd to be introduced to somebody he’d thought he’d known for a year.
"And this is Ron -"
"Don’t call me Ron, Ron," said the young witch with a shudder, "it’s Weasley."
"Ron Weasley, who prefers to be known by her surname only," finished Weasley.
"So would you if your fool of a mother had called you Ron," muttered Weasley.
"And this is Ron Weasley." He indicated the tall black wizard, who bowed. "Ron
Weasley." The wheezy-voiced wizard nodded. "Dedalus Weasley -"
"We’ve met before," squeaked the excitable Weasley, dropping his violet-colored top hat.
"Ron Weasley." A stately-looking witch in an emerald green shawl inclined her head.
"Ron Weasley." A square-jawed wizard with thick straw-colored hair winked. "And Hestia
Jones." A pink-cheeked, black-haired witch waved form next to the toaster.
Ron inclined his head awkwardly at each of them as they were introduced. He wished they
would look at something other than him; it was as though he had suddenly been ushered onstage.
He also wondered why so many of them were there.
"A surprising number of people volunteered to come and get you," said Weasley, as though he had
read Ron’s mind; the corners of his mouth twitched slightly.
"Yeah, well, the more the better," said Weasley darkly. "We’re your guard, Weasley."
"We’re just waiting for the signal to tell us it’s safe to set off," said Weasley, glancing out of the
kitchen window. "We’ve got about fifteen minutes."
"Very clean, aren’t they, these Muggles?" said the witch called Weasley, who was looking around
the kitchen with great interest. "My dad’s Muggle-born and he’s a right old slob. I suppose it
varies, just as it does with wizards?"
"Er - yeah," said Ron. "Look -" he turned back to Weasley, "what’s going on, I haven’t heard
anything from anyone, what’s Vol--?"
Several of the witches and wizards made odd hissing noises; Dedalus Weasley dropped his hat
again and Weasley growled, "Shut up!"
"What?" said Ron.
"We’re not discussing anything here, it’s too risky," said Weasley, turning his normal eye on
Ron. His magical eye remained focused on the ceiling. "Damn it," he added angrily, putting a
hand up to the magical eye, "it keeps getting stuck - ever since that scum wore it."
And with a nasty squelching sound much like a plunger being pulled from a sink, he popped out
his eye.
"Mad-Eye, you do know that’s disgusting, don’t you?" said Weasley conversationally.
"Get me a glass of water, would you, Ron," requested Weasley.
Ron crossed to the dishwasher, took out a clean glass and filled it with water at the sink, still
watched eagerly by the band of wizards. Their relentless staring was starting to annoy him.
"Cheers," said Weasley, when Ron handed him the glass. He dropped the magical eyeball into
the water and prodded it up and down; the eye whizzed around, staring at them all in turn. "I
want three hundred and sixty degrees visibility on the return journey."
"How’re we getting - wherever we’re going?" Ron asked.
"Brooms," said Weasley. "Only way. You’re too young to Apparate, they’ll be watching the Floo
Network and it’s more than our life’s worth to set up an unauthorized Portkey."
"Ron says you’re a good flier," said Ron Weasley in his deep voice.
"He’s excellent," said Weasley, who was checking his watch. "Anyway, you’d better go and get
packed, Ron, we want to be ready to go when the signal comes."
"I’ll come and help you," said Weasley brightly.
She followed Ron back into the hall and up the stairs, looking around with much curiosity and
interest.
"Funny place," she said. "It’s a bit too clean, d’you know what I mean? Bit unnatural. Oh, this is
better," she added, as they entered Ron’s bedroom and he turned on the light.
His room was certainly much messier than the rest of the house. Confined to it for four days in a
very bad mood, Ron had not bothered tidying up after himself. Most of the books he owned
were strewn over the floor where he’d tried to distract himself with each in turn and thrown it
aside; Ron’s cage needed cleaning out and was starting to smell; and his trunk lay open,
revealing a jumbled mixture of Muggle clothes and wizards’ robes that had spilled on to the floor
around it.
Ron started picking up books and throwing them hastily into his trunk. Weasley paused at his
open wardrobe to look critically at her reflection in the mirror on the inside of the door.
"You know, I don’t think violet’s really my color," she said pensively, tugging at a lock of spiky hair. "D’you think it makes me look a bit peaky?"
"Er -" said Ron, looking up at her over the top of Quidditch Teams of Britain and Ireland.
"Yeah, it does," said Weasley decisively. She screwed up her eyes in a strained expression as
though she was struggling to remember something. A second later, her hair had turned bubblegum pink.
"How did you do that?" said Ron, gaping at her as she opened her eyes again.
"I’m a Metamorphmagus," she said, looking back at her reflection and turning her head so that
she could see her hair from all directions. "It means I can change my appearance at will," she
added, spotting Ron’s puzzled expression in the mirror behind her. "I was born one. I got top
marks in Concealment and Disguise during Auror training without any study at all, it was great."
"You’re an Auror?" said Ron, impressed. Being a Dark-wizard-catcher was the only career he’d ever considered after Hogwarts.
"Yeah," said Weasley, looking proud. "Ron is as well, he’s a bit higher up than me, though. I
only qualified a year ago. Nearly failed on Stealth and Tracking. I’m dead clumsy, did you hear
me break that plate when we arrived downstairs?"
"Can you learn how to be a Metamorphmagus?" Ron asked her, straightening up, completely
forgetting about packing.
Weasley chuckled.
"Bet you wouldn’t mind hiding that scar sometimes, eh?"
Her eyes found the lightning-shaped scar on Ron’s forehead.
"No, I wouldn’t mind," Ron mumbled, turning away. He did not like people staring at his scar.
"Well, you’ll have to learn the hard way, I’m afraid," said Weasley. "Metamorphmagi are really
rare, they’re born, not made. Most wizards need to use a wand, or potions, to change their
appearance. But we’ve got to get going, Ron, we’re supposed to be packing," she added
guiltily, looking around at all the mess on the floor.
"Oh -- yeah," said Ron, grabbing a few more books.
"Don’t be stupid, it’ll be much quicker if I - pack!" cried Weasley, waving her wand in a long,
sweeping movement over the floor.
Books, clothes, telescope and scales all soared into the air and flew pell-mell into the trunk.
"It’s not very neat," said Weasley, walking over to t he trunk and looking down at the jumble inside.
"My mums got this knack of getting stuff to fit itself in neatly - she even gets the socks to fold
themselves - but I’ve never mastered how she does it - it’s a kind of flick -" She flicked her wand
hopefully.
One of Ron’s socks gave a feeble sort of wiggle and flopped back on top of the mess in the
trunk.
"Ah, well," said Weasley, slamming the trunk’s lid shut, "at least it’s all in. That could do with a bit of cleaning, too." She pointed her wand at Ron’s cage. "Scourgify." A few feathers and
droppings vanished. "Well, that’s a bit better - I’ve never quite got the hang of these householdy
sort of spells. Right - got everything? Cauldron? Broom? Wow! - A Firebolt!"
Her eyes widened as they fell on the broomstick in Ron’s right hand it was his pride and joy, a
gift from Ron, an international-standard broomstick.
"And I’m still riding a Comet Two Sixty" said Weasley enviously. "Ah well... wand still in your
jeans? Both buttocks still on? Okay, let’s go. Locomotor trunk."
Ron’s trunk rose a few inches into the air. Holding her wand like a conductor’s baton, Weasley
made the trunk hover across the room and out of the door ahead of them, Ron’s cage in her
left hand. Ron followed her down the stairs carrying his broomstick.
Back in the kitchen Weasley had replaced his eye, which was spinning so fast after its cleaning it
made Ron feel sick to look at it. Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley were examining
the microwave and Hestia Jones was laughing at a potato peeler she had come across while
rummaging in the drawers. Weasley was sealing a letter addressed to the Weasleys.
"Excellent," said Weasley, looking up as Weasley and Ron entered. "We’ve got about a minute, I
think. We should probably get out into the garden so we’re ready. Ron, I’ve left a letter telling
your aunt and uncle not to worry -"
"They won’t," said Ron.
"- that you’re safe -"
"That’ll just depress them."
"- and you’ll see them next summer."
"Do I have to?"
Weasley smiled but made no answer.
"Come here, boy," said Weasley gruffly, beckoning Ron towards him with his wand. "I need to
Disillusion you."
"You need to what?" said Ron nervously.
"Disillusionment Charm," said Weasley, raising his wand. "Weasley says you’ve got an Invisibility
Cloak, but it won’t stay on while we’re flying; this’ll disguise you better. Here you go -
He rapped him hard on the top of the head and Ron felt a curious sensation as though Weasley
had just smashed an egg there; cold trickles seemed to be running down his body from the point
the wand had struck.
"Nice one, Mad-Eye," said Weasley appreciatively, staring at Ron’s midriff.
Ron looked down at his body, or rather, what had been his body, for it didn’t look anything like
his any more. It was not invisible; it had simply taken on the exact color and texture of the
kitchen unit behind him. He seemed to have become a human chameleon.
"Come on," said Weasley, unlocking the back door with his wand.
They all stepped outside on to Uncle Ron’s beautifully kept lawn.
"Clear night," grunted Weasley, his magical eye scanning the heavens. "Could’ve done with a bit
more cloud cover. Right, you," he barked at Ron," we’re going to be flying in close formation.
Weasley’ll be right in front of you, keep close on her tail. Weasley’ll be covering you from below I’m
going to be behind you. The rest’ll be circling us. We don’t break ranks for anything, got me? If
one of us is killed -
"Is that likely?" Ron asked apprehensively, but Weasley ignored him.
"- the others keep flying, don’t stop, don’t break ranks. If they take out all of us and you survive,
Ron, the rear guard are standing by to take over; keep flying east and they’ll join you."
"Stop being so cheerful, Mad-Eye, he’ll think we’re not taking this seriously" said Weasley, as she
strapped Ron’s trunk and Ron’s cage into a harness hanging from her broom.
"I’m just telling the boy the plan," growled Weasley. "Our jobs to deliver him safely to
Headquarters and if we die in the attempt -"
"No one’s going to die," said Ron Weasley in his deep, calming voice.
"Mount your brooms, that’s the first signal!" said Weasley sharply pointing into the sky.
Far, far above them, a shower of bright red sparks had flared among the stars, Ron recognized
them at once as wand sparks. He swung his right leg over his Firebolt, gripped its handle tightly
and felt it vibrating very slightly, as though it was as keen as he was to be up in the air once
more.
"Second signal, let’s go!" said Weasley loudly as more sparks, green this time, exploded high above them.
Ron kicked off hard from the ground. The cool night air rushed through his hair as the neat
square gardens of Privet Drive fell away, shrinking rapidly into a patchwork of dark greens and
blacks, and every thought of the Ministry hearing was swept from his mind as though the rush of
air had blown it out of his head. He felt as though his heart was going to explode with pleasure;
he was flying again, flying away from Privet Drive as he’d been fantasizing about all summer, he
was going home... for a few glorious moments, all his problems seemed to recede to nothing,
insignificant in the vast, starry sky.
"Hard left, hard left, there’s a Muggle looking up!" shouted Weasley from behind him. Weasley
swerved and Ron followed her, watching his trunk swinging wildly beneath her broom. "We
need more height... give it another quarter of a mile!"
Ron’s eyes watered in the chill as they soared upwards; he could see nothing below now but
tiny pinpricks of light that were car headlights and streetlamps. Two of those tiny lights might
belong to Uncle Ron’s car... the Weasleys would be heading back to their empty house right
now, full of rage about the non-existent Lawn Competition... and Ron laughed aloud at the
thought, though his voice was drowned by the flapping robes of the others, the creaking of the
harness holding his trunk and the cage, and the whoosh of the wind in their ears as they sped
through the air. He had not felt this alive in a month, or this happy.
"Bearing south!" shouted Mad-Eye. "’Town ahead!"
They soared right to avoid passing directly over the glittering spider’s web of lights below.
"Bear southeast and keep climbing, there’s some low cloud ahead we can lose ourselves in!"
called Weasley.
"We’re not going through clouds!" shouted Weasley angrily, "we’ll get soaked, Mad-Eye!"
Ron was relieved to hear her say this; his hands were growing numb on the Firebolt’s handle.
He wished he had thought to put on a coat; he was starting to shiver.
They altered their course every now and then according to Mad-Eyes instructions. Ron’s eyes
were screwed up against the rush of icy wind that was starting to make his ears ache; he could
remember being this cold on a broom only once before, during the Quidditch match against
Weasley in his third year, which had taken place in a storm. The guard around him was
circling continuously like giant birds of prey. Ron lost track of time. He wondered how long
they had been flying, it felt like an hour at least.
"Turning southwest!" yelled Weasley "We want to avoid the motorway!"
Ron was now so chilled he thought longingly of the snug, dry interiors of the cars streaming
along below, then, even more longingly, of traveling by Floo powder; it might be uncomfortable
to spin around in fireplaces but it was at least warm in the flames... Ron Weasley
swooped around him, bald pate and earring gleaming slightly in the moonlight... now Ron
Weasley was on his right, her wand out, her head turning left and right... then she, too, swooped
over him, to be replaced by Ron Weasley...
"We ought to double back for a bit, just to make sure we’re not being followed!" Weasley shouted.
"ARE YOU MAD, MAD-EYE"‘ Weasley screamed from the front. "We’re all frozen to our
brooms! If we keep going off-course we’re not going to get there until next week! Besides, we’re
nearly there now!"
"Time to start the descent!" came Weasley’s voice. "Follow Weasley, Ron!"
Ron followed Weasley into a dive. They were heading for the largest collection of lights he had
yet seen, a huge, sprawling crisscrossing mass, glittering in lines and grids, interspersed with
patches of deepest black. Lower and lower they flew, until Ron could see individual headlights
and streetlamps, chimneys and television aerials. He wanted to reach the ground very much,
though he felt sure someone would have to unfreeze him from his broom.
"Here we go!" called Weasley, and a few seconds later she had landed.
Ron touched down right behind her and dismounted on a patch of unkempt grass in the middle
of a small square. Weasley was already unbuckling Ron’s trunk. Shivering, Ron looked around.
The grimy fronts of the surrounding houses were not welcoming; some of them had broken
windows, glimmering dully in the light fro the streetlamps, paint was peeling from many of the
doors and heaps of rubbish lay outside several sets of front steps.
"Where are we?" Ron asked, but Weasley said quietly, "In a minute."
Weasley was rummaging in his cloak, his gnarled hands clumsy with cold.
"Got it," he muttered, raising what looked like a silver cigarette lighter into the air and clicking it.
The nearest streetlamp went out with a pop. He clicked the unlighter again; the next lamp went
out; he kept clicking until every lamp in the square was extinguished and the only remaining
light came from curtained windows and the sickle moon overhead.
"Borrowed it from Weasley," growled Weasley, pocketing the Put-Outer. "That’ll take care of
any Muggles looking out of the window, see? Now come on, quick."
He took Ron by the arm and led him from the patch of grass, across the road and on to the
pavement; Weasley and Weasley followed, carrying Ron’s trunk between them, the rest of the
guard, all with their wands out, flanking them.
The muffled pounding of a stereo was coming from an upper window in the nearest house. A
pungent smell of rotting rubbish came from the pile of bulging bin-bags just inside the broken
gate.
"Here," Weasley muttered, thrusting a piece of parchment towards Ron’s Disillusioned hand and
holding his lit wand close to it, so as to illuminate the writing. "Read quickly and memories."
Ron looked down at the piece of paper. The narrow handwriting was vaguely familiar. It said:
The Headquarters of the Order of the Phoenix may be found at number twelve, Grimmauld
Place, London.
CHAPTER FOUR
Number Twelve, Grimmauld Place
"What’s the Order of the -?" Ron began.
"Not here, boy!" snarled Weasley. "Wait till we’re inside!"
He pulled the piece of parchment out of Ron’s hand and set fire to it with his wand-tip. As the
message curled into flames and floated to the ground, Ron looked around at the houses again.
They were standing outside number eleven; he looked to the left and saw number ten; to the
right, however, was number thirteen.
"But where’s -?"
"Think about what you’ve just memorized," said Weasley quietly.
Ron thought, and no sooner had he reached the part about number twelve, Grimmauld Place,
than a battered door emerged out of nowhere between numbers eleven and thirteen, followed
swiftly by dirty walls and grimy windows. It was as though an extra house had inflated, pushing
those on either side out of its way. Ron gaped at it. The stereo in number eleven thudded on.
Apparently the Muggles inside hadn’t felt anything.
"Come on, hurry," growled Weasley, prodding Ron in the back.
Ron walked up the worn stone steps, staring at the newly materialized door. Its black paint was
shabby and scratched. The silver doorknocker was in the form of a twisted serpent. There was no
keyhole or letterbox.
Weasley pulled out his wand and tapped the door once. Ron heard many loud, metallic clicks and
what sounded like the clatter of a chain. The door creaked open.
"Get in quick, Ron," Weasley whispered, "but don’t go far inside and don’t touch anything."
Ron stepped over the threshold into the almost total darkness of the hall. He could smell damp,
dust and a sweetish, rotting smell; the place had the feeling of a derelict building. He looked over
his shoulder and saw the others filing in behind him, Weasley and Weasley carrying his trunk and
Ron’s cage. Weasley was standing on the top step releasing the balls of light the Put-Outer had
stolen from the streetlamps; they flew back to their bulbs and the square glowed momentarily
with orange light before Weasley limped inside and closed the front door, so that the darkness in
the hall became complete.
"Here -"
He rapped Ron hard over the head with his wand; Ron felt as though something hot was
trickling down his back this time and knew that the Disillusionment Charm must have lifted.
"Now stay still, everyone, while I give us a bit of light in here," Weasley whispered.
The others’ hushed voices were giving Ron an odd feeling of foreboding; it was as though they
had just entered the house of a dying person. He heard a soft hissing noise and then old-fashioned gas lamps sputtered into life all along the walls, casting a flickering insubstantial light
over the peeling wallpaper and threadbare carpet of a long, gloomy hallway, where a cobwebby
chandelier glimmered overhead and age-blackened portraits hung crooked on the walls. Ron
heard something scuttling behind the baseboard. Both the chandelier and the candelabra on a
rickety table nearby were shaped like serpents.
There were hurried footsteps and Ron’s mother, Mrs. Weasley, emerged from a door at the far
end of the hall. She was beaming in welcome as she hurried towards them, though Ron noticed
that she was rather thinner and paler than she had been last time he had seen her.
"Oh, Ron, it’s lovely to see you!" she whispered, pulling him into a rib-cracking hug before
holding him at arm’s length and examining him critically. "You’re looking peaky; you need
feeding up, but you’ll have to wait a bit for dinner, I’m afraid."
She turned to the gang of wizards behind him and whispered urgently, "He’s just arrived, the
meetings started."
The wizards behind Ron all made noises of interest and excitement and began filing past him
towards the door through which Mrs. Weasley had just come. Ron made to follow Weasley, but
Mrs. Weasley held him back.
"No, Ron, the meetings only for members of the Order. Ron and Ron are upstairs, you
can wait with them until the meetings over, then we’ll have dinner. And keep your voice down in
the hall," she added in an urgent whisper.
"Why?"
"I don’t want anything to wake up."
"What d’you -?"
"I’ll explain later, I’ve got to hurry, I’m supposed to be at the meeting - I’ll just show you where
you’re sleeping."
Pressing her finger to her lips, she led him on tiptoe past a pair of long, moth-eaten curtains,
behind which Ron supposed there must be another door, and after skirting a large umbrella
stand that looked as though it had been made from a severed troll’s leg they started up the dark
staircase, passing a row of shrunken heads mounted on plaques on the wall. A closer look
showed Ron that the heads belonged to house-elves. All of them had the same rather snout-like
nose.
Ron’s bewilderment deepened with every step he took. What on earth were they doing in a
house that looked as though it belonged to the darkest of wizards?
"Mrs. Weasley, why -?"
"Ron and Ron will explain everything, dear, I’ve really got to dash," Mrs. Weasley
whispered distractedly. "There -" they had reached the second landing, "- you’re the door on the
right. I’ll call you when it’s over."
And she hurried off downstairs again.
Ron crossed the dingy landing, turned the bedroom doorknob, which was shaped like a serpents
head, and opened the door.
He caught a brief glimpse of a gloomy high-ceilinged, twin-bedded room; then there was a loud
twittering noise, followed by an even louder shriek, and his vision was completely obscured by a
large quantity of very bushy hair. Ron had thrown herself on to him in a hug that nearly
knocked him flat, while Ron’s tiny owl, Ron, zoomed excitedly round and round their
heads.
"Ron! Ron, he’s here, Ron’s here! We didn’t hear you arrive! Oh, how are you? Are you all right? Have you been furious with us? I bet you have, I know our letters were useless - but we
couldn’t tell you anything, Weasley made us swear we wouldn’t, oh, we’ve got so much to
tell you, and you’ve got things to tell us - the Dementors! When we heard - and that Ministry
hearing - it’s just outrageous, I’ve looked it all up, they can’t expel you, they just can’t, there’s
provision in the Decree for the Reasonable Restriction of Underage Sorcery for the use of magic
in life-threatening situations -"
"Let him breathe, Ron," said Ron, grinning as he closed the door behind Ron. He seemed
to have grown several more inches during their month apart, making him taller and more gangly
looking than ever, though the long nose, bright red hair and freckles were the same.
Still beaming, Ron let go of Ron, but before she could say another word there was a soft
whooshing sound and something white soared from the top of a dark wardrobe and landed gently
on Ron’s shoulder.
"Ron!"
The snowy owl clicked her beak and nibbled his ear affectionately as Ron stroked her feathers.
"She’s been in a right state," said Ron. "Pecked us half to death when she brought your last
letters, look at this -"
He showed Ron the index finger of his right hand, which sported a half-healed but clearly deep
cut.
"Oh, yeah," Ron said. "Sorry about that, but I wanted answers, you know -"
"We wanted to give them to you, mate," said Ron. "Ron was going spare, she kept saying
you’d do something stupid if you were stuck all on your own without news, but Weasley
made us -"
"- swear not to tell me," said Ron. "Yeah, Ron’s already said."
The warm glow that had flared inside him at the sight of his two best friends was extinguished as
something icy flooded the pit of his stomach. All of a sudden - after yearning to see them for a
solid month -- he felt he would rather Ron and Ron left him alone.
There was a strained silence in which Ron stroked Ron automatically, not looking at either
of the others.
"He seemed to think it was best," said Ron rather breathlessly. "Weasley, I mean."
"Right," said Ron. He noticed that her hands, too, bore the marks of Rons beak and found
that he was not at all sorry.
"I think he thought you were safest with the Muggles -" Ron began.
"Yeah?" said Ron, raising his eyebrows. "Have either of you been attacked by Dementors this
summer?"
"Well, no-but that’s why he’s had people from the Order of the Phoenix tailing you all the time-"
Ron felt a great jolt in his guts as though he had just missed a step going downstairs. So
everyone had known he was being followed, except him.
"Didn’t work that well, though, did it?" said Ron, doing his utmost to keep his voice even.
"Had to look after myself after all, didn’t I?"
"He was so angry," said Ron, in an almost awestruck voice. "Weasley. We saw him.
When he found out Ron had left before his shift had ended. He was scary."
"Well, I’m glad he left," Ron said coldly. "If he hadn’t, I wouldn’t have done magic and
Weasley would probably have left me at Privet Drive all summer."
"Aren’t you... aren’t you worried about the Ministry of Magic hearing?" said Ron quietly.
"No," Ron lied defiantly. He walked away from them, looking around, with Ron nestled
contentedly on his shoulder, but this room was not likely to raise his spirits. It was dank and
dark. A blank stretch of canvas in an ornate picture frame was all that relieved the bareness of
the peeling walls, and as Ron passed it he thought he heard someone, who was lurking out of
sight, snigger.
"So why’s Weasley been so keen to keep me in the dark?" Ron asked, still trying hard to
keep his voice casual. "Did you - er - bother to ask him at all?"
He glanced up just in time to see them exchanging a look that told him he was behaving just as
they had feared he would. It did nothing to improve his temper.
"We told Weasley we wanted to tell you what was going on," said Ron. "We did, mate. But
he’s really busy now, we’ve only seen him twice since we came here and he didn’t have much
time, he just made us swear not to tell you important stuff when we wrote, he said the owls might
be intercepted."
"He could still’ve kept me informed if he’d wanted to," Ron said shortly. "You’re not telling me he doesn’t know ways to send messages without owls."
Ron glanced at Ron and then said, "I thought that, too. But he didn’t want you to
know anything."
"Maybe he thinks I can’t be trusted," said Ron, watching their expressions.
"Don’t be thick," said Ron, looking highly disconcerted.
"Or that I can’t take care of myself."
"Of course he doesn’t think that!" said Ron anxiously.
"So how come I have to stay at the Weasleys’ while you two get to join in everything that’s going
on here?" said Ron, the words tumbling over one another in a rush, his voice growing louder
with every word. "How come you two are allowed to know everything that’s going on?"
"We’re not!" Ron interrupted. "Mum won’t let us near the meetings, she says we’re too young -"
But before he knew it, Ron was shouting.
"SO YOU HAVEN’T BEEN IN THE MEETINGS, BIG DEAL! YOU’VE STILL BEEN HERE,
HAVEN’T YOU? YOU’VE STILL BEEN TOGETHER! ME, I’VE BEEN STUCK AT THE
WeasleyS’ FOR A MONTH! AND I’VE HANDLED MORE THAN YOU TWO’VE EVER
MANAGED AND Weasley KNOWS IT - WHO SAVED THE SORCERER’S
STONE? WHO GOT RID OF Weasley? WHO SAVED BOTH YOUR SKINS FROM THE
DEMENTORS?"
Every bitter and resentful thought Ron had had in the past month was pouring out of him: his
frustration at the lack of news, the hurt that they had all been together without him, his fury at
being followed and not told about it - all the feelings he was half-ashamed of finally burst their
boundaries. Ron took fright at the noise and soared off to the top of the wardrobe again;
Ron twittered in alarm and zoomed even faster around their heads.
"WHO HAD TO GET PAST DRAGONS AND SPHINXES AND EVERY OTHER FOUL
THING LAST YEAR? WHO SAW HIM COME BACK? WHO HAD TO ESCAPE FROM
HIM? ME!"
Ron was standing there with his mouth half-open, clearly stunned and at a loss for anything to
say, while Ron looked on the verge of tears.
"BUT WHY SHOULD I KNOW WHAT’S GOING ON? WHY SHOULD ANYONE BOTHER
TO TELL ME WHAT’S BEEN HAPPENING?"
"Ron, we wanted to tell you, we really did -" Ron began.
"CAN’T’VE WANRon TO THAT MUCH, CAN YOU, OR YOU’D HAVE SENT ME AN
OWL, BUT Weasley MADEYOU SWEAR-"
"Well, he did -"
"FOUR WEEKS I’VE BEEN STUCK IN PRIVET DRIVE, RonING PAPERS OUT OF BINS
TO TRY AND FIND OUT WHAT’S BEEN GOING ON -"
"We wanted to -"
"I SUPPOSE YOU’VE BEEN HAVING A REAL LAUGH, HAVEN’T YOU, ALL HOLED UP
HERE TOGETHER -"
"No, honest -"
"Ron we’re really sorry!" said Ron desperately, her eyes now sparkling with tears. "You’re absolutely right, Ron - I’d be furious if it was me!"
Ron glared at her, still breathing deeply, then turned away from them again, pacing up and
down. Ron hooted glumly from the top of the wardrobe. There was a long pause, broken only
by the mournful creak of the floorboards below Ron’s feet.
"What is this place, anyway?" he shot at Ron and Ron.
"Headquarters of the Order of the Phoenix," said Ron at once.
"Is anyone going to bother telling me what the Order of the Phoenix -?"
"It’s a secret society," said Ron quickly. "Weasley’s in charge, he founded it. It’s the
people who fought against You-Know-Who last time."
"Who’s in it?" said Ron, coming to a halt with his hands in his pockets.
"Quite a few people -"
"We’ve met about twenty of them," said Ron, "but we think there are more."
Ron glared at them.
"Well?" he demanded, looking from one to the other.
"Er," said Ron. "Well what?"
"Weasley!" said Ron furiously, and both Ron and Ron winced. "What’s happening?
What’s he up to? Where is he? What are we doing to stop him?"
"We’ve told you, the Order don’t let us in on their meetings," said Ron nervously. "So we
don’t know the details - but we’ve got a general idea," she added hastily, seeing the look on
Ron’s face.
"Ron and Ron have invented Extendable Ears, see," said Ron. "They’re really useful."
"Extendable -?"
"Ears, yeah. Only we’ve had to stop using them lately because Mum found out and went berserk.
Ron and Ron had to hide them all to stop Mum binning them. But we got a good bit of use
out of them before Mum realized what was going on. We know some of the Order are following
known Death Eaters, keeping tabs on them, you know -"
"Some of them are working on recruiting more people to the Order -" said Ron.
"And some of them are standing guard over something," said Ron. "They’re always talking about guard duty."
"Couldn’t have been me, could it?" said Ron sarcastically.
"Oh, yeah," said Ron, with a look of dawning comprehension.
Ron snorted. He walked around the room again, looking anywhere but at Ron and Ron.
"So, what have you two been doing, if you’re not allowed in meetings?" he demanded. "You said you’d been busy"‘
"We have," said Ron quickly. "We’ve been decontaminating this house, it’s been empty for ages and stuff’s been breeding in here. We’ve managed to clean out the kitchen, most of the
bedrooms and I think we’re doing the drawing room tomo-"
With two loud cracks, Ron and Ron, Ron’s elder twin brothers, had materialized out of thin
air in the middle of the room. Ron twittered more wildly than ever and zoomed off to join
Ron on top of the wardrobe.
"Stop doing that!" Ron said weakly to the twins, who were as vividly red-haired as Ron,
though stockier and slightly shorter.
"Hello, Ron," said Ron, beaming at him. "We thought we heard your dulcet tones."
"You don’t want to bottle up your anger like that, Ron, let it all out," said Ron, also beaming.
"There might be a couple of people fifty miles away who didn’t hear you."
"You two passed your Apparation tests, then?" asked Ron grumpily.
"With distinction," said Ron, who was holding what looked like a piece of very long, flesh colored string.
"It would have taken you about thirty seconds longer to walk down the stairs," said Ron.
"Time is Galleons, little brother" said Ron. "Anyway, Ron, you’re interfering with reception.
Extendable Ears," he added in response to Ron’s raised eyebrows, and held up the string which
Ron now saw was trailing out on to the landing. "We’re trying to hear what’s going on
downstairs."
"You want to be careful," said Ron, staring at the Ear, "if Mum sees one of them again..."
"It’s worth the risk, that’s a major meeting they’re having," said Ron.
The door opened and a long mane of red hair appeared.
"Oh, hello, Ron!" said Ron’s younger sister, Ron, brightly. "I thought I heard your voice."
Turning to Ron and Ron, she said, "It’s no-go with the Extendable Ears, she’s gone and put
an Imperturbable Charm on the kitchen door."
"How d’you know?" said Ron, looking crestfallen.
"Weasley told me how to find out," said Ron. "You just chuck stuff at the door and if it can’t
make contact the door’s been Imperturbed. I’ve been flicking Dungbombs at it from the top of
the stairs and they just soar away from it, so there’s no way the Extendable Ears will be able to
get under the gap."
Ron heaved a deep sigh.
"Shame. I really fancied finding out what old Weasley’s been up to."
"Weasley!" said Ron quickly. "Is he here?"
"Yeah," said Ron, carefully closing the door and sitting down on one of the beds; Ron and
Ron followed. "Giving a report. Top secret."
"Git," said Ron idly.
"He’s on our side now," said Ron reprovingly.
Ron snorted. "Doesn’t stop him being a git. The way he looks at us when he sees us."
"Ron doesn’t like him, either," said Ron, as though that settled the matter.
Ron was not sure his anger had abated yet; but his thirst for information was now overcoming
his urge to keep shouting. He sank on to the bed opposite the others.
"Is Ron here?" he asked. "I thought he was working in Egypt?"
"He applied for a desk job so he could come home and work for the Order," said Ron. "He says
he misses the tombs, but;" he smirked, "there are compensations."
"What d’you mean?"
"Remember old Ron Weasley?" said Ron. "She’s got a job at Gringotts to eempwve ‘er
Eeenglish -"
"And Ron’s been giving her a lot of private lessons," sniggered Ron.
"Ron’s in the Order, too," said Ron, "but he’s still in Romania. Weasley wants as many foreign wizards brought in as possible, so Ron’s trying to make contacts on his days off."
"Couldn’t Ron do that?" Ron asked. The last he had heard, the third Weasley brother was
working in the Department of International Magical Co-operation at the Ministry of Magic.
At Ron’s words, all the Weasleys and Ron exchanged darkly significant looks.
"Whatever you do, don’t mention Ron in front of Mum and Dad," Ron told Ron in a tense
voice.
"Why not?"
"Because every time Ron’s name’s mentioned, Dad breaks whatever he’s holding and Mum
starts crying," Ron said.
"It’s been awful," said Ron sadly.
"I think we’re well shut of him," said Ron, with an uncharacteristically ugly look on his face.
"What’s happened?" Ron said.
"Ron and Dad had a row," said Ron. "I’ve never seen Dad row with anyone like that. It’s
normally Mum who shouts."
"It was the first week back after term ended," said Ron. "We were about to come and join the
Order. Ron came home and told us he’d been promoted."
"You’re kidding?" said Ron.
Though he knew perfectly well that Ron was highly ambitious, Ron’s impression was that
Ron had not made a great success of his first job at the Ministry of Magic. Ron had
committed the fairly large oversight of failing to notice that his boss was being controlled by
Lord Weasley (not that the Ministry had believed it - they all thought Mr. Weasley had gone
mad).
"Yeah, we were all surprised," said Ron, "because Ron got into a load of trouble about
Weasley, there was an inquiry and everything. They said Ron ought to have realized Weasley was
off his rocker and informed a superior. But you know Ron, Weasley left him in charge, he
wasn’t going to complain."
"So how come they promoted him?"
"That’s exactly what we wondered," said Ron, who see med very keen to keep normal
conversation going now that Ron had stopped yelling. "He came home really pleased with
himself - even more pleased than usual, if you can imagine that - and told Dad he’d been offered
a position in Weasley’s own office. A really good one for someone only a year out of Hogwarts:
Junior Assistant to the Minister. He expected Dad to be all impressed, I think."
"Only Dad wasn’t," said Ron grimly.
"Why not?" said Ron.
"Well, apparently Weasley has been storming round the Ministry checking that nobody’s having
any contact with Weasley," said Ron.
"Weasley’s name is mud with the Ministry these days, see," said Ron. "They all think he’s
just making trouble saying You-Know-Who’s back."
"Dad says Weasley has made it clear that anyone who’s in league with Weasley can clear out
their desks," said Ron.
"Trouble is, Weasley suspects Dad, he knows he’s friendly with Weasley, and he’s always
thought Dad’s a bit of a weirdo because of his Muggle obsession."
"But what’s that got to do with Ron?" asked Ron, confused.
"I’m coming to that. Dad reckons Weasley only wants Ron in his office because he wants to use
him to spy on the family - and Weasley."
Ron let out a low whistle.
"Bet Ron loved that."
Ron laughed in a hollow sort of way.
"He went completely berserk. He said - well, he said loads of terrible stuff. He said he’s been
having to struggle against Dad’s lousy reputation ever since he joined the Ministry and that
Dad’s got no ambition and that’s why we’ve always been - you know - not had a lot of money, I
mean -"
"What?" said Ron in disbelief, as Ron made a noise like an angry cat.
"I know," said Ron in a low voice. "And it got worse. He said Dad was an idiot to run around
with Weasley, that Weasley was heading for big trouble and Dad was going to go down
with him, and that he - Ron - knew where his loyalty lay and it was with the Ministry. And if
Mum and Dad were going to become traitors to the Ministry he was going to make sure everyone
knew he didn’t belong to our family any more. And he packed his bags the same night and left.
He’s living here in London now."
Ron swore under his breath. He had always liked Ron least of Ron’s brothers, but he had
never imagined he would say such things to Mr. Weasley.
"Mum’s been in a right state," said Ron dully. "You know - crying and stuff. She came up to
London to try and talk to Ron but he slammed the door in her face. I dunno what he does if he
meets Dad at work - ignores him, I s’pose."
"But Ron must know Weasley’s back," said Ron s lowly. "He’s not stupid, he must know
your mum and dad wouldn’t risk everything without proof."
"Yeah, well, your name got dragged into the row," said Ron, shooting Ron a furtive look.
"Ron said the only evidence was your word and... I dunno... he didn’t think it was good
enough."
"Ron takes the Daily Prophet seriously," said Ron tartly, and the others all nodded.
"What are you talking about?" Ron asked, looking around at them all. They were all regarding
him warily.
"Haven’t - haven’t you been getting the Daily Prophet!" Ron asked nervously.
"Yeah, I have!" said Ron.
"Have you - er - been reading it thoroughly?" Ron asked, still more anxiously.
"Not cover to cover," said Ron defensively. "If they were going to report anything about
Weasley it would be headline news, wouldn’t it?"
The others flinched at the sound of the name. Ron hurried on, "Well, you’d need to read it
cover to cover to pick it up, but they - um - they mention you a couple of times a week."
"But I’d have seen -"
"Not if you’ve only been reading the front page, you wouldn’t," said Ron, shaking her
head. "I’m not talking about big articles. They just slip you in, like you’re a standing joke."
"What d’you -?"
"It’s quite nasty, actually," said Ron in a voice of forced calm. "They’re just building on
Ron’s stuff."
"But she’s not writing for them any more, is she?"
"Oh, no, she’s kept her promise - not that she’s got any choice," Ron added with
satisfaction. "But she laid the foundation for what they’re trying to do now."
"Which is what?" said Ron impatiently.
"Okay, you know she wrote that you were collapsing all over the place and saying your scar was
hurting and all that?"
"Yeah," said Ron, who was not likely to forget Ron Weasleys stories about him in a hurry.
"Well, they’re writing about you as though you’re this deluded, attention-seeking person who
thinks he’s a great tragic hero or something," said Ron, very fast, as though it would be less
unpleasant for Ron to hear these facts quickly. "They keep slipping in snide comments about
you. If some far-fetched story appears, they say something like, ‘tale worthy of Ron Weasley’, and if anyone has a funny accident or anything it’s, ‘lets hope he hasn’t got a scar on his forehead or we’ll be asked to worship him next -"
"I don’t want anyone to worship -" Ron began hotly.
"I know you don’t," said Ron quickly, looking frightened. "I know, Ron. But you see what they’re doing? They want to turn you into someone nobody will believe. Weasley is behind it, I’ll bet anything. They want wizards on the street to think you’re just some stupid boy who’s a bit of a joke, who tells ridiculous tall stories because he loves being famous and wants to keep it
going."
"I didn’t ask - I didn’t want - Weasley killed my parents!" Ron spluttered. "I got famous
because he murdered my family but couldn’t kill me! Who wants to be famous for that? Don’t
they think I’d rather it’d never -"
"We know, Ron," said Ron earnestly.
"And of course, they didn’t report a word about the Dementors attacking you," said Ron.
"Someone’s told them to keep that quiet. That should’ve been a really big story, out-of-control
Dementors. They haven’t even reported that you broke the International Statute of Secrecy. We
thought they would, it would tie in so well with this image of you as some stupid show-off. We
think they’re biding their time until you’re expelled, then they’re really going to go to town - I
mean, if you’re expelled, obviously," she went on hastily. "You really shouldn’t be, not if they
abide by their own laws, there’s no case against you."
They were back on the hearing and Ron did not want to think about that. He cast around for
another change of subject, but was saved the necessity of finding one by the sound of footsteps
coming up the stairs.
"Uh oh."
Ron gave the Extendable Ear a hearty tug; there was another loud crack and he and Ron
vanished. Seconds later, Mrs. Weasley appeared in the bedroom doorway.
"The meeting’s over, you can come down and have dinner now. Everyone’s dying to see you,
Ron. And who’s left all those Dungbombs outside the kitchen door?"
"Ron," said Ron unblushingly. "He loves playing with them."
"Oh," said Mrs. Weasley, "I thought it might have been Ron, he keeps doing odd things like
that. Now don’t forget to keep your voices down in the hall. Ron, your hands are filthy, what
have you been doing? Go and wash them before dinner, please."
Ron grimaced at the others and followed her mother out of the room, leaving Ron alone with
Ron and Ron. Both of them were watching him apprehensively, as though they feared he
would start shouting again now that everyone else had gone. The sight of them looking so
nervous made him feel slightly ashamed.
"Look..." he muttered, but Ron shook his head, and Ron said quietly, "We knew you’d be
angry, Ron, we really don’t blame you, but you’ve got to understand, we did try to persuade
Weasley -"
"Yeah, I know," said Ron shortly.
He cast around for a topic that didn’t involve his headmaster, because the very thought of
Weasley made Ron’s insides burn with anger again.
"Who’s Ron?" he asked.
"The house-elf who lives here," said Ron. "Nutter. Never met one like him."
Ron frowned at Ron.
"He’s not a nutter, Ron."
"His life’s ambition is to have his head cut off and stuck up on a plaque just like his mother," said Ron irritably. "Is that normal, Ron?"
"Well - well, if he is a bit strange, it’s not his fault."
Ron rolled his eyes at Ron.
"Ron still hasn’t given up on SPEW -"
"It’s not SPEW!" said Ron heatedly. "It’s the Society for the Promotion of Elfish Welfare.
And it’s not just me, Weasley says we should be kind to Ron too."
"Yeah, yeah," said Ron. "C’mon, I’m starving."
He led the way out of the door and on to the landing, but before they could descend the stairs -
"Hold it!" Ron breathed, flinging out an arm to stop Ron and Ron walking any further.
"They’re still in the hall, we might be able to hear something."
The three of them looked cautiously over the banisters. The gloomy hallway below was packed
with witches and wizards, including all of Ron’s guard. They were whispering excitedly
together. In the very center of the group Ron saw the dark, greasy-haired head and prominent
nose of his least favorite teacher at Hogwarts, Professor Weasley. Ron leaned further over the
banisters. He was very interested in what Weasley was doing for the Order of the Phoenix...
A thin piece of flesh-colored string descended in front of Ron’s eyes. Looking up, he saw Ron
and Ron on the landing above, cautiously lowering the Extendable Ear towards the dark knot
of people below. A moment later, however, they all began to move towards the front door and
out of sight.
"Damnit," Ron heard Ron whisper, as he hoisted t he Extendable Ear back up again.
They heard the front door open, then close.
"Weasley never eats here," Ron told Ron quietly. "Thank God. C’mon."
"And don’t forget to keep your voice down in the hall, Ron," Ron whispered.
As they passed the row of house-elf heads on the wall, they saw Weasley, Mrs. Weasley and Weasley
at the front door, magically sealing its many locks and bolts behind those who had just left.
"We’re eating down in the kitchen," Mrs. Weasley whispered, meeting them at the bottom of the
stairs. "Ron, dear, if you’ll just tiptoe across the hall, it’s through this door here -"
CRASH.
"Weasley!" cried Mrs. Weasley in exasperation, turning to look behind her.
"I’m sorry!" wailed Weasley, who was lying flat on the floor. "It’s that stupid umbrella stand, that’s the second time I’ve tripped over -"
But the rest of her words were drowned by a horrible, ear-splitting, blood-curdling screech.
The moth-eaten velvet curtains Ron had passed earlier had flown apart, but there was no door
behind them. For a split second, Ron thought he was looking through a window, a window
behind which an old woman in a black cap was screaming and screaming as though she were
being tortured - then he realized it was simply a life-size portrait, but the most realiztic, and the
most unpleasant, he had ever seen in his life.
The old woman was drooling, her eyes were rolling, the yellowing skin of her face stretched taut
as she screamed; and all along the hall behind them, the other portraits awoke and began to yell,
too, so that Ron actually screwed up his eyes at the noise and clapped his hands over his ears.
Weasley and Mrs. Weasley darted forward and tried to tug the curtains shut over the old woman,
but they would not close and she screeched louder than ever, brandishing clawed hands as
though trying to tear at their faces.
"Filth! Scum! By-products of dirt and vileness! Half-breeds, mutants, freaks, begone from this
place! How dare you befoul the house of my fathers -"
Weasley apologized over and over again, dragging the huge, heavy troll’s leg back off the floor;
Mrs. Weasley abandoned the attempt to close the curtains and hurried up and down the hall,
stunning all the other portraits with her wand; and a man with long black hair came charging out
of a door facing Ron.
"Shut up, you horrible old hag, shut UP!" he roared, seizing the curtain Mrs. Weasley had
abandoned.
The old woman’s face blanched.
"Yoooou!" she howled, her eyes popping at the sight of the man. "Blood traitor, abomination,
shame of my flesh!"
"I said - shut - UP!" roared the man, and with a stupendous effort he and Weasley managed to force the curtains closed again.
The old woman’s screeches died and an echoing silence fell. Panting slightly and sweeping his
long dark hair out of his eyes, Ron’s godfather Ron turned to face him.
"Hello, Ron," he said grimly, "I see you’ve met my mother."
CHAPTER FIVE
The Order of the Phoenix
"Your -?"
"My dear old mum, yeah," said Ron. "We’ve been trying to get her down for a month but we
think she put a Permanent Sticking Charm on the back of the canvas. Let’s get downstairs, quick,
before they all wake up again."
"But what’s a portrait of your mother doing here?" Ron asked, bewildered, as they went
through the door from the hall and led the way down a flight of narrow stone steps, the others
just behind them.
"Hasn’t anyone told you? This was my parents’ house," said Ron. "But I’m the last Weasley left,
so it’s mine now. I offered it to Weasley for Headquarters - about the only useful thing I’ve
been able to do."
Ron, who had expected a better welcome, noted how hard and bitter Ron’s voice sounded. He
followed his godfather to the bottom of the steps and through a door leading into the basement
kitchen.
It was scarcely less gloomy than the hall above, a cavernous room with rough stone walls. Most
of the light was coming from a large fire at the far end of the room. A haze of pipe smoke hung
in the air like battle fumes, through which loomed the menacing shapes of heavy iron pots and
pans hanging from the dark ceiling. Many chairs had been crammed into the room for the
meeting and a long wooden table stood in the middle of them, littered with rolls of parchment,
goblets, empty wine bottles, and a heap of what appeared to be rags. Mr. Weasley and his eldest
son Ron were talking quietly with their heads together at the end of the table.
Mrs. Weasley cleared her throat. Her husband, a thin, balding, red-haired man who wore horn-rimmed glasses, looked around and jumped to his feet.
"Ron!" Mr. Weasley said, hurrying forward to greet him, and shaking his hand vigorously.
"Good to see you!"
Over his shoulder Ron saw Ron, who still wore his long hair in a ponytail, hastily rolling up the
lengths of parchment left on the table.
"Journey all right, Ron?" Ron called, trying to gather up twelve scrolls at once. "Mad-Eye didn’t make you come via Greenland, then?"
"He tried," said Weasley, striding over to help Ron and immediately toppling a candle on to the last
piece of parchment. "Oh no - sorry -
"Here, dear," said Mrs. Weasley, sounding exasperated, and she repaired the parchment with a
wave of her wand. In the flash of light caused by Mrs. Weasley’s charm Ron caught a glimpse
of what looked like the plan of a building.
Mrs. Weasley had seen him looking. She snatched the plan off the table and stuffed it into Ron’s
already overladen arms.
"This sort of thing ought to be cleared away promptly at the end of meetings," she snapped,
before sweeping off towards an ancient dresser from which she started unloading dinner plates.
Ron took out his wand, muttered, "Evanesco!" and the scrolls vanished.
"Sit down, Ron," said Ron. "You’ve met Ron, haven’t you?"
The thing Ron had taken to be a pile of rags gave a prolonged, grunting snore, then jerked
awake.
‘Some’n say m’name?’ Ron mumbled sleepily. "I ‘gree with Ron..." He raised a very
grubby hand in the air as though voting, his droopy, bloodshot eyes unfocused.
Ron giggled.
"The meeting’s over, Dung," said Ron, as they all sat down around him at the table. "Ron’s
arrived."
"Eh?" said Ron, peering balefully at Ron through his matted ginger hair. "Blimey, so ‘e
‘as. Yeah... you all right, ‘Arry?"
"Yeah," said Ron.
Ron fumbled nervously in his pockets, still staring at Ron, and pulled out a grimy black
pipe. He stuck it in his mouth, ignited the end of it with his wand and took a deep pull on it.
Great billowing clouds of greenish smoke obscured him within seconds.
"Owe you a ‘pology," grunted a voice from the middle of the smelly cloud.
"For the last time, Ron," called Mrs. Weasley, "will you please not smoke that thing in the kitchen, especially not when we’re about to eat!"
"Ah," said Ron. "Right. Sorry, Ron."
The cloud of smoke vanished as Ron stowed his pipe back in his pocket, but an acrid
smell of burning socks lingered.
"And if you want dinner before midnight I’ll need a hand," Mrs. Weasley said to the room at
large. "No, you can stay where you are, Ron dear, you’ve had a long journey."
"What can I do, Ron?" said Weasley enthusiastically, bounding forwards.
Mrs. Weasley hesitated, looking apprehensive.
"Er - no, it’s all right, Weasley, you have a rest too, you’ve done enough today."
"No, no, I want to help!" said Weasley brightly, knocking over a chair as she hurried towards the
dresser, from which Ron was collecting cutlery.
Soon, a series of heavy knives were chopping meat and vegetables of their own accord,
supervised by Mr. Weasley, while Mrs. Weasley stirred a cauldron dangling over the fire and the
others took out plates, more goblets and food from the pantry. Ron was left at the table with
Ron and Ron, who was still blinking at him mournfully.
"Seen old Weasleyy since?" he asked.
"No," said Ron, "I haven’t seen anyone."
"See, I wouldn’t ‘ave left," said Ron, leaning forward, a pleading note in his voice, "but I
‘ad a business opportunity -"
Ron felt something brush against his knees and started, but it was only Ron,
Ron’s bandy-legged ginger cat, who wound himself once around Ron’s legs, purring,
then jumped on to Ron’s lap and curled up. Ron scratched him absent-mindedly behind the
ears as he turned, still grim-faced, to Ron.
"Had a good summer so far?"
"No, it’s been lousy," said Ron.
For the first time, something like a grin flitted across Ron’s face.
"Don’t know what you’re complaining about, myself."
"What?" said Ron incredulously.
"Personally, I’d have welcomed a Dementor attack. A deadly struggle for my soul would have
broken the monotony nicely. You think you’ve had it bad, at least you’ve been able to get out
and about, stretch your legs, get into a few fights... I’ve been stuck inside for a month."
"How come?" asked Ron, frowning.
"Because the Ministry of Magic’s still after me, and Weasley will know all about me being an
Animagus by now, Wormtail will have told him, so my big disguise is useless. There’s not much
I can do for the Order of the Phoenix... or so Weasley feels."
There was something about the slightly flattened tone of voice in which Ron uttered
Weasley’s name that told Ron that Ron, too, was not very happy with the Headmaster.
Ron felt a sudden upsurge of affection for his godfather.
"At least you’ve known what’s been going on," he said bracingly.
"Oh yeah," said Ron sarcastically. "Listening to Weasley’s reports, having to take all his snide
hints that he’s out there risking his life while I’m sat on my backside here having a nice
comfortable time... asking me how the cleanings going -"
"What cleaning?" asked Ron.
"Trying to make this place fit for human habitation," said Ron, waving a hand around the dismal kitchen. "No one’s lived here for ten years, not since my dear mother died, unless you count her old house-elf, and he’s gone round the twist - hasn’t cleaned anything in ages."
"Ron," said Ron, who did not appear to have paid any attention to the conversation, but
had been closely examining an empty goblet. "This solid silver, mate?"
"Yes," said Ron, surveying it with distaste. "Finest fifteenth-century goblin-wrought silver,
embossed with the Weasley family crest."
"That’d come off, though," muttered Ron, polishing it with his cuff.
"Ron - Ron - NO, JUST CARRY THEM!" Mrs. Weasley shrieked.
Ron, Ron and Ron looked round and, a split second later, they had dived away from
the table. Ron and Ron had bewitched a large cauldron of stew, an iron flagon of Butterbeer
and a heavy wooden breadboard, complete with knife, to hurtle through the air towards them. The stew skidded the length of the table and came to a halt just before the end, leaving a long
black burn on the wooden surface; the flagon of Butterbeer fell with a crash, spilling its contents
everywhere; the bread knife slipped off the board and landed, point down and quivering
ominously, exactly where Ron’s right hand had been seconds before.
"FOR HEAVEN’S SAKE!" screamed Mrs. Weasley. "THERE WAS NO NEED - I’VE HAD
ENOUGH OF THIS - JUST BECAUSE YOU’RE ALLOWED TO USE MAGIC NOW, YOU
DON’T HAVE TO WHIP YOUR WANDS OUT FOR EVERY TINY LITTLE THING!"
"We were just trying to save a bit of time!" said Ron, hurrying forward to wrench the bread knife out of the table. "Sorry, Ron, mate - didn’t mean to -"
Ron and Ron were both laughing; Ron, who had toppled backwards off his chair, was
swearing as he got to his feet; Ron had given an angry hiss and shot off under the
dresser, from where his large yellow eyes glowed in the darkness.
"Boys," Mr. Weasley said, lifting the stew back into the middle of the table, "your mother’s right, you’re supposed to show a sense of responsibility now you’ve come of age -"
"None of your brothers caused this sort of trouble!" Mrs. Weasley raged at the twins as she
slammed a fresh flagon of Butterbeer on to the table, and spilling almost as much again. "Ron
didn’t feel the need to Apparate every few feet! Ron didn’t charm everything he met! Ron -"
She stopped dead, catching her breath with a frightened look at her husband, whose expression
was suddenly wooden.
"Let’s eat," said Ron quickly.
"It looks wonderful, Ron," said Weasley, ladling stew on to a plate for her and handing it across
the table.
For a few minutes there was silence but for the chink of plates and cutlery and the scraping of
chairs as everyone settled down to their food. Then Mrs. Weasley turned to Ron.
"I’ve been meaning to tell you, Ron, there’s something trapped in that writing desk in the
drawing room, it keeps rattling and shaking. Of course, it could just be a Boggart, but I thought
we ought to ask Ron to have a look at it before we let it out."
"Whatever you like," said Ron indifferently.
"The curtains in there are full of Doxys, too," Mrs. Weasley went on. "I thought we might try and tackle them tomorrow."
"I look forward to it," said Ron. Ron heard the sarcasm in his voice, but he was not sure that
anyone else did.
Opposite Ron, Weasley was entertaining Ron and Ron by transforming her nose between
mouthfuls. Screwing up her eyes each time with the same pained expression she had worn back
in Ron’s bedroom, her nose swelled to a beak-like protuberance that resembled Weasley’s, shrank
to the size of a button mushroom and then sprouted a great deal of hair from each nostril.
Apparently this was a regular mealtime entertainment, because Ron and Ron were soon
requesting their favorite noses.
"Do that one like a pig snout, Weasley."
Weasley obliged, and Ron, looking up, had the fleeting impression that a female Ron was
grinning at him from across the table.
Mr. Weasley, Ron and Weasley were having an intense discussion about goblins.
"They’re not giving anything away yet," said Ron. "I still can’t work out whether or not they
believe he’s back. Course, they might prefer not to take sides at all. Keep out of it."
"I’m sure they’d never go over to You-Know-Who," said Mr. Weasley, shaking his head.
"They’ve suffered losses too; remember that goblin family he murdered last time, somewhere
near Weasleyingham?"
"I think it depends what they’re offered," said Weasley. "And I’m not talking about gold. If they’re
offered the freedoms we’ve been denying them for centuries they’re going to be tempted. Have
you still not had any luck with Ragnok, Ron?"
"He’s feeling pretty anti-wizard at the moment," said Ron, "he hasn’t stopped raging about the
Weasley business, he reckons the Ministry did a cover-up, those goblins never got their gold
from him, you know -"
A gale of laughter from the middle of the table drowned the rest of Ron’s words. Ron, Ron,
Ron and Ron were rolling around in their seats.
"... and then," choked Ron, tears running down his face, "and then, if you’ll believe it, ‘e
says to me, ‘e says, ‘Ere, Dung, where did ya get all them toads from? ‘Cos some son of a
Bludger’s gone and nicked all mine!’ And I says, ‘Roned all your toads, Will, what next? So
you’ll be wanting some more, then?’ And if you’ll believe me, lads, the gormless gargoyle buys
all ‘is own toads back orf me for a lot more’n what ‘e paid in the first place -"
"I don’t think we need to hear any more of your business dealings, thank you very much,
Ron," said Mrs. Weasley sharply, as Ron slumped forwards on to the table, howling with
laughter.
"Beg pardon, Ron," said Ron at once, wiping his eyes and winking at Ron. "But, you
know, Will nicked ‘em orf Warty Harris in the first place so I wasn’t really doing nothing
wrong."
"I don’t know where you learned about right and wrong, Ron, but you seem to have
missed a few crucial lessons," said Mrs. Weasley coldly.
Ron and Ron buried their faces in their goblets of Butterbeer; Ron was hiccoughing. For
some reason, Mrs. Weasley threw a very nasty look at Ron before getting to her feet and going
to fetch a large rhubarb crumble for pudding. Ron looked round at his godfather.
"Ron doesn’t approve of Ron," said Ron in an undertone.
"How come he’s in the Order?" Ron said, very quietly.
"He’s useful," Ron muttered. "Knows all the crooks - well, he would, seeing as he’s one
himself. But he’s also very loyal to Weasley, who helped him out of a tight spot once. It pays
to have someone like Dung around, he hears things we don’t. But Ron thinks inviting him to
stay for dinner is going too far. She hasn’t forgiven him for slipping off duty when he was
supposed to be tailing you."
Three helpings of rhubarb crumble and custard later and the waistband on Ron’s jeans was
feeling uncomfortably tight (which was saying something as the jeans had once been Ron’s).
As he laid down his spoon there was a lull in the general conversation: Mr. Weasley was leaning
back in his chair, looking replete and relaxed; Weasley was yawning widely, her nose now back to
normal; and Ron who had lured Ron out from under the dresser, was sitting cross-legged on the floor, rolling Butterbeer corks for him to chase.
"Nearly time for bed, I think," said Mrs. Weasley with a yawn.
"Not just yet, Ron" said Ron, pushing away his empty plate and turning to look at Ron.
"You know, I’m surprised at you. I thought the first thing you’d do when you got here would be
to start asking questions about Weasley."
The atmosphere in the room changed with the rapidity Ron associated with the arrival of
Dementors. Where seconds before it had been sleepily relaxed, it was now alert, even tense. A
frisson had gone around the table at the mention of Weasley’s name. Weasley, who had been
about to take a sip of wine, lowered his goblet slowly, looking wary.
"I did!" said Ron indignantly. "I asked Ron and Ron but they said we’re not allowed in the Order, so -"
"And they’re quite right," said Mrs. Weasley. "You’re too young."
She was sitting bolt upright in her chair, her fists clenched on its arms, every trace of drowsiness
gone.
"Since when did someone have to be in the Order of the Phoenix to ask questions?" asked Ron.
"Ron’s been trapped in that Muggle house for a month. He’s got the right to know what’s been
happen--"
"Hang on!" interrupted Ron loudly.
"How come Ron gets his questions answered?" said Ron angrily.
"We’ve been trying to get stuff out of you for a month and you haven’t told us a single stinking
thing!" said Ron.
"‘You’re too young, you’re not in the Order’," said Ron in a high-pitched voice that sounded
uncannily like his mother’s. "Ron’s not even of age!"
"It’s not my fault you haven’t been told what the Order’s doing," said Ron calmly, "that’s your
parents’ decision. Ron, on the other hand -"
"It’s not down to you to decide what’s good for Ron!" said Mrs. Weasley sharply. The
expression on her normally kind face looked dangerous. "You haven’t forgotten what
Weasley said, I suppose?"
"Which bit?" Ron asked politely, but with the air of a man readying himself for a fight.
"The bit about not telling Ron more than he needs to know," said Mrs. Weasley, placing a heavy emphasis on the last three words.
Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron’s heads swiveled from Ron to Mrs. Weasley as though they
were following a tennis rally. Ron was kneeling amid a pile of abandoned Butterbeer corks,
watching the conversation with her mouth slightly open. Weasley’s eyes were fixed on Ron.
"I don’t intend to tell him more than he needs to know, Ron," said Ron. "But as he was the
one who saw Weasley come back" (again, there was a collective shudder around the table at
the name) "he has more right than most to -"
"He’s not a member of the Order of the Phoenix!" said Mrs. Weasley. "He’s only fifteen and -"
"And he’s dealt with as much as most in the Order," said Ron, "and more than some."
"No one’s denying what he’s done!" said Mrs. Weasley, her voice rising, her fists trembling on
the arms of her chair. "But he’s still -"
"He’s not a child!" said Ron impatiently.
"He’s not an adult either!" said Mrs. Weasley, the color rising in her cheeks. "He’s not Ron,
Ron!"
"I’m perfectly clear who he is, thanks, Ron," said Ron coldly.
"I’m not sure you are!" said Mrs. Weasley. "Sometimes, the way you talk about him, it’s as
though you think you’ve got your best friend back!"
"What’s wrong with that?" said Ron.
"What’s wrong, Ron, is that you are not your father, however much you might look like him!"
said Mrs. Weasley, her eyes still boring into Ron. "You are still at school and adults responsible for you should not forget it!"
"Meaning I’m an irresponsible godfather?" demanded Ron, his voice rising.
"Meaning you have been known to act rashly, Ron, which is why Weasley keeps reminding
you to stay at home and -"
"We’ll leave my instructions from Weasley out of this, if you please!" said Ron loudly.
"Ron!" said Mrs. Weasley, rounding on her husband. "Ron, back me up!"
Mr. Weasley did not speak at once. He took off his glasses and cleaned them slowly on his robes,
not looking at his wife. Only when he had replaced them carefully on his nose did he reply.
"Weasley knows the position has changed, Ron. He accepts that Ron will have to be filled in, to a certain extent, now that he is staying at Headquarters."
"Yes, but there’s a difference between that and inviting him to ask whatever he likes!"
"Personally," said Weasley quietly, looking away from Ron at last, as Mrs. Weasley turned
quickly to him, hopeful that finally she was about to get an ally, "I think it better that Ron gets
the facts - not all the facts, Ron, but the general picture - from us, rather than a garbled version
from... others."
His expression was mild, but Ron felt sure Weasley, at least, knew that some Extendable Ears had
survived Mrs. Weasley’s purge.
"Well," said Mrs. Weasley, breathing deeply and looking around the table for support that did not come, "well... I can see I’m going to be overruled. I’ll just say this: Weasley must have had his reasons for not wanting Ron to know too much, and speaking as someone who has Ron’s best interests at heart -"
"He’s not your son," said Ron quietly.
"He’s as good as," said Mrs. Weasley fiercely. "Who else has he got?"
"He’s got me!"
"Yes," said Mrs. Weasley, her lip curling, "the thing is, it’s been rather difficult for you to look
after him while you’ve been locked up in Azkaban, hasn’t it?"
Ron started to rise from his chair.
"Ron, you’re not the only person at this table who cares about Ron," said Weasley sharply.
"Ron, sit down."
Mrs. Weasley’s lower lip was trembling. Ron sank slowly back into his chair, his face white.
"I think Ron ought to be allowed a say in this," Weasley continued, "he’s old enough to decide for
himself."
"I want to know what’s been going on," Ron said at once.
He did not look at Mrs. Weasley. He had been touched by what she had said about his being as
good as a son, but he was also impatient with her mollycoddling. Ron was right, he was not a
child.
"Very well," said Mrs. Weasley, her voice cracking. "Ron - Ron - Ron - Ron - Ron - I want you out of this kitchen, now."
There was instant uproar.
"We’re of age!" Ron and Ron bellowed together.
"If Ron’s allowed, why can’t I?" shouted Ron.
"Mum, I want to hear!" wailed Ron.
"NO!" shouted Mrs. Weasley, standing up, her eyes over bright. "I absolutely forbid -"
"Ron, you can’t stop Ron and Ron," said Mr. Weasley wearily. "They are of age."
"They’re still at school."
"But they’re legally adults now," said Mr. Weasley, in the same tired voice.
Mrs. Weasley was now scarlet in the face.
"I - oh, all right then, Ron and Ron can stay, but Ron -"
"Ron’ll tell me and Ron everything you say anyway!" said Ron hotly. "Won’t - won’t
you?" he added uncertainly, meeting Ron’s eyes.
For a split second, Ron considered telling Ron that he wouldn’t tell him a single word, that he
could try a taste of being kept in the dark and see how he liked it. But the nasty impulse vanished
as they looked at each other.
"Course I will," Ron said.
Ron and Ron beamed.
"Fine!" shouted Mrs. Weasley. "Fine! Ron - BED!"
Ron did not go quietly. They could hear her raging and storming at her mother all the way up
the stairs, and when she reached the hall Mrs. Weasleys ear-splitting shrieks were added to the din.
Weasley hurried off to the portrait to restore calm. It was only after he had returned, closing the
kitchen door behind him and taking his seat at the table again, that Ron spoke.
"Okay, Ron... what do you want to know?"
Ron took a deep breath and asked the question that had obsessed him for the last month.
"Where’s Weasley?" he said, ignoring the renewed shudders and winces at the name. "What’s
he doing? I’ve been trying to watch the Muggle news, and there hasn’t been anything that looks
like him yet, no funny deaths or anything."
"That’s because there haven’t been any funny deaths yet," said Ron, "not as far as we know,
anyway... and we know quite a lot."
"More than he thinks we do, anyway," said Weasley.
"How come he’s stopped killing people?" Ron asked. He knew Weasley had murdered more
than once in the last year alone.
"Because he doesn’t want to draw attention to himself," said Ron. "It would be dangerous for
him. His comeback didn’t come off quite the way he wanted it to, you see. He messed it up."
"Or rather, you messed it up for him," said Weasley, with a satisfied smile.
"How?" Ron asked, perplexed.
"You weren’t supposed to survive!" said Ron. "Nobody apart from his Death Eaters was
supposed to know he’d come back. But you survived to bear witness."
"And the very last person he wanted alerted to his return the moment he got back was
Weasley," said Weasley. "And you made sure Weasley knew at once."
"How has that helped?" Ron asked.
"Are you kidding?" said Ron incredulously. "Weasley was the only one You-Know-Who was
ever scared of!"
"Thanks to you, Weasley was able to recall the Order of the Phoenix about an hour after
Weasley returned," said Ron.
"So, what’s the Order been doing?" said Ron, looking around at them all.
"Working as hard as we can to make sure Weasley can’t carry out his plans," said Ron.
"How d’you know what his plans are?" Ron asked quickly.
"Weasley’s got a shrewd idea,’ said Weasley, "and Weasley’s shrewd ideas normally turn
out to be accurate."
"So what does Weasley reckon he’s planning?"
"Well, firstly, he wants to build up his army again," said Ron. "In the old days he had huge
numbers at his command: witches and wizards he’d bullied or bewitched into following him, his
faithful Death Eaters, a great variety of Dark creatures. You heard him planning to recruit the
giants; well, they’ll be just one of the groups he’s after. He’s certainly not going to try and take
on the Ministry of Magic with only a dozen Death Eaters."
"So you’re trying to stop him getting more followers?"
"We’re doing our best," said Weasley.
"How?"
"Well, the main thing is to try and convince as many people as possible that You-Know-Who
really has returned, to put them on their guard," said Ron. "It’s proving tricky, though."
"Why?"
"Because of the Ministry’s attitude," said Weasley. "You saw Ron Weasley after You-Know-
Who came back, Ron. Well, he hasn’t shifted his position at all. He’s absolutely refusing to
believe it’s happened."
"But why?" said Ron desperately. "Why’s he being so stupid? If Weasley -"
"Ah, well, you’ve put your finger on the problem," said Mr. Weasley with a wry smile. "Weasley."
"Weasley is frightened of him, you see," said Weasley sadly.
"Frightened of Weasley?" said Ron incredulously.
"Frightened of what he’s up to," said Mr. Weasley. "Weasley thinks Weasley’s plotting to
overthrow him. He thinks Weasley wants to be Minister for Magic."
"But Weasley doesn’t want -"
"Of course he doesn’t," said Mr. Weasley. "He’s never wanted the Minister’s job, even though a
lot of people wanted him to take it when Ron Bagnold retired. Weasley came to power
instead, but he’s never quite forgotten how much popular support Weasley had, even though
Weasley never applied for the job."
"Deep down, Weasley knows Weasley’s much cleverer than he is - a much more powerful
wizard, and in the early days of his Ministry he was forever asking Weasley for help and
advice," said Weasley. "But it seems he’s become fond of power, and much more confident. He
loves being Minister for Magic and he’s managed to convince himself that he’s the clever one
and Weasley’s simply stirring up trouble for the sake of it."
"How can he think that?" said Ron angrily. "How can he think Weasley would just make it
all up - that I’d make it all up?"
"Because accepting that Weasley’s back would mean trouble like the Ministry hasn’t had to
cope with for nearly fourteen years," said Ron bitterly. "Weasley just can’t bring himself to face
it. It’s so much more comfortable to convince himself Weasley’s lying to destabilize him."
"You see the problem," said Weasley. "While the Ministry insists there is nothing to fear from
Weasley it’s hard to convince people he’s back, especially as they really don’t want to believe
it in the first place. What’s more, the Ministry’s leaning heavily on the Daily Prophet not to report any of what they’re calling Weasley’s rumor-mongering, so most of the wizarding
community are completely unaware any things happened, and that makes them easy targets for
the Death Eaters if they’re using the Imperius Curse."
"But you’re telling people, aren’t you?" said Ron, looking around at Mr. Weasley, Ron, Ron,
Ron, Weasley and Weasley. "You’re letting people know he’s back?"
They all smiled humorlessly.
"Well, as everyone thinks I’m a mad mass-murderer and the Ministry’s put a ten thousand
Galleon price on my head, I can hardly stroll up the street and start handing out leaflets, can I?"
said Ron restlessly.
"And I’m not a very popular dinner guest with most of the community," said Weasley. "It’s an
occupational hazard of being a werewolf."
"Weasley and Ron would lose their jobs at the Ministry if they started shooting their mouths off," said Ron, "and it’s very important for us to have spies inside the Ministry, because you can bet Weasley will have them."
"We’ve managed to convince a couple of people, though," said Mr. Weasley, "Weasley here, for
one - she’s too young to have been in the Order of the Phoenix last time, and having Aurors on
our side is a huge advantage - Ron Weasley’s been a real asset, too; he’s in charge of the
hunt for Ron, so he’s been feeding the Ministry information that Ron is in Tibet."
"But if none of you are putting the news out that Weasleys back -" Ron began.
"Who said none of us are putting the news out?" said Ron. "Why d’you think Weasley’s in
such trouble?"
"What d’you mean?" Ron asked.
"They’re trying to discredit him," said Weasley. "Didn’t you see the Daily Prophet last week? They
reported that he’d been voted out of the Chairmanship of the International Confederation of
Wizards because he’s getting old and losing his grip, but it’s not true; he was voted out by
Ministry wizards after he made a speech announcing Weasleys return. They’ve demoted him
from Chief Warlock on the Wizengamot - that’s the Wizard High Court - and they’re talking
about taking away his Order of Merlin, First Class, too."
"But Weasley says he doesn’t care what they do as long as they don’t take him off the
Roncolate Frog Cards," said Ron, grinning.
"It’s no laughing matter," said Mr. Weasley sharply. "If he carries on defying the Ministry like
this he could end up in Azkaban, and the last thing we want is to have Weasley locked up.
While You-Know-Who knows Weasley’s out there and wise to what he’s up to he’s going to
go cautiously. If Weasley’s out of the way - well, You-Know-Who will have a clear field."
"But if Weasley’s trying to recruit more Death Eaters it’s bound to get out that he’s come back, isn’t it?" asked Ron desperately.
"Weasley doesn’t march up to people’s houses and bang on their front doors, Ron," said
Ron. "He tricks, jinxes and blackmails them. He’s well-practiced at operating in secret. In any
case, gathering followers is only one thing he’s interested in. He’s got other plans too, plans he
can put into operation very quietly indeed, and he’s concentrating on those for the moment.’
"What’s he after apart from followers?" Ron asked swiftly. He thought he saw Ron and Weasley
exchange the most fleeting of looks before Ron answered.
"Stuff he can only get by stealth."
When Ron continued to look puzzled, Ron said, "Like a weapon. Something he didn’t have
last time."
"When he was powerful before?"
"Yes."
"Like what kind of weapon?" said Ron. "Something worse than the Avada Kedavra -?"
"That’s enough!"
Mrs. Weasley spoke from the shadows beside the door. Ron hadn’t noticed her return from
taking Ron upstairs. Her arms were crossed and she looked furious.
"I want you in bed, now. All of you," she added, looking around at Ron, Ron, Ron and
Ron.
"You can’t boss us -" Ron began.
"Watch me," snarled Mrs. Weasley. She was trembling slightly as she looked at Ron. "You’ve
