encouragement, chased the second one away from his cousin. And that that is what happened,"
Mrs. Weasley finished, somewhat lamely.
Ron Weasley looked down at Mrs. Weasley in silence. Weasley was not looking at her at all, but
fidgeting with his papers. Finally, he raised his eyes and said, rather aggressively, "that’s what
you saw, is it?"
"That is what happened," Mrs. Weasley repeated.
"Very well," said Weasley. "You may go."
Mrs. Weasley cast a frightened look from Weasley to Weasley, then got up and shuffled off
towards the door. Ron heard it thud shut behind her.
"Not a very convincing witness," said Weasley loftily.
"Oh, I don’t know," said Ron Weasley, in her booming voice. "She certainly described the effects of a Dementor attack very accurately. And I can’t imagine why she would say they were there if they weren’t."
"But Dementors wandering into a Muggle suburb and just happening to come across a wizard?"
snorted Weasley. "The odds on that must be very, very long. Even Weasley wouldn’t have bet -"
"Oh, I don’t think any of us believe the Dementors were there by coincidence," said Weasley
lightly.
The witch sitting to the right of Weasley, with her face in shadow, moved slightly but everyone
else was quite still and silent.
"And what is that supposed to mean?" Weasley asked icily.
"It means that I think they were ordered there," said Weasley.
"I think we might have a record of it if someone had ordered a pair of Dementors to go strolling
through Little Whanging!" barked Weasley.
"Not if the Dementors are taking orders from someone other than the Ministry of Magic these
days," said Weasley calmly. "I have already given you my views on this matter, Ron."
"Yes, you have"‘ said Weasley forcefully, "and I have no reason to believe that your views are
anything other than bilge, Weasley. The Dementors remain in place in Azkaban and are
doing everything we ask them to."
"Then," said Weasley, quietly but clearly, "we must ask ourselves why somebody within the
Ministry ordered a pair of Dementors into that alleyway on the second of August."
In the complete silence that greeted these words, the witch to the right of Weasley leaned forwards
so that Ron saw her for the first time.
He thought she looked just like a large, pale toad. She was rather squat with a broad, flabby face,
as little neck as Uncle Ron and a very wide, slack mouth. Her eyes were large, round and
slightly bulging. Even the little black velvet bow perched on top of her short curly hair put him
in mind of a large fly she was about to catch on a long sticky tongue.
"The Chair recognizes Ron  Weasley, Senior Undersecretary to the Minister," said
Weasley.
The witch spoke in a fluttery, girlish, high-pitched voice that took Ron aback; he had been
expecting a croak.
"I’m sure I must have misunderstood you, Professor Weasley," she said, with a simper that left her big, round eyes as cold as ever. "So silly of me. But it sounded for a teensy moment as though you were suggesting that the Ministry of Magic had ordered an attack on this boy!"
She gave a silvery laugh that made the hairs on the back of Ron’s neck stand up. A few other
members of the Wizengamot laughed with her. It could not have been plainer that not one of
them was really amused.
"If it is true that the Dementors are taking orders only from the Ministry of Magic, and it is also
true that two Dementors attacked Ron and his cousin a week ago, then it follows logically that
somebody at the Ministry might have ordered the attacks," said Weasley politely. "Of course,
these particular Dementors may have been outside Ministry control -"
"There are no Dementors outside Ministry control!" snapped Weasley, who had turned brick red.
Weasley inclined his head in a little bow.
"Then undoubtedly the Ministry will be making a full inquiry into why two Dementors were so
very far from Azkaban and why they attacked without authorization."
"It is not for you to decide what the Ministry of Magic does or does not do, Weasley!"
snapped Weasley, now a shade of magenta of which Uncle Ron would have been proud.
"Of course it isn’t," said Weasley mildly. "I was merely expressing my confidence that this
matter will not go uninvestigated."
He glanced at Ron Weasley, who readjusted her monocle and stared back at him, frowning
slightly.
"I would remind everybody that the behavior of these Dementors, if indeed they are not
figments of this boy’s imagination, is not the subject of this hearing!" said Weasley. "We are here to examine Ron Weasley’s offences under the Decree for the Reasonable Restriction of Underage
Sorcery!"
"Of course we are," said Weasley, "but the presence of Dementors in that alleyway is highly
relevant. Clause Seven of the Decree states that magic may be used before Muggles in
exceptional circumstances, and as those exceptional circumstances include situations which
threaten the life of the wizard or witch him - or herself, or any witches, wizards or Muggles
present at the time of the -"
"We are familiar with Clause Seven, thank you very much!" snarled Weasley.
"Of course you are," said Weasley courteously. "Then we are in agreement that Ron’s use of the Patronus Charm in these circumstances falls precisely into the category of exceptional
circumstances the clause describes?"
"If there were Dementors, which I doubt."
"You have heard it from an eyewitness," Weasley interrupted. "If you still doubt her truthfulness, call her back, question her again. I am sure she would not object."
"I - that - not -" blustered Weasley, fiddling with the papers before him. "It’s - I want this over with
today, Weasley!"
"But naturally, you would not care how many times you heard from a witness, if the alternative
was a serious miscarriage of justice," said Weasley.
"Serious miscarriage, my hat!" said Weasley at the top of his voice. "Have you ever bothered to tot
up the number of cock-and-bull stories this boy has come out with, Weasley, while trying to
cover up his flagrant misuse of magic out of school? I suppose you’ve forgotten the Hover
Charm he used three years ago -"
"That wasn’t me, it was a house-elf!" said Ron.
"YOU SEE" roared Weasley, gesturing flamboyantly in Ron’s direction. "A house-elf! In a
Muggle house! I ask you."
"The house-elf in question is currently in the employ of Hogwarts School," said Weasley. "I
can summon him here in an instant to give evidence if you wish."
"I - not - I haven’t got time to listen to house-elves! Anyway, that’s not the only - he blew up his
aunt, for God’s sake!" Weasley shouted, banging his fist on the judge’s bench and upsetting a bottle of ink.
"And you very kindly did not press charges on that occasion, accepting, I presume, that even the
best wizards cannot always control their emotions," said Weasley calmly, as Weasley attempted to scrub the ink off his notes.
"And I haven’t even started on what he gets up to at school."
"But, as the Ministry has no authority to punish Hogwarts students for misdemeanors at school,
Ron’s behavior there is not relevant to this hearing," said Weasley, as politely as ever, but
now with a suggestion of coolness behind his words.
"Oho!" said Weasley. "Not our business what he does at school, eh? You think so?"
"The Ministry does not have the power to expel Hogwarts students, Ron, as I reminded you
on the night of the second of August," said Weasley. "Nor does it have the right to confiscate wands until charges have been successfully proven; again, as I reminded you on the night of the second of August. In your admirable haste to ensure that the law is upheld, you appear, inadvertently I am sure, to have overlooked a few laws yourself."
"Laws can be changed," said Weasley savagely.
"Of course they can," said Weasley, inclining his head. "And you certainly seem to be making many changes, Ron. Why, in the few short weeks since I was asked to leave the
Wizengamot, it has already become the practice to hold a full criminal trial to deal with a simple
matter of underage magic!"
A few of the wizards above them shifted uncomfortably in their seats. Weasley turned a slightly
deeper shade of puce. The toadlike witch on his right, however, merely gazed at Weasley,
her face quite expressionless.
"As far as I am aware," Weasley continued, "there is no law yet in place that says this court’s
job is to punish Ron for every bit of magic he has ever performed. He has been charged with a
specific offence and he has presented his defense. All he and I can do now is to await your
verdict."
Weasley put his fingertips together again and said no more. Weasley glared at him, evidently
incensed. Ron glanced sideways at Weasley, seeking reassurance; he was not at all sure that
Weasley was right in telling the Wizengamot, in effect, that it was about time they made a
decision. Again, however, Weasley seemed oblivious to Ron’s attempt to catch his eye. He
continued to look up at the benches where the entire Wizengamot had fallen into urgent,
whispered conversations.
Ron looked at his feet. His heart, which seemed to have swollen to an unnatural size, was
thumping loudly under his ribs. He had expected the hearing to last longer than this. He was not
at all sure that he had made a good impression. He had not really said very much. He ought to
have explained more fully about the Dementors, about how he had fallen over, about how both
he and Ron had nearly been kissed...
Twice he looked up at Weasley and opened his mouth to speak, but his swollen heart was now
constricting his air passages and both times he merely took a deep breath and looked back down
at his shoes.
Then the whispering stopped. Ron wanted to look up at the judges, but found that it was really
much, much easier to keep examining his laces.
"Those in favor of clearing the witness of all charges?" said Ron Weasleys booming voice.
Ron’s head jerked upwards. There were hands in the air, many of them... more than half!
Breathing very fast, he tried to count, but before he could finish, Ron Weasley had said, "And
those in favor of conviction?"
Weasley raised his hand; so did half a dozen others, including the witch on his right and the
heavily-moustached wizard and the frizzy-haired witch in the second row.
Weasley glanced around at them all, looking as though there was something large stuck in his
throat, then lowered his own hand. He took two deep breaths and said, in a voice distorted by
suppressed rage, "Very well, very well... cleared of all charges."
"Excellent," said Weasley briskly, springing to his feet, pulling out his wand and causing the
two chintz armchairs to vanish. "Well, I must be getting along. Good-day to you all." And without looking once at Ron, he swept from the dungeon.
CHAPTER NINE
The Woes of Mrs. Weasley
Weasley’s abrupt departure took Ron completely by surprise. He remained sitting where he
was in the chained chair, struggling with his feelings of shock and relief. The Wizengamot were
all getting to their feet, talking, gathering up their papers and packing them away. Ron stood
up. Nobody seemed to be paying him the slightest bit of attention, except the toadlike witch on
Weasley’s right, who was now gazing down at him instead of at Weasley. Ignoring her, he tried
to catch Weasley’s eye, or Ron Weasley’s, wanting to ask whether he was free to go, but Weasley
seemed quite determined not to notice Ron, and Ron Weasley was busy with her briefcase, so
he took a few tentative steps towards the exit and, when nobody called him back, broke into a
very fast walk.
He took the last few steps at a run, wrenched open the door and almost collided with Mr.
Weasley, who was standing right outside, looking pale and apprehensive.
"Weasley didn’t say -"
"Cleared," Ron said, pulling the door closed behind him, "of all charges!"
Beaming, Mr. Weasley seized Ron by the shoulders.
"Ron, that’s wonderful! Well, of course, they couldn’t have found you guilty, not on the
evidence, but even so, I can’t pretend I wasn’t -"
But Mr. Weasley broke off, because the courtroom door had just opened again. The Wizengamot
were filing out.
"Merlin’s beard!" exclaimed Mr. Weasley wonderingly, pulling Ron aside to let them all pass.
"You were tried by the full court?"
"I think so," said Ron quietly.
One or two of the wizards nodded to Ron as they passed and a few, including Ron Weasley,
said, "Morning, Ron," to Mr. Weasley, but most averted their eyes. Ron Weasley and the
toadlike witch were almost the last to leave the dungeon. Weasley acted as though Mr. Weasley
and Ron were part of the wall, but again, the witch looked almost appraisingly at Ron as she
passed. Last of all to pass was Ron. Like Weasley, he completely ignored his father and Ron; he
marched past clutching a large roll of parchment and a handful of spare quills, his back rigid and
his nose in the air. The lines around Mr. Weasleys mouth tightened slightly, but other than this
he gave no sign that he had seen his third son.
"I’m going to take you straight back so you can tell the others the good news," he said, beckoning Ron forwards as Ron’s heels disappeared up the steps to Level Nine. "I’ll drop you off on the way to that toilet in Bethnal Green. Come on..."
"So, what will you have to do about the toilet?" Ron asked, grinning. Everything suddenly
seemed five times funnier than usual. It was starting to sink in: he was cleared, he was going back to Hogwarts.
"Oh, it’s a simple enough anti-jinx," said Mr. Weasley as they mounted the stairs, "but it’s not so
much having to repair the damage, it’s more the attitude behind the vandalism, Ron. Mugglebaiting might strike some wizards as funny, but it’s an expression of something much deeper and nastier, and I for one -"
Mr. Weasley broke off in mid-sentence. They had just reached the ninth-level corridor and
Ron Weasley was standing a few feet away from them, talking quietly to a tall man with sleek
blond hair and a pointed, pale face.
The second man turned at the sound of their footsteps. He, too, broke off in mid-conversation,
his cold grey eyes narrowed and fixed upon Ron’s face.
"Well, well, well... Patronus Weasley," said Ron Weasley coolly.
Ron felt winded, as though he had just walked into something solid. He had last seen those cold
grey eyes through slits in a Death Eaters hood, and last heard that man’s voice jeering in a dark
graveyard while Lord Weasley tortured him. Ron could not believe that Ron Weasley dared
look him in the face; he could not believe that he was here, in the Ministry of Magic, or that
Ron Weasley was talking to him, when Ron had told Weasley mere weeks ago that Weasley
was a Death Eater.
"The Minister was just telling me about your lucky escape, Weasley," drawled Mr. Weasley. "Quite
astonishing, the way you continue to wriggle out of very tight holes... snakelike, in fact."
Mr. Weasley gripped Ron’s shoulder in warning.
"Yeah," said Ron, "yeah, I’m good at escaping."
Ron Weasley raised his eyes to Mr. Weasley’s face.
"And Ron Weasley too! What are you doing here, Ron?"
"I work here," said Mr. Weasley curtly.
"Not here, surely?" said Mr. Weasley, raising his eye brows and glancing towards the door over
Mr. Weasley’s shoulder. "I thought you were up on the second floor... don’t you do something
that involves sneaking Muggle artifacts home and bewitching them?"
"No," Mr. Weasley snapped, his fingers now biting into Ron’s shoulder.
"What are you doing here, anyway?" Ron asked Ron Weasley.
"I don’t think private matters between myself and the Minister are any concern of yours, Weasley,"
said Weasley, smoothing the front of his robes. Ron distinctly heard the gentle clinking of what
sounded like a full pocket of gold. "Really, just because you are Weasley’s favorite boy, you must not expect the same indulgence from the rest of us... shall we go up to your office, then, Minister?"
"Certainly" said Weasley, turning his back on Ron and Mr. Weasley. "This way, Ron."
They strode off together, talking in low voices. Mr. Weasley did not let go of Ron’s shoulder
until they had disappeared into the lift.
"Why wasn’t he waiting outside Weasley’s office if they’ve got business to do together?" Ron
burst out furiously. "What was he doing down here?"
"Trying to sneak down to the courtroom, if you ask me," said Mr. Weasley, looking extremely
agitated and glancing over his shoulder as though making sure they could not be overheard.
"Trying to find out whether you’d been expelled or not. I’ll leave a note for Weasley when I
drop you off, he ought to know Weasleys been talking to Weasley again."
"What private business have they got together, anyway?"
"Gold, I expect," said Mr. Weasley angrily. "Weasley’s been giving generously to all sorts of
things for years... gets him in with the right people... then he can ask favors... delay laws he
doesn’t want passed... oh, he’s very well-connected, Ron Weasley."
The lift arrived; it was empty except for a flock of memos that flapped around Mr. Weasley’s
head as he pressed the button for the Atrium and the doors clanged shut. He waved them away
irritably.
"Mr. Weasley" said Ron slowly, "if Weasley is meeting Death Eaters like Weasley, if he’s seeing
them alone, how do we know they haven’t put the Imperius Curse on him?"
"Don’t think it hasn’t occurred to us, Ron" said Mr. Weasley quietly. "But Weasley thinks
Weasley is acting of his own accord at the moment - which, as Weasley says, is not a lot of
comfort. Best not talk about it any more just now, Ron."
The doors slid open and they stepped out into the now almost-deserted Atrium. Eric the
watchwizard was hidden behind his Daily Prophet again. They had walked straight past the
golden fountain before Ron remembered.
"Wait..." he told Mr. Weasley, and, pulling his moneybag from his pocket, he turned back to the
fountain.
He looked up into the handsome wizard’s face, but up close Ron thought he looked rather weak
and foolish. The witch was wearing a vapid smile like a beauty contestant, and from what Ron
knew of goblins and centaurs, they were most unlikely to be caught staring so soppily at humans
of any description. Only the house-elf’s attitude of creeping servility looked convincing. With a
grin at the thought of what Ron would say if she could see the statue of the elf, Ron
turned his moneybag upside-down and emptied not just ten Galleons, but the whole contents into
the pool.
"I knew it!" yelled Ron, punching the air. "You always get away with stuff!"
"They were bound to clear you," said Ron, who had looked positively faint with anxiety
when Ron had entered the kitchen and was now holding a shaking hand over her eyes, "there
was no case against you, none at all."
"Everyone seems quite relieved, though, considering you all knew I’d get off," said Ron,
smiling.
Mrs. Weasley was wiping her face on her apron, and Ron, Ron and Ron were doing a kind
of war dance to a chant that went: "He got off, he got off, he got off..."
"That’s enough! Settle down!" shouted Mr. Weasley, though he too was smiling. "Listen, Ron,
Ron Weasley was at the Ministry -"
"What?" said Ron sharply.
"He got off, he got off, he got off..."
"Be quiet, you three! Yes, we saw him talking to Weasley on Level Nine, then they went up to
Weasley’s office together. Weasley ought to know."
"Absolutely," said Ron. "We’ll tell him, don’t worry."
"Well, I’d better get going, there’s a vomiting toilet waiting for me in Bethnal Green. Ron, I’ll
be late, I’m covering for Weasley, but Ron might be dropping in for dinner -"
"He got off, he got off, he got off..."
"That’s enough - Ron - Ron - Ron!" said Mrs. Weasley, as Mr. Weasley left the kitchen.
"Ron, dear, come and sit down, have some lunch, you hardly ate breakfast."
Ron and Ron sat themselves down opposite him, looking happier than they had done since
he had first arrived at Grimmauld Place, and Ron’s feeling of giddy relief, which had been
somewhat dented by his encounter with Ron Weasley, swelled again. The gloomy house
seemed warmer and more welcoming all of a sudden; even Ron looked less ugly as he
poked his snoutlike nose into the kitchen to investigate the source of all the noise.
"Course, once Weasley turned up on your side, there was no way they were going to convict
you," said Ron happily, now dishing great mounds of mashed potatoes on to everyone’s plates.
"Yeah, he swung it for me," said Ron. He felt it would sound highly ungrateful, not to mention
childish, to say, "I wish he’d talked to me, though. Or even looked at me."
And as he thought this, the scar on his forehead burned so badly that he clapped his hand to it.
"What’s up?" said Ron, looking alarmed.
"Scar," Ron mumbled. "But it’s nothing... it happens all the time now..."
None of the others had noticed a thing; all of them were now helping themselves to food while
gloating over Ron’s narrow escape; Ron, Ron and Ron were still singing. Ron
looked rather anxious, but before she could say anything, Ron had said happily, "I bet
Weasley turns up this evening, to celebrate with us, you know."
"I don’t think he’ll be able to, Ron," said Mrs. Weasley, setting a huge plate of roast chicken
down in front of Ron. "He’s really very busy at the moment."
"HE GOT OFF, HE GOT OFF, HE GOT OFF"
"SHUT UP!" roared Mrs. Weasley.
Over the next few days Ron could not help noticing that there was one person within number
twelve, Grimmauld Place, who did not seem wholly overjoyed that he would be returning to
Hogwarts. Ron had put up a very good show of happiness on first hearing the news, wringing
Ron’s hand and beaming just like the rest of them. Soon, however, he was moodier and surlier
than before, talking less to everybody, even Ron, and spending increasing amounts of time shut
up in his mother’s room with Ron.
"Don’t you go feeling guilty!" said Ron sternly, after Ron had confided some of his
feelings to her and Ron while they scrubbed out a mouldy cupboard on the third floor a few days
later. "You belong at Hogwarts and Ron knows it. Personally, I think he’s being selfish."
"That’s a bit harsh, Ron," said Ron, frowning as he attempted to prize off a bit of mould
that had attached itself firmly to his finger, "you wouldn’t want to be stuck inside this house
without any company."
"He’ll have company!" said Ron. "It’s Headquarters to the Order of the Phoenix, isn’t it?
He just got his hopes up that Ron would be coming to live here with him."
"I don’t think that’s true" said Ron, wringing out his cloth. "He wouldn’t give me a straight
answer when I asked him if I could."
"He just didn’t want to get his own hopes up even more," said Ron wisely. "And he
probably felt a bit guilty himself, because I think a part of him was really hoping you’d be
expelled. Then you’d both be outcasts together."
"Come off it!" said Ron and Ron together, but Ron merely shrugged.
"Suit yourselves. But I sometimes think Ron’s mums right and Ron gets confused about whether you’re you or your father, Ron."
"So you think he’s touched in the head?" said Ron heatedly.
"No, I just think he’s been very lonely for a long time," said Ron simply.
At this point, Mrs. Weasley entered the bedroom behind them.
"Still not finished?" she said, poking her head into the cupboard.
"I thought you might be here to tell us to have a break" said Ron bitterly. "D’you know how
much mould we’ve got rid of since we arrived here?"
"You were so keen to help the Order," said Mrs. Weasley, "you can do your bit by making
Headquarters fit to live in."
"I feel like a house-elf," grumbled Ron.
"Well, now you understand what dreadful lives they lead, perhaps you’ll be a bit more active in
SPEW!" said Ron hopefully, as Mrs. Weasley left them to it. "You know, maybe it
wouldn’t be a bad idea to show people exactly how horrible it is to clean all the time - we could
do a sponsored scrub of Weasley common room, all proceeds to SPEW, it would raise
awareness as well as funds."
"I’ll sponsor you to shut up about SPEW," Ron muttered irritably, but only so Ron could hear
him.
Ron found himself daydreaming about Hogwarts more and more as the end of the holidays
approached; he could not wait to see Weasley again, to play Quidditch, even to stroll across the
vegetable patches to the Herbology greenhouses; it would be a treat just to leave this dusty,
musty house, where half of the cupboards were still bolted shut and Ron wheezed insults
out of the shadows as you passed, though Ron was careful not to say any of this within earshot
of Ron.
The fact was that living at the Headquarters of the anti-Weasley movement was not nearly as
interesting or exciting as Ron would have expected before he’d experienced it. Though
members of the Order of the Phoenix came and went regularly, sometimes staying for meals,
sometimes only for a few minutes of whispered conversation, Mrs. Weasley made sure that
Ron and the others were kept well out of earshot (whether Extendable or normal) and nobody,
not even Ron, seemed to feel that Ron needed to know anything more than he had heard on
the night of his arrival.
On the very last day of the holidays Ron was sweeping up Rons owl droppings from the top
of the wardrobe when Ron entered their bedroom carrying a couple of envelopes.
"Booklists have arrived," he said, throwing one of the envelopes up to Ron, who was standing
on a chair. "About time, I thought they’d forgotten, they usually come much earlier than this..."
Ron swept the last of the droppings into a rubbish bag and threw the bag over Ron’s head into
the wastepaper basket in the corner, which swallowed it and belched loudly. He then opened his
letter. It contained two pieces of parchment: one the usual reminder that term started on the first
of September; the other telling him which books he would need for the coming year.
"Only two new ones," he said, reading the list, "The Rondard Book of Spells, Grade 5, by
Miranda Goshawk, and Defensive Magical Theory, by Wilbert Slinkhard."
Crack.
Ron and Ron Apparated right beside Ron. He was so used to them doing this by now that
he didn’t even fall off his chair.
"We were just wondering who assigned the Slinkhard book," said Ron conversationally.
"Because it means Weasley’s found a new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher," said
Ron.
"And about time too," said Ron.
"What d’you mean?" Ron asked, jumping down beside them.
"Well, we overheard Mum and Dad talking on the Extendable Ears a few weeks back," Ron told
Ron, "and from what they were saying, Weasley was having real trouble finding anyone to
do the job this year."
"Not surprising, is it, when you look at what’s happened to the last four?" said Ron.
"One sacked, one dead, one’s memory removed and one locked in a trunk for nine months," said
Ron, counting them off on his fingers. "Yeah, I see what you mean."
"What’s up with you, Ron?" asked Ron.
Ron did not answer. Ron looked round. Ron was standing very still with his mouth slightly
open, gaping at his letter from Hogwarts.
"What’s the matter?" said Ron impatiently, moving around Ron to look over his shoulder at the
parchment.
Ron’s mouth fell open, too.
"Prefect?" he said, staring incredulously at the letter. "Prefect?"
Ron leapt forwards, seized the envelope in Ron’s other hand and turned it upside-down. Ron
saw something scarlet and gold fall into Ron’s palm.
"No way," said Ron in a hushed voice.
"There’s been a mistake," said Ron, snatching the letter out of Ron’s grasp and holding it up to
the light as though checking for a watermark. "No one in their right mind would make Ron a
prefect."
The twins’ heads turned in unison and both of them stared at Ron.
"We thought you were a cert!" said Ron, in a tone that suggested Ron had tricked them in some way.
"We thought Weasley was bound to pick you!" said Ron indignantly.
"Winning the Triwizard and everything!" said Ron.
"I suppose all the mad stuff must’ve counted against him," said Ron to Ron.
"Yeah," said Ron slowly. "Yeah, you’ve caused too much trouble, mate. Well, at least one of
you’s got their priorities right."
He strode over to Ron and clapped him on the back while giving Ron a scathing look.
"Prefect... ickle Ronnie the Prefect."
"Oh, Mum’s going to be revolting," groaned Ron, thrusting the prefect badge back at Ron as
though it might contaminate him.
Ron, who still had not said a word, took the badge, stared at it for a moment, then held it out to
Ron as though asking mutely for confirmation that it was genuine. Ron took it. A large P was
superimposed on the Weasley lion. He had seen a badge just like this on Ron’s chest on his
very first day at Hogwarts.
The door banged open. Ron came tearing into the room, her cheeks flushed and her hair
flying. There was an envelope in her hand.
"Did you - did you get -?"
She spotted the badge in Ron’s hand and let out a shriek.
"I knew it!’ she said excitedly, brandishing her letter. "Me too, Ron, me too!"
"No," said Ron quickly, pushing the badge back into Ron’s hand. "It’s Ron, not me."
"It - what?"
"Ron’s prefect, not me," Ron said.
"Ron?" said Ron, her jaw dropping. "But... are you sure? I mean -"
She turned red as Ron looked round at her with a defiant expression on his face.
"It’s my name on the letter," he said.
"I..." said Ron, looking thoroughly bewildered. "I... well... wow! Well done, Ron! That’s
really -"
"Unexpected," said Ron, nodding.
"No," said Ron, blushing harder than ever, "no it’s not... Ron’s done loads of... he’s
really..."
The door behind her opened a little wider and Mrs. Weasley backed into the room carrying a pile
of freshly laundered robes.
"Ron said the booklists had come at last," she said, glancing around at all the envelopes as she
made her way over to the bed and started sorting the robes into two piles. "If you give them to
me I’ll take them over to Diagon Alley this afternoon and get your books while you’re packing.
Ron, I’ll have to get you more pajamas, these are at least six inches too short, I can’t believe how
fast you’re growing... what color would you like?"
"Get him red and gold to match his badge," said Ron, smirking.
"Match his what?" said Mrs. Weasley absently, rolling up a pair of maroon socks and placing
them on Ron’s pile.
"His badge," said Ron, with the air of getting the worst over quickly. "His lovely shiny
new prefect’s badge."
Ron’s words took a moment to penetrate Mrs. Weasley’s preoccupation with pajamas.
"His... but... Ron, you’re not...?"
Ron held up his badge.
Mrs. Weasley let out a shriek just like Ron’s.
"I don’t believe it! I don’t believe it! Oh, Ron, how wonderful! A prefect! That’s everyone in the
family!"
"What are Ron and I, next-door neighbors?" said Ron indignantly, as his mother pushed him
aside and flung her arms around her youngest son.
"Wait until your father hears! Ron, I’m so proud of you, what wonderful news, you could end up
Head Boy just like Ron and Ron, it’s the first step! Oh, what a thing to happen in the middle of
all this worry, I’m just thrilled, oh, Ronnie --"
Ron and Ron were both making loud retching noises behind her back but Mrs. Weasley did
not notice; arms tight around Ron’s neck, she was kissing him all over his face, which had turned
a brighter scarlet than his badge.
"Mum... don’t... Mum, get a grip..." he muttered, trying to push her away.
She let go of him and said breathlessly, "Well, what will it be? We gave Ron an owl, but you’ve already got one, of course."
"W-what do you mean?" said Ron, looking as though he did not dare believe his ears.
"You’ve got to have a reward for this!" said Mrs. Weasley fondly. "How about a nice new set of
dress robes?"
"We’ve already bought him some," said Ron sourly, who looked as though he sincerely regretted this generosity.
"Or a new cauldron, Ron’s old one’s rusting through, or a new rat, you always liked Ron"
"Mum," said Ron hopefully, "can I have a new broom?"
Mrs. Weasley’s face fell slightly; broomsticks were expensive.
"Not a really good one!" Ron hastened to add. "Just - just a new one for a change..."
Mrs. Weasley hesitated, then smiled.
"Of course you can... well, I’d better get going if I’ve got a broom to buy too. I’ll see you all
later... little Ronnie, a prefect! And don’t forget to pack your trunks... a prefect... oh, I’m all of
a dither!"
She gave Ron yet another kiss on the cheek, sniffed loudly, and bustled from the room.
Ron and Ron exchanged looks.
"You don’t mind if we don’t kiss you, do you, Ron?" said Ron in a falsely anxious voice.
"We could curtsey, if you like," said Ron.
"Oh, shut up," said Ron, scowling at them.
"Or what?" said Ron, an evil grin spreading across his face. "Going to put us in detention?"
"I’d love to see him try," sniggered Ron.
"He could if you don’t watch out!" said Ron angrily.
Ron and Ron burst out laughing, and Ron muttered, "Drop it, Ron."
"We’re going to have to watch our step, Ron," said Ron, pretending to tremble, "with these
two on our case..."
"Yeah, it looks like our law-breaking days are finally over," said Ron, shaking his head.
And with another loud crack, the twins Disapparated.
"Those two!" said Ron furiously, staring up at the ceiling, through which they could now
hear Ron and Ron roaring with laughter in the room upstairs. "Don’t pay any attention to
them, Ron, they’re only jealous!"
"I don’t think they are," said Ron doubtfully, also looking up at the ceiling. "They’ve always said only prats become prefects... still," he added on a happier note, "they’ve never had new brooms! I wish I could go with Mum and choose... she’ll never be able to afford a Nimbus, but there’s the new Cleansweep out, that’d be great... yeah, I think I’ll go and tell her I like the Cleansweep, just so she knows."
He dashed from the room, leaving Ron and Ron alone.
For some reason, Ron found he did not want to look at Ron. He turned to his bed, picked
up the pile of clean robes Mrs. Weasley had laid on it and crossed the room to his trunk.
"Ron?" said Ron tentatively.
"Well done, Ron," said Ron, so heartily it did not sound like his voice at all, and, still not
looking at her, "brilliant. Prefect. Great."
"Thanks," said Ron. "Erm - Ron - could I borrow Ron so I can tell Mum and Dad?
They’ll be really pleased - I mean prefect is something they can understand."
"Yeah, no problem," said Ron, still in the horrible hearty voice that did not belong to him.
"Take her!"
He leaned over his trunk, laid the robes on the bottom of it and pretended to be rummaging for
something while Ron crossed to the wardrobe and called Ron down. A few moments
passed; Ron heard the door close but remained bent double, listening; the only sounds he could
hear were the blank picture on the wall sniggering again and the wastepaper basket in the corner
coughing up the owl droppings.
He straightened up and looked behind him. Ron had left and Ron had gone. Ron
hurried across the room, closed the door, then returned slowly to his bed and sank on to it, gazing
unseeingly at the foot of the wardrobe.
He had forgotten completely about prefects being chosen in the fifth year. He had been too
anxious about the possibility of being expelled to spare a thought for the fact that badges must be
winging their way towards certain people. But if he had remembered... if he had thought about
it... what would he have expected?
Not this, said a small and truthful voice inside his head.
Ron screwed up his face and buried it in his hands. He could not lie to himself; if he had known
the prefect badge was on its way, he would have expected it to come to him, not Ron. Did this
make him as arrogant as Ron Weasley? Did he think himself superior to everyone else? Did he
really believe he was better than Ron?
No, said the small voice defiantly.
Was that true? Ron wondered, anxiously probing his own feelings.
I’m better at Quidditch, said the voice. But I’m not better at anything else.
That was definitely true, Ron thought; he was no better than Ron in lessons. But what about
outside lessons? What about those adventures he, Ron and Ron had had together since
starting at Hogwarts, often risking much worse than expulsion?
Well, Ron and Ron were with me most of the time, said the voice in Ron’s head.
Not all the time, though, Ron argued with himself. They didn’t fight Weasley with me. They
didn’t take on Weasley and the Basilisk. They didn’t get rid of all those Dementors the night Ron
escaped. They weren’t in that graveyard with me, the night Weasley returned...
And the same feeling of ill-usage that had overwhelmed him on the night he had arrived rose
again. I’ve definitely done more, Ron thought indignantly. I’ve done more than either of them!
But maybe, said the small voice fairly, maybe Weasley doesn’t choose prefects because
they’ve got themselves into a load of dangerous situations... maybe he chooses them for other
reasons... Ron must have something you don’t...
Ron opened his eyes and stared through his fingers at the wardrobe’s clawed feet, remembering
what Ron had said: "No one in their right mind would make Ron a prefect..."
Ron gave a small snort of laughter. A second later he felt sickened with himself.
Ron had not asked Weasley to give him the prefect badge. This was not Ron’s fault. Was he,
Ron, Ron’s best friend in the world, going to sulk because he didn’t have a badge, laugh with
the twins behind Ron’s back, ruin this for Ron when, for the first time, he had beaten Ron at
something?
At this point Ron heard Ron’s footsteps on the stairs again. He stood up, straightened his
glasses, and hitched a grin on to his face as Ron bounded back through the door.
"Just caught her!" he said happily. "She says she’ll get the Cleansweep if she can."
"Cool," Ron said, and he was relieved to hear that his voice had stopped sounding hearty.
"Listen - Ron - well done, mate."
The smile faded off Ron’s face.
"I never thought it would be me!" he said, shaking his head. "I thought it would be you!"
"Nah, I’ve caused too much trouble," Ron said, echoing Ron.
"Yeah," said Ron, "yeah, I suppose... well, we’d better get our trunks packed, hadn’t we?"
It was odd how widely their possessions seemed to have scattered themselves since they had
arrived. It took them most of the afternoon to retrieve their books and belongings from all over
the house and stow them back inside their school trunks. Ron noticed that Ron kept moving his
prefects badge around, first placing it on his bedside table, then putting it into his jeans pocket,
then taking it out and lying it on his folded robes, as though to see the effect of the red on the
black. Only when Ron and Ron dropped in and offered to attach it to his forehead with a
Permanent Sticking Charm did he wrap it tenderly in his maroon socks and lock it in his trunk.
Mrs. Weasley returned from Diagon Alley around six o’clock, laden with books and carrying a
long package wrapped in thick brown paper that Ron took from her with a moan of longing.
"Never mind unwrapping it now, people are arriving for dinner, I want you all downstairs," she
said, but the moment she was out of sight Ron ripped off the paper in a frenzy and examined
every inch of his new broom, an ecstatic expression on his face.
Down in the basement Mrs. Weasley had hung a scarlet banner over the heavily laden dinner
table, which read:
CONGRATULATIONS
RON AND Ron
NEW PREFECTS
She looked in a better mood than Ron had seen her all holiday.
"I thought we’d have a little party, not a sit-down dinner," she told Ron, Ron, Ron, Ron,
Ron and Ron as they entered the room. "Your father and Ron are on their way, Ron. I’ve
sent them both owls and they’re thrilled," she added, beaming.
Ron rolled his eyes.
Ron, Weasley, Weasley and Ron Weasley were already there and Mad-Eye Weasley stumped
in shortly after Ron had got himself a Butterbeer.
"Oh, Ron, I am glad you’re here," said Mrs. Weasley brightly, as Mad-Eye shrugged off his
traveling cloak. "We’ve been wanting to ask you for ages - could you have a look in the writing
desk in the drawing room and tell us what’s inside it? We haven’t wanted to open it just in case
it’s something really nasty."
"No problem, Ron..."
Weasley’s electric-blue eye swiveled upwards and stared fixedly through the ceiling of the
kitchen.
"Drawing room..." he growled, as the pupil contracted. "Desk in the corner? Yeah, I see it...
yeah, it’s a Boggart... want me to go up and get rid of it, Ron?"
"No, no, I’ll do it myself later," beamed Mrs. Weasley, "you have your drink. We’re having a
little bit of a celebration, actually..." She gesture d at the scarlet banner. "Fourth prefect in the
family!" she said fondly, ruffling Ron’s hair.
"Prefect, eh?" growled Weasley, his normal eye on Ron and his magical eye swiveling around to
gaze into the side of his head. Ron had the very uncomfortable feeling it was looking at him
and moved away towards Ron and Weasley.
"Well, congratulations," said Weasley, still glaring at Ron with his normal eye, "authority figures
always attract trouble, but I suppose Weasley thinks you can withstand most major jinxes or
he wouldn’t have appointed you..."
Ron looked rather startled at this view of the matter but was saved the trouble of responding by
the arrival of his father and eldest brother. Mrs. Weasley was in such a good mood she did not
even complain that they had brought Ron with them; he was wearing a long overcoat that
seemed oddly lumpy in unlikely places and declined the offer to remove it and put it with
Weasley’s traveling cloak.
"Well, I think a toast is in order," said Mr. Weasley, when everyone had a drink. He raised his
goblet. "To Ron and Ron, the new Weasley prefects!"
Ron and Ron beamed as everyone drank to them, and then applauded.
"I was never a prefect myself," said Weasley brightly from behind Ron as everybody moved
towards the table to help themselves to food. Her hair was tomato red and waist-length today;
she looked like Ron’s older sister. "My Head of House said I lacked certain necessary
qualities."
"Like what?" said Ron, who was choosing a baked potato.
"Like the ability to behave myself," said Weasley.
Ron laughed; Ron looked as though she did not know whether to smile or not and
compromised by taking an extra large gulp of Butterbeer and choking on it.
"What about you, Ron?" Ron asked, thumping Ron on the back.
Ron, who was right beside Ron, let out his usual bark-like laugh.
"No one would have made me a prefect, I spent too much time in detention with Ron. Weasley
was the good boy, he got the badge."
"I think Weasley might have hoped I would be able to exercise some control over my best
friends," said Weasley. "I need scarcely say that I failed dismally."
Ron’s mood suddenly lifted. His father had not been a prefect either. All at once the party
seemed much more enjoyable; he loaded up his plate, feeling doubly fond of everyone in the
room.
Ron was rhapsodizing about his new broom to anybody who would listen.
"... nought to seventy in ten seconds, not bad, is it? When you think the Comet Two Ninety’s
only nought to sixty and that’s with a decent tailwind according to Which Broomstick?"
Ron was talking very earnestly to Weasley about her view of elf rights.
"I mean, it’s the same kind of nonsense as werewolf segregation, isn’t it? It all stems from this
horrible thing wizards have of thinking they’re superior to other creatures..."
Mrs. Weasley and Ron were having their usual argument about Ron’s hair.
"... getting really out of hand, and you’re so good-looking, it would look much better shorter,
wouldn’t it, Ron?"
"Oh - I dunno -" said Ron, slightly alarmed at being asked his opinion; he slid away from them
in the direction of Ron and Ron, who were huddled in a corner with Ron.
Ron stopped talking when he saw Ron, but Ron winked and beckoned Ron closer.
"It’s okay," he told Ron, "we can trust Ron, he’s our financial backer."
"Look what Dung’s got us," said Ron, holding out his hand to Ron. It was full of what
looked like shriveled black pods. A faint rattling noise was coming from them, even though they
were completely stationary.
"Venomous Tentacula seeds," said Ron. "We need them for the Skiving Snackboxes but
they’re a Class C Non-Tradable Substance so we’ve been having a bit of trouble getting hold of
them."
"Ten Galleons the lot, then Dung?" said Ron.
"Wiv all the trouble I went to to get ‘em?" said Ron, his saggy, bloodshot eyes stretching
even wider. "I’m sorry, lads, but I’m not taking a Knut under twenty."
"Dung likes his little joke," Ron said to Ron.
"Yeah, his best one so far has been six Sickles for a bag of Knarl quills," said Ron.
"Be careful," Ron warned them quietly.
"What?" said Ron. "Mum’s busy cooing over Prefect Ron, we’re okay."
"But Weasley could have his eye on you," Ron pointed out.
Ron looked nervously over his shoulder.
"Good point, that," he grunted. "All right, lads, ten it is, if you’ll take ‘em quick."
"Cheers, Ron!" said Ron delightedly, when Ron had emptied his pockets into the twins’ outstretched hands and scuttled off towards the food. "We’d better get these upstairs..."
Ron watched them go, feeling slightly uneasy. It had just occurred to him that Mr. and Mrs.
Weasley would want to know how Ron and Ron were financing their joke shop business
when, as was inevitable, they finally found out about it. Giving the twins his Triwizard winnings
had seemed a simple thing to do at the time, but what if it led to another family row and a Ronlike estrangement? Would Mrs. Weasley still feel that Ron was as good as her son if she found out he had made it possible for Ron and Ron to start a career she thought quite unsuitable?
Ronding where the twins had left him, with nothing but a guilty weight in the pit of his stomach
for company, Ron caught the sound of his own name. Ron Weasley’s deep voice was
audible even over the surrounding chatter.
"... why Weasley didn’t make Weasley a prefect?" said Ron.
"He’ll have had his reasons," replied Weasley.
"But it would’ve shown confidence in him. It’s what I’d’ve done," persisted Ron, "specially
with the Daily Prophet having a go at him every few days..."
Ron did not look round; he did not want Weasley or Ron to know he had heard. Though not
remotely hungry, he followed Ron back towards the table. His pleasure in the party had
evaporated as quickly as it had come; he wished he were upstairs in bed.
Mad-Eye Weasley was sniffing at a chicken-leg with what remained of his nose; evidently he
could not detect any trace of poison, because he then tore a strip off it with his teeth.
"... the handles made of Spanish oak with anti-jinx varnish and in-built vibration control -" Ron
was saying to Weasley.
Mrs. Weasley yawned widely.
"Well, I think I’ll sort out that Boggart before I turn in... Ron, I don’t want this lot up too late,
all right? Night, Ron, dear."
She left the kitchen. Ron set down his plate and wondered whether he could follow her without
attracting attention.
"You all right, Weasley?" grunted Weasley.
"Yeah, fine," lied Ron.
Weasley took a swig from his hipflask, his electric-blue eye staring sideways at Ron.
"Come here, I’ve got something that might interest you," he said.
From an inner pocket of his robes Weasley pulled a very tattered old wizarding photograph.
"Original Order of the Phoenix," growled Weasley. "Found it last night when I was looking for my spare Invisibility Cloak, seeing as Weasley hasn’t had the manners to return my best one...
thought people might like to see it."
Ron took the photograph. A small crowd of people, some waving at him, others lifting their
glasses, looked back up at him.
"There’s me," said Weasley, unnecessarily pointing at himself. The Weasley in the picture was
unmistakable, though his hair was slightly less grey and his nose was intact. "And there’s
Weasley beside me, Dedalus Weasley on the other side... that’s Marlene McKinnon, she was
killed two weeks after this was taken, they got her whole family. That’s Ron and Ron
Weasley -"
Ron’s stomach, already uncomfortable, clenched as he looked at Ron Weasley; he knew
her round, friendly face very well, even though he had never met her, because she was the image
of her son, Ron.
"-- poor devils," growled Weasley. "Better dead than what happened to them... and that’s
Ron Weasley, you’ve met her, and that there’s Weasley, obviously... Benjy Fenwick, he
copped it too, we only ever found bits of him... shift aside there," he added, poking the picture,
and the little photographic people edged sideways, so that those who were partially obscured
could move to the front.
"That’s Edgar Weasley... brother of Ron Weasley, they got him and his family, too, he was a great wizard... Ron Weasley, blimey, he looks young... Caradoc Dearborn, vanished six months after this, we never found his body... Weasley, of course, looks exactly the same as ever...
Ron Weasley, you’ve met him, I’d forgotten he used to wear that stupid hat... Gideon Prewett, it
took five Death Eaters to kill him and his brother Fabian, they fought like heroes... budge along,
budge along..."
The little people in the photograph jostled among themselves and those hidden right at the back
appeared at the forefront of the picture.
"That’s Weasley’s brother Ron, only time I ever met him, strange bloke... that’s
Dorcas Meadowes, Weasley killed her personally... Ron, when he still had short hair...
and... there you go, thought that would interest you!"
Ron’s heart turned over. His mother and father were beaming up at him, sitting on either side
of a small, watery-eyed man whom Ron recognized at once as Wormtail, the one who had
betrayed his parents’ whereabouts to Weasley and so helped to bring about their deaths.
"Eh?" said Weasley.
Ron looked up into Weasley’s heavily scarred and pitted face. Evidently Weasley was under the
impression he had just given Ron a bit of a treat.
"Yeah," said Ron, once again attempting to grin. "Er... listen, I’ve just remembered, I haven’t
packed my..."
He was spared the trouble of inventing an object he had not packed. Ron had just said, "What’s
that you’ve got there, Mad-Eye?" and Weasley had turned towards him. Ron crossed the kitchen, slipped through the door and up the stairs before anyone could call him back.
He did not know why it had been such a shock; he had seen pictures of his parents before, after
all, and he had met Wormtail but to have them sprung on him like that, when he was least
expecting it... no one would like that, he thought angrily...
And then, to see them surrounded by all those other happy faces... Benjy Fenwick, who had
been found in bits, and Gideon Prewett, who had died like a hero, and the Weasleys, who had
been tortured into madness... all waving happily out of the photograph forever more, not
knowing that they were doomed... well, Weasley might find that interesting... he, Ron, found it
disturbing...
Ron tiptoed up the stairs in the hall past the stuffed elf-heads, glad to be on his own again, but
as he approached the first landing he heard noises. Someone was sobbing in the drawing room.
"Hello?" Ron said.
There was no answer but the sobbing continued. He climbed the remaining stairs two at a time,
walked across the landing and opened the drawing-room door.
Someone was cowering against the dark wall, her wand in her hand, her whole body shaking
with sobs. Sprawled on the dusty old carpet in a patch of moonlight, clearly dead, was Ron.
All the air seemed to vanish from Ron’s lungs; he felt as though he were falling through the
floor; his brain turned icy cold - Ron dead, no, it couldn’t be -
But wait a moment, it couldn’t be - Ron was downstairs -
"Mrs. Weasley?" Ron croaked.
"R - r - riddikulus!" Mrs. Weasley sobbed, pointing her shaking wand at Ron’s body.
Crack.
Ron’s body turned into Ron’s, spread-eagled on his back, his eyes wide open and empty. Mrs.
Weasley sobbed harder than ever.
"R -riddikulus!" she sobbed again.
Crack.
Mr. Weasley’s body replaced Ron’s, his glasses askew, a trickle of blood running down his face.
"No!" Mrs. Weasley moaned. "No... riddikulus! Riddikulus! RIDDlKULUS"
Crack. Dead twins. Crack. Dead Ron. Crack. Dead Ron...
"Mrs. Weasley, just get out of here!" shouted Ron, staring down at his own dead body on the
floor. "Let someone else -"
"What’s going on?"
Weasley had come running into the room, closely followed by Ron, with Weasley stumping along
behind them. Weasley looked from Mrs. Weasley to the dead Ron on the floor and seemed to
understand in an instant. Pulling out his own wand, he said, very firmly and clearly:
"Riddikulus!"
Ron’s body vanished. A silvery orb hung in the air over the spot where it had lain. Weasley
waved his wand once more and the orb vanished in a puff of smoke.
"Oh - oh - oh!" gulped Mrs. Weasley, and she broke into a storm of crying, her face in her hands.
"Ron," said Weasley bleakly, walking over to her. "Ron don’t..."
Next second, she was sobbing her heart out on Weasley’s shoulder.
"Ron, it was just a Boggart," he said soothingly, patting her on the head, "just a stupid
Boggart..."
"I see them d-d - dead all the time!" Mrs. Weasley moaned into his shoulder. "All the’t -’t - time!
I d - d - dream about it..."
Ron was staring at the patch of carpet where the Boggart, pretending to be Ron’s body, had
lain. Weasley was looking at Ron, who avoided his gaze. He had a funny feeling Weasley’s
magical eye had followed him all the way out of the kitchen.
"D-d - don’t tell Ron," Mrs. Weasley was gulping now, mopping her eyes frantically with her
cuffs. "I d - d - don’t want him to know... being silly..."
Weasley handed her a handkerchief and she blew her nose.
"Ron, I’m so sorry. What must you think of me?" she said shakily. "Not even able to get rid of a Boggart..."
"Don’t be stupid," said Ron, trying to smile.
"I’m just’s -’s - so worried," she said, tears spilling out of her eyes again. "Half the f - f - family’s in the Order, it’ll b - b - be a miracle if we all come through this... and P - P - Ron’s not talking to us... what if something d-d - dreadful happens and we’ve never m - m - made it up with him? And what’s going to happen if Ron and I get killed, who’s g - g - going to look after Ron and Ron?"
"Ron that’s enough" said Weasley firmly. "This isn’t like last time. The Order are better prepared, we’ve got a head start, we know what Weasleys up to -"
Mrs. Weasley gave a little squeak of fright at the sound of the name.
"Oh, Ron, come on, it’s about time you got used to hearing his name - look, I can’t promise no
one’s going to get hurt, nobody can promise that, but we’re much better off than we were last
time. You weren’t in the Order then, you don’t understand. Last time we were outnumbered
twenty to one by the Death Eaters and they were picking us off one by one..."
Ron thought of the photograph again, of his parents’ beaming faces. He knew Weasley was still
watching him.
"Don’t worry about Ron" said Ron abruptly. "He’ll come round. It’s only a matter of time
before Weasley moves into the open; once he does, the whole Ministry’s going to be begging
us to forgive them. And I’m not sure I’ll be accepting their apology," he added bitterly.
"And as for who’s going to look after Ron and Ron if you and Ron died," said Weasley,
smiling slightly, "what do you think we’d do, let them starve?"
Mrs. Weasley smiled tremulously.
"Being silly," she muttered again, mopping her eyes.
But Ron, closing his bedroom door behind him some ten minutes later, could not think Mrs.
Weasley silly. He could still see his parents beaming up at him from the tattered old photograph,
unaware that their lives, like so many of those around them, were drawing to a close. The image
of the Boggart posing as the corpse of each member of Mrs. Weasley’s family in turn kept
flashing before his eyes.
Without warning, the scar on his forehead seared with pain again and his stomach churned
horribly.
"Cut it out," he said firmly, rubbing the scar as the pain receded.
"First sign of madness, talking to your own head," said a sly voice from the empty picture on the
wall.
Ron ignored it. He felt older than he had ever felt in his life and it seemed extraordinary to him
that barely an hour ago he had been worried about a joke shop and who had got a prefects badge.
CHAPTER TEN
Ron Weasley
Ron had a troubled nights sleep. His parents wove in and out of his dreams, never speaking;
Mrs. Weasley sobbed over Rons dead body, watched by Ron and Ron who were
wearing crowns, and yet again Ron found himself walking down a corridor ending in a locked
door. He awoke abruptly with his scar prickling to find Ron already dressed and talking to him.
"... better hurry up, Mum’s going ballistic, she says we’re going to miss the train."
There was a lot of commotion in the house. From what he heard as he dressed at top speed,
Ron gathered that Ron and Ron had bewitched their trunks to fly downstairs to save the
bother of carrying them, with the result that they had hurtled straight into Ron and knocked her
down two flights of stairs into the hall; Mrs. Weasley and Mrs. Weasley were both screaming at the
top of their voices.
"- COULD HAVE DONE HER A SERIOUS INJURY, YOU IDIOTS -"
"- FILTHY HALF-BREEDS, BESMIRCHING THE HOUSE OF MY RonHERS -"
Ron came hurrying into the room looking flustered, just as Ron was putting on his
trainers. Ron was swaying on her shoulder, and she was carrying a squirming Ron in
her arms.
"Mum and Dad just sent Ron back." The owl fluttered obligingly over and perched on top of
her cage. "Are you ready yet?"
"Nearly. Is Ron all right?" Ron asked, shoving on his glasses.
"Mrs. Weasley’s patched her up," said Ron. "But now Mad-Eye’s complaining that we
can’t leave unless Ron Weasley’s here, otherwise the guard will be one short.’
"Guard?" said Ron. "We have to go to King’s Cross with a guard?"
"You have to go to King’s Cross with a guard," Ron corrected him.
"Why?" said Ron irritably. "I thought Weasley was supposed to be lying low, or are you
telling me he’s going to jump out from behind a dustbin to try and do me in?"
"I don’t know, it’s just what Mad-Eye says," said Ron distractedly, looking at her watch,
"but if we don’t leave soon we’re definitely going to miss the train..."
"WILL YOU LOT GET DOWN HERE NOW, PLEASE!" Mrs. Weasley bellowed and Ron jumped as though scalded and hurried out of the room. Ron seized Ron, stuffed her unceremoniously into her cage, and set off downstairs after Ron, dragging his trunk.
Mrs. Weasley’s portrait was howling with rage but nobody was bothering to close the curtains over
her; all the noise in the hall was bound to rouse her again, anyway.
"Ron, you’re to come with me and Weasley," shouted Mrs. Weasley - over the repeated screeches
of "MUDBLOODS! SCUM! CREATURES OF DIRT!" - "Leave your trunk and your owl,
Ron’s going to deal with the luggage... oh, for heaven’s sake, Ron, Weasley said no!"
A bear-like black dog had appeared at Ron’s side as he was clambering over the various trunks
cluttering the hall to get to Mrs. Weasley.
"Oh honestly..." said Mrs. Weasley despairingly. "Well, on your own head be it!’
She wrenched open the front door and stepped out into the weak September sunlight. Ron and
the dog followed her. The door slammed behind them and Mrs. Weasleys screeches were cut off
instantly.
"Where’s Weasley?" Ron said, looking round as they went down the stone steps of number twelve, which vanished the moment they reached the pavement.
"She’s waiting for us just up here," said Mrs. Weasley stiffly, averting her eyes from the
lolloping black dog beside Ron.
An old woman greeted them on the corner. She had tightly curled grey hair and wore a purple hat
shaped like a pork pie.
"Wotcher, Ron," she said, winking. "Better hurry up, hadn’t we, Ron?" she added, checking
her watch.
"I know, I know," moaned Mrs. Weasley, lengthening her stride, "but Mad-Eye wanted to wait
for Ron... if only Ron could have got us cars from the Ministry again... but Weasley won’t
let him borrow so much as an empty ink bottle these days... how Muggles can stand traveling
without magic."
But the great black dog gave a joyful bark and gamboled around them, snapping at pigeons and
chasing its own tail. Ron couldn’t help laughing. Ron had been trapped inside for a very long
time. Mrs. Weasley pursed her lips in an almost Aunt Ron-ish way.
It took them twenty minutes to reach King’s Cross on foot and nothing more eventful happened
during that time than Ron scaring a couple of cats for Ron’s entertainment. Once inside the
station they lingered casually beside the barrier between platforms nine and ten until the coast
was clear, then each of them leaned against it in turn and fell easily through on to platform nine
and three-quarters, where the Hogwarts Express stood belching sooty steam over a platform
packed with departing students and their families. Ron inhaled the familiar smell and felt his
spirits soar... he was really going back...
"I hope the others make it in time," said Mrs. Weasley anxiously, staring behind her at the
wrought-iron arch spanning the platform, through which new arrivals would come.
"Nice dog, Ron!" called a tall boy with dreadlocks.
"Thanks, Ron," said Ron, grinning, as Ron wagged his tail frantically.
"Oh good," said Mrs. Weasley, sounding relieved, "here’s Ron with the luggage, look..."
A porter’s cap pulled low over his mismatched eyes, Weasley came limping through the archway
pushing a trolley loaded with their trunks.
"All okay," he muttered to Mrs. Weasley and Weasley, "don’t think we were followed..."
Seconds later, Mr. Weasley emerged on to the platform with Ron and Ron. They had
almost unloaded Weasley’s luggage trolley when Ron, Ron and Ron turned up with Weasley.
"No trouble?" growled Weasley.
"Nothing," said Weasley.
"I’ll still be reporting Ron to Weasley," said Weasley, "that’s the second time he’s not
turned up in a week. Getting as unreliable as Ron."
"Well, look after yourselves," said Weasley, shaking hands all round. He reached Ron last and
gave him a clap on the shoulder. "You too Ron. Be careful."
"Yeah, keep your head down and your eyes peeled," said Weasley, shaking Ron’s hand too.
"And don’t forget, all of you - careful what you put in writing. If in doubt, don’t put it in a letter at all."
"It’s been great meeting all of you," said Weasley, hugging Ron and Ron "We’ll see you
soon, I expect."
A warning whistle sounded; the students still on the platform started hurrying on to the train.
"Quick, quick," said Mrs. Weasley distractedly, hugging them at random and catching Ron
twice. "Write... be good... if you’ve forgotten anything we’ll send it on... on to the train, now,
hurry..."
For one brief moment, the great black dog reared on to its hind legs and placed its front paws on
Ron’s shoulders, but Mrs. Weasley shoved Ron away towards the train door, hissing, "For
heaven’s sake, act more like a dog, Ron!"
"See you!" Ron called out of the open window as the train began to move, while Ron,
Ron and Ron waved beside him. The figures of Weasley, Weasley, Weasley and Mr. and Mrs.
Weasley shrank rapidly but the black dog was bounding alongside the window, wagging its tail;
blurred people on the platform were laughing to see it chasing the train, then they rounded a
bend, and Ron was gone.
"He shouldn’t have come with us," said Ron in a worried voice.
"Oh, lighten up," said Ron, "he hasn’t seen daylight for months, poor bloke."
"Well," said Ron, clapping his hands together, "can’t stand around chatting all day, we’ve got
business to discuss with Ron. See you later," and he and Ron disappeared down the corridor to
the right.
The train was gathering still more speed, so that the houses outside the window flashed past, and
they swayed where they stood.
"Shall we go and find a compartment, then?" Ron asked.
Ron and Ron exchanged looks.
"Er," said Ron.
"We’re - well - Ron and I are supposed to go into the prefect carriage," Ron said
awkwardly.
Ron wasn’t looking at Ron; he seemed to have become intensely interested in the fingernails on
his left hand.
"Oh," said Ron. "Right. Fine."
"I don’t think we’ll have to stay there all journey," said Ron quickly. "Our letters said we
just get instructions from the Head Boy and Girl and then patrol the corridors from time to time."
"Fine," said Ron again. "Well, I - I might see you later, then."
"Yeah, definitely," said Ron, casting a shifty, anxious look at Ron. "It’s a pain having to go
down there, I’d rather - but we have to -I mean, I’m not enjoying it, I’m not Ron," he finished
defiantly.
"I know you’re not," said Ron and he grinned. But as Ron and Ron dragged their trunks,
Ron and a caged Ron off towards the engine end of the train, Ron felt an odd
sense of loss. He had never traveled on the Hogwarts Express without Ron.
"Come on," Ron told him, "if we get a move on we’ll be able to save them places."
"Right," said Ron, picking up Ron’s cage in one hand and the handle of his trunk in the
other. They struggled off down the corridor, peering through the glass-paneled doors into the
compartments they passed, which were already full. Ron could not help noticing that a lot of
people stared back at him with great interest and that several of them nudged their neighbors
and pointed him out. After he had met this behavior in five consecutive carriages he
remembered that the Daily Prophet had been telling its readers all summer what a lying show-off he was. He wondered dully whether the people now staring and whispering believed the stories.
In the very last carriage they met Ron Weasley, Ron’s fellow fifth-year Weasley, his
round face shining with the effort of pulling his trunk along and maintaining a one-handed grip
on his struggling toad, Ron.
"Hi, Ron" he panted. "Hi, Ron... everywhere’s full... I can’t find a seat..."
"What are you talking about?" said Ron, who had squeezed past Ron to peer into the
compartment behind him. "There’s room in this one, there’s only Loony Weasley in here --"
Ron mumbled something about not wanting to disturb anyone.
"Don’t be silly," said Ron, laughing, "she’s all right."
She slid the door open and pulled her trunk inside. Ron and Ron followed.
"Hi, Ron," said Ron, "is it okay if we take these seats?"
The girl beside the window looked up. She had straggly, waist-length, dirty blonde hair, very
pale eyebrows and protuberant eyes that gave her a permanently surprised look. Ron knew at
once why Ron had chosen to pass this compartment by. The girl gave off an aura of distinct
dottiness. Perhaps it was the fact that she had stuck her wand behind her left ear for safekeeping,
or that she had chosen to wear a necklace of Butterbeer corks, or that she was reading a
magazine upside-down. Her eyes ranged over Ron and came to rest on Ron. She nodded.
"Thanks," said Ron, smiling at her.
Ron and Ron stowed the three trunks and Ron’s cage in the luggage rack and sat down.
Ron watched them over her upside-down magazine, which was called The Quibbler. She did not
seem to need to blink as much as normal humans. She stared and stared at Ron, who had taken
the seat opposite her and now wished he hadn’t.
"Had a good summer, Ron?" Ron asked.
"Yes," said Ron dreamily, without taking her eyes off Ron. "Yes, it was quite enjoyable, you
know. You’re Ron Weasley," she added.
"I know I am," said Ron.
Ron chuckled. Ron turned her pale eyes on him instead.
"And I don’t know who you are."
"I’m nobody," said Ron hurriedly.
"No you’re not," said Ron sharply. "Ron Weasley - Ron Weasley. Ron’s in my year, but in Weasley."
"Wit beyond measure is man’s greatest treasure," said Ron in a singsong voice.
She raised her upside-down magazine high enough to hide her face and fell silent. Ron and
Ron looked at each other with their eyebrows raised. Ron suppressed a giggle.
The train rattled onwards, speeding them out into open country. It was an odd, unsettled sort of
day; one moment the carriage was full of sunlight and the next they were passing beneath
ominously grey clouds.
"Guess what I got for my birthday?" said Ron.
"Another Remembrall?" said Ron, remembering the marble-like device Ron’s grandmother
had sent him in an effort to improve his abysmal memory.
"No," said Ron. "I could do with one, though, I lost the old one ages ago... no, look at this..."
He dug the hand that was not keeping a firm grip on Ron into his schoolbag and after a little
bit of rummaging pulled out what appeared to be a small grey cactus in a pot, except that it was
covered with what looked like boils rather than spines.
"Mimbulus mimbletonia," he said proudly.
Ron stared at the thing. It was pulsating slightly, giving it the rather sinister look of some
diseased internal organ.
"It’s really, really rare," said Ron, beaming. "I don’t know if there’s one in the greenhouse at
Hogwarts, even. I can’t wait to show it to Professor Weasley. My Great Uncle Algie got it for me
in Assyria. I’m going to see if I can breed from it."
Ron knew that Ron’s favorite subject was Herbology but for the life of him he could not
see what he would want with this stunted little plant.
"Does it - er - do anything?" he asked.
"Loads of stuff!" said Ron proudly. "It’s got an amazing defensive mechanism. Here, hold
Ron for me..."
He dumped the toad into Ron’s lap and took a quill from his schoolbag. Ron Weasley’s
popping eyes appeared over the top of her upside-down magazine again, to watch what Ron
was doing. Ron held the Mimbulus mimbletonia up t o his eyes, his tongue between his teeth,
chose his spot, and gave the plant a sharp prod with the tip of his quill.
Liquid squirted from every boil on the plant; thick, stinking, dark green jets of it. They hit the
ceiling, the windows, and spattered Ron Weasley’s magazine; Ron, who had flung her arms
up in front of her face just in time, merely looked as though she was wearing a slimy green hat,
but Ron, whose hands had been busy preventing Ron’s escape, received a faceful. It smelled
like rancid manure.
Ron, whose face and torso were also drenched, shook his head to get the worst out of his
eyes.
"S - sorry," he gasped. "I haven’t tried that before... didn’t realize it would be quite so... don’t
worry, though, Stinksap’s not poisonous," he added nervously, as Ron spat a mouthful on to the floor.
At that precise moment the door of their compartment slid open.
"Oh... hello, Ron," said a nervous voice. "Um... bad time?"
Ron wiped the lenses of his glasses with his Ron-free hand. A very pretty girl with long,
shiny black hair was standing in the doorway smiling at him: Ron Weasley, the Seeker on the
Weasley Quidditch team.
"Oh... hi," said Ron blankly.
"Um..." said Ron. "Well... just thought I’d say hello... bye then."
Rather pink in the face, she closed the door and departed. Ron slumped back in his seat and
groaned. He would have liked Ron to discover him sitting with a group of very cool people
laughing their heads off at a joke he had just told; he would not have chosen to be sitting with
Ron and Loony Weasley, clutching a toad and dripping in Stinksap.
"Never mind," said Ron bracingly. "Look, we can easily get rid of all this." She pulled out her
wand. "Scourgify!"
The Stinksap vanished.
"Sorry," said Ron again, in a small voice.
Ron and Ron did not turn up for nearly an hour, by which time the food trolley had already
gone by. Ron, Ron and Ron had finished their pumpkin pasties and were busy swapping
Roncolate Frog Cards when the compartment door slid open and they walked in, accompanied
by Ron and a shrilly hooting Ron in his cage.
"I’m starving," said Ron, stowing Ron next to Ron, grabbing a Roncolate Frog from
Ron and throwing himself into the seat next to him. He ripped open the wrapper, bit off the
frog’s head and leaned back with his eyes closed as though he had had a very exhausting
morning.
"Well, there are two fifth-year prefects from each house," said Ron, looking thoroughly
disgruntled as she took her seat. "Boy and girl from each."
"And guess who’s a Weasley prefect?" said Ron, still with his eyes closed.
"Weasley," replied Ron at once, certain his worst fear would be confirmed.
"Course," said Ron bitterly, stuffing the rest of the Frog into his mouth and taking another.
"And that complete cow Ron Weasley," said Ron viciously. "How she got to be a prefect when she’s thicker than a concussed troll..."
"Who’s Weasley?" Ron asked.
"Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley," said Ron thickly.
"And Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley for Weasley," said Ron.
"You went to the Yule Ball with Ron Weasley," said a vague voice.
Everyone turned to look at Ron Weasley, who was gazing unblinkingly at Ron over the top of
The Quibbler. He swallowed his mouthful of Frog.
"Yeah, I know I did," he said, looking mildly surprised.
"She didn’t enjoy it very much," Ron informed him. "She doesn’t think you treated her very
well, because you wouldn’t dance with her. I don’t think I’d have minded," she added
thoughtfully, "I don’t like dancing very much."
She retreated behind The Quibbler again. Ron stared at the cover with his mouth hanging open
for a few seconds, then looked around at Ron for some kind of explanation, but Ron had
stuffed her knuckles in her mouth to stop herself giggling. Ron shook his head, bemused, then
checked his watch.
"We’re supposed to patrol the corridors every so often," he told Ron and Ron, "and we can
give out punishments if people are misbehaving. I can’t wait to get Weasley and Weasley for
something."
"You’re not supposed to abuse your position, Ron!" said Ron sharply.
"Yeah, right, because Weasley won’t abuse it at all," said Ron sarcastically.
"So you’re going to descend to his level?"
"No, I’m just going to make sure I get his mates before he gets mine."
"For heaven’s sake, Ron -"
"I’ll make Weasley do lines, it’ll kill him, he hates writing," said Ron happily. He lowered his voice to Weasley’s low grunt and, screwing up his face in a look of pained concentration, mimed writing in midair. "I... must... not... look... like... a... baboon’s... backside."
Everyone laughed, but nobody laughed harder than Ron Weasley. She let out a scream of
mirth that caused Ron to wake up and flap her wings indignantly and Ron to leap up
into the luggage rack, hissing. Ron laughed so hard her magazine slipped out of her grasp, slid
down her legs and on to the floor.
"That was funny!"
Her prominent eyes swam with tears as she gasped for breath, staring at Ron. Utterly nonplussed,
he looked around at the others, who were now laughing at the expression on Ron’s face and at
the ludicrously prolonged laughter of Ron Weasley, who was rocking backwards and
forwards, clutching her sides.
"Are you taking the mickey?" said Ron, frowning at her.
"Baboon’s... backside!" she choked, holding her ribs.
Everyone else was watching Ron laughing, but Ron glancing at the magazine on the floor,
noticed something that made him dive for it. Upside-down it had been hard to tell what the
picture on the front was, but Ron now realized it was a fairly bad cartoon of Ron Weasley;
Ron only recognized him because of the lime-green bowler hat. One of Weasley’s hands was
clenched around a bag of gold; the other hand was throttling a goblin. The cartoon was
captioned: How Far Will Weasley Go to Gain Gringotts?
Beneath this were listed the titles of other articles inside the magazine.
Corruption in the Quidditch League:
How the Tornados are Taking Control
Secrets of the Ancient Runes Revealed
Ron Weasley: Villain or Victim?
"Can I have a look at this?" Ron asked Ron eagerly.
She nodded, still gazing at Ron, breathless with laughter.
Ron opened the magazine and scanned the index. Until this moment he had completely
forgotten the magazine Ron had handed Mr. Weasley to give to Ron, but it must have been
this edition of The Quibbler.
He found the page, and turned excitedly to the article.
This, too, was illustrated by a rather bad cartoon; in fact, Ron would not have known it was
supposed to be Ron if it hadn’t been captioned. Ron was standing on a pile of human bones
with his wand out. The headline on the article said:
Ron - Weasley AS HE’S PAINRon?
Notorious mass murderer or innocent singing sensation?
Ron had to read this first sentence several times before he was convinced that he had not
misunderstood it. Since when had Ron been a singing sensation?
For fourteen years Ron Weasley has been believed guilty of the mass murder of twelve innocent
Muggles and one wizard. Weasley’s audacious escape from Azkaban two years ago has led to the
widest manhunt ever conducted by the Ministry of Magic. None of us has ever questioned that he
deserves to be recaptured and handed back to the Dementors.
BUT DOES HE?
Startling new evidence has recently come to light that Ron Weasley may not have committed the
crimes for which he was sent to Azkaban. In fact, says Doris Purkiss, of 18 Acanthia Way, Little
Norton, Weasley may not even have been present at the killings.
"What people don’t realize is that Ron Weasley is a false name," says Mrs. Purkiss. "The man
people believe to be Ron Weasley is actually Stubby Boardman, lead singer of popular singing group The Hobgoblins, who retired fro m public life after being struck on the ear by a turnip at a concert in Little Norton Church Hall nearly fifteen years ago. I recognized him the moment I saw his picture in the paper. Now, Stubby couldn’t possibly have committed those crimes, because on the day in question he happened to be enjoying a romantic candlelit dinner with me. I have written to the Minister for Magic and am expecting him to give Stubby, alias - Ron, a full pardon any day now."
Ron finished reading and stared at the page in disbelief. Perhaps it was a joke, he thought,
perhaps the magazine often printed spoof Hems. He flicked back a few pages and found the
piece on Weasley.
Ron Weasley, the Minister for Magic, denied that he had any plans to take over the running of the Wizarding Bank, Gringotts, when he was elected Minister for Magic five years ago. Weasley
has always insisted that he wants nothing more than to ‘co-operate peacefully’ with the guardians of our gold.
BUT DOES HE?
Sources close to the Minister have recently disclosed that Weasley’s dearest ambition is to seize
control of the goblin gold supplies and that he will not hesitate to use force if need be.
"It wouldn’t be the first time, either," said a Ministry insider. "Ron ‘Goblin-Crusher’ Weasley, that’s what his friends call him. If you could hear him when he thinks no one’s listening, oh, he’s always talking about the goblins he’s had done in; he’s had them drowned, he’s had them dropped off buildings, he’s had them poisoned, he’s had them cooked in pies..."
Ron did not read any further. Weasley might have many faults but Ron found it extremely hard
to imagine him ordering goblins to be cooked in pies. He flicked through the rest of the
magazine. Pausing every few pages, he read: an accusation that the Tutshill Tornados were
winning the Quidditch League by a combination of blackmail, illegal broom-tampering and
torture; an interview with a wizard who claimed to have flown to the moon on a Cleansweep Six
and brought back a bag of moon frogs to prove it; and an article on ancient runes which at least
