explained why Ron had been reading The Quibbler upside-down. According to the magazine, if
you turned the runes on their heads they revealed a spell to make your enemy’s ears turn into
kumquats. In fact, compared to the rest of the articles in The Quibbler, the suggestion that Ron
might really be the lead singer of The Hobgoblins was quite sensible.
"Anything good in there?" asked Ron as Ron closed the magazine.
"Of course not," said Ron scathingly, before Ron could answer. "The Quibbler’s rubbish,
everyone knows that."
"Excuse me," said Ron; her voice had suddenly lost its dreamy quality. "My father’s the editor."
"I - oh," said Ron, looking embarrassed. "Well, it’s got some interesting... I mean, it’s
quite..."
"I’ll have it back, thank you," said Ron coldly, and leaning forwards she snatched it out of
Ron’s hands. Riffling through it to page fifty-seven, she turned it resolutely upside-down again
and disappeared behind it, just as the compartment door opened for the third time.
Ron looked around; he had expected this, but that did not make the sight of Ron Weasley
smirking at him from between his cronies Weasley and Weasley any more enjoyable.
"What?" he said aggressively, before Weasley could open his mouth.
"Manners, Weasley, or I’ll have to give you a detention," drawled Weasley, whose sleek blond hair
and pointed chin were just like his fathers. "You see, I, unlike you, have been made a prefect,
which means that I, unlike you, have the power to hand out punishments."
"Yeah," said Ron, "but you, unlike me, are a git, so get out and leave us alone."
Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron laughed. Weasley’s lip curled.
"Tell me, how does it feel being second-best to Weasley, Weasley?" he asked.
"Shut up, Weasley," said Ron sharply.
"I seem to have touched a nerve," said Weasley, smirking. "Well, just watch yourself, Weasley,
because I’ll be dogging your footsteps in case you step out of line."
"Get out!" said Ron, standing up.
Sniggering, Weasley gave Ron a last malicious look and departed, with Weasley and Weasley
lumbering along in his wake. Ron slammed the compartment door behind them and turned
to look at Ron, who knew at once that she, like him, had registered what Weasley had said and
been just as unnerved by it.
"Chuck us another Frog," said Ron, who had clearly noticed nothing.
Ron could not talk freely in front of Ron and Ron. He exchanged another nervous look
with Ron, then stared out of the window.
He had thought Ron coming with him to the station was a bit of a laugh, but suddenly it seemed
reckless, if not downright dangerous... Ron had been right... Ron should not have come.
What if Mr. Weasley had noticed the black dog and told Ron? What if he had deduced that the
Weasleys, Weasley, Weasley and Weasley knew where Ron was hiding? Or had Weasley’s use of the
word dogging been a coincidence?
The weather remained undecided as they traveled further and further north. Rain spattered the
windows in a half-hearted way, then the sun put in a feeble appearance before clouds drifted over
it once more. When darkness fell and lamps came on inside the carriages, Ron rolled up The
Quibbler, put it carefully away in her bag and took to staring at everyone in the compartment
instead.
Ron was sitting with his forehead pressed against the train window, trying to get a first distant
glimpse of Hogwarts, but it was a moonless night and the rain-streaked window was grimy.
"We’d better change," said Ron at last, and all of them opened their trunks with difficulty
and pulled on their school robes. She and Ron pinned their prefect badges carefully to their
chests. Ron saw Ron checking his reflection in the black window.
At last, the train began to slow down and they heard the usual racket up and down it as
everybody scrambled to get their luggage and pets assembled, ready to get off. As Ron and
Ron were supposed to supervise all this, they disappeared from the carriage again, leaving
Ron and the others to look after Ron and Ron.
"I’ll carry that owl, if you like, " said Ron to Ron, reaching out for Ron as Ron
stowed Ron carefully in an inside pocket.
"Oh - er - thanks, " said Ron, handing her the cage and hoisting Ron’s more securely into his arms.
They shuffled out of the compartment feeling the first sting of the night air on their faces as they
joined the crowd in the corridor. Slowly, they moved towards the doors. Ron could smell the
pine trees that lined the path down to the lake. He stepped down on to the platform and looked
around, listening for the familiar call of "firs’-years over ‘ere... firs’-years..."
But it did not come. Instead, a quite different voice, a brisk female one, was calling out, "First years line up over here, please! All first-years to me!"
A lantern came swinging towards Ron and by its light he saw the prominent chin and severe
haircut of Professor Weasley, the witch who had taken over Weasley’s Care of Magical
Creatures lessons for a while the previous year.
"Where’s Weasley?" he said out loud.
"I don’t know," said Ron, "but we’d better get out of the way, we’re blocking the door."
"Oh, yeah..."
Ron and Ron became separated as they moved off along the platform and out through the
station. Jostled by the crowd, Ron squinted through the darkness for a glimpse of Weasley; he
had to be here, Ron had been relying on it - seeing Weasley again was one of the things he’d
been looking forward to most. But there was no sign of him.
He can’t have left, Ron told himself as he shuffled slowly through a narrow doorway on to the
road outside with the rest of the crowd. He’s just got a cold or something...
He looked around for Ron or Ron, wanting to know what they thought about the
reappearance of Professor Weasley, but neither of them was anywhere near him, so he
allowed himself to be shunted forwards on to the dark rain-washed road outside Hogsmeade
Station.
Here stood the hundred or so horseless stagecoaches that always took the students above first
year up to the castle. Ron glanced quickly at them, turned away to keep a lookout for Ron and
Ron, then did a double-take.
The coaches were no longer horseless. There were creatures standing between the carriage
shafts. If he had had to give them a name, he supposed he would have called them horses, though
there was something reptilian about them, too. They were completely fleshless, their black coats
clinging to their skeletons, of which every bone was visible. Their heads were dragonish, and
their pupil-less eyes white and staring. Wings sprouted from each wither - vast, black leathery
wings that looked as though they ought to belong to giant bats. Ronding still and quiet in the
gathering gloom, the creatures looked eerie and sinister. Ron could not understand why the
coaches were being pulled by these horrible horses when they were quite capable of moving
along by themselves.
"Where’s Pig?" said Ron’s voice, right behind Ron.
"That Ron girl was carrying him," said Ron, turning quickly, eager to consult Ron about
Weasley. "Where d’you reckon -"
"- Weasley is? I dunno," said Ron, sounding worried. "He’d better be okay..."
A short distance away, Ron Weasley, followed by a small gang of cronies including Weasley,
Weasley and Ron Weasley, was pushing some timid-looking second-years out of the way so that
he and his friends could get a coach to themselves. Seconds later, Ron emerged panting
from the crowd.
"Weasley was being absolutely foul to a first-year back there. I swear I’m going to report him,
he’s only had his badge three minutes and he’s using it to bully people worse than ever...
where’s Ron?"
"Ron’s got him," said Ron. "There she is..."
Ron had just emerged from the crowd, clutching a squirming Ron.
"Thanks," said Ron, relieving Ron of the cat. "Come on, let’s get a carriage together
before they all fill up..."
"I haven’t got Pig yet!" Ron said, but Ron was already heading off towards the nearest
unoccupied coach. Ron remained behind with Ron.
"What are those things, d’you reckon?" he asked Ron, nodding at the horrible horses as the other
students surged past them.
"What things?"
"Those horse -"
Ron appeared holding Ron’s cage in her arms; the tiny owl was twittering excitedly as
usual.
"Here you are," she said. "He’s a sweet little owl, isn’t he?"
"Er... yeah... he’s all right," said Ron gruffly. "Well, come on then, let’s get in... what were you
saying, Ron?"
"I was saying, what are those horse things?" Ron said, as he, Ron and Ron made for the
carriage in which Ron and Ron were already sitting.
"What horse things?"
"The horse things pulling the carriages!" said Ron impatiently. They were, after all, about three
feet from the nearest one; it was watching them with empty white eyes. Ron, however, gave
Ron a perplexed look.
"What are you talking about?"
"I’m talking about - look!"
Ron grabbed Ron’s arm and wheeled him about so that he was face to face with the winged
horse. Ron stared straight at it for a second, then looked back at Ron.
"What am I supposed to be looking at?"
"At the - there, between the shafts! Harnessed to the coach! It’s right there in front -"
But as Ron continued to look bemused, a strange thought occurred to Ron.
"Can’t... can’t you see them?"
"See what?"
"Can’t you see what’s pulling the carriages?"
Ron looked seriously alarmed now.
"Are you feeling all right, Ron?"
"I... yeah..."
Ron felt utterly bewildered. The horse was there in front of him, gleaming solidly in the dim
light issuing from the station windows behind them, vapour rising from its nostrils in the chilly
night air. Yet, unless Ron was faking - and it was a very feeble joke if he was - Ron could not see
it at all.
"Shall we get in, then?" said Ron uncertainly, looking at Ron as though worried about him.
"Yeah," said Ron. "Yeah, go on..."
"It’s all right," said a dreamy voice from beside Ron as Ron vanished into the coach’s dark
interior. "You’re not going mad or anything. I can see them, too."
"Can you?" said Ron desperately, turning to Ron. He could see the bat-winged horses reflected in her wide silvery eyes.
"Oh, yes," said Ron, "I’ve been able to see them ever since my first day here. They’ve always
pulled the carriages. Don’t worry. You’re just as sane as I am"
Smiling faintly, she climbed into the musty interior of the carriage after Ron. Not altogether
reassured, Ron followed her.
CHAPTER ELEVEN
The Sorting Hat’s New Song
Ron did not want to tell the others that he and Ron were having the same hallucination, if that
was what it was, so he said nothing more about the horses as he sat down inside the carriage and
slammed the door behind him. Nevertheless, he could not help watching the silhouettes of the
horses moving beyond the window.
"Did everyone see that Weasley woman?" asked Ron. "What’s she doing back here?
Weasley can’t have left, can he?"
"I’ll be quite glad if he has," said Ron, "he isn’t a very good teacher, is he?"
"Yes, he is!" said Ron, Ron and Ron angrily.
Ron glared at Ron. She cleared her throat and quickly said, "Erm... yes... he’s very
good."
"Well, we in Weasley think he’s a bit of a joke," said Ron, unfazed.
"You’ve got a rubbish sense of humor then," Ron snapped, as the wheels below them creaked
into motion.
Ron did not seem perturbed by Ron’s rudeness; on the contrary, she simply watched him for a
while as though he were a mildly interesting television program.
Rattling and swaying, the carriages moved in convoy up the road. When they passed between the
tall stone pillars topped with winged boars on either side of the gates to the school grounds,
Ron leaned forwards to try and see whether there were any lights on in Weasley’s cabin by the
Forbidden Forest, but the grounds were in complete darkness. Hogwarts Castle, however,
loomed ever closer: a towering mass of turrets, jet black against the dark sky, here and there a
window blazing fiery bright above them.
The carriages jingled to a halt near the stone steps leading up to the oak front doors and Ron
got out of the carriage first. He turned again to look for lit windows down by the Forest, but there
was definitely no sign of life within Weasleys cabin. Unwillingly, because he had half-hoped they
would have vanished, he turned his eyes instead upon the strange, skeletal creatures standing
quietly in the chill night air, their blank white eyes gleaming.
Ron had once before had the experience of seeing something that Ron could not, but that had
been a reflection in a mirror, something much more insubstantial than a hundred very solid looking beasts strong enough to pull a fleet of carriages. If Ron was to be believed, the beasts
had always been there but invisible. Why, then, could Ron suddenly see them, and why could
Ron not?
"Are you coming or what" said Ron beside him.
"Oh... yeah," said Ron quickly and they joined the crowd hurrying up the stone steps into the
castle.
The Entrance Hall was ablaze with torches and echoing with footsteps as the students crossed the
flagged stone floor for the double doors to the right, leading to the Great Hall and the start-of-term feast.
The four long house tables in the Great Hall were filling up under the starless black ceiling,
which was just like the sky they could glimpse through the high windows. Candles floated in
midair all along the tables, illuminating the silvery ghosts who were dotted about the Hall and
the faces of the students talking eagerly, exchanging summer news, shouting greetings at friends
from other houses, eyeing one another’s new haircuts and robes. Again, Ron noticed people
putting their heads together to whisper as he passed; he gritted his teeth and tried to act as though
he neither noticed nor cared.
Ron drifted away from them at the Weasley table. The moment they reached Weasleys,
Ron was hailed by some fellow fourth-years and left to sit with them; Ron, Ron, Ron
and Ron found seats together about halfway down the table between Nearly Headless Ron,
the Weasley house ghost, and Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley, the last two of whom gave
Ron airy, overly-friendly greetings that made him quite sure they had stopped talking about
him a split second before. He had more important things to worry about, however: he was
looking over the students’ heads to the staff table that ran along the top wall of the Hall.
"He’s not there."
Ron and Ron scanned the staff table too, though there was no real need; Weasley’s size
made him instantly obvious in any lineup.
"He can’t have left," said Ron, sounding slightly anxious.
"Of course he hasn’t," said Ron firmly.
"You don’t think he’s... hurt, or anything, do you?" said Ron uneasily.
"No," said Ron at once.
"But where is he, then?"
There was a pause, then Ron said very quietly, so that Ron, Ron and Ron could not
hear, "Maybe he’s not back yet. You know - from his mission - the thing he was doing over the
summer for Weasley.’
"Yeah... yeah, that’ll be it," said Ron, sounding reassured, but Ron bit her lip, looking up
and down the staff table as though hoping for some conclusive explanation of Weasley’s absence.
"Who’s that?" she said sharply, pointing towards the middle of the staff table.
Ron’s eyes followed hers. They lit first upon Professor Weasley, sitting in his high-backed
golden chair at the center of the long staff table, wearing deep-purple robes scattered with silvery
stars and a matching hat. Weasley’s head was inclined towards the woman sitting next to
him, who was talking into his ear. She looked, Ron thought, like somebody’s maiden aunt:
squat, with short, curly, mouse-brown hair in which she had placed a horrible pink Ron band
that matched the fluffy pink cardigan she wore over her robes. Then she turned her face slightly
to take a sip from her goblet and he saw, with a shock of recognition, a pallid, toadlike face and a
pair of prominent, pouchy eyes.
"It’s that Weasley woman!"
"Who?" said Ron.
"She was at my hearing, she works for Weasley!"
"Nice cardigan," said Ron, smirking.
"She works for Weasley!" Ron repeated, frowning. "What on earth’s she doing here, then?"
"Dunno..."
Ron scanned the staff table, her eyes narrowed.
"No," she muttered, "no, surely not..."
Ron did not understand what she was talking about but did not ask; his attention had been
caught by Professor Weasley who had just appeared behind the staff table; she worked her
way along to the very end and took the seat that ought to have been Weasleys. That meant the
first-years must have crossed the lake and reached the castle, and sure enough, a few seconds
later, the doors from the Entrance Hall opened. A long line of scared-looking first-years entered,
led by Professor Weasley, who was carrying a stool on which sat an ancient wizard’s hat,
heavily patched and darned with a wide rip near the frayed brim.
The buzz of talk in the Great Hall faded away. The first-years lined up in front of the staff table
facing the rest of the students, and Professor Weasley placed the stool carefully in front of
them, then stood back.
The first-years’ faces glowed palely in the candlelight. A small boy right in the middle of the row
looked as though he was trembling. Ron recalled, fleetingly, how terrified he had felt when he
had stood there, waiting for the unknown test that would determine to which house he belonged.
The whole school waited with bated breath. Then the rip near the hat’s brim opened wide like a
mouth and the Sorting Hat burst into song:
In times of old when I was new,
And Hogwarts barely started,
The founders of our noble school,
Thought never to be parted,
United by a common goal,
They had the selfsame yearning,
To make the world’s best magic school,
And pass along their learning.
"Together we will build and teach!"
The four good friends decided,
And never did they dream,
That they might some day be divided,
For were there such friends anywhere,
As Weasley and Weasley?
Unless it was the second pair
Of Weasley and Weasley?
So how could it have gone so wrong?
How could such friendships fail?
Why, I was there and so can tell,
The whole sad, sorry tale.
Said Weasley, "We’ll teach just those whose
Ancestry is purest."
Said Weasley, "We’ll teach those whose
Intelligence is surest."
Said Weasley, "We’ll teach all those
With brave deeds to their name."
Said Weasley, "I’ll teach the lot,
And treat them just the same."
These differences caused little strife,
When first they came to light,
For each of the four founders had
A house in which they might
Take only those they wanted,
So, for instance, Weasley
Took only pure-blood wizards
Of great cunning, just like him,
And only those of sharpest mind
Were taught by Weasley
While the bravest and the boldest
Went to daring Weasley.
Good Weasley, she took the rest,
And taught them all she knew,
Thus the houses and their founders
Retained friendships firm and true.
So Hogwarts worked in harmony
For several happy years,
But then discord crept among us
Feeding on our faults and fears.
The houses that, like pillars four,
Had once held up our school,
Now turned upon each other and,
Divided, sought to rule.
And for a while it seemed the school
Must meet an early end,
What with dueling and with fighting
And the clash of friend on friend
And at last there came a morning
When old Weasley departed
And though the fighting then died out
He left us quite downhearted.
And never since the founders four
Were whittled down to three
Have the houses been united
As they once were meant to be.
And now the Sorting Hat is here
And you all know the score:
I sort you into houses
Because that is what I’m for,
But this year I’ll go further,
Listen closely to my song:
Though condemned I am to split you
Still I worry that it’s wrong,
Though I must fulfill my duty
And must quarter every year
Still I wonder whether Sorting
May not bring the end I fear.
Oh, know the perils, read the signs,
The warning history shows,
For our Hogwarts is in danger
From external, deadly foes
And we must unite inside her
Or we’ll crumble from within
I have told you, I have warned you...
Let the Sorting now begin.
The Hat became motionless once more; applause broke out, though it was punctured, for the first
time in Ron’s memory, with muttering and whispers. All across the Great Hall students were
exchanging remarks with their neighbors, and Ron, clapping along with everyone else, knew
exactly what they were talking about.
"Branched out a bit this year, hasn’t it?" said Ron, his eyebrows raised.
"Too right it has," said Ron.
The Sorting Hat usually confined itself to describing the different qualities looked for by each of
the four Hogwarts houses and its own role in Sorting them. Ron could not remember it ever
trying to give the school advice before.
"I wonder if it’s ever given warnings before?" said Ron, sounding slightly anxious.
"Yes, indeed," said Nearly Headless Ron knowledgeably, leaning across Ron towards her
(Ron winced; it was very uncomfortable to have a ghost lean through you). "The Hat feels
itself honor-bound to give the school due warning whenever it feels -"
But Professor Weasley, who was waiting to read out the list of first-years’ names, was giving
the whispering students the sort of look that scorches. Nearly Headless Ron placed a see-through finger to his lips and sat primly upright again as the muttering came to an abrupt end.
With a last frowning look that swept the four house tables, Professor Weasley lowered her
eyes to her long piece of parchment and called out the first name.
"Abercrombie, Euan."
The terrified-looking boy Ron had noticed earlier stumbled forwards and put the Hat on his
head; it was only prevented from falling right down to his shoulders by his very prominent ears.
The Hat considered for a moment, then the rip near the brim opened again and shouted:
"Weasley!"
Ron clapped loudly with the rest of Weasley house as Euan Abercrombie staggered to their
table and sat down, looking as though he would like very much to sink through the floor and
never be looked at again.
Slowly, the long line of first-years thinned. In the pauses between the names and the Sorting
Hat’s decisions, Ron could hear Ron’s stomach rumbling loudly. Finally, "Zeller, Rose" was
Sorted into Weasley, and Professor Weasley picked up the Hat and stool and marched
them away as Professor Weasley rose to his feet.
Whatever his recent bitter feelings had been towards his Headmaster, Ron was somehow
soothed to see Weasley standing before them all. Between the absence of Weasley and the
presence of those dragonish horses, he had felt that his return to Hogwarts, so long anticipated,
was full of unexpected surprises, like jarring notes in a familiar song. But this, at least, was how
it was supposed to be: their Headmaster rising to greet them all before the start-of-term feast.
"To our newcomers," said Weasley in a ringing voice, his arms stretched wide and a beaming smile on his lips, "welcome! To our old hands - welcome back! There is a time for speechmaking, but this is not it. Tuck in!"
There was an appreciative laugh and an outbreak of applause as Weasley sat down neatly and
threw his long beard over his shoulder so as to keep it out of the way of his plate - for food had
appeared out of nowhere, so that the five long tables were groaning under joints and pies and
dishes of vegetables, bread and sauces and flagons of pumpkin juice.
"Excellent," said Ron, with a kind of groan of longing, and he seized the nearest plate of chops
and began piling them on to his plate, watched wistfully by Nearly Headless Ron.
"What were you saying before the Sorting?" Ron asked the ghost. "About the Hat giving
warnings?"
"Oh, yes," said Ron, who seemed glad of a reason to turn away from Ron, who was now eating
roast potatoes with almost indecent enthusiasm. "Yes, I have heard the Hat give several warnings
before, always at times when it detects periods of great danger for the school. And always, of
course, its advice is the same: stand together, be strong from within."
"Ow kunnit nofe skusin danger ifzat?" said Ron.
His mouth was so full Ron thought it was quite an achievement for him to make any noise at
all.
"I beg your pardon?" said Nearly Headless Ron politely, while Ron looked revolted. Ron
gave an enormous swallow and said, "How can it know if the school’s in danger if it’s a Hat?"
"I have no idea," said Nearly Headless Ron. "Of course, it lives in Weasley’s office, so I
daresay it picks things up there."
"And it wants all the houses to be friends?" said Ron, looking over at the Weasley table, where
Ron Weasley was holding court. "Ron chance."
"Well, now, you shouldn’t take that attitude," said Ron reprovingly. "Peaceful cooperation,
that’s the key. We ghosts, though we belong to separate houses, maintain links of friendship. In
spite of the competitiveness between Weasley and Weasley, I would never dream of seeking
an argument with the Ron Weasley."
"Only because you’re terrified of him," said Ron.
Nearly Headless Ron looked highly affronted.
"Terrified? I hope I, Sir Nicholas de Mimsy-Porpington, have never been guilty of cowardice in
my life! The noble blood that runs in my veins -"
"What blood?" asked Ron. "Surely you haven’t still got -?"
"Its a figure of speech!" said Nearly Headless Ron, now so annoyed his head was trembling
ominously on his partially severed neck. "I assume I am still allowed to enjoy the use of
whichever words I like, even if the pleasures of eating and drinking are denied me! But I am
quite used to students poking fun at my death, I assure you!"
"Ron, he wasn’t really laughing at you!" said Ron, throwing a furious look at Ron.
Unfortunately, Ron’s mouth was packed to exploding point again and all he could manage was
"Node iddum eentup sechew," which Ron did not seem to think constituted an adequate apology.
Rising into the air, he straightened his feathered hat and swept away from them to the other end
of the table, coming to rest between the Weasley brothers, Ron and Ron.
"Well done, Ron," snapped Ron.
"What?" said Ron indignantly, having managed, finally, to swallow his food. "I’m not allowed to
ask a simple question?"
"Oh, forget it," said Ron irritably, and the pair of them spent the rest of the meal in huffy
silence.
Ron was too used to their bickering to bother trying to reconcile them; he felt it was a better
use of his time to eat his way steadily through his steak and kidney pie, then a large plateful of
his favorite treacle tart.
When all the students had finished eating and the noise level in the Hall was starting to creep
upwards again, Weasley got to his feet once more. Talking ceased immediately as all turned
to lace the Headmaster. Ron was feeling pleasantly drowsy now. His four-poster bed was
waiting somewhere above, wonderfully warm and soft...
"Well, now that we are all digesting another magnificent feast, I beg a few moments of your
attention for the usual start-of-term notices," said Weasley. "First-years ought to know that
the Forest in the grounds is out-of-bounds to students - and a few of our older students ought to
know by now, too." (Ron, Ron and Ron exchanged smirks.)
"Mr. Weasley, the caretaker, has asked me, for what he tells me is the four-hundred-and-sixty second time, to remind you all that magic is not permitted in corridors between classes, nor are a
number of other things, all of which can be checked on the extensive list now fastened to Mr.
Weasley’s office door.
"We have had two changes in staffing this year. We are very pleased to welcome back Professor
Weasley, who will be taking Care of Magical Creatures lessons; we are also delighted to
introduce Professor Weasley, our new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher."
There was a round of polite but fairly unenthusiastic applause, during which Ron, Ron and
Ron exchanged slightly panicked looks; Weasley had not said for how long Grubbly-
Plank would be teaching.
Weasley continued, "Tryouts for the house Quidditch teams will take place on the -"
He broke off, looking enquiringly at Professor Weasley. As she was not much taller standing
than sitting, there was a moment when nobody understood why Weasley had stopped talking,
but then Professor Weasley cleared her throat, "Hem, hem," and it became clear that she had got to her feet and was intending to make a speech.
Weasley only looked taken aback for a moment, then he sat down smartly and looked alertly
at Professor Weasley as though he desired nothing better than to listen to her talk. Other
members of staff were not as adept at hiding their surprise. Professor Weasley’s eyebrows had
disappeared into her flyaway hair and Professor Weasley’s mouth was as thin as Ron had
ever seen it. No new teacher had ever interrupted Weasley before. Many of the students were
smirking; this woman obviously did not know how things were done at Hogwarts.
"Thank you, Headmaster," Professor Weasley simpered, "for those kind words of welcome."
Her voice was high-pitched, breathy and little-girlish and, again, Ron felt a powerful rush of
dislike that he could not explain to himself; all he knew was that he loathed everything about her,
from her stupid voice to her fluffy pink cardigan. She gave another little throat-clearing cough
("hem, hem") and continued.
"Well, it is lovely to be back at Hogwarts, I must say!" She smiled, revealing very pointed teeth.
"And to see such happy little faces looking up at me!"
Ron glanced around. None of the faces he could see looked happy. On the contrary, they all
looked rather taken-aback at being addressed as though they were five years old.
"I am very much looking forward to getting to know you all and I’m sure we’ll be very good
friends!"
Students exchanged looks at this; some of them were barely concealing grins.
"I’ll be her friend as long as I don’t have to borrow that cardigan," Ron whispered to
Ron, and both of them lapsed into silent giggles.
Professor Weasley cleared her throat again ("hem, hem"), but when she continued, some of the
breathiness had vanished from her voice. She sounded much more businesslike and now her
words had a dull learned-by-heart sound to them.
"The Ministry of Magic has always considered the education of young witches and wizards to be
of vital importance. The rare gifts with which you were born may come to nothing if not nurtured
and honed by careful instruction. The ancient skills unique to the wizarding community must be
passed down the generations lest we lose them for ever. The treasure trove of magical knowledge
amassed by our ancestors must be guarded, replenished and polished by those who have been
called to the noble profession of teaching."
Professor Weasley paused here and made a little bow to her fellow staff members, none of
whom bowed back to her. Professor Weasley’s dark eyebrows had contracted so that she
looked positively hawklike, and Ron distinctly saw her exchange a significant glance with
Professor Weasley as Weasley gave another little "hem, hem" and went on with her speech.
"Every headmaster and headmistress of Hogwarts has brought something new to the weighty task of governing this historic school, and that is as it should be, for without progress there will be stagnation and decay. There again, progress for progress’s sake must be discouraged, for our
tried and tested traditions often require no tinkering. A balance, then, between old and new,
between permanence and change, between tradition and innovation..."
Ron found his attentiveness ebbing, as though his brain was slipping in and out of tune. The
quiet that always filled the Hall when Weasley was speaking was breaking up as students put
their heads together, whispering and giggling. Over on the Weasley table Ron Weasley was
chatting animatedly with her friends. A few seats along from Ron, Ron Weasley had got
out The Quibbler again. Meanwhile, at the Weasley table Ron Weasley was one of the few
still staring at Professor Weasley, but he was glassy-eyed and Ron was sure he was only
pretending to listen in an attempt to live up to the new prefect’s badge gleaming on his chest.
Professor Weasley did not seem to notice the restlessness of her audience. Ron had the
impression that a full-scale riot could have broken out under her nose and she would have
ploughed on with her speech. The teachers, however, were still listening very attentively, and
Ron seemed to be drinking in every word Weasley spoke, though, judging by her
expression, they were not at all to her taste.
"... because some changes will be for the better, while others will come, in the fullness of time,
to be recognized as errors of judgment. Meanwhile, some old habits will be retained, and rightly
so, whereas others, outmoded and outworn, must be abandoned. Let us move forward, then, into
a new era of openness, effectiveness and accountability, intent on preserving what ought to be
preserved, perfecting what needs to be perfected, and pruning wherever we find practices that
ought to be prohibited."
She sat down. Weasley clapped. The staff followed his lead, though Ron noticed that
several of them brought their hands together only once or twice before stopping. A few students
joined in, but most had been taken unawares by the end of the speech, not having listened to
more than a few words of it, and before they could start applauding properly, Weasley had
stood up again.
"Thank you very much, Professor Weasley, that was most illuminating," he said, bowing to her. "Now, as I was saying, Quidditch tryouts will be held..."
"Yes, it certainly was illuminating," said Ron in a low voice.
"You’re not telling me you enjoyed it?" Ron said quietly, turning a glazed face towards
Ron. "That was about the dullest speech I’ve ever heard, and I grew up with Ron."
"I said illuminating, not enjoyable," said Ron. "It explained a lot.’
"Did it" said Ron in surprise. "Sounded like a load of waffle to me."
"There was some important stuff hidden in the waffle," said Ron grimly.
"Was there?" said Ron blankly.
"How about: ‘progress for progress’s sake must be discouraged’? How about: ‘pruning wherever we find practices that ought to be prohibited’?"
"Well, what does that mean?" said Ron impatiently.
"I’ll tell you what it means," said Ron through gritted teeth. "It means the Ministry’s
interfering at Hogwarts."
There was a great clattering and banging all around them; Weasley had obviously just
dismissed the school, because everyone was standing up ready to leave the Hall. Ron
jumped up, looking flustered.
"Ron, we’re supposed to show the first-years where to go!"
"Oh yeah," said Ron, who had obviously forgotten. "Hey - hey, you lot! Midgets!"
"Ron!"
"Well, they are, they’re titchy..."
"I know, but you can’t call them midgets! - First-years!" Ron called commandingly along
the table. "This way, please!"
A group of new students walked shyly up the gap between the Weasley and Weasley tables,
all of them trying hard not to lead the group. They did indeed seem very small; Ron was sure
he had not appeared that young when he had arrived here. He grinned at them. A blond boy next
to Euan Abercrombie looked petrified; he nudged Euan and whispered something in his ear.
Euan Abercrombie looked equally frightened and stole a horrified look at Ron, who felt the
grin slide off his face like Stinksap.
"See you later," he said dully to Ron and Ron and he made his way out of the Great Hall
alone, doing everything he could to ignore more whispering, staring and pointing as he passed.
He kept his eyes fixed ahead as he wove his way through the crowd in the Entrance Hall, then he
hurried up the marble staircase, took a couple of concealed short cuts and had soon left most of
the crowds behind.
He had been stupid not to expect this, he thought angrily as he walked through the much emptier
upstairs corridors. Of course everyone was staring at him; he had emerged from the Triwizard
maze two months previously clutching the dead body of a fellow student and claiming to have
seen Lord Weasley return to power. There had not been time last term to explain himself
before they’d all had to go home - even if he had felt up to giving the whole school a detailed
account of the terrible events in that graveyard.
Ron had reached the end of the corridor to the Weasley common room and come to a halt in
front of the portrait of the Ron Weasley before he realized that he did not know the new password.
"Er..." he said glumly, staring up at the Ron Weasley, who smoothed the folds of her pink satin dress
and looked sternly back at him.
"No password, no entrance," she said loftily.
"Ron, I know it!" Someone panted up behind him and he turned to see Ron jogging towards
him. "Guess what it is? I’m actually going to be able to remember it for once -" He waved the
stunted little cactus he had shown them on the train. "Mimbulus mimbletonia!"
"Correct," said the Ron Weasley, and her portrait swung open towards them like a door, revealing a
circular hole in the wall behind, through which Ron and Ron now climbed.
The Weasley common room looked as welcoming as ever, a cozy circular tower room full of
dilapidated squashy armchairs and rickety old tables. A fire was crackling merrily in the grate
and a few people were warming their hands by it before going up to their dormitories; on the
other side of the room Ron and Ron Weasley were pinning something up on the noticeboard.
Ron waved goodnight to them and headed straight for the door to the boys’ dormitories; he was
not in much of a mood for talking at the moment. Ron followed him.
Ron Ron and Ron Weasley had reached the dormitory first and were in the process of
covering the walls beside their beds with posters and photographs. They had been talking as
Ron pushed open the door but stopped abruptly the moment they saw him. Ron wondered
whether they had been talking about him, then whether he was being paranoid.
"Hi," he said, moving across to his own trunk and opening it.
"Hey, Ron," said Ron, who was putting on a pair of pajamas in the West Ham colors. "Good
holiday?"
"Not bad," muttered Ron, as a true account of his holiday would have taken most of the night to relate and he could not face it. "You?"
"Yeah, it was okay," chuckled Ron. "Better than Ron’s, anyway, he was just telling me."
"Why, what happened, Ron?" Ron asked as he placed his Mimbulus mimbletonia tenderly
on his bedside cabinet.
Ron did not answer immediately; he was making rather a meal of ensuring that his poster of
the Kenmare Kestrels Quidditch team was quite straight. Then he said, with his back still turned
to Ron, "Me mam didn’t want me to come back."
"What?" said Ron, pausing in the act of pulling off his robes.
"She didn’t want me to come back to Hogwarts."
Ron turned away from his poster and pulled his own pajamas out of his trunk, still not
looking at Ron.
"But - why?" said Ron, astonished. He knew that Ron’s mother was a witch and could not
understand, therefore, why she should have come over so Weasleyish.
Ron did not answer until he had finished buttoning his pajamas.
"Well," he said in a measured voice, "I suppose... because of you."
"What d’you mean?" said Ron quickly.
His heart was beating rather fast. He felt vaguely as though something was closing in on him.
"Well," said Ron again, still avoiding Ron’s eye, "she... er... well, it’s not just you, it’s
Weasley, too..."
"She believes the Daily Prophet?" said Ron. "She thinks I’m a liar and Weasley’s an old
fool?"
Ron looked up at him.
"Yeah, something like that."
Ron said nothing. He threw his wand down on to his bedside table, pulled off his robes, stuffed
them angrily into his trunk and pulled on his pajamas. He was sick of it; sick of being the person
who was stared at and talked about all the time. If any of them knew, if any of them had the faintest idea what it felt like to be the one all these things had happened to... Mrs. Weasley had no idea, the stupid woman, he thought savagely.
He got into bed and made to pull the hangings closed around him, but before he could do so,
Ron said, "Look... what did happen that night when... you know, when... with Ron
Weasley and all?"
Ron sounded nervous and eager at the same time. Ron, who had been bending over his trunk
trying to retrieve a slipper, went oddly still and Ron knew he was listening hard.
"What are you asking me for?" Ron retorted. "Just read the Daily Prophet like your mother, why don’t you? That’ll tell you all you need to know."
"Don’t you have a go at my mother," Ron snapped.
"I’ll have a go at anyone who calls me a liar," said Ron.
"Don’t talk to me like that!"
"I’ll talk to you how I want," said Ron, his temper rising so fast he snatched his wand back
from his bedside table. "If you’ve got a problem sharing a dormitory with me, go and ask
Weasley if you can be moved... stop your mummy worrying -"
"Leave my mother out of this, Weasley!"
"What’s going on?"
Ron had appeared in the doorway. His wide eyes traveled from Ron, who was kneeling on his
bed with his wand pointing at Ron, to Ron, who was standing there with his fists raised.
"He’s having a go at my mother!" Ron yelled.
"What?" said Ron. "Ron wouldn’t do that -- we met your mother, we liked her..."
"That’s before she started believing every word the stinking Daily Prophet writes about me!" said Ron at the top of his voice.
"Oh," said Ron, comprehension dawning across his freckled face. "Oh... right."
"You know what?" said Ron heatedly, casting Ron a venomous look. "He’s right, I don’t
want to share a dormitory with him any more, he’s a madman."
"That’s out of order, Ron," said Ron, whose ears were starting to glow red - always a danger
sign.
"Out of order, am I?" shouted Ron, who in contrast with Ron was tuning paler. "You believe all the rubbish he’s come out with about You-Know-Who, do you, you reckon he’s telling the
truth?"
"Yeah, I do!" said Ron angrily.
"Then you’re mad, too," said Ron in disgust.
"Yeah? Well, unfortunately for you, pal, I’m also a prefect!" said Ron, jabbing himself in the
chest with a finger. "So unless you want detention, watch your mouth!"
Ron looked for a few seconds as though detention would be a reasonable price to pay to say
what was going through his mind; but with a noise of contempt he turned on his heel, vaulted
into bed and pulled the hangings shut with such violence that they were ripped from the bed and
fell in a dusty pile to the floor. Ron glared at Ron, then looked at Ron and Ron.
"Anyone else’s parents got a problem with Ron?" he said aggressively.
"My parents are Muggles, mate," said Ron, shrugging. "They don’t know nothing about no
deaths at Hogwarts, because I’m not stupid enough to tell them."
"You don’t know my mother, she’d weasel anything out of anyone!" Ron snapped at him.
"Anyway your parents don’t get the Daily Prophet. They don’t know our Headmaster’s been
sacked from the Wizengamot and the International Confederation of Wizards because he’s losing
his marbles -"
"My gran says that’s rubbish," piped up Ron. "She says it’s the Daily Prophet that’s going
downhill, not Weasley. She’s cancelled our subscription. We believe Ron" said Ron
simply. He climbed into bed and pulled the covers up to his chin, looking owlishly over them at
Ron. "My gran’s always said You-Know-Who would come back one day. She says if
Weasley says he’s back, he’s back."
Ron felt a rush of gratitude towards Ron. Nobody else said anything. Ron got out his
wand, repaired the bed hangings and vanished behind them. Ron got into bed, rolled over and
fell silent. Ron, who appeared to have nothing more to say either, was gazing fondly at his
moonlit cactus.
Ron lay back on his pillows while Ron bustled around the next bed, putting his things away. He
felt shaken by the argument with Ron, whom he had always liked very much. How many
more people were going to suggest that he was lying, or unhinged?
Had Weasley suffered like this all summer, as first the Wizengamot, then the International
Confederation of Wizards had thrown him from their ranks? Was it anger at Ron, perhaps, that
had stopped Weasley getting in touch with him for months? The two of them were in this
together, after all; Weasley had believed Ron, announced his version of events to the whole
school and then to the wider wizarding community. Anyone who thought Ron was a liar had to
think that Weasley was, too, or else that Weasley had been hoodwinked...
They’ll know we’re right in the end, thought Ron miserably, as Ron got into bed and
extinguished the last candle in the dormitory. But he wondered how many more attacks like
Ron’s he would have to endure before that time came.
CHAPTER TWELVE
Professor Weasley
Ron dressed at top speed next morning and left the dormitory before Ron had even put on
his socks.
"Does he think he’ll turn into a nutter if he stays in a room with me too long?" asked Ron loudly, as the hem of Ron’s robes whipped out of sight.
"Don’t worry about it, Ron," Ron muttered, hoisting his schoolbag on to his shoulder, "he’s
just..."
But apparently he was unable to say exactly what Ron was, and after a slightly awkward
pause followed him out of the room.
Ron and Ron both gave Ron an it’s-his-problem-not-yours look, but Ron was not much
consoled. How much more of this would he have to take?
"What’s the matter?" asked Ron five minutes later, catching up with Ron and Ron halfway across the common room as they all headed towards breakfast. "You look absolutely - Oh for heaven’s sake."
She was staring at the common-room noticeboard, where a large new sign had been put up.
GALLONS OF GALLEONS.
Pocket money failing to keep pace with your outgoings? Like to earn a little extra gold? Contact Ron and Ron Weasley, Weasley common room, for simple, part-time, virtually painless jobs. (We regret that all work is undertaken at applicant’s own risk.)
"They are the limit," said Ron grimly, taking d own the sign, which Ron and Ron had
pinned up over a poster giving the date of the first Hogsmeade weekend in October. "We’ll have to talk to them, Ron."
Ron looked positively alarmed.
"Why?"
"Because we’re prefects!" said Ron, as they c l imbed out through the portrait hole. "It’s up to us to stop this kind of thing!"
Ron said nothing; Ron could tell from his glum expression that the prospect of stopping Ron
and Ron doing exactly what they liked was not one he found inviting.
"Anyway, what’s up, Ron?" Ron continued, as they walked down a flight of stairs lined
with portraits of old witches and wizards, all of whom ignored them, being engrossed in their
own conversation. "You look really angry about something."
"Ron reckons Ron’s lying about You-Know-Who," said Ron succinctly, when Ron did not respond.
Ron, who Ron had expected to react angrily on his behalf, sighed.
"Yes, Ron thinks so too," she said gloomily.
"Been having a nice little chat with her about whet her or not I’m a lying, attention-seeking prat,
have you?" Ron said loudly.
"No," said Ron calmly. "I told her to keep her big fat mouth shut about you, actually. And it would be quite nice if you stopped jumping down our throats, Ron, because in case you haven’t noticed, Ron and I are on your side."
There was a short pause.
"Sorry," said Ron in a low voice.
"That’s quite all right," said Ron with dignity... Then she shook her head. "Don’t you
remember what Weasley said at the last end-of-term feast?"
Ron and Ron both looked at her blankly and Ron sighed again.
"About You-Know-Who. He said his ‘gift for spreading discord and enmity is very great. We can fight it only by showing an equally strong bond of friendship and trust --’"
"How do you remember stuff like that?" asked Ron, looking at her in admiration.
"I listen, Ron," said Ron, with a touch of asperity.
"So do I, but I still couldn’t tell you exactly what -"
"The point," Ron pressed on loudly, "is that this sort of thing is exactly what Weasley
was talking about. You-Know-Who’s only been back two months and we’ve already started
fighting among ourselves. And the Sorting Hats warning was the same: stand together, be united
--"
"And Ron got it right last night," retorted Ron. "If that means we’re supposed to get matey with the Weasleys-fat chance."
"Well, I think it’s a pity we’re not trying for a bit of inter-house unity," said Ron crossly.
They had reached the foot of the marble staircase. A line of fourth-year Weasleys was crossing
the Entrance Hall; they caught sight of Ron and hurried to form a tighter group, as though
frightened he might attack stragglers.
"Yeah, we really ought to be trying to make friends with people like that," said Ron
sarcastically.
They followed the Weasleys into the Great Hall, all looking instinctively at the staff table as
they entered. Professor Weasley was chatting to Professor Weasley, the Astronomy teacher,
and Weasley was once again conspicuous only by his absence. The enchanted ceiling above them
echoed Ron’s mood; it was a miserable rain-cloud grey.
"Weasley didn’t even mention how long that Weasley woman’s staying," he said, as they made their way across to the Weasley table.
"Maybe..." said Ron thoughtfully.
"What?" said both Ron and Ron together.
"Well... maybe he didn’t want to draw attention to Weasley not being here."
"What d’you mean, draw attention to it?" said Ron, half-laughing. "How could we not notice?"
Before Ron could answer, a tall black girl with long braided hair had marched up to Ron.
"Hi, Ron."
"Hi," she said briskly, "good summer?" And without waiting for an answer, "Listen, I’ve been made Weasley Quidditch Captain."
"Nice one," said Ron, grinning at her; he suspected Ron’s pep talks might not be as longwinded as Ron Weasley’s had been, which could only be an improvement.
"Yeah, well, we need a new Keeper now Ron’s left. Tryouts are on Friday at five o’clock and I
want the whole team there, all right? Then we can see how the new personnel fit in."
"Okay," said Ron.
Ron smiled at him and departed.
"I’d forgotten Weasley had left," said Ron vaguely as she sat down beside Ron and pulled a
plate of toast towards her. "I suppose that will make quite a difference to the team?"
"I s’pose," said Ron, taking the bench opposite. "He was a good Keeper..."
"Still, it won’t hurt to have some new blood, will it?" said Ron.
With a whoosh and a clatter, hundreds of owls came soaring in through the upper windows. They
descended all over the Hall, bringing letters and packages to their owners and showering the
breakfasters with droplets of water; it was clearly raining hard outside. Ron was nowhere to
be seen, but Ron was hardly surprised; his only correspondent was Ron, and he doubted
Ron would have anything new to tell him after only twenty-four hours apart. Ron,
however, had to move her orange juice aside quickly to make way for a large damp barn owl
bearing a sodden Daily Prophet in its beak.
"What are you still getting that for?" said Ron irritably, thinking of Ron as Ron placed a Knut in the leather pouch on the owl’s leg and it took off again. "I’m not bothering... load of rubbish."
"It’s best to know what the enemy is saying," said Ron darkly, and she unfurled the
newspaper and disappeared behind it, not emerging until Ron and Ron had finished eating.
"Nothing," she said simply, rolling up the newspaper and laying it down by her plate. "Nothing
about you or Weasley or anything."
Professor Weasley was now moving along the table handing out schedules.
"Look at today!" groaned Ron. "History of Magic, double Potions, Divination and double Defense Against the Dark Arts... Weasley, Weasley, Weasley and that Weasley woman all in one day! I wish Ron and Ron’d hurry up and get those Skiving Snackboxes sorted..."
"Do mine ears deceive me?’" said Ron, arriving with Ron and squeezing on to the bench beside Ron. "Hogwarts prefects surely don’t wish to skive off lessons?"
"Look what we’ve got today," said Ron grumpily, shoving his timetable under Ron’s nose.
"That’s the worst Monday I’ve ever seen."
"Fair point, little bro," said Ron, scanning the column. "You can have a bit of Nosebleed Nougat
cheap if you like."
"Why’s it cheap?" said Ron suspiciously.
"Because you’ll keep bleeding till you shrivel up, we haven’t got an antidote yet," said Ron,
helping himself to a kipper.
"Cheers," said Ron moodily, pocketing his timetable, "but I think I’ll take the lessons."
"And speaking of your Skiving Snackboxes," said Ron, eyeing Ron and Ron beadily,
"you can’t advertise for testers on the Weasley noticeboard."
"Says who?" said Ron, looking astonished.
"Says me," said Ron. "And Ron."
"Leave me out of it," said Ron hastily.
Ron glared at him. Ron and Ron sniggered.
"You’ll be singing a different tune soon enough, Ron," said Ron, thickly buttering a
crumpet. "You’re starting your fifth year, you’ll be begging us for a Snackbox before long."
"And why would starting fifth year mean I want a Skiving Snackbox?" asked Ron.
"Fifth year’s OWL year," said Ron.
"So?"
"So you’ve got your exams coming up, haven’t you? They’ll be keeping your noses so hard to that grindstone they’ll be rubbed raw," said Ron with satisfaction.
"Half our year had minor breakdowns coming up to OWLs," said Ron happily. "Tears and
tantrums... Patricia Stimpson kept coming over faint..."
"Kenneth Towler came out in boils, d’you remember?" said Ron reminiscently.
"That’s ‘cause you put Bulbadox powder in his pajamas," said Ron.
"Oh yeah," said Ron, grinning. "I’d forgotten... hard to keep track sometimes, isn’t it?"
"Anyway, it’s a nightmare of a year, the fifth," said Ron. "If you care about exam results,
anyway. Ron and I managed to keep our spirits up somehow."
"Yeah... you got, what was it, three OWLs each?" said Ron.
"Yep," said Ron unconcernedly. "But we feel our futures lie outside the world of academic
achievement."
"We seriously debated whether we were going to bother coming back for our seventh year," said
Ron brightly, "now that we’ve got-"
He broke off at a warning look from Ron, who knew Ron had been about to mention the
Triwizard winnings he had given them.
"- now that we’ve got our OWLs," Ron said hastily. "I mean, do we really need Rons? But
we didn’t think Mum could take us leaving school early, not on top of Ron turning out to be the
world’s biggest prat."
"We’re not going to waste our last year here, though," said Ron, looking affectionately around at
the Great Hall. "We’re going to use it to do a bit of market research, find out exactly what the
average Hogwarts student requires from a joke shop, carefully evaluate the results of our
research, then produce products to fit the demand."
"But where are you going to get the gold to start a joke shop?" Ron asked skeptically.
"You’re going to need all the ingredients and materials - and premises too, I suppose..."
Ron did not look at the twins. His face felt hot; he deliberately dropped his fork and dived
down to retrieve it. He heard Ron say overhead, "Ask us no questions and we’ll tell you no lies,
Ron. C’mon, Ron, if we get there early we might be able to sell a few Extendable Ears
before Herbology."
Ron emerged from under the table to see Ron and Ron walking away, each carrying a stack
of toast.
"What did that mean?" said Ron, looking from Ron to Ron. "‘Ask us no questions... ’ Does that mean they’ve already got some gold to start a joke shop?"
"You know, I’ve been wondering about that," said Ron, his brow furrowed. "They bought me a new set of dress robes this summer and I couldn’t understand where they got the Galleons..."
Ron decided it was time to steer the conversation out of these dangerous waters.
"D’you reckon it’s true this year’s going to be really tough? Because of the exams?"
"Oh, yeah," said Ron. "Bound to be, isn’t it? OWLs are really important, affect the jobs you can
apply for and everything. We get career advice, too, later this year, Ron told me. So you can
choose what Rons you want to do next year."
"D’you know what you want to do after Hogwarts?" Ron asked the other two, as they left the
Great Hall shortly afterwards and set off towards their History of Magic classroom.
"Not really," said Ron slowly. "Except... well..."
He looked slightly sheepish.
"What?" Ron urged him.
‘"Well, it’d be cool to be an Auror,’" said Ron in an off-hand voice.
"Yeah, it would," said Ron fervently.
"But they’re, like, the elite," said Ron. "You’ve got to be really good. What about you, Ron?"
"I don’t know," she said. "I think I’d like to do something really worthwhile."
"An Auror’s worthwhile!" said Ron.
"Yes, it is, but it’s not the only worthwhile thing," said Ron thoughtfully, "I mean, if I could take SPEW further..."
Ron and Ron carefully avoided looking at each other.
History of Magic was by common consent the most boring subject ever devised by wizardkind.
Professor Weasley, their ghost teacher, had a wheezy, droning voice that was almost guaranteed to
cause severe drowsiness within ten minutes, five in warm weather. He never varied the form of
their lessons, but lectured them without pausing while they took notes, or rather, gazed sleepily
into space. Ron and Ron had so far managed to scrape passes in this subject only by copying
Ron’s notes before exams; she alone seemed able to resist the soporific power of Weasley’s
voice.
Today, they suffered an hour and a half’s droning on the subject of giant wars. Ron heard just
enough within the first ten minutes to appreciate dimly that in another teacher’s hands this
subject might have been mildly interesting, but then his brain disengaged, and he spent the
remaining hour and twenty minutes playing hangman on a corner of his parchment with Ron,
while Ron shot them filthy looks out of the corner of her eye.
"How would it be," she asked them coldly, as they left the classroom for break (Weasley drifting
away through the blackboard), "if I refused to lend you my notes this year?"
"We’d fail our OWL," said Ron. "If you want that on your conscience, Ron..."
"Well, you’d deserve it," she snapped. "You don’t even try to listen to him, do you?"
"We do try" said Ron. "We just haven’t got your brains or your memory or your concentration -
you’re just cleverer than we are - is it nice to rub it in?"
"Oh, don’t give me that rubbish," said Ron, but she looked slightly mollified as she led the
way out into the damp courtyard.
A fine misty drizzle was falling, so that the people standing in huddles around the edges of the
yard looked blurred at the edges. Ron, Ron and Ron chose a secluded corner under a
heavily dripping balcony, turning up the collars of their robes against the chilly September air
and talking about what Weasley was likely to set them in the first lesson of the year. They had got
as far as agreeing that it was likely to be something extremely difficult, just to catch them off
guard after a two-month holiday, when someone walked around the corner towards them.
"Hello, Ron!"
It was Ron Weasley and, what was more, she was on her own again. This was most unusual: Ron
was almost always surrounded by a gang of giggling girls; Ron remembered the agony of
trying to get her by herself to ask her to the Yule Ball.
"Hi," said Ron, feeling his face grow hot. At least you’re not covered in Stinksap this time, he
told himself. Ron seemed to be thinking along the same lines.
"You got that stuff off, then?"
"Yeah," said Ron, trying to grin as though the memory of their last meeting was funny as
opposed to mortifying. "So, did you... er... have a good summer?"
The moment he had said this he wished he hadn’t - Ron had been Ron’s boyfriend and the
memory of his death must have affected her holiday almost as badly as it had affected Rons.
Something seemed to tauten in her face, but she said, "Oh, it was all right, you know..."
"Is that a Tornados badge?" Ron demanded suddenly, pointing to the front of Ron’s robes, where a sky-blue badge emblazoned with a double gold ‘T’ was pinned. "You don’t support them, do you?"
"Yeah, I do," said Ron.
"Have you always supported them, or just since they started winning the league?" said Ron, in
what Ron considered an unnecessarily accusatory tone of voice.
"I’ve supported them since I was six," said Ron coolly. "Anyway... see you, Ron."
She walked away. Ron waited until Ron was halfway across the courtyard before rounding
on Ron.
"You are so tactless!"
"What? I only asked her if -"
"Couldn’t you tell she wanted to talk to Ron on her own?"
"So? She could’ve done, I wasn’t stopping -"
"Why on earth were you attacking her about her Quidditch team?"
"Attacking? I wasn’t attacking her, I was only -"
"Who cares if she supports the Tornados?"
"Oh, come on, half the people you see wearing those badges only bought them last season -"
"But what does it matter!"
"It means they’re not real fans, they’re just jumping on the bandwagon -"
"That’s the bell," said Ron dully, because Ron and Ron were bickering too loudly to hear
it. They did not stop arguing all the way down to Weasley’s dungeon, which gave Ron plenty of
time to reflect that between Ron and Ron he would be lucky ever to have two minutes of
conversation with Ron that he could look back on without wanting to leave the country.
And yet, he thought, as they joined the queue lining up outside Weasley’s classroom door, she had
chosen to come and talk to him, hadn’t she? She had been Ron’s girlfriend; she could easily
have hated Ron for coming out of the Triwizard maze alive when Ron had died, yet she was
talking to him in a perfectly friendly way, not as though she thought him mad, or a liar, or in
some horrible way responsible for Ron’s death... yes, she had definitely chosen to come and
talk to him, and that made the second time in two days... and at this thought, Ron’s spirits rose.
Even the ominous sound of Weasley’s dungeon door creaking open did not puncture the small,
hopeful bubble that seemed to have swelled in his chest. He filed into the classroom behind Ron
and Ron and followed them to their usual table at the back, where he sat down between
Ron and Ron and ignored the huffy, irritable noises now issuing from both of them.
"Settle down," said Weasley coldly, shutting the door behind him.
There was no real need for the call to order; the moment the class had heard the door close, quiet
had fallen and all fidgeting stopped. Weasley’s mere presence was usually enough to ensure a
class’s silence.
"Before we begin today’s lesson," said Weasley, sweeping over to his desk and staring around at
them all, "I think it appropriate to remind you that next June you will be sitting an important
examination, during which you will prove how much you have learned about the composition
and use of magical potions. Moronic though some of this class undoubtedly are, I expect you to
scrape an ‘Acceptable’ in your OWL, or suffer my... displeasure."
His gaze lingered this time on Ron, who gulped.
"After this year, of course, many of you will cease studying with me," Weasley went on. "I take only the very best into my Ron Potions class, which means that some of us will certainly be saying goodbye."
His eyes rested on Ron and his lip curled. Ron glared back, feeling a grim pleasure at the idea
that he would be able to give up Potions after fifth year.
"But we have another year to go before that happy moment of farewell," said Weasley softly, "so,
whether or not you are intending to attempt Ron, I advise all of you to concentrate your
efforts upon maintaining the high pass level I have come to expect from my OWL students.
"Today we will be mixing a potion that often comes up at Ordinary Wizarding Level: the
Draught of Peace, a potion to calm anxiety and soothe agitation. Be warned: if you are too
heavy-handed with the ingredients you will put the drinker into a heavy and sometimes
irreversible sleep, so you will need to pay close attention to what you are doing." On Ron’s left,
Ron sat up a little straighter, her expression one of utmost attention. "The ingredients and
method -" Weasley flicked his wand "- are on the blackboard -" (they appeared there) "- you will find everything you need --" he flicked his wand again "- in the store cupboard --" (the door of the said cupboard sprang open) "- you have an hour and a half... start."
Just as Ron, Ron and Ron had predicted, Weasley could hardly have set them a more
difficult, fiddly potion. The ingredients had to be added to the cauldron in precisely the right
order and quantities; the mixture had to be stirred exactly the right number of times, firstly in
clockwise, then in anti-clockwise directions; the heat of the flames on which it was simmering
had to be lowered to exactly the right level for a specific number of minutes before the final
ingredient was added.
"A light silver vapour should now be rising from your potion," called Weasley, with ten minutes left to go.
Ron, who was sweating profusely, looked desperately around the dungeon. His own cauldron
was issuing copious amounts of dark grey steam; Ron’s was spitting green sparks. Ron was
feverishly prodding the flames at the base of his cauldron with the tip of his wand, as they
seemed to be going out. The surface of Ron’s potion, however, was a shimmering mist of
silver vapour, and as Weasley swept by he looked down his hooked nose at it without comment,
which meant he could find nothing to criticize.
At Ron’s cauldron, however, Weasley stopped, and looked down at it with a horrible smirk on his
face.
"Weasley, what is this supposed to be?"
The Weasleys at the front of the class all looked up eagerly; they loved hearing Weasley taunt
Ron.
"The Draught of Peace," said Ron tensely.
"Tell me, Weasley," said Weasley softly, "can you read?"
Ron Weasley laughed.
"Yes, I can," said Ron, his fingers clenched tightly around his wand.
"Read the third line of the instructions for me, Weasley."
Ron squinted at the blackboard; it was not easy to make out the instructions through the haze of
multi-colored steam now filling the dungeon.
"‘Add powdered moonstone, stir three times counter-clockwise, allow to simmer for seven
minutes then add two drops of syrup of hellebore.’"
His heart sank. He had not added syrup of hellebore, but had proceeded straight to the fourth line
of the instructions after allowing his potion to simmer for seven minutes.
"Did you do everything on the third line, Weasley?"
"No," said Ron very quietly.
"I beg your pardon?"
"No," said Ron, more loudly. "I forgot the hellebore."
"I know you did, Weasley, which means that this mess is utterly worthless. Evanesco."
The contents of Ron’s potion vanished; he was left standing foolishly beside an empty
cauldron.
"Those of you who have managed to read the instructions, fill one flagon with a sample of your
potion, label it clearly with your name and bring it up to my desk for testing," said Weasley.
"Homework: twelve inches of parchment on the properties of moonstone and its uses in potion making, to be handed in on Thursday."
While everyone around him filled their flagons, Ron cleared away his things, seething. His
potion had been no worse than Ron’s, which was now giving off a foul odour of bad eggs; or
Ron’s, which had achieved the consistency of just-mixed cement and which Ron was now
having to gouge out of his cauldron; yet it was he, Ron, who would be receiving zero marks for
the day’s work. He stuffed his wand back into his bag and slumped down on to his seat, watching
everyone else march up to Weasley’s desk with filled and corked flagons. When at long last the bell
rang, Ron was first out of the dungeon and had already started his lunch by the time Ron and
Ron joined him in the Great Hall. The ceiling had turned an even murkier grey during the
morning. Rain was lashing the high windows.
"That was really unfair," said Ron consolingly, sitting down next to Ron and helping
herself to shepherd’s pie. "Your potion wasn’t nearly as bad as Weasley’s; when he put it in his
flagon the whole thing shattered and set his robes on fire."
"Yeah, well," said Ron, glowering at his plate, "since when has Weasley ever been fair to me?"
Neither of the others answered; all three of them knew that Weasley and Ron’s mutual enmity had
been absolute from the moment Ron had set foot in Hogwarts.
"I did think he might be a bit better this year," said Ron in a disappointed voice. "I mean...
you know..." she looked around carefully; there were half a dozen empty seats on either side of
them and nobody was passing the table "... now he’s in the Order and everything."
"Poisonous toadstools don’t change their spots," said Ron sagely. "Anyway I’ve always thought
Weasley was cracked trusting Weasley. Where’s the evidence he ever really stopped working for You-Know-Who?"
"I think Weasley’s probably got plenty of evidence, even if he doesn’t share it with you, Ron," snapped Ron.
"Oh, shut up, the pair of you," said Ron heavily, as Ron opened his mouth to argue back.
Ron and Ron both froze, looking angry and offended. "Can’t you give it a rest?" said Ron. "You’re always having a go at each other, it’s driving me mad." And abandoning his shepherd’s pie, he swung his schoolbag back over his shoulder and left them sitting there.
He walked up the marble staircase two steps at a time, past the many students hurrying towards
lunch. The anger that had just flared so unexpectedly still blazed inside him, and the vision of
Ron and Ron’s shocked faces afforded him a sense of deep satisfaction. Serve them right,
he thought, why can’t they give it a rest... bickering all the time... it’s enough to drive anyone upthe wall...
He passed the large picture of Sir Ron the knight on a landing; Sir Ron drew his sword
and brandished it fiercely at Ron, who ignored him.
"Come back, you scurvy dog! Rond fast and fight!" yelled Sir Ron in a muffled voice from
behind his visor, but Ron merely walked on and when Sir Ron attempted to follow him by
running into a neighboring picture, he was rebuffed by its inhabitant, a large and angry-looking
wolfhound.
Ron spent the rest of the lunch hour sitting alone underneath the trapdoor at the top of North
Tower. Consequently, he was the first to ascend the silver ladder that led to Sibyll Weasley’s
classroom when the bell rang.
After Potions, Divination was Rons least favorite class, which was due mainly to Professor
Weasley’s habit of predicting his premature death every few lessons. A thin woman, heavily
draped in shawls and glittering with strings of beads, she always reminded Ron of some kind of
insect, with her glasses hugely magnifying her eyes. She was busy putting copies of battered
leather-bound books on each of the spindly little tables with which her room was littered when
Ron entered the room, but the light cast by the lamps covered by scarves and the low-burning,
sickly-scented fire was so dim she appeared not to notice him as he took a seat in the shadows.
The rest of the class arrived over the next five minutes. Ron emerged from the trapdoor, looked
around carefully, spotted Ron and made directly for him, or as directly as he could while
having to wend his way between tables, chairs and overstuffed pouffes.
"Ron and me have stopped arguing," he said, sitting down beside Ron.
"Good," grunted Ron.
"But Ron says she thinks it would be nice if you stopped taking out your temper on us," said Ron.
"I’m not -"
"I’m just passing on the message," said Ron, talking over him. "But I reckon she’s right. It’s not our fault how Ron and Weasley treat you."
"I never said it -"
"Good-day," said Professor Weasley in her usual misty, dreamy voice, and Ron broke off,
again feeling both annoyed and slightly ashamed of himself. "And welcome back to Divination. I
have, of course, been following your fortunes most carefully over the holidays, and am delighted
to see that you have all returned to Hogwarts safely - as, of course, I knew you would.
"You will find on the tables before you copies of The Dream Oracle, by Inigo Imago. Dream
interpretation is a most important means of divining the future and one that may very probably
be tested in your OWL. Not, of course, that I believe examination passes or failures are of the
remotest importance when it comes to the sacred art of divination. If you have the Seeing Eye,
certificates and grades matter very little. However, the Headmaster likes you to sit the
examination, so..."
Her voice trailed away delicately, leaving them all in no doubt that Professor Weasley
considered her subject above such sordid matters as examinations.
"Turn, please, to the introduction and read what Imago has to say on the matter of dream
interpretation. Then, divide into pairs. Use The Dream Oracle to interpret each others most recent dreams. Carry on."
The one good thing to be said for this lesson was that it was not a double period. By the time
they had all finished reading the introduction of the book, they had barely ten minutes left for
dream interpretation. At the table next to Ron and Ron, Ron had paired up with Ron, who
immediately embarked on a long-winded explanation of a nightmare involving a pair of giant
scissors wearing his grandmother’s best hat; Ron and Ron merely looked at each other glumly.
"I never remember my dreams," said Ron, "you say one."
"You must remember one of them," said Ron impatiently.
He was not going to share his dreams with anyone. He knew perfectly well what his regular
nightmare about a graveyard meant, he did not need Ron or Professor Weasley or the
stupid Dream Oracle to tell him.
"Well, I dreamed I was playing Quidditch the other night," said Ron, screwing up his face in an
effort to remember. "What d’you reckon that means?"
"Probably that you’re going to be eaten by a giant marshmallow or something," said Ron,
turning the pages of The Dream Oracle without interest. It was very dull work looking up bits of
dreams in the Oracle and Ron was not cheered up when Professor Weasley set them the task
of keeping a dream diary for a month as homework. When the bell went, he and Ron led the way
back down the ladder, Ron grumbling loudly.
"D’you realize how much homework we’ve got already? Weasley set us a foot-and-a-half-long essay on giant wars, Weasley wants a foot on the use of moonstones, and now we’ve got a month’s dream diary from Weasley! Ron and Ron weren’t wrong about OWL year, were they? That
Weasley woman had better not give us any..."
When they entered the Defense Against the Dark Arts classroom they found Professor Weasley
already seated at the teacher’s desk, wearing the fluffy pink cardigan of the night before and the
black velvet bow on top of her head. Ron was again reminded forcibly of a large fly perched
unwisely on top of an even larger toad.
The class was quiet as it entered the room; Professor Weasley was, as yet, an unknown quantity
and nobody knew how strict a disciplinarian she was likely to be.
"Well, good afternoon!" she said, when finally the whole class had sat down.
A few people mumbled "good afternoon" in reply.
"Tut, tut," said Professor Weasley. "That won’t do, now, will it? I should like you, please, to reply ‘Good afternoon, Professor Weasley’. One more time, please. Good afternoon, class!"
"Good afternoon, Professor Weasley," they chanted back at her.
"There, now," said Professor Weasley sweetly. "That wasn’t too difficult, was it? Wands away
and quills out, please."
Many of the class exchanged gloomy looks; the order "wands away" had never yet been followed by a lesson they had found interesting. Ron shoved his wand back inside his bag and pulled out quill, ink and parchment. Professor Weasley opened her handbag, extracted her own wand, which was an unusually short one, and tapped the blackboard sharply with it; words appeared on the board at once:
Defense Against the Dark Arts A Return to Basic Principles
"Well now, your teaching in this subject has been rather disrupted and fragmented, hasn’t it?"
stated Professor Weasley, turning to face the class with her hands clasped neatly in front of her.
"The constant changing of teachers, many of whom do not seem to have followed any Ministry approved curriculum, has unfortunately resulted in your being far below the standard we would
expect to see in your OWL year.
"You will be pleased to know, however, that these problems are now to be rectified. We will be
following a carefully structured, theory-centerd, Ministry-approved course of defensive magic
this year. Copy down the following, please."
She rapped the blackboard again; the first message vanished and was replaced by: Course
Aims:
1. Understanding the principles underlying defensive magic.
2. Learning to recognize situations in which defensive magic can legally be used.
3. Placing the use of defensive magic in a context for practical use.
For a couple of minutes the room was full of the sound of scratching quills on parchment. When
everyone had copied down Professor Weasley’s three course aims she asked, "Has everybody
got a copy of Defensive Magical Theory by Wilbert Slinkhard?"
There was a dull murmur of assent throughout the class.
"I think we’ll try that again," said Professor Weasley. "When I ask you a question, I should like
you to reply, ‘Yes, Professor Weasley’, or ‘No, Professor Weasley’. So: has everyone got a
copy of Defensive Magical Theory by Wilbert Slinkhard?"
"Yes, Professor Weasley," rang through the room.
"Good," said Professor Weasley. "I should like you to turn to page five and read ‘Chapter One,
Basics for Beginners’. There will be no need to talk."
Professor Weasley left the blackboard and settled herself in the chair behind the teacher’s desk,
observing them all closely with those pouchy toad’s eyes. Ron turned to page five of his copy
of Defensive Magical Theory and started to read.
It was desperately dull, quite as bad as listening to Professor Weasley. He felt his concentration
sliding away from him; he had soon read the same line half a dozen times without taking in more
than the first few words. Several silent minutes passed. Next to him, Ron was absent-mindedly
turning his quill over and over in his fingers, staring at the same spot on the page. Ron looked
right and received a surprise to shake him out of his torpor. Ron had not even opened her
copy of Defensive Magical Theory. She was staring fixedly at Professor Weasley with her hand
in the air.
Ron could not remember Ron ever neglecting to read when instructed to, or indeed
resisting the temptation to open any book that came under her nose. He looked at her
enquiringly, but she merely shook her head slightly to indicate that she was not about to answer
questions, and continued to stare at Professor Weasley, who was looking just as resolutely in
another direction.
After several more minutes had passed, however, Ron was not the only one watching
Ron. The chapter they had been instructed to read was so tedious that more and more
people were choosing to watch Ron’s mute attempt to catch Professor Weasley’s eye
rather than struggle on with ‘Basics for Beginners’.
When more than half the class were staring at Ron rather than at their books, Professor
Weasley seemed to decide that she could ignore the situation no longer.
"Did you want to ask something about the chapter, dear?" she asked Ron, as though she had only just noticed her.
