"Not about the chapter, no," said Ron.
"Well, we’re reading just now," said Professor Weasley, showing her small pointed teeth. "If you have other queries we can deal with them at the end of class."
"I’ve got a query about your course aims," said Ron.
Professor Weasley raised her eyebrows.
"And your name is?"
"Ron Weasley," said Ron.
"Well, Miss Weasley, I think the course aims are perfectly clear if you read them through
carefully" said Professor Weasley in a voice of determined sweetness.
"Well, I don’t," said Ron bluntly. "There’s nothing written up there about using defensive
spells."
There was a short silence in which many members of the class turned their heads to frown at the
three course aims still written on the blackboard.
"Using defensive spells?" Professor Weasley repeated with a little laugh. "Why, I can’t imagine any situation arising in my classroom that would require you to use a defensive spell, Miss Weasley. You surely aren’t expecting to be attacked during class?"
"We’re not going to use magic?" Ron exclaimed loudly.
"Students raise their hands when they wish to speak in my class, Mr. -?"
"Weasley," said Ron, thrusting his hand into the air.
Professor Weasley, smiling still more widely, turned her back on him. Ron and Ron
immediately raised their hands too. Professor Weasley’s pouchy eyes lingered on Ron for a
moment before she addressed Ron.
"Yes, Miss Weasley? You wanted to ask something else?"
"Yes," said Ron. "Surely the whole point of Defence Against the Dark Arts is to practice
defensive spells?"
"Are you a Ministry-trained educational expert, Miss Weasley?" asked Professor Weasley, in her falsely sweet voice.
"No, but -"
"Well then, I’m afraid you are not qualified to decide what the ‘whole point’ of any class is.
Wizards much older and cleverer than you have devised our new program of study. You will
be learning about defensive spells in a secure, risk-free way -"
"What use is that?" said Ron loudly. "If we’re going to be attacked, it won’t be in a -"
"Hand, Mr. Weasley!" sang Professor Weasley.
Ron thrust his fist in the air. Again, Professor Weasley promptly turned away from him, but
now several other people had their hands up, too.
"And your name is?" Professor Weasley said to Ron.
"Ron Ron."
"Well, Mr. Ron?"
"Well, it’s like Ron said, isn’t it?" said Ron. "If we’re going to be attacked, it won’t be risk free."
"I repeat," said Professor Weasley, smiling in a very irritating fashion at Ron, "do you expect to be attacked during my classes?"
"No, but -"
Professor Weasley talked over him. "I do not wish to criticize the way things have been run in
this school," she said, an unconvincing smile stretching her wide mouth, "but you have been
exposed to some very irresponsible wizards in this class, very irresponsible indeed - not to
mention," she gave a nasty little laugh, "extremely dangerous half-breeds."
"If you mean Professor Weasley," piped up Ron angrily, "he was the best we ever -"
"Hand, Mr. Ron! As I was saying - you have been introduced to spells that have been
complex, inappropriate to your age group and potentially lethal. You have been frightened into
believing that you are likely to meet Dark attacks every other day -"
"No we haven’t," Ron said, "we just -"
"Your hand is not up, Miss Weasley!"
Ron put up her hand. Professor Weasley turned away from her.
"It is my understanding that my predecessor not only performed illegal curses in front of you, he
actually performed them on you."
"Well, he turned out to be a maniac, didn’t he?" said Ron hotly. "Mind you, we still learned
loads."
"Your hand is not up, Mr. Ron!" trilled Professor Weasley. "Now, it is the view of the
Ministry that a theoretical knowledge will be more than sufficient to get you through your
examination, which, after all, is what school is all about. And your name is?" she added, staring
at Ron, whose hand had just shot up.
"Ron Weasley, and isn’t there a practical bit in our Defense Against the Dark Arts OWL? Aren’t
we supposed to show that we can actually do the counter-curses and things?"
"As long as you have studied the theory hard enough, there is no reason why you should not be
able to perform the spells under carefully controlled examination conditions," said Professor
Weasley dismissively.
"Without ever practicing them beforehand?" said Ron incredulously. "Are you telling us that the first time we’ll get to do the spells will be during our exam?"
"I repeat, as long as you have studied the theory hard enough -"
"And what good’s theory going to be in the real world?" said Ron loudly, his fist in the air again.
Professor Weasley looked up.
"This is school, Mr. Weasley, not the real world," she said softly.
"So we’re not supposed to be prepared for what’s waiting for us out there?"
"There is nothing waiting out there, Mr. Weasley."
"Oh, yeah?" said Ron. His temper, which seemed to have been bubbling just beneath the surface all day, was reaching boiling point.
"Who do you imagine wants to attack children like yourselves?" enquired Professor Weasley in
a horribly honeyed voice.
"Hmm, let’s think..." said Ron in a mock thoughtful voice. "Maybe... Lord Weasley!"
Ron gasped; Ron Weasley uttered a little scream; Ron slipped sideways off his stool.
Professor Weasley, however, did not flinch. She was staring at Ron with a grimly satisfied
expression on her face.
"Ten points from Weasley, Mr. Weasley."
The classroom was silent and still. Everyone was staring at either Weasley or Ron.
"Now, let me make a few things quite plain."
Professor Weasley stood up and leaned towards them, her stubby-fingered hands splayed on her
desk.
"You have been told that a certain Dark wizard has returned from the dead -"
"He wasn’t dead," said Ron angrily, "but yeah, he’s returned!"
‘"Mr-Weasley-you-have-already-lost-your-house-ten-points-do-not-make-matters-worse-for yourself," said Professor Weasley in one breath without looking at him. "As I was saying, you have been informed that a certain Dark wizard is at large once again. This is a lie."
"It is NOT a lie!" said Ron. "I saw him, I fought him!"
"Detention, Mr. Weasley!" said Professor Weasley triumphantly. "Ronorrow evening. Five
o’clock. My office. I repeat, this is a lie. The Ministry of Magic guarantees that you are not in
danger from any Dark wizard. If you are still worried, by all means come and see me outside
class hours. If someone is alarming you with fibs about reborn Dark wizards, I would like to hear
about it. I am here to help. I am your friend. And now, you will kindly continue your reading.
Page five, ‘Basics for Beginners’."
Professor Weasley sat down behind her desk. Ron, however, stood up. Everyone was staring
at him; Ron looked half-scared, half-fascinated.
"Ron, no!" Ron whispered in a warning voice, tugging at his sleeve, but Ron jerked his
arm out of her reach.
"So, according to you, Ron Weasley dropped dead of his own accord, did he?" Ron asked, his voice shaking.
There was a collective intake of breath from the class, for none of them, apart from Ron and
Ron, had ever heard Ron talk about what had happened on the night Ron had died.
They stared avidly from Ron to Professor Weasley, who had raised her eyes and was staring
at him without a trace of a fake smile on her face.
"Ron Weasley’s death was a tragic accident," she said coldly.
"It was murder," said Ron. He could feel himself shaking. He had hardly spoken to anyone about this, least of all thirty eagerly listening classmates. "Weasley killed him and you know it."
Professor Weasley’s face was quite blank. For a moment, Ron thought she was going to
scream at him. Then she said, in her softest, most sweetly girlish voice, "Come here, Mr. Weasley,
dear."
He kicked his chair aside, strode around Ron and Ron and up to the teacher’s desk. He
could feel the rest of the class holding its breath. He felt so angry he did not care what happened
next.
Professor Weasley pulled a small roll of pink parchment out of her handbag, stretched it out on
the desk, dipped her quill into a bottle of ink and started scribbling, hunched over so that Ron
could not see what she was writing. Nobody spoke. After a minute or so she rolled up the
parchment and tapped it with her wand; it sealed itself seamlessly so that he could not open it.
"Take this to Professor Weasley, dear," said Professor Weasley, holding out the note to him.
He took it from her without saying a word, turned on his heel and left the room, not even looking
back at Ron and Ron, slamming the classroom door shut behind him. He walked very fast
along the corridor, the note to Weasley clutched tight in his hand, and turning a corner
walked slap into Ron the poltergeist, a wide-mouthed little man floating on his back in midair,
juggling several inkwells.
"Why it’s Potty Wee Weasley!" cackled Ron, allowing two of the inkwells to fall to the ground
where they smashed and spattered the walls with ink; Ron jumped backwards out of the way
with a snarl.
"Get out of it, Ron."
"Oooh, Crackpot’s feeling cranky" said Ron, pursuing Ron along the corridor, leering as he
zoomed along above him. "What is it this time, my fine Potty friend? Hearing voices? Seeing
visions? Speaking in -" Ron blew a gigantic raspberry "-- tongues?"
"I said, leave me ALONE!" Ron shouted, running down the nearest flight of stairs, but Ron
merely slid down the banister on his back beside him.
"Oh, most think he’s barking, the potty wee lad, But some are more kindly and think he’s just sad, but Rony knows better and says that he’s mad -- "
"SHUT UP!"
A door to his left flew open and Professor Weasley emerged from her office looking grim
and slightly harassed.
"What on earth are you shouting about, Weasley?" she snapped, as Ron cackled gleefully and
zoomed out of sight. ‘"Why aren’t you in class?"
"I’ve been sent to see you," said Ron stiffly.
"Sent? What do you mean, sent?"
He held out the note from Professor Weasley. Professor Weasley took it from him,
frowning, slit it open with a tap of her wand, stretched it out and began to read. Her eyes zoomed
from side to side behind their square spectacles as she read what Weasley had written, and with
each line they became narrower.
"Come in here, Weasley."
He followed her inside her study. The door closed automatically behind him.
"Well?" said Professor Weasley, rounding on him. "Is this true?"
"Is what true?" Ron asked, rather more aggressively than he had intended. "Professor?" he added, in an attempt to sound more polite.
"Is it true that you shouted at Professor Weasley?"
"Yes," said Ron.
"You called her a liar?"
"Yes."
"You told her He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named is back?"
"Yes."
Professor Weasley sat down behind her desk, watching Ron closely. Then she said, "Have a biscuit, Weasley."
"Have - what?"
"Have a biscuit," she repeated impatiently, indicating a tartan tin of cookies lying on top of one of the piles of papers on her desk. "And sit down."
There had been a previous occasion when Ron, expecting to be caned by Professor
Weasley, had instead been appointed by her to the Weasley Quidditch team. He sank into a
chair opposite her and helped himself to a Ginger Ron, feeling just as confused and wrong footed as he had done on that occasion.
Professor Weasley set down Professor Weasley’s note and looked very seriously at Ron.
"Weasley, you need to be careful."
Ron swallowed his mouthful of Ginger Ron and stared at her. Her tone of voice was not at all
what he was used to; it was not brisk, crisp and stern; it was low and anxious and somehow much
more human than usual.
"Misbehavior in Ron Weasley’s class could cost you much more than house points and a
detention."
"What do you -?"
"Weasley, use your common sense," snapped Professor Weasley, with an abrupt return to her
usual manner. "You know where she comes from, you must know to whom she is reporting."
The bell rang for the end of the lesson. Overhead and all around came the elephantine sounds of
hundreds of students on the move.
"It says here she’s given you detention every evening this week, starting tomorrow," Professor
Weasley said, looking down at Weasley’s note again.
"Every evening this week!" Ron repeated, horrified. "But, Professor, couldn’t you -?"
"No, I couldn’t," said Professor Weasley flatly.
"But -"
"She is your teacher and has every right to give you detention. You will go to her room at five
o’clock tomorrow for the first one. Just remember: tread carefully around Ron Weasley."
"But I was telling the truth!" said Ron, outraged. "Weasley is back, you know he is; Professor Weasley knows he is -"
"For heaven’s sake, Weasley!" said Professor Weasley, straightening her glasses angrily (she had winced horribly when he had used Weasley’s name). "Do you really think this is about truth or lies? It’s about keeping your head down and your temper under control!"
She stood up, nostrils wide and mouth very thin, and Ron stood up, too.
"Have another biscuit," she said irritably, thrusting the tin at him.
"No, thanks," said Ron coldly.
"Don’t be ridiculous," she snapped.
He took one.
"Thanks," he said grudgingly.
"Didn’t you listen to Ron Weasley’s speech at the start-of-term feast, Weasley?"
"Yeah," said Ron. "Yeah... she said... progress will be prohibited or... well, it meant that... that the Ministry of Magic is trying to interfere at Hogwarts."
Professor Weasley eyed him closely for a moment, then sniffed, walked around her desk and
held open the door for him.
"Well, I’m glad you listen to Ron Weasley at any rate," she said, pointing him out of her
office.
CHAPTER THIRTEEN
Detention with Ron
Dinner in the Great Hall that night was not a pleasant experience for Ron. The news about his
shouting match with Weasley had traveled exceptionally fast even by Hogwarts’ standards. He
heard whispers all around him as he sat eating between Ron and Ron. The funny thing was
that none of the whisperers seemed to mind him overhearing what they were saying about him.
On the contrary, it was as though they were hoping he would get angry and start shouting again,
so that they could hear his story first-hand.
"He says he saw Ron Weasley murdered..."
"He reckons he dueled with You-Know-Who..."
"Come off it..."
"Who does he think he’s kidding?"
"Pur-Lease..."
"What I don’t get," said Ron through clenched teeth, laying down his knife and fork (his hands
were shaking too much to hold them steady), "is why they all believed the story two months ago
when Weasley told them..."
"The thing is, Ron, I’m not sure they did," said Ron grimly. "Oh, let’s get out of here."
She slammed down her own knife and fork; Ron looked longingly at his half-finished apple pie
but followed suit. People stared at them all the way out of the Hall.
"What d’you mean, you’re not sure they believed Weasley?" Ron asked Ron when
they reached the first-floor landing.
"Look, you don’t understand what it was like after it happened," said Ron quietly. "You
arrived back in the middle of the lawn clutching Ron’s dead body... none of us saw what
happened in the maze... we just had Weasley’s word for it that You-Know-Who had come
back and killed Ron and fought you."
"Which is the truth!" said Ron loudly.
"I know it is, Ron, so will you please stop biting my head off?" said Ron wearily. "It’s just that before the truth could sink in, everyone went home for the summer, where they spent two months reading about how you’re a nutcase and Weasley’s going senile!"
Rain pounded on the windowpanes as they strode along the empty corridors back to Weasley
Tower. Ron felt as though his first day had lasted a week, but he still had a mountain of
homework to do before bed. A dull pounding pain was developing over his right eye. He glanced
out of a rain-washed window at the dark grounds as they turned into the Ron Weasley’s corridor.
There was still no light in Weasley’s cabin.
"Mimbulus mimbletonia," said Ron, before the Ron Weasley could ask. The portrait swung
open to reveal the hole behind it and the three of them scrambled through it.
The common room was almost empty; nearly everyone was still down at dinner. Ron
uncoiled himself from an armchair and trotted to meet them, purring loudly, and when Ron,
Ron and Ron took their three favorite chairs at the fireside he leapt lightly on to
Ron’s lap and curled up there like a furry ginger cushion. Ron gazed into the flames,
feeling drained and exhausted.
"How can Weasley have let this happen?" Ron cried suddenly, making Ron and Ron
jump; Ron leapt off her, looking affronted. She pounded the arms of her chair in fury, so
that bits of stuffing leaked out of the holes. "How can he let that terrible woman teach us? And in
our OWL year, too!"
"Well, we’ve never had great Defense Against the Dark Arts teachers, have we?" said Ron.
"You know what it’s like, Weasley told us, nobody wants the job; they say it’s jinxed."
"Yes, but to employ someone who’s actually refusing to let us do magic! What’s Weasley
playing at?"
"And she’s trying to get people to spy for her," said Ron darkly. "Remember when she said she wanted us to come and tell her if we hear anyone saying You-Know-Who’s back?"
"Of course she’s here to spy on us all, that’s obvious, why else would Weasley have wanted her to
come?" snapped Ron.
"Don’t start arguing again," said Ron wearily, as Ron opened his mouth to retaliate. "Can’t we
just... let’s just do that homework, get it out of the way..."
They collected their schoolbags from a corner and returned to the chairs by the fire. People were
coming back from dinner now. Ron kept his face averted from the portrait hole, but could still
sense the stares he was attracting.
"Shall we do Weasley’s stuff first?" said Ron, dipping his quill into his ink. "The properties... of
moonstone... and its uses... in potion-making..." he muttered, writing the words across the top
of his parchment as he spoke them. "There." He underlined the title, then looked up expectantly
at Ron.
"So, what are the properties of moonstone and its uses in potion-making?"
But Ron was not listening; she was squinting over into the far corner of the room, where
Ron, Ron and Ron Weasley were now sitting at the center of a knot of innocent-looking first years, all of whom were chewing something that seemed to have come out of a large paper bag
that Ron was holding.
"No, I’m sorry, they’ve gone too far," she said, standing up and looking positively furious.
"Come on, Ron."
"I - what?" said Ron, plainly playing for time. "No- come on, Ron - we can’t tell them off
for giving out sweets."
"You know perfectly well that those are bits of Nosebleed Nougat or - or Puking Pastilles or -"
"Fainting Fancies?" Ron suggested quietly.
One by one, as though hit over the head with an invisible mallet, the first-years were slumping
unconscious in their seats; some slid right on to the floor, others merely hung over the arms of
their chairs, their tongues lolling out. Most of the people watching were laughing; Ron,
however, squared her shoulders and marched directly over to where Ron and Ron now stood
with clipboards, closely observing the unconscious first-years. Ron rose halfway out of his chair,
hovered uncertainly for a moment or two, then muttered to Ron, "She’s got it under control,"
before sinking as low in his chair as his lanky frame permitted.
"That’s enough!" Ron said forcefully to Ron and Ron, both of whom looked up in mild
surprise.
"Yeah, you’re right," said Ron, nodding, "this dosage looks strong enough, doesn’t it?"
"I told you this morning, you can’t test your rubbish on students!"
"We’re paying them!" said Ron indignantly.
"I don’t care, it could be dangerous!"
"Rubbish," said Ron.
"Calm down, Ron, they’re fine!" said Ron reassuringly as he walked from first-year to first year, inserting purple sweets into their open mouths.
"Yeah, look, they’re coming round now," said Ron.
A few of the first-years were indeed stirring. Several looked so shocked to find themselves lying
on the floor, or dangling off their chairs, that Ron was sure Ron and Ron had not warned
them what the sweets were going to do.
"Feel all right?" said Ron kindly to a small dark-haired girl lying at his feet.
"I - I think so," she said shakily.
"Excellent," said Ron happily, but the next second Ron had snatched both his clipboard and the paper bag of Fainting Fancies from his hands.
"It is NOT excellent!"
"Course it is, they’re alive, aren’t they?" said Ron angrily.
"You can’t do this, what if you made one of them really ill?"
"We’re not going to make them ill, we’ve already tested them all on ourselves, this is just to see
if everyone reacts the same -"
"If you don’t stop doing it, I’m going to -"
"Put us in detention?" said Ron, in an I’d-like-to-see-you-try-it voice.
"Make us write lines?" said Ron, smirking.
Onlookers all over the room were laughing. Ron drew herself up to her full height; her eyes were narrowed and her bushy hair seemed to crackle with electricity.
"No," she said, her voice quivering with anger, "but I will write to your mother."
"You wouldn’t," said Ron, horrified, taking a step back from her.
"Oh, yes, I would," said Ron grimly. "I can’t stop you eating the stupid things yourselves,
but you’re not to give them to the first-years."
Ron and Ron looked thunderstruck. It was clear that as far as they were concerned,
Ron’s threat was way below the belt. With a last threatening look at them, she thrust Ron’s
clipboard and the bag of Fancies back into his arms, and stalked back to her chair by the fire. Ron was now so low in his seat that his nose was roughly level with his knees.
"Thank you for your support, Ron," Ron said acidly.
"You handled it fine by yourself," Ron mumbled.
Ron stared down at her blank piece of parchment for a few seconds, then said edgily, "Oh,
it’s no good, I can’t concentrate now. I’m going to bed."
She wrenched her bag open; Ron thought she was about to put her books away, but instead she
pulled out two misshapen woolly objects, placed them carefully on a table by the fireplace,
covered them with a few screwed-up bits of parchment and a broken quill and stood back to
admire the effect.
"What in the name of Merlin are you doing?" said Ron, watching her as though fearful for her
sanity.
"They’re hats for house-elves," she said briskly, now stuffing her books back into her bag. "I did
them over the summer. I’m a really slow knitter without magic but now I’m back at school I
should be able to make lots more."
"You’re leaving out hats for the house-elves?" said Ron slowly. "And you’re covering them up
with rubbish first?"
"Yes," said Ron defiantly, swinging her bag on to her back.
"That’s not on," said Ron angrily. "You’re trying to trick them into picking up the hats. You’re
setting them free when they might not want to be free."
"Of course they want to be free!" said Ron at once, though her face was turning pink.
"Don’t you dare touch those hats, Ron!"
She turned on her heel and left. Ron waited until she had disappeared through the door to the
girls’ dormitories, then cleared the rubbish off the woolly hats.
"They should at least see what they’re picking up," he said firmly. "Anyway..." he rolled up the
parchment on which he had written the title of Weasley’s essay, "there’s no point trying to finish
this now, I can’t do it without Ron, I haven’t got a clue what you’re supposed to do with
moonstones, have you?"
Ron shook his head, noticing as he did so that the ache in his right temple was getting worse.
He thought of the long essay on giant wars and the pain stabbed at him sharply. Knowing
perfectly well that when the morning came, he would regret not finishing his homework that
night, he piled his books back into his bag.
"I’m going to bed too."
He passed Ron on the way to the door leading to the dormitories, but did not look at him.
Ron had a fleeting impression that Ron had opened his mouth to speak, but he sped up and
reached the soothing peace of the stone spiral staircase without having to endure any more
provocation.
The following day dawned just as leaden and rainy as the previous one. Weasley was still absent
from the staff table at breakfast.
"But on the plus side, no Weasley today" said Ron bracingly.
Ron yawned widely and poured herself some coffee. She looked mildly pleased about
something, and when Ron asked her what she had to be so happy about, she simply said, "The
hats have gone. Seems the house-elves do want freedom after all."
"I wouldn’t bet on it," Ron told her cuttingly. "They might not count as clothes. They didn’t look anything like hats to me, more like woolly bladders."
Ron did not speak to him all morning.
Double Charms was succeeded by double Transfiguration. Professor Weasley and Professor
Weasley both spent the first fifteen minutes of their lessons lecturing the class on the
importance of OWLs.
"What you must remember," said little Professor Weasley squeakily perched as ever on a pile of
books so that he could see over the top of his desk, "is that these examinations may influence
your futures for many years to come! If you have not already given serious thought to your
careers, now is the time to do so. And in the meantime, I’m afraid, we shall be working harder
than ever to ensure that you all do yourselves justice!"
They then spent over an hour reviewing Summoning Charms, which according to Professor
Weasley were bound to come up in their OWL, and he rounded off the lesson by setting them
their largest ever amount of Charms homework.
It was the same, if not worse, in Transfiguration.
"You cannot pass an OWL," said Professor Weasley grimly, "without serious application,
practice and study. I see no reason why everybody in this class should not achieve an OWL in
Transfiguration as long as they put in the work." Ron made a sad little disbelieving noise.
"Yes, you too, Weasley," said Professor Weasley. "There’s nothing wrong with your work except lack of confidence. So... today we are starting Vanishing Spells. These are easier than Conjuring Spells, which you would not usually attempt until Ron level, but they are still
among the most difficult magic you will be tested on in your OWL."
She was quite right; Ron found the Vanishing Spells horribly difficult. By the end of a double
period neither he nor Ron had managed to vanish the snails on which they were practicing,
though Ron said hopefully he thought his looked a bit paler. Ron, on the other hand,
successfully vanished her snail on the third attempt, earning her a ten-point bonus for Weasley
from Professor Weasley. She was the only person not given homework; everybody else was
told to practice the spell overnight, ready for a fresh attempt on their snails the following
afternoon.
Now panicking slightly about the amount of homework they had to do, Ron and Ron spent
their lunch hour in the library looking up the uses of moonstones in potion-making. Still angry
about Ron’s slur on her woolly hats, Ron did not join them. By the time they reached Care
of Magical Creatures in the afternoon, Ron’s head was aching again.
The day had become cool and breezy, and as they walked down the sloping lawn towards
Weasley’s cabin on the edge of the Forbidden Forest, they felt the occasional drop of rain on their
faces. Professor Weasley stood waiting for the class some ten yards from Weasley’s front
door, a long trestle table in front of her laden with twigs. As Ron and Ron reached her, a loud
shout of laughter sounded behind them; turning, they saw Ron Weasley striding towards them,
surrounded by his usual gang of Weasley cronies. He had clearly just said something highly
amusing, because Weasley, Weasley, Ron Weasley and the rest continued to snigger heartily as
they gathered around the trestle table and, judging by the way they all kept looking over at
Ron, he was able to guess the subject of the joke without too much difficulty.
"Everyone here?" barked Professor Weasley, once all the Weasleys and Weasleys had
arrived. "Let’s crack on then. Who can tell me what these things are called?"
She indicated the heap of twigs in front of her. Ron’s hand shot into the air. Behind her
back, Weasley did a buck-toothed imitation of her jumping up and down in eagerness to answer a
question. Ron Weasley gave a shriek of laughter that turned almost at once into a scream, as
the twigs on the table leapt into the air and revealed themselves to be what looked like tiny pixieish creatures made of wood, each with knobbly brown arms and legs, two twiglike fingers at the end of each hand and a funny flat, barklike face in which a pair of beetle-brown eyes glittered.
"Oooooh!" said Ron and Ron, thoroughly irritating Ron. Anyone would have thought
Weasley had never shown them impressive creatures; admittedly, the Flobberworms had been a bit
dull, but the Salamanders and Hippogriffs had been interesting enough, and the Blast-Ended
Skrewts perhaps too much so.
"Kindly keep your voices down, girls!" said Professor Weasley sharply, scattering a
handful of what looked like brown rice among the stick-creatures, who immediately fell upon the
food. "So - anyone know the names of these creatures? Miss Weasley?"
"Bowtruckles," said Ron. "They’re tree-guardians, usually live in wand-trees."
"Five points for Weasley," said Professor Weasley. "Yes, these are Bowtruckles, and as
Miss Weasley rightly says, they generally live in trees whose wood is of wand quality. Anybody
know what they eat?"
"Weasleylice," said Ron promptly which explained why what Ron had taken to be grains of
brown rice were moving. "But fairy eggs if they can get them."
"Good girl, take another five points. So, whenever you need leaves or wood from a tree in which
a Bowtruckle lodges, it is wise to have a gift of woodlice ready to distract or placate it. They may
not look dangerous, but if angered they will try to gouge at human eyes with their fingers, which,
as you can see, are very sharp and not at all desirable near the eyeballs. So if you’d like to gather
closer, take a few woodlice and a Bowtruckle - I have enough here for one between three - you
can study them more closely. I want a sketch from each of you with all body-parts labeled by
the end of the lesson."
The class surged forwards around the trestle table. Ron deliberately circled around the back so
that he ended up right next to Professor Weasley.
"Where’s Weasley?" he asked her, while everyone else was choosing Bowtruckles.
"Never you mind," said Professor Weasley repressively, which had been her attitude last
time Weasley had failed to turn up for a class, too. Smirking all over his pointed face, Ron
Weasley leaned across Ron and seized the largest Bowtruckle.
"Maybe," said Weasley in an undertone, so that only Ron could hear him, "the stupid great oaf’s
got himself badly injured."
"Maybe you will if you don’t shut up," said Ron out of the side of his mouth.
"Maybe he’s been messing with stuff that’s too big for him, if you get my drift."
Weasley walked away, smirking over his shoulder at Ron, who felt suddenly sick. Did Weasley
know something? His father was a Death Eater after all; what if he had information about
Weasley’s fate that had not yet reached the ears of the Order? He hurried back around the table to
Ron and Ron who were squatting on the grass some distance away and attempting to
persuade a Bowtruckle to remain still long enough for them to draw it. Ron pulled out
parchment and quill, crouched down beside the others and related in a whisper what Weasley had
just said.
"Weasley would know if some thing had happened to Weasley," said Ron at once. "It’s
just playing into Weasley’s hands to look worried; it tells him we don’t know exactly what’s
going on. We’ve got to ignore him, Ron. Here, hold the Bowtruckle for a moment, just so I can
draw its face..."
"Yes," came Weasley’s clear drawl from the group nearest them, "Ronher was talking to the
Minister just a couple of days ago, you know, and it sounds as though the Ministry’s really
determined to crack down on sub-standard teaching in this place. So even if that overgrown
moron does show up again, he’ll probably be sent packing straightaway."
"OUCH!"
Ron had gripped the Bowtruckle so hard that it had almost snapped, and it had just taken a
great retaliatory swipe at his hand with its sharp fingers, leaving two long deep cuts there. Ron
dropped it. Weasley and Weasley, who had already been guffawing at the idea of Weasley being
sacked, laughed still harder as the Bowtruckle set off at full tilt towards the Forest, a little
moving stick-man soon swallowed up among the tree roots. When the bell echoed distantly over
the grounds, Ron rolled up his blood-stained Bowtruckle picture and marched off to Herbology
with his hand wrapped in Ron’s handkerchief, and Weasley’s derisive laughter still ringing
in his ears.
"If he calls Weasley a moron one more time..." said Ron through gritted teeth.
"Ron, don’t go picking a row with Weasley, don’t forget, he’s a prefect now, he could make life
difficult for you..."
"Wow, I wonder what it’d be like to have a difficult life?" said Ron sarcastically. Ron laughed,
but Ron frowned. Together, they traipsed across the vegetable patch. The sky still appeared
unable to make up its mind whether it wanted to rain or not.
"I just wish Weasley would hurry up and get back, that’s all," said Ron in a low voice, as they
reached the greenhouses. "And don’t say that Weasley woman’s a better teacher!" he added threateningly.
"I wasn’t going to," said Ron calmly.
"Because she’ll never be as good as Weasley," said Ron firmly, fully aware that he had just
experienced an exemplary Care of Magical Creatures lesson and was thoroughly annoyed about
it.
The door of the nearest greenhouse opened and some fourth-years spilled out of it, including
Ron.
"Hi," she said brightly as she passed. A few seconds later, Ron Weasley emerged, trailing
behind the rest of the class, a smudge of earth on her nose, and her hair tied in a knot on the top
of her head. When she saw Ron, her prominent eyes seemed to bulge excitedly and she made a
beeline straight for him. Many of his classmates turned curiously to watch. Ron took a great
breath and then said, without so much as a preliminary hello, "I believe He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named is back and I believe you fought him and escaped from him."
"Er - right," said Ron awkwardly. Ron was wearing what looked like a pair of orange radishes
for earrings, a fact that Ron and Ron seemed to have noticed, as they were both giggling
and pointing at her earlobes.
"You can laugh," Ron said, her voice rising, apparently under the impression that Ron and
Ron were laughing at what she had said rather than what she was wearing, "but people used
to believe there were no such things as the Blibbering Humdinger or the Crumple-Horned
Snorkack!"
"Well, they were right, weren’t they?’ said Ron impatiently. "There weren’t any such things as the Blibbering Humdinger or the Crumple-Horned Snorkack."
Ron gave her a withering look and flounced away, radishes swinging madly Ron and
Ron were not the only ones hooting with laughter now.
"D’you mind not offending the only people who believe me?" Ron asked Ron as they
made their way into class.
"Oh, for heaven’s sake, Ron, you can do better than her," said Ron. "Ron’s told me all
about her; apparently, she’ll only believe in things as long as there’s no proof at all. Well, I
wouldn’t expect anything else from someone whose father runs The Quibbler."
Ron thought of the sinister winged horses he had seen on the night he had arrived and how
Ron had said she could see them too. His spirits sank slightly. Had she been lying? But before
he could devote much more thought to the matter, Ron Weasley had stepped up to him.
"I want you to know, Weasley," he said in a loud, carrying voice, "that it’s not only weirdos who
support you. I personally believe you one hundred percent. My family have always stood firm
behind Weasley, and so do I."
"Er - thanks very much, Ron," said Ron, taken aback but pleased. Ron might be pompous on
occasions like this, but Ron was in a mood to deeply appreciate a vote of confidence from
somebody who did not have radishes dangling from their ears. Ron’s words had certainly wiped
the smile from Ron Weasley’s face and as he turned to talk to Ron and Ron, Ron
caught Ron’s expression, which looked both confused and defiant.
To nobody’s surprise, Professor Weasley started their lesson by lecturing them about the
importance of OWLs. Ron wished all the teachers would stop doing this; he was starting to get
an anxious, twisted feeling in his stomach every time he remembered how much homework he
had to do, a feeling that worsened dramatically when Professor Weasley gave them yet another
essay at the end of class. Tired and smelling strongly of dragon dung, Professor Weasley’s
preferred type of fertilizer, the Weasleys trooped back up to the castle an hour and a half later,
none of them talking very much; it had been another long day.
As Ron was starving, and he had his first detention with Weasley at five o’clock, he headed
straight for dinner without dropping off his bag in Weasley Tower so that he could bolt
something down before facing whatever she had in store for him. He had barely reached the
entrance of the Great Hall, however, when a loud and angry voice yelled, "Oy, Weasley!"
"What now?" he muttered wearily, turning to face Ron Ronson, who looked as though she
was in a towering temper.
"I’ll tell you what now," she said, marching straight up to him and poking him hard in the chest
with her finger. "How come you’ve landed yourself in detention for five o’clock on Friday?"
"What?" said Ron. "Why... oh yeah, Keeper tryouts!"
"Now he remembers!" snarled Ron. "Didn’t I tell you I wanted to do a tryout with the wholeteam, and find someone who fitted in with everyone! Didn’t I tell you I’d booked the Quidditch pitch specially? And now you’ve decided you’re not going to be there!"
"I didn’t decide not to be there!" said Ron, stun g by the injustice of these words. "I got
detention from that Weasley woman, just because I told her the truth about You-Know-Who."
"Well, you can just go straight to her and ask her to let you off on Friday," said Ron fiercely, "and I don’t care how you do it. Tell her You-Know-Who’s a figment of your imagination if you like, just make sure you’re there!"
She turned on her heel and stormed away.
"You know what?" Ron said to Ron and Ron as they entered the Great Hall. "I think we’d better check with Puddlemere United whether Ron Weasley’s been killed during a training
session, because Ron seems to be channeling his spirit."
"What d’you reckon are the odds of Weasley letting you off on Friday?" said Ron skeptically,
as they sat down at the Weasley table.
"Less than zero," said Ron glumly, tipping lamb c hops on to his plate and starting to eat. "Better try, though, hadn’t I? I’ll offer to do two more detentions or something, I dunno..." He
swallowed a mouthful of potato and added, "I hope she doesn’t keep me too long this evening.
You realize we’ve got to write three essays, practice Vanishing Spells for Weasley, work out
a counter-charm for Weasley, finish the Bowtruckle drawing and start that stupid dream diary for
Weasley?"
Ron moaned and for some reason glanced up at the ceiling.
"And it looks like it’s going to rain."
"What’s that got to do with our homework?" said Ron, her eyebrows raised.
"Nothing," said Ron at once, his ears reddening.
At five to five Ron bade the other two goodbye and set off for Weasley’s office on the third
floor. When he knocked on the door she called, "Come in," in a sugary voice. He entered
cautiously, looking around.
He had known this office under three of its previous occupants.
In the days when Ron Weasley had lived here it had been plastered in beaming portraits of
himself. When Weasley had occupied it, it was likely you would meet some fascinating Dark
creature in a cage or tank if you came to call. In the impostor Weasley’s days it had been packed
with various instruments and artifacts for the detection of wrong doing and concealment.
Now, however, it looked totally unrecognizable. The surfaces had all been draped in lacy covers
and cloths. There were several vases full of dried flowers, each one residing on its own doily,
and on one of the walls was a collection of ornamental plates, each decorated with a large
technicolor kitten wearing a different bow around its neck. These were so foul that Ron stared
at them, transfixed, until Professor Weasley spoke again.
"Good evening, Mr. Weasley."
Ron started and looked around. He had not noticed her at first because she was wearing a
luridly flowered set of robes that blended only too well with the tablecloth on the desk behind
her.
"Evening, Professor Weasley," Ron said stiffly.
"Well, sit down," she said, pointing towards a small table draped in lace beside which she had
drawn up a straight-backed chair. A piece of blank parchment lay on the table, apparently
waiting for him.
"Er," said Ron, without moving. "Professor Weasley. Er - before we start, I - I wanted to ask
you a... a favor."
Her bulging eyes narrowed.
"Oh, yes?"
"Well, I’m... I’m in the Weasley Quidditch team. And I was supposed to be at the tryouts for
the new Keeper at five o’clock on Friday and I was - was wondering whether I could skip
detention that night and do it - do it another night... instead..."
He knew long before he reached the end of his sentence that it was no good.
"Oh, no," said Weasley, smiling so widely that she looked as though she had just swallowed a
particularly juicy fly. "Oh, no, no, no. This is your punishment for spreading evil, nasty,
attention-seeking stories, Mr. Weasley, and punishments certainly cannot be adjusted to suit the
guilty one’s convenience. No, you will come here at five o’clock tomorrow, and the next day,
and on Friday too, and you will do your detentions as planned. I think it rather a good thing that
you are missing something you really want to do. It ought to reinforce the lesson I am trying to
teach you."
Ron felt the blood surge to his head and heard a thumping noise in his ears. So he told ‘evil,
nasty, attention-seeking stones’, did he?
She was watching him with her head slightly to one side, still smiling widely, as though she
knew exactly what he was thinking and was waiting to see whether he would start shouting
again. With a massive effort, Ron looked away from her, dropped his schoolbag beside the
straight-backed chair and sat down.
"There," said Weasley sweetly, "we’re getting better at controlling our temper already, aren’t
we? Now, you are going to be doing some lines for me, Mr. Weasley. No, not with your quill," she
added, as Ron bent down to open his bag. "You’re going to be using a rather special one of
mine. Here you are."
She handed him a long, thin black quill with an unusually sharp point.
"I want you to write, I must not tell lies," she told him softly.
"How many times?" Ron asked, with a creditable imitation of politeness.
"Oh, as long as it takes for the message to sink in," said Weasley sweetly. "Off you go."
She moved over to her desk, sat down and bent over a stack of parchment that looked like essays
for marking. Ron raised the sharp black quill, then realized what was missing.
"You haven’t given me any ink," he said.
"Oh, you won’t need ink," said Professor Weasley, with the merest suggestion of a laugh in her
voice.
Ron placed the point of the quill on the paper and wrote: I must not tell lies.
He let out a gasp of pain. The words had appeared on the parchment in what appeared to be
shining red ink. At the same time, the words had appeared on the back of Rons right hand, cut
into his skin as though traced there by a scalpel - yet even as he stared at the shining cut, the skin
healed over again, leaving the place where it had been slightly redder than before but quite
smooth.
Ron looked round at Weasley. She was watching him, her wide, toadlike mouth stretched in a
smile.
"Yes?"
"Nothing," said Ron quietly.
He looked back at the parchment, placed the quill on it once more, wrote I must not tell lies, and
felt the searing pain on the back of his hand for a second time; once again, the words had been
cut into his skin; once again, they healed over seconds later.
And on it went. Again and again Ron wrote the words on the parchment in what he soon came
to realize was not ink, but his own blood. And, again and again, the words were cut into the back
of his hand, healed, and reappeared the next time he set quill to parchment.
Darkness fell outside Weasley’s window. Ron did not ask when he would be allowed to stop.
He did not even check his watch. He knew she was watching him for signs of weakness and he
was not going to show any, not even if he had to sit there all night, cutting open his own hand
with this quill...
"Come here," she said, after what seemed hours.
He stood up. His hand was stinging painfully. When he looked down at it he saw that the cut had
healed, but that the skin there was red raw.
"Hand," she said.
He extended it. She took it in her own. Ron repressed a shudder as she touched him with her
thick, stubby fingers on which she wore a number of ugly old rings.
"Tut, tut, I don’t seem to have made much of an impression yet," she said, smiling. "Well, we’ll
just have to try again tomorrow evening, won’t we? You may go."
Ron left her office without a word. The school was quite deserted; it was surely past midnight.
He walked slowly up the corridor, then, when he had turned the corner and was sure she would
not hear him, broke into a run.
He had not had time to practice Vanishing Spells, had not written a single dream in his dream
diary and had not finished the drawing of the Bowtruckle, nor had he written his essays. He
skipped breakfast next morning to scribble down a couple of made-up dreams for Divination,
their first lesson, and was surprised to find a disheveled Ron keeping him company.
"How come you didn’t do it last night?" Ron asked, as Ron stared wildly around the common
room for inspiration. Ron, who had been fast asleep when Ron got back to the dormitory,
muttered something about "doing other stuff", bent low over his parchment and scrawled a few
words.
"That’ll have to do," he said, slamming the diary shut. "I’ve said I dreamed I was buying a new
pair of shoes, she can’t make anything weird out of that, can she?"
They hurried off to North Tower together.
"How was detention with Weasley, anyway? What did she make you do?"
Ron hesitated for a fraction of a second, then said, "Lines."
"That’s not too bad, then, eh?" said Ron.
"Nope," said Ron.
"Hey - I forgot - did she let you off for Friday?"
"No," said Ron.
Ron groaned sympathetically.
It was another bad day for Ron; he was one of the worst in Transfiguration, not having
practiced Vanishing Spells at all. He had to give up his lunch hour to complete the picture of the
Bowtruckle and, meanwhile, Professors Weasley, Weasley and Weasley gave them yet
more homework, which he had no prospect of finishing that evening because of his second
detention with Weasley. To cap it all, Ron Ronson tracked him down at dinner again and,
on learning that he would not be able to attend Friday’s Keeper tryouts, told him she was not at
all impressed by his attitude and that she expected players who wished to remain on the team to
put training before their other commitments.
"I’m in detention!" Ron yelled after her as she s talked away. "D’you think I’d rather be stuck in a room with that old toad or playing Quidditch?"
"At least it’s only lines," said Ron consolingly, as Ron sank back on to his bench and
looked down at his steak and kidney pie, which he no longer fancied very much. "It’s not as if
it’s a dreadful punishment, really..."
Ron opened his mouth, closed it again and nodded. He was not really sure why he was not
telling Ron and Ron exactly what was happening in Weasley’s room: he only knew that
he did not want to see their looks of horror; that would make the whole thing seem worse and
therefore more difficult to face. He also felt dimly that this was between himself and Weasley,
a private battle of wills, and he was not going to give her the satisfaction of hearing that he had
complained about it.
"I can’t believe how much homework we’ve got," said Ron miserably.
"Well, why didn’t you do any last night?" Ron asked him. "Where were you, anyway?"
"I was... I fancied a walk," said Ron shiftily.
Ron had the distinct impression that he was not alone in concealing things at the moment.
The second detention was just as bad as the previous one. The skin on the back of Ron’s hand
became irritated more quickly now and was soon red and inflamed. Ron thought it unlikely that
it would keep healing as effectively for long. Soon the cut would remain etched into his hand and
Weasley would, perhaps, be satisfied. He let no gasp of pain escape him, however, and from
the moment of entering the room to the moment of his dismissal, again past midnight, he said
nothing but "good evening" and "goodnight."
His homework situation, however, was now desperate, and when he returned to the Weasley
common room he did not, though exhausted, go to bed, but opened his books and began Weasley’s
moonstone essay. It was half past two by the time he had finished it. He knew he had done a poor
job, but there was no help for it; unless he had something to give in he would be in detention
with Weasley next. He then dashed off answers to the questions Professor Weasley had set
them, cobbled together something on the proper handling of Bowtruckles for Professor Grubbly-
Plank, and staggered up to bed, where he fell fully clothed on top of the covers and fell asleep
immediately.
Thursday passed in a haze of tiredness. Ron seemed very sleepy too, though Ron could not see
why he should be. Ron’s third detention passed in the same way as the previous two, except
that after two hours the words I must not tell lies did not fade from the back of Rons hand, but
remained scratched there, oozing droplets of blood. The pause in the pointed quill’s scratching
made Professor Weasley look up.
"Ah," she said softly, moving around her desk to examine his hand herself. "Good. That ought to
serve as a reminder to you, oughtn’t it? You may leave for tonight."
"Do I still have to come back tomorrow?" said Ron picking up his schoolbag with his left hand
rather than his smarting right one.
"Oh yes," said Professor Weasley, smiling as widely as before. "Yes, I think we can etch the
message a little deeper with another evening’s work."
Ron had never before considered the possibility that there might be another teacher in the
world he hated more than Weasley, but as he walked back towards Weasley Tower he had to
admit he had found a strong contender. She’s evil, he thought, as he climbed a staircase to the
seventh floor, she’s an evil, twisted, mad old-
"Ron?"
He had reached the top of the stairs, turned right and almost walked into Ron, who was lurking
behind a statue of Lachlan the Lanky, clutching his broomstick. He gave a great leap of surprise
when he saw Ron and attempted to hide his new Cleansweep Eleven behind his back.
"What are you doing?"
"Er - nothing. What are you doing?"
Ron frowned at him.
"Come on, you can tell me! What are you hiding here for?"
"I’m - I’m hiding from Ron and Ron, if you must know," said Ron. "They just went past with a bunch of first-years, I bet they’re testing stuff on them again. I mean, they can’t do it in the
common room now, can they, not with Ron there."
He was talking in a very fast, feverish way.
"But what have you got your broom for, you haven’t been flying, have you?" Ron asked.
"I - well - well, okay, I’ll tell you, but don’t laugh, all right?" Ron said defensively, turning redder with every second. "I - I thought I’d try out for Weasley Keeper now I’ve got a decent broom. There. Go on. Laugh."
"I’m not laughing," said Ron. Ron blinked. "It’s a brilliant idea! It’d be really cool if you got on the team! I’ve never seen you play Keeper, are you good?"
"I’m not bad," said Ron, who looked immensely relieved at Ron’s reaction. "Ron, Ron and
Ron always made me Keep for them when they were training during the holidays."
"So you’ve been practicing tonight?"
"Every evening since Tuesday... just on my own, though. I’ve been trying to bewitch Quaffles to
fly at me, but it hasn’t been easy and I don’t know how much use it’ll be." Ron looked nervous
and anxious. "Ron and Ron are going to laugh themselves stupid when I turn up for the
tryouts. They haven’t stopped taking the mickey out of me since I got made a prefect."
"I wish I was going to be there," said Ron bitterly, as they set off together towards the common
room.
"Yeah, so do - Ron, what’s that on the back of your hand?"
Ron, who had just scratched his nose with his free right hand, tried to hide it, but had as much
success as Ron with his Cleansweep.
"It’s just a cut - it’s nothing - it’s -"
But Ron had grabbed Ron’s forearm and pulled the back of Ron’s hand up level with his
eyes. There was a pause, during which he stared at the words carved into the skin, then, looking
sick, he released Ron.
"I thought you said she was just giving you lines?"
Ron hesitated, but after all, Ron had been honest with him, so he told Ron the truth about the
hours he had been spending in Weasley’s office.
"The old hag!" Ron said in a revolted whisper as they came to a halt in front of the Ron Weasley, who was dozing peacefully with her head against her frame. "She’s sick! Go to Weasley, say
something!"
"No," said Ron at once. "I’m not giving her the satisfaction of knowing she’s got to me."
"Got to you? You can’t let her get away with this!"
"I don’t know how much power Weasley’s got over her," said Ron.
"Weasley, then, tell Weasley!"
"No," said Ron flatly.
"Why not?"
"He’s got enough on his mind," said Ron, but that was not the true reason. He was not going to
go to Weasley for help when Weasley had not spoken to him once since June.
"Well, I reckon you should -" Ron began, but he was interrupted by the Ron Weasley, who had been
watching them sleepily and now burst out, "Are you going to give me the password or will I have to stay awake all night waiting for you to finish your conversation?"
Friday dawned sullen and sodden as the rest of the week. Though Ron automatically glanced
towards the staff table when he entered the Great Hall, it was without any real hope of seeing
Weasley, and he turned his mind immediately to his more pressing problems, such as the
mountainous pile of homework he had to do and the prospect of yet another detention with
Weasley.
Two things sustained Ron that day. One was the thought that it was almost the weekend; the
other was that, dreadful though his final detention with Weasley was sure to be, he had a distant
view of the Quidditch pitch from her window and might, with luck, be able to see something of
Ron’s tryout. These were rather feeble rays of light, it was true, but Ron was grateful for
anything that might lighten his present darkness; he had never had a worse first week of term at
Hogwarts.
At five o’clock that evening he knocked on Professor Weasley’s office door for what he
sincerely hoped would be the final time, and was told to enter. The blank parchment lay ready
for him on the lace-covered table, the pointed black quill beside it.
"You know what to do, Mr. Weasley," said Weasley, smiling sweetly at him.
Ron picked up the quill and glanced through the window. If he just shifted his chair an inch or
so to the right... on the pretext of shifting himself closer to the table, he managed it. He now had
a distant view of the Weasley Quidditch team soaring up and down the pitch, while half a
dozen black figures stood at the foot of the three high goalposts, apparently awaiting their turn to
Keep. It was impossible to tell which one was Ron at this distance.
I must not tell lies, Ron wrote. The cut in the back of his right hand opened and began to bleed
afresh.
I must not tell lies. The cut dug deeper, stinging and smarting.
I must not tell lies. Blood trickled down his wrist.
He chanced another glance out of the window. Whoever was defending the goalposts now was
doing a very poor job indeed. Ron Weasley scored twice in the few seconds Ron dared to watch.
Hoping very much that the Keeper wasn’t Ron, he dropped his eyes back to the parchment
shining with blood.
I must not tell lies.
I must not tell lies.
He looked up whenever he thought he could risk it; when he could hear the scratching of
Weasleys quill or the opening of a desk drawer. The third person to try out was pretty good, the
fourth was terrible, the fifth dodged a Bludger exceptionally well but then fumbled an easy save.
The sky was darkening, and Ron doubted he would be able to see the sixth and seventh people
at all.
I must not tell lies.
I must not tell lies.
The parchment was now dotted with drops of blood from the back of his hand, which was
searing with pain. When he next looked up, night had fallen and the Quidditch pitch was no
longer visible.
"Let’s see if you’ve gotten the message yet, shall we?" said Weasleys soft voice half an hour later. She moved towards him, stretching out her short ringed fingers for his arm. And then, as she took hold of him to examine the words now cut into his skin, pain seared, not across the back of his hand, but across the scar on his forehead. At the same time, he had a most peculiar sensation somewhere around his midriff.
He wrenched his arm out of her grip and leapt to his feet, staring at her. She looked back at him,
a smile stretching her wide, slack mouth.
"Yes, it hurts, doesn’t it?" she said softly.
He did not answer. His heart was thumping very hard and fast. Was she talking about his hand or
did she know what he had just felt in his forehead?
"Well, I think I’ve made my point, Mr. Weasley. You may go."
He caught up his schoolbag and left the room as quickly as he could.
Stay calm, he told himself, as he sprinted up the stairs. Stay calm, it doesn’t necessarily mean
what you think it means...
"Mimbulus mimbletonia!" he gasped at the Ron Weasley, who swung forwards once more.
A roar of sound greeted him. Ron came running towards him, beaming all over his face and
slopping Butterbeer down his front from the goblet he was clutching.
"Ron, I did it, I’m in, I’m Keeper!"
"What? Oh - brilliant!" said Ron, trying to smile naturally, while his heart continued to race and his hand throbbed and bled.
"Have a Butterbeer." Ron pressed a bottle on him. "I can’t believe it - where’s Ron gone?"
"She’s there," said Ron, who was also swigging Butterbeer, and pointed to an armchair by the
fire. Ron was dozing in it, her drink tipping precariously in her hand.
"Well, she said she was pleased when I told her," said Ron, looking slightly put out.
"Let her sleep," said Ron hastily. It was a few moments before Ron noticed that several of
the first-years gathered around them bore unmistakable signs of recent nosebleeds.
"Come here, Ron, and see if Ron’s old robes fit you," called Ron Weasley, "we can take off his
name and put yours on instead..."
As Ron moved away, Ron came striding up to Ron.
"Sorry I was a bit short with you earlier, Weasley," she said abruptly. "It’s stressful this managing
lark, you know, I’m starting to think I was a bit hard on Weasley sometimes." She was watching
Ron over the rim of her goblet with a slight frown on her face.
"Look, I know he’s your best mate, but he’s not fabulous," she said bluntly. "I think with a bit of
training he’ll be all right, though. He comes from a family of good Quidditch players. I’m
banking on him turning out to have a bit more talent than he showed today, to be honest. Vicky
Frobisher and Geoffrey Hooper both flew better this evening, but Hoopers a real whiner, he’s
always moaning about something or other, and Vicky’s involved in all sorts of societies. She
admitted herself that if training clashed with her Charms Club she’d put Charms first. Anyway,
we’re having a practice session at two o’clock tomorrow, so just make sure you’re there this
time. And do me a favor and help Ron as much as you can, okay?"
He nodded, and Ron strolled back to Ron Weasley. Ron moved over to sit next to
Ron, who awoke with a jerk as he put down his bag.
"Oh, Ron, it’s you... good about Ron, isn’t it?" she said blearily. "I’m just so-so - so tired," she
yawned. "I was up until one o’clock making more hat s. They’re disappearing like mad!"
And sure enough, now that he looked, Ron saw that there were woolly hats concealed all
around the room where unwary elves might accidentally pick them up.
"Great," said Ron distractedly; if he did not tell somebody soon, he would burst. "Listen,
Ron, I was just up in Weasley’s office and she touched my arm."
Ron listened closely. When Ron had finished, she said slowly "You’re worried You-
Know-Who’s controlling her like he controlled Weasley?"
"Well," said Ron, dropping his voice, "it’s a possibility, isn’t it?"
"I suppose so," said Ron, though she sounded unconvinced. "But I don’t think he can
be possessing her the way he possessed Weasley, I mean, he’s properly alive again now, isn’t he,
he’s got his own body, he wouldn’t need to share someone else’s. He could have her under the
Imperius Curse, I suppose..."
Ron watched Ron, Ron and Ron Weasley juggling empty Butterbeer bottles for a moment.
Then Ron said, "But last year your scar hurt when nobody was touching you, and didn’t
Weasley say it had to do with what You-Know-Who was feeling at the time? I mean, maybe
this hasn’t got anything to do with Weasley at all, maybe it’s just coincidence it happened
while you were with her?"
"She’s evil," said Ron flatly. "Twisted."
"She’s horrible, yes, but... Ron, I think you ought to tell Weasley your scar hurt."
It was the second time in two days he had been advised to go to Weasley and his answer to
Ron was just the same as his answer to Ron.
"I’m not bothering him with this. Like you just said, its not a big deal. It’s been hurting on and
off all summer - it was just a bit worse tonight, that’s all -"
"Ron, I’m sure Weasley would want to be bothered by this -"
"Yeah," said Ron, before he could stop himself, "that’s the only bit of me Weasley cares
about, isn’t it, my scar?"
"Don’t say that, it’s not true!"
"I think I’ll write and tell Ron about it, see what he thinks -"
"Ron, you can’t put something like that in a letter!" said Ron, looking alarmed. "Don’t
you remember, Weasley told us to be careful what we put in writing! We just can’t guarantee owls
aren’t being intercepted any more!"
"All right, all right, I won’t tell him, then!" said Ron irritably. He got to his feet. "I’m going to
bed. Tell Ron for me, will you?"
"Oh no," said Ron, looking relieved, "if you’re going that means I can go too, without being rude. I’m absolutely exhausted and I want to make some more hats tomorrow. Listen, you can help me if you like, it’s quite fun, I’m getting better, I can do patterns and bobbles and all sorts of things now."
Ron looked into her face, which was shining with glee, and tried to look as though he was
vaguely tempted by this offer.
"Er... no, I don’t think I will, thanks," he said. "Er- not tomorrow. I’ve got loads of homework to
do..."
And he traipsed off to the boys’ stairs, leaving her looking slightly disappointed.
CHAPTER FOURTEEN
Ron and Padfoot
Ron was first to wake up in his dormitory next morning. He lay for a moment watching dust
swirl in the chink of sunlight coming through the gap in his four-posters hangings, and savored
the thought that it was Saturday. The first week of term seemed to have dragged on forever, like
one gigantic History of Magic lesson.
Judging by the sleepy silence and the freshly minted look of that beam of sunlight, it was just
after daybreak. He pulled open the curtains around his bed, got up and started to dress. The only
sound apart from the distant twittering of birds was the slow, deep breathing of his fellow
Weasleys. He opened his schoolbag carefully, pulled out parchment and quill and headed out
of the dormitory for the common room.
Making straight for his favorite squashy old armchair beside the now extinct fire, Ron settled
himself down comfortably and unrolled his parchment while looking around the room. The
detritus of crumpled-up bits of parchment, old Gobstones, empty ingredient jars and sweet
wrappers that usually covered the common room at the end of each day was gone, as were all
Ron’s elf hats. Wondering vaguely how many elves had now been set free whether they
wanted to be or not, Ron uncorked his ink bottle, dipped his quill into it, then held it suspended
an inch above the smooth yellowish surface of his parchment, thinking hard... but after a minute
or so he found himself staring into the empty grate, at a complete loss for what to say.
He could now appreciate how hard it had been for Ron and Ron to write him letters over
the summer. How was he supposed to tell Ron everything that had happened over the past
week and pose all the questions he was burning to ask without giving potential letter-thieves a lot
of information he did not want them to have?
He sat quite motionless for a while, gazing into the fireplace, then, finally coming to a decision,
he dipped his quill into the ink bottle once more and set it resolutely on the parchment.
Dear Snuffles,
Hope you’re okay, the first week back here’s been terrible, I’m really glad it’s the weekend.
We’ve got a new Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher, Professor Weasley. She’s nearly as
nice as your mum. I’m writing because that thing I wrote to you about last summer happened
again last night when I was doing a detention with Weasley.
We’re all missing our biggest friend, we hope he’ll be back soon.
Please write back quickly.
Best,
Ron
Ron reread the letter several times, trying to see it from the point of view of an outsider. He
could not see how they would know what he was talking about - or who he was talking to - just
from reading this letter. He did hope Ron would pick up the hint about Weasley and tell them
when he might be back. Ron did not want to ask directly in case it drew too much attention to
what Weasley might be up to while he was not at Hogwarts.
Considering it was a very short letter, it had taken a long time to write; sunlight had crept
halfway across the room while he had been working on it and he could now hear distant sounds
of movement from the dormitories above. Sealing the parchment carefully, he climbed through
the portrait hole and headed off for the Owlery.
"I would not go that way if I were you," said Nearly Headless Ron, drifting disconcertingly
through a wall just ahead of Ron as he walked down the passage. "Ron is planning an
amusing joke on the next person to pass the bust of Paracelsus halfway down the corridor."
"Does it involve Paracelsus falling on top of the persons head?" asked Ron.
"Funnily enough, it does," said Nearly Headless Ron in a bored voice. "Subtlety has never been
Ron’s strong point. I’m off to try and find the Ron Weasley... he might be able to put a stop
to it... see you, Ron"
"Yeah, bye," said Ron and instead of turning right, he turned left, taking a longer but safer route up to the Owlery. His spirits rose as he walked past window after window showing brilliantly blue sky; he had training later, he would be back on the Quidditch pitch at last.
Something brushed his ankles. He looked down and saw the caretaker’s skeletal grey cat, Mrs.
Norris, slinking past him. She turned lamplike yellow eyes on him for a moment before
disappearing behind a statue of Wilfred the Wistful.
"I’m not doing anything wrong," Ron called after her. She had the unmistakable air of a cat
that was off to report to her boss, yet Ron could not see why; he was perfectly entitled to walk
up to the Owlery on a Saturday morning.
The sun was high in the sky now and when Ron entered the Owlery the glassless windows
dazzled his eyes; thick silvery beams of sunlight crisscrossed the circular room in which
hundreds of owls nestled on rafters, a little restless in the early-morning light, some clearly just
returned from hunting. The straw-covered floor crunched a little as he stepped across tiny animal
bones, craning his neck for a sight of Ron.
"There you are," he said, spotting her somewhere near the very top of the vaulted ceiling. "Get
down here, I’ve got a letter for you."
With a low hoot she stretched her great white wings and soared down on to his shoulder.
"Right, I know this says Snuffles on the outside," he told her, giving her the letter to clasp in her
beak and, without knowing exactly why, whispering, "but it’s for Ron, okay?"
She blinked her amber eyes once and he took that to mean that she understood.
"Safe flight, then," said Ron and he carried her to one of the windows; with a moment’s
pressure on his arm, Ron took off into the blindingly bright sky. He watched her until she
became a tiny black speck and vanished, then switched his gaze to Weasley’s hut, clearly visible
from this window, and just as clearly uninhabited, the chimney smokeless, the curtains drawn.
The treetops of the Forbidden Forest swayed in a light breeze. Ron watched them, savoring
the fresh air on his face, thinking about Quidditch later... then he saw it. A great, reptilian
winged horse, just like the ones pulling the Hogwarts carriages, with leathery black wings spread
wide like a pterodactyl’s, rose up out of the trees like a grotesque, giant bird. It soared in a great
circle, then plunged back into the trees. The whole thing had happened so quickly, Ron could
hardly believe what he had seen, except that his heart was hammering madly.
The Owlery door opened behind him. He leapt in shock and, turning quickly, saw Ron Weasley
holding a letter and a parcel in her hands.
"Hi," said Ron automatically.
"Oh... hi," she said breathlessly. "I didn’t think anyone would be up here this early... I only
remembered five minutes ago, it’s my mum’s birthday."
She held up the parcel.
"Right," said Ron. His brain seemed to have jammed. He wanted to say something funny and
interesting, but the memory of that terrible winged horse was fresh in his mind.
"Nice day," he said, gesturing to the windows. His insides seemed to shrivel with embarrassment.
The weather. He was talking about the weather...
"Yeah," said Ron, looking around for a suitable owl. "Good Quidditch conditions. I haven’t been
out all week, have you?"
"No," said Ron.
Ron had selected one of the school barn owls. She coaxed it down on to her arm where it held
out an obliging leg so that she could attach the parcel.
"Hey, has Weasley got a new Keeper yet?" she asked.
"Yeah," said Ron. "It’s my friend Ron Weasley, d’you know him?"
"The Tornados-hater?" said Ron rather coolly. "Is he any good?"
"Yeah," said Ron, "I think so. I didn’t see his tryout, though, I was in detention."
Ron looked up, the parcel only half-attached to the owl’s legs.
"That Weasley woman’s foul," she said in a low voice. "Putting you in detention just because
you told the truth about how - how - how he died. Everyone heard about it, it was all over the
school. You were really brave standing up to her like that."
Ron’s insides re-inflated so rapidly he felt as though he might actually float a few inches off
the dropping-strewn floor. Who cared about a stupid flying horse; Ron thought he had been
really brave. For a moment, he considered accidentally-on-purpose showing her his cut hand as
he helped her tie her parcel on to her owl... but the very instant this thrilling thought occurred,
the Owlery door opened again.
Weasley the caretaker came wheezing into the room. There were purple patches on his sunken,
veined cheeks, his jowls were aquiver and his thin grey hair disheveled; he had obviously run
here. Mrs. Norris came trotting at his heels, gazing up at the owls overhead and mewing hungrily.
There was a restless shifting of wings from above and a large brown owl snapped his beak in a
menacing fashion.
"Aha!’ said Weasley, taking a flat-footed step toward s Ron, his pouchy cheeks trembling with
anger. "I’ve had a tip-off that you are intending to place a massive order for Dungbombs!"
Ron folded his arms and stared at the caretaker.
"Who told you I was ordering Dungbombs?"
Ron was looking from Ron to Weasley, also frowning; the barn owl on her arm, tired of standing
on one leg, gave an admonitory hoot but she ignored it.
"I have my sources," said Weasley in a self-satisfied hiss. "Now hand over whatever it is you’re
sending."
Feeling immensely thankful that he had not dawdled in posting off the letter, Ron said, "I can’t,
it’s gone."
"Gone?" said Weasley, his face contorting with rage.
"Gone," said Ron calmly.
Weasley opened his mouth furiously, mouthed for a few seconds, then raked Rons robes with his
eyes.
"How do I know you haven’t got it in your pocket?"
"Because -"
"I saw him send it," said Ron angrily.
Weasley rounded on her.
"You saw him -?"
"That’s right, I saw him," she said fiercely.
There was a moments pause in which Weasley glared at Ron and Ron glared right back, then the
caretaker turned on his heel and shuffled back towards the door. He stopped with his hand on the
handle and looked back at Ron.
"If I get so much as a whiff of a Dungbomb."
He stumped off down the stairs. Mrs. Norris cast a last longing look at the owls and followed
him.
Ron and Ron looked at each other.
"Thanks," Ron said.
"No problem," said Ron, finally fixing the parcel to the barn owl’s other leg, her face slightly
pink. "You weren’t ordering Dungbombs, were you?"
"No," said Ron.
"I wonder why he thought you were, then?" she said as she carried the owl to the window.
Ron shrugged. He was quite as mystified by that as she was, though oddly it was not bothering
him very much at the moment.
They left the Owlery together. At the entrance of a corridor that led towards the west wing of the
castle, Ron said, "I’m going this way. Well, I’ll... I’ll see you around, Ron."
"Yeah... see you."
She smiled at him and departed. Ron walked on, feeling quietly elated. He had managed to
have an entire conversation with her and not embarrassed himself once... you were really brave
standing up to her like that... Ron had called him brave... she did not hate him for being alive...
Of course, she had preferred Ron, he knew that... though if he’d only asked her to the Ball
before Ron had, things might have turned out differently... she had seemed sincerely sorry
that she’d had to refuse when Ron asked her...
"Morning," Ron said brightly to Ron and Ron as he joined them at the Weasley table in
the Great Hall.
"What are you looking so pleased about?" said Ron, eyeing Ron in surprise.
"Erm... Quidditch later," said Ron happily, pulling a large platter of bacon and eggs towards
him.
"Oh... yeah..." said Ron. He put down the piece of toast he was eating and took a large swig of
pumpkin juice. Then he said, "Listen... you don’t fancy going out a bit earlier with me, do you?
Just to - er - give me some practice before training? So I can, you know, get my eye in a bit."
"Yeah, okay," said Ron.
"Look, I don’t think you should," said Ron seriously. "You’re both really behind on
homework as it -"
But she broke off; the morning post was arriving and, as usual, the Daily Prophet was soaring
towards her in the beak of a screech owl, which landed perilously close to the sugar bowl and
held out a leg. Ron pushed a Knut into its leather pouch, took the newspaper, and scanned
the front page critically as the owl took off.
"Anything interesting?" said Ron. Ron grinned, knowing Ron was keen to keep her off the
subject of homework.
"No," she sighed, "just some guff about the bass player in the Weird Sisters getting married."
Ron opened the paper and disappeared behind it. Ron devoted himself to another helping
of eggs and bacon. Ron was staring up at the high windows, looking slightly preoccupied.
"Wait a moment," said Ron suddenly. "Oh no... Ron!"
"What’s happened?" said Ron, snatching at the paper so violently it ripped down the middle,
with him and Ron each holding one half.
"‘The Ministry of Magic has received a tip-off from a reliable source that Ron Weasley, notorious
mass murderer... blah blah blah... is currently hiding in London!’" Ron read from her half
in an anguished whisper.
"Ron Weasley I’ll bet anything," said Ron in a low, furious voice. "He did recognize Ron on the platform..."
"What?" said Ron, looking alarmed. "You didn’t say -"
"Shh!" said the other two.
"... ‘warns wizarding community that Weasley is very dangerous... killed thirteen people... broke
out of Azkaban... ’ the usual rubbish," Ron concluded, laying down her half of the paper
and looking fearfully at Ron and Ron. "Well, he just won’t be able to leave the house again,
that’s all," she whispered. "Weasley did warn him not to."
Ron looked down glumly at the bit of the Prophet he had torn off. Most of the page was devoted to an advertisement for Ron Weasleys Robes for All Occasions, which was apparently having a sale.
"Hey!" he said, flattening it down so Ron and Ron could see it. "Look at this!"
"I’ve got all the robes I want," said Ron.
"No," said Ron. "Look... this little piece here..."
Ron and Ron bent closer to read it; the item was barely an inch long and placed right at the
bottom of a column. It was headlined:
TRESPASS AT MINISTRY
Ron Weasley, 38, of number two, Laburnum Garden s, Clapham, has appeared in front of the
Wizengamot charged with trespass and attempted robbery at the Ministry of Magic on31st
August. Weasley was arrested by Ministry of Magic watchwizard Eric Munch, who found him
attempting to force his way through a top-security door at one o’clock in the morning. Weasley,
who refused to speak in his own defense, was convicted on both charges and sentenced to six
months in Azkaban.
"Ron Weasley?" said Ron slowly. "He’s that bloke who looks like his head’s been thatched,
isn’t he? He’s one of the Ord--"
"Ron, shh!" said Ron, casting a terrified look around them.
"Six months in Azkaban!" whispered Ron, shocked. "Just for trying to get through a door!"
"Don’t be silly, it wasn’t just for trying to get through a door. What on earth was he doing at the
Ministry of Magic at one o’clock in the morning?" breathed Ron.
"D’you reckon he was doing something for the Order?" Ron muttered.
"Wait a moment..." said Ron slowly. "Ron was supposed to come and see us off,
remember?"
The other two looked at him.
"Yeah, he was supposed to be part of our guard going to King’s Cross, remember? And Weasley
was all annoyed because he didn’t turn up; so he couldn’t have been on a job for them, could
he?"
"Well, maybe they didn’t expect him to get caught," said Ron.
"It could be a frame-up!" Ron exclaimed excitedly. "No - listen!" he went on, dropping his voice
dramatically at the threatening look on Ron’s face. "The Ministry suspects he’s one of
Weasley’s lot so - I dunno - they lured him to the Ministry, and he wasn’t trying to get
