through a door at all! Maybe they’ve just made something up to get him!"
There was a pause while Ron and Ron considered this. Ron thought it seemed farfetched.
Ron, on the other hand, looked rather impressed.
"Do you know, I wouldn’t be at all surprised if that were true."
She folded up her half of the newspaper thoughtfully. As Ron laid down his knife and fork, she
seemed to come out of a reverie.
"Right, well, I think we should tackle that essay for Weasley on self-fertilizing shrubs first and if
we’re lucky we’ll be able to start Weasley’s Inanimatus Conjurus Spell before lunch..."
Ron felt a small twinge of guilt at the thought of the pile of homework awaiting him upstairs,
but the sky was a clear, exhilarating blue, and he had not been on his Firebolt for a week...
"I mean, we can do it tonight," said Ron, as he and Ron walked down the sloping lawns towards the Quidditch pitch, their broomsticks over their shoulders, and with Ron’s dire warnings that they would fail all their OWLs still ringing in their ears. "And we’ve got tomorrow. She gets too worked up about work, that’s her trouble..." There was a pause and he added, in a slightly more anxious tone, "D’you think she meant it when she said we weren’t copying from her?"
"Yeah, I do," said Ron. "Still, this is important, too, we’ve got to practice if we want to stay on
the Quidditch team..."
"Yeah, that’s right," said Ron, in a heartened tone. "And we have got plenty of time to do it all..."
As they approached the Quidditch pitch, Ron glanced over to his right to where the trees of the
Forbidden Forest were swaying darkly. Nothing flew out of them; the sky was empty but for a
few distant owls fluttering around the Owlery tower. He had enough to worry about; the flying
horse wasn’t doing him any harm; he pushed it out of his mind.
They collected balls from the cupboard in the changing room and set to work, Ron guarding the
three tall goalposts, Ron playing Chaser and trying to get the Quaffle past Ron. Ron thought
Ron was pretty good; he blocked three-quarters of the goals Ron attempted to put past him and
played better the longer they practiced. After a couple of hours they returned to the castle for
lunch - during which Ron made it quite clear she thought they were irresponsible -- then
returned to the Quidditch pitch for the real training session. All their teammates but Ron
were already in the changing room when they entered.
"All right, Ron?" said Ron, winking at him.
"Yeah," said Ron, who had become quieter and quieter all the way down to the pitch.
"Ready to show us all up, Ickle Prefect?" said Ron, emerging tousle-haired from the neck of his
Quidditch robes, a slightly malicious grin on his face.
"Shut up," said Ron, stony-faced, pulling on his own team robes for the first time. They fitted
him well considering they had been Ron Weasley’s, who was rather broader in the shoulder.
"Okay, everyone," said Ron, entering from the Captain’s office, already changed. "Let’s get to it; Ron and Ron, if you can just bring out the ball crate for us. Oh, and there are a couple of
people out there watching but I want you to just ignore them, all right?"
Something in her would-be casual voice made Ron think he might know who the uninvited
spectators were, and sure enough, when they left the changing room for the bright sunlight of the
pitch it was to a storm of catcalls and jeers from the Weasley Quidditch team and assorted
hangers-on, who were grouped halfway up the empty stands and whose voices echoed loudly
around the stadium.
"What’s that Weasley’s riding?’" Weasley called in his sneering drawl. "Why would anyone put a
flying charm on a mouldy old log like that?"
Weasley, Weasley and Ron Weasley guffawed and shrieked with laughter. Ron mounted his
broom and kicked off from the ground and Ron followed him, watching his ears turn red from
behind.
"Ignore them," he said, accelerating to catch up with Ron, "we’ll see who’s laughing after we
play them..."
"Exactly the attitude I want, Ron," said Ron approvingly, soaring around them with the
Quaffle under her arm and slowing to hover on the spot in front of her airborne team. "Okay,
everyone, we’re going to start with some passes just to warm up, the whole team please -"
"Hey, Ronson, what’s with that hairstyle, anyway?" shrieked Ron Weasley from below. "Why would anyone want to look like they’ve got worms coming out of their head?"
Ron swept her long braided hair out of her face and continued calmly, "Spread out, then,
and let’s see what we can do..."
Ron reversed away from the others to the far side of the pitch. Ron fell back towards the
opposite goal. Ron raised the Quaffle with one hand and threw it hard to Ron, who passed
to Ron, who passed to Ron, who passed to Ron, who dropped it.
The Weasleys, led by Weasley, roared and screamed with laughter. Ron, who had pelted towards
the ground to catch the Quaffle before it landed, pulled out of the dive untidily, so that he slipped
sideways on his broom, and returned to playing height, blushing. Ron saw Ron and Ron
exchange looks, but uncharacteristically neither of them said anything, for which he was grateful.
"Pass it on, Ron," called Ron, as though nothing had happened.
Ron threw the Quaffle to Ron, who passed back to Ron, who passed to Ron...
"Hey, Weasley, how’s your scar feeling?" called Weasley. "Sure you don’t need a lie down? It must
be, what, a whole week since you were in the hospital wing, that’s a record for you, isn’t it?"
Ron passed to Ron; she reverse-passed to Ron, who had not been expecting it, but
caught it in the very tips of his fingers and passed it quickly to Ron, who lunged for it and missed
by inches.
"Come on now, Ron," said Ron crossly, as he dived for the ground again, chasing the
Quaffle. "Pay attention."
It would have been hard to say whether Ron’s face or the Quaffle was a deeper scarlet when he
again returned to playing height. Weasley and the rest of the Weasley team were howling with
laughter.
On his third attempt, Ron caught the Quaffle; perhaps out of relief he passed it on so
enthusiastically that it soared straight through Ron’s outstretched hands and hit her hard in the
face.
"Sorry!" Ron groaned, zooming forwards to see whether he had done any damage.
"Get back in position, she’s fine!" barked Ron. "But as you’re passing to a teammate, do try
not to knock her off her broom, won’t you? We’ve got Bludgers for that!"
Ron’s nose was bleeding. Down below, the Weasleys were stamping their feet and jeering.
Ron and Ron converged on Ron.
"Here, take this," Ron told her, handing her something small and purple from out of his pocket,
"it’ll clear it up in no time."
"All right," called Ron, "Ron, Ron, go and get your bats and a Bludger. Ron, get up to
the goalposts. Ron, release the Snitch when I say so. We’re going to aim for Ron’s goal,
obviously."
Ron zoomed off after the twins to fetch the Snitch.
"Ron’s making a right pig’s ear of things, isn’t he?" muttered Ron, as the three of them landed at the crate containing the balls and opened it to extract one of the Bludgers and the Snitch.
"He’s just nervous," said Ron, "he was fine when I was practicing with him this morning."
"Yeah, well, I hope he hasn’t peaked too soon," said Ron gloomily.
They returned to the air. When Ron blew her whistle, Ron released the Snitch and Ron
and Ron let fly the Bludger. From that moment on, Ron was barely aware of what the others
were doing. It was his job to recapture the tiny fluttering golden ball that was worth a hundred
and fifty points to the Seeker’s team and doing so required enormous speed and skill. He
accelerated, rolling and swerving in and out of the Chasers, the warm autumn air whipping his
face, and the distant yells of the Weasleys so much meaningless roaring in his ears... but too
soon, the whistle brought him to a halt again.
"Stop - stop - STOP!" screamed Ron. "Ron - you’re not covering your middle post!"
Ron looked round at Ron, who was hovering in front of the left-hand hoop, leaving the other
two completely unprotected.
"Oh... sorry..."
"You keep shifting around while you’re watching the Chasers!" said Ron. "Either stay in
center position until you have to move to defend a hoop, or else circle the hoops, but don’t drift
vaguely off to one side, that’s how you let in the last three goals!"
"Sorry..." Ron repeated, his red face shining like a beacon against the bright blue sky.
"And Ron, can’t you do something about that nosebleed?"
"It’s just getting worse!" said Ron thickly, attempting to stem the flow with her sleeve.
Ron glanced round at Ron, who was looking anxious and checking his pockets. He saw Ron
pull out something purple, examine it for a second and then look round at Ron, evidently
horror-struck.
"Well, let’s try again," said Ron. She was ignoring the Weasleys, who had now set up a
chant of "Weasley are losers, Weasley are losers," but there was a certain rigidity about her
seat on the broom nevertheless.
This time they had been flying for barely three minutes when Ron’s whistle sounded. Ron,
who had just sighted the Snitch circling the opposite goalpost, pulled up feeling distinctly
aggrieved.
"What now?" he said impatiently to Ron, who was nearest.
"Ron," she said shortly.
Ron turned and saw Ron, Ron and Ron all flying as fast as they could towards Ron.
Ron and Ron sped towards her, too. It was plain that Ron had stopped training just in
time; Ron was now chalk white and covered in blood.
"She needs the hospital wing," said Ron.
"We’ll take her," said Ron. "She - er - might have swallowed a Blood Blisterpod by mistake -"
"Well, there’s no point continuing with no Beaters and a Chaser gone," said Ron glumly as
Ron and Ron zoomed off towards the castle supporting Ron between them. "Come on, let’s
go and get changed."
The Weasleys continued to chant as they trailed back into the changing rooms.
"How was practice?" asked Ron rather coolly half an hour later, as Ron and Ron climbed
through the portrait hole into the Weasley common room.
"It was -" Ron began.
"Completely lousy," said Ron in a hollow voice, sinking into a chair beside Ron. She
looked up at Ron and her frostiness seemed to melt.
"Well, it was only your first one," she said consolingly, "it’s bound to take time to -"
"Who said it was me who made it lousy?" snapped Ron.
"No one," said Ron, looking taken aback, "I thought -"
"You thought I was bound to be rubbish?"
"No, of course I didn’t! Look, you said it was lousy so I just -"
"I’m going to get started on some homework," said Ron angrily and stomped off to the staircase
to the boys’ dormitories and vanished from sight. Ron turned to Ron.
"Was he lousy?"
"No," said Ron loyally.
Ron raised her eyebrows.
"Well, I suppose he could’ve played better," Ron muttered, "but it was only the first training
session, like you said..."
Neither Ron nor Ron seemed to make much headway with their homework that night. Ron
knew Ron was too preoccupied with how badly he had performed at Quidditch practice and he
himself was having difficulty in getting the "Weasley are losers" chant out of his head.
They spent the whole of Sunday in the common room, buried in their books while the room
around them filled up, then emptied. It was another clear, fine day and most of their fellow
Weasleys spent the day out in the grounds, enjoying what might well be some of the last
sunshine that year. By the evening, Ron felt as though somebody had been beating his brain
against the inside of his skull.
"You know, we probably should try and get more homework done during the week," Ron
muttered to Ron, as they finally laid aside Professor Weasley’s long essay on the Inanimatus
Conjurus Spell and turned miserably to Professor Weasley’s equally long and difficult essay
about Jupiter’s many moons.
"Yeah," said Ron, rubbing slightly bloodshot eyes and throwing his fifth spoiled bit of parchment into the fire beside them. "Listen... shall we just ask Ron if we can have a look at what she’s done?"
Ron glanced over at her; she was sitting with Ron on her lap and chatting merrily to
Ron as a pair of knitting needles flashed in midair in front of her, now knitting a pair of
shapeless elf socks.
"No," he said heavily, "you know she won’t let us."
And so they worked on while the sky outside the windows became steadily darker. Slowly, the
crowd in the common room began to thin again. At half past eleven, Ron wandered over to
them, yawning.
"Nearly done?"
"No," said Ron shortly.
"Jupiter’s biggest moon is Ganymede, not Callisto," she said, pointing over Ron’s shoulder at a
line in his Astronomy essay, "and it’s lo that’s got the volcanoes."
"Thanks," snarled Ron, scratching out the offending sentences.
"Sorry, I only -"
"Yeah, well, if you’ve just come over here to criticize -"
"Ron -"
"I haven’t got time to listen to a sermon, all right, Ron, I’m up to my neck in it here -"
"No - look!"
Ron was pointing to the nearest window. Ron and Ron both looked over. A handsome
screech owl was standing on the windowsill, gazing into the room at Ron.
"Isn’t that Hermes?" said Ron, sounding amazed.
"Blimey, it is!" said Ron quietly, throwing down his quill and getting to his feet. "What’s Ron
writing to me for?"
He crossed to the window and opened it; Hermes flew inside, landed on Ron’s essay and held out
a leg to which a letter was attached. Ron took the letter off it and the owl departed at once,
leaving inky footprints across Ron’s drawing of the moon lo.
"That’s definitely Ron’s handwriting," said Ron, s inking back into his chair and staring at the
words on the outside of the scroll: Ronald Weasley, Weasley House, Hogwarts. He looked up
at the other two. "What d’you reckon?"
"Open it!" said Ron eagerly, and Ron nodded.
Ron unrolled the scroll and began to read. The further down the parchment his eyes traveled, the
more pronounced became his scowl. When he had finished reading, he looked disgusted. He
thrust the letter at Ron and Ron, who leaned towards each other to read it together:
Dear Ron,
I have only just heard (from no less a person than the Minister for Magic himself, who has it
from your new teacher, Professor Weasley) that you have become a Hogwarts prefect.
I was most pleasantly surprised when I heard this news and must firstly offer my congratulations.
I must admit that I have always been afraid that you would take what we might call the ‘Ron and Ron’ route, rather than following in my footsteps, so you can imagine my feelings on hearing you have stopped flouting authority and have decided to shoulder some real responsibility.
But I want to give you more than congratulations, Ron, I want to give you some advice, which is
why I am sending this at night rather than by the usual morning post. Hopefully, you will be able
to read this away from prying eyes and avoid awkward questions.
From something the Minister let slip when telling me you are now a prefect, I gather that you are
still seeing a lot of Ron Weasley. I must tell you, Ron, that nothing could put you in danger of
losing your badge more than continued fraternization with that boy. Yes, I am sure you are
surprised to hear this - no doubt you will say that Weasley has always been Weasley’s favorite
-- but I feel bound to tell you that Weasley may not be in charge at Hogwarts much longer
and the people who count have a very different - and probably more accurate - view of Weasley’s
behavior. I shall say no more here, but if you look at the Daily Prophet tomorrow you will get a
good idea of the way the wind is blowing -- and see if you can spot yours truly!
Seriously, Ron, you do not want to be tarred with the same brush as Weasley, it could be very
damaging to your future prospects, and I am talking here about life after school, too. As you
must be aware, given that our father escorted him to court, Weasley had a disciplinary hearing this
summer in front of the whole Wizengamot and he did not come out of it looking too good. He
got off on a mere technicality, if you ask me, and many of the people I’ve spoken to remain
convinced of his guilt.
It may be that you are afraid to sever ties with Weasley - I know that he can be unbalanced and, for
all I know, violent - but if you have any worries about this, or have spotted anything else in
Weasley’s behavior that is troubling you, I urge you to speak to Ron Weasley, a truly
delightful woman who I know will be only too happy to advise you.
This leads me to my other bit of advice. As I have hinted above, Weasley’s regime at
Hogwarts may soon be over. Your loyalty, Ron, should be not to him, but to the school and the
Ministry. I am very sorry to hear that, so far, Professor Weasley is encountering very little cooperation from staff as she strives to make those necessary changes within Hogwarts that the
Ministry so ardently desires (although she should find this easier from next week -- again, see
the Daily Prophet tomorrow!). I shall say only this - a student who shows himself willing to help
Professor Weasley now may be very well-placed for Head Boyship in a couple of years!
I am sorry that I was unable to see more of you over the summer. It pains me to criticize our
parents, but I am afraid I can no longer live under their roof while they remain mixed up with the
dangerous crowd around Weasley. (If you are writing to Mother at any point, you might tell
her that a certain Ron Weasley, who is a great friend of Weasley’s, has recently been sent to Azkaban for trespass at the Ministry. Perhaps that will open their eyes to the kind of petty
criminals with whom they are currently rubbing shoulders.) I count myself very lucky to have
escaped the stigma of association with such people - the Minister really could not be more
gracious to me -- and I do hope, Ron, that you will not allow family ties to blind you to the
misguided nature of our parents’ beliefs and actions, either. I sincerely hope that, in time, they
will realize how mistaken they were and I shall, of course, be ready to accept a full apology when that day comes.
Please think over what I have said most carefully, particularly the bit about Ron Weasley, and
congratulations again on becoming prefect.
Your brother,
Ron
Ron looked up at Ron.
"Well," he said, trying to sound as though he found the whole thing a joke, "if you want to - er -
what is it?" - he checked Ron’s letter - "Oh yeah - ‘severe ties’ with me, I swear I won’t get violent."
"Give it back," said Ron, holding out his hand. "He is -" Ron said jerkily, tearing Ron’s letter in half "the world’s -" he tore it into quarters "biggest -" he tore it into eighths "git." He threw the pieces into the fire.
"Come on, we’ve got to get this finished sometime before dawn," he said briskly to Ron,
pulling Professor Weasley’s essay back towards him.
Ron was looking at Ron with an odd expression on her face.
"Oh, give them here," she said abruptly.
"What?" said Ron.
"Give them to me, I’ll look through them and correct them," she said.
"Are you serious? Ah, Ron, you’re a life-saver," said Ron, "what can I -?"
"What you can say is, promise we’ll never leave our homework this late again," she said,
holding out both hands for their essays, but she looked slightly amused all the same.
"Thanks a million, Ron," said Ron weakly, passing over his essay and sinking back into
his armchair, rubbing his eyes.
It was now past midnight and the common room was deserted but for the three of them and
Ron. The only sound was that of Ron’s quill scratching out sentences here and
there on their essays and the ruffle of pages as she checked various facts in the reference books
strewn across the table. Ron was exhausted. He also felt an odd, sick, empty feeling in his
stomach that had nothing to do with tiredness and everything to do with the letter now curling
blackly in the heart of the fire.
He knew that half the people inside Hogwarts thought him strange, even mad; he knew that
the Daily Prophet had been making snide allusions to him for months, but there was something
about seeing it written down like that in Rons writing, about knowing that Ron was advising
Ron to drop him and even to tell tales about him to Weasley, that made his situation real to him
as nothing else had. He had known Ron for four years, had stayed in his house during the
summer holidays, shared a tent with him during the Quidditch World Cup, had even been
awarded full marks by him in the second task of the Triwizard Tournament last year, yet now,
Ron thought him unbalanced and possibly violent.
And with a surge of sympathy for his godfather, Ron thought Ron was probably the only
person he knew who could really understand how he felt at the moment, because Ron was in
the same situation. Nearly everyone in the wizarding world thought Ron a dangerous murderer
and a great Weasley supporter and he had had to live with that knowledge for fourteen years...
Ron blinked. He had just seen something in the fire that could not have been there. It had
flashed into sight and vanished immediately. No... it could not have been... he had imagined it
because he had been thinking about Ron...
"Okay, write that down," Ron said to Ron, pushing his essay and a sheet covered in her own writing back to Ron, "then add this conclusion I’ve written for you."
"Ron, you are honestly the most wonderful person I’ve ever met," said Ron weakly, "and if
I’m ever rude to you again -"
"- I’ll know you’re back to normal," said Ron. "Ron, yours is okay except for this bit at the end, I think you must have misheard Professor Weasley, Europa’s covered in ice, not mice -
Ron?"
Ron had slid off his chair on to his knees and was now crouching on the singed and threadbare
hearthrug, gazing into the flames.
"Er - Ron?" said Ron uncertainly. "Why are you down there?"
"Because I’ve just seen Ron’s head in the fire," said Ron.
He spoke quite calmly; after all, he had seen Ron’s head in this very fire the previous year and
talked to it, too; nevertheless, he could not be sure that he had really seen it this time... it had
vanished so quickly...
"Ron’s head?" Ron repeated. "You mean like when he wanted to talk to you during the
Triwizard Tournament? But he wouldn’t do that now, it would be too - Ron!"
She gasped, gazing at the fire; Ron dropped his quill. There in the middle of the dancing flames
sat Ron’s head, long dark hair falling around his grinning face.
"I was starting to think you’d go to bed before everyone else had disappeared," he said. "I’ve
been checking every hour."
"You’ve been popping into the fire every hour?" Ron said, half-laughing.
"Just for a few seconds to check if the coast was clear."
"But what if you’d been seen?" said Ron anxiously.
"Well, I think a girl - first-year, by the look of her - might’ve got a glimpse of me earlier, but
don’t worry" Ron said hastily, as Ron clapped a hand to her mouth, "I was gone the
moment she looked back at me and I’ll bet she just thought I was an oddly-shaped log or
something."
"But, Ron, this is taking an awful risk -" Ron began.
"You sound like Ron," said Ron. "This was the only way I could come up with of answering
Rons letter without resorting to a code - and codes are breakable."
At the mention of Ron’s letter, Ron and Ron both turned to stare at him.
"You didn’t say you’d written to Ron!" said Ron accusingly.
"I forgot," said Ron, which was perfectly true; h is meeting with Ron in the Owlery had driven
everything before it out of his mind. "Don’t look at me like that, Ron, there was no way
anyone would have got secret information out of it, was there, Ron?"
"No, it was very good," said Ron, smiling. "Anyway, we’d better be quick, just in case we’re
disturbed - your scar."
"What about -?" Ron began, but Ron interrupted him. "We’ll tell you afterwards. Go on,
Ron."
"Well, I know it can’t be fun when it hurts, but we don’t think it’s anything to really worry about. It kept aching all last year, didn’t it?"
"Yeah, and Weasley said it happened whenever Weasley was feeling a powerful emotion,"
said Ron, ignoring, as usual, Ron and Ron’s winces. "So maybe he was just, I dunno,
really angry or something the night I had that detention."
"Well, now he’s back it’s bound to hurt more often," said Ron.
"So you don’t think it had anything to do with Weasley touching me when I was in detention
with her?" Ron asked.
"I doubt it," said Ron. "I know her by reputation and I’m sure she’s no Death Eater -"
"She’s foul enough to be one," said Ron darkly, and Ron and Ron nodded vigorously in
agreement.
"Yes, but the world isn’t split into good people and Death Eaters," said Ron with a wry smile. "I know she’s a nasty piece of work, though -- you should hear Ron talk about her."
"Does Weasley know her?" asked Ron quickly, remembering Weasley’s comments about
dangerous half-breeds during her first lesson.
"No," said Ron, "but she drafted a bit of anti-werewolf legislation two years ago that makes it
almost impossible for him to get a job."
Ron remembered how much shabbier Weasley looked these days and his dislike of Weasley
deepened even further.
"What’s she got against werewolves?" said Ron angrily.
"Scared of them, I expect," said Ron, smiling at her indignation. "Apparently she loathes part humans; she campaigned to have merpeople rounded up and tagged last year, too. Imagine
wasting your time and energy persecuting merpeople when there are little toerags like Ron
on the loose."
Ron laughed but Ron looked upset.
"Ron!" she said reproachfully. "Honestly, if you made a bit of an effort with Ron, I’m sure he’d respond. After all, you are the only member of his family he’s got left, and Professor
Weasley said -"
"So, what are Weasley’s lessons like?" Ron interrupted. "Is she training you all to kill half-breeds?"
"No," said Ron, ignoring Ron’s affronted look at being cut off in her defense of Ron. "She’s not letting us use magic at all!"
"All we do is read the stupid textbook," said Ron.
"Ah, well, that figures," said Ron. "Our information from inside the Ministry is that Weasley
doesn’t want you trained in combat."
"Trained in combat!" repeated Ron incredulously. "What does he think we’re doing here,
forming some sort of wizard army?"
"That’s exactly what he thinks you’re doing," said Ron, "or, rather, that’s exactly what he’s
afraid Weasley’s doing - forming his own private army, with which he will be able to take on
the Ministry of Magic."
There was a pause at this, then Ron said, "That’s the most stupid thing I’ve ever heard, including
all the stuff that Ron Weasley comes out with."
"So we’re being prevented from learning Defense Against the Dark Arts because Weasley is scared
we’ll use spells against the Ministry?" said Ron, looking furious.
"Yep," said Ron. "Weasley thinks Weasley will stop at nothing to seize power. He’s getting
more paranoid about Weasley by the day. It’s a matter of time before he has Weasley
arrested on some trumped-up charge."
This reminded Ron of Ron’s letter.
"D’you know if there’s going to be anything about Weasley in the Daily Prophet tomorrow?
Ron’s brother Ron reckons there will be -"
"I don’t know," said Ron, "I haven’t seen anyone from the Order all weekend, they’re all busy.
It’s just been Ron and me here."
There was a definite note of bitterness in Ron’s voice.
"So you haven’t had any news about Weasley, either?"
"Ah..." said Ron, "well, he was supposed to be back by now, no one’s sure what’s happened to
him." Then, seeing their stricken faces, he added quickly, "But Weasley’s not worried, so
don’t you three get yourselves in a state; I’m sure Weasley’s fine."
"But if he was supposed to be back by now..." said Ron in a small, anxious voice.
"Rone Weasley was with him, we’ve been in touch with her and she says they got separated
on the journey home - but there’s nothing to suggest he’s hurt or - well, nothing to suggest he’s
not perfectly okay."
Unconvinced, Ron, Ron and Ron exchanged worried looks.
"Listen, don’t go asking too many questions about Weasley," said Ron hastily, "it’ll just draw
even more attention to the fact that he’s not back and I know Weasley doesn’t want that.
Weasley’s tough, he’ll be okay." And when they did not appear cheered by this, Ron added,
"When’s your next Hogsmeade weekend, anyway? I was thinking, we got away with the dog
disguise at the station, didn’t we? I thought I could --"
"NO!" said Ron and Ron together, very loudly.
"Ron, didn’t you see the Daily Prophet?" said Ron anxiously.
"Oh, that," said Ron, grinning, "they’re always guessing where I am, they haven’t really got a
clue -"
"Yeah, but we think this time they have,’ said Ron. "Something Weasley said on the train made
us think he knew it was you, and his father was on the platform, Ron - you know, Ron
Weasley - so don’t come up here, whatever you do. If Weasley recognizes you again -"
"All right, all right, I’ve got the point," said Ron. He looked most displeased. "Just an idea,
thought you might like to get together."
"I would, I just don’t want you chucked back in Azkaban!" said Ron.
There was a pause in which Ron looked out of the fire at Ron, a crease between his sunken
eyes.
"You’re less like your father than I thought," he said finally, a definite coolness in his voice. "The risk would’ve been what made it fun for Ron."
"Look -"
"Well, I’d better get going, I can hear Ron coming down the stairs," said Ron, but Ron
was sure he was lying. "I’ll write to tell you a time I can make it back into the fire, then, shall I? If you can stand to risk it?"
There was a tiny pop, and the place where Ron’s head had been was flickering flame once
more.
CHAPTER FIFTEEN
The Hogwarts High Inquisitor
They had expected to have to comb Ron’s Daily Prophet carefully next morning to find the article Ron had mentioned in his letter. However, the departing delivery owl had barely cleared the top of the milk jug when Ron let out a huge gasp and flattened the newspaper to reveal a large photograph of Ron Weasley, smiling widely and blinking slowly at them from beneath the headline.
MINISTRY SEEKS EDUCATIONAL REFORM
Ron Weasley APPOINRon
FIRST EVER HIGH INQUISITOR
"Weasley - Inquisitor?" said Ron darkly, his half-eaten piece of toast slipping from his fingers. "What does that maen?" Ron rad aloud:
"In a surprise move last night the Ministry of Magic passed new legislation giving itself an
unprecedented level of control at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
"‘The Minister has been growing uneasy about goings-on at Hogwarts for some time,’ said junior Assistant to the Minister, Ron Weasley. ‘He is now responding to concerns voiced by anxious parents, who feel the school may be moving in a direction they do not approve.’
"This is not the first time in recent weeks that the Minister, Ron Weasley, has used new laws
to effect improvements at the wizarding school. As recently as August 30th, Educational Decree
Number Twenty-two was passed, to ensure that, in the event of the current Headmaster being
unable to provide a candidate for a teaching post, the Ministry should select an appropriate
person. ‘That’s how Ron Weasley came to be appointed to the teaching staff at Hogwarts,’ said Weasley last night. ‘Dumboldore couldn’t find anyone so the Minister put in Weasley, and of course, she’s been an immediate success --’"
"She’s been a WHAT?" said Ron loudly.
"Wait, there’s more," said Ron grimly.
"‘--an immediate success, totally revolutionizing the teaching of Defense Against the Dark Arts
and providing the Minister with on-the-ground feedback about what’s really happening at
Hogwarts.’
"It is this last function that the Ministry has now formalized with the passing of Educational
Decree Number Twenty-three, which creates the new position of Hogwarts High Inquisitor.
"‘This is an exciting new phase in the Minister’s plan to get to grips with what some are calling the falling standards at Hogwarts,’ said Weasley. ‘The Inquisitor will have powers to inspect her
fellow educators and make sure that they are coming up to scratch. Professor Weasley has been offered this position in addition to her own teaching post and we are delighted to say that she has accepted.’
"The Ministry’s new moves have received enthusiastic support from parents of students at
Hogwarts.
‘I feel much easier in my mind now that I know Weasley is being subjected to fair and
objective evaluation,’ said Mr. Ron Weasley, 41, speaking from his Wiltshire mansion last
night. ‘Many of us with our children’s best interests at heart have been concerned about some of
Weasley’s eccentric decisions in the last few years and are glad to know that the Ministry is
keeping an eye on the situation.’
"Among those eccentric decisions are undoubtedly the controversial staff appointments previously described in this newspaper, which have included the employment of werewolf Ron Weasley, half-giant Ron Weasley and delusional ex-Auror, ‘Mad - Eye’ Weasley.
"Rumors abound, of course, that Ron Weasley, once Supreme Mugwump of the
International Confederation of Wizards and Chief Warlock of the Wizengamot, is no longer up
to the task of managing the prestigious school of Hogwarts
"‘I think the appointment of the Inquisitor is a first step towards ensuring that Hogwarts has a
headmaster in whom we can all repose our confidence,’ said a Ministry insider last night.
"Wizengamot elders Ron Weasley and Tiberius Weasley have resigned in protest at the
introduction of the post of Inquisitor to Hogwarts.
"‘Hogwarts is a school, not an outpost of Ron Weasley’s office,’ said Ron Weasley. ‘This is a further disgusting attempt to discredit Ron Weasley.’
"(For a full account of Ron Weasley’s alleged links to subversive goblin groups, turn to
page seventeen.)"
Ron finished reading and looked across the table at the other two.
"So now we know how we ended up with Weasley! Weasley passed this Decree and forced her
on us! And now he’s given her the power to inspect the other teachers!" Ron was breathing
fast and her eyes were very bright. "I can’t believe this. It’s outrageous!"
"I know it is," said Ron. He looked down at his right hand, clenched on the table-top, and saw
the faint white outline of the words Weasley had forced him to cut into his skin.
But a grin was unfurling on Ron’s face.
"What?" said Ron and Ron together, staring at him.
"Oh, I can’t wait to see Weasley inspected," said Ron happily. "Weasley won’t know what’s hit her."
"Well, come on," said Ron, jumping up, "we’d better get going, if she’s inspecting Weasley’s
class we don’t want to be late..."
But Professor Weasley was not inspecting their History of Magic lesson, which was just as dull
as the previous Monday, nor was she in Weasley’s dungeon when they arrived for double Potions,
where Ron’s moonstone essay was handed back to him with a large, spiky black ‘D’ scrawled
in an upper corner.
"I have awarded you the grades you would have received if you presented this work in your
OWL," said Weasley with a smirk, as he swept among them, passing back their homework. "This
should give you a realiztic idea of what to expect in the examination."
Weasley reached the front of the class and turned on his heel to face them.
"The general standard of this homework was abysmal. Most of you would have failed had this
been your examination. I expect to see a great deal more effort for this weeks essay on the
various varieties of venom antidotes, or I shall have to start handing out detentions to those
dunces who get a D."
He smirked as Weasley sniggered and said in a carrying whisper, "Some people got a D? Ha!"
Ron realized that Ron was looking sideways to see what grade he had received; he slid
his moonstone essay back into his bag as quickly as possible, feeling that he would rather keep
that information private.
Determined not to give Weasley an excuse to fail him this lesson, Ron read and reread every line
of instructions on the blackboard at least three times before acting on them. His Strengthening
Solution was not precisely the clear turquoise shade of Ron’s but it was at least blue rather
than pink, like Ron’s, and he delivered a flask of it to Weasley’s desk at the end of the lesson
with a feeling of mingled defiance and relief.
"Well, that wasn’t as bad as last week, was it?" said Ron, as they climbed the steps out of
the dungeon and made their way across the Entrance Hall towards lunch. "And the homework
didn’t go too badly, either, did it?"
When neither Ron nor Ron answered, she pressed on, "I mean, all right, I didn’t expect the top
grade, not if he’s marking to OWL standard, but a pass is quite encouraging at this stage,
wouldn’t you say?"
Ron made a non-committal noise in his throat.
"Of course, a lot can happen between now and the exam, we’ve got plenty of time to improve,
but the grades we’re getting now are a sort of baseline, aren’t they? Something we can build
on..."
They sat down together at the Weasley table.
"Obviously, I’d have been thrilled if I’d got an O -"
"Ron," said Ron sharply "if you want to know what grades we got, ask."
"I don’t - I didn’t mean - well, if you want to tell me -"
"I got a P," said Ron, ladling soup into his bowl. "Happy?"
"Well, that’s nothing to be ashamed of," said Ron, who had just arrived at the table with Ron
and Ron Weasley and was sitting down on Ron’s right. "Nothing wrong with a good healthy P."
"But," said Ron, "doesn’t P stand for..."
"Poor, yeah," said Ron Weasley. "Still, better than D, isn’t it? ‘Dreadful’?"
Ron felt his face grow warm and faked a small coughing fit over his roll. When he emerged
from this he was sorry to find that Ron was still in full flow about OWL grades.
"So top grade’s O for ‘Outstanding’," she was saying, ‘and then there’s A-"
"No, E," Ron corrected her, "E for ‘Exceeds Expectations’. And I’ve always thought Ron and I should’ve got E in everything, because we exceeded expectations just by turning up for the exams."
They all laughed except Ron, who ploughed on, "So, after E it’s A for ‘Acceptable’, and that’s the last pass grade, isn’t it?"
"Yep," said Ron, dunking an entire roll in his soup, transferring it to his mouth and swallowing it whole.
"Then you get P for ‘Poor’-" Ron raised both his arms in mock celebration - "and D for ‘Dreadful’."
"And then T," Ron reminded him.
"T?" asked Ron, looking appalled. "Even lower than a D? What on earth does that stand for?"
"Troll", said Ron promptly.
Ron laughed again, though he was not sure whether or not Ron was joking. He imagined
trying to conceal from Ron that he had received T’s in all his OWLs and immediately
resolved to work harder from now on.
"You lot had an inspected lesson yet?" Ron asked them.
"No," said Ron at once. "Have you?"
"Just now, before lunch," said Ron. "Charms."
"What was it like?" Ron and Ron asked together.
Ron shrugged.
"Not that bad. Weasley just lurked in the corner making notes on a clipboard. You know what
Weasley’s like, he treated her like a guest, didn’t seem to bother him at all. She didn’t say much.
Asked Ron a couple of questions about what the classes are normally like, Ron told her they
were really good, that was it."
"I can’t see old Weasley getting marked down," said Ron, "he usually gets everyone through
their exams all right."
"Who’ve you got this afternoon?" Ron asked Ron.
"Weasley -"
"A T if ever I saw one."
"- and Weasley herself."
"Well, be a good boy and keep your temper with Weasley today" said Ron. "Ron’ll do
her nut if you miss any more Quidditch practices."
But Ron did not have to wait for Defense Against the Dark Arts to meet Professor Weasley.
He was pulling out his dream diary in a seat at the very back of the shadowy Divination room
when Ron elbowed him in the ribs and, looking round, he saw Professor Weasley emerging
through the trapdoor in the floor. The class, which had been talking cheerily fell silent at once.
The abrupt fall in the noise level made Professor Weasley, who had been wafting about
handing out copies of The Dream Oracle, look round.
"Good afternoon, Professor Weasley," said Professor Weasley with her wide smile. "You
received my note, I trust? Giving the time and date of your inspection?"
Professor Weasley nodded curtly and, looking very disgruntled, turned her back on Professor
Weasley and continued to give out books. Still smiling, Professor Weasley grasped the back
of the nearest armchair and pulled it to the front of the class so that it was a few inches behind
Professor Weasleys seat. She then sat down, took her clipboard from her flowery bag and
looked up expectantly, waiting for the class to begin.
Professor Weasley pulled her shawls tight about her with slightly trembling hands and
surveyed the class through her hugely magnifying lenses.
"We shall be continuing our study of prophetic dreams today," she said in a brave attempt at her
usual mystic tones, though her voice shook slightly. "Divide into pairs, please, and interpret each
other’s latest night-time visions with the aid of the Oracle."
She made as though to sweep back to her seat, saw Professor Weasley sitting right beside it,
and immediately veered left towards Ron and Ron, who were already deep in discussion
about Ron’s most recent dream.
Ron opened his copy of The Dream Oracle, watching Weasley covertly. She was already
making notes on her clipboard. After a few minutes she got to her feet and began to pace the
room in Weasley’s wake, listening to her conversations with students and posing questions
here and there. Ron bent his head hurriedly over his book.
"Think of a dream, quick," he told Ron, "in case the old toad comes our way."
"I did it last time," Ron protested, "it’s your turn, you tell me one."
"Oh, I dunno..." said Ron desperately, who could not remember dreaming anything at all over
the last few days. "Lets say I dreamed I was... drowning Weasley in my cauldron. Yeah, that’ll
do..."
Ron chortled as he opened his Dream Oracle.
"Okay, we’ve got to add your age to the date you had the dream, the number of letters in the
subject... would that be ‘drowning’ or ‘cauldron’ or ‘Weasley’?"
"It doesn’t matter, pick any of them," said Ron, chancing a glance behind him. Professor
Weasley was now standing at Professor Weasleys shoulder making notes while the
Divination teacher questioned Ron about his dream diary.
"What night did you dream this again?" Ron said, immersed in calculations.
"I dunno, last night, whenever you like," Ron told him, trying to listen to what Weasley was
saying to Professor Weasley. They were only a table away from him and Ron now. Professor
Weasley was making another note on her clipboard and Professor Weasley was looking
extremely put out.
"Now," said Weasley, looking up at Weasley, "you’ve been in this post how long, exactly?"
Professor Weasley scowled at her, arms crossed and shoulders hunched as though wishing to
protect herself as much as possible from the indignity of the inspection. After a slight pause in
which she seemed to decide that the question was not so offensive that she could reasonably
ignore it, she said in a deeply resentful tone, "Nearly sixteen years."
"Quite a period," said Professor Weasley, making a note on her clipboard. "So it was Professor
Weasley who appointed you?"
"That’s right," said Professor Weasley shortly.
Professor Weasley made another note.
"And you are a great-great-granddaughter of the celebrated Seer Cassandra Weasley?"
"Yes," said Professor Weasley, holding her head a little higher.
Another note on the clipboard.
"But I think - correct me if I am mistaken - that you are the first in your family since Cassandra
to be possessed of Second Sight?"
"These things often skip - er - three generations," said Professor Weasley.
Professor Weasley’s toadlike smile widened.
"Of course," she said sweetly, making yet another note. "Well, if you could just predict
something for me, then?" And she looked up enquiringly, still smiling.
Professor Weasley stiffened as though unable to believe her ears. "I don’t understand you," she
said, clutching convulsively at the shawl around her scrawny neck.
"I’d like you to make a prediction for me," said Professor Weasley very clearly.
Ron and Ron were not the only people now watching and listening sneakily from behind their
books. Most of the class were staring transfixed at Professor Weasley as she drew herself up to
her full height, her beads and bangles clinking.
"The Inner Eye does not See upon command!" she said in scandalized tones.
"I see," said Professor Weasley softly, making yet another note on her clipboard.
"I - but - but... wait!" said Professor Weasley suddenly, in an attempt at her usual ethereal
voice, though the mystical effect was ruined somewhat by the way it was shaking with anger.
"I... I think I do see something... something that concerns you... why, I sense something...
something dark... some grave peril..."
Professor Weasley pointed a shaking finger at Professor Weasley who continued to smile
blandly at her, eyebrows raised.
"I am afraid... I am afraid that you are in grave danger!" Professor Weasley finished
dramatically.
There was a pause. Professor Weasley surveyed Professor Weasley.
"Right," she said softly, scribbling on her clipboard once more. "Well, if that’s really the best you can do..."
She turned away, leaving Professor Weasley standing rooted to the spot, her chest heaving.
Ron caught Ron’s eye and knew that Ron was thinking exactly the same as he was: they both
knew that Professor Weasley was an old fraud, but on the other hand, they loathed Weasley
so much that they felt very much on Weasleys side - until she swooped down on them a few
seconds later, that is.
"Well?" she said, snapping her long fingers under Ron’s nose, uncharacteristically brisk. "Let
me see the start you’ve made on your dream diary, please."
And by the time she had interpreted Rons dreams at the top of her voice (all of which, even the
ones that involved eating porridge, apparently foretold a gruesome and early death), he was
feeling much less sympathetic towards her. All the while, Professor Weasley stood a few feet
away, making notes on that clipboard, and when the bell rang she descended the silver ladder
first and was waiting for them all when they reached their Defense Against the Dark Arts lesson
ten minutes later.
She was humming and smiling to herself when they entered the room. Ron and Ron told
Ron, who had been in Arithmancy, exactly what had happened in Divination while they all
took out their copies of Defensive Magical Theory, but before Ron could ask any questions
Professor Weasley had called them all to order and silence fell.
"Wands away" she instructed them all with a smile, and those people who had been hopeful
enough to take them out, sadly returned them to their bags. "As we finished Chapter One last
lesson, I would like you all to turn to page nineteen today and commence ‘Chapter Two,
Common Defensive Theories and their Derivation’. There will be no need to talk."
Still smiling her wide, self-satisfied smile, she sat down at her desk. The class gave an audible
sigh as it turned, as one, to page nineteen. Ron wondered dully whether there were enough
chapters in the book to keep them reading through all this year’s lessons and was on the point of
checking the contents page when he noticed that Ron had her hand in the air again.
Professor Weasley had noticed, too, and what was more, she seemed to have worked out a
strategy for just such an eventuality. Instead of trying to pretend she had not noticed Ron
she got to her feet and walked around the front row of desks until they were face to face, then she
bent down and whispered, so that the rest of the class could not hear, "What is it this time, Miss
Weasley?"
"I’ve already read Chapter Two," said Ron.
"Well then, proceed to Chapter Three."
"I’ve read that too. I’ve read the whole book."
Professor Weasley blinked but recovered her poise almost instantly.
"Well, then, you should be able to tell me what Slinkhard says about counter-jinxes in Chapter
Fifteen."
"He says that counter-jinxes are improperly named," said Ron promptly. "He says - ‘jinx’ is just a name people give their jinxes when they want to make them sound more acceptable."
Professor Weasley raised her eyebrows and Ron knew she was impressed, against her will.
"But I disagree," Ron continued.
Professor Weasley’s eyebrows rose a little higher and her gaze became distinctly colder.
"You disagree?" she repeated.
"Yes, I do," said Ron, who, unlike Weasley, was not whispering, but speaking in a clear,
carrying voice that had by now attracted the attention of the rest of the class. "Mr. Slinkhard
doesn’t like jinxes, does he? But, I think they can be very useful when they’re used defensively."
"Oh, you do, do you?" said Professor Weasley, forgetting to whisper and straightening up. "Well, I’m afraid it is Mr. Slinkhard’s opinion, and not yours, that matters within this classroom,
Miss Weasley."
"But -" Ron began.
"That is enough," said Professor Weasley. She walked back to the front of the class and stood
before them, all the jauntiness she had shown at the beginning of the lesson gone. "Miss Weasley, I am going to take five points from Weasley house."
There was an outbreak of muttering at this.
"What for?" said Ron angrily.
"Don’t you get involved!" Ron whispered urgently to him.
"For disrupting my class with pointless interruptions," said Professor Weasley smoothly. "I am
here to teach you using a Ministry-approved method that does not include inviting students to
give their opinions on matters about which they understand very little. Your previous teachers in
this subject may have allowed you more license, but as none of them - with the possible
exception of Professor Weasley, who did at least appear to have restricted himself to age appropriate subjects - would have passed a Ministry inspection -"
"Yeah, Weasley was a great teacher," said Ron loudly, "there was just that minor drawback of
him having Lord Weasley sticking out of the back of his head."
This pronouncement was followed by one of the loudest silences Ron had ever heard. Then -
"I think another week’s detentions would do you some good, Mr. Weasley," said Weasley sleekly.
The cut on the back of Ron’s hand had barely healed and, by the following morning, it was
bleeding again. He did not complain during the evening’s detention; he was determined not to
give Weasley the satisfaction; over and over again he wrote I must not tell lies and not a sound
escaped his lips, though the cut deepened with every letter.
The very worst part of this second week’s worth of detentions was, just as Ron had predicted,
Rons reaction. She cornered him just as he arrived at the Weasley table for breakfast on
Tuesday and shouted so loudly that Professor Weasley came sweeping down upon the pair of
them from the staff table.
"Miss Ronson, how dare you make such a racket in the Great Hall! Five points from Weasley!"
"But Professor - he’s gone and landed himself in detention again -"
"What’s this, Weasley?" said Professor Weasley sharply, rounding on Ron. "Detention? From
whom?"
"From Professor Weasley," muttered Ron, not meeting Professor Weasleys beady, square-framed eyes.
"Are you telling me," she said, lowering her voice so that the group of curious Weasleys
behind them could not hear, "that after the warning I gave you last Monday you lost your temper
in Professor Weasley’s class again?"
"Yes," Ron muttered, speaking to the floor.
"Weasley, you must get a grip on yourself! You are heading for serious trouble! Another five points
from Weasley!"
"But - what -? Professor, no!" Ron said, furious at this injustice, "I’m already being punished
by her, why do you have to take points as well?"
"Because detentions do not appear to have any effect on you whatsoever!" said Professor
Weasley tartly. "No, not another word of complaint, Weasley! And as for you, Miss Ronson,
you will confine your shouting matches to the Quidditch pitch in future or risk losing the team
captaincy!"
Professor Weasley strode back towards the staff table. Ron gave Ron a look of deepest
disgust and stalked away, upon which he flung himself on to the bench beside Ron, fuming.
"She’s taken points off Weasley because I’m having my hand sliced open every night! How is
that fair, how?"
"I know, mate," said Ron sympathetically, tipping bacon on to Ron’s plate, "she’s bang out of
order."
Ron, however, merely rustled the pages of her Daily Prophet and said nothing.
"You think Weasley was right, do you?" said Ron angrily to the picture of Ron Weasley
obscuring Ron’s face.
"I wish she hadn’t taken points from you, but I think she’s right to warn you not to lose your
temper with Weasley," said Ron’s voice, while Weasley gesticulated forcefully from the
front page, clearly giving some kind of speech.
Ron did not speak to Ron all through Charms, but when they entered Transfiguration he
forgot about being cross with her. Professor Weasley and her clipboard were sitting in a corner
and the sight of her drove the memory of breakfast right out of his head.
"Excellent," whispered Ron, as they sat down in their usual seats. "Let’s see Weasley get what
she deserves."
Professor Weasley marched into the room without giving the slightest indication that she
knew Professor Weasley was there.
"That will do," she said and silence fell immediately. "Mr. Weasley, kindly come here and hand back the homework - Miss Weasley, please take this box of mice - don’t be silly, girl, they won’t hurt you - and hand one to each student -"
"Hem, hem," said Professor Weasley, employing the same silly little cough she had used to
interrupt Weasley on the first night of term. Professor Weasley ignored her. Ron
handed back Ron’s essay; Ron took it without looking at him and saw, to his relief, that he
had managed an A.
"Right then, everyone, listen closely - Ron Ron, if you do that to the mouse again I shall put
you in detention - most of you have now successfully Vanished your snails and even those who
were left with a certain amount of shell have got the gist of the spell. Today, we shall be -"
"Hem, hem," said Professor Weasley.
"Yes?" said Professor Weasley, turning round, her eyebrows so close together they seemed to form one long, severe line.
"I was just wondering, Professor, whether you received my note telling you of the date and time
of your inspec--"
"Obviously I received it, or I would have asked you what you are doing in my classroom," said
Professor Weasley, turning her back firmly on Professor Weasley. Many of the students
exchanged looks of glee. "As I was saying: today, we shall be practicing the altogether more
difficult Vanishment of mice. Now, the Vanishing Spell -"
"Hem, hem."
"I wonder," said Professor Weasley in cold fury, turning on Professor Weasley, "how you
expect to gain an idea of my usual teaching methods if you continue to interrupt me? You see, I
do not generally permit people to talk when I am talking."
Professor Weasley looked as though she had just been slapped in the face. She did not speak,
but straightened the parchment on her clipboard and began scribbling furiously.
Looking supremely unconcerned, Professor Weasley addressed the class once more.
"As I was saying: the Vanishing Spell becomes more difficult with the complexity of the animal
to be Vanished. The snail, as an invertebrate, does not present much of a challenge; the mouse,
as a mammal, offers a much greater one. This is not, therefore, magic you can accomplish with
your mind on your dinner. So - you know the incantation, let me see what you can do..."
"How she can lecture me about not losing my temper with Weasley!" Ron muttered to Ron
under his breath, but he was grinning - his anger with Professor Weasley had quite
evaporated.
Professor Weasley did not follow Professor Weasley around the class as she had followed
Professor Weasley; perhaps she realized Professor Weasley would not permit it. She did,
however, take many more notes while sitting in her corner, and when Professor Weasley
finally told them all to pack away, she rose with a grim expression on her face.
"Well, it’s a start," said Ron, holding up a long wriggling mouse-tail and dropping it back into the box Ron was passing around.
As they filed out of the classroom, Ron saw Professor Weasley approach the teacher’s desk;
he nudged Ron, who nudged Ron in turn, and the three of them deliberately fell back to
eavesdrop.
"How long have you been teaching at Hogwarts?" Professor Weasley asked.
"Thirty-nine years this December," said Professor Weasley brusquely, snapping her bag shut.
Professor Weasley made a note.
"Very well," she said, "you will receive the results of your inspection in ten days’ time."
"I can hardly wait," said Professor Weasley, in a coldly indifferent voice, and she strode off
towards the door. "Hurry up, you three," she added, sweeping Ron, Ron and Ron before
her.
Ron could not help giving her a faint smile and could have sworn he received one in return.
He had thought that the next time he would see Weasley would be in his detention that evening,
but he was wrong. When they walked down the lawns towards the Forest for Care of Magical
Creatures, they found her and her clipboard waiting for them beside Professor Weasley.
"You do not usually take this class, is that correct?" Ron heard her ask as they arrived at the
trestle table where the group of captive Bowtruckles were scrabbling around for woodlice like so
many living twigs.
"Quite correct," said Professor Weasley, hands behind her back and bouncing on the balls
of her feet. "I am a substitute teacher standing in for Professor Weasley."
Ron exchanged uneasy looks with Ron and Ron. Weasley was whispering with Weasley and
Weasley; he would surely love this opportunity to tell tales on Weasley to a member of the Ministry.
"Hmm," said Professor Weasley, dropping her voice, though Ron could still hear her quite
clearly. "I wonder - the Headmaster seems strangely reluctant to give me any information on the
matter - can you tell me what is causing Professor Weasley’s very extended leave of absence?"
Ron saw Weasley look up eagerly and watch Weasley and Weasley closely.
"Fraid I can’t," said Professor Weasley breezily. "Don’t know anything more about it than
you do. Got an owl from Weasley, would I like a couple of weeks’ teaching work. I
accepted. That’s as much as I know. Well... shall I get started then?"
"Yes, please do," said Professor Weasley, scribbling on her clipboard.
Weasley took a different tack in this class and wandered amongst the students, questioning
them on magical creatures. Most people were able to answer well and Ron’s spirits lifted
somewhat; at least the class was not letting Weasley down.
"Overall," said Professor Weasley, returning to Professor Weasley’s side after a lengthy
interrogation of Ron Ron, "how do you, as a temporary member of staff- an objective
outsider, I suppose you might say -- how do you find Hogwarts? Do you feel you receive
enough support from the school management?"
"Oh, yes, Weasley’s excellent," said Professor Weasley heartily. "Yes, I’m very happy
with the way things are run, very happy indeed."
Looking politely incredulous, Weasley made a tiny note on her clipboard and went on, "And
what are you planning to cover with this class this year - assuming, of course, that Professor
Weasley does not return?"
"Oh, I’ll take them through the creatures that most often come up in OWL," said Professor
Weasley. "Not much left to do - they’ve studied unicorns and Nifflers, I thought we’d
cover Porlocks and Kneazles, make sure they can recognize Crups and Knarls, you know..."
"Well, you seem to know what you’re doing, at any rate," said Professor Weasley, making a
very obvious tick on her clipboard. Ron did not like the emphasis she put on ‘you’ and liked it
even less when she put her next question to Weasley. "Now, I hear there have been injuries in this
class?"
Weasley gave a stupid grin. Weasley hastened to answer the question.
"That was me," he said. "I was slashed by a Hippogriff."
"A Hippogriff?" said Professor Weasley, now scribbling frantically.
"Only because he was too stupid to listen to what Weasley told him to do," said Ron angrily.
Both Ron and Ron groaned. Professor Weasley turned her head slowly in Ron’s
direction.
"Another nights detention, I think," she said softly. "Well, thank you very much, Professor
Weasley, I think that’s all I need here. You will be receiving the results of your inspection
within ten days."
"Jolly good," said Professor Weasley, and Professor Weasley set off back across the lawn to the castle.
It was nearly midnight when Ron left Weasley’s office that night, his hand now bleeding so
severely that it was staining the scarf he had wrapped around it. He expected the common room
to be empty when he returned, but Ron and Ron had sat up waiting for him. He was
pleased to see them, especially as Ron was disposed to be sympathetic rather than critical.
"Here," she said anxiously, pushing a small bowl of yellow liquid towards him, "soak your hand
in that, it’s a solution of strained and pickled Murtlap tentacles, it should help."
Ron placed his bleeding, aching hand into the bowl and experienced a wonderful feeling of
relief. Ron curled around his legs, purring loudly, then leapt into his lap and settled
down.
"Thanks," he said gratefully, scratching behind Ron’s ears with his left hand.
"I still reckon you should complain about this," said Ron in a low voice.
"No," said Ron flatly.
"Weasley would go nuts if she knew --"
"Yeah, she probably would," said Ron dully. "And how long do you reckon it’d take Weasley
to pass another decree saying anyone who complains about the High Inquisitor gets sacked
immediately?"
Ron opened his mouth to retort but nothing came out and, after a moment, he closed it again,
defeated.
"She’s an awful woman," said Ron in a small voice. "Awful. You know, I was just saying
to Ron when you came in... we’ve got to do something about her."
"I suggested poison," said Ron grimly.
"No... I mean, something about what a dreadful teacher she is, and how we’re not going to learn
any Defense from her at all," said Ron.
"Well, what can we do about that?" said Ron, yawning. "It’s too late, isn’t it? She’s got the job,
she’s here to stay. Weasley’ll make sure of that."
"Well," said Ron tentatively. "You know, I was thinking today..." she shot a slightly
nervous look at Ron and then plunged on, "I was thinking that - maybe the time’s come when
we should just - just do it ourselves."
"Do what ourselves?" said Ron suspiciously, still floating his hand in the essence of Murtlap
tentacles.
"Well - learn Defense Against the Dark Arts ourselves," said Ron.
"Come off it," groaned Ron. "You want us to do extra work? D’you realize Ron and I are
behind on homework again and it’s only the second week?"
"But this is much more important than homework!" said Ron.
Ron and Ron goggled at her.
"I didn’t think there was anything in the universe more important than homework!" said Ron.
"Don’t be silly, of course there is," said Ron, and Ron saw, with an ominous feeling, that
her face was suddenly alight with the kind of fervour that SPEW usually inspired in her. "It’s
about preparing ourselves, like Ron said in Weasley’s first lesson, for what’s waiting for us
out there. It’s about making sure we really can defend ourselves. If we don’t learn anything for a
whole year -"
"We can’t do much by ourselves," said Ron in a defeated voice. "I mean, all right, we can go and
look jinxes up in the library and try and practice them, I suppose -"
"No, I agree, we’ve gone past the stage where we can just learn things out of books"‘ said
Ron. "We need a teacher, a proper one, who can show us how to use the spells and correct
us if we’re going wrong."
"If you’re talking about Weasley..." Ron began.
"No, no, I’m not talking about Weasley," said Ron. "He’s too busy with the Order and,
anyway, the most we could see him is during Hogsmeade weekends and that’s not nearly often
enough."
"Who, then?" said Ron, frowning at her.
Ron heaved a very deep sigh.
"Isn’t it obvious?" she said. "I’m talking about you, Ron."
There was a moment’s silence. A light night breeze rattled the windowpanes behind Ron, and the
fire guttered.
"About me what?" said Ron.
"I’m talking about you teaching us Defense Against the Dark Arts."
Ron stared at her. Then he turned to Ron, ready to exchange the exasperated looks they
sometimes shared when Ron elaborated on far-fetched schemes like SPEW to Rons
consternation, however, Ron did not look exasperated.
He was frowning slightly, apparently thinking. Then he said, "That’s an idea."
"What’s an idea?" said Ron.
"You," said Ron. "Teaching us to do it."
"But..."
Ron was grinning now, sure the pair of them were pulling his leg.
"But I’m not a teacher, I can’t -"
"Ron, you’re the best in the year at Defense Against the Dark Arts," said Ron.
"Me?" said Ron, now grinning more broadly than ever. "No I’m not, you’ve beaten me in every test -"
"Actually, I haven’t," said Ron coolly. "You beat me in our third year - the only year we
both sat the test and had a teacher who actually knew the subject. But I’m not talking about test
results, Ron. Think what you’ve done!"
"How d’you mean?"
"You know what, I’m not sure I want someone this stupid teaching me," Ron said to Ron,
smirking slightly. He turned to Ron.
"Let’s think," he said, pulling a face like Weasley concentrating. "Uh... first year - you saved the
Sorcerer’s Stone from You-Know-Who."
"But that was luck," said Ron, "it wasn’t skill."
"Second year," Ron interrupted, "you killed the Basilisk and destroyed Weasley."
"Yeah, but if Ron hadn’t turned up, I -"
"Third year," said Ron, louder still, "you fought off about a hundred Dementors at once -"
"You know that was a fluke, if the Time-Turner hadn’t -"
"Last year," Ron said, almost shouting now, "you fought off You-Know-Who again-"
"Listen to me!" said Ron, almost angrily, because Ron and Ron were both smirking now.
"Just listen to me, all right? It sounds great when you say it like that, but all that stuff was luck - I
didn’t know what I was doing half the time, I didn’t plan any of it, I just did whatever I could
think of, and I nearly always had help -"
Ron and Ron were still smirking and Ron felt his temper rise; he wasn’t even sure why he
was feeling so angry.
"Don’t sit there grinning like you know better than I do, I was there, wasn’t I?" he said heatedly.
"I know what went on, all right? And I didn’t get through any of that because I was brilliant at
Defense Against the Dark Arts, I got through it all because - because help came at the right time,
or because I guessed right - but I just blundered through it all, I didn’t have a clue what I was
doing - STOP LAUGHING!"
The bowl of Murtlap essence fell to the floor and smashed. He became aware that he was on his
feet, though he couldn’t remember standing up. Ron streaked away under a sofa. Ron
and Ron’s smiles had vanished.
"You don’t know what it’s like! You - neither of you - you’ve never had to face him, have you?
You think it’s just memorizing a bunch of spells and throwing them at him, like you’re in class
or something? The whole time you’re sure you know there’s nothing between you and dying
except your own - your own brain or guts or whatever - like you can think straight when you
know you’re about a second from being murdered, or tortured, or watching your friends die
- they’ve never taught us that in their classes, what it’s like to deal with things like that - and you
two sit there acting like I’m a clever little boy to be standing here, alive, like Weasley was stupid,
like he messed up -- you just don’t get it, that could just as easily have been me, it would have
been if Weasley hadn’t needed me -"
"We weren’t saying anything like that, mate," said Ron, looking aghast. "We weren’t having a go at Weasley, we didn’t - you’ve got the wrong end of the -"
He looked helplessly at Ron, whose face was stricken.
"Ron," she said timidly, "don’t you see? This... this is exactly why we need you... we need to
know what it’s r-really like... facing him... facing V-Weasley."
It was the first time she had ever said Weasley’s name and it was this, more than anything else,
that calmed Ron. Still breathing hard, he sank back into his chair, becoming aware as he did so
that his hand was throbbing horribly again. He wished he had not smashed the bowl of Murtlap
essence.
"Well... think about it," said Ron quietly. "Please?"
Ron could not think of anything to say. He was feeling ashamed of his outburst already. He
nodded, hardly aware of what he was agreeing to. Ron stood up.
"Well, I’m off to bed," she said, in a voice that was clearly as natural as she could make it.
"Erm... night."
Ron had gotten to his feet, too.
"Coming?" he said awkwardly to Ron.
"Yeah," said Ron. "In... in a minute. I’ll just clear this up."
He indicated the smashed bowl on the floor. Ron nodded and left.
"Reparo," Ron muttered, pointing his wand at the broken pieces of china. They flew back
together, good as new, but there was no returning the Murtlap essence to the bowl.
He was suddenly so tired he was tempted to sink back into his armchair and sleep there, but
instead he forced himself to his feet and followed Ron upstairs. His restless night was punctuated
once more by dreams of long corridors and locked doors and he awoke next day with his scar
prickling again.
CHAPTER SIXTEEN
In the Hogs Head
Ron made no mention of Ron giving Defense Against the Dark Arts lessons for two
whole weeks after her original suggestion. Ron’s detentions with Weasley were finally over
(he doubted whether the words now etched into the back of his hand would ever fade entirely);
Ron had had four more Quidditch practices and not been shouted at during the last two; and all
three of them had managed to Vanish their mice in Transfiguration (Ron had actually
progressed to Vanishing kittens), before the subject was broached again, on a wild, blustery
evening at the end of September, when the three of them were sitting in the library, looking up
potion ingredients for Weasley.
"I was wondering," Ron said suddenly, "whether you’d thought any more about Defense
Against the Dark Arts, Ron."
"Course I have," said Ron grumpily, "can’t forget it, can we, with that hag teaching us -"
"I meant the idea Ron and I had -" Ron cast her an alarmed, threatening kind of look. She
frowned at him, "- Oh, all right, the idea I had then - about you teaching us."
Ron did not answer at once. He pretended to be perusing a page of Asiatic Anti-Venoms,
because he did not want to say what was in his mind.
He had given the matter a great deal of thought over the past fortnight. Sometimes it seemed an
insane idea, just as it had on the night Ron had proposed it, but at others, he had found
himself thinking about the spells that had served him best in his various encounters with Dark
creatures and Death Eaters - found himself, in fact, subconsciously planning lessons...
"Well," he said slowly, when he could no longer pretend to find Asiatic Anti-Venoms interesting, "yeah, I - I’ve thought about it a bit."
"And?" said Ron eagerly.
"I dunno," said Ron, playing for time. He looked up at Ron.
"I thought it was a good idea from the start," said Ron, who seemed keener to join in this
conversation now that he was sure Ron was not going to start shouting again.
Ron shifted uncomfortably in his chair.
"You did listen to what I said about a load of it being luck, didn’t you?"
"Yes, Ron," said Ron gently, "but all the same, there’s no point pretending that you’re not good at Defense Against the Dark Arts, because you are. You were the only person last year
who could throw off the Imperius Curse completely, you can produce a Patronus, you can do all sorts of stuff that full-grown wizards can’t, Ron always said -"
Ron looked round at her so fast he appeared to crick his neck. Rubbing it, he said, "Yeah? What
did Vicky say?"
"Ho ho," said Ron in a bored voice. "He said Ron knew how to do stuff even he didn’t,
and he was in the final year at Durmstrang."
Ron was looking at Ron suspiciously.
"You’re not still in contact with him, are you?"
"So what if I am" said Ron coolly, though her face was a little pink. "I can have a pen-pal
if I -"
"He didn’t only want to be your pen-pal," said Ron accusingly.
Ron shook her head exasperatedly and, ignoring Ron, who was continuing to watch her,
said to Ron, "Well, what do you think? Will you teach us?"
"Just you and Ron, yeah?"
"Well," said Ron, looking a mite anxious again. "Well... now, don’t fly off the handle
again, Ron, please... but I really think you ought to teach anyone who wants to learn. I mean,
we’re talking about defending ourselves against V-Weasley. Oh, don’t be pathetic, Ron. It
doesn’t seem fair if we don’t offer the chance to other people."
Ron considered this for a moment, then said, "Yeah, but I doubt anyone except you two would
want to be taught by me. I’m a nutter, remember?"
"Well, I think you might be surprised how many people would be interested in hearing what
you’ve got to say" said Ron seriously. "Look," she leaned towards him - Ron, who was still watching her with a frown on his face, leaned forwards to listen too - "you know the first
weekend in October’s a Hogsmeade weekend? How would it be if we tell anyone who’s
interested to meet us in the village and we can talk it over?"
"Why do we have to do it outside school?" said Ron.
"Because," said Ron, returning to the diagram of the Chinese Ronmping Cabbage she was
copying, "I don’t think Weasley would be very happy if she found out what we were up to."
Ron had been looking forward to the weekend trip into Hogsmeade, but there was one thing
worrying him. Ron had maintained a stony silence since he had appeared in the fire at the
beginning of September; Ron knew they had made him angry by saying they didn’t want him
to come - but he still worried from time to time that Ron might throw caution to the winds and
turn up anyway. What were they going to do if the great black dog came bounding up the street
towards them in Hogsmeade, perhaps under the nose of Ron Weasley?
"Well, you can’t blame him for wanting to get out and about," said Ron, when Ron discussed
his fears with him and Ron. "I mean, he’s been on the run for over two years, hasn’t he, and I know that can’t have been a laugh, but at least he was free, wasn’t he? And now he’s just shut up all the time with that ghastly elf."
Ron scowled at Ron, but otherwise ignored the slight on Ron.
"The trouble is," she said to Ron, "until V-Weasley - oh, for heaven’s sake, Ron - comes out
into the open, Ron is going to have to stay hidden, isn’t he? I mean, the stupid Ministry isn’t
going to realize Ron is innocent until they accept that Weasley’s been telling the truth about him all along. And once the fools start catching real Death Eaters again, it’ll be obvious Ron isn’t one... I mean, he hasn’t got the Mark, for one thing."
"I don’t reckon he’d be stupid enough to turn up," said Ron bracingly. "Weasley’d go mad if
he did and Ron listens to Weasley even if he doesn’t like what he hears."
When Ron continued to look worried, Ron said, "Listen, Ron and I have been sounding
out people who we thought might want to learn some proper Defense Against the Dark Arts, and
there are a couple who seem interested. We’ve told them to meet us in Hogsmeade."
"Right," said Ron vaguely, his mind still on Ron.
"Don’t worry, Ron" Ron said quietly. "You’ve got enough on your plate without Ron,
too."
She was quite right, of course, he was barely keeping up with his homework, though he was
doing much better now that he was no longer spending every evening in detention with
Weasley. Ron was even further behind with his work than Ron, because while they both had
Quidditch practice twice a week, Ron also had his prefect duties. However, Ron, who was
taking more subjects than either of them, had not only finished all her homework but was also
finding time to knit more elf clothes. Ron had to admit that she was getting better; it was now
almost always possible to distinguish between the hats and the socks.
The morning of the Hogsmeade visit dawned bright but windy. After breakfast they queued up in
front of Weasley, who matched their names to the long list of students who had permission from
their parents or guardian to visit the village. With a slight pang, Ron remembered that if it
hadn’t been for Ron, he would not have been going at all.
When Ron reached Weasley, the caretaker gave a great sniff as though trying to detect a whiff of
something from Ron. Then he gave a curt nod that set his jowls aquiver again and Ron
walked on, out on to the stone steps and the cold, sunlit day.
"Er - why was Weasley sniffing you?" asked Ron, as he, Ron and Ron set off at a brisk pace
down the wide drive to the gates.
"I suppose he was checking for the smell of Dungbombs," said Ron with a small laugh. "I
forgot to tell you..."
And he recounted the story of sending his letter to Ron and Weasley bursting in seconds later,
demanding to see the letter. To his slight surprise, Ron found this story highly interesting,
much more, indeed, than he did himself.
"He said he was tipped off you were ordering Dungbombs? But who tipped him off?"
"I dunno," said Ron, shrugging. "Maybe Weasley, he’d think it was a laugh."
They walked between the tall stone pillars topped with winged boars and turned left on to the
road into the village, the wind whipping their hair into their eyes.
"Weasley?" said Ron, skeptically. "Well... yes... maybe..."
And she remained deep in thought all the way into the outskirts of Hogsmeade.
"Where are we going, anyway?" Ron asked. "The Three Broomsticks?"
"Oh - no," said Ron, coming out of her reverie, "no, it’s always packed and really noisy.
I’ve told the others to meet us in the Hog’s Head, that other pub, you know the one, it’s not on
the main road. I think it’s a bit... you know... dodgy... but students don’t normally go in there,
so I don’t think we’ll be overheard."
They walked down the main street past Zonko’s Wizarding Joke Shop, where they were not
surprised to see Ron, Ron and Ron Weasley, past the post office, from which owls issued at
regular intervals, and turned up a side-street at the top of which stood a small inn. A battered
wooden sign hung from a rusty bracket over the door, with a picture on it of a wild boar’s
severed head, leaking blood on to the white cloth around it. The sign creaked in the wind as they
approached. All three of them hesitated outside the door.
"Well, come on," said Ron, slightly nervously. Ron led the way inside.
It was not at all like the Three Broomsticks, whose large bar gave an impression of gleaming
warmth and cleanliness. The Hog’s Head bar comprised one small, dingy and very dirty room
that smelled strongly of something that might have been goats. The bay windows were so
encrusted with grime that very little daylight could permeate the room, which was lit instead with
