the stubs of candles sitting on rough wooden tables. The floor seemed at first glance to be
compressed earth, though as Ron stepped on to it he realized that there was stone beneath what
seemed to be the accumulated filth of centuries.
Ron remembered Weasley mentioning this pub in his first year: "Yeh get a lot o’ funny folk in
the Hogs Head" he had said, explaining how he had won a dragon’s egg from a hooded stranger
there. At the time Ron had wondered why Weasley had not found it odd that the stranger kept his
face hidden throughout their encounter; now he saw that keeping your face hidden was
something of a fashion in the Hog’s Head. There was a man at the bar whose whole head was
wrapped in dirty grey bandages, though he was still managing to gulp endless glasses of some
smoking, fiery substance through a slit over his mouth; two figures shrouded in hoods sat at a
table in one of the windows; Ron might have thought them Dementors if they had not been
talking in strong Yorkshire accents, and in a shadowy corner beside the fireplace sat a witch with
a thick, black veil that fell to her toes. They could just see the tip of her nose because it caused
the veil to protrude slightly.
"I don’t know about this, Ron," Ron muttered, as they crossed to the bar. He was looking
particularly at the heavily veiled witch. "Has it occurred to you Weasley might be under that?"
Ron cast an appraising eye over the veiled figure.
"Weasley is shorter than that woman," she said quietly. "And anyway, even if Weasley does
come in here there’s nothing she can do to stop us, Ron, because I’ve double- and triplechecked
the school rules. We’re not out of bounds; I specifically asked Professor Weasley whether students were allowed to come in the Hog’s Head, and he said yes, but he advised me
strongly to bring our own glasses. And I’ve looked up everything I can think of about study
groups and homework groups and they’re definitely allowed. I just don’t think it’s a good idea if
we parade what we’re doing."
"No," said Ron dryly, "especially as it’s not exactly a homework group you’re planning, is it?"
The barman sidled towards them out of a back room. He was a grumpy-looking old man with a
great deal of long grey hair and beard. He was tall and thin and looked vaguely familiar to Ron.
"What?" he grunted.
"Three Butterbeers, please," said Ron.
The man reached beneath the counter and pulled up three very dusty, very dirty bottles, which he
slammed on the bar.
"Six Sickles," he said.
"I’ll get them," said Ron quickly, passing over the silver. The barman’s eyes traveled over
Ron, resting for a fraction of a second on his scar. Then he turned away and deposited Ron’s
money in an ancient wooden till whose drawer slid open automatically to receive it. Ron, Ron
and Ron retreated to the furthest table from the bar and sat down, looking around. The man
in the dirty grey bandages rapped the counter with his knuckles and received another smoking
drink from the barman.
"You know what?" Ron murmured, looking over at the bar with enthusiasm. "We could order
anything we liked in here. I bet that bloke would sell us anything, he wouldn’t care. I’ve always
wanted to try Firewhisky -"
"You - are - a -prefect," snarled Ron.
"Oh," said Ron, the smile fading from his face. "Yeah..."
"So, who did you say is supposed to be meeting us?" Ron asked, wrenching open the rusty top
of his Butterbeer and taking a swig.
"Just a couple of people," Ron repeated, checking her watch and looking anxiously towards the door. "I told them to be here about now and I’m sure they all know where it is - oh, look, this might be them now."
The door of the pub had opened. A thick band of dusty sunlight split the room in two for a
moment and then vanished, blocked by the incoming rush of a crowd of people.
First came Ron with Ron and Ron, who were closely followed by Ron and Ron
Weasley with (Ron’s stomach did a back-flip) Ron and one of her usually-giggling girlfriends, then
(on her own and looking so dreamy she might have walked in by accident) Ron Weasley; then
Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley and Ron Ronson, Ron and Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley,
Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley, a Weasley girl with a long plait down her back whose
name Ron did not know; three Weasley boys he was pretty sure were called Ron
Weasley, Ron Weasley and Ron Weasley, Ron, closely followed by a tall skinny blond boy
with an upturned nose whom Ron recognized vaguely as being a member of the Weasley
Quidditch team and, bringing up the rear, Ron and Ron Weasley with their friend Ron Weasley,
all three of whom were carrying large paper bags crammed with Zonko’s merchandise.
"A couple of people?" said Ron hoarsely to Ron. "A couple of people?"
"Yes, well, the idea seemed quite popular," said Ron happily, "Ron, do you want to pull up
some more chairs?"
The barman had frozen in the act of wiping out a glass with a rag so filthy it looked as though it
had never been washed. Possibly, he had never seen his pub so full.
"Hi," said Ron, reaching the bar first and counting his companions quickly, "could we have...
twenty-five Butterbeers, please?"
The barman glared at him for a moment, then, throwing down his rag irritably as though he had
been interrupted in something very important, he started passing up dusty Butterbeers from under
the bar.
"Cheers," said Ron, handing them out. "Cough up, everyone, I haven’t got enough gold for all of
these..."
Ron watched numbly as the large chattering group took their beers from Ron and rummaged in
their robes to find coins. He could not imagine what all these people had turned up for until the
horrible thought occurred to him that they might be expecting some kind of speech, at which he
rounded on Ron.
"What have you been telling people?" he said in a low voice. "What are they expecting?"
"I’ve told you, they just want to hear what you’ve got to say," said Ron soothingly; but
Ron continued to look at her so furiously that she added quickly, "you don’t have to do
anything yet, I’ll speak to them first."
"Hi, Ron," said Ron, beaming and taking a seat opposite him.
Ron tried to smile back, but did not speak; his mouth was exceptionally dry. Ron had just
smiled at him and sat down on Ron’s right. Her friend, who had curly reddish-blonde hair, did
not smile, but gave Ron a thoroughly mistrustful look which plainly told him that, given her
way, she would not be here at all.
In twos and threes the new arrivals settled around Ron, Ron and Ron, some looking
rather excited, others curious, Ron Weasley gazing dreamily into space. When everybody had
pulled up a chair, the chatter died out. Every eye was upon Ron.
"Er," said Ron, her voice slightly higher than usual out of nerves. "Well - er - hi."
The group focused its attention on her instead, though eyes continued to dart back regularly to
Ron.
"Well... erm... well, you know why you’re here. Erm... well, Ron here had the idea - I mean"
(Ron had thrown her a sharp look) "I had the idea - that it might be good if people who wanted
to study Defense Against the Dark Arts - and I mean, really study it, you know, not the rubbish
that Weasley is doing with us -" (Ron’s voice became suddenly much stronger and more
confident) "- because nobody could call that Defense Against the Dark Arts -" ("Hear, hear," said Ron Weasley, and Ron looked heartened) "- Well, I thought it would be good if we, well, took matters into our own hands."
She paused, looked sideways at Ron, and went on, "And by that I mean learning how to defend
ourselves properly, not just in theory but doing the real spells -"
"You want to pass your Defense Against the Dark Arts OWL too, though, I bet?" said Ron
Weasley, who was watching her closely.
"Of course I do," said Ron at once. "But more than that, I want to be properly trained in
defense because... because..." she took a great breath and finished, "because Lord Weasley is
back."
The reaction was immediate and predictable. Ron’s friend shrieked and slopped Butterbeer down
herself; Ron Weasley gave a kind of involuntary twitch; Ron Weasley shuddered, and Ron gave
an odd yelp that he managed to turn into a cough. All of them, however, looked fixedly, even
eagerly, at Ron.
"Well... that’s the plan, anyway" said Ron. "If you want to join us, we need to decide how
we’re going to -"
"Where’s the proof You-Know-Who’s back?" said the blond Weasley player in a rather
aggressive voice.
"Well, Weasley believes it -" Ron began.
"You mean, Weasley believes him," said the blond boy, nodding at Ron.
"Who are you?" said Ron, rather rudely.
"Ron Weasley," said the boy, "and I think we’ve got the right to know exactly what makes him say You-Know-Who’s back."
"Look," said Ron, intervening swiftly, "that’s really not what this meeting was supposed to
be about -"
"It’s okay, Ron," said Ron.
It had just dawned on him why there were so many people there. He thought Ron should
have seen this coming. Some of these people - maybe even most of them - had turned up in the
hopes of hearing Ron’s story firsthand.
"What makes me say You-Know-Who’s back?" he repeated, looking Ron straight in the
face. "I saw him. But Weasley told the whole school what happened last year, and if you
didn’t believe him, you won’t believe me, and I’m not wasting an afternoon trying to convince
anyone."
The whole group seemed to have held its breath while Ron spoke. Ron had the impression
that even the barman was listening. He was wiping the same glass with the filthy rag, making it
steadily dirtier.
Ron said dismissively, "All Weasley told us last year was that Ron Weasley got
killed by You-Know-Who and that you brought Weasley’s body back to Hogwarts. He didn’t
give us details, he didn’t tell us exactly how Weasley got murdered, I think we’d all like to know
-"
"If you’ve come to hear exactly what it looks like when Weasley murders someone I can’t help
you," Ron said. His temper, always so close to the surface these days, was rising again. He did
not take his eyes from Ron Weasley’s aggressive face, and was determined not to look at Ron.
"I don’t want to talk about Ron Weasley, all right? So if that’s what you’re here for, you might as well clear out."
He cast an angry look in Ron’s direction. This was, he felt, all her fault; she had decided to
display him like some sort of freak and of course they had all turned up to see just how wild his
story was. But none of them left their seats, not even Ron Weasley, though he continued to
gaze intently at Ron.
"So," said Ron, her voice very high-pitched again. "So... like I was saying... if you want to learn some defense, then we need to work out how we’re going to do it, how often we’re going to meet and where we’re going to -"
"Is it true," interrupted the girl with the long plait down her back, looking at Ron, "that you can produce a Patronus?"
There was a murmur of interest around the group at this.
"Yeah," said Ron slightly defensively.
"A corporeal Patronus?"
The phrase stirred something in Ron’s memory.
"Er - you don’t know Ron Weasley, do you?" he asked.
The girl smiled.
"She’s my auntie," she said. "I’m Ron Weasley. She told me about your hearing. So - is it really
true? You make a stag Patronus?"
"Yes," said Ron.
"Blimey, Ron!" said Ron, looking deeply impressed. "I never knew that!"
"Mum told Ron not to spread it around," said Ron, grinning at Ron. "She said you got enough
attention as it was."
"She’s not wrong," mumbled Ron, and a couple of people laughed.
The veiled witch sitting alone shifted very slightly in her seat.
"And did you kill a Basilisk with that sword in Weasley’s office?" demanded Ron Weasley. "That’s what one of the portraits on the wall told me when I was in there last year..."
"Er - yeah, I did, yeah," said Ron.
Ron Weasley whistled; the Weasley brothers exchanged awestruck looks and Ron
Weasley said "Wow!" softly. Ron was feeling slightly hot around the collar now; he was
determinedly looking anywhere but at Ron.
"And in our first year," said Ron to the group at large, "he saved that Sorcerous Stone -"
"Sorcerer’s," hissed Ron.
"Yes, that - from You-Know-Who," finished Ron.
Ron Weasley’s eyes were as round as Galleons.
"And that’s not to mention," said Ron (Ron’s eyes snapped across to her; she was looking at
him, smiling; his stomach did another somersault) "all the tasks he had to get through in the
Triwizard Tournament last year - getting past dragons and merpeople and Acromantula and
things..."
There was a murmur of impressed agreement around the table. Ron’s insides were squirming.
He was trying to arrange his face so that he did not look too pleased with himself. The fact that
Ron had just praised him made it much, much harder for him to say the thing he had sworn to
himself he would tell them.
"Look," he said, and everyone fell silent at once, " I... I don’t want to sound like I’m trying to be
modest or anything, but... I had a lot of help with all that stuff..."
"Not with the dragon, you didn’t," said Ron Weasley at once. "That was a seriously cool bit of
flying..."
"Yeah, well -" said Ron, feeling it would be churlish to disagree.
"And nobody helped you get rid of those Dementors this summer," said Ron Weasley.
"No," said Ron, "no, okay, I know I did bits of it without help, but the point I’m trying to make is -"
"Are you trying to weasel out of showing us any of this stuff?" said Ron Weasley.
"Here’s an idea," said Ron loudly, before Ron could speak, "why don’t you shut your mouth?"
Perhaps the word ‘weasel’ had affected Ron particularly strongly. In any case, he was now
looking at Ron as though he would like nothing better than to thump him. Ron
flushed.
"Well, we’ve all turned up to learn from him and now he’s telling us he can’t really do any of it,"
he said.
"That’s not what he said," snarled Ron.
"Would you like us to clean out your ears for you?" enquired Ron, pulling a long and lethal looking metal instrument from inside one of the Zonko’s bags.
"Or any part of your body, really, we’re not fussy where we stick this," said Ron.
"Yes, well," said Ron hastily, "moving on... the point is, are we agreed we want to take
lessons from Ron?"
There was a murmur of general agreement. Ron folded his arms and said nothing, though
perhaps this was because he was too busy keeping an eye on the instrument in Ron’s hand.
"Right," said Ron, looking relieved that something had at last been settled. "Well, then, the
next question is how often we do it. I really don’t think there’s any point in meeting less than
once a week -"
"Hang on," said Ron, "we need to make sure this doesn’t clash with our Quidditch practice."
"No," said Ron, "nor with ours."
"Nor ours," added Ron Weasley.
"I’m sure we can find a night that suits everyone," aid Ron, slightly impatiently, "but you
know, this is rather important, we’re talking about learning to defend ourselves against V-Weasley’s Death Eaters -"
"Well said!" barked Ron Weasley, who Ron had been expecting to speak long before this.
"Personally I think this is really important, possibly more important than anything else we’ll do
this year, even with our OWLs coming up!"
He looked around impressively, as though waiting for people to cry "Surely not!" When nobody
spoke, he went on, "I, personally am at a loss to see why the Ministry has foisted such a useless
teacher on us at this critical period. Obviously, they are in denial about the return of You-Know-
Who, but to give us a teacher who is trying to actively prevent us from using defensive spells -"
"We think the reason Weasley doesn’t want us trained in Defense Against the Dark Arts," said
Ron, "is that she’s got some... some mad idea that Weasley could use the students in
the school as a kind of private army. She thinks he’d mobilize us against the Ministry."
Nearly everybody looked stunned at this news; everybody except Ron Weasley, who piped up,
"Well, that makes sense. After all, Ron Weasley has got his own private army."
"What?" said Ron, completely thrown by this unexpected piece of information.
"Yes, he’s got an army of Heliopaths," said Ron so lemnly.
"No, he hasn’t," snapped Ron.
"Yes, he has," said Ron.
"What are Heliopaths?" asked Ron, looking blank.
"They’re spirits of fire," said Ron, her protuberant eyes widening so that she looked madder than ever, "great tall flaming creatures that gallop across the ground burning everything in front of -"
"They don’t exist, Ron," said Ron tartly.
"Oh, yes, they do!" said Ron angrily.
"I’m sorry, but where’s the proof of that?" snapped Ron.
"There are plenty of eye-witness accounts. Just because you’re so narrow-minded you need to
have everything shoved under your nose before you -"
"Hem, hem," said Ron, in such a good imitation of Professor Weasley that several people
looked around in alarm and then laughed. "Weren’t we trying to decide how often we’re going to meet and have defense lessons?"
"Yes," said Ron at once, "yes, we were, you’re right, Ron."
"Well, once a week sounds cool," said Ron Weasley.
"As long as -" began Ron.
"Yes, yes, we know about the Quidditch," said Ron in a tense voice. "Well, the other thing
to decide is where we’re going to meet..."
This was rather more difficult; the whole group fell silent.
"Library?" suggested Ron Weasley after a few moments.
"I can’t see Ron Weasley being too chuffed with us doing jinxes in the library," said Ron.
"Maybe an unused classroom?" said Ron.
"Yeah," said Ron, "Weasley might let us have hers, she did when Ron was practicing for the Triwizard."
But Ron was pretty certain that Weasley would not be so accommodating this time. For all
that Ron had said about study and homework groups being allowed, he had the distinct
feeling that this one might be considered a lot more rebellious.
"Right, well, we’ll try to find somewhere," said Ron. "We’ll send a message round to
everybody when we’ve got a time and a place for the first meeting."
She rummaged in her bag and produced parchment and a quill, then hesitated, rather as though
she was steeling herself to say something.
"I - I think everybody should write their name down, just so we know who was here. But I also
think," she took a deep breath, "that we all ought to agree not to shout about what we’re doing. So if you sign, you’re agreeing not to tell Weasley or anybody else what we’re up to."
Ron reached out for the parchment and cheerfully wrote his signature, but Ron noticed at once
that several people looked less than happy at the prospect of putting their names on the list.
"Er..." said Ron slowly, not taking the parchment that Ron was trying to pass to him,
"well... I’m sure Ron will tell me when the meeting is."
But Ron was looking rather hesitant about signing, too. Ron raised her eyebrows at him.
"I - well, we are prefects," Ron burst out. "And if this list was found... well, I mean to say...
you said yourself, if Weasley finds out -"
"You just said this group was the most important thing you’d do this year," Ron reminded him.
"I - yes," said Ron, "yes, I do believe that, it ‘ s just -"
"Ron, do you really think I’d leave that list lying around?" said Ron testily.
"No. No, of course not," said Ron, looking slightly less anxious. "I - yes, of course I’ll sign."
Nobody raised objections after Ron, though Ron saw Ron’s friend give her a rather
reproachful look before adding her own name. When the last person - Ron - had signed,
Ron took the parchment back and slipped it carefully into her bag. There was an odd
feeling in the group now. It was as though they had just signed some kind of contract.
"Well, time’s ticking on," said Ron briskly, getting to his feet. "Ron, Ron and I have got items of a sensitive nature to purchase, we’ll be seeing you all later."
In twos and threes the rest of the group took their leave, too.
Ron made rather a business of fastening the catch on her bag before leaving, her long dark
curtain of hair swinging forwards to hide her face, but her friend stood beside her, arms folded,
clicking her tongue, so that Ron had little choice but to leave with her. As her friend ushered her
through the door, Ron looked back and waved at Ron.
"Well, I think that went quite well," said Ron happily, as she, Ron and Ron walked out of
the Hog’s Head into the bright sunlight a few moments later. Ron and Ron were clutching their
bottles of Butterbeer.
"That Ron bloke’s a wart," said Ron, who was glowering after the figure of Weasley, just
discernible in the distance.
"I don’t like him much, either," admitted Ron, "but he overheard me talking to Ron and
Ron at the Weasley table and he seemed really interested in coming, so what could I say?
But the more people the better really - I mean, Ron Weasley and his friends wouldn’t have
come if he hadn’t been going out with Ron -"
Ron, who had been draining the last few drops from his Butterbeer bottle, gagged and sprayed
Butterbeer down his front.
"He’s WHAT?" spluttered Ron, outraged, his ears now resembling curls of raw beef. "She’s
going out with - my sister’s going - what d’you mean, Ron Weasley?"
"Well, that’s why he and his friends came, I think - well, they’re obviously interested in learning
defense, but if Ron hadn’t told Ron what was going on -"
"When did this - when did she -?"
"They met at the Yule Ball and got together at the end of last year," said Ron composedly. They had turned into the High Street and she paused outside Scrivenshaft’s Quill Shop, where
there was a handsome display of pheasant feather quills in the window. "Hmm... I could do with
a new quill."
She turned into the shop. Ron and Ron followed her.
"Which one was Ron Weasley?" Ron demanded furiously.
"The dark one," said Ron.
"I didn’t like him," said Ron at once.
"Big surprise," said Ron under her breath.
"But," said Ron, following Ron along a row of quills in copper pots, "I thought Ron
fancied Ron!"
Ron looked at him rather pityingly and shook her head.
"Ron used to fancy Ron, but she gave up on him months ago. Not that she doesn’t like you, of course," she added kindly to Ron while she examined a long black and gold quill.
Ron, whose head was still full of Ron’s parting wave, did not find this subject quite as
interesting as Ron, who was positively quivering with indignation, but it did bring something
home to him that until now he had not really registered.
"So that’s why she talks now?" he asked Ron. "She never used to talk in front of me."
"Exactly," said Ron. "Yes, I think I’ll have this one..."
She went up to the counter and handed over fifteen Sickles and two Knuts, with Ron still
breathing down her neck.
"Ron," she said severely as she turned and trod on his feet, "this is exactly why Ron hasn’t told
you she’s seeing Ron, she knew you’d take it badly. So don’t harp on about it, for heaven’s
sake."
"What d’you mean? Who’s taking anything badly? I’m not going to harp on about anything..."
Ron continued to chunter under his breath all the way down the street.
Ron rolled her eyes at Ron and then said in an undertone, while Ron was still muttering
imprecations about Ron Weasley, "And talking about Ron and Ron... what about Ron
and you?"
"What d’you mean?" said Ron quickly.
It was as though boiling water was rising rapidly inside him; a burning sensation that was
causing his face to smart in the cold -had he been that obvious?
"Well," said Ron, smiling slightly, "she just couldn’t keep her eyes off you, could she?"
Ron had never before appreciated just how beautiful the village of Hogsmeade was.
CHAPTER SEVENTEEN
Educational Decree Number Twenty-Four
Ron felt happier for the rest of the weekend than he had done all term. He and Ron spent much
of Sunday catching up with all their homework again, and although this could hardly be called
fun, the last burst of autumn sunshine persisted, so rather than sitting hunched over tables in the
common room they took their work outside and lounged in the shade of a large beech tree on the
edge of the lake. Ron, who of course was up to date with all her work, brought more wool
outside with her and bewitched her knitting needles so that they flashed and clicked in midair
beside her, producing more hats and scarves.
Knowing they were doing something to resist Weasley and the Ministry, and that he was a key
part of the rebellion, gave Ron a feeling of immense satisfaction. He kept reliving Saturdays
meeting in his mind: all those people, coming to him to learn Defense Against the Dark Arts...
and the looks on their faces as they had heard some of the things he had done... and Ron praising
his performance in the Triwizard Tournament - The knowledge that all those people did not think him a lying weirdo, but someone to be admired, buoyed him up so much that he was still cheerful on Monday morning, despite the imminent prospect of all his least favorite classes.
He and Ron headed downstairs from their dormitory, discussing Rons idea that they were to
work on a new move called the Sloth Grip Roll during that night’s Quidditch practice, and not
until they were halfway across the sunlit common room did they notice the addition to the room
that had already attracted the attention of a small group of people.
A large sign had been affixed to the Weasley noticeboard; so large it covered everything else
on it - the lists of secondhand spellbooks for sale, the regular reminders of school rules from
Ron Weasley, the Quidditch team training timetable, the offers to barter certain Roncolate Frog
Cards for others, the Weasleys’ latest advertisement for testers, the dates of the Hogsmeade
weekends and the lost and found notices. The new sign was printed in large black letters and
there was a highly official-looking seal at the bottom beside a neat and curly signature.
BY ORDER OF THE HIGH INQUISITOR OF HOGWARTS
All student organizations, societies, teams, groups and clubs are henceforth disbanded.
An organization, society, team, group or club is hereby defined as a regular meeting of three or
more students.
Permission to re-form may be sought from the High Inquisitor (Professor Weasley).
No student organization, society, team, group or club may exist without the knowledge and
approval of the High Inquisitor.
Any student found to have formed, or to belong to, an organization, society, team, group or club
that has not been approved by the High Inquisitor will be expelled.
The above is in accordance with Educational Decree Number Twenty-four.
Signed: Ron  Weasley, High Inquisitor
Ron and Ron read the notice over the heads of some anxious-looking second-years.
"Does this mean they’re going to shut down the Gobstones Club?" one of them asked his friend.
"I reckon you’ll be okay with Gobstones," Ron said darkly, making the second-year jump. "I don’t think we’re going to be as lucky, though, do you?" he asked Ron as the second-years hurried away.
Ron was reading the notice through again. The happiness that had filled him since Saturday
was gone. His insides were pulsing with rage.
"This isn’t a coincidence," he said, his hands forming fists. "She knows."
"She can’t," said Ron at once.
"There were people listening in that pub. And let’s face it, we don’t know how many of the people who turned up we can trust... any of them could have run off and told Weasley..."
And he had thought they believed him, thought they even admired him...
"Ron Weasley!" said Ron at once, punching a fist into his hand. "Or - I thought that Ron
Weasley had a really shifty look, too -"
"I wonder if Ron’s seen this yet?" Ron said, looking round at the door to the girls’
dormitories.
"Let’s go and tell her," said Ron. He bounded forwards, pulled open the door and set off up the
spiral staircase.
He was on the sixth stair when there was a loud, wailing, klaxon-like sound and the steps melted
together to make a long, smooth stone slid. There was a brief moment when Ron tried to keep running, arms working madly like windmills, then he toppled over backwards and shot down the newly created slide, coming to rest on his back at Ron’s feet.
"Er - I don’t think we’re allowed in the girls’ dormitories," said Ron, pulling Ron to his feet and trying not to laugh.
Two fourth-year girls came zooming gleefully down the stone slide.
"Oooh, who tried to get upstairs?" they giggled happily, leaping to their feet and ogling Ron
and Ron.
"Me," said Ron, who was still rather disheveled. " I didn’t realize that would happen. It’s not
fair!" he added to Ron, as the girls headed off for the portrait hole, still giggling madly. "Ron’s allowed in our dormitory, how come we’re not allowed -?"
"Well, it’s an old-fashioned rule," said Ron, who had just slid neatly on to a rug in front of
them and was now getting to her feet, "but it says in Hogwarts A History, that the founders
thought boys were less trustworthy than girls. Anyway, why were you trying to get in there?"
"To see you - look at this!" said Ron, dragging her over to the noticeboard.
Ron’s eyes slid rapidly down the notice. Her expression became stony.
"Someone must have blabbed to her!" Ron said angrily.
"They can’t have done," said Ron in a low voice.
"You’re so naive," said Ron, "you think just because you’re all honorable and trustworthy -"
"No, they can’t have done, because I put a jinx on that piece of parchment we all signed," said
Ron grimly. "Believe me, if anyone’s run off and told Weasley, we’ll know exactly who
they are and they will really regret it."
"What’ll happen to them?" said Ron eagerly.
"Well, put it this way" said Ron, "it’ll make Eloise Midgeon’s acne look like a couple of
cute freckles. Come on, let’s get down to breakfast and see what the others think... I wonder
whether this has been put up in all the houses?"
It was immediately apparent on entering the Great Hall that Weasley’s sign had not only
appeared in Weasley Tower. There was a peculiar intensity about the chatter and an extra
measure of movement in the Hall as people scurried up and down their tables conferring on what
they had read. Ron, Ron and Ron had barely taken their seats when Ron, Ron, Ron,
Ron and Ron descended upon them.
"Did you see it?"
"D’you reckon she knows?"
"What are we going to do?"
They were all looking at Ron. He glanced around to make sure there were no teachers near
them.
"We’re going to do it anyway of course," he said quietly.
"Knew you’d say that"‘ said Ron, beaming and thumping Ron on the arm.
"The prefects as well?" said Ron, looking quizzically at Ron and Ron.
"Of course," said Ron coolly.
"Here come Ron and Ron Weasley," said Ron, looking over his shoulder. "And those
Weasley blokes and Weasley... and no one looks very spotty."
Ron looked alarmed.
"Nevermind spots, the idiots can’t come over here now, it’ll look really suspicious - sit down!"
she mouthed to Ron and Ron, gesturing frantically to them to rejoin the Weasley table.
"Later! We’ll - talk - to - you - later!"
"I’ll tell Ron," said Ron impatiently, swinging herself off her bench, "the fool, honestly..."
She hurried off towards the Weasley table; Ron watched her go. Ron was sitting not far
away, talking to the curly-haired friend she had brought along to the Hog’s Head. Would
Weasley’s notice scare her off meeting them again?
But the full repercussions of the sign were not felt until they were leaving the Great Hall for
History of Magic.
"Ron! Ron!"
It was Ron and she was hurrying towards them looking perfectly desperate.
"It’s okay," said Ron quietly, when she was near enough to hear him. "We’re still going to -"
"You realize she’s including Quidditch in this?" Ron said over him. "We have to go and ask
permission to re-form the Weasley team!"
"What?" said Ron.
"No way," said Ron, appalled.
"You read the sign, it mentions teams too! So listen, Ron... I am saying this for the last time...
please, please don’t lose your temper with Weasley again or she might not let us play any
more!"
"Okay,okay," said Ron, for Ron looked as though she was on the verge of tears. "Don’t
worry, I’ll behave myself..."
"Bet Weasley is in History of Magic," said Ron grimly, as they set off for Weasley’s lesson. "She
hasn’t inspected Weasley yet... bet you anything she’s there..."
But he was wrong; the only teacher present when they entered was Professor Weasley, floating an
inch or so above his chair as usual and preparing to continue his monotonous drone on giant
wars. Ron did not even attempt to follow what he was saying today; he doodled idly on his
parchment ignoring Ron’s frequent glares and nudges, until a particularly painful poke in
the ribs made him look up angrily.
"What?"
She pointed at the window. Ron looked round. Ron was perched on the narrow window
ledge, gazing through the thick glass at him, a letter tied to her leg. Ron could not understand
it; they had just had breakfast, why on earth hadn’t she delivered the letter then, as usual? Many
of his classmates were pointing out Ron to each other, too.
"Oh, I’ve always loved that owl, she’s so beautiful," Ron heard Ron sigh to Ron.
He glanced round at Professor Weasley who continued to read his notes, serenely unaware that the
class’s attention was even less focused upon him than usual. Ron slipped quietly off his chair,
crouched down and hurried along the row to the window, where he slid the catch and opened it
very slowly.
He had expected Ron to hold out her leg so that he could remove the letter and then fly off to
the Owlery but the moment the window was open wide enough she hopped inside, hooting
dolefully. He closed the window with an anxious glance at Professor Weasley, crouched low again
and sped back to his seat with Ron on his shoulder. He regained his seat, transferred Ron
to his lap and made to remove the letter tied to her leg.
Only then did he realize that Ron’s feathers were oddly ruffled; some were bent the wrong
way, and she was holding one of her wings at an odd angle.
"She’s hurt!" Ron whispered, bending his head low over her. Ron and Ron leaned in
closer; Ron even put down her quill. "Look - there’s something wrong with her wing -"
Ron was quivering; when Ron made to touch the wing she gave a little jump, all her
feathers on end as though she was inflating herself, and gazed at him reproachfully.
"Professor Weasley," said Ron loudly, and everyone in the class turned to look at him. "I’m not
feeling well."
Professor Weasley raised his eyes from his notes, looking amazed, as always, to find the room in
front of him full of people.
"Not feeling well?" he repeated hazily.
"Not at all well," said Ron firmly getting to his feet with Ron concealed behind his back. "I
think I need to go to the hospital wing."
"Yes," said Professor Weasley, clearly very much wrong-footed. "Yes... yes, hospital wing... well,
off you go, then, Perkins..."
Once outside the room, Ron returned Ron to his shoulder and hurried off up the corridor,
pausing to think only when he was out of sight of Weasley’s door. His first choice of somebody to
cure Ron would have been Weasley, of course, but as he had no idea where Weasley was his
only remaining option was to find Professor Weasley and hope she would help.
He peered out of a window at the blustery, overcast grounds. There was no sign of her anywhere
near Weasley’s cabin; if she was not teaching, she was probably in the staff room. He set off
downstairs, Ron hooting feebly as she swayed on his shoulder.
Two stone gargoyles flanked the staff-room door. As Ron approached, one of them croaked,
"You should be in class, Sonny Ron."
"This is urgent," said Ron curtly.
"Ooooh, urgent, is it?" said the other gargoyle in a high-pitched voice. "Well, that’s put us in our
place, hasn’t it?"
Ron knocked. He heard footsteps, then the door opened and he found himself face to face with
Professor Weasley.
"You haven’t been given another detention!" she said at once, her square spectacles flashing
alarmingly.
"No, Professor!" said Ron hastily.
"Well then, why are you out of class?"
"It’s urgent, apparently," said the second gargoyle snidely.
"I’m looking for Professor Weasley," Ron explained. "It’s my owl, she’s injured."
"Injured owl, did you say?"
Professor Weasley appeared at Professor Weasley’s shoulder, smoking a pipe and
holding a copy of the Daily Prophet.
"Yes," said Ron, lifting Ron carefully off his shoulder, "she turned up after the other post
owls and her wing’s all funny, look -"
Professor Weasley stuck her pipe firmly between her teeth and took Ron from Ron
while Professor Weasley watched.
"Hmm," said Professor Weasley, her pipe waggling slightly as she talked. "Looks like
something’s attacked her. Can’t think what would have done it, though. Thestrals will sometimes
go for birds, of course, but Weasley’s got the Hogwarts Thestrals well-trained not to touch owls."
Ron neither knew nor cared what Thestrals were; he just wanted to know that Ron was
going to be all right. Professor Weasley, however, looked sharply at Ron and said, "Do you
know how far this owl’s traveled, Weasley?"
"Er," said Ron. "From London, I think."
He met her eyes briefly and knew, by the way her eyebrows had joined in the middle, that she
understood ‘London’ to mean ‘number twelve, Grimmauld Place’.
Professor Weasley pulled a monocle out of the inside of her robes and screwed it into her
eye, to examine Ron’s wing closely. "I should be able to sort this out if you leave her with
me, Weasley," she said, "she shouldn’t be flying long distances for a few days, in any case."
"Er - right - thanks"‘ said Ron, just as the bell rang for break.
"No problem," said Professor Weasley gruffly, turning back into the staff room.
"Just a moment, Ron!" said Professor Weasley. "Weasleys letter!"
"Oh yeah!" said Ron, who had momentarily forgotten the scroll tied to Ron’s leg. Professor
Weasley handed it over and then disappeared into the staff room carrying Ron, who
was staring at Ron as though unable to believe he would give her away like this. Feeling
slightly guilty, he turned to go, but Professor Weasley called him back.
"Weasley!"
"Yes, Professor?"
She glanced up and down the corridor; there were students coming from both directions.
"Bear in mind," she said quickly and quietly, her eyes on the scroll in his hand, "that channels of
communication in and out of Hogwarts may be being watched, won’t you?"
"I -" said Ron, but the flood of students rolling along the corridor was almost upon him.
Professor Weasley gave him a curt nod and retreated into the staff room, leaving Ron to be
swept out into the courtyard with the crowd. He spotted Ron and Ron already standing in a
sheltered corner, their cloak collars turned up against the wind. Ron slit open the scroll as he
hurried towards them and found five words in Ron’s handwriting:
Today, same time, same place.
"Is Ron okay?" asked Ron anxiously, the moment he was within earshot.
"Where did you take her?" asked Ron.
"To Weasley," said Ron. "And I met Weasley... listen..."
And he told them what Professor Weasley had said. To his surprise, neither of the others
looked shocked. On the contrary, they exchanged significant looks.
"What?" said Ron, looking from Ron to Ron and back again.
"Well, I was just saying to Ron... what if someone had tried to intercept Ron? I mean, she’s
never been hurt on a flight before, has she?"
"Who’s the letter from, anyway?" asked Ron, taking the note from Ron.
"Snuffles"‘ said Ron quietly.
"‘Same time, same place?’ Does he mean the fire in the common room?"
"Obviously," said Ron, also reading the note. She looked uneasy. "I just hope nobody else
has read this..."
"But it was still sealed and everything," said Ron, trying to convince himself as much as her.
"And nobody would understand what it meant if they didn’t know where we’d spoken to him
before, would they?"
"I don’t know," said Ron anxiously, hitching h er bag back over her shoulder as the bell
rang again, "it wouldn’t be exactly difficult to re-seal the scroll by magic... and if anyone’s
watching the Floo Network... but I don’t really see how we can warn him not to come
without that being intercepted, too!"
They trudged down the stone steps to the dungeons for Potions, all three of them lost in thought,
but as they reached the bottom of the steps they were recalled to themselves by the voice of
Ron Weasley who was standing just outside Weasley’s classroom door, waving around an official looking piece of parchment and talking much louder than was necessary so that they could hear
every word.
"Yeah, Weasley gave the Weasley Quidditch team permission to continue playing
straightaway, I went to ask her first thing this morning. Well, it was pretty much automatic, I
mean, she knows my father really well, he’s always popping in and out of the Ministry... it’ll be
interesting to see whether Weasley are allowed to keep playing, won’t it?"
"Don’t rise," Ron whispered imploringly to Ron and Ron, who were both watching
Weasley, faces set and fists clenched. "It’s what he wants."
"I mean," said Weasley, raising his voice a little more, his grey eyes glittering malevolently in
Ron and Ron’s direction, "if it’s a question of influence with the Ministry, I don’t think they’ve
got much chance... from what my father says, they’ve been looking for an excuse to sack Ron
Weasley for years... and as for Weasley... my father says it’s a matter of time before the Ministry
has him carted off to St. Mungo’s... apparently they’ve got a special ward for people whose
brains have been addled by magic."
Weasley made a grotesque face, his mouth sagging open and his eyes rolling. Weasley and Weasley
gave their usual grunts of laughter; Ron Weasley shrieked with glee.
Something collided hard with Ron’s shoulder, knocking him sideways. A split second later he
realized that Ron had just charged past him, heading straight for Weasley.
"Ron, no!"
Ron leapt forward and seized the back of Ron’s robes; Ron struggled frantically, his fists
flailing, trying desperately to get at Weasley who looked, for a moment, extremely shocked.
"Help me!" Ron flung at Ron, managing to get an arm around Ron’s neck and dragging him
backwards, away from the Weasleys. Weasley and Weasley were flexing their arms as they stepped
in front of Weasley, ready for the fight. Ron seized Ron’s arms, and together he and Ron
succeeded in dragging Ron back into the Weasley line. Ron’s face was scarlet; the
pressure Ron was exerting on his throat rendered him quite incomprehensible, but odd words
spluttered from his mouth.
"Not... funny... don’t... Mungo’s... show... him..."
The dungeon door opened. Weasley appeared there. His black eyes swept up the Weasley line to
the point where Ron and Ron were wrestling with Ron.
"Fighting, Weasley, Weasley, Weasley?" Weasley said in his cold, sneering voice. "Ten points from Weasley. Release Weasley, Weasley, or it will be detention. Inside, all of you."
Ron let go of Ron, who stood panting and glaring at him.
"I had to stop you," Ron gasped, picking up his bag. "Weasley and Weasley would’ve torn you
apart."
Ron said nothing; he merely snatched up his own bag and stalked off into the dungeon.
"What in the name of Merlin," said Ron slowly, as they followed Ron, "was that about?"
Ron did not answer. He knew exactly why the subject of people who were in St. Mungo’s
because of magical damage to their brains was highly distressing to Ron, but he had sworn to
Weasley that he would not tell anyone Ron’s secret. Even Ron did not know Ron
knew.
Ron, Ron and Ron took their usual seats at the back of the class, pulled out parchment,
quills and their copies of One Thousand Magical Herb s and Fungi. The class around them was
whispering about what Ron had just done, but when Weasley closed the dungeon door with an
echoing bang, everybody immediately fell silent.
"You will notice," said Weasley, in his low, sneering voice, "that we have a guest with us today."
He gestured towards the dim corner of the dungeon and Ron saw Professor Weasley sitting
there, clipboard on her knee. He glanced sideways at Ron and Ron, his eyebrows raised.
Weasley and Weasley, the two teachers he hated most. It was hard to decide which one he wanted
to triumph over the other.
"We are continuing with our Strengthening Solution today. You will find your mixtures as you
left them last lesson; if correctly made they should have matured well over the weekend -
instructions -" he waved his wand again "- on the board. Carry on."
Professor Weasley spent the first half hour of the lesson making notes in her corner. Ron was
very interested in hearing her question Weasley; so interested, that he was becoming careless with
his potion again.
"Salamander blood, Ron!" Ron moaned, grabbing his wrist to prevent him adding the
wrong ingredient for the third time, "not pomegranate juice!"
"Right," said Ron vaguely, putting down the bottle and continuing to watch the corner.
Weasley had just got to her feet. "Ha," he said softly, as she strode between two lines of desks
towards Weasley, who was bending over Ron Ron’s cauldron.
"Well, the class seem fairly advanced for their level," she said briskly to Weasley’s back. "Though I would question whether it is advisable to teach them a potion like the Strengthening Solution. I
think the Ministry would prefer it if that was removed from the syllabus."
Weasley straightened up slowly and turned to look at her.
"Now... how long have you been teaching at Hogwarts?" she asked, her quill poised over her
clipboard.
"Fourteen years," Weasley replied. His expression was unfathomable. Ron, watching him closely,
added a few drops to his potion; it hissed menacingly and turned from turquoise to orange.
"You applied first for the Defense Against the Dark Arts post, I believe?" Professor Weasley
asked Weasley.
"Yes," said Weasley quietly.
"But you were unsuccessful?"
Weasley’s lip curled.
"Obviously"
Professor Weasley scribbled on her clipboard.
"And you have applied regularly for the Defense Against the Dark Arts post since you first
joined the school, I believe?"
"Yes," said Weasley quietly, barely moving his lips. He looked very angry.
"Do you have any idea why Weasley has consistently refused to appoint you?" asked
Weasley.
"I suggest you ask him," said Weasley jerkily.
"Oh, I shall," said Professor Weasley, with a sweet smile.
"I suppose this is relevant?" Weasley asked, his black eyes narrowed.
"Oh yes," said Professor Weasley, "yes, the Ministry wants a thorough understanding of
teachers - er - backgrounds."
She turned away, walked over to Ron Weasley and began questioning her about the lessons.
Weasley looked round at Ron and their eyes met for a second. Ron hastily dropped his gaze to
his potion, which was now congealing foully and giving off a strong smell of burned rubber.
"No marks again, then, Weasley" said Weasley maliciously, emptying Ron’s cauldron with a wave
of his wand. "You will write me an essay on the correct composition of this potion, indicating
how and why you went wrong, to be handed in next lesson, do you understand?"
"Yes," said Ron furiously. Weasley had already given them homework and he had Quidditch
practice this evening; this would mean another couple of sleepless nights. It did not seem
possible that he had awoken that morning feeling very happy. All he felt now was a fervent
desire for this day to end.
"Maybe I’ll skive off Divination," he said glumly, as they stood in the courtyard after lunch, the
wind whipping at the hems of robes and brims of hats. "I’ll pretend to be ill and do Weasley’s essay
instead, then I won’t have to stay up half the night."
"You can’t skive off Divination," said Ron severely.
"Hark who’s talking, you walked out of Divination, you hate Weasley!" said Ron indignantly.
"I don’t hate her," said Ron loftily. "I just think she’s an absolutely appalling teacher and a
real old fraud. But Rons already missed History of Magic and I don’t think he ought to miss
anything else today!"
There was too much truth in this to ignore, so half an hour later Ron took his seat in the hot,
overperfumed atmosphere of the Divination classroom, feeling angry at everybody. Professor
Weasley was yet again handing out copies of The Dream Oracle. Ron thought he’d surely be
much better employed doing Weasley’s punishment essay than sitting here trying to find meaning
in a lot of made-up dreams.
It seemed, however, that he was not the only person in Divination who was in a temper.
Professor Weasley slammed a copy of the Oracle down on the table between Ron and Ron
and swept away, her lips pursed; she threw the next copy of the Oracle at Ron and Ron,
narrowly avoiding Ron’s head, and thrust the final one into Ron’s chest with such force
that he slipped off his pouffe.
"Well, carry on!" said Professor Weasley loudly, her voice high-pitched and somewhat
hysterical, "you know what to do! Or am I such a sub-standard teacher that you have never
learned how to open a book?"
The class stared perplexedly at her, then at each other. Ron, however, thought he knew what
was the matter. As Professor Weasley flounced back to the high-backed teacher’s chair, her
magnified eyes full of angry tears, he leaned his head closer to Ron’s and muttered, "I think she’s got the results of her inspection back."
"Professor?" said Ron Weasley in a hushed voice (she and Ron had always rather admired
Professor Weasley). "Professor, is there anything - er - wrong?"
"Wrong!" cried Professor Weasley in a voice throbbing with emotion. "Certainly not! I have
been insulted, certainly... insinuations have been made against me... unfounded accusations
leveled... but no, there is nothing wrong, certainly not!"
She took a great shuddering breath and looked away from Ron, angry tears spilling from
under her glasses.
"I say nothing," she choked, "of sixteen years of devoted service... it has passed, apparently,
unnoticed... but I shall not be insulted, no, I shall not!"
"But, Professor, who’s insulting you?" asked Ron timidly.
"The Establishment!" said Professor Weasley, in a deep, dramatic, wavering voice. "Yes, those
with eyes too clouded by the mundane to See as I See, to Know as I Know... of course, we Seers
have always been feared, always persecuted... it is - alas -our fate."
She gulped, dabbed at her wet cheeks with the end of her shawl, then she pulled a small
embroidered handkerchief from her sleeve, and blew her nose very hard with a sound like Ron
blowing a raspberry.
Ron sniggered. Ron shot him a disgusted look.
"Professor," said Ron, "do you mean... is it something Professor Weasley -?"
"Do not speak to me about that woman!" cried Professor Weasley, leaping to her feet, her
beads rattling and her spectacles flashing. "Kindly continue with your work!"
And she spent the rest of the lesson striding among them, tears still leaking from behind her
glasses, muttering what sounded like threats under her breath.
"... may well choose to leave... the indignity of it... on probation... we shall see... how she
dares..."
"You and Weasley have got something in common," Ron told Ron quietly when they
met again in Defense Against the Dark Arts. "She obviously reckons Weasley’s an old fraud,
too... looks like she’s put her on probation."
Weasley entered the room as he spoke, wearing her black velvet bow and an expression of
great smugness.
"Good afternoon, class."
"Good afternoon, Professor Weasley," they chanted dully.
"Wands away, please."
But there was no answering flurry of movement this time; nobody had bothered to take out their
wands.
"Please turn to page thirty-four of Defensive Magical Theory and read the third chapter, entitled
‘Case for Non-Offensive Responses to Magical Attack’. There will be -"
"- no need to talk," Ron, Ron and Ron said together, under their breaths.
"No Quidditch practice," said Ron in hollow tones when Ron, Ron and Ron entered
the common room after dinner that night.
"But I kept my temper!" said Ron, horrified. "I didn’t say anything to her, Ron, I swear, I -"
"I know, I know," said Ron miserably. "She just said she needed a bit of time to consider."
"Consider what?" said Ron angrily. "She’s given the Weasleys permission, why not us?"
But Ron could imagine how much Weasley was enjoying holding the threat of no Weasley
Quidditch team over their heads and could easily understand why she would not want to
relinquish that weapon over them too soon.
"Well," said Ron, "look on the bright side - at least now you’ll have time to do Weasley’s
essay!"
"That’s a bright side, is it?" snapped Ron, while Ron stared incredulously at Ron. "No
Quidditch practice, and extra Potions?"
Ron slumped down into a chair, dragged his Potions essay reluctantly from his bag and set to
work. It was very hard to concentrate; even though he knew Ron was not due in the fire until
much later, he could not help glancing into the flames every few minutes just in case. There was
also an incredible amount of noise in the room: Ron and Ron appeared finally to have
perfected one type of Skiving Snackbox, which they were taking turns to demonstrate to a
cheering and whooping crowd.
First, Ron would take a bite out of the orange end of a chew, at which he would vomit
spectacularly into a bucket they had placed in front of them. Then he would force down the
purple end of the chew, at which the vomiting would immediately cease. Ron Weasley, who was
assisting the demonstration, was lazily Vanishing the vomit at regular intervals with the same
Vanishing Spell Weasley kept using on Rons potions.
What with the regular sounds of retching, cheering and the sound of Ron and Ron taking
advance orders from the crowd, Ron was finding it exceptionally difficult to focus on the
correct method for Strengthening Solution. Ron was not helping matters; the cheers and the
sound of vomit hitting the bottom of Ron and Ron’s bucket were punctuated by her loud and
disapproving sniffs, which Ron found, if anything, more distracting.
"Just go and stop them, then!" he said irritably, after crossing out the wrong weight of powdered
griffin claw for the fourth time.
"I can’t, they’re not technically doing anything wrong," said Ron through gritted teeth.
"They’re quite within their rights to eat the foul things themselves and I can’t find a rule that says the other idiots aren’t entitled to buy them, not unless they’re proven to be dangerous in some way and it doesn’t look as though they are."
She, Ron and Ron watched Ron projectile-vomit into the bucket, gulp down the rest of the
chew and straighten up, beaming with his arms wide to protracted applause.
"You know, I don’t get why Ron and Ron only got three OWLs each," said Ron, watching
as Ron, Ron and Ron collected gold from the eager crowd. "They really know their stuff."
"Oh, they only know flashy stuff that’s of no real use to anyone," said Ron disparagingly.
"No real use?" said Ron in a strained voice. "Ron, they’ve made about twenty-six Galleons
already."
It was a long while before the crowd around the Weasley twins dispersed, then Ron, Ron and
Ron sat up counting their takings even longer, so it was well past midnight when Ron, Ron
and Ron finally had the common room to themselves. At long last, Ron had closed the
doorway to the boys’ dormitories behind him, rattling his box of Galleons ostentatiously so that
Ron scowled. Ron, who was making very little progress with his Potions essay, decided
to give it up for the night. As he put his books away, Ron, who was dozing lightly in an
armchair, gave a muffled grunt, awoke, and looked blearily into the fire.
"Ron!" he said.
Ron whipped round. Rons untidy dark head was sitting in the fire again.
"Hi," he said, grinning.
"Hi," chorused Ron, Ron and Ron, all three kneeling down on the hearthrug. Ron purred loudly and approached the fire, trying, despite the heat, to put his face close
to Ron’s.
"How’re things?" said Ron.
"Not that good," said Ron, as Ron pulled Ron back to stop him singeing his
whiskers. "The Ministry’s forced through another decree, which means we’re not allowed to have Quidditch teams -"
"Or secret Defense Against the Dark Arts groups?" said Ron.
There was a short pause.
"How did you know about that?" Ron demanded.
"You want to choose your meeting places more carefully," said Ron, grinning still more
broadly. "The Hog’s Head, I ask you."
"Well, it was better than the Three Broomsticks!" said Ron defensively. "That’s always
packed with people -"
"Which means you’d have been harder to overhear," said Ron. "You’ve got a lot to learn,
Ron."
"Who overheard us?" Ron demanded.
"Ron, of course," said Ron, and when they all looked puzzled he laughed. "He was the
witch under the veil."
"That was Ron?" Ron said, stunned. "What was he doing in the Hog’s Head?"
"What do you think he was doing?" said Ron impatiently. "Keeping an eye on you, of course."
"I’m still being followed?" asked Ron angrily.
"Yeah, you are," said Ron, "and just as well, isn’t it, if the first thing you’re going to do on your weekend off is organize an illegal defense group."
But he looked neither angry nor worried. On the contrary, he was looking at Ron with distinct
pride.
"Why was Dung hiding from us?" asked Ron, sounding disappointed. "We’d’ve liked to’ve seen
him."
"He was banned from the Hog’s Head twenty years ago," said Ron, "and that barman’s got a
long memory. We lost Weasley’s spare Invisibility Cloak when Ron was arrested, so Dung’s
been dressing as a witch a lot lately... anyway... first of all, Ron - I’ve sworn to pass on a
message from your mother."
"Oh yeah?" said Ron, sounding apprehensive.
"She says on no account whatsoever are you to take part in an illegal secret Defense Against the
Dark Arts group. She says you’ll be expelled for sure and your future will be ruined. She says
there will be plenty of time to learn how to defend yourself later and that you are too young to be
worrying about that right now. She also" (Ron’s eyes turned to the other two) "advises Ron
and Ron not to proceed with the group, though she accepts that she has no authority over
either of them and simply begs them to remember that she has their best interests at heart. She
would have written all this to you, but if the owl had been intercepted you’d all have been in real
trouble, and she can’t say it for herself because she’s on duty tonight."
"On duty doing what?" said Ron quickly.
"Never you mind, just stuff for the Order," said Ron. "So it’s fallen to me to be the messenger
and make sure you tell her I passed it all on, because I don’t think she trusts me to."
There was another pause in which Ron, mewing, attempted to paw Ron’s head, and
Ron fiddled with a hole in the hearthrug.
"So, you want me to say I’m not going to take part in the Defense group?" he muttered finally.
"Me? Certainly not!" said Ron, looking surprised. "I think it’s an excellent idea!"
"You do?" said Ron, his heart lifting.
"Of course I do!" said Ron. "D’you think your father and I would’ve lain down and taken orders from an old hag like Weasley?"
"But - last term all you did was tell me to be careful and not take risks -"
"Last year, all the evidence was that someone inside Hogwarts was trying to kill you, Ron!"
said Ron impatiently. "This year, we know there’s someone outside Hogwarts who’d like to kill us all, so I think learning to defend yourselves properly is a very good idea!"
"And if we do get expelled?" Ron asked, a quizzical look on her face.
"Ron, this whole thing was your idea!" said Ron, staring at her.
"I know it was. I just wondered what Ron thought," she said, shrugging.
"Well, better expelled and able to defend yourselves than sitting safely in school without a clue,"
said Ron.
"Hear, hear," said Ron and Ron enthusiastically.
"So," said Ron, "how are you organizing this group? Where are you meeting?"
"Well, that’s a bit of a problem now," said Ron. "Dunno where we’re going to be able to go."
"How about the Shrieking Shack?" suggested Ron.
"Hey, that’s an idea!" said Ron excitedly, but Ron made a skeptical noise and all three of
them looked at her, Ron’s head turning in the flames.
"Well, Ron, it’s just that there were only four of you meeting in the Shrieking Shack when you
were at school," said Ron, "and all of you could transform into animals and I suppose you
could all have squeezed under a single Invisibility Cloak if you’d wanted to. But there are
twenty-eight of us and none of us is an Animagus, so we wouldn’t need so much an Invisibility
Cloak as an Invisibility Marquee -"
"Fair point," said Ron, looking slightly crestfallen. "Well, I’m sure you’ll come up with
somewhere. There used to be a pretty roomy secret passageway behind that big mirror on the
fourth floor, you might have enough space to practice jinxes in there."
"Ron and Ron told me it’s blocked," said Ron, shaking his head. "Caved in or something."
"Oh..." said Ron, frowning. "Well, I’ll have a think and get back to -"
He broke off. His face was suddenly tense, alarmed. He turned sideways, apparently looking into
the solid brick wall of the fireplace.
"Ron?" said Ron anxiously.
But he had vanished. Ron gaped at the flames for a moment, then turned to look at Ron and
Ron.
"Why did he -?"
Ron gave a horrified gasp and leapt to her feet, still staring at the fire.
A hand had appeared amongst the flames, groping as though to catch hold of something; a
stubby, short-fingered hand covered in ugly old-fashioned rings.
The three of them ran for it. At the door of the boys’ dormitory Ron looked back. Weasley’s
hand was still making snatching movements amongst the flames, as though she knew exactly
where Ron’s hair had been moments before and was determined to seize it.
CHAPTER EIGHTEEN
Weasley’s Army
"Weasley has been reading your mail, Ron. There’s no other explanation."
"You think Weasley attacked Ron?" he said, outraged.
"I’m almost certain of it," said Ron grimly. "Watch your frog, it’s escaping."
Ron pointed his wand at the bullfrog that had been hopping hopefully towards the other side of
the table - "Accio!" - and it zoomed gloomily back into his hand.
Charms was always one of the best lessons in which to enjoy a private chat; there was generally
so much movement and activity that the danger of being overheard was very slight. Today, with
the room full of croaking bullfrogs and cawing ravens, and with a heavy downpour of rain
clattering and pounding against the classroom windows, Ron, Ron and Ron’s whispered
discussion about how Weasley had nearly caught Ron went quite unnoticed.
"I’ve been suspecting this ever since Weasley accused you of ordering Dungbombs, because it
seemed such a stupid lie," Ron whispered. "I mean, once your letter had been read it would
have been quite clear you weren’t ordering them, so you wouldn’t have been in trouble at all - it’s a bit of a feeble joke, isn’t it? But then I thought, what if somebody just wanted an excuse to read your mail? Well then, it would be a perfect way for Weasley to manage it - tip off Weasley, let him do the dirty work and confiscate the letter, then either find a way of stealing it from him or else demand to see it - I don’t think Weasley would object, when’s he ever stuck up for a student’s rights? Ron, you’re squashing your frog."
Ron looked down; he was indeed squeezing his bullfrog so tightly its eyes were popping; he
replaced it hastily upon the desk.
"It was a very, very close call last night," said Ron. "I just wonder if Weasley knows how
close it was. Silencio."
The bullfrog on which she was practicing her Silencing Charm was struck dumb mid-croak and
glared at her reproachfully.
"If she’d caught Snuffles -"
Ron finished the sentence for her.
"- He’d probably be back in Azkaban this morning." He waved his wand without really
concentrating; his bullfrog swelled like a green balloon and emitted a high-pitched whistle.
"Silencio!" said Ron hastily, pointing her wand at Ron’s frog, which deflated silently
before them. "Well, he mustn’t do it again, that’s all. I just don’t know how we’re going to let
him know. We can’t send him an owl."
"I don’t reckon he’ll risk it again," said Ron. "He’s not stupid, he knows she nearly got
him. Silencio."
The large and ugly raven in front of him let out a derisive caw.
"Silencio. SILENCIO!"
The raven cawed more loudly.
"Its the way you’re moving your wand," said Ron, watching Ron critically, "you don’t want to wave it, it’s more a sharp jab."
"Ravens are harder than frogs," said Ron through clenched teeth.
"Fine, let’s swap," said Ron, seizing Rons raven and replacing it with her own fat bullfrog.
"Silencio!" The raven continued to open and close its sharp beak, but no sound came out.
"Very good, Miss Weasley!" said Professor Weasley’s squeaky little voice, making Ron, Ron
and Ron all jump. "Now, let me see you try, Mr. Weasley."
"Wha--? Oh - oh, right," said Ron, very flustered. "Er - silencio!"
He jabbed at the bullfrog so hard he poked it in the eye: the frog gave a deafening croak and
leapt off the desk.
It came as no surprise to any of them that Ron and Ron were given additional practice of the
Silencing Charm for homework.
They were allowed to remain inside over break due to the downpour outside. They found seats in
a noisy and overcrowded classroom on the first floor in which Ron was floating dreamily up
near the chandelier, occasionally blowing an ink pellet at the top of somebody’s head. They had
barely sat down when Ron came struggling towards them through the groups of gossiping
students.
"I’ve got permission!" she said. "To re-form the Quidditch team!"
"Excellent!" said Ron and Ron together.
"Yeah," said Ron, beaming. "I went to Weasley and I think she might have appealed to
Weasley. Anyway, Weasley had to give in. Ha! So I want you down at the pitch at seven
o’clock tonight, all right, because we’ve got to make up time. You realize we’re only three weeks away from our first match?"
She squeezed away from them, narrowly dodged an ink pellet from Ron, which hit a nearby
first-year instead, and vanished from sight.
Ron’s smile slipped slightly as he looked out of the window, which was now opaque with
hammering rain.
"Hope this clears up. What’s up with you, Ron?"
She, too, was gazing at the window, but not as though she really saw it. Her eyes were unfocused
and there was a frown on her face.
"Just thinking..." she said, still frowning at the rain-washed window.
"About Siri-- Snuffles?" said Ron.
"No... not exactly..." said Ron slowly. "More... wondering... I suppose we’re doing the
right thing... I think... aren’t we?"
Ron and Ron looked at each other.
"Well, that clears that up," said Ron. "It would’ve been really annoying if you hadn’t explained
yourself properly."
Ron looked at him as though she had only just realized he was there.
"I was just wondering," she said, her voice stronger now, "whether we’re doing the right thing,
starting this Defense Against the Dark Arts group."
"What?" said Ron and Ron together.
"Ron, it was your idea in the first place!" said Ron indignantly.
"I know," said Ron, twisting her fingers together. "But after talking to Snuffles..."
"But he’s all for it," said Ron.
"Yes," said Ron, staring at the window again. "Yes, that’s what made me think maybe it
wasn’t a good idea after all..."
Ron floated over them on his stomach, peashooter at the ready; automatically all three of them
lifted their bags to cover their heads until he had passed.
"Let’s get this straight," said Ron angrily, as t hey put their bags back on the floor, "Ron agrees with us, so you don’t think we should do it any more?"
Ron looked tense and rather miserable. Now staring at her own hands, she said, "Do you
honestly trust his judgment?"
"Yes, I do!" said Ron at once. "He’s always given us great advice!"
An ink pellet whizzed past them, striking Ron Weasley squarely in the ear. Ron watched Ron
leap to her feet and start throwing things at Ron; it was a few moments before Ron
spoke again and it sounded as though she was choosing her words very carefully.
"You don’t think he has become... sort of... reckless... since he’s been cooped up in Grimmauld
Place? You don’t think he’s... kind of... living through us?"
"What d’you mean, ‘through us’?" Ron retorted.
"I mean... well, I think he’d love to be forming secret Defense societies right under the nose of
someone from the Ministry... I think he’s really frustrated at how little he can do where he is...
so I think he’s keen to kind of... egg us on."
Ron looked utterly perplexed.
"Ron is right," he said, "you do sound just like my mother."
Ron bit her lip and did not answer. The bell rang just as Ron swooped down on Ron
and emptied an entire ink bottle over her head.
The weather did not improve as the day wore on, so that at seven o’clock that evening, when
Ron and Ron went down to the Quidditch pitch for practice, they were soaked through within
minutes, their feet slipping and sliding on the sodden grass. The sky was a deep, thundery grey
and it was a relief to gain the warmth and light of the changing rooms, even if they knew the
respite was only temporary. They found Ron and Ron debating whether to use one of their
own Skiving Snackboxes to get out of flying.
"... but I bet she’d know what we’d done," Ron said out of the corner of his mouth. "If only I
hadn’t offered to sell her some Puking Pastilles yesterday."
"We could try the Fever Weasley," Ron muttered, "no one’s seen that yet -"
"Does it work?" enquired Ron hopefully, as the hammering of rain on the roof intensified and
wind howled around the building.
"Well, yeah," said Ron, "your temperature’ll go right up."
"But you get these massive pus-filled boils, too," said Ron, "and we haven’t worked out how
to get rid of them yet."
"I can’t see any boils," said Ron, staring at the, twins.
"No, well, you wouldn’t," said Ron darkly, "they’re not in a place we generally display to the
public."
"But they make sitting on a broom a right pain in the -"
"All right, everyone, listen up," said Ron loudly, emerging from the Captain’s office. "I
know it’s not ideal weather, but there’s a chance we’ll be playing Weasley in conditions like this
so it’s a good idea to work out how we’re going to cope with them. Ron, didn’t you do
something to your glasses to stop the rain fogging them up when we played Weasley in that
storm?’
"Ron did it," said Ron. He pulled out his wand, tapped his glasses and said, "Impervius!"
"I think we all ought to try that," said Ron. "If we could just keep the rain off our faces it
would really help visibility - all together, come on - Impervius! okay. Let’s go."
They all stowed their wands back in the inside pockets of their robes, shouldered their brooms
and followed Ron out of the changing rooms.
They squelched through the deepening mud to the middle of the pitch; visibility was still very
poor even with the Impervius Charm; light was fading fast and curtains of rain were sweeping
the grounds.
"All right, on my whistle," shouted Ron.
Ron kicked off from the ground, spraying mud in all directions, and shot upwards, the wind
pulling him slightly off course.
He had no idea how he was going to see the Snitch in this weather; he was having enough
difficulty seeing the one Bludger with which they were practicing; a minute into the practice it
almost unseated him and he had to use the Sloth Grip Roll to avoid it. Unfortunately, Ron
did not see this. In fact, she did not appear to be able to see anything; none of them had a clue
what the others were doing. The wind was picking up; even at a distance Ron could hear the
swishing, pounding sounds of the rain pummeling the surface of the lake.
Ron kept them at it for nearly an hour before conceding defeat. She led her sodden and
disgruntled team back into the changing rooms, insisting that the practice had not been a waste of
time, though without any real conviction in her voice. Ron and Ron were looking particularly
annoyed; both were bandy-legged and winced with every movement. Ron could hear them
complaining in low voices as he toweled his hair dry.
"I think a few of mine have ruptured," said Ron in a hollow voice.
"Mine haven’t," said Ron, through clenched teeth, "they’re throbbing like mad... feel bigger if anything."
"OUCH!" said Ron.
He pressed the towel to his face, his eyes screwed tight with pain. The scar on his forehead had
seared again, more painfully than it had in weeks.
"What’s up?" said several voices.
Ron emerged from behind his towel; the changing room was blurred because he was not
wearing his glasses, but he could still tell that everyone’s face was turned towards him.
"Nothing," he muttered, "I - poked myself in the eye, that’s all."
But he gave Ron a significant look and the two of them hung back as the rest of the team filed
back outside, muffled in their cloaks, their hats pulled low over their ears.
"What happened?" said Ron, the moment Ron had disappeared through the door. "Was it your
scar?"
Ron nodded.
"But..." looking scared, Ron strode across to the window and stared out into the rain, "he - he
can’t be near us now, can he?"
"No," Ron muttered, sinking on to a bench and rubbing his forehead. "He’s probably miles
away. It hurt because... he’s... angry."
Ron had not meant to say that at all, and heard the words as though a stranger had spoken them
- yet knew at once that they were true. He did not know how he knew it, but he did; Weasley,
wherever he was, whatever he was doing, was in a towering temper.
"Did you see him?" said Ron, looking horrified. "Did you... get a vision, or something?"
Ron sat quite still, staring at his feet, allowing his mind and his memory to relax in the
aftermath of the pain.
A confused tangle of shapes, a howling rush of voices...
"He wants something done, and it’s not happening fast enough," he said.
Again, he felt surprised to hear the words coming out of his mouth, and yet was quite certain
they were true.
"But... how do you know?" said Ron.
Ron shook his head and covered his eyes with his hands, pressing down upon them with his
palms. Little stars erupted in them. He felt Ron sit down on the bench beside him and knew Ron
was staring at him.
"Is this what it was about last time?" said Ron in a hushed voice. "When your scar hurt in
Weasley’s office? You-Know-Who was angry?"
Ron shook his head.
"What is it, then?"
Ron was thinking himself back. He had been looking into Weasley’s face... his scar had
hurt... and he had had that odd feeling in his stomach... a strange, leaping feeling... a happy
feeling... but of course, he had not recognized it for what it was, as he had been feeling so
miserable himself...
"Last time, it was because he was pleased," he said. "Really pleased. He thought... something
good was going to happen. And the night before we came back to Hogwarts..." he thought back
to the moment when his scar had hurt so badly in his and Ron’s bedroom in Grimmauld Place...
"he was furious."
He looked round at Ron, who was gaping at him.
"You could take over from Weasley, mate," he said in an awed voice.
"I’m not making prophecies," said Ron.
"No, you know what you’re doing?" Ron said, sounding both scared and impressed. "Ron, you’re reading You-Know-Who’s mind!"
"No," said Ron, shaking his head. "It’s more like... his mood, I suppose. I’m just getting flashes of what mood he’s in. Weasley said something like this was happening last year. He said that when Weasley was near me, or when he was feeling hatred, I could tell. Well, now I’m feeling it when he’s pleased, too..."
There was a pause. The wind and rain lashed at the building.
"You’ve got to tell someone," said Ron.
"I told Ron last time."
"Well, tell him about this time!"
"Can’t, can I?" said Ron grimly. "Weasley is watching the owls and the fires, remember?"
"Well then, Weasley."
"I’ve just told you, he already knows," said Ron shortly, getting to his feet, taking his cloak off
his peg and swinging it around him. "There’s no point telling him again."
Ron did up the fastening of his own cloak, watching Ron thoughtfully.
"Weasley’d want to know," he said.
Ron shrugged.
"C’mon... we’ve still got Silencing Charms to practice."
They hurried back through the dark grounds, sliding and stumbling up the muddy lawns, not
talking. Ron was thinking hard. What was it that Weasley wanted done that was not
happening quickly enough?
"... he’s got other plans... plans he can put into operation very quietly indeed... stuff he can only
get by stealth... like a weapon. Something he didn’t have last time."
Ron had not thought about those words in weeks; he had been too absorbed in what was going
on at Hogwarts, too busy dwelling on the ongoing battles with Weasley, the injustice of all the
Ministry interference... but now they came back to him and made him wonder... Weasley’s
anger would make sense if he was no nearer to laying hands on the weapon, whatever it was.
Had the Order thwarted him, stopped him from seizing it? Where was it kept? Who had it now?
"Mimbulus mimbletonia," said Ron’s voice and Ron came back to his senses just in time to
clamber through the portrait hole into the common room.
It appeared that Ron had gone to bed early, leaving Ron curled in a nearby chair
and an assortment of knobbly knitted elf hats lying on a table by the fire. Ron was rather
grateful that she was not around, because he did not much want to discuss his scar hurting and
have her urge him to go to Weasley, too. Ron kept throwing him anxious glances, but Ron
pulled out his Charms books and set to work on finishing his essay, though he was only
pretending to concentrate and by the time Ron said he was going up to bed, too, he had written
hardly anything.
Midnight came and went while Ron was reading and rereading a passage about the uses of
scurvy-grass, lovage and sneezewort and not taking in a word of it.
These plants are most efficacious in the inflaming of the brain, and are therefore much used
in Confusing and Befuddlement Draughts, where the wizard is desirous of producing hot-headedness and recklessness...
... Ron said Ron was becoming reckless cooped up in Grimmauld Place...
... most efficacious in the inflaming of the brain, and are therefore much used...
... the Daily Prophet would think his brain was inflamed if they found out that he knew what
Weasley was feeling...
... therefore much used in Confusing and Befuddlement Draughts...
... confusing was the word, all right; why did he know what Weasley was feeling? What was
this weird connection between them, which Weasley had never been able to explain
satisfactorily?
... where the wizard is desirous...
... how Ron would like to sleep...
... producing hot-headedness...
... it was warm and comfortable in his armchair before the fire, with the rain still beating heavily
on the windowpanes, Ron purring, and the crackling of the flames...
The book slipped from Ron’s slack grip and landed with a dull thud on the hearthrug. His head
rolled sideways...
He was walking once more along a windowless corridor, his footsteps echoing in the silence. As
the door at the end of the passage loomed larger, his heart beat fast with excitement... if he could
only open it... enter beyond...
He stretched out his hand... his fingertips were inches from it...
"Ron Weasley, sir!"
