He awoke with a start. The candles had all been extinguished in the common room, but there was
something moving close by.
"Whozair?" said Ron, sitting upright in his chair. The fire was almost out, the room very dark.
"Ron has your owl, sir!" said a squeaky voice.
"Ron?" said Ron thickly, peering through the gloom towards the source of the voice.
Ron the house-elf was standing beside the table on which Ron had left half a dozen of
her knitted hats. His large, pointed ears were now sticking out from beneath what looked like all
the hats Ron had ever knitted; he was wearing one on top of the other, so that his head
seemed elongated by two or three feet, and on the very topmost bobble sat Ron, hooting
serenely and obviously cured.
"Ron volunteered to return Ron Weasley’s owl," said the elf squeakily, with a look of positive
adoration on his face, "Professor Weasley says she is all well now, sir." He sank into a
deep bow so that his pencil-like nose brushed the threadbare surface of the hearthrug and
Ron gave an indignant hoot and fluttered on to the arm of Ron’s chair.
"Thanks, Ron!" said Ron, stroking Ron’s head and blinking hard, trying to rid himself of
the image of the door in his dream... it had been very vivid. Surveying Ron more closely, he
noticed that the elf was also wearing several scarves and innumerable socks, so that his feet
looked far too big for his body.
"Er... have you been taking all the clothes Ron’s been leaving out?"
"Oh, no, sir," said Ron happily. "Ron has been taking some for Ron, too, sir."
"Yeah, how is Ron?" asked Ron.
Ron’s ears drooped slightly.
"Ron is still drinking lots, sir," he said sadly, his enormous round green eyes, large as tennis
balls, downcast. "She still does not care for clothes, Ron Weasley. Nor do the other house-elves.
None of them will clean Weasley Tower any more, not with the hats and socks hidden
everywhere, they finds them insulting, sir. Ron does it all himself, sir, but Ron does not
mind, sir, for he always hopes to meet Ron Weasley and tonight, sir, he has got his wish!" Ron
sank into a deep bow again. "But Ron Weasley does not seem happy," Ron went on,
straightening up again and looking timidly at Ron. "Ron heard him muttering in his sleep.
Was Ron Weasley having bad dreams?"
"Not really bad," said Ron, yawning and rubbing his eyes. "I’ve had worse."
The elf surveyed Ron out of his vast, orb-like eyes. Then he said very seriously, his ears
drooping, "Ron wishes he could help Ron Weasley, for Ron Weasley set Ron free and Ron
is much, much happier now."
Ron smiled.
"You can’t help me, Ron, but thanks for the offer."
He bent and picked up his Potions book. He’d have to try to finish the essay tomorrow. He
closed the book and as he did so the firelight illuminated the thin white scars on the back of his
hand - the result of his detentions with Weasley...
"Wait a moment - there is something you can do for me, Ron," said Ron slowly.
The elf looked round, beaming.
"Name it, Ron Weasley, sir!"
"I need to find a place where twenty-eight people can practice Defense Against the Dark Arts
without being discovered by any of the teachers. Especially," Ron clenched his hand on the
book, so that the scars shone pearly white, "Professor Weasley."
He expected the elf’s smile to vanish, his ears to droop; he expected him to say it was
impossible, or else that he would try to find somewhere, but his hopes were not high. What he
had not expected was for Ron to give a little skip, his ears waggling cheerfully, and clap his
hands together.
"Ron knows the perfect place, sir!" he said happily. "Ron heard tell of it from the other
house-elves when he came to Hogwarts, sir. It is known by us as the Come and Go Room, sir, or
else as the Room of Requirement!"
"Why?" said Ron curiously.
"Because it is a room that a person can only enter," said Ron seriously, "when they have real
need of it. Sometimes it is there, and sometimes it is not, but when it appears, it is always
equipped for the seeker’s needs. Ron has used it, sir," said the elf, dropping his voice and
looking guilty, "when Ron has been very drunk; he has hidden her in the Room of
Requirement and he has found antidotes to Butterbeer there, and a nice elf-sized bed to settle her
on while she sleeps it off, sir... and Ron knows Mr. Weasley has found extra cleaning materials
there when he has run short, sir, and -"
"And if you really needed a bathroom," said Ron, suddenly remembering something
Weasley had said at the Yule Ball the previous Christmas, "would it fill itself with chamber
pots?"
"Ron expects so, sir," said Ron, nodding earnestly. "It is a most amazing room, sir."
"How many people know about it?" said Ron, sitting up straighter in his chair.
"Very few, sir. Mostly people stumbles across it when they needs it, sir, but often they never
finds it again, for they do not know that it is always there waiting to be called into service, sir."
"It sounds brilliant," said Ron, his heart racing. "It sounds perfect, Ron. When can you show me where it is?"
"Any time, Ron Weasley, sir," said Ron, looking delighted at Rons enthusiasm. "We could go
now, if you like!"
For a moment Ron was tempted to go with Ron. He was halfway out of his seat, intending to
hurry upstairs for his Invisibility Cloak when, not for the first time, a voice very much like
Ron’s whispered in his ear: reckless. It was, after all, very late, he was exhausted, and had
Weasley’s essay to finish.
"Not tonight, Ron," said Ron reluctantly, sinking back into his chair. "This is really
important... I don’t want to blow it, it’ll need proper planning. Listen, can you just tell me
exactly where this Room of Requirement is, and how to get in there?"
Their robes billowed and swirled around them as they splashed across the flooded vegetable
patch to double Herbology, where they could hardly hear what Professor Weasley was saying over
the hammering of raindrops hard as hailstones on the greenhouse roof. The afternoons Care of
Magical Creatures lesson was to be relocated from the storm-swept grounds to a free classroom
on the ground floor and, to their intense relief, Ron had sought out her team at lunch to tell
them that Quidditch practice was cancelled.
"Good," said Ron quietly, when she told him, "because we’ve found somewhere to have our
first Defense meeting. Tonight, eight o’clock, seventh floor opposite that tapestry of Barnabas
the Barmy being clubbed by those trolls. Can you tell Ron and Ron?"
She looked slightly taken aback but promised to tell the others. Ron returned hungrily to his
sausages and mash. When he looked up to take a drink of pumpkin juice, he found Ron
watching him.
"What?" he said thickly.
"Well... it’s just that Ron’s plans aren’t always that safe. Don’t you remember when he lost
you all the bones in your arm?"
"This room isn’t just some mad idea of Ron’s; Weasley knows about it, too, he mentioned
it to me at the Yule Ball."
Ron’s expression cleared.
"Weasley told you about it?"
"Just in passing," said Ron, shrugging.
"Oh, well, that’s all right then," said Ron briskly and raised no more objections.
Together with Ron they had spent most of the day seeking out those people who had signed their
names to the list in the Hog’s Head and telling them where to meet that evening. Somewhat to
Ron’s disappointment, it was Ron who managed to find Ron Weasley and her friend first;
however, by the end of dinner he was confident that the news had been passed to every one of
the twenty-five people who had turned up in the Hog’s Head.
At half past seven Ron, Ron and Ron left the Weasley common room, Ron clutching
a certain piece of aged parchment in his hand. Fifth-years were allowed to be out in the corridors
until nine o’clock, but all three of them kept looking around nervously as they made their way
along the seventh floor.
"Hold it," Ron warned, unfolding the piece of parchment at the top of the last staircase, tapping
it with his wand and muttering, "I solemnly swear that I am up to no good."
A map of Hogwarts appeared on the blank surface of the parchment. Tiny black moving dots,
labeled with names, showed where various people were.
"Weasley is on the second floor," said Ron, holding the map close to his eyes, "and Mrs. Norris is
on the fourth."
"And Weasley?" said Ron anxiously.
"In her office," said Ron, pointing. "Okay, lets go."
They hurried along the corridor to the place Ron had described to Ron, a stretch of blank
wall opposite an enormous tapestry depicting Barnabas the Barmy’s foolish attempt to train trolls
for the ballet.
"Okay," said Ron quietly, while a moth-eaten troll paused in his relentless clubbing of the would be ballet teacher to watch them. "Ron said to walk past this bit of wall three times,
concentrating hard on what we need."
They did so, turning sharply at the window just beyond the blank stretch of wall, then at the man-sized vase on its other side. Ron had screwed up his eyes in concentration; Ron was
whispering something under her breath; Ron’s fists were clenched as he stared ahead of him.
We need somewhere to learn to fight... he thought. Just give us a place to practice... somewhere they can’t find us...
"Ron!" said Ron sharply, as they wheeled around after their third walk past.
A highly polished door had appeared in the wall. Ron was staring at it, looking slightly wary.
Ron reached out, seized the brass handle, pulled open the door and led the way into a spacious
room lit with flickering torches like those that illuminated the dungeons eight floors below.
The walls were lined with wooden bookcases and instead of chairs there were large silk cushions
on the floor. A set of shelves at the far end of the room carried a range of instruments such as
Sneakoscopes, Secrecy Sensors and a large, cracked Foe-Glass that Ron was sure had hung, the
previous year, in the fake Weasleys office.
"These will be good when we’re practicing Stunning, " said Ron enthusiastically, prodding one of the cushions with his foot.
"And just look at these books!" said Ron excitedly, running a finger along the spines of the
large leather-bound tomes. "A Compendium of Common Curses and their Counter-Actions...
The Dark Arts Outsmarted... Self-Defensive Spellwork... wow..." She looked around at Ron,
her face glowing, and he saw that the presence of hundreds of books had finally convinced
Ron that what they were doing was right. "Ron, this is wonderful, there’s everything we
need here!"
And without further ado she slid ‘Jinxes for the Jinxed’ from its shelf, sank on to the nearest
cushion and began to read.
There was a gentle knock on the door. Ron looked round. Ron, Ron, Ron, Ron
and Ron had arrived.
"Whoa," said Ron, staring around, impressed. "What is this place?"
Ron began to explain, but before he had finished more people had arrived and he had to start all
over again. By the time eight o’clock arrived, every cushion was occupied. Ron moved across
to the door and turned the key protruding from the lock; it clicked in a satisfyingly loud way and
everybody fell silent, looking at him. Ron carefully marked her page of ‘Jinxes for the
Jinxed’ and set the book aside.
"Well," said Ron, slightly nervously. "This is the place we’ve found for practice sessions, and
you’ve - er - obviously found it okay."
"It’s fantastic!" said Ron, and several people murmured their agreement.
"It’s bizarre," said Ron, frowning around at it. "We once hid from Weasley in here, remember,
Ron? But it was just a broom cupboard then."
"Hey, Ron, what’s this stuff?" asked Ron from the rear of the room, indicating the
Sneakoscopes and the Foe-Glass.
"Dark detectors," said Ron, stepping between the cushions to reach them. "Basically they all
show when Dark wizards or enemies are around, but you don’t want to rely on them too much,
they can be fooled..."
He gazed for a moment into the cracked Foe-Glass; shadowy figures were moving around inside
it, though none was recognizable. He turned his back on it.
"Well, I’ve been thinking about the sort of stuff we ought to do first and - er -" He noticed a
raised hand. "What, Ron?"
"I think we ought to elect a leader," said Ron.
"Ron’s leader," said Ron at once, looking at Ron as though she were mad.
Rons stomach did yet another back-flip.
"Yes, but I think we ought to vote on it properly," said Ron, unperturbed. "It makes it
formal and it gives him authority. So - everyone who thinks Ron ought to be our leader?"
Everybody put up their hand, even Ron Weasley, though he did it very half-heartedly.
"Er - right, thanks," said Ron, who could feel his face burning. "And -what, Ron?"
"I also think we ought to have a name," she said brightly, her hand still in the air. "It would
promote a feeling of team spirit and unity, don’t you think?"
"Can we be the Anti-Weasley League?" said Ron hopefully.
"Or the Ministry of Magic are Morons Group?" suggested Ron.
"I was thinking," said Ron, frowning at Ron, "more of a name that didn’t tell everyone
what we were up to, so we can refer to it safely outside meetings."
"The Defense Association?" said Ron. "The D.A. for short, so nobody knows what we’re talking
about?"
"Yeah, the D.A.’s good," said Ron. "Only let’s make it stand for Weasleys Army, because
that’s the Ministry’s worst fear, isn’t it?"
There was a good deal of appreciative murmuring and laughter at this.
"All in favor of the D.A.?" said Ron bossily, kneeling up on her cushion to count. "That’s a
majority - motion passed!"
She pinned the piece of parchment with all of their signatures on it on to the wall and wrote
across the top in large letters:
"Right," said Ron, when she had sat down again, "shall we get practicing then? I was thinking,
the first thing we should do is Expelliarmus, you know, the Disarming Charm. I know it’s pretty basic but I’ve found it really useful -"
"Oh, please," said Ron Weasley, rolling his eye s and folding his arms. "I don’t think Expelliarmus is exactly going to help us against You-Know-Who, do you?"
"I’ve used it against him," said Ron quietly. "It saved my life in June."
Weasley opened his mouth stupidly. The rest of the room was very quiet.
"But if you think it’s beneath you, you can leave," Ron said.
Weasley did not move. Nor did anybody else.
"Okay," said Ron, his mouth slightly drier than usual with all these eyes upon him, "I reckon we should all divide into pairs and practice."
It felt very odd to be issuing instructions, but not nearly as odd as seeing them followed.
Everybody got to their feet at once and divided up. Predictably, Ron was left partnerless.
"You can practice with me," Ron told him. "Right-on the count of three, then-one, two, three-"
The room was suddenly full of shouts of Expelliarmus. Wands flew in all directions; missed
spells hit books on shelves and sent them flying into the air. Ron was too quick for Ron,
whose wand went spinning out of his hand, hit the ceiling in a shower of sparks and landed with
a clatter on top of a bookshelf, from which Ron retrieved it with a Summoning Charm.
Glancing around, he thought he had been right to suggest they practice the basics first; there was
a lot of shoddy spellwork going on; many people were not succeeding in Disarming their
opponents at all, but merely causing them to jump backwards a few paces or wince as their
feeble spell whooshed over them.
"Expelliarmus!" said Ron, and Ron, caught unawares, felt his wand fly out of his hand.
"I DID IT!" said Ron gleefully. "I’ve never done it before - I DID IT!"
"Good one!" said Ron encouragingly, deciding not to point out that in a real duel Rons
opponent was unlikely to be staring in the opposite direction with his wand held loosely at his
side. "Listen, Ron, can you take it in turns to practice with Ron and Ron for a couple of
minutes so I can walk around and see how the rest are doing?"
Ron moved off into the middle of the room. Something very odd was happening to Ron
Weasley. Every time he opened his mouth to disarm Ron Weasley, his own wand would fly
out of his hand, yet Ron did not seem to be making a sound. Ron did not have to look far
to solve the mystery: Ron and Ron were several feet from Weasley and taking it in turns to
point their wands at his back.
"Sorry, Ron" said Ron hastily, when Ron caught his eye. "Couldn’t resist."
Ron walked around the other pairs, trying to correct those who were doing the spell wrong.
Ron was teamed with Ron Weasley; she was doing very well, whereas Ron was either
very bad or unwilling to jinx her. Ron Weasley was flourishing his wand unnecessarily,
giving his partner time to get in under his guard; the Weasley brothers were enthusiastic but
erratic and mainly responsible for all the books leaping off the shelves around them; Ron
Weasley was similarly patchy, occasionally sending Ron Weasley’s wand spinning out
of his hand, at other times merely causing his hair to stand on end.
"Okay, stop!" Ron shouted. "Stop! STOP!"
I need a whistle, he thought, and immediately spotted one lying on top of the nearest row of
books. He caught it up and blew hard. Everyone lowered their wands.
"That wasn’t bad," said Ron, "but there’s definite room for improvement." Ron Weasley
glared at him. "Let’s try again."
He moved off around the room again, stopping here and there to make suggestions. Slowly, the
general performance improved.
He avoided going near Ron and her friend for a while, but after walking twice around every other
pair in the room felt he could not ignore them any longer.
"Oh no," said Ron rather wildly as he approached. "Expelliarmious! I mean, Expellimellius!! I -
oh, sorry, Ron!"
Her curly-haired friend’s sleeve had caught fire; Ron extinguished it with her own wand and
glared at Ron as though it was his fault.
"You made me nervous, I was doing all right before then!" Ron told Ron ruefully.
"That was quite good," Ron lied, but when she raised her eyebrows he said, "Well, no, it was
lousy, but I know you can do it properly, I was watching from over there."
She laughed. Her friend Ron looked at them rather sourly and turned away.
"Don’t mind her," Ron muttered. "She doesn’t really want to be here but I made her come with
me. Her parents have forbidden her to do anything that might upset Weasley. You see - her
mum works for the Ministry."
"What about your parents?" asked Ron.
"Well, they’ve forbidden me to get on the wrong side of Weasley, too," said Ron, drawing
herself up proudly. "But if they think I’m not going to fight You-Know-Who after what
happened to Ron -"
She broke off, looking rather confused, and an awkward silence fell between them; Ron Weasley’s
wand went whizzing past Ron’s ear and hit Ron Weasley hard on the nose.
"Well, my dad is very supportive of any anti-Ministry action!" said Ron Weasley proudly from just behind Ron; evidently she had been eavesdropping on his conversation while Ron Weasley attempted to disentangle himself from the robes that had flown up over his head. "He’s always saying he’d believe anything of Weasley; I mean, the number of goblins Weasley has had assassinated! And of course he uses the Department of Mysteries to develop terrible poisons,
which he secretly feeds to anybody who disagrees with him. And then there’s his Umgubular
Slashkilter --"
"Don’t ask," Ron muttered to Ron as she opened her mouth, looking puzzled. She giggled.
"Hey, Ron," Ron called from the other end of the room, "have you checked the time?"
He looked down at his watch and was shocked to see it was already ten past nine, which meant
they needed to get back to their common rooms immediately or risk being caught and punished
by Weasley for being out of bounds. He blew his whistle; everybody stopped shouting
"Expelliarmus" and the last couple of wands clattered to the floor.
"Well, that was pretty good," said Ron, "but we’ve overrun, we’d better leave it here. Same
time, same place next week?"
"Sooner!’ said Ron Ron eagerly and many people nodded in agreement.
Ron, however, said quickly. "The Quidditch season’s about to start, we need team practices
too!"
"Let’s say next Wednesday night, then," said Ron, "we can decide on additional meetings then. Come on, we’d better get going."
He pulled out the Marauder’s Map again and checked it carefully for signs of teachers on the
seventh floor. He let them all leave in threes and fours, watching their tiny dots anxiously to see
that they returned safely to their dormitories: the Weasleys to the basement corridor that also
led to the kitchens; the Weasleys to a tower on the west side of the castle, and the Weasleys
along the corridor to the Ron Weasley’s portrait.
"That was really, really good, Ron" said Ron, when finally it was just her, Ron and Ron
who were left.
"Yeah, it was!" said Ron enthusiastically, as they slipped out of the door and watched it melt
back into stone behind them. "Did you see me disarm Ron, Ron?"
"Only once," said Ron, stung. "I got you loads more than you got me -"
"I did not only get you once, I got you at least three times -"
"Well, if you’re counting the one where you tripped over your own feet and knocked the wand
out of my hand -"
They argued all the way back to the common room, but Ron was not listening to them. He had
one eye on the Marauder’s Map, but he was also thinking of Ron saying he made her nervous.
CHAPTER NINETEEN
The Lion and the Serpent
Ron felt as though he were carrying some kind of talisman inside his chest over the following
two weeks, a glowing secret that supported him through Weasley’s classes and even made it
possible for him to smile blandly as he looked into her horrible bulging eyes. He and the D.A.
were resisting her under her very nose, doing the very thing she and the Ministry most feared,
and whenever he was supposed to be reading Wilbert Slinkhard’s book during her lessons he
dwelled instead on satisfying memories of their most recent meetings, remembering how Ron
had successfully disarmed Ron, how Ron Weasley had mastered the Impediment Jinx
after three meetings’ hard effort, how Ron Weasley had produced such a good Reductor Curse
that she had reduced the table carrying all the Sneakoscopes to dust.
He was finding it almost impossible to fix a regular night of the week for the D.A. meetings, as
they had to accommodate three separate team’s Quidditch practices, which were often rearranged
due to bad weather conditions; but Ron was not sorry about this; he had a feeling that it was
probably better to keep the timing of their meetings unpredictable. If anyone was watching them,
it would be hard to make out a pattern.
Ron soon devised a very clever method of communicating the time and date of the next
meeting to all the members in case they needed to change it at short notice, because it would
look suspicious if people from different Houses were seen crossing the Great Hall to talk to each
other too often. She gave each of the members of the D.A. a fake Galleon (Ron became very
excited when he first saw the basket and was convinced she was actually giving out gold).
"You see the numerals around the edge of the coins?" Ron said, holding one up for
examination at the end of their fourth meeting. The coin gleamed fat and yellow in the light from
the torches. "On real Galleons that’s just a serial number referring to the goblin who cast the
coin. On these fake coins, though, the numbers will change to reflect the time and date of the
next meeting. The coins will grow hot when the date changes, so if you’re carrying them in a
pocket you’ll be able to feel them. We take one each, and when Ron sets the date of the next
meeting he’ll change the numbers on his coin, and because I’ve put a Protean Charm on them,
they’ll all change to mimic his."
A blank silence greeted Ron’s words. She looked around at all the faces upturned to her,
rather disconcerted.
"Well - I thought it was a good idea," she said uncertainly, "I mean, even if Weasley asked us to turn out our pockets, there’s nothing fishy about carrying a Galleon, is there? But... well, if you don’t want to use them -"
"You can do a Protean Charm?" said Ron Weasley.
"Yes," said Ron.
"But that’s... that’s Ron standard, that is," he said weakly.
"Oh," said Ron, trying to look modest. "Oh... well... yes, I suppose it is."
"How come you’re not in Weasley?" he demanded, staring at Ron with something close
to wonder. "With brains like yours?"
"Well, the Sorting Hat did seriously consider putting me in Weasley during my Sorting," said
Ron brightly, "but it decided on Weasley in the end. So, does that mean we’re using the
Galleons?"
There was a murmur of assent and everybody moved forwards to collect one from the basket.
Ron looked sideways at Ron.
"You know what these remind me of?"
"No, what’s that?"
"The Death Eaters’ scars. Weasley touches one of them, and all their scars burn, and they
know they’ve got to join him."
"Well... yes," said Ron quietly, "that is where I got the idea but you’ll notice I decided to
engrave the date on bits of metal rather than on our members’ skin."
"Yeah... I prefer your way," said Ron, grinning, as he slipped his Galleon into his pocket. "I
suppose the only danger with these is that we might accidentally spend them."
"Ron chance," said Ron, who was examining his own fake Galleon with a slightly mournful air, "I haven’t got any real Galleons to confuse it with."
As the first Quidditch match of the season, Weasley versus Weasley, drew nearer, their D.A.
meetings were put on hold because Ron insisted on almost daily practices. The fact that the
Quidditch Cup had not been held for so long added considerably to the interest and excitement
surrounding the forthcoming game; the Weasleys and Weasleys were taking a lively interest
in the outcome, for they, of course, would be playing both teams over the coming year; and the
Heads of House of the competing teams, though they attempted to disguise it under a decent
pretence of sportsmanship, were determined to see their own side victorious. Ron realized how
much Professor Weasley cared about beating Weasley when she abstained from giving them
homework in the week leading up to the match.
"I think you’ve got enough to be getting on with at the moment," she said loftily. Nobody could
quite believe their ears until she looked directly at Ron and Ron and said grimly, "I’ve become
accustomed to seeing the Quidditch Cup in my study, boys, and I really don’t want to have to
hand it over to Professor Weasley, so use the extra time to practice, won’t you?"
Weasley was no less obviously partisan; he had booked the Quidditch pitch for Weasley practice
so often that the Weasleys had difficulty getting on it to play. He was also turning a deaf ear to
the many reports of Weasley attempts to hex Weasley players in the corridors. When Ron
Weasley turned up in the hospital wing with her eyebrows growing so thick and fast they
obscured her vision and obstructed her mouth, Weasley insisted that she must have attempted a
Hair-thickening Charm on herself and refused to listen to the fourteen eye-witnesses who
insisted they had seen the Weasley Keeper, Miles Bletchley, hit her from behind with a jinx
while she worked in the library.
Ron felt optimistic about Weasley’s chances; they had, after all, never lost to Weasley’s team.
Admittedly, Ron was still not performing to Weasley’s standard, but he was working extremely
hard to improve. His greatest weakness was a tendency to lose confidence after he’d made a
blunder; if he let in one goal he became flustered and was therefore likely to miss more. On the
other hand, Ron had seen Ron make some truly spectacular saves when he was on form; during
one memorable practice he had hung one-handed from his broom and kicked the Quaffle so hard
away from the goal hoop that it soared the length of the pitch and through the center hoop at the
other end; the rest of the team felt this save compared favorably with one made recently by
Barry Ryan, the Irish International Keeper, against Poland’s top Chaser, Ladislaw Zamojski.
Even Ron had said that Ron might yet make him and Ron proud, and that they were seriously
considering admitting he was related to them, something they assured him they had been trying
to deny for four years.
The only thing really worrying Ron was how much Ron was allowing the tactics of the
Weasley team to upset him before they even got on to the pitch. Ron, of course, had endured
their snide comments for over four years, so whispers of, "Hey, Potty, I heard Warrington’s
sworn to knock you off your broom on Saturday", far from chilling his blood, made him laugh.
"Warrington’s aim’s so pathetic I’d be more worried if he was aiming for the person next to me,"
he retorted, which made Ron and Ron laugh and wiped the smirk off Ron Weasleys
face.
But Ron had never endured a relentless campaign of insults, jeers and intimidation. When
Weasleys, some of them seventh-years and considerably larger than he was, muttered as they
passed in the corridors, "Got your bed booked in the hospital wing, Weasley?" he didn’t laugh,
but turned a delicate shade of green. When Ron Weasley imitated Ron dropping the Quaffle
(which he did whenever they came within sight of each other), Ron’s ears glowed red and his
hands shook so badly that he was likely to drop whatever he was holding at the time, too.
October extinguished itself in a rush of howling winds and driving rain and November arrived,
cold as frozen iron, with hard frosts every morning and icy draughts that bit at exposed hands
and faces. The skies and the ceiling of the Great Hall turned a pale, pearly grey, the mountains
around Hogwarts were snowcapped, and the temperature in the castle dropped so low that many
students wore their thick protective dragon skin gloves in the corridors between lessons.
The morning of the match dawned bright and cold. When Ron awoke he looked round at Ron’s
bed and saw him sitting bolt upright, his arms around his knees, staring fixedly into space.
"You all right?" said Ron.
Ron nodded but did not speak. Ron was reminded forcibly of the time Ron had accidentally put
a Slug-vomiting Charm on himself; he looked just as pale and sweaty as he had done then, not to
mention as reluctant to open his mouth.
"You just need some breakfast," Ron said bracingly. "C’mon."
The Great Hall was filling up fast when they arrived, the talk louder and the mood more
exuberant than usual. As they passed the Weasley table there was an upsurge of noise. Ron
looked round and saw that, in addition to the usual green and silver scarves and hats, every one
of them was wearing a silver badge in the shape of what seemed to be a crown. For some reason
many of them waved at Ron, laughing uproariously. Ron tried to see what was written on the
badges as he walked by, but he was too concerned to get Ron past their table quickly to linger
long enough to read them.
They received a rousing welcome at the Weasley table, where everyone was wearing red and
gold, but far from raising Ron’s spirits the cheers seemed to sap the last of his morale; he
collapsed on to the nearest bench looking as though he were facing his final meal.
"I must’ve been mental to do this," he said in a croaky whisper. "Mental."
"Don’t be thick," said Ron firmly, passing him a choice of cereals, "you’re going to be fine. It’s normal to be nervous."
"I’m rubbish," croaked Ron. "I’m lousy. I can’t play to save my life. What was I thinking?"
"Get a grip," said Ron sternly. "Look at that save you made with your foot the other day, even
Ron and Ron said it was brilliant."
Ron turned a tortured face to Ron.
"That was an accident," he whispered miserably. "I didn’t mean to do it - I slipped off my broom
when none of you were looking and when I was trying to get back on I kicked the Quaffle by
accident."
"Well," said Ron, recovering quickly from this unpleasant surprise, "a few more accidents like
that and the game’s in the bag, isn’t it?"
Ron and Ron sat down opposite them wearing red and gold scarves, gloves and rosettes.
"How’re you feeling?" Ron asked Ron, who was now staring into the dregs of milk at the
bottom of his empty cereal bowl as though seriously considering attempting to drown himself in
them.
"He’s just nervous," said Ron.
"Well, that’s a good sign, I never feel you perform as well in exams if you’re not a bit nervous,"
said Ron heartily.
"Hello," said a vague and dreamy voice from behind them. Ron looked up: Ron Weasley had
drifted over from the Weasley table. Many people were staring at her and a few were openly
laughing and pointing; she had managed to procure a hat shaped like a life-size lion’s head,
which was perched precariously on her head.
"I’m supporting Weasley," said Ron, pointing un necessarily at her hat. "Look what it does..."
She reached up and tapped the hat with her wand. It opened its mouth wide and gave an
extremely realiztic roar that made everyone in the vicinity jump.
"It’s good, isn’t it?" said Ron happily. "I wanted to have it chewing up a serpent to represent
Weasley, you know, but there wasn’t time. Anyway... good luck, Ronald!"
She drifted away. They had not quite recovered from the shock of Ron’s hat before Ron
came hurrying towards them, accompanied by Ron and Ron, whose eyebrows had mercifully
been returned to normal by Ron Weasley.
"When you’re ready" she said, "we’re going to go straight down to the pitch, check out conditions and change."
"We’ll be there in a bit," Ron assured her. "Ron’s just got to have some breakfast."
It became clear after ten minutes, however, that Ron was not capable of eating anything more
and Ron thought it best to get him down to the changing rooms. As they rose from the table,
Ron got up, too, and taking Ron’s arm she drew him to one side.
"Don’t let Ron see what’s on those Weasleys’ badges," she whispered urgently.
Ron looked questioningly at her, but she shook her head warningly; Ron had just ambled over
to them, looking lost and desperate.
"Good luck, Ron," said Ron, standing on tiptoe and kissing him on the cheek. "And you,
Ron -"
Ron seemed to come to himself slightly as they walked back across the Great Hall. He touched
the spot on his face where Ron had kissed him, looking puzzled, as though he was not quite
sure what had just happened. He seemed too distracted to notice much around him, but Ron
cast a curious glance at the crown-shaped badges as they passed the Weasley table, and this time
he made out the words etched on to them:
Weasley Is Our King
With an unpleasant feeling that this could mean nothing good, he hurried Ron across the
Entrance Hall, down the stone steps and out into the icy air.
The frosty grass crunched under their feet as they hurried down the sloping lawns towards the
stadium. There was no wind at all and the sky was a uniform pearly white, which meant that
visibility would be good without the drawback of direct sunlight in the eyes. Ron pointed out
these encouraging factors to Ron as they walked, but he was not sure that Ron was listening.
Ron had changed already and was talking to the rest of the team when they entered. Ron
and Ron pulled on their robes (Ron attempted to do his up back-to-front for several minutes
before Ron took pity on him and went to help), then sat down to listen to the pre-match talk
while the babble of voices outside grew steadily louder as the crowd came pouring out of the
castle towards the pitch.
"Okay, I’ve only just found out the final line-up for Weasley," said Ron, consulting a piece of parchment. "Last year’s Beaters, Derrick and Bole, have left, but it looks as though Weasley’s replaced them with the usual gorillas, rather than anyone who can fly particularly well. They’re two blokes called Weasley and goyle, I don’t know much about them-"
"We do," said Ron and Ron together.
"Well, they don’t look bright enough to tell one end of a broom from the other," said Ron,
pocketing her parchment, "but then I was always surprised Derrick and Bole managed to find
their way on to the pitch without signposts."
"Weasley and Weasley are in the same mould," Ron assured her.
They could hear hundreds of footsteps mounting the banked benches of the spectators’ stands.
Some people were singing, though Ron could not make out the words. He was starting to feel
nervous, but he knew his butterflies were as nothing compared to Ron’s, who was clutching his
stomach and staring straight ahead again, his jaw set and his complexion pale grey.
"It’s time," said Ron in a hushed voice, looking at her watch. "C’mon everyone... good
luck."
The team rose, shouldered their brooms and marched in single file out of the changing room and
into the dazzling sunlight. A roar of sound greeted them in which Ron could still hear singing,
though it was muffled by the cheers and whistles.
The Weasley team was standing waiting for them. They, too, were wearing those silver crownshaped badges. The new Captain, Weasley, was built along the same lines as Ron Weasley, with massive forearms like hairy hams. Behind him lurked Weasley and Weasley, almost as large, blinking stupidly in the sunlight, swinging their new Beaters’ bats. Weasley stood to one side, the sunlight gleaming on his white-blond head. He caught Ron’s eye and smirked, tapping the crown-shaped badge on his chest.
"Captains, shake hands," ordered the referee Ron Weasley, as Ron and Weasley reached
each other. Ron could tell that Weasley was trying to crush Ron’s fingers, though she did
not wince. "Mount your brooms..."
Ron Weasley placed her whistle in her mouth and blew.
The balls were released and the fourteen players shot upwards. Out of the corner of his eye Ron
saw Ron streak off towards the goal hoops. Ron zoomed higher, dodging a Bludger, and set off
on a wide lap of the pitch, gazing around for a glint of gold; on the other side of the stadium,
Ron Weasley was doing exactly the same.
"And it’s Ronson - Ronson with the Quaffle, what a player that girl is, I’ve been saying it for
years but she still won’t go out with me -"
"Weasley!" yelled Professor Weasley.
"- just a fun fact, Professor, adds a bit of interest - and she’s ducked Warrington, she’s passed
Weasley, she’s -- ouch - been hit from behind by a Bludger from Weasley... Weasley catches
the Quaffle, Weasley heading back up the pitch and - nice Bludger there from Ron Weasley,
that’s a Bludger to the head for Weasley, he drops the Quaffle, caught by Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley
of Weasley reverse-passes to Ron Weasley and Weasley’s away -"
Ron Weasley’s commentary rang through the stadium and Ron listened as hard as he could
through the wind whistling in his ears and the din of the crowd, all yelling and booing and
singing.
"- dodges Warrington, avoids a Bludger - close call, Ron - and the crowd are loving this, just
listen to them, what’s that they’re singing?"
And as Ron paused to listen, the song rose loud and clear from the sea of green and silver in the
Weasley section of the stands:
"Weasley cannot save a thing, He cannot block a single ring, That’s why Weasleys all sing:
Weasley is our King."
"Weasley was born in a bin He always lets the Quaffle in Weasley will make sure we win
Weasley is our King."
"--and Ron passes back to Ron!" Ron shouted, and as Ron swerved, his insides boiling
at what he had just heard, he knew Ron was trying to drown out the words of the song. "Come on
now, Ron -- looks like she’s got just the Keeper to beat! - SHE SHOOTS - SHE - aaaah..."
Bletchley, the Weasley Keeper, had saved the goal; he threw the Quaffle to Warrington who
sped off with it, zig-zagging in between Ron and Ron; the singing from below grew louder
and louder as he drew nearer and nearer Ron.
"Weasley is our King, Weasley is our King, He always lets the Quaffle in Weasley is our King."
Ron could not help himself: abandoning his search for the Snitch, he wheeled around to watch
Ron, a lone figure at the far end of the pitch, hovering before the three goal hoops while the
massive Warrington pelted towards him.
"- and it’s Warrington with the Quaffle, Warrington heading for goal, he’s out of Bludger range
with just the Keeper ahead -"
A great swell of song rose from the Weasley stands below:
"Weasley cannot save a thing, He cannot block a single ring..."
"- so it’s the first test for new Weasley Keeper Weasley, brother of Beaters Ron and Ron,
and a promising new talent on the team - come on, Ron!"
But the scream of delight came from the Weasleys’ end: Ron had dived wildly, his arms wide,
and the Quaffle had soared between them straight through Ron’s central hoop.
"Weasley score!" came Ron’s voice amid the cheering and booing from the crowds below, "so
that’s ten-nil to Weasley - bad luck, Ron."
The Weasleys sang even louder:
"Weasley WAS BORN IN A BIN, HE ALWAYS LETS THE QUAFFLE IN..."
"- and Weasley back in possession and it’s Ron Weasley tanking up the pitch -" cried Ron
valiantly, though the singing was now so deafening that he could hardly make himself heard
above it.
"Weasley WILL MAKE SURE WE WIN Weasley IS OUR KING..."
"Ron, WHAT ARE YOU DOING?" screamed Ron, soaring past him to keep up with
Ron. "GET GOING!"
Ron realized he had been stationary in midair for over a minute, watching the progress of the
match without sparing a thought for the whereabouts of the Snitch; horrified, he went into a dive
and started circling the pitch again, staring around, trying to ignore the chorus now thundering
through the stadium:
"Weasley IS OUR KING, Weasley IS OUR KING..."
There was no sign of the Snitch anywhere he looked; Weasley was still circling the stadium just as
he was. They passed one another midway around the pitch, going in opposite directions, and
Ron heard Weasley singing loudly:
"Weasley WAS BORN IN A BIN..."
"--and it’s Warrington again," bellowed Ron, "who passes to Pucey, Pucey’s off past Weasley,
come on now, Ron, you can take him - turns out you can’t - but nice Bludger from Ron
Weasley, I mean, Ron Weasley, oh, who cares, one of them, anyway, and Warrington drops
the Quaffle and Ron Weasley -- er - drops it, too - so that’s Weasley with the Quaffle, Weasley
Captain Weasley takes the Quaffle and he’s off up the pitch, come on now, Weasley, block
him!"
Ron zoomed around the end of the stadium behind the Weasley goal hoops, willing himself not
to look at what was going on at Ron’s end. As he sped past the Weasley Keeper, he heard
Bletchley singing along with the crowd below:
"Weasley CANNOT SAVE A THING..."
"- and Pucey’s dodged Ron again and he’s heading straight for goal, stop it, Ron!"
Ron did not have to look to see what had happened: there was a terrible groan from the
Weasley end, coupled with fresh screams and applause from the Weasleys. Looking down,
Ron saw the pug-faced Ron Weasley right at the front of the stands, her back to the pitch as
she conducted the Weasley supporters who were roaring:
"THAT’S WHY WeasleyS ALL SING Weasley ISOUR KING."
But twenty-nil was nothing, there was still time for Weasley to catch up or catch the Snitch. A
few goals and they would be in the lead as usual, Ron assured himself, bobbing and weaving
through the other players in pursuit of something shiny that turned out to be Weasley’s
watchstrap.
But Ron let in two more goals. There was an edge of panic in Ron’s desire to find the Snitch
now. If he could just get it soon and finish the game quickly.
"- and Ron Weasley of Weasley dodges Pucey, ducks Weasley, nice swerve, Ron, and she
throws to Ronson, Ron Ronson takes the Quaffle, she’s past Warrington, she’s heading for
goal, come on now, Ron - Weasley SCORE! It’s forty-ten, forty-ten to Weasley and
Pucey has the Quaffle"
Ron could hear Ron’s ludicrous lion hat roaring amidst the Weasley cheers and felt
heartened; only thirty points in it, that was nothing, they could pull back easily. Ron ducked a
Bludger that Weasley had sent rocketing in his direction and resumed his frantic scouring of the
pitch for the Snitch, keeping one eye on Weasley in case he showed signs of having spotted it, but
Weasley, like him, was continuing to soar around the stadium, searching fruitlessly...
"-- Pucey throws to Warrington, Warrington to Weasley, Weasley back to Pucey -Ronson
intervenes, Ronson takes the Quaffle, Ronson to Weasley, this looks good - I mean bad - Weasleys hit
by a Bludger from Weasley of Weasley and it’s Pucey in possession"
"Weasley WAS BORN IN A BIN, HE ALWAYS LETS THE QUAFFLE IN"
"Weasley WILL MAKE SURE WE WIN"
But Ron had seen it at last: the tiny fluttering Golden Snitch was hovering feet from the ground
at the Weasley end of the pitch.
He dived...
In a matter of seconds, Weasley was streaking out of the sky on Ron’s left, a green and silver
blur lying flat on his broom...
The Snitch skirted the foot of one of the goal hoops and scooted off towards the other side of the
stands; its change of direction suited Weasley, who was nearer; Ron pulled his Firebolt around,
he and Weasley were now neck and neck...
Feet from the ground, Ron lifted his right hand from his broom, stretching towards the
Snitch... to his right, Weasley’s arm extended too, was reaching, groping...
It was over in two breathless, desperate, windswept seconds - Ron’s fingers closed around the
tiny, struggling ball - Weasley’s fingernails scrabbled the back of Rons hand hopelessly - Ron
pulled his broom upwards, holding the struggling ball in his hand and the Weasley spectators
screamed their approval...
They were saved, it did not matter that Ron had let in those goals, nobody would remember as
long as Weasley had won -
WHAM.
A Bludger hit Ron squarely in the small of the back and he flew forwards off his broom.
Luckily he was only five or six feet above the ground, having dived so low to catch the Snitch,
but he was winded all the same as he landed flat on his back on the frozen pitch. He heard
Ron Weasley’s shrill whistle, an uproar in the stands compounded of catcalls, angry yells and
jeering, a thud, then Rons frantic voice.
"Are you all right?"
"Course I am," said Ron grimly, taking her hand and allowing her to pull him to his feet.
Ron Weasley was zooming towards one of the Weasley players above him, though he could
not see who it was from this angle.
"It was that thug Weasley," said Ron angrily, "he whacked the Bludger at you the moment he saw you’d got the Snitch - but we won, Ron, we won!"
Ron heard a snort from behind him and turned around, still holding the Snitch tightly in his
hand: Ron Weasley had landed close by. White-faced with fury, he was still managing to sneer.
"Saved Weasley’s neck, haven’t you?" he said to Ron. "I’ve never seen a worse Keeper... but
then he was born in a bin... did you like my lyrics, Weasley?"
Ron didn’t answer. He turned away to meet the rest of the team who were now landing one by
one, yelling and punching the air in triumph; all except Ron, who had dismounted from his
broom over by the goalposts and seemed to be making his way slowly back to the changing
rooms alone.
"We wanted to write another couple of verses!" Weasley called, as Ron and Ron hugged Ron. "But we couldn’t find rhymes for fat and ugly - we wanted to sing about his mother, see-"
"Talk about sour grapes," said Ron, casting Weasley a disgusted look.
"- we couldn’t fit in useless loser either - for his father, you know -"
Ron and Ron had realized what Weasley was talking about. Halfway through shaking Ron’s
hand, they stiffened, looking round at Weasley.
"Leave it!" said Ron at once, taking Ron by the arm. "Leave it, Ron, let him yell, he’s just
sore he lost, the jumped-up little -"
"- but you like the Weasleys, don’t you, Weasley?" said Weasley, sneering. "Spend holidays there
and everything, don’t you? Can’t see how you stand the stink, but I suppose when you’ve been
dragged up by Muggles, even the Weasleys’ hovel smells okay -"
Ron grabbed hold of Ron. Meanwhile, it was taking the combined efforts of Ron,
Ron and Ron to stop Ron leaping on Weasley, who was laughing openly. Ron looked around
for Ron Weasley, but she was still berating Weasley for his illegal Sludger attack.
"Or perhaps," said Weasley, leering as he backed away, "you can remember what your mother’s
house stank like, Weasley, and Weasleys pigsty reminds you of it --"
Ron was not aware of releasing Ron, all he knew was that a second later both of them were
sprinting towards Weasley. He had completely forgotten that all the teachers were watching: all he
wanted to do was cause Weasley as much pain as possible; with no time to draw out his wand, he
merely drew back the fist clutching the Snitch and sank it as hard as he could into Weasleys
stomach -
"Ron! Ron! Ron! NO"
He could hear girls’ voices screaming, Weasley yelling, Ron swearing, a whistle blowing and
the bellowing of the crowd around him, but he did not care. Not until somebody in the vicinity
yelled "Impedimenta!" and he was knocked over backwards by the force of the spell, did he
abandon the attempt to punch every inch of Weasley he could reach.
"What do you think you’re doing?" screamed Ron Weasley, as Ron leapt to his feet. It seemed to have been her who had hit him with the Impediment Jinx; she was holding her whistle
in one hand and a wand in the other; her broom lay abandoned several feet away. Weasley was curled up on the ground, whimpering and moaning, his nose bloody; Ron was sporting a swollen lip; Ron was still being forcibly restrained by the three Chasers, and Weasley was cackling in the background. "I’ve never seen behavior like it - back up to the castle, both of you, and straight to your Head of House’s office! Go! Now."
Ron and Ron turned on their heels and marched off the pitch, both panting, neither saying a
word to the other. The howling and jeering of the crowd grew fainter and fainter until they
reached the Entrance Hall, where they could hear nothing except the sound of their own
footsteps. Ron became aware that something was still struggling in his right hand, the knuckles
of which he had bruised against Weasley’s jaw. Looking down, he saw the Snitch’s silver wings
protruding from between his fingers, struggling for release.
They had barely reached the door of Professor Weasley’s office when she came marching
along the corridor behind them. She was wearing a Weasley scarf, but tore it from her throat
with shaking hands as she strode towards them, looking livid.
"In!" she said furiously, pointing to the door. Ron and Ron entered. She strode around
behind her desk and faced them, quivering with rage as she threw the Weasley scarf aside on
to the floor.
"Well?" she said. "I have never seen such a disgraceful exhibition. Two on one! Explain
yourselves!"
"Weasley provoked us," said Ron stiffly.
"Provoked you?" shouted Professor Weasley, slamming a fist on to her desk so that her tartan tin slid sideways off it and burst open, littering the floor with Ginger Rons. "He’d just lost, hadn’t he? Of course he wanted to provoke you! But what on earth he can have said that justified what you two --"
"He insulted my parents," snarled Ron. "And Ron’s mother."
"But instead of leaving it to Ron Weasley to sort out, you two decided to give an exhibition of
Muggle dueling, did you?" bellowed Professor Weasley. "Have you any idea what you’ve -
?"
"Hem, hem."
Ron and Ron both wheeled round. Ron Weasley was standing in the doorway wrapped
in a green tweed cloak that greatly enhanced her resemblance to a giant toad, and was smiling in
the horrible, sickly, ominous way that Ron had come to associate with imminent misery.
"May I help, Professor Weasley?" asked Professor Weasley in her most poisonously sweet
voice.
Blood rushed into Professor Weasley’s face.
"Help?" she repeated, in a constricted voice. "What do you mean, help?"
Professor Weasley moved forwards into the office, still smiling her sickly smile.
"Why, I thought you might be grateful for a little extra authority"
Ron would not have been surprised to see sparks fly from Professor Weasley’s nostrils.
"You thought wrong," she said, turning her back on Weasley.
"Now, you two had better listen closely. I do not care what provocation Weasley offered you, I do
not care if he insulted every family member you possess, your behavior was disgusting and I
am giving each of you a week’s worth of detentions! Do not look at me like that, Weasley, you
deserve it! And if either of you ever -"
"Hem, hem."
Professor Weasley closed her eyes as though praying for patience as she turned her face
towards Professor Weasley again.
"Yes?"
"I think they deserve rather more than detentions," said Weasley, smiling still more broadly.
Professor Weasley’s eyes flew open.
"But unfortunately" she said, with an attempt at a reciprocal smile that made her look as though
she had lockjaw, "it is what I think that counts, as they are in my House, Ron."
"Well, actually, Ron," simpered Professor Weasley, "I think you’ll find that what I
think does count. Now, where is it? Ron just sent it... I mean," she gave a false little laugh
as she rummaged in her handbag, "the Minister just sent it... ah yes..."
She had pulled out a piece of parchment which she now unfurled, clearing her throat fussily
before starting to read what it said.
"Hem, hem... ‘Educational Decree Number Twenty-five’."
"Not another one!" exclaimed Professor Weasley violently.
"Well, yes," said Weasley, still smiling. "As a matter of fact, Ron, it was you who made me see that we needed a further amendment... you remember how you overrode me, when I was
unwilling to allow the Weasley Quidditch team to re-form? How you took the case to
Weasley, who insisted that the team be allowed to play? Well, now, I couldn’t have that. I
contacted the Minister at once, and he quite agreed with me that the High Inquisitor has to have
the power to strip pupils of privileges, or she - that is to say, I - would have less authority than
common teachers! And you see now, don’t you, Ron, how right I was in attempting to stop
the Weasley team re-forming? Dreadful tempers... anyway, I was reading out our
amendment... hem, hem... ‘High Inquisitor will henceforth have supreme authority over all
punishments, sanctions and removal of privileges pertaining to the students of Hogwarts, and the
power to alter such punishments, sanctions and removals of privileges as may have been ordered
by other staff members. Signed, Ron Weasley, Minister for Magic, Order of Merlin First
Class, etc., etc.’"
She rolled up the parchment and put it back into her handbag, still smiling.
"So... I really think I will have to ban these two from playing Quidditch ever again," she said,
looking from Ron to Ron and back again.
Ron felt the Snitch fluttering madly in his hand.
"Ban us?" he said, and his voice sounded strangely distant. "From playing... ever again?"
"Yes, Mr. Weasley, I think a lifelong ban ought to do the trick," said Weasley, her smile widening
still further as she watched him struggle to comprehend what she had said. "You and Mr. Weasley here. And I think, to be safe, this young man’s twin ought to be stopped, too - if his teammates had not restrained him, I feel sure he would have attacked young Mr. Weasley as well. I will want their broomsticks confiscated, of course; I shall keep them safely in my office, to make sure there is no infringement of my ban. But I am not unreasonable, Professor Weasley," she continued, turning back to Professor Weasley who was now standing as still as though carved from ice, staring at her. "The rest of the team can continue playing, I saw no signs of violence from any of them. Well... good afternoon to you."
And with a look of the utmost satisfaction, Weasley left the room, leaving a horrified silence in
her wake.
"Banned," said Ron in a hollow voice, late that evening in the common room. "Banned. No
Seeker and no Beaters... what on earth are we going to do?"
It did not feel as though they had won the match at all. Everywhere Ron looked there were
disconsolate and angry faces; the team themselves were slumped around the fire, all apart from
Ron, who had not been seen since the end of the match.
"It’s just so unfair," said Ron numbly. "I mean, what about Weasley and that Bludger he hit after the whistle had been blown? Has she banned him?"
"No," said Ron miserably; she and Ron were sitting on either side of Ron. "He just got
lines, I heard Weasley laughing about it at dinner."
"And banning Ron when he didn’t even do anything!" said Ron furiously, pummeling her
knee with her fist.
"It’s not my fault I didn’t," said Ron, with a very ugly look on his face, "I would’ve pounded the
little scumbag to a pulp if you three hadn’t been holding me back."
Ron stared miserably at the dark window. Snow was falling. The Snitch he had caught earlier
was now zooming around and around the common room; people were watching its progress as
though hypnotized and Ron was leaping from chair to chair, trying to catch it.
"I’m going to bed," said Ron, getting slowly t o her feet. "Maybe this will all turn out to have been a bad dream... maybe I’ll wake up tomorrow and find we haven’t played yet..."
She was soon followed by Ron and Ron. Ron and Ron sloped off to bed some time later,
glowering at everyone they passed, and Ron went not long after that. Only Ron and
Ron were left beside the fire.
"Have you seen Ron?" Ron asked in a low voice.
Ron shook his head.
"I think he’s avoiding us," said Ron. "Where d o you think he -?"
But at that precise moment, there was a creaking sound behind them as the Ron Weasley swung
forwards and Ron came clambering through the portrait hole. He was very pale indeed and there
was snow in his hair. When he saw Ron and Ron, he stopped dead in his tracks.
"Where have you been?" said Ron anxiously, springing up.
"Walking," Ron mumbled. He was still wearing his Quidditch things.
"You look frozen," said Ron. "Come and sit down!"
Ron walked to the fireside and sank into the chair furthest from Ron’s, not looking at him. The
stolen Snitch zoomed over their heads.
"I’m sorry," Ron mumbled, looking at his feet.
"What for?" said Ron.
"For thinking I can play Quidditch," said Ron. "I’m going to resign first thing tomorrow."
"If you resign," said Ron testily, "there’ll only be three players left on the team." And when Ron looked puzzled, he said, "I’ve been given a lifetime ban. So’ve Ron and Ron."
"What?" Ron yelped.
Ron told him the full story; Ron could not bear to tell it again. When she had finished,
Ron looked more anguished than ever.
"This is all my fault -"
"You didn’t make me punch Weasley," said Ron angrily.
"- if I wasn’t so terrible at Quidditch -"
"- it’s got nothing to do with that."
"- it was that song that wound me up -"
"- it would’ve wound anyone up."
Ron got up and walked to the window, away from the argument, watching the snow
swirling down against the pane.
"Look, drop it, will you!" Ron burst out. "It’s bad enough, without you blaming yourself for
everything!"
Ron said nothing but sat gazing miserably at the damp hem of his robes. After a while he said in
a dull voice, "This is the worst I’ve ever felt in my life."
"Join the club," said Ron bitterly.
"Well," said Ron, her voice trembling slightly. "I can think of one thing that might cheer
you both up."
"Oh yeah?" said Ron skeptically.
"Yeah," said Ron, turning away from the pitch-black, snow-flecked window, a broad smile
spreading across her face. "Weasleys back."
CHAPTER TWENTY
Weasley’s Tale
Ron sprinted up to the boys’ dormitories to fetch the Invisibility Cloak and the Marauder’s
Map from his trunk; he was so quick that he and Ron were ready to leave at least five minutes
before Ron hurried back down from the girls’ dormitories, wearing scarf, gloves and one of
her own knobbly elf hats.
"Well, it’s cold out there!" she said defensively, as Ron clicked his tongue impatiently.
They crept through the portrait hole and covered themselves hastily in the Cloak - Ron had
grown so much he now needed to crouch to prevent his feet showing - then, moving slowly and
cautiously, they proceeded down the many staircases, pausing at intervals to check on the map
for signs of Weasley or Mrs. Norris. They were lucky; they saw nobody but Nearly Headless Ron,
who was gliding along absent-mindedly humming something that sounded horribly like
Weasley is our King. They crept across the Entrance Hall and out into the silent, snowy
grounds. With a great leap of his heart, Ron saw little golden squares of light ahead and smoke
coiling up from Weasley’s chimney. He set off at a quick march, the other two jostling and
bumping along behind him. They crunched excitedly through the thickening snow until at last
they reached the wooden front door. When Ron raised his fist and knocked three times, a dog
started barking frantically inside.
"Weasley, its us!" Ron called through the keyhole.
"Shoulda known!" said a gruff voice.
They beamed at each other under the Cloak; they could tell by Weasley’s voice that he was
pleased. "Bin home three seconds... out the way, Ron... out the way, yeh dozy dog..."
The bolt was drawn back, the door creaked open and Weasley’s head appeared in the gap.
Ron screamed.
"Merlin’s beard, keep it down!" said Weasley hastily, staring wildly over their heads. "Under that
Cloak, are yeh? Well, get in, get in!"
"I’m sorry!" Ron gasped, as the three of them squeezed past Weasley into the house and
pulled the Cloak off themselves so he could see them. "I just - oh, Weasley!"
"It’s nuthin’, it’s nuthin’!" said Weasley hastily, shutting the door behind them and hurrying to
close all the curtains, but Ron continued to gaze up at him in horror.
Weasley’s hair was matted with congealed blood and his left eye had been reduced to a puffy slit
amid a mass of purple and black bruising. There were many cuts on his face and hands, some of
them still bleeding, and he was moving gingerly, which made Ron suspect broken ribs. It was
obvious that he had only just got home; a thick black traveling cloak lay over the back of a chair
and a haversack large enough to carry several small children leaned against the wall inside the
door. Weasley himself, twice the size of a normal man, was now limping over to the fire and
placing a copper kettle over it.
"What happened to you?" Ron demanded, while Ron danced around them all, trying to lick
their faces.
"Told yeh, nuthin’," said Weasley firmly. "Want a cuppa?"
"Come off it," said Ron, "you’re in a right state!"
"I’m tellin’ yeh, I’m fine," said Weasley, straightening up and turning to beam at them all, but
wincing. "Blimey, it’s good ter see yeh three again - had good summers, did yeh?"
"Weasley, you’ve been attacked!" said Ron.
"Fer the las’ time, it’s nuthin’!" said Weasley firmly.
"Would you say it was nothing if one of us turned up with a pound of mince instead of a face?"
Ron demanded.
"You ought to go and see Ron Weasley, Weasley," said Ron anxiously, "some of those
cuts look nasty."
"I’m dealin’ with it, all righ’?" said Weasley repressively.
He walked across to the enormous wooden table that stood in the middle of his cabin and
twitched aside a tea towel that had been lying on it. Underneath was a raw, bloody, green-tinged
steak slightly larger than the average car tire.
"You’re not going to eat that, are you, Weasley?" said Ron, leaning in for a closer look. "It looks
poisonous."
"It’s s’posed ter look like that, it’s dragon meat," Weasley said. "An’ I didn’ get it ter eat."
He picked up the steak and slapped it over the left side of his face. Greenish blood trickled down
into his beard as he gave a soft moan of satisfaction.
"Tha’s better. It helps with the stingin’, yeh know."
"So, are you going to tell us what’s happened to you?" Ron asked.
"Can’t, Ron. Top secret. More’n me job’s worth ter tell yeh that."
"Did the giants beat you up, Weasley?" asked Ron quietly.
Weasley’s fingers slipped on the dragon steak and it slid squelchily on to his chest.
"Giants?" said Weasley, catching the steak before it reached his belt and slapping it back over his
face, "who said anythin’ abou’ giants? Who yeh bin talkin’ to? Who’s told yeh what I’ve - who’s
said I’ve bin - eh?"
"We guessed," said Ron apologetically.
"Oh, yeh did, did yeh?" said Weasley, surveying her sternly with the eye that was not hidden by
the steak.
"It was kind of... obvious," said Ron. Ron nodded.
Weasley glared at them, then snorted, threw the steak back on to the table and strode over to the
kettle, which was now whistling.
"Never known kids like you three fer knowin’ more’n yeh oughta," he muttered, splashing
boiling water into three of his bucket-shaped mugs. "An’ I’m not complimentin’ yeh, neither.
Nosy, some’d call it. Interferin’."
But his beard twitched.
"So you have been to look for giants?" said Ron, grinning as he sat down at the table.
Weasley set tea in front of each of them, sat down, picked up his steak again and slapped it back
over his face.
"Yeah, all righ’," he grunted, "I have."
"And you found them?" said Ron in a hushed voice.
"Well, they’re not that difficult ter find, ter be honest," said Weasley. "Pretty big, see."
"Where are they?" said Ron.
"Mountains," said Weasley unhelpfully.
"So why don’t Muggles -?"
"They do," said Weasley darkly. "On’y their deaths are always put down ter mountaineerin’
accidents, aren’ they?"
He adjusted the steak a little so that it covered the worst of the bruising.
"Come on, Weasley, tell us what you’ve been up to!" said Ron. "Tell us about being attacked by the giants and Ron can tell you about being attacked by the Dementors -"
Weasley choked in his mug and dropped his steak at the same time; a large quantity of spit, tea and
dragon blood was sprayed over the table as Weasley coughed and spluttered and the steak slid,
with a soft splat, on to the floor.
"Whadda yeh mean, attacked by Dementors?" growled Weasley.
"Didn’t you know?" Ron asked him, wide-eyed.
"I don’ know anythin’ that’s bin happenin’ since I left. I was on a secret mission, wasn’ I, didn’
wan’ owls followin’ me all over the place - ruddy Dementors! Yeh’re not serious?"
"Yeah, I am, they turned up in Little Whinging and attacked my cousin and me, and then the
Ministry of Magic expelled me -"
"WHAT?"
"- and I had to go to a hearing and everything, but tell us about the giants first."
"You were expelled!"
"Tell us about your summer and I’ll tell you about mine."
Weasley glared at him through his one open eye. Ron looked right back, an expression of
innocent determination on his face.
"Oh, all righ’," Weasley said in a resigned voice.
He bent down and tugged the dragon steak out of Ron’s mouth.
"Oh, Weasley, don’t, it’s not hygien--" Ron began, but Weasley had already slapped the meat
back over his swollen eye.
He took another fortifying gulp of tea, then said, "Well, we set off righ’ after term ended -"
"Rone Weasley went with you, then?" Ron interjected.
"Yeah, tha’s righ’," said Weasley, and a softened expression appeared on the few inches of face
that were not obscured by beard or green steak. "Yeah, it was jus’ the pair of us. An’ I’ll tell yeh
this, she’s not afraid of roughin’ it, Ron. Yeh know, she’s a fine, well-dressed woman, an’
knowin’ where we was goin’ I wondered ‘ow she’d feel abou’ clamberin’ over boulders an’
sleepin’ in caves an’ tha’, bu’ she never complained once."
"You knew where you were going?" Ron repeated. "You knew where the giants were?"
"Well, Weasley knew, an’ he told us," said Weasley.
"Are they hidden?" asked Ron. "Is it a secret, where they are?"
"Not really" said Weasley, shaking his shaggy head. "It’s jus’ that mos’ wizards aren’ bothered
where they are,’s long as it’s a good long way away. But where they are’s very difficult ter get
ter, fer humans anyway, so we needed Weasley’s instructions. Took us abou’ a month ter get
there -"
"A month?" said Ron, as though he had never heard o f a journey lasting such a ridiculously long
time. "But - why couldn’t you just grab a Portkey or something?"
There was an odd expression in Weasley’s unobscured eye as he surveyed Ron; it was almost
pitying.
"We’re bein’ watched, Ron," he said gruffly.
"What d’you mean?"
"Yeh don’ understand," said Weasley. "The Ministry’s keepin’ an eye on Weasley an’ anyone
they reckon’s in league with ‘im, an’ -"
"We know about that," said Ron quickly keen to hear the rest of Weasley’s story, "we know
about the Ministry watching Weasley -"
"So you couldn’t use magic to get there?" asked Ron, looking thunderstruck, "you had to act like
Muggles all the way?"
"Well, not exactly all the way" said Weasley cagily. "We jus’ had ter be careful, ‘cause Ron an’ me, we stick out a bit --"
Ron made a stifled noise somewhere between a snort and a sniff and hastily took a gulp of tea.
"- so we’re not hard ter follow. We was pretendin’ we was goin’ on holiday together, so we got
inter France an’ we made like we was headin’ fer where Rons school is, ‘cause we knew we
was bein’ tailed by someone from the Ministry. We had to go slow, ‘cause I’m not really s’posed
ter use magic an’ we knew the Ministry’d be lookin’ fer a reason ter run us in. But we managed
ter give the berk tailin’ us the slip round abou’ Dee-Ron --"
"Ooooh, Dijon?" said Ron excitedly. "I’ve been there on holiday, did you see -?"
She fell silent at the look on Ron’s face.
"We chanced a bit o’ magic after that an’ it wasn’ a bad journey. Ran inter a couple o’ mad trolls
on the Polish border an’ I had a sligh’ disagreement with a vampire in a pub in Minsk, bu’ apart
from tha’ couldn’t’a bin smoother.
"An’ then we reached the place, an’ we started trekkin’ up through the mountains, lookin’ fer
signs of ‘em...
"We had ter lay off the magic once we got near ‘em. Partly ‘cause they don’ like wizards an’ we
didn’ want ter put their backs up too soon, an’ partly ‘cause Weasley had warned us You-
Know-Who was bound ter be after the giants an’ all. Said it was odds on he’d sent a messenger
off ter them already. Told us ter be very careful of drawin’ attention ter ourselves as we got
nearer in case there was Death Eaters around."
Weasley paused for a long draught of tea.
"Go on!" said Ron urgently.
"Found ‘em," said Weasley baldly. "Went over a ridge one nigh’ an’ there they was, spread ou’
underneath us. Little fires burnin’ below an’ huge shadows... it was like watchin’ bits o’ the
mountain movin’."
"How big are they?" asked Ron in a hushed voice.
"Bout twenty feet," said Weasley casually. "Some o’ the bigger ones mighta bin twenty-five."
"And how many were there?" asked Ron.
"I reckon abou’ seventy or eighty," said Weasley.
"Is that all?" said Ron.
"Yep," said Weasley sadly, "eighty left, an’ there was loads once, musta bin a hundred diff’rent
tribes from all over the world. Bu’ they’ve bin dyin’ out fer ages. Wizards killed a few, o’
course, bu’ mostly they killed each other, an’ now they’re dyin’ out faster than ever. They’re not
made ter live bunched up together like tha’. Weasley says it’s our fault, it was the wizards
who forced ‘em to go an’ made ‘em live a good long way from us an’ they had no choice bu’ ter
stick together fer their own protection."
"So," said Ron, "you saw them and then what?"
"Well, we waited till morning, didn’ want ter go sneakin’ up on ‘em in the dark, fer our own
safety," said Weasley. "Bout three in the mornin’ they fell asleep jus’ where they was sittin’. We
didn’ dare sleep. Fer one thing, we wanted ter make sure none of ‘em woke up an’ came up
where we were, an’ fer another, the snorin’ was unbelievable. Caused an avalanche near
mornin’.
"Anyway, once it was light we wen’ down ter see ‘em."
"Just like that?" said Ron, looking awestruck. "You just walked right into a giant camp?"
"Well, Weasley’d told us how ter do it," said Weasley. "Give the Gurg gifts, show some
respect, yeh know."
"Give the what gifts?" asked Ron.
"Oh, the Gurg - means the chief."
"How could you tell which one was the Gurg?" asked Ron.
Weasley grunted in amusement.
"No problem," he said. "He was the biggest, the ugliest an’ the laziest. Sittin’ there waitin’ ter be
brought food by the others. Dead goats an’ such like. Name o’ Karkus. I’d put him at twenty-two, twenty-three feet an’ the weight o’ a couple o’ bull elephants. Skin like rhino hide an’ all."
"And you just walked up to him?" said Ron breathlessly.
"Well... down ter him, where he was lyin’ in the valley. They was in this dip between four pretty
high mountains, see, beside a mountain lake, an’ Karkus was lyin’ by the lake roarin’ at the
others ter feed him an’ his wife. Ron an’ I went down the mountainside -"
"But didn’t they try and kill you when they saw you?" asked Ron incredulously.
"It was def’nitely on some o’ their minds," said Ha grid, shrugging, "but we did what Weasley told us ter do, which was ter hold our gift up high an’ keep our eyes on the Gurg an’ ignore the others. So tha’s what we did. An’ the rest of ‘em went quiet an’ watched us pass an’ we got right up ter Karkus’s feet an’ we bowed an’ put our present down in front o’ him."
"What do you give a giant?" asked Ron eagerly. "Food?"
"Nah, he can get food all righ’ fer himself," said Weasley. "We took him magic. Giants like magic, jus’ don’ like us usin’ it against ‘em. Anyway, that firs’ day we gave ‘im a branch o’ Gubraithian fire."
Ron said, "Wow!" softly, but Ron and Ron both frowned in puzzlement.
"A branch of -?"
"Everlasting fire," said Ron irritably, "you ought to know that by now. Professor Weasley’s
mentioned it at least twice in class!"
"Well, anyway," said Weasley quickly, intervening before Ron could answer back, "Weasley’d bewitched this branch to burn fer evermore, which isn’ somethin’ any wizard could do, an’ so I lies it down in the snow by Karkus’s feet and says, ‘A gift to the Gurg of the giants from Ron Weasley, who sends his respectful greetings.’"
"And what did Karkus say?" asked Ron eagerly.
"Nothin’," said Weasley. "Didn’ speak English."
"You’re kidding!"
"Didn’ matter," said Weasley imperturbably, "Weasley had warned us tha’ migh’ happen.
Karkus knew enough to yell fer a couple o’ giants who knew our lingo an’ they translated fer us."
"And did he like the present?" asked Ron.
"Oh yeah, it went down a storm once they understood what it was," said Weasley, turning his
dragon steak over to press the cooler side to his swollen eye. "Very pleased. So then I said,
Weasley asks the Gurg to speak with his messenger when he returns tomorrow with another
gift."
"Why couldn’t you speak to them that day?" asked Ron.
"Weasley wanted us ter take it very slow," said Weasley. "Let ‘em see we kept our
promises. We’ll come back tomorrow with another present, an’ then we do come back with
another present - gives a good impression, see? An’ gives them time ter test out the firs’ present
an’ find out it’s a good one, an’ get ‘em eager fer more. In any case, giants like Karkus -
overload ‘em with information an’ they’ll kill yeh jus’ to simplify things. So we bowed outta the
way an’ went off an’ found ourselves a nice little cave ter spend that night in an’ the followin’
mornin’ we went back an’ this time we found Karkus sittin’ up waitin’ fer us lookin’ all eager."
"And you talked to him?"
"Oh yeah. Firs’ we presented him with a nice battle helmet -goblin-made an’ indestructible, yeh
know - an’ then we sat down an’ we talked."
"What did he say?"
"Not much," said Weasley. "Listened mostly. Bu’ there were good signs. He’d heard o’
Weasley, heard he’d argued against the killin’ o’ the last giants in Britain. Karkus seemed ter
be quite int’rested in what Weasley had ter say. An’ a few o’ the others, ‘specially the ones
who had some English, they gathered round an’ listened too. We were hopeful when we left that
day. Promised ter come back next mornin’ with another present...
"Bu’ that night it all wen’ wrong."
"What d’you mean?" said Ron quickly.
"Well, like I say, they’re not meant ter live together, giants," said Weasley sadly. "Not in big
groups like that. They can’ help themselves, they half kill each other every few weeks. The men
fight each other an’ the women fight each other; the remnants of the old tribes fight each other,
an’ that’s even without squabbles over food an’ the best fires an’ sleepin’ spots. Yeh’d think,
seein’ as how their whole race is abou’ finished, they’d lay off each other, bu’..."
Weasley sighed deeply.
"That night a fight broke out, we saw it from the mouth of our cave, lookin’ down on the valley.
Went on fer hours, yeh wouldn’ believe the noise. An’ when the sun came up the snow was
scarlet an’ his head was lyin’ at the bottom o’ the lake."
"Whose head?" gasped Ron.
"Karkus’s," said Weasley heavily. "There was a new Gurg, Golgomath." He sighed deeply.
"Well, we hadn’ bargained on a new Gurg two days after we’d made friendly contact with the firs’ one, an’ we had a funny feelin’ Golgomath wouldn’ be so keen ter listen to us, bu’ we had ter try."
"You went to speak to him?" asked Ron incredulously. "After you’d watched him rip off another
giant’s head?"
"Course we did," said Weasley, "we hadn’ gone all that way ter give up after two days! We wen’
down with the next present we’d meant ter give ter Karkus.
"I knew it was no go before I’d opened me mouth. He was sitting there wearin’ Karkus’s helmet,
leerin’ at us as we got nearer. He’s massive, one o’ the biggest ones there. Weasley hair an’
matchin’ teeth an’ a necklace o’ bones. Human-lookin’ bones, some of ‘em. Well, I gave it a go -
held out a great roll o’ dragon skin - an’ said, ‘gift fer the Gurg of the giants --’ Nex’ thing I
knew, I was hangin’ upside-down in the air by me feet, two of his mates had grabbed me."
Ron clapped her hands to her mouth.
"How did you get out of that?" asked Ron.
"Wouldn’ta done if Ron hadn’ bin there," said Weasley. "She pulled out her wand an’ did some o’ the fastes’ spellwork I’ve ever seen. Ruddy marvellous. Hit the two holdin’ me right in the eyes with Conjunctivitus Curses an’ they dropped me straightaway - bu’ we were in trouble then, ‘cause we’d used magic against ‘em, an’ that’s what giants hate abou’ wizards. We had ter leg it an’ we knew there was no way we was going ter be able ter march inter the camp again."
"Blimey, Weasley," said Ron quietly.
"So, how come it’s taken you so long to get home if you were only there for three days?" asked
Ron.
"We didn’ leave after three days!" said Weasley, looking outraged. "Weasley was relyin’ on
us!"
"But you’ve just said there was no way you could go back!"
"Not by daylight we couldn’, no. We just had ter rethink a bit. Spent a couple o’ days lyin’ low
up in the cave an’ watchin’. An’ wha’ we saw wasn’ good."
"Did he rip off more heads?" asked Ron, sounding squeamish.
"No," said Weasley, "I wish he had."
"What d’you mean?"
"I mean we soon found out he didn’ object ter all wizards - just us."
"Death Eaters?" said Ron quickly.
"Yep," said Weasley darkly. "Couple of ‘em were visitin’ him ev’ry day, bringin’ gifts ter the
Gurg, an’ he wasn’ dangling them upside-down."
"How d’you know they were Death Eaters?" said Ron.
"Because I recognized one of ‘em," Weasley growled. "Weasley, remember him? Bloke they sent
ter kill Ron? Maniac, he is. Likes killin’ as much as Golgomath; no wonder they were
gettin’ on so well."
