"So Weasleys persuaded the giants to join You-Know-Who?" said Ron desperately.
"Hold yer Hippogriffs, I haven’ finished me story yet!" said Weasley indignantly, who, considering he had not wanted to tell them anything in the first place, now seemed to be rather enjoying himself. "Me an’ Ron talked it over an’ we agreed, jus’ ‘cause the Gurg looked like favorin’ You-Know-Who didn’ mean all of ‘em would. We had ter try an’ persuade some o’ the others, the ones who hadn’ wanted Golgomath as Gurg."
"How could you tell which ones they were?" asked Ron.
"Well, they were the ones bein’ beaten to a pulp, weren’ they?" said Weasley patiently. "The ones
with any sense were keepin’ outta Golgomath’s way, hidin’ out in caves roun’ the gully jus’ like
we were. So we decided we’d go pokin’ round the caves by night an’ see if we couldn’ persuade
a few o’ them."
"You went poking around dark caves looking for giants?" said Ron, with awed respect in his
voice.
"Well, it wasn’ the giants who worried us most," said Weasley. "We were more concerned abou’
the Death Eaters. Weasley had told us before we wen’ not ter tangle with ‘em if we could
avoid it, an’ the trouble was they knew we was around -- ‘spect Golgomath told ‘em abou’ us.
At night, when the giants were sleepin’ an’ we wanted ter be creepin’ inter the caves, Weasley
an’ the other one were sneakin’ round the mountains lookin’ fer us. I was hard put to stop
Ron jumpin’ out at ‘em," said Weasley, the corners of his mouth lifting his wild beard, "she
was rarin’ ter attack ‘em... she’s somethin’ when she’s roused, Ron... fiery, yeh know...
‘spect it’s the French in her..."
Weasley gazed misty-eyed into the fire. Ron allowed him thirty seconds of reminiscence before
clearing his throat loudly.
"So, what happened? Did you ever get near any of the other giants?"
"What? Oh... oh, yeah, we did. Yeah, on the third night after Karkus was killed we crept outta
the cave we’d bin hidin’ in an’ headed back down inter the gully, keepin’ our eyes skinned fer
the Death Eaters. Got inside a few o’ the caves, no go - then, in abou’ the sixth one, we found
three giants hidin’."
"Cave must’ve been cramped," said Ron.
"Wasn’ room ter swing a Kneazle," said Weasley.
"Didn’t they attack you when they saw you?" asked Ron.
"Probably woulda done if they’d bin in any condition," said Weasley, "but they was badly hurt, all
three o’ them; Golgomath’s lot had beaten ‘em unconscious; they’d woken up an’ crawled inter
the nearest shelter they could find. Anyway, one o’ them had a bit of English an’ ‘e translated fer
the others, an’ what we had ter say didn’ seem ter go down too badly. So we kep’ goin’ back,
visitin’ the wounded... I reckon we had abou’ six or seven o’ them convinced at one poin’."
"Six or seven?" said Ron eagerly. "Well that’s not bad - are they going to come over here and
start fighting You-Know-Who with us?"
But Ron said, "What do you mean ‘one point’, Weasley?"
Weasley looked at her sadly.
"Golgomath’s lot raided the caves. The ones tha’ survived didn’ wan’ no more ter to do with us
after that."
"So... so there aren’t any giants coming?" said Ron, looking disappointed.
"Nope," said Weasley, heaving a deep sigh as he turned over his steak and applied the cooler side
to his face, "but we did wha’ we meant ter do, we g ave ‘em Weasley’s message an’ some o’
them heard it an’ I spect some o’ them’ll remember it. Jus’ maybe, them that don’ want ter stay
around Golgomath’ll move outta the mountains, an’ there’s gotta be a chance they’ll remember
Weasley’s friendly to ‘em... could be they’ll come."
Snow was filling up the window now. Ron became aware that the knees of his robes were
soaked through: Ron was drooling with his head in Ron’s lap.
"Weasley?" said Ron quietly after a while.
"Mmm?"
"Did you... was there any sign of... did you hear anything about your... your... mother while
you were there?"
Weasley’s unobscured eye rested upon her and Ron looked rather scared.
"I’m sorry... I... forget it -"
"Dead," Weasley grunted. "Died years ago. They told me."
"Oh... I’m... I’m really sorry" said Ron in a very small voice. Weasley shrugged his massive shoulders.
"No need," he said shortly. "Can’t remember her much. Wasn’ a great mother."
They were silent again. Ron glanced nervously at Ron and Ron, plainly wanting them to
speak.
"But you still haven’t explained how you got in this state, Weasley," Ron said, gesturing towards
Weasley’s bloodstained face.
"Or why you’re back so late," said Ron. "Ron says Rone Weasley got back ages ago -"
"Who attacked you?" said Ron.
"I haven’ bin attacked!" said Weasley emphatically. "I -"
But the rest of his words were drowned in a sudden outbreak of rapping on the door. Ron
gasped; her mug slipped through her fingers and smashed on the floor; Ron yelped. All four of
them stared at the window beside the doorway. The shadow of somebody small and squat rippled
across the thin curtain.
"It’s her!" Ron whispered.
"Get under here!" Ron said quickly; seizing the Invisibility Cloak, he whirled it over himself
and Ron while Ron tore around the table and dived under the Cloak as well. Huddled
together, they backed away into a corner. Ron was barking madly at the door. Weasley looked
thoroughly confused.
"Weasley, hide our mugs!"
Weasley seized Ron and Ron’s mugs and shoved them under the cushion in Ron’s basket. Ron
was now leaping up at the door; Weasley pushed him out of the way with his foot and pulled it
open.
Professor Weasley was standing in the doorway wearing her green tweed cloak and a matching
hat with earflaps. Lips pursed, she leaned back so as to see Weasley’s face; she barely reached his
navel.
"So," she said slowly and loudly, as though speaking to somebody deaf. "You’re Weasley, are
you?"
Without waiting for an answer she strolled into the room, her bulging eyes rolling in every
direction.
"Get away," she snapped, waving her handbag at Ron, who had bounded up to her and was
attempting to lick her face.
"Er - I don’ want ter be rude," said Weasley, staring at her, "but who the ruddy hell are you?"
"My name is Ron Weasley."
Her eyes were sweeping the cabin. Twice they stared directly into the corner where Ron stood,
sandwiched between Ron and Ron.
"Ron Weasley?" Weasley said, sounding thoroughly confused. "I thought you were one o’
them Ministry - don’ you work with Weasley?"
"I was Senior Undersecretary to the Minister, yes," said Weasley, now pacing around the cabin,
taking in every tiny detail within, from the haversack against the wall to the abandoned traveling
cloak. "I am now the Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher -"
"Tha’s brave of yeh," said Weasley, "there’s not many’d take tha’ job any more."
"- and Hogwarts High Inquisitor," said Weasley, giving no sign that she had heard him.
"Wha’s that?" said Weasley, frowning.
"Precisely what I was going to ask," said Weasley, pointing at the broken shards of china on the floor that had been Ron’s mug.
"Oh," said Weasley, with a most unhelpful glance towards the corner where Ron, Ron and
Ron stood hidden, "oh, tha’ was... was Ron. He broke a mug. So I had ter use this one
instead."
Weasley pointed to the mug from which he had been drinking, one hand still clamped over the
dragon steak pressed to his eye. Weasley stood facing him now, taking in every detail of his
appearance instead of the cabin’s.
"I heard voices," she said quietly.
"I was talkin’ ter Ron," said Weasley stoutly.
"And was he talking back to you?"
"Well... in a manner o’ speakin’," said Weasley, looking uncomfortable. "I sometimes say Ron’s
near enough human -"
"There are three sets of footprints in the snow leading from the castle doors to your cabin," said
Weasley sleekly.
Ron gasped; Ron clapped a hand over her mouth. Luckily, Ron was sniffing loudly
around the hem of Professor Weasley’s robes and she did not appear to have heard.
"Well, I on’y jus’ got back," said Weasley, waving an enormous hand at the haversack. "Maybe
someone came ter call earlier an’ I missed ‘em."
"There are no footsteps leading away from your cabin door."
"Well, I... I don’ know why that’d be..." said Weasley, tugging nervously at his beard and again
glancing towards the corner where Ron, Ron and Ron stood, as though asking for help.
"Erm..."
Weasley wheeled round and strode the length of the cabin, looking around carefully. She bent
and peered under the bed. She opened Weasley’s cupboards. She passed within two inches of
where Ron, Ron and Ron stood pressed against the wall; Ron actually pulled in his
stomach as she walked by. After looking carefully inside the enormous cauldron Weasley used for
cooking, she wheeled round again and said, "What has happened to you? How did you sustain
those injuries?"
Weasley hastily removed the dragon steak from his face, which in Rons opinion was a mistake,
because the black and purple bruising all around his eye was now clearly visible, not to mention
the large amount of fresh and congealed blood on his face. "Oh, I... had a bit of an accident," he
said lamely.
"What sort of accident?"
"I - I tripped."
"You tripped," she repeated coolly.
"Yeah, tha’s right. Over... over a friend’s broomstick. I don’ fly, meself. Well, look at the size o’
me, I don’ reckon there’s a broomstick that’d hold me. Friend o’ mine breeds Abraxan horses, I
dunno if you’ve ever seen ‘em, big beasts, winged, yeh know, I’ve had a bit of a ride on one o’
them an’ it was -"
"Where have you been?" asked Weasley, cutting coolly through Weasley’s babbling.
"Where’ve I -?"
"Been, yes," she said. "Term started two months ago. Another teacher has had to cover your
classes. None of your colleagues has been able to give me any information as to your
whereabouts. You left no address. Where have you been?"
There was a pause in which Weasley stared at her with his newly uncovered eye. Ron could
almost hear his brain working furiously.
"I - I’ve been away for me health," he said.
"For your health," repeated Professor Weasley. Her eyes traveled over Weasley’s discolored
and swollen face; dragon blood dripped gently and silently on to his waistcoat. "I see."
"Yeah," said Weasley, "bit o’ - o’ fresh air, yeh know -"
"Yes, as gamekeeper fresh air must be so difficult to come by," said Weasley sweetly. The
small patch of Weasley’s face that was not black or purple, flushed.
"Well -- change o’ scene, yeh know -"
"Mountain scenery?" said Weasley swiftly.
She knows, Ron thought desperately.
"Mountains?" Weasley repeated, clearly thinking fast. "Nope, South o’ France fer me. Bit o’ sun
an’... an’ sea."
"Really?" said Weasley. "You don’t have much of a tan."
"Yeah... well... sensitive skin," said Weasley, attempting an ingratiating smile. Ron noticed that
two of his teeth had been knocked out. Weasley looked at him coldly; his smile faltered. Then
she hoisted her handbag a little higher into the crook of her arm and said, "I shall, of course, be
informing the Minister of your late return."
"Righ’," said Weasley, nodding.
"You ought to know, too, that as High Inquisitor it is my unfortunate but necessary duty to
inspect my fellow teachers. So I daresay we shall meet again soon enough."
She turned sharply and marched back to the door.
"You’re inspectin’ us?" Weasley repeated blankly, looking after her.
"Oh, yes," said Weasley softly, looking back at him with her hand on the door handle. "The
Ministry is determined to weed out unsatisfactory teachers, Weasley. Goodnight."
She left, closing the door behind her with a snap. Ron made to pull off the Invisibility Cloak
but Ron seized his wrist.
"Not yet," she breathed in his ear. "She might not be gone yet."
Weasley seemed to be thinking the same way; he stumped across the room and pulled back the
curtain an inch or so.
"She’s goin’ back ter the castle," he said in a low voice. "Blimey... inspectin’ people, is she?"
"Yeah," said Ron, pulling off the Cloak. "Weasley’s on probation already..."
"Um... what sort of thing are you planning to do with us in class, Weasley?" asked Ron.
"Oh, don’ you worry abou’ that, I’ve got a great load o’ lessons planned," said Weasley
enthusiastically, scooping up his dragon steak from the table and slapping it over his eye again.
"I’ve bin keepin’ a couple o’ creatures saved fer yer OWL year; you wait, they’re somethin’
really special."
"Erm... special in what way?" asked Ron tentatively.
"I’m not sayin’," said Weasley happily. "I don’ wan t ter spoil the surprise."
"Look, Weasley," said Ron urgently, dropping all pretence, "Professor Weasley won’t be at all happy if you bring anything to class that’s too dangerous."
"Dangerous?" said Weasley, looking genially bemused. "Don’ be silly, I wouldn’ give yeh anythin’ dangerous! I mean, all righ’, they can look after themselves -"
"Weasley, you’ve got to pass Weasley’s inspection, and to do that it would really be better if she
saw you teaching us how to look after Porlocks, how to tell the difference between Knarls and
hedgehogs, stuff like that!" said Ron earnestly.
"But tha’s not very interestin’, Ron," said Weasley. "The stuff I’ve got’s much more
impressive. I’ve bin bringin’ ‘em on fer years, I reckon I’ve got the on’y domestic herd in
Britain."
"Weasley... please..." said Ron, a note of real desperation in her voice. "Weasley is looking for any excuse to get rid of teachers she thinks are too close to Weasley. Please, Weasley, teach us something dull that’s bound to come up in our OWL."
But Weasley merely yawned widely and cast a one-eyed look of longing towards the vast bed in
the corner.
"Lis’en, it’s bin a long day an’ it’s late," he said, patting Ron gently on the shoulder, so that her knees gave way and hit the floor with a thud. "Oh - sorry -" He pulled her back up by the
neck of her robes. "Look, don’ you go worryin’ abou’ me, I promise yeh I’ve got really good
stuff planned fer yer lessons now I’m back... now you lot had better get back up to the castle, an’
don’ forget ter wipe yer footprints out behind yeh!"
"I dunno if you got through to him," said Ron a sho rt while later when, having checked that the
coast was clear, they walked back up to the castle through the thickening snow, leaving no trace
behind them due to the Obliteration Charm Ron was performing as they went.
"Then I’ll go back again tomorrow," said Ron determinedly. "I’ll plan his lessons for him if I have to. I don’t care if she throws out Weasley but she’s not getting rid of Weasley!"
CHAPTER TWENTY-ONE
The Eye of the Snake
Ron ploughed her way back to Weasley’s cabin through two feet of snow on Sunday
morning. Ron and Ron wanted to go with her, but their mountain of homework had reached an
alarming height again, so they remained grudgingly in the common room, trying to ignore the
gleeful shouts drifting up from the grounds outside, where students were enjoying themselves
skating on the frozen lake, tobogganing and, worst of all, bewitching snowballs to zoom up to
Weasley Tower and rap hard on the windows.
"Oy!" bellowed Ron, finally losing patience and sticking his head out of the window, "I am a
prefect and if one more snowball hits this window - OUCH!"
He withdrew his head sharply, his face covered in snow.
"It’s Ron and Ron," he said bitterly, slamming the window behind him. "Gits..."
Ron returned from Weasley’s just before lunch, shivering slightly, her robes damp to the
knees.
"So?" said Ron, looking up when she entered. "Got all his lessons planned for him?"
"Well, I tried," she said dully, sinking into a chair beside Ron. She pulled out her wand and
gave it a complicated little wave so that hot air streamed out of the tip; she then pointed this at
her robes, which began to steam as they dried out. "He wasn’t even there when I arrived, I was
knocking for at least half an hour. And then he came stumping out of the Forest -"
Ron groaned. The Forbidden Forest was teeming with the kind of creatures most likely to get
Weasley the sack. "What’s he keeping in there? Did he say?" he asked.
"No," said Ron miserably. "He says he wants them to be a surprise. I tried to explain about
Weasley, but he just doesn’t get it. He kept saying nobody in their right mind would rather
study Knarls than Chimaeras - oh, I don’t think he’s got a Chimaera," she added at the appalled
look on Ron and Ron’s faces, "but that’s not for lack of trying, from what he said about how
hard it is to get eggs. I don’t know how many times I told him he’d be better off following
Weasley’s plan, I honestly don’t think he listened to half of what I said. He’s in a bit of a
funny mood, you know. He still won’t say how he got all those injuries."
Weasley’s reappearance at the staff table at breakfast next day was not greeted by enthusiasm from
all students. Some, like Ron, Ron and Ron, roared with delight and sprinted up the aisle
between the Weasley and Weasley tables to wring Weasley’s enormous hand; others, like
Ron and Ron, exchanged gloomy looks and shook their heads. Ron knew that many of
them preferred Professor Weasley’s lessons, and the worst of it was that a very small,
unbiased part of him knew that they had good reason: Weasley’s idea of an interesting
class was not one where there was a risk that somebody might have their head ripped off.
It was with a certain amount of apprehension that Ron, Ron and Ron headed down to
Weasley’s on Tuesday, heavily muffled against the cold. Ron was worried, not only about what
Weasley might have decided to teach them, but also about how the rest of the class, particularly
Weasley and his cronies, would behave if Weasley was watching them.
However, the High Inquisitor was nowhere to be seen as they struggled through the snow
towards Weasley, who stood waiting for them on the edge of the Forest. He did not present a
reassuring sight; the bruises that had been purple on Saturday night were now tinged with green
and yellow and some of his cuts still seemed to be bleeding. Ron could not understand this: had
Weasley perhaps been attacked by some creature whose venom prevented the wounds it inflicted
from healing? As though to complete the ominous picture, Weasley was carrying what looked like
half a dead cow over his shoulder.
"We’re workin’ in here today!" Weasley called happily to the approaching students, jerking his
head back at the dark trees behind him. "Bit more sheltered! Anyway, they prefer the dark."
"What prefers the dark?" Ron heard Weasley say sharply to Weasley and Weasley, a trace of panic
in his voice. "What did he say prefers the dark - did you hear?"
Ron remembered the only other occasion on which Weasley had entered the Forest before now;
he had not been very brave then, either. He smiled to himself; after the Quidditch match anything
that caused Weasley discomfort was all right with him.
"Ready?" said Weasley cheerfully, looking around at the class. "Right, well, I’ve bin savin’ a trip
inter the Forest fer yer fifth year. Thought we’d go an’ see these creatures in their natural habitat.
Now, what we’re studyin’ today is pretty rare, I reckon I’m probably the on’y person in Britain
who’s managed ter train ‘em."
"And you’re sure they’re trained, are you?" said Weasley, the panic in his voice even more
pronounced. "Only it wouldn’t be the first time you’d brought wild stuff to class, would it?"
The Weasleys murmured agreement and a few Weasleys looked as though they thought
Weasley had a fair point, too.
"Course they’re trained," said Weasley, scowling and hoisting the dead cow a little higher on his
shoulder.
"So what happened to your face, then?" demanded Weasley.
"Mind yer own business!" said Weasley, angrily. "Now, if yeh’ve finished askin’ stupid questions,
follow me!"
He turned and strode straight into the Forest. Nobody seemed much disposed to follow. Ron
glanced at Ron and Ron, who sighed but nodded, and the three of them set off after Weasley,
leading the rest of the class.
They walked for about ten minutes until they reached a place where the trees stood so closely
together that it was as dark as twilight and there was no snow at all on the ground. With a grunt,
Weasley deposited his half a cow on the ground, stepped back and turned to face his class, most of
whom were creeping from tree to tree towards him, peering around nervously as though
expecting to be set upon at any moment.
"Gather roun’, gather roun’," Weasley encouraged. "Now, they’ll be attracted by the smell o’ the
meat but I’m goin’ ter give ‘em a call anyway, ‘cause they’ll like ter know it’s me."
He turned, shook his shaggy head to get the hair out of his face and gave an odd, shrieking cry
that echoed through the dark trees like the call of some monstrous bird. Nobody laughed: most of
them looked too scared to make a sound.
Weasley gave the shrieking cry again. A minute passed in which the class continued to peer
nervously over their shoulders and around trees for a first glimpse of whatever it was that was
coming. And then, as Weasley shook his hair back for a third time and expanded his enormous
chest, Ron nudged Ron and pointed into the black space between two gnarled yew trees.
A pair of blank, white, shining eyes were growing larger through the gloom and a moment later
the dragonish face, neck and then skeletal body of a great, black, winged horse emerged from the
darkness. It surveyed the class for a few seconds, swishing its long black tail, then bowed its
head and began to tear flesh from the dead cow with its pointed fangs.
A great wave of relief broke over Ron. Here at last was proof that he had not imagined these
creatures, that they were real: Weasley knew about them too. He looked eagerly at Ron, but Ron
was still staring around into the trees and after a few seconds he whispered, "Why doesn’t Weasley call again?"
Most of the rest of the class were wearing expressions as confused and nervously expectant as
Ron’s and were still gazing everywhere but at the horse standing feet from them. There were
only two other people who seemed to be able to see them: a stringy Weasley boy standing just
behind Weasley was watching the horse eating with an expression of great distaste on his face; and
Ron, whose eyes were following the swishing progress of the long black tail.
"Oh, an’ here comes another one!" said Weasley proudly, as a second black horse appeared out of
the dark trees, folded its leathery wings closer to its body and dipped its head to gorge on the
meat. "Now... put yer hands up, who can see ‘em?"
Immensely pleased to feel that he was at last going to understand the mystery of these horses,
Ron raised his hand. Weasley nodded at him.
"Yeah... yeah, I knew you’d be able ter, Ron," he said seriously. "An’ you too, Ron, eh? An’ -"
"Excuse me," said Weasley in a sneering voice, "but what exactly are we supposed to be seeing?"
For an answer, Weasley pointed at the cow carcass on the ground. The whole class stared at it for a
few seconds, then several people gasped and Ron squealed. Ron understood why: bits of
flesh stripping themselves away from the bones and vanishing into thin air had to look very odd
indeed.
"What’s doing it?" Ron demanded in a terrified voice, retreating behind the nearest tree.
"What’s eating it?"
"Thestrals," said Weasley proudly and Ron gave a soft "Oh!" of comprehension at Ron’s
shoulder. "Hogwarts has got a whole herd of ‘em in here. Now, who knows -?"
"But they’re really, really unlucky!" interrupted Ron, looking alarmed. "They’re supposed to
bring all sorts of horrible misfortune on people who see them. Professor Weasley told me once
-"
"No, no, no," said Weasley, chuckling, "tha’s jus’ superstition, that is, they aren’ unlucky, they’re
dead clever an’ useful! Course, this lot don’ get a lot o’ work, it’s mainly jus’ pullin’ the school
carriages unless Weasley’s takin’ a long journey an’ don’ want ter Apparate - an’ here’s
another couple, look -"
Two more horses came quietly out of the trees, one of them passing very close to Ron, who
shivered and pressed herself closer to the tree, saying, "I think I felt something, I think it’s near
me!"
"Don’ worry, it won’ hurt yen," said Weasley patiently. "Righ’, now, who can tell me why some o’ yeh can see ‘em an’ some can’t?"
Ron raised her hand.
"Go on then," said Weasley, beaming at her.
"The only people who can see Thestrals," she said, "are people who have seen death."
"Tha’s exactly right," said Weasley solemnly, "ten points ter Weasley. Now, Thestrals -"
"Hem, hem."
Professor Weasley had arrived. She was standing a few feet away from Ron, wearing her
green hat and cloak again, her clipboard at the ready. Weasley, who had never heard Weasley’s
fake cough before, was gazing in some concern at the closest Thestral, evidently under the
impression that it had made the sound.
"Hem, hem."
"Oh, hello!" Weasley said, smiling, having located the source of the noise.
"You received the note I sent to your cabin this morning?" said Weasley, in the same loud, slow voice she had used with him earlier, as though she were addressing somebody both foreign and very slow. "Telling you that I would be inspecting y our lesson?"
"Oh, yeah," said Weasley brightly. "Glad yeh found the place all righ’! Well, as you can see - or, I
dunno - can you? We’re doin’ Thestrals today -"
"I’m sorry?" said Professor Weasley loudly, cupping her hand around her ear and frowning.
"What did you say?"
Weasley looked a little confused.
"Er - Thestrals!" he said loudly. "Big - er - winged horses, yeh know!"
He flapped his gigantic arms hopefully. Professor Weasley raised her eyebrows at him and
muttered as she made a note on her clipboard: "Has... to... resort... to... crude...
sign... language."
"Well... anyway..." said Weasley, turning back to the class and looking slightly flustered, "erm...
what was I sayin’?"
"Appears... to... have... poor... short... term... memory," muttered Weasley, loudly enough
for everyone to hear her. Ron Weasley looked as though Christmas had come a month early;
Ron, on the other hand, had turned scarlet with suppressed rage.
"Oh, yeah," said Weasley, throwing an uneasy glance at Weasley’s clipboard, but ploughing on
valiantly. "Yeah, I was gonna tell yeh how come we got a herd. Yeah, so, we started off with a
male an’ five females. This one," he patted the fir st horse to have appeared, "name o’ Tenebrus,
he’s my special favorite, firs’ one born here in the Forest -"
"Are you aware," Weasley said loudly, interrupting him, "that the Ministry of Magic has
classified Thestrals as ‘dangerous’?"
Ron’s heart sank like a stone, but Weasley merely chuckled.
"Thestrals aren’ dangerous! All righ’, they might take a bite outta yeh if yeh really annoy them -"
"Shows... signs... of... pleasure... at... idea... of... violence," muttered Weasley, scribbling
on her clipboard again.
"No - come on!" said Weasley, looking a little anxious now. "I mean, a dog’ll bite if yeh bait it,
won’ it - but Thestrals have jus’ got a bad reputation because o’ the death thing - people used ter
think they were bad omens, didn’ they? Jus’ didn’ understand, did they?"
Weasley did not answer; she finished writing her last note, then looked up at Weasley and said,
again very loudly and slowly, "Please continue teaching as usual. I am going to walk," she
mimed walking (Weasley and Ron Weasley were having silent fits of laughter) "among the
students" (she pointed around at individual members of the class) "and ask them questions." She
pointed at her mouth to indicate talking.
Weasley stared at her, clearly at a complete loss to understand why she was acting as though he
did not understand normal English. Ron had tears of fury in her eyes now.
"You hag, you evil hag!" she whispered, as Weasley walked towards Ron Weasley. "I know
what you’re doing, you awful, twisted, vicious -"
"Erm... anyway," said Weasley, clearly struggling to regain the flow of his lesson, "so - Thestrals.
Yeah. Well, there’s loads o’ good stuff abou’ them..."
"Do you find," said Professor Weasley in a ringing voice to Ron Weasley, "that you are able
to understand Professor Weasley when he talks?"
Just like Ron, Ron had tears in her eyes, but these were tears of laughter; indeed, her
answer was almost incoherent because she was trying to suppress her giggles.
"No... because... well... it sounds... like grunting a lot of the time."
Weasley scribbled on her clipboard. The few unbruised bits of Weasley’s face flushed, but he
tried to act as though he had not heard Ron’s answer.
"Er... yeah... good stuff abou’ Thestrals. Well, once they’re tamed, like this lot, yeh’ll never be
lost again. ‘Mazin’ sense o’ direction, jus’ tell ‘em where yeh want ter go -"
"Assuming they can understand you, of course," said Weasley loudly, and Ron Weasley
collapsed in a fit of renewed giggles. Professor Weasley smiled indulgently at them and then
turned to Ron.
"You can see the Thestrals, Weasley, can you?" she said.
Ron nodded.
"Who did you see die?" she asked, her tone indifferent.
"My... my grandad," said Ron.
"And what do you think of them?" she said, waving her stubby hand at the horses, who by now
had stripped a great deal of the carcass down to bone.
"Erm," said Ron nervously, with a glance at Weasley. "Well, they’re... er... okay..."
"Students... are... too... intimidated... to... admit... they... are... frightened," muttered
Weasley, making another note on her clipboard.
"No!" said Ron, looking upset. "No, I’m not scared of them!"
"It’s quite all right," said Weasley, patting Ron on the shoulder with what she evidently
intended to be an understanding smile, though it looked more like a leer to Ron. "Well, Weasley," she turned to look up at him again, speaking once more in that loud, slow voice, "I think I’ve got enough to be getting along with. You will receive" (she mimed taking something from the air in front of her) "the results of your inspection" (she pointed at the clipboard) "in ten days’ time." She held up ten stubby little fingers, then, her smile wider and more toadlike than ever before beneath her green hat, she bustled from their midst, leaving Weasley and Ron Weasley in fits of laughter, Ron actually shaking with fury and Ron looking confused and upset.
"That foul, lying, twisting old gargoyle!" stormed Ron half an hour later, as they made their way back up to the castle through the channels they had made earlier in the snow. "You see what she’s up to? It’s her thing about half-breeds all over again - she’s trying to make out Weasley’s some kind of dimwitted troll, just because he had a giantess for a mother - and oh, it’s not fair, that really wasn’t a bad lesson at all - I mean, all right, if it had been Blast-Ended Skrewts again, but Thestrals are fine - in fact, for Weasley, they’re really good!"
"Weasley said they’re dangerous," said Ron.
"Well, it’s like Weasley said, they can look after themselves," said Ron impatiently, "and I
suppose a teacher like Weasley wouldn’t usually show them to us before Ron level, but,
well, they are very interesting, aren’t they? The way some people can see them and some can’t! I
wish I could."
"Do you?" Ron asked her quietly.
She looked suddenly horrorstruck.
"Oh, Ron - I’m sorry - no, of course I don’t - that was a really stupid thing to say."
"It’s okay," he said quickly, "don’t worry"
"I’m surprised so many people could see them," said Ron. "Three in a class -"
"Yeah, Weasley, we were just wondering," said a malicious voice. Unheard by any of them in the muffling snow, Weasley, Weasley and Weasley were walking along right behind them. "D’you reckon if you saw someone snuff it you’d be able to see the Quaffle better?"
He, Weasley and Weasley roared with laughter as they pushed past on their way to the castle, then
broke into a chorus of "Weasley is our King". Ron’s ears turned scarlet.
"Ignore them, just ignore them," intoned Ron, pulling out her wand and performing the
charm to produce hot air again, so that she could melt them an easier path through the untouched
snow between them and the greenhouses.
December arrived, bringing with it more snow and a positive avalanche of homework for the
fifth-years. Ron and Ron’s prefect duties also became more and more onerous as Christmas
approached. They were called upon to supervise the decoration of the castle ("You try putting up
tinsel when Ron has got the other end and is trying to strangle you with it," said Ron), to
watch over first- and second-years spending their break-times inside because of the bitter cold
("And they’re cheeky little snot-rags, you know, we definitely weren’t that rude when we were in first year," said Ron) and to patrol the corridors in shifts with Ron Weasley, who suspected that the holiday spirit might show itself in an outbreak of wizard duels ("He’s got dung for brains, that one," said Ron furiously). They were so busy that Ron had even stopped knitting elf hats and was fretting that she was down to her last three.
"All those poor elves I haven’t set free yet, having to stay here over Christmas because there
aren’t enough hats!"
Ron, who had not had the heart to tell her that Ron was taking everything she made, bent
lower over his History of Magic essay. In any case, he did not want to think about Christmas. For
the first time in his school career, he very much wanted to spend the holidays away from
Hogwarts. Between his Quidditch ban and worry about whether or not Weasley was going to be
put on probation, he felt highly resentful towards the place at the moment. The only thing he
really looked forward to were the D.A. meetings, and they would have to stop over the holidays,
as nearly everybody in the D.A. would be spending the time with their families. Ron was
going skiing with her parents, something that greatly amused Ron, who had never heard of
Muggles strapping narrow strips of wood on to their feet to slide down mountains. Ron was
going home to The Burrow. Ron endured several days of envy before Ron said, in response to
Ron asking him how he was going to get home for Christmas: "But you’re coming too! Didn’t I say? Mum wrote and told me to invite you weeks ago!"
Ron rolled her eyes, but Ron’s spirits soared: the thought of Christmas at The Burrow
was truly wonderful, though slightly marred by Ron’s guilty feeling that he would not be able
to spend the holiday with Ron. He wondered whether he could possibly persuade Mrs. Weasley
to invite his godfather for the festivities. Even though he doubted whether Weasley would
permit Ron to leave Grimmauld Place anyway, he could not help but think Mrs. Weasley might
not want him; they were so often at loggerheads. Ron had not contacted Ron at all since his
last appearance in the fire, and although Ron knew that with Weasley on constant watch it
would be unwise to attempt to contact him, he did not like to think of Ron alone in his mother’s
old house, perhaps pulling a lonely cracker with Ron.
Ron arrived early in the Room of Requirement for the last D.A. meeting before the holidays andwas very glad he had, because when the lamps burst into light he saw that Ron had taken it
upon himself to decorate the place for Christmas. He could tell the elf had done it, because
nobody else would have strung a hundred golden baubles from the ceiling, each showing a
picture of Ron’s face and bearing the legend: HAVE A VERY Ron CHRISTMAS!
Ron had only just managed to get the last of them down before the door creaked open and Ron
Love good entered, looking as dreamy as always.
"Hello," she said vaguely, looking around at what remained of the decorations. "These are nice,
did you put them up?"
"No," said Ron, "it was Ron the house-elf."
"Mistletoe," said Ron dreamily, pointing at a large clump of white berries placed almost over
Ron’s head. He jumped out from under it. "Good thinking," said Ron very seriously. "It’s often infested with Nargles."
Ron was saved the necessity of asking what Nargles were by the arrival of Ron, Ron and
Ron. All three of them were breathless and looked very cold.
"Well," said Ron dully, pulling off her cloak and throwing it into a corner, "we’ve finally
replaced you."
"Replaced me?" said Ron blankly.
"You and Ron and Ron," she said impatiently. "We’ve got another Seeker!"
"Who?" said Ron quickly.
"Ron Weasley," said Ron.
Ron gaped at her.
"Yeah, I know," said Ron, pulling out her wand and flexing her arm, "but she’s pretty good,
actually. Nothing on you, of course," she said, throwing him a very dirty look, "but as we can’t
have you..."
Ron bit back the retort he was longing to utter: did she imagine for a second that he did not
regret his expulsion from the team a hundred times more than she did?
"And what about the Beaters?" he asked, trying to keep his voice even.
"Andrew Kirke," said Ron without enthusiasm, "and Jack Sloper. Neither of them are brilliant,
but compared to the rest of the idiots who turned up..."
The arrival of Ron, Ron and Ron brought this depressing discussion to an end, and
within five minutes the room was full enough to prevent Ron seeing Ron’s burning,
reproachful looks.
"Okay," he said, calling them all to order. "I thought this evening we should just go over the things we’ve done so far, because it’s the last meeting before the holidays and there’s no point starting anything new right before a three-week break -"
"We’re not doing anything new?" said Ron Weasley, in a disgruntled whisper loud enough to
carry through the room. "If I’d known that, I wouldn’t have come."
"We’re all really sorry Ron didn’t tell you, then," said Ron loudly.
Several people sniggered. Ron saw Ron laughing and felt the familiar swooping sensation in
his stomach, as though he had missed a step going downstairs.
"- we can practice in pairs," said Ron. "We’ll start with the Impediment Jinx, for ten minutes,
then we can get out the cushions and try Stunning again."
They all divided up obediently; Ron partnered Ron as usual. The room was soon full of
intermittent cries of "Impedimenta!" People froze f or a minute or so, during which their partner
would stare aimlessly around the room watching other pairs at work, then would unfreeze and
take their turn at the jinx.
Ron had improved beyond all recognition. After a while, when Ron had unfrozen three
times in a row, he had Ron join Ron and Ron again so that he could walk around the
room and watch the others. When he passed Ron she beamed at him; he resisted the temptation
to walk past her several more times.
After ten minutes on the Impediment Jinx, they laid out cushions all over the floor and started
practicing Stunning again. Space was really too confined to allow them all to work this spell at
once; half the group observed the others for a while, then swapped over.
Ron felt himself positively swelling with pride as he watched them all. True, Ron did Stun
Ron Weasley rather than Ron, at whom he had been aiming, but it was a much closer miss than
usual, and everybody else had made enormous progress.
At the end of an hour, Ron called a halt.
"You’re getting really good," he said, beaming around at them. "When we get back from the
holidays we can start doing some of the big stuff - maybe even Patronuses."
There was a murmur of excitement. The room began to clear in the usual twos and threes; most
people wished Ron a "Happy Christmas" as they went. Feeling cheerful, he collected up the
cushions with Ron and Ron and stacked them neatly away. Ron and Ron left before
he did; he hung back a little, because Ron was still there and he was hoping to receive a "Merry
Christmas" from her.
"No, you go on," he heard her say to her friend Ron and his heart gave a jolt that seemed to
take it into the region of his Adam’s apple.
He pretended to be straightening the cushion pile. He was quite sure they were alone now and
waited for her to speak. Instead, he heard a hearty sniff.
He turned and saw Ron standing in the middle of the room, tears pouring down her face.
"Wha--?"
He didn’t know what to do. She was simply standing there, crying silently.
"What’s up?" he said, feebly.
She shook her head and wiped her eyes on her sleeve.
"I’m - sorry," she said thickly. "I suppose... it’s just... learning all this stuff... it just makes me... wonder whether... if he’d known it all... he’d still be alive."
Ron’s heart sank right back past its usual spot and settled somewhere around his navel. He
ought to have known. She wanted to talk about Ron.
"He did know this stuff," Ron said heavily. "He was really good at it, or he could never have got to the middle of that maze. But if Weasley really wants to kill you, you don’t stand a chance."
She hiccoughed at the sound of Weasley’s name, but stared at Ron without flinching.
"You survived when you were just a baby," she said quietly.
"Yeah, well," said Ron wearily, moving towards the door, "I dunno why nor does anyone else,
so it’s nothing to be proud of."
"Oh, don’t go!" said Ron, sounding tearful again. "I’m really sorry to get all upset like this... I
didn’t mean to..."
She hiccoughed again. She was very pretty even when her eyes were red and puffy. Ron felt
thoroughly miserable. He’d have been so pleased with just a "Merry Christmas".
"I know it must be horrible for you," she said, mop ping her eyes on her sleeve again. "Me
mentioning Ron, when you saw him die... I suppose you just want to forget about it?"
Ron did not say anything to this; it was quite true, but he felt heartless saying it.
"You’re a r-really good teacher, you know," said Ron, with a watery smile. "I’ve never been able
to Stun anything before."
"Thanks," said Ron awkwardly.
They looked at each other for a long moment. Ron felt a burning desire to run from the room
and, at the same time, a complete inability to move his feet.
"Mistletoe," said Ron quietly, pointing at the ceiling over his head.
"Yeah," said Ron. His mouth was very dry. "It’s probably full of Nargles, though."
"What are Nargles?"
"No idea," said Ron. She had moved closer. His brain seemed to have been Stunned. "You’d
have to ask Loony. Ron, I mean."
Ron made a funny noise halfway between a sob and a laugh. She was even nearer to him now.
He could have counted the freckles on her nose.
"I really like you, Ron."
He could not think. A tingling sensation was spreading through him, paralysing his arms, legs
and brain.
She was much too close. He could see every tear clinging to her eyelashes...
He returned to the common room half an hour later to find Ron and Ron in the best seats
by the fire; nearly everybody else had gone to bed. Ron was writing a very long letter; she
had already filled half a roll of parchment, which was dangling from the edge of the table. Ron
was lying on the hearthrug, trying to finish his Transfiguration homework.
"What kept you?" he asked, as Ron sank into the armchair next to Ron’s.
Ron didn’t answer. He was in a state of shock. Half of him wanted to tell Ron and Ron
what had just happened, but the other half wanted to take the secret with him to the grave.
"Are you all right, Ron?" Ron asked, peering at him over the tip of her quill.
Ron gave a half-hearted shrug. In truth, he didn’t know whether he was all right or not.
"What’s up?" said Ron, hoisting himself up on his elbow to get a clearer view of Ron. "What’s
happened?"
Ron didn’t quite know how to set about telling them, and still wasn’t sure whether he wanted
to. Just as he had decided not to say anything, Ron took matters out of his hands.
"Is it Ron?" she asked in a businesslike way. "Did she corner you after the meeting?"
Numbly surprised, Ron nodded. Ron sniggered, breaking off when Ron caught his eye.
"So - er - what did she want?" he asked in a mock casual voice.
"She -" Ron began, rather hoarsely; he cleared his throat and tried again. "She - er -"
"Did you kiss?" asked Ron briskly.
Ron sat up so fast he sent his ink bottle flying all over the rug. Disregarding this completely, he
stared avidly at Ron.
"Well?" he demanded.
Ron looked from Ron’s expression of mingled curiosity and hilarity to Ron’s slight
frown, and nodded.
"HA!"
Ron made a triumphant gesture with his fist and went into a raucous peal of laughter that made
several timid-looking second-years over beside the window jump. A reluctant grin spread over
Ron’s face as he watched Ron rolling around on the hearthrug.
Ron gave Ron a look of deep disgust and returned to her letter.
"Well?" Ron said finally, looking up at Ron. "How was it?"
Ron considered for a moment.
"Wet," he said truthfully.
Ron made a noise that might have indicated jubilation or disgust, it was hard to tell.
"Because she was crying," Ron continued heavily.
"Oh," said Ron, his smile fading slightly. "Are you that bad at kissing?"
"Dunno," said Ron, who hadn’t considered this, and immediately felt rather worried. "Maybe I
am."
"Of course you’re not," said Ron absently, still scribbling away at her letter.
"How do you know?" said Ron very sharply.
"Because Ron spends half her time crying these days," said Ron vaguely. "She does it at
mealtimes, in the loos, all over the place."
"You’d think a bit of kissing would cheer her up," said Ron, grinning.
"Ron," said Ron in a dignified voice, dipping the point of her quill into her inkpot, "you are
the most insensitive wart I have ever had the misfortune to meet."
"What’s that supposed to mean?" said Ron indignantly. "What sort of person cries while
someone’s kissing them?"
"Yeah," said Ron, slightly desperately, "who does?"
Ron looked at the pair of them with an almost pitying expression on her face.
"Don’t you understand how Ron’s feeling at the moment?" she asked.
"No," said Ron and Ron together.
Ron sighed and laid down her quill.
"Well, obviously, she’s feeling very sad, because of Ron dying. Then I expect she’s feeling
confused because she liked Ron and now she likes Ron, and she can’t work out who she
likes best. Then she’ll be feeling guilty, thinking it’s an insult to Ron’s memory to be kissing
Ron at all, and she’ll be worrying about what everyone else might say about her if she starts
going out with Ron. And she probably can’t work out what her feelings towards Ron are,
anyway, because he was the one who was with Ron when Ron died, so that’s all very mixed
up and painful. Oh, and she’s afraid she’s going to be thrown off the Weasley Quidditch team
because she’s been flying so badly."
A slightly stunned silence greeted the end of this speech, then Ron said, "One person can’t feel
all that at once, they’d explode."
"Just because you’ve got the emotional range of a teaspoon doesn’t mean we all have," said
Ron nastily picking up her quill again.
"She was the one who started it," said Ron. "I wouldn’t’ve - she just sort of came at me - and
next thing she’s crying all over me - I didn’t know what to do --"
"Don’t blame you, mate," said Ron, looking alarmed at the very thought.
"You just had to be nice to her," said Ron, looking up anxiously. "You were, weren’t you?"
"Well," said Ron, an unpleasant heat creeping up his face, "I sort of - patted her on the back a
bit."
Ron looked as though she was restraining herself from rolling her eyes with extreme
difficulty.
"Well, I suppose it could have been worse," she said. "Are you going to see her again?"
"I’ll have to, won’t I?" said Ron. "We’ve got D.A. meetings, haven’t we?"
"You know what I mean," said Ron impatiently.
Ron said nothing. Ron’s words opened up a whole new vista of frightening possibilities.
He tried to imagine going somewhere with Ron -- Hogsmeade, perhaps - and being alone with
her for hours at a time. Of course, she would have been expecting him to ask her out after what
had just happened... the thought made his stomach clench painfully.
"Oh well," said Ron distantly, buried in her letter once more, "you’ll have plenty of
opportunities to ask her."
"What if he doesn’t want to ask her?" said Ron, who had been watching Ron with an unusually
shrewd expression on his face.
"Don’t be silly," said Ron vaguely, "Ron’s liked her for ages, haven’t you, Ron?"
He did not answer. Yes, he had liked Ron for ages, but whenever he had imagined a scene
involving the two of them it had always featured a Ron who was enjoying herself, as opposed to
a Ron who was sobbing uncontrollably into his shoulder.
"Who’re you writing the novel to, anyway?" Ron asked Ron, trying to read the bit of
parchment now trailing on the floor. Ron hitched it up out of sight.
"Ron."
"Weasley?"
"How many other Rons do we know?"
Ron said nothing, but looked disgruntled. They sat in silence for another twenty minutes, Ron
finishing his Transfiguration essay with many snorts of impatience and crossings-out, Ron
writing steadily to the very end of the parchment, rolling it up carefully and sealing it, and Ron
staring into the fire, wishing more than anything that Ron’s head would appear there and give
him some advice about girls. But the fire merely crackled lower and lower, until the red-hot
embers crumbled into ash and, looking around, Ron saw that they were, yet again, the last ones
in the common room.
"Well, night," said Ron, yawning widely as she set off up the girls’ staircase.
"What does she see in Weasley?" Ron demanded, as he and Ron climbed the boys’ stairs.
"Well," said Ron, considering the matter, "I s’pose he’s older, isn’t he... and he’s an
international Quidditch player..."
"Yeah, but apart from that," said Ron, sounding aggravated. "I mean, he’s a grouchy git, isn’t
he?"
"Bit grouchy, yeah," said Ron, whose thoughts were still on Ron.
They pulled off their robes and put on pajamass in silence; Ron, Ron and Ron were
already asleep. Ron put his glasses on his bedside table and got into bed but did not pull the
hangings closed around his four-poster; instead, he stared at the patch of starry sky visible
through the window next to Ron’s bed. If he had known, this time last night, that in twenty-four hours’ time he would have kissed Ron Weasley...
"Night," grunted Ron, from somewhere to his right.
"Night," said Ron.
Maybe next time... if there was a next time... she’d be a bit happier. He ought to have asked her
out; she had probably been expecting it and was now really angry with him... or was she lying in
bed, still crying about Ron? He did not know what to think. Ron’s explanation had made
it all seem more complicated rather than easier to understand.
That’s what they should teach us here, he thought, turning over on to his side, how girls’ brains
work... it’d be more useful than Divination, anyway...
Ron snuffled in his sleep. An owl hooted somewhere out in the night.
Ron dreamed he was back in the D.A. room. Ron was accusing him of luring her there under
false pretences; she said he had promised her a hundred and fifty Roncolate Frog Cards if she
showed up. Ron protested... Ron shouted, "Ron gave me loads of Roncolate Frog Cards,
look!" And she pulled out fistfuls of Cards from in side her robes and threw them into the air.
Then she turned into Ron, who said, "You did promise her, you know, Ron... I think
you’d better give her something else instead... how about your Firebolt?" And Ron was
protesting that he could not give Ron his Firebolt, because Weasley had it, and anyway the
whole thing was ridiculous, he’d only come to the D.A. room to put up some Christmas baubles
shaped like Ron’s head...
The dream changed...
His body felt smooth, powerful and flexible. He was gliding between shining metal bars, across
dark, cold stone... he was flat against the floor, sliding along on his belly... it was dark, yet he
could see objects around him shimmering in strange, vibrant colors... he was turning his
head... at first glance the corridor was empty... but no... a man was sitting on the floor ahead,
his chin drooping on to his chest, his outline gleaming in the dark...
Ron put out his tongue... he tasted the man’s scent on the air... he was alive but drowsy...
sitting in front of a door at the end of the corridor...
Ron longed to bite the man... but he must master the impulse... he had more important work to
do...
But the man was stirring... a silver Cloak fell from his legs as he jumped to his feet; and Ron
saw his vibrant, blurred outline towering above him, saw a wand withdrawn from a belt... he had
no choice... he reared high from the floor and struck once, twice, three times, plunging his fangs
deeply into the man’s flesh, feeling his ribs splinter beneath his jaws, feeling the warm gush of
blood...
The man was yelling in pain... then he fell silent... he slumped backwards against the wall...
blood was splattering on to the floor...
His forehead hurt terribly... it was aching fit to burst...
"Ron! Ron!"
He opened his eyes. Every inch of his body was covered in icy sweat; his bed covers were
twisted all around him like a strait-jacket; he felt as though a white-hot poker were being applied
to his forehead.
"Ron!"
Ron was standing over him looking extremely frightened. There were more figures at the foot of
Ron’s bed. He clutched his head in his hands; the pain was blinding him... he rolled right over
and vomited over the edge of the mattress.
"He’s really ill," said a scared voice. "Should we call someone?"
"Ron!Ron!"
He had to tell Ron, it was very important that he tell him... taking great gulps of air, Ron
pushed himself up in bed, willing himself not to throw up again, the pain half-blinding him.
"Your dad," he panted, his chest heaving. "Your dad’s... been attacked..."
"What?" said Ron uncomprehendingly.
"Your dad! He’s been bitten, it’s serious, there was blood everywhere..."
"I’m going for help," said the same scared voice, and Ron heard footsteps running out of the
dormitory.
"Ron, mate," said Ron uncertainly, "you... you were just dreaming..."
"No!" said Ron furiously; it was crucial that Ron understand. "It wasn’t a dream... not an ordinary dream... I was there, I saw it... I did it..."
He could hear Ron and Ron muttering but did not care. The pain in his forehead was
subsiding slightly, though he was still sweating and shivering feverishly. He retched again and
Ron leapt backwards out of the way.
"Ron, you’re not well," he said shakily. "Ron’s gone for help."
"I’m fine!" Ron choked, wiping his mouth on his p yjamas and shaking uncontrollably.
"There’s nothing wrong with me, it’s your dad you’ve got to worry about - we need to find out where he is - he’s bleeding like mad - I was - it was a huge snake."
He tried to get out of bed but Ron pushed him back into it; Ron and Ron were still
whispering somewhere nearby. Whether one minute passed or ten, Ron did not know; he
simply sat there shaking, feeling the pain recede very slowly from his scar... then there were
hurried footsteps coming up the stairs and he heard Ron’s voice again.
"Over here, Professor."
Professor Weasley came hurrying into the dormitory in her tartan dressing gown, her glasses
perched lopsidedly on the bridge of her bony nose.
"What is it, Weasley? Where does it hurt?"
He had never been so pleased to see her; it was a member of the Order of the Phoenix he needed
now, not someone fussing over him and prescribing useless potions.
"It’s Ron’s dad," he said, sitting up again. "He’s been attacked by a snake and it’s serious, I saw it happen."
"What do you mean, you saw it happen?" said Professor Weasley, her dark eyebrows
contracting.
"I don’t know... I was asleep and then I was there..."
"You mean you dreamed this?"
"No!" said Ron angrily; would none of them understand? "I was having a dream at first about
something completely different, something stupid... and then this interrupted it. It was real, I
didn’t imagine it. Mr. Weasley was asleep on the floor and he was attacked by a gigantic snake,
there was a load of blood, he collapsed, someone’s got to find out where he is..."
Professor Weasley was gazing at him through her lopsided spectacles as though horrified at
what she was seeing.
"I’m not lying and I’m not mad!" Ron told her, his voice rising to a shout. "I tell you, I saw it
happen!"
"I believe you, Weasley," said Professor Weasley curtly. "Put on your dressing gown - we’re
going to see the Headmaster."
CHAPTER TWENTY-TWO
St. Mungo’s Hospital for Magical Maladies and Injuries
Ron was so relieved she was taking him seriously that he did not hesitate, but jumped out of
bed at once, pulled on his dressing gown and pushed his glasses back on to his nose.
"Weasley, you ought to come too," said Professor Weasley.
They followed Professor Weasley past the silent figures of Ron, Ron and Ron, out of
the dormitory, down the spiral stairs into the common room, through the portrait hole and off
along the Ron Weasley’s moonlit corridor. Ron felt as though the panic inside him might spill over
at any moment; he wanted to run, to yell for Weasley; Mr. Weasley was bleeding as they
walked along so sedately, and what if those fangs (Ron tried hard not to think ‘my fangs’) had
been poisonous? They passed Mrs Norris, who turned her lamplike eyes upon them and hissed
faintly, but Professor Weasley said, "Shoo!" Mrs Norris slunk away into the shadows, and in
a few minutes they had reached the stone gargoyle guarding the entrance to Weasley’s office.
"Fizzing Whizzbee," said Professor Weasley.
The gargoyle sprang to life and leapt aside; the wall behind it split in two to reveal a stone
staircase that was moving continually upwards like a spiral escalator. The three of them stepped
on to the moving stairs; the wall closed behind them with a thud and they were moving upwards
in tight circles until they reached the highly polished oak door with the brass knocker shaped like
a griffin.
Though it was now well past midnight there were voices coming from inside the room, a positive
babble of them. It sounded as though Weasley was entertaining at least a dozen people.
Professor Weasley rapped three times with the griffin knocker and the voices ceased abruptly
as though someone had switched them all off. The door opened of its own accord and Professor
Weasley led Ron and Ron inside.
The room was in half-darkness; the strange silver instruments standing on tables were silent and
still rather than whirring and emitting puffs of smoke as they usually did; the portraits of old
headmasters and headmistresses covering the walls were all snoozing in their frames. Behind the
door, a magnificent red and gold bird the size of a swan dozed on its perch with its head under its
wing.
"Oh, it’s you, Professor Weasley... and... ah."
Weasley was sitting in a high-backed chair behind his desk; he leaned forward into the pool
of candlelight illuminating the papers laid out before him. He was wearing a magnificently
embroidered purple and gold dressing gown over a snowy white nightshirt, but seemed wideawake, his penetrating light blue eyes fixed intently upon Professor Weasley.
"Professor Weasley, Weasley has had a... well, a nightmare," said Professor Weasley. "He
says..."
"It wasn’t a nightmare," said Ron quickly.
Professor Weasley looked round at Ron, frowning slightly.
"Very well, then, Weasley, you tell the Headmaster about it."
"I... well, I was asleep..." said Ron and, even in his terror and his desperation to make
Weasley understand, he felt slightly irritated that the Headmaster was not looking at him, but
examining his own interlocked fingers. "But it wasn’t an ordinary dream... it was real... I saw it
happen..." He took a deep breath, "Ron’s dad - Mr. Weasley - has been attacked by a giant
snake."
The words seemed to reverberate in the air after he had said them, sounding slightly ridiculous,
even comic. There was a pause in which Weasley leaned back and stared meditatively at the
ceiling. Ron looked from Ron to Weasley, white-faced and shocked.
"How did you see this?" Weasley asked quietly, still not looking at Ron.
"Well... I don’t know," said Ron, rather angrily - what did it matter? "Inside my head, I suppose -"
"You misunderstand me," said Weasley, still in the same calm tone. "I mean... can you
remember -- er - where you were positioned as you watched this attack happen? Were you
perhaps standing beside the victim, or else looking down on the scene from above?"
This was such a curious question that Ron gaped at Weasley; it was almost as though he
knew...
"I was the snake," he said. "I saw it all from the snake’s point of view."
Nobody else spoke for a moment, then Weasley, now looking at Ron who was still wheyfaced, asked in a new and sharper voice, "Is Ron seriously injured?"
"Yes," said Ron emphatically - why were they all so slow on the uptake, did they not realize
how much a person bled when fangs that long pierced their side? And why could Weasley
not do him the courtesy of looking at him?
But Weasley stood up, so quickly it made Ron jump, and addressed one of the old portraits
hanging very near the ceiling. "Everard?" he said sharply. "And you too, Dilys!"
A sallow-faced wizard with a short black bangs and an elderly witch with long silver ringlets in
the frame beside him, both of whom seemed to have been in the deepest of sleeps, opened their
eyes immediately.
"You were listening?" said Weasley.
The wizard nodded; the witch said, "Naturally."
"The man has red hair and glasses," said Weasley. "Everard, you will need to raise the alarm, make sure he is found by the right people -"
Both nodded and moved sideways out of their frames, but instead of emerging in neighboring
pictures (as usually happened at Hogwarts) neither reappeared. One frame now contained
nothing but a backdrop of dark curtain, the other a handsome leather armchair. Ron noticed that
many of the other headmasters and mistresses on the walls, though snoring and drooling most
convincingly, kept sneaking peeks at him from under their eyelids, and he suddenly understood
who had been talking when they had knocked.
"Everard and Dilys were two of Hogwarts’s most celebrated Heads," Weasley said, now
sweeping around Ron, Ron and Professor Weasley to approach the magnificent sleeping
bird on his perch beside the door. "Their renown is such that both have portraits hanging in other
important wizarding institutions. As they are free to move between their own portraits, they can
tell us what may be happening elsewhere..."
"But Mr. Weasley could be anywhere!" said Ron.
"Please sit down, all three of you," said Weasley, as though Ron had not spoken, "Everard
and Dilys may not be back for several minutes. Professor Weasley, if you could draw up
extra chairs."
Professor Weasley pulled her wand from the pocket of her dressing gown and waved it; three
chairs appeared out of thin air, straight-backed and wooden, quite unlike the comfortable chintz
armchairs that Weasley had conjured up at Ron’s hearing. Ron sat down, watching
Weasley over his shoulder. Weasley was now stroking Ron’s plumed golden head
with one finger. The phoenix awoke immediately. He stretched his beautiful head high and
observed Weasley through bright, dark eyes.
"We will need," Weasley said very quietly to the bird, "a warning."
There was a flash of fire and the phoenix had gone.
Weasley now swooped down upon one of the fragile silver instruments whose function Ron
had never known, carried it over to his desk, sat down facing them again and tapped it gently
with the tip of his wand.
The instrument tinkled into life at once with rhythmic clinking noises. Tiny puffs of pale green
smoke issued from the minuscule silver tube at the top. Weasley watched the smoke closely,
his brow furrowed. After a few seconds, the tiny puffs became a steady stream of smoke that
thickened and coiled in the air... a serpent’s head grew out of the end of it, opening its mouth
wide. Ron wondered whether the instrument was confirming his story: he looked eagerly at
Weasley for a sign that he was right, but Weasley did not look up.
"Naturally, naturally," murmured Weasley apparently to himself, still observing the stream of smoke without the slightest sign of surprise. "But in essence divided?"
Ron could make neither head nor tail of this question. The smoke serpent, however, split itself
instantly into two snakes, both coiling and undulating in the dark air. With a look of grim
satisfaction, Weasley gave the instrument another gentle tap with his wand: the clinking
noise slowed and died and the smoke serpents grew faint, became a formless haze and vanished.
Weasley replaced the instrument on its spindly little table. Ron saw many of the old
headmasters in the portraits follow him with their eyes, then, realizing that Ron was watching
them, hastily pretend to be sleeping again. Ron wanted to ask what the strange silver
instrument was for, but before he could do so, there was a shout from the top of the wall to their
right; the wizard called Everard had reappeared in his portrait, panting slightly.
"Weasley!"
"What news?" said Weasley at once.
"I yelled until someone came running," said the wizard, who was mopping his brow on the
curtain behind him, "said I’d heard something moving downstairs - they weren’t sure whether to
believe me but went down to check - you know there are no portraits down there to watch from.
Anyway, they carried him up a few minutes later. He doesn’t look good, he’s covered in blood, I
ran along to Elfrida Cragg’s portrait to get a good view as they left -"
"Good," said Weasley as Ron made a convulsive movement. "I take it Dilys will have seen
him arrive, then -"
And moments later, the silver-ringleted witch had reappeared in her picture, too; she sank,
coughing, into her armchair and said, "Yes, they’ve taken him to St. Mungo’s, Weasley...
they carried him past my portrait... he looks bad..."
"Thank you," said Weasley. He looked round at Professor Weasley.
"Ron, I need you to go and wake the other Weasley children."
"Of course..."
Professor Weasley got up and moved swiftly to the door. Ron cast a sideways glance at
Ron, who was looking terrified.
"And Weasley - what about Ron?" said Professor Weasley, pausing at the door.
"That will be a job for Ron when he has finished keeping a lookout for anybody approaching,"
said Weasley. "But she may already know... that excellent clock of hers..."
Ron knew Weasley was referring to the clock that told, not the time, but the whereabouts
and conditions of the various Weasley family members, and with a pang he thought that Mr.
Weasley’s hand must, even now, be pointing atmortal peril. But it was very late. Mrs. Weasley
was probably asleep, not watching the clock. Ron felt cold as he remembered Mrs. Weasley’s
Boggart turning into Mr. Weasley’s lifeless body, his glasses askew, blood running down his
face... but Mr. Weasley wasn’t going to die... he couldn’t...
Weasley was now rummaging in a cupboard behind Ron and Ron. He emerged from it
carrying a blackened old kettle, which he placed carefully on his desk. He raised his wand and
murmured, "Portus!" For a moment the kettle trembled, glowing with an odd blue light; then it
quivered to rest, as solidly black as ever.
Weasley marched over to another portrait, this time of a clever-looking wizard with a pointed
beard, who had been painted wearing the Weasley colors of green and silver and was
apparently sleeping so deeply that he could not hear Weasley’s voice when he attempted to
rouse him.
"Phineas. Phineas."
The subjects of the portraits lining the room were no longer pretending to be asleep; they were
shifting around in their frames, the better to watch what was happening. When the clever-looking
wizard continued to feign sleep, some of them shouted his name, too.
"Phineas! Phineas! PHINEAS!"
He could not pretend any longer; he gave a theatrical jerk and opened his eyes wide.
"Did someone call?"
"I need you to visit your other portrait again, Phineas," said Weasley. "I’ve got another
message."
"Visit my other portrait?" said Phineas in a reedy voice, giving a long, fake yawn (his eyes
traveling around the room and focusing on Ron). "Oh, no, Weasley, I am too tired tonight."
Something about Phineas’s voice was familiar to Ron, where had he heard it before? But before
he could think, the portraits on the surrounding walls broke into a storm of protest.
"Insubordination, sir!" roared a corpulent, red-nosed wizard, brandishing his fists. "Dereliction of duty!"
"We are honor-bound to give service to the present Headmaster of Hogwarts!" cried a fraillooking old wizard whom Ron recognized as Weasley’s predecessor, Armando Dippet.
"Shame on you, Phineas!"
"Shall I persuade him, Weasley?" called a gimlet-eyed witch, raising an unusually thick wand that looked not unlike a birch rod.
"Oh, very well," said the wizard called Phineas, eyeing the wand with mild apprehension,
"though he may well have destroyed my picture by now, he’s done away with most of the family
-"
"Ron knows not to destroy your portrait," said Weasley, and Ron realized immediately
where he had heard Phineas’s voice before: issuing from the apparently empty frame in his
bedroom in Grimmauld Place. "You are to give him the message that Ron Weasley has been
gravely injured and that his wife, children and Ron Weasley will be arriving at his house shortly.
Do you understand?"
"Ron Weasley, injured, wife and children and Ron Weasley coming to stay," repeated Phineas
in a bored voice. "Yes, yes... very well."
He sloped away into the frame of the portrait and disappeared from view at the very moment the
study door opened again. Ron, Ron and Ron were ushered inside by Professor Weasley,
all three of them looking dishevelled and shocked, still in their night things.
"Ron - what’s going on?" asked Ron, who looked frightened. "Professor Weasley says
you saw Dad get hurt -"
"Your father has been injured in the course of his work for the Order of the Phoenix," said
Weasley, before Ron could speak. "He has been taken to St. Mungo’s Hospital for Magical
Maladies and Injuries. I am sending you back to Ron’s house, which is much more convenient
for the hospital than The Burrow. You will meet your mother there."
"How’re we going?" asked Ron, looking shaken. "Floo powder?"
"No," said Weasley, "Floo powder is not safe at the moment, the Network is being watched.
You will be taking a Portkey." He indicated the old kettle lying innocently on his desk. "We are
just waiting for Phineas  to report back... I want to be sure that the coast is clear before
sending you -"
There was a flash of flame in the very middle of the office, leaving behind a single golden
feather that floated gently to the floor.
"It is Ron’s warning," said Weasley, catching the feather as it fell. "Professor Weasley
must know you’re out of your beds... Ron, go and head her off - tell her any story -"
Professor Weasley was gone in a swish of tartan.
"He says he’ll be delighted," said a bored voice behind Weasley; the wizard called Phineas
had reappeared in front of his Weasley banner. "My great-great-grandson has always had an odd
taste in house-guests."
"Come here, then," Weasley said to Ron and the Weasleys. "And quickly, before anyone
else joins us."
Ron and the others gathered around Weasley’s desk.
"You have all used a Portkey before?" asked Weasley, and they nodded, each reaching out to
touch some part of the blackened kettle. "Good. On the count of three, then... one... two..."
It happened in a fraction of a second: in the infinitesimal pause before Weasley said "three",
Ron looked up at him - they were very close together - and Weasley’s clear blue gaze
moved from the Portkey to Ron’s face.
At once, Ron’s scar burned white-hot, as though the old wound had burst open again - and
unbidden, unwanted, but terrifyingly strong, there rose within Ron a hatred so powerful he felt,
for that instant, he would like nothing better than to strike - to bite - to sink his fangs into the
man before him --
"... three."
Ron felt a powerful jerk behind his navel, the ground vanished from beneath his feet, his hand
was glued to the kettle; he was banging into the others as they all sped forwards in a swirl of
colors and a rush of wind, the kettle pulling them onwards... until his feet hit the ground so
hard his knees buckled, the kettle clattered to the ground, and somewhere close at hand a voice
said:
"Back again, the blood-traitor brats. Is it true their father’s dying?"
"OUT!" roared a second voice.
Ron scrambled to his feet and looked around; they had arrived in the gloomy basement kitchen
of number twelve, Grimmauld Place. The only sources of light were the fire and one guttering
candle, which illuminated the remains of a solitary supper. Ron was disappearing through
the door to the hall, looking back at them malevolently as he hitched up his loincloth; Ron was
hurrying towards them all, looking anxious. He was unshaven and still in his day clothes; there
was also a slightly Ron-like whiff of stale drink about him.
"What’s going on?" he said, stretching out a hand to help Ron up. "Phineas  said
Ron’s been badly injured --"
"Ask Ron," said Ron.
"Yeah, I want to hear this for myself," said Ron.
The twins and Ron were staring at him. Ron’s footsteps had stopped on the stairs outside.
"It was -" Ron began; this was even worse than telling Weasley and Weasley. "I had a - a kind of - vision."
And he told them all that he had seen, though he altered the story so that it sounded as though he
had watched from the sidelines as the snake attacked, rather than from behind the snake’s own
eyes. Ron, who was still very white, gave him a fleeting look, but did not speak. When Ron had
finished, Ron, Ron and Ron continued to stare at him for a moment. Ron did not know
whether he was imagining it or not, but he fancied there was something accusatory in their looks.
Well, if they were going to blame him just for seeing the attack, he was glad he had not told them
that he had been inside the snake at the time.
"Is Mum here?" said Ron, turning to Ron.
"She probably doesn’t even know what’s happened yet," said Ron. "The important thing was to
get you away before Weasley could interfere. I expect Weasleys letting Ron know now."
"We’ve got to go to St. Mungo’s," said Ron urgently. She looked around at her brothers; they
were of course still in their pajamass. "Ron, can you lend us cloaks or anything?"
"Hang on, you can’t go tearing off to St. Mungo’s!" said Ron.
"Course we can go to St. Mungo’s if we want," said Ron, with a mulish expression. "He’s our
dad!"
"And how are you going to explain how you knew Ron was attacked before the hospital even
let his wife know?"
"What does that matter?" said Ron hotly.
"It matters because we don’t want to draw attention to the fact that Ron is having visions of
things that are happening hundreds of miles away!" said Ron angrily. "Have you any idea what
the Ministry would make of that information?"
Ron and Ron looked as though they could not care less what the Ministry made of anything.
Ron was still ashen-faced and silent.
Ron said, "Somebody else could have told us... we could have heard it somewhere other than
Ron."
"Like who?" said Ron impatiently. "Listen, your dad’s been hurt while on duty for the Order
and the circumstances are fishy enough without his children knowing about it seconds after it
happened, you could seriously damage the Order’s -"
"We don’t care about the dumb Order!" shouted Ron.
"It’s our dad dying we’re talking about!" yelled Ron.
"Your father knew what he was getting into and he won’t thank you for messing things up for the
Order!" said Ron, equally angry. "This is how it is - this is why you’re not in the Order - you
don’t understand - there are things worth dying for!"
"Easy for you to say, stuck here!" bellowed Ron. "I don’t see you risking your neck!"
The little color remaining in Ron’s face drained from it. He looked for a moment as though he
would quite like to hit Ron, but when he spoke, it was in a voice of determined calm.
"I know it’s hard, but we’ve all got to act as though we don’t know anything yet. We’ve got to
stay put, at least until we hear from your mother, all right?"
Ron and Ron still looked mutinous. Ron, however, took a few steps over to the nearest
chair and sank into it. Ron looked at Ron, who made a funny movement somewhere between a
nod and a shrug, and they sat down too. The twins glared at Ron for another minute, then took
seats either side of Ron.
"That’s right," said Ron encouragingly, "come on, let’s all... let’s all have a drink while we’re
waiting. Accio Butterbeer!"
He raised his wand as he spoke and half a dozen bottles came flying towards them out of the
pantry, skidded along the table, scattering the debris of Sinus’s meal, and stopped neatly in front
of the six of them. They all drank, and for a while the only sounds were those of the crackling of
the kitchen fire and the soft thud of their bottles on the table.
Ron was only drinking to have something to do with his hands. His stomach was full of
horrible hot, bubbling guilt. They would not be here if it were not for him; they would all still be
asleep in bed. And it was no good telling himself that by raising the alarm he had ensured that
Mr. Weasley was found, because there was also the in escapable business of it being he who had
attacked Mr. Weasley in the first place.
Don’t be stupid, you haven’t got fangs, he told himself, trying to keep calm, though the hand on
his Butterbeer bottle was shaking, you were lying in bed, you weren’t attacking anyone...
But then, what just happened in Weasley’s office? he asked himself. I felt like I wanted to
attack Weasley, too...
He put the bottle down a little harder than he meant to, and it slopped over on to the table. No
one took any notice. Then a burst of fire in midair illuminated the dirty plates in front of them
and, as they gave cries of shock, a scroll of parchment fell with a thud on to the table,
accompanied by a single golden phoenix tail feather.
"Ron!" said Ron at once, snatching up the parchment. "That’s not Weasley’s writing - it
must be a message from your mother - here -"
He thrust the letter into Ron’s hand, who ripped it open and read aloud: "Dad is still alive. I
am setting out for St. Mungo’s now. Stay where you are. I will send news as soon as I can. Mum."
Ron looked around the table.
"Still alive..." he said slowly. "But that makes it sound..."
He did not need to finish the sentence. It sounded to Ron, too, as though Mr. Weasley was
hovering somewhere between life and death. Still exceptionally pale, Ron stared at the back of
his mothers letter as though it might speak words of comfort to him. Ron pulled the parchment
out of Ron’s hands and read it for himself, then looked up at Ron, who felt his hand shaking
on his Butterbeer bottle again and clenched it more tightly to stop the trembling.
If Ron had ever sat through a longer night than this one, he could not remember it. Ron
suggested once, without any real conviction, that they all go to bed, but the Weasleys’ looks of
disgust were answer enough. They mostly sat in silence around the table, watching the candle
wick sinking lower and lower into liquid wax, occasionally raising a bottle to their lips, speaking
only to check the time, to wonder aloud what was happening, and to reassure each other that if
there was bad news, they would know straightaway, for Mrs. Weasley must long since have
arrived at St. Mungo’s.
