Ron fell into a doze, his head lolling sideways on to his shoulder. Ron was curled like a cat on
her chair, but her eyes were open; Ron could see them reflecting the firelight. Ron was sitting
with his head in his hands, whether awake or asleep it was impossible to tell. Ron and Ron
looked at each other every so often, intruders upon the family grief, waiting... waiting...
At ten past five in the morning by Ron’s watch, the kitchen door swung open and Mrs. Weasley
entered the kitchen. She was extremely pale, but when they all turned to look at her, Ron, Ron
and Ron half rising from their chairs, she gave a wan smile.
"He’s going to be all right," she said, her voice weak with tiredness. "He’s sleeping. We can all
go and see him later. Ron’s sitting with him now; he’s going to take the morning off work."
Ron fell back into his chair with his hands over his face. Ron and Ron got up, walked
swiftly over to their mother and hugged her. Ron gave a very shaky laugh and downed the rest of
his Butterbeer in one.
"Breakfast!" said Ron loudly and joyfully, jumping to his feet. "Where’s that accursed house-elf? Ron! Ron!"
But Ron did not answer the summons.
"Oh, forget it, then," muttered Ron, counting the people in front of him. "So, it’s breakfast for -
let’s see - seven... bacon and eggs, I think, and some tea, and toast -"
Ron hurried over to the stove to help. He did not want to intrude on the Weasleys’ happiness
and he dreaded the moment when Mrs. Weasley would ask him to recount his vision. However,
he had barely taken plates from the dresser when Mrs. Weasley lifted them out of his hands and
pulled him into a hug.
"I don’t know what would have happened if it hadn’t been for you, Ron," she said in a muffled
voice. "They might not have found Ron for hours, and then it would have been too late, but
thanks to you he’s alive and Weasley’s been able to think up a good cover story for Ron
being where he was, you’ve no idea what trouble he would have been in otherwise, look at poor
Ron..."
Ron could hardly bear her gratitude, but fortunately she soon released him to turn to Ron and
thank him for looking after her children through the night. Ron said he was very pleased to
have been able to help, and hoped they would all stay with him as long as Mr. Weasley was in
hospital.
"Oh, Ron, I’m so grateful... they think he’ll be there a little while and it would be wonderful to
be nearer... of course, that might mean we’re here for Christmas."
"The more the merrier!" said Ron with such obvious sincerity that Mrs. Weasley beamed at him, threw on an apron and began to help with breakfast.
"Ron," Ron muttered, unable to stand it a moment longer. "Can I have a quick word? Er -
now?"
He walked into the dark pantry and Ron followed. Without preamble, Ron told his godfather
every detail of the vision he had had, including the fact that he himself had been the snake who
had attacked Mr. Weasley.
When he paused for breath, Ron said, "Did you tell Weasley this?"
"Yes," said Ron impatiently, "but he didn’t tell me what it meant. Well, he doesn’t tell me
anything any more."
"I’m sure he would have told you if it was anything to worry about," said Ron steadily.
"But that’s not all," said Ron, in a voice only a little above a whisper. "Ron, I... I think I’m
going mad. Back in Weasley’s office, just before we took the Portkey... for a couple of
seconds there I thought I was a snake, I felt like one - my scar really hurt when I was looking at
Weasley - Ron, I wanted to attack him!"
He could only see a sliver of Rons face; the rest was in darkness.
"It must have been the aftermath of the vision, that’s all," said Ron. "You were still thinking of
the dream or whatever it was and -"
"It wasn’t that," said Ron, shaking his head, "it was like something rose up inside me, like
there’s a snake inside me."
"You need to sleep," said Ron firmly. "You’re going to have breakfast, then go upstairs to bed,
and after lunch you can go and see Ron with the others. You’re in shock, Ron; you’re
blaming yourself for something you only witnessed, and it’s lucky you did witness it or Ron
might have died. Just stop worrying."
He clapped Ron on the shoulder and left the pantry, leaving Ron standing alone in the dark.
Everyone but Ron spent the rest of the morning sleeping. He went up to the bedroom he and
Ron had shared over the last few weeks of summer, but while Ron crawled into bed and was
asleep within minutes, Ron sat fully clothed, hunched against the cold metal bars of the
bedstead, keeping himself deliberately uncomfortable, determined not to fall into a doze, terrified
that he might become the serpent again in his sleep and wake to find that he had attacked Ron, or
else slithered through the house after one of the others...
When Ron woke up, Ron pretended to have enjoyed a refreshing nap too. Their trunks arrived
from Hogwarts while they were eating lunch, so they could dress as Muggles for the trip to St
Mungo’s. Everybody except Ron was riotously happy and talkative as they changed out of their
robes into jeans and sweatshirts. When Weasley and Mad-Eye turned up to escort them across
London, they greeted them gleefully, laughing at the bowler hat Mad-Eye was wearing at an
angle to conceal his magical eye and assuring him, truthfully, that Weasley, whose hair was short
and bright pink again, would attract far less attention on the Underground.
Weasley was very interested in Ron’s vision of the attack on Mr. Weasley, something Ron was
not remotely interested in discussing.
"There isn’t any Seer blood in your family, is there?" she enquired curiously, as they sat side by
side on a train rattling towards the heart of the city.
"No," said Ron, thinking of Professor Weasley and feeling insulted.
"No," said Weasley musingly, "no, I suppose it’s not really prophecy you’re doing, is it? I mean,
you’re not seeing the future, you’re seeing the present... it’s odd, isn’t it? Useful, though..."
Ron didn’t answer; fortunately, they got out at the next stop, a station in the very heart of
London, and in the bustle of leaving the train he was able to allow Ron and Ron to get
between himself and Weasley, who was leading the way. They all followed her up the escalator,
Weasley clunking along at the back of the group, his bowler tilted low and one gnarled hand stuck
in between the buttons of his coat, clutching his wand. Ron thought he sensed the concealed
eye staring hard at him. Trying to avoid any more questions about his dream, he asked Mad-Eye
where St. Mungo’s was hidden.
"Not far from here," grunted Weasley as they stepped out into the wintry air on a broad store-lined
street packed with Christmas shoppers. He pushed Ron a little ahead of him and stumped along
just behind; Ron knew the eye was rolling in all directions under the tilted hat. "Wasn’t easy to
find a good location for a hospital. Nowhere in Diagon Alley was big enough and we couldn’t
have it underground like the Ministry - wouldn’t be healthy. In the end they managed to get hold
of a building up here. Theory was, sick wizards could come and go and just blend in with the
crowd."
He seized Ron’s shoulder to prevent them being separated by a gaggle of shoppers plainly
intent on nothing but making it into a nearby shop full of electrical gadgets.
"Here we go," said Weasley a moment later.
They had arrived outside a large, old-fashioned, red-brick department store called Purge &
Dowse Ltd. The place had a shabby, miserable air; the window displays consisted of a few
chipped dummies with their wigs askew, standing at random and modelling fashions at least ten
years out of date. Large signs on all the dusty doors read: "Closed for Refurbishment". Ron
distinctly heard a large woman laden with plastic shopping bags say to her friend as they passed,
"It’snever open, that place..."
"Right," said Weasley, beckoning them towards a window displaying nothing but a particularly
ugly female dummy. Its false eyelashes were hanging off and it was modelling a green nylon
pinafore dress. "Everybody ready?"
They nodded, clustering around her. Weasley gave Ron another shove between the shoulder
blades to urge him forward and Weasley leaned close to the glass, looking up at the very ugly
dummy, her breath steaming up the glass. "Wotcher... We’re here to see Ron
Weasley."
Ron thought how absurd it was for Weasley to expect the dummy to hear her talking so quietly
through a sheet of glass, with buses rumbling along behind her and all the racket of a street full
of shoppers. Then he reminded himself that dummies couldn’t hear anyway. Next second, his
mouth opened in shock as the dummy gave a tiny nod and beckoned with its jointed finger, and
Weasley had seized Ron and Mrs. Weasley by the elbows, stepped right through the glass and
vanished.
Ron, Ron and Ron stepped after them. Ron glanced around at the jostling crowd; not one of
them seemed to have a glance to spare for window displays as ugly as those of Purge & Dowse
Ltd; nor did any of them seem to have noticed that six people had just melted into thin air in
front of them.
"C’mon," growled Weasley, giving Ron yet another poke in the back, and together they stepped
forward through what felt like a sheet of cool water, emerging quite warm and dry on the other
side.
There was no sign of the ugly dummy or the space where she had stood. They were in what
seemed to be a crowded reception area where rows of witches and wizards sat upon rickety
wooden chairs, some looking perfectly normal and perusing out-of-date copies of WitchWeekly,
others sporting gruesome disfigurements such as elephant trunks or extra hands sticking out of
their chests. The room was scarcely less quiet than the street outside, for many of the patients
were making very peculiar noises: a sweaty-faced witch in the center of the front row, who was
fanning herself vigorously with a copy of the Daily Prophet, kept letting off a high-pitched
whistle as steam came pouring out of her mouth; a grubby-looking warlock in the corner clanged
like a bell every time he moved and, with each clang, his head vibrated horribly so that he had to
seize himself by the ears to hold it steady.
Witches and wizards in lime-green robes were walking up and down the rows, asking questions
and making notes on clipboards like Weasley’s. Ron noticed the emblem embroidered on
their chests: a wand and bone, crossed.
"Are they doctors?" he asked Ron quietly.
"Doctors?" said Ron, looking startled. "Those Muggle nutters that cut people up? Nah, they’re
Healers."
"Over here!" called Mrs. Weasley above the renewed c langing of the warlock in the corner, and
they followed her to the queue in front of a plump blonde witch seated at a desk marked Enquiries. The wall behind her was covered in notices and posters saying things like: A
CLEAN CAULDRON KEEPS POTIONS FROM BECOMING POISONS and ANTIDOTES
ARE ANTI-DON’TS UNLESS APPROVED BY A QUALIFIED HEALER. There was also a
large portrait of a witch with long silver ringlets which was labelled:
Dilys Derwent
St. Mungo’s Healer 1722-
Headmistress of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry 1741-
Dilys was eyeing the Weasley party closely as though counting them; when Ron caught her eye
she gave a tiny wink, walked sideways out of her portrait and vanished.
Meanwhile, at the front of the queue, a young wizard was performing an odd on-the-spot jig and
trying, in between yelps of pain, to explain his predicament to the witch behind the desk.
"It’s these - ouch - shoes my brother gave me - ow- they’re eating my - OUCH - feet - look at
them, there must be some kind of - AARGH - jinx on them and I can’t - AAAAARGH - get
them off." He hopped from one foot to the other as though dancing on hot coals.
"The shoes don’t prevent you reading, do they?" said the blonde witch, irritably pointing at a
large sign to the left of her desk. "You want Spell Damage, fourth floor. Just like it says on the
floor guide. Next!"
As the wizard hobbled and pranced sideways out of the way, the Weasley party moved forward a
few steps and Ron read the floor guide:
ARTEFACT ACCIDENTS... Ground floor
Cauldron explosion, wand backfiring, broom crashes, etc.
CREATURE-INDUCED INJURIES... First floor
Bites, stings, burns, embedded spines, etc.
MAGICAL BUGS... Second floor
Contagious maladies, e.g. dragon pox, vanishing sickness, scrojungulus, etc.
POTION AND PLANT POISONING... Third floor
Rashes,regurgitation (uncontrollable), etc.
SPELL DAMAGE... Fourth floor
Unliftable jinxes, hexes, and incorrectly applied charms, etc.
VISITORS’ TEAROOM AND HOSPITAL SHOP... Fifth floor
IF YOU ARE UNSURE WHERE TO GO, INCAPABLE OF NORMAL SPEECH OR
UNABLE TO REMEMBER WHY YOU ARE HERE, OUR WELCOME WITCH WILL BE
PLEASED TO HELP.
A very old, stooped wizard with a hearing trumpet had shuffled to the front of the queue now.
"I’m here to see Broderick Bode!" he wheezed.
"Ward forty-nine, but I’m afraid you’re wasting your time," said the witch dismissively. "He’s
completely addled, you know - still thinks he’s a teapot. Next!"
A harassed-looking wizard was holding his small daughter tightly by the ankle while she flapped
around his head using the immensely large, feathery wings that had sprouted right out through
the back of her romper suit.
"Fourth floor," said the witch, in a bored voice, without asking, and the man disappeared through
the double doors beside the desk, holding his daughter like an oddly shaped balloon. "Next!"
Mrs. Weasley moved forward to the desk.
"Hello," she said, "my husband, Ron Weasley, was supposed to be moved to a different ward
this morning, could you tell us -?"
"Ron Weasley?" said the witch, running her finger down a long list in front of her. "Yes, first
floor, second door on the right, Dai Llewellyn Ward."
"Thank you," said Mrs. Weasley. "Come on, you lot."
They followed her through the double doors and along the narrow corridor beyond, which was
lined with more portraits of famous Healers and lit by crystal bubbles full of candles that floated
up on the ceiling, looking like giant soapsuds. More witches and wizards in lime-green robes
walked in and out of the doors they passed; a foul-smelling yellow gas wafted into the
passageway as they passed one door, and every now and then they heard distant wailing. They
climbed a flight of stairs and entered the Creature-Induced Injuries corridor, where the second
door on the right bore the words: Dangerous’ Dai Llewellyn Ward: Serious Bites. Underneath
this was a card in a brass holder on which had been handwritten:Healer-in-Charge: Hippocrates
Smethwyck. Trainee Healer: Ron Pye.
"We’ll wait outside, Ron," Weasley said. "Ron won’t want too many visitors at once... it ought to be just the family first."
Mad-Eye growled his approval of this idea and set himself with his back against the corridor
wall, his magical eye spinning in all directions. Ron drew back, too, but Mrs. Weasley reached
out a hand and pushed him through the door, saying, "Don’t be silly, Ron, Ron wants to
thank you."
The ward was small and rather dingy, as the only window was narrow and set high in the wall
facing the door. Most of the light came from more shining crystal bubbles clustered in the middle
of the ceiling. The walls were of panelled oak and there was a portrait of a rather vicious-looking
wizard on the wall, captioned: Urquhart Rackharrow, 1612--1697, Inventor of the Entrail-expelling Curse.
There were only three patients. Mr. Weasley was occupying the bed at the far end of the ward
beside the tiny window. Ron was pleased and relieved to see that he was propped up on several
pillows and reading the Daily Prophet by the solitary ray of sunlight falling on to his bed. He
looked up as they walked towards him and, seeing who it was, beamed.
"Hello!" he called, throwing the Prophet aside. "Ron just left, Ron, had to get back to work, but he says he’ll drop in on you later."
"How are you, Ron?" asked Mrs. Weasley, bending down to kiss his cheek and looking
anxiously into his face. "You’re still looking a bit peaky."
"I feel absolutely fine," said Mr. Weasley brightly, holding out his good arm to give Ron a hug.
"If they could only take the bandages off, I’d be f it to go home."
"Why can’t they take them off, Dad?" asked Ron.
"Well, I start bleeding like mad every time they try," said Mr. Weasley cheerfully, reaching across for his wand, which lay on his bedside cabinet, and waving it so that six extra chairs appeared at his bedside to seat them all. "It seems there was some rather unusual kind of poison in that snake’s fangs that keeps wounds open. They’re sure they’ll find an antidote, though; they say they’ve had much worse cases than mine, and in the meantime I just have to keep taking a
Blood-Replenishing Potion every hour. But that fellow over there," he said, dropping his voice
and nodding towards the bed opposite in which a man lay looking green and sickly and staring at
the ceiling. "Bitten by a werewolf, poor chap. No cure at all."
"A werewolf?" whispered Mrs. Weasley, looking alarmed. "Is he safe in a public ward? Shouldn’t he be in a private room?"
"It’s two weeks till full moon," Mr. Weasley reminded her quietly. "They’ve been talking to him this morning, the Healers, you know, trying to persuade him he’ll be able to lead an almost
normal life. I said to him - didn’t mention names, of course - but I said I knew a werewolf
personally, very nice man, who finds the condition quite easy to manage."
"What did he say?" asked Ron.
"Said he’d give me another bite if I didn’t shut up," said Mr. Weasley sadly. "And that woman
over there," he indicated the only other occupied bed, which was right beside the door, "won’t
tell the Healers what bit her, which makes us all think it must have been something she was
handling illegally. Whatever it was took a real chunk out of her leg,very nasty smell when they
take off the dressings."
"So, you going to tell us what happened, Dad?" asked Ron, pulling his chair closer to the bed.
"Well, you already know, don’t you?" said Mr. Weasley, with a significant smile at Ron. "It’s
very simple - I’d had a very long day, dozed off, got sneaked up on and bitten."
"Is it in the Prophet, you being attacked?" asked Ron, indicating the newspaper Mr. Weasley had cast aside.
"No, of course not," said Mr. Weasley, with a slightly bitter smile, "the Ministry wouldn’t want
everyone to know a dirty great serpent got --"
"Ron!" Mrs. Weasley warned him.
"- got - er - me," Mr. Weasley said hastily, though Ron was quite sure that was not what he had
meant to say.
"So where were you when it happened, Dad?" asked Ron.
"That’s my business," said Mr. Weasley, though with a small smile. He snatched up the Daily
Prophe, shook it open again and said, "I was just reading about Willy Widdershins’s arrest
when you arrived. You know Willy turned out to be behind those regurgitating toilets back in the
summer? One of his jinxes backfired, the toilet exploded and they found him lying unconscious
in the wreckage covered from head to foot in -"
"When you say you were ‘on duty’," Ron interrupted in a low voice, "what were you doing?"
"You heard your father," whispered Mrs. Weasley, "we are not discussing this here! Go on about
Willy Widdershins, Ron."
"Well, don’t ask me how, but he actually got off the toilet charge," said Mr. Weasley grimly. "I
can only suppose gold changed hands -"
"You were guarding it, weren’t you?" said Ron quietly. "The weapon? The thing You-Know-
Who’s after?"
"Ron, be quiet!" snapped Mrs. Weasley.
"Anyway," said Mr. Weasley, in a raised voice, "this time Willy’s been caught selling biting
doorknobs to Muggles and I don’t think he’ll be able to worm his way out of it because,
according to this article, two Muggles have lost fingers and are now in St. Mungo’s for
emergency bone re-growth and memory modification. Just think of it, Muggles in St. Mungo’s! I
wonder which ward they’re in?"
And he looked eagerly around as though hoping to see a signpost.
"Didn’t you say You-Know-Who’s got a snake, Ron?" asked Ron, looking at his father for a
reaction. "A massive one? You saw it the night he returned, didn’t you?"
"That’s enough," said Mrs. Weasley crossly. "Mad-Eye and Weasley are outside, Ron, they want
to come and see you. And you lot can wait outside," she added to her children and Ron. "You
can come and say goodbye afterwards. Go on."
They trooped back into the corridor. Mad-Eye and Weasley went in and closed the door of the ward
behind them. Ron raised his eyebrows.
"Fine," he said coolly, rummaging in his pockets, "be like that. Don’t tell us anything."
"Looking for these?" said Ron, holding out what looked like a tangle of flesh-colored string.
"You read my mind," said Ron, grinning. "Let’s see if St. Mungo’s puts Imperturbable Charms on its ward doors, shall we?"
He and Ron disentangled the string and separated five Extendable Ears from each other. Ron
and Ron handed them around. Ron hesitated to take one.
"Go on, Ron, take it! You saved Dad’s life. If anyone’s got the right to eavesdrop on him, it’s
you."
Grinning in spite of himself, Ron took the end of the string and inserted it into his ear as the
twins had done.
"Okay, go!" Ron whispered.
The flesh-colored strings wriggled like long skinny worms and snaked under the door. At first,
Ron could hear nothing, then he jumped as he heard Weasley whispering as clearly as though she
were standing right beside him.
"... they searched the whole area but couldn’t find the snake anywhere. It just seems to have
vanished after it attacked you, Ron... but You-Know-Who can’t have expected a snake to get
in, can he?"
"I reckon he sent it as a lookout," growled Weasley, "cause he’s not had any luck so far, has he?
No, I reckon he’s trying to get a clearer picture of what he’s facing and if Ron hadn’t been
there the beast would’ve had a lot more time to look around. So, Weasley says he saw it all
happen?"
"Yes," said Mrs. Weasley. She sounded rather uneasy. "You know, Weasley seems almost to
have been waiting for Ron to see something like this."
"Yeah, well," said Weasley, "there’s something funny about the Weasley kid, we all know that."
"Weasley seemed worried about Ron when I spoke to him this morning," whispered Mrs
Weasley.
"Course he’s worried," growled Weasley. "The boy’s seeing things from inside You-Know-Who’s
snake. Obviously, Weasley doesn’t realize what that means, but if You-Know-Who’s possessing
him --"
Ron pulled the Extendable Ear out of his own, his heart hammering very fast and heat rushing
up his face. He looked around at the others. They were all staring at him, the strings still trailing
from their ears, looking suddenly fearful.
CHAPTER TWENTY-THREE
Christmas on the Closed Ward
Was this why Weasley would no longer meet Ron’s eyes? Did he expect to see Weasley
staring out of them, afraid, perhaps, that their vivid green might turn suddenly to scarlet, with
catlike slits for pupils? Ron remembered how the snakelike face of Weasley had once forced
itself out of the back of Professor Weasley’s head and ran his hand over the back of his own,
wondering what it would feel like if Weasley burst out of his skull.
He felt dirty, contaminated, as though he were carrying some deadly germ, unworthy to sit on the
Underground train back from the hospital with innocent, clean people whose minds and bodies
were free of the taint of Weasley... he had not merely seen the snake, he hadbeen the snake, he
knew it now...
A truly terrible thought then occurred to him, a memory bobbing to the surface of his mind, one
that made his insides writhe and squirm like serpents.
What’s he after, apart from followers?
Stuff he can only get by stealth... like a weapon. Something he didn’t have last time.
I’m the weapon, Ron thought, and it was as though poison were pumping through his veins,
chilling him, bringing him out in a sweat as he swayed with the train through the dark tunnel. I’m
the one Weasleys trying to use, that’s why they’ve got guards around me everywhere I go, it’s
not for my protection, it’s for other people’s, only it’s not working, they can’t have someone on
me all the time at Hogwarts... I did attack Mr. Weasley last night, it was me. Weasley made me do it and he could be inside me, listening to my thoughts right now -
"Are you all right, Ron, dear?" whispered Mrs. Wea sley leaning across Ron to speak to him as the train rattled along through its dark tunnel. "You don’t look very well. Are you feeling sick?"
They were all watching him. He shook his head violently and stared up at an advertisement for
home insurance.
"Ron, dear, are you sure you’re all right?" said Mrs. Weasley in a worried voice, as they walked around the unkempt patch of grass in the middle of Grimmauld Place. "You look ever so pale... are you sure you slept this morning? You go upstairs to bed right now and you can have a couple of hours of sleep before dinner, all right?"
He nodded; here was a ready-made excuse not to talk to any of the others, which was precisely
what he wanted, so when she opened the front door he hurried straight past the troll’s-leg
umbrella stand, up the stairs and into his and Ron’s bedroom.
Here, he began to pace up and down, past the two beds and Phineas ’s empty picture
frame, his brain teeming and seething with questions and ever more dreadful ideas.
How had he become a snake? Perhaps he was an Animagus... no, he couldn’t be, he would
know... perhapsWeasley was an Animagus... yes, thought Ron, that would fit, he would turn
into a snake of course... and when he’s possessing me, then we both transform... that still
doesn’t explain how I got to London and back to my bed in the space of about five minutes... but
then Weasley’s about the most powerful wizard in the world, apart from Weasley, it’s
probably no problem at all to him to transport people like that.
And then, with a terrible stab of panic, he thought,but this is insane - if Weasley’s possessing
me, I’m giving him a clear view into the Headquarter s of the Order of the Phoenix right now!
He’ll know who’s in the Order and where Ron is... and I’ve heard loads of stuff I shouldn’t
have, everything Ron told me the first night I was here...
There was only one thing for it: he would have to leave Grimmauld Place straightaway. He
would spend Christmas at Hogwarts without the others, which would keep them safe over the
holidays at least... but no, that wouldn’t do, there were still plenty of people at Hogwarts to
maim and injure. What if it was Ron, Ron or Ron next time? He stopped his pacing and
stood staring at Phineas ’s empty frame. A leaden sensation was settling in the pit of his
stomach. He had no alternative: he was going to have to return to Privet Drive, cut himself off
from other wizards entirely.
Well, if he had to do it, he thought, there was no point hanging around. Trying with all his might
not to think how the Weasleys were going to react when they found him on their doorstep six
months earlier than they had expected, he strode over to his trunk, slammed the lid shut and
locked it, then glanced around automatically for Ron before remembering that she was still at
Hogwarts - well, her cage would be one less thing to carry - he seized one end of his trunk and
had dragged it halfway towards the door when a snide voice said, "Running away, are we?"
He looked around. Phineas  had appeared on the canvas of his portrait and was leaning
against the frame, watching Ron with an amused expression on his face.
"Not running away, no," said Ron shortly, dragging his trunk a few more feet across the room.
"I thought," said Phineas , stroking his pointed beard, "that to belong in Weasley house you were supposed to be brave! It looks to me as though you would have been better off in my own house. We Weasleys are brave, yes, but not stupid. For instance, given the choice, we will always choose to save our own necks."
"It’s not my own neck I’m saving," said Ron tersely, tugging the trunk over a patch of
particularly uneven, moth-eaten carpet right in front of the door.
"Oh, I see," said Phineas , still stroking his beard, "this is no cowardly flight - you are
being noble."
Ron ignored him. His hand was on the doorknob when Phineas  said lazily, "I have a
message for you from Ron Weasley."
Ron span round.
"What is it?"
"‘Stay where you are.’"
"I haven’t moved!" said Ron, his hand still upon the doorknob. "So what’s the message?"
"I have just given it to you, dolt," said Phineas Ni gellus smoothly. "Weasley says, ‘Stay
where you are.’"
"Why?" said Ron eagerly, dropping the end of his trunk. "Why does he want me to stay? What
else did he say?"
"Nothing whatsoever," said Phineas , raising a thin black eyebrow as though he found
Ron impertinent.
Ron’s temper rose to the surface like a snake rearing from long grass. He was exhausted, he
was confused beyond measure, he had experienced terror, relief, then terror again in the last
twelve hours, and still Weasley did not want to talk to him!
"So that’s it, is it?" he said loudly. "‘Stay where you a re’! That’s all anyone could tell me after I got attacked by those Dementors, too! Just stay put while the grown-ups sort it out, Ron! We won’t bother telling you anything, though, because your tiny little brain might not be able to cope with it!"
"You know," said Phineas , even more loudly than Ron "this is precisely why I loathed
being a teacher! Young people are so infernally convinced that they are absolutely right about
everything. Has it not occurred to you, my poor puffed-up popinjay, that there might be an
excellent reason why the Headmaster of Hogwarts is not confiding every tiny detail of his plans
to you? Have you never paused, while feeling hard-done-by, to note that following Weasleys
orders has never yet led you into harm? No. No, like all young people, you are quite sure that
you alone feel and think, you alone recognize danger, you alone are the only one clever enough
to realize what the Dark Lord may be planning -"
"He is planning something to do with me, then?" said Ron swiftly.
"Did I say that?" said Phineas , idly examining his silk gloves. "Now, if you will excuse
me, I have better things to do than listen to adolescent agonising... good-day to you."
And he strolled to the edge of his frame and out of sight.
"Fine, go then!" Ron bellowed at the empty frame. "And tell Weasley thanks for nothing!"
The empty canvas remained silent. Fuming, Ron dragged his trunk back to the foot of his bed,
then threw himself face down on the moth-eaten covers, his eyes shut, his body heavy and
aching.
He felt as though he had journeyed for miles and miles... it seemed impossible that less than
twenty-four hours ago Ron Weasley had been approaching him under the mistletoe... he was so
tired... he was scared to sleep... yet he did not know how long he could fight it... Weasley
had told him to stay... that must mean he was allowed to sleep... but he was scared... what if it
happened again?
He was sinking into shadows...
It was as though a film in his head had been waiting to start. He was walking down a deserted
corridor towards a plain black door, past rough stone walls, torches, and an open doorway on to a
flight of stone steps leading downstairs on the left...
He reached the black door but could not open it... he stood gazing at it, desperate for entry...
something he wanted with all his heart lay beyond... a prize beyond his dreams... if only his scar
would stop prickling... then he would be able to think more clearly...
"Ron," said Ron’s voice, from far, far away, "Mum says dinner’s ready, but she’ll save you
something if you want to stay in bed."
Ron opened his eyes, but Ron had already left the room.
He doesn’t want to be on his own with me, Ron thought. Not after what he heard Weasley say.
He supposed none of them would want him there any more, now that they knew what was inside
him.
He would not go down to dinner; he would not inflict his company on them. He turned over on to
his other side and, after a while, dropped back off to sleep. He woke much later, in the early
hours of the morning, his insides aching with hunger and Ron snoring in the next bed. Squinting
around the room, he saw the dark outline of Phineas  standing again in his portrait and it
occurred to Ron that Weasley had probably sent Phineas  to watch over him, in
case he attacked somebody else.
The feeling of being unclean intensified. He half-wished he had not obeyed Weasley... if this
was how life was going to be for him in Grimmauld Place from now on, maybe he would be
better off in Privet Drive after all.
Everybody else spent the following morning putting up Christmas decorations. Ron could not
remember Ron ever being in such a good mood; he was actually singing carols, apparently
delighted that he was to have company over Christmas. Ron could hear his voice echoing up
through the floor in the cold drawing room where he was sitting alone, watching the sky growing
whiter outside the windows, threatening snow, all the time feeling a savage pleasure that he was
giving the others the opportunity to keep talking about him, as they were bound to be doing.
When he heard Mrs. Weasley calling his name softly u p the stairs around lunchtime, he retreated
further upstairs and ignored her.
Around six o’clock in the evening the doorbell rang and Mrs. Weasley started screaming again.
Assuming that Ron or some other Order member had come to call, Ron merely settled
himself more comfortably against the wall of Ron’s room where he was hiding, trying to
ignore how hungry he felt as he fed dead rats to the Hippogriff. It came as a slight shock when
somebody hammered hard on the door a few minutes later.
"I know you’re in there," said Ron’s voice. "Will you please come out? I want to talk to
you."
"What are you doing here?" Ron asked her, pulling open the door as Ron resumed his
scratching at the straw-strewn floor for any fragments of rat he may have dropped. "I thought you were skiing with your mum and dad?"
"Well, to tell the truth, skiing’s not really my thing," said Ron. "So, I’ve come here for
Christmas." There was snow in her hair and her face was pink with cold. "But don’t tell Ron. I
told him it’s really good because he kept laughing so much. Mum and Dad are a bit
disappointed, but I’ve told them that everyone who is serious about the exams is staying at
Hogwarts to study. They want me to do well, they’ll understand. Anyway," she said briskly,
"let’s go to your bedroom, Ron’s mum has lit a fire in there and she’s sent up sandwiches."
Ron followed her back to the second floor. When he entered the bedroom, he was rather
surprised to see both Ron and Ron waiting for them, sitting on Ron’s bed.
"I came on the Knight Bus," said Ron airily, pulling off her jacket before Ron had time to speak. "Weasley told me what had happened first thing this morning, but I had to wait for
term to end officially before setting off. Weasley is already livid that you lot disappeared right
under her nose, even though Weasley told her Mr. Weasley was in St. Mungo’s and he’d
given you all permission to visit. So..."
She sat down next to Ron, and the two girls and Ron all looked up at Ron.
"How’re you feeling?" asked Ron.
"Fine," said Ron stiffly.
"Oh, don’t lie, Ron," she said impatiently. "Ron and Ron say you’ve been hiding from
everyone since you got back from St. Mungo’s."
"They do, do they?" said Ron, glaring at Ron and Ron. Ron looked down at his feet but
Ron seemed quite unabashed.
"Well, you have!" she said. "And you won’t look at any of us!"
"It’s you lot who won’t look at me!" said Ron ang rily.
"Maybe you’re taking it in turns to look, and keep missing each other," suggested Ron, the
corners of her mouth twitching.
"Very funny," snapped Ron, turning away.
"Oh, stop feeling all misunderstood," said Ron sharply. "Look, the others have told me what you overheard last night on the Extendable Ears -"
"Yeah?" growled Ron, his hands deep in his pockets as he watched the snow now falling
thickly outside. "All been talking about me, have you? Well, I’m getting used to it."
"We wanted to talk to you, Ron," said Ron, "but as you’ve been hiding ever since we got back -"
"I didn’t want anyone to talk to me," said Ron, w ho was feeling more and more nettled.
"Well, that was a bit stupid of you," said Ron angrily, "seeing as you don’t know anyone but
me who’s been possessed by You-Know-Who, and I can tell you how it feels."
Ron remained quite still as the impact of these words hit him. Then he wheeled round.
"I forgot," he said.
"Lucky you," said Ron coolly.
"I’m sorry" Ron said, and he meant it. "So... so, do you think I’m being possessed, then?"
"Well, can you remember everything you’ve been doing?" Ron asked. "Are there big blank
periods where you don’t know what you’ve been up to?"
Ron racked his brains.
"No," he said.
"Then You-Know-Who hasn’t ever possessed you," said Ron simply. "When he did it to me, I
couldn’t remember what I’d been doing for hours at a time. I’d find myself somewhere and not
know how I got there."
Ron hardly dared believe her, yet his heart was lightening almost in spite of himself.
"That dream I had about your dad and the snake, though --"
"Ron you’ve had these dreams before," Ron said. "You had flashes of what Weasley
was up to last year."
"This was different," said Ron, shaking his head. "I was inside that snake. It was like I was the
snake... what if Weasley somehow transported me to London --?"
"One day," said Ron, sounding thoroughly exasperated, "you’ll read Hogwarts: A History,
and perhaps it will remind you that you can’t Apparate or Disapparate inside Hogwarts. Even
Weasley couldn’t just make you fly out of your dormitory, Ron."
"You didn’t leave your bed, mate," said Ron. "I saw you thrashing around in your sleep for at
least a minute before we could wake you up."
Ron started pacing up and down the room again, thinking. What they were all saying was not
only comforting, it made sense... without really thinking, he took a sandwich from the plate on
the bed and crammed it hungrily into his mouth.
I’m not the weapon after all, thought Ron. His heart swelled with happiness and relief, and he
felt like joining in as they heard Ron tramping past their door towards Ron’s room, singing "God Rest Ye, Merry Hippogriffs" at the top of his voice.
How could he have dreamed of returning to Privet Drive for Christmas? Ron’s delight at
having the house full again, and especially at having Ron back, was infectious. He was no
longer their sullen host of the summer; now he seemed determined that everyone should enjoy
themselves as much, if not more than they would have done at Hogwarts, and he worked
tirelessly in the run-up to Christmas Day, cleaning and decorating with their help, so that by the
time they all went to bed on Christmas Eve the house was barely recognisable. The tarnished
chandeliers were no longer hung with cobwebs but with garlands of holly and gold and silver
streamers; magical snow glittered in heaps over the threadbare carpets; a great Christmas tree,
obtained by Ron and decorated with live fairies, blocked Ron’s family tree from view,
and even the stuffed elf-heads on the hall wall wore Ronher Christmas hats and beards.
Ron awoke on Christmas morning to find a stack of presents at the foot of his bed and Ron
already halfway through opening his own, rather larger, pile.
"Good haul this year," he informed Ron through a cloud of paper. "Thanks for the Broom
Compass, it’s excellent; beats Rons - she got me a homework planner-"
Ron sorted through his presents and found one with Rons handwriting on it. She had
given him, too, a book that resembled a diary except that it said things like "Do it today or later you'll pay!" every time he opend a page.
Ron and Weasley had given Ron a set of excellent books entitled Practical Defensive Magic and its Use Against the Dark Arts, which had superb, moving color illustrations of all the counterjinxes and hexes it described. Ron flicked through the first volume eagerly; he could see it was going to be highly useful in his plans for the D.A.. Weasley had sent a furry brown wallet that had fangs, which were presumably supposed to be an anti-theft device, but unfortunately prevented Ron putting any money in without getting his fingers ripped off. Weasley’s present was a small, working model of a Firebolt, which Ron watched fly around the room, wishing he still
had his full-size version; Ron had given him an enormous box of Every-Flavour Beans, Mr. and Mrs. Weasley the usual hand-knitted jumper and some mince pies, and Ron a truly dreadful
painting that Ron suspected had been done by the elf himself. He had just turned it upsidedown
to see whether it looked better that way when, with a loudcrack, Ron and Ron
Apparated at the foot of his bed.
"Merry Christmas," said Ron. "Don’t go downstairs for a bit."
"Why not?" said Ron.
"Mum’s crying again," said Ron heavily. "Ron sent back his Christmas jumper."
"Without a note," added Ron. "Hasn’t asked how Dad is or visited him or anything."
"We tried to comfort her," said Ron, moving around the bed to look at Ron’s portrait. "Told her Ron’s nothing more than a humungous pile of rat droppings."
"Didn’t work," said Ron, helping himself to a Roncolate Frog. "So Weasley took over. Best let
him cheer her up before we go down for breakfast, I reckon."
"What’s that supposed to be, anyway?" asked Ron, squinting at Ron’s painting. "Looks like a
gibbon with two black eyes."
"It’s Ron!" said Ron, pointing at the back of the picture, "says so on the back!"
"Good likeness," said Ron, grinning. Ron threw his new homework diary at him; it hit the wall
opposite and fell to the floor where it said happily: "If you’ve dotted the ‘i’s and crossed the ‘t’s then you may do whatever you please!"
They got up and dressed. They could hear the various inhabitants of the house calling "Merry
Christmas" to one another. On their way downstairs they met Ron.
"Thanks for the book, Ron" she said happily. "I’ve been wanting that New Theory of
Numerology for ages! And that perfume’s really unusual, Ron."
"No problem," said Ron. "Who’s that for, anyway?" he added, nodding at the neatly wrapped
present she was carrying.
"Ron," said Ron brightly.
"It had better not be clothes!" Ron warned her. "You know what Ron said: Ron knows too much, we can’t set him free!"
"It isn’t clothes," said Ron, "although if I had my way I’d certainly give him something to
wear other than that filthy old rag. No, it’s a patchwork quilt, I thought it would brighten up his
bedroom."
"What bedroom?" said Ron, dropping his voice to a whisper as they were passing the portrait of Ron’s mother.
"Well, Ron says it’s not so much a bedroom, more a kind of -den," said Ron. "Apparently he sleeps under the boiler in that cupboard off the kitchen."
Mrs. Weasley was the only person in the basement when they arrived there. She was standing at
the stove and sounded as though she had a bad head cold as she wished them "Merry Christmas,"
and they all averted their eyes.
"So, is this Ron’s bedroom?" said Ron, strolling over to a dingy door in the corner opposite
the pantry. Ron had never seen it open.
"Yes," said Ron, now sounding a little nervous. "Er... I think we’d better knock."
Ron rapped on the door with his knuckles but there was no reply.
"He must be sneaking around upstairs," he said, and without further ado pulled open the door.
"Urgh!"
Ron peered inside. Most of the cupboard was taken up with a very large and old-fashioned
boiler, but in the foot’s space underneath the pipes Ron had made himself something that
looked like a nest. A jumble of assorted rags and smelly old blankets were piled on the floor and
the small dent in the middle of it showed where Ron curled up to sleep every night. Here
and there among the material were stale bread crusts and mouldy old bits of cheese. In a far
corner glinted small objects and coins that Ron guessed Ron had saved, magpie-like, from
Ron’s purge of the house, and he had also managed to retrieve the silver-framed family
photographs that Ron had thrown away over the summer. Their glass might be shattered, but
still the little black-and-white people inside them peered up at him haughtily, including - he felt a
little jolt in his stomach - the dark, heavy-lidded woman whose trial he had witnessed in
Weasley’s Pensieve: Weasleyatrix Weasley. By the looks of it, hers was Ron’s favorite
photograph; he had placed it to the fore of all the others and had mended the glass clumsily with
Spellotape.
"I think I’ll just leave his present here," said Ron, laying the package neatly in the middle
of the depression in the rags and blankets and closing the door quietly. "He’ll find it later, that’ll
be fine."
"Come to think of it," said Ron, emerging from the pantry carrying a large turkey as they closed the cupboard door, "has anyone actually seen Ron lately?"
"I haven’t seen him since the night we came back here," said Ron. "You were ordering him out of the kitchen."
"Yeah..." said Ron, frowning. "You know, I think that’s the last time I saw him, too... he must
be hiding upstairs somewhere."
"He couldn’t have left, could he?" said Ron. "I mean, when you said ‘out’, maybe he thought you meant get out of the house?"
"No, no, house-elves can’t leave unless they’re given clothes. They’re tied to their family’s
house," said Ron.
"They can leave the house if they really want to," Ron contradicted him. "Ron did, he left the Weasleys’ to give me warnings two years ago. He had to punish himself afterwards, but he still managed it."
Ron looked slightly disconcerted for a moment, then said, "I’ll look for him later, I expect I’ll
find him upstairs crying his eyes out over my mother’s old bloomers or something. Of course, he
might have crawled into the airing cupboard and died... but I mustn’t get my hopes up."
Ron, Ron and Ron laughed; Ron, however, looked reproachful.
Once they had eaten their Christmas lunch, the Weasleys, Ron and Ron were planning to
pay Mr. Weasley another visit, escorted by Mad-Eye and Weasley. Ron turned up in time
for Christmas pudding and trifle, having managed to ‘borrow’ a car for the occasion, as the
Underground did not run on Christmas Day. The car, which Ron doubted very much had been
taken with the knowledge or consent of it's owner, had had a similar Enlarging Spell put upon it as the Weasley's old Ford Anglia; although normally proportioned outside, ten people with Ron driving were able to fit into it quite comfortably. Mrs. Weasley hesitated before getting inside - Ron knew her disapproval of Ron was battling with her dislike of traveling without magic - but, finally, the cold outside and her children’s pleading triumphed, and she settled herself into the back seat between Ron and Ron with good grace.
The journey to St. Mungo’s was quite quick as there was very little traffic on the roads. A small
trickle of witches and wizards was creeping furtively up the otherwise deserted street to visit the
hospital. Ron and the others got out of the car, and Ron drove off around the corner to
wait for them. They strolled casually towards the window where the dummy in green nylon
stood, then, one by one, stepped through the glass.
The reception area looked pleasantly festive: the crystal orbs that illuminated St. Mungo’s had
been colored red and gold to become gigantic, glowing Christmas baubles; holly hung around
every doorway; and shining white Christmas trees covered in magical snow and icicles glittered
in every corner, each one topped with a gleaming gold star. It was less crowded than the last time
they had been there, although halfway across the room Ron found himself shunted aside by a
witch with a walnut jammed up her left nostril.
"Family argument, eh?" smirked the blonde witch behind the desk. "You’re the third I’ve seen
today... Spell Damage, fourth floor."
They found Mr. Weasley propped up in bed with the remains of his turkey dinner on a tray on his
lap and a rather sheepish expression on his face.
"Everything all right, Ron?" asked Mrs. Weasley, after they had all greeted Mr. Weasley and
handed over their presents.
"Fine, fine," said Mr. Weasley, a little too heartily. "You -- er -- haven’t seen Healer
Smethwyck, have you?"
"No," said Mrs. Weasley suspiciously, "why?"
"Nothing, nothing," said Mr. Weasley airily, starting to unwrap his pile of gifts. "Well, everyone
had a good day? What did you all get for Christmas? Oh, Ron - this is absolutely wonderful!" For he had just opened Ron’s gift of fuse-wire and screwdrivers.
Mrs. Weasley did not seem entirely satisfied with Mr. Weasley’s answer. As her husband leaned
over to shake Ron’s hand, she peered at the bandaging under his nightshirt.
"Ron," she said, with a snap in her voice like a mousetrap, "you’ve had your bandages
changed. Why have you had your bandages changed a day early, Ron? They told me they
wouldn’t need doing until tomorrow."
"What?" said Mr. Weasley, looking rather frightened and pulling the bed covers higher up his
chest. "No, no - it’s nothing - it’s -I-"
He seemed to deflate under Mrs. Weasley’s piercing gaze.
"Well - now don’t get upset, Ron, but Ron Pye had an idea... he’s the Trainee Healer, you know, lovely young chap and very interested in... um... complementary medicine... I mean,
some of these old Muggle remedies... well, they’re called stitches, Ron, and they work very
well on - on Muggle wounds -"
Mrs. Weasley let out an ominous noise somewhere between a shriek and a snarl. Weasley strolled
away from the bed and over to the werewolf, who had no visitors and was looking rather
wistfully at the crowd around Mr. Weasley; Ron muttered something about getting himself a cup
of tea and Ron and Ron leapt up to accompany him, grinning.
"Do you mean to tell me," said Mrs. Weasley, her voice growing louder with every word and
apparently unaware that her fellow visitors were scurrying for cover, "that you have been
messing about with Muggle remedies?"
"Not messing about, Ron, dear," said Mr. Weasley imploringly, "it was just - just something Pye and I thought we’d try - only, most unfortunately -- well, with these particular kinds of wounds - it doesn’t seem to work as well as we’d hoped -"
"Meaning?"
"Well... well, I don’t know whether you know what - what stitches are?"
"It sounds as though you’ve been trying to sew your skin back together," said Mrs. Weasley with
a snort of mirthless laughter, "but even you, Ron, wouldn’t be that stupid --"
"I fancy a cup of tea, too," said Ron, jumping to his feet.
Ron, Ron and Ron almost sprinted to the door with him. As it swung closed behind them,
they heard Mrs. Weasley shriek, "WHAT DO YOU MEAN, TH AT’S THE GENERAL IDEA?"
"Typical Dad," said Ron, shaking her head as they set off up the corridor. "Stitches... I ask
you..."
"Well, you know, they do work well on non-magical wounds," said Ron fairly. "I suppose
something in that snake’s venom dissolves them or something. I wonder where the tearoom is?"
"Fifth floor," said Ron, remembering the sign over the welcome witch’s desk.
They walked along the corridor, through a set of double doors and found a rickety staircase lined
with more portraits of brutal-looking Healers. As they climbed it, the various Healers called out
to them, diagnosing odd complaints and suggesting horrible remedies. Ron was seriously
affronted when a medieval wizard called out that he clearly had a bad case of spattergroit.
"And what’s that supposed to be?" he asked angrily, as the Healer pursued him through six more
portraits, shoving the occupants out of the way.
"Tis a most grievous affliction of the skin, young master, that will leave you pockmarked and
more gruesome even than you are now -"
"Watch who you’re calling gruesome!" said Ron, his ears turning red.
"- the only remedy is to take the liver of a toad, bind it tight about your throat, stand naked at the
full moon in a barrel of eels’ eyes -"
"I have not got spattergroit!"
"But the unsightly blemishes upon your visage, young master -"
"They’re freckles!" said Ron furiously. "Now get back in your own picture and leave me alone!"
He rounded on the others, who were all keeping determinedly straight faces.
"What floor’s this?"
"I think it’s the fifth," said Ron.
"Nah, it’s the fourth," said Ron, "one more --"
But as he stepped on to the landing he came to an abrupt halt, staring at the small window set
into the double doors that marked the start of a corridor signposted SPELL DAMAGE. A man
was peering out at them all with his nose pressed against the glass. He had wavy blond hair,
bright blue eyes and a broad vacant smile that revealed dazzlingly white teeth.
"Blimey!" said Ron, also staring at the man.
"Oh, my goodness," said Ron suddenly, sounding breathless. "Professor Weasley!"
Their ex-Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher pushed open the doors and moved towards
them, wearing a long lilac dressing gown.
"Well, hello there!" he said. "I expect you’d like my autograph, would you?"
"Hasn’t changed much, has he?" Ron muttered to Ron, who grinned.
"Er -- how are you, Professor?" said Ron, sounding slightly guilty. It had been Ron’s
malfunctioning wand that had damaged Professor Weasley’s memory so badly that he had
landed in St. Mungo’s in the first place, though as Weasley had been attempting to permanently
wipe Ron and Ron’s memories at the time, Rons sympathy was limited.
"I’m very well indeed, thank you!" said Weasley exuberantly, pulling a rather battered peacockfeather quill from his pocket. "Now, how many autographs would you like? I can do joined-up writing now, you know!"
"Er - we don’t want any at the moment, thanks," said Ron, raising his eyebrows at Ron, who
asked, "Professor, should you be wandering around the corridors? Shouldn’t you be in a ward?"
The smile faded slowly from Weasley’s face. For a few moments he gazed intently at Ron,
then he said, "Haven’t we met?"
"Er... yeah, we have," said Ron. "You used to teach us at Hogwarts, remember?"
"Teach?" repeated Weasley, looking faintly unsettled. "Me? Did I?"
And then the smile reappeared upon his face so suddenly it was rather alarming.
"Taught you everything you know, I expect, did I? Well, how about those autographs, then?
Shall we say a round dozen, you can give them to all your little friends then and nobody will be
left out!"
But just then a head poked out of a door at the far end of the corridor and a voice called,
"Ron, you naughty boy, where have you wandered off to?"
A motherly-looking Healer wearing a tinsel wreath in her hair came bustling up the corridor,
smiling warmly at Ron and the others.
"Oh, Ron, you’ve got visitors! How lovely, and on Christmas Day, too! Do you know,
he never gets visitors, poor lamb, and I can’t think why, he’s such a sweetie, aren’t you?"
"We’re doing autographs!" Ron told the Healer with another glittering smile. "They want
loads of them, won’t take no for an answer! I just hope we’ve got enough photographs!"
"Listen to him," said the Healer, taking Weasley’s arm and beaming fondly at him as though he
were a precocious two-year-old. "He was rather well known a few years ago; we very much hope
that this liking for giving autographs is a sign that his memory might be starting to come back.
Will you step this way? He’s in a closed ward, you know, he must have slipped out while I was
bringing in the Christmas presents, the door’s usually kept locked... not that he’s dangerous!
But," she lowered her voice to a whisper, "he’s a bit of a danger to himself, bless him... doesn’t
know who he is, you see, wanders off and can’t remember how to get back... it is nice of you to
have come to see him."
"Er," said Ron, gesturing uselessly at the floor above, "actually, we were just -- er -"
But the Healer was smiling expectantly at them, and Ron’s feeble mutter of "going to have a cup
of tea" trailed away into nothingness. They looked at each other helplessly, then followed
Weasley and his Healer along the corridor.
"Let’s not stay long," Ron said quietly.
The Healer pointed her wand at the door of the Janus Thickey Ward and muttered, "Alohomora."
The door swung open and she led the way inside, keeping a firm grasp on Rons arm until
she had settled him into an armchair beside his bed.
"This is our long-term residents’ ward," she informed Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron
in a low voice. "For permanent spell damage, you know. Of course, with intensive remedial potions and charms and a bit of luck, we can produce some improvement. Ron does seem to be getting back some sense of himself; and we’ve seen a real improvement in Mr. Bode, he seems to be regaining th e power of speech very well, though he isn’t speaking any language we recognize yet. Well, I must finish giving out the Christmas presents, I’ll leave you all to chat."
Ron looked around. The ward bore unmistakable signs of being a permanent home to its
residents. They had many more personal effects around their beds than in Mr. Weasley’s ward;
the wall around Ron’s headboard, for instance, was papered with pictures of himself, all
beaming toothily and waving at the new arrivals. He had autographed many of them to himself in
disjointed, childish writing. The moment he had been deposited in his chair by the Healer,
Ron pulled a fresh stack of photographs towards him, seized a quill and started signing them
all feverishly.
"You can put them in envelopes," he said to Ron, throwing the signed pictures into her lap one
by one as he finished them. "I am not forgotten, you know, no, I still receive a very great deal of
fan mail... Gladys Gudgeon writes weekly... I just wish I knew why." He paused, looking faintly puzzled, then beamed again and returned to his signing with renewed vigour. "I suspect it is simply my good looks..."
A sallow-skinned, mournful-looking wizard lay in the bed opposite staring at the ceiling; he was
mumbling to himself and seemed quite unaware of anything around him. Two beds along was a
woman whose entire head was covered in fur; Ron remembered something similar happening
to Ron during their second year, although fortunately the damage, in her case, had not been
permanent. At the far end of the ward flowery curtains had been drawn around two beds to give
the occupants and their visitors some privacy.
"Here you are, Agnes," said the Healer brightly to the furry-faced woman, handing her a small
pile of Christmas presents. "See, not forgotten, are you? And your son’s sent an owl to say he’s
visiting tonight, so that’s nice, isn’t it?"
Agnes gave several loud barks.
"And look, Broderick, you’ve been sent a potted plant and a lovely calendar with a different fancy Hippogriff for each month; they’ll brighten things up, won’t they?" said the Healer, bustling along to the mumbling man, setting a rather ugly plant with long, swaying tentacles on the bedside cabinet and fixing the calendar to the wall with her wand. "And - oh, Mrs. Weasley, are you leaving already?"
Ron’s head span round. The curtains had been drawn back from the two beds at the end of the
ward and two visitors were walking back down the aisle between the beds: a formidable-looking
old witch wearing a long green dress, a moth-eaten fox fur and a pointed hat decorated with what
was unmistakeably a stuffed vulture and, trailing behind her looking thoroughly depressed -
Ron.
With a sudden rush of understanding, Ron realized who the people in the end beds must be. He
cast around wildly for some means of distracting the others so that Ron could leave the ward
unnoticed and unquestioned, but Ron had also looked up at the sound of the name "Weasley", and before Ron could stop him had called out, "Ron!"
Ron jumped and cowered as though a bullet had narrowly missed him.
"It’s us, Ron!" said Ron brightly, getting to h i s feet. "Have you seen -? Weasley’s here!
Who’ve you been visiting?"
"Friends of yours, Ron, dear?" said Ron’s grandmother graciously, bearing down upon
them all.
Ron looked as though he would rather be anywhere in the world but here. A dull purple flush
was creeping up his plump face and he was not making eye contact with any of them.
"Ah, yes," said his grandmother, looking closely at Ron and sticking out a shrivelled, clawlike
hand for him to shake. "Yes, yes, I know who you are, of course. Ron speaks most highly of
you."
"Er - thanks," said Ron, shaking hands. Ron did not look at him, but surveyed his own feet,
the color deepening in his face all the while.
"And you two are clearly Weasleys," Mrs. Weasley continued, proffering her hand regally to
Ron and Ron in turn. "Yes, I know your parents -- not well, of course -- but fine people, fine
people... and you must be Ron Weasley?"
Ron looked rather startled that Mrs. Weasley knew her name, but shook hands all the
same.
"Yes, Ron’s told me all about you. Helped him out of a few sticky spots, haven’t you? He’s a
good boy," she said, casting a sternly appraising look down her rather bony nose at Ron, "but
he hasn’t got his father’s talent, I’m afraid to say." And she jerked her head in the direction of the two beds at the end of the ward, so that the stuffed vulture on her hat trembled alarmingly.
"What?" said Ron, looking amazed. (Ron wanted to stamp on Ron’s foot, but that sort of thing
is much harder to bring off unnoticed when you’re wearing jeans rather than robes.) "Is that
your dad down the end, Ron?"
"What’s this?" said Mrs. Weasley sharply. "Haven’t you told your friends about your parents, Ron?"
Ron took a deep breath, looked up at the ceiling and shook his head. Ron could not
remember ever feeling sorrier for anyone, but he could not think of any way of helping Ron
out of the situation.
"Well, it’s nothing to be ashamed of!" said Mrs. Weasley angrily. "You should be proud,
Ron, proud! They didn’t give their health and their sanity so their only son would be ashamed of them, you know!"
"I’m not ashamed," said Ron, very faintly, still looking anywhere but at Ron and the others.
Ron was now standing on tiptoe to look over at the inhabitants of the two beds.
"Well, you’ve got a funny way of showing it!" said Mrs. Weasley. "My son and his wife," she said, turning haughtily to Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron, "were tortured into insanity by You- Know-Who’s followers."
Ron and Ron both clapped their hands over their mouths. Ron stopped craning his neck
to catch a glimpse of Ron’s parents and looked mortified.
"They were Aurors, you know, and very well respected within the wizarding community" Mrs.
Weasley went on. "Highly gifted, the pair of them. I - yes, Ron dear, what is it?"
Ron’s mother had come edging down the ward in her nightdress. She no longer had the
plump, happy-looking face Ron had seen in Weasley’s old photograph of the original Order of
the Phoenix. Her face was thin and worn now, her eyes seemed overlarge and her hair, which had
turned white, was wispy and dead-looking. She did not seem to want to speak, or perhaps she
was not able to, but she made timid motions towards Ron, holding something in her
outstretched hand.
"Again?" said Mrs. Weasley, sounding slightly weary. "Very well, Ron dear, very well -
Ron, take it, whatever it is."
But Ron had already stretched out his hand, into which his mother dropped an empty
Drooble’s Best Blowing Gum wrapper.
"Very nice, dear," said Ron’s grandmother in a falsely cheery voice, patting his mother on the
shoulder.
But Ron said quietly, "Thanks, Mum."
His mother tottered away, back up the ward, humming to herself. Ron looked around at the
others, his expression defiant, as though daring them to laugh, but Ron did not think he’d ever
found anything less funny in his life.
"Well, we’d better get back," sighed Mrs Weasley, drawing on long green gloves. "Very nice
to have met you all. Ron, put that wrapper in the bin, she must have given you enough of
them to paper your bedroom by now."
But as they left, Ron was sure he saw Ron slip the candy wrapper into his pocket.
The door closed behind them.
"I never knew," said Ron, who looked tearful.
"Nor did I," said Ron rather hoarsely.
"Nor me," whispered Ron.
They all looked at Ron.
"I did," he said glumly. "Weasley told me but I promised I wouldn’t tell anyone... that’s what Weasleyatrix Weasley got sent to Azkaban for, using the Cruciatus Curse on Ron’s parents until they lost their minds."
"Weasleyatrix Weasley did that?" whispered Ron, horrified. "That woman Ron’s got a
photo of in his den?"
There was a long silence, broken by Weasleys angry voice.
"Look, I didn’t learn joined-up writing for nothing, you know!"
CHAPTER TWENTY-FOUR
Occlumency
Ron, it transpired, had been lurking in the attic. Ron said he had found him up there,
covered in dust, no doubt looking for more relics of the Weasley family to hide in his cupboard.
Though Ron seemed satisfied with this story, it made Ron uneasy. Ron seemed to be in a
better mood on his reappearance, his bitter muttering had subsided somewhat and he submitted
to orders more docilely than usual, though once or twice Ron caught the house-elf staring at
him avidly, but always looking quickly away whenever he saw that Ron had noticed.
Ron did not mention his vague suspicions to Ron, whose cheerfulness was evaporating fast
now that Christmas was over. As the date of their departure back to Hogwarts drew nearer, he
became more and more prone to what Mrs. Weasley call ed ‘fits of the sullens’, in which he would become taciturn and grumpy, often withdrawing to Ron’s room for hours at a time. His gloom seeped through the house, oozing under doorways like some noxious gas, so that all of them became infected by it.
Ron didn’t want to leave Ron again with only Ron for company; in fact, for the first time
in his life, he was not looking forward to returning to Hogwarts. Going back to school would
mean placing himself once again under the tyranny of Ron Weasley, who had no doubt
managed to force through another dozen decrees in their absence; there was no Quidditch to look
forward to now that he had been banned; there was every likelihood that their burden of
homework would increase as the exams drew even nearer; and Weasley remained as remote
as ever. In fact, if it hadn’t been for the D.A., Ron thought he might have begged Ron to let
him leave Hogwarts and remain in Grimmauld Place.
Then, on the very last day of the holidays, something happened that made Ron positively dread
his return to school.
"Ron, dear," said Mrs. Weasley, poking her head in to his and Ron’s bedroom, where the pair of them were playing wizard chess watched by Ron, Ron and Ron, "could you
come down to the kitchen? Professor Weasley would like a word with you."
Ron did not immediately register what she had said; one of his castles was engaged in a violent
tussle with a pawn of Rons and he was egging it on enthusiastically.
"Squash him - squash him, he’s only a pawn, you idiot. Sorry, Mrs. Weasley, what did you say?"
"Professor Weasley, dear. In the kitchen. He’d like a word."
Ron’s mouth fell open in horror. He looked around at Ron, Ron and Ron, all of whom
were gaping back at him. Ron, whom Ron had been restraining with difficulty for
the past quarter of an hour, leapt gleefully on to the board and set the pieces running for cover,
squealing at the top of their voices.
"Weasley?" said Ron blankly.
"Professor Weasley, dear," said Mrs. Weasley reprovingly. "Now come on, quickly, he says he can’t stay long."
"What’s he want with you?" said Ron, looking unnerved as Mrs. Weasley withdrew from the
room. "You haven’t done anything, have you?"
"No!" said Ron indignantly, racking his brains to think what he could have done that would
make Weasley pursue him to Grimmauld Place. Had his last piece of homework perhaps earned a T?
A minute or two later, he pushed open the kitchen door to find Ron and Weasley both seated at
the long kitchen table, glaring in opposite directions. The silence between them was heavy with
mutual dislike. A letter lay open on the table in front of Ron.
"Er," said Ron, to announce his presence.
Weasley looked around at him, his face framed between curtains of greasy black hair.
"Sit down, Weasley."
"You know," said Ron loudly, leaning back on his rear chair legs and speaking to the ceiling, "I
think I’d prefer it if you didn’t give orders here, Weasley. It’s my house, you see."
An ugly flush suffused Weasley’s pallid face. Ron sat down in a chair beside Ron, facing Weasley
across the table.
"I was supposed to see you alone, Weasley," said Weasley, the familiar sneer curling his mouth, "but
Weasley -"
"I’m his godfather," said Ron, louder than ever.
"I am here on Weasley’s orders," said Weasley, whose voice, by contrast, was becoming more
and more quietly waspish, "but by all means stay, Weasley, I know you like to feel... involved."
"What’s that supposed to mean?" said Ron, letting his chair fall back on to all four legs with a
loud bang.
"Merely that I am sure you must feel - ah - frustrated by the fact that you can do nothing useful,"
Weasley laid a delicate stress on the word, "for the Order."
It was Ron’s turn to flush. Weasley’s lip curled in triumph as he turned to Ron.
"The Headmaster has sent me to tell you, Weasley, that it is his wish for you to study Occlumency
this term."
"Study what?" said Ron blankly.
Weasley’s sneer became more pronounced.
"Occlumency, Weasley. The magical Defense of the mind against external penetration. An obscure
branch of magic, but a highly useful one."
Ron’s heart began to pump very fast indeed. Defense against external penetration? But he was
not being possessed, they had all agreed on that...
"Why do I have to study Occlu -- thing?" he blurted out.
"Because the Headmaster thinks it a good idea," said Weasley smoothly. "You will receive private
lessons once a week, but you will not tell anybody what you are doing, least of all Ron
Weasley. You understand?"
"Yes," said Ron. "Who’s going to be teaching me?"
Weasley raised an eyebrow.
"I am," he said.
Ron had the horrible sensation that his insides were melting.
Extra lessons with Weasley - what on earth had he done to deserve this? He looked quickly round
at Ron for support.
"Why can’t Weasley teach Ron?" asked Ron aggressively. "Why you?"
"I suppose because it is a headmaster’s privilege to delegate less enjoyable tasks," said Weasley
silkily. "I assure you I did not beg for the job." He got to his feet. "I will expect you at six o’clock on Monday evening, Weasley. My office. If anybody asks, you are taking remedial Potions.
Nobody who has seen you in my classes could deny you need them."
He turned to leave, his black traveling cloak billowing behind him.
"Wait a moment," said Ron, sitting up straighter in his chair.
Weasley turned back to face them, sneering.
"I am in rather a hurry, Weasley. Unlike you, I do not have unlimited leisure time."
"I’ll get to the point, then," said Ron, standing up. He was rather taller than Weasley who, Ron
noticed, balled his fist in the pocket of his cloak over what Ron was sure was the handle of his
wand. "If I hear you’re using these Occlumency lessons to give Ron a hard time, you’ll have
me to answer to."
"How touching," Weasley sneered. "But surely you have noticed that Weasley is very like his father?"
"Yes, I have," said Ron proudly.
"Well then, you’ll know he’s so arrogant that criticism simply bounces off him," Weasley said
sleekly.
Ron pushed his chair roughly aside and strode around the table towards Weasley, pulling out his
wand as he went. Weasley whipped out his own. They were squaring up to each other, Ron
looking livid, Weasley calculating, his eyes darting from Ron’s wand-tip to his face.
"Ron!" said Ron loudly, but Ron appeared not to hear him.
"I’ve warned you, Snivellus," said Ron, his face barely a foot from Weasley’s, "I don’t care if
Weasley thinks you’ve reformed, I know better -"
"Oh, but why don’t you tell him so?" whispered Weasley. "Or are you afraid he might not take very
seriously the advice of a man who has been hiding inside his mother’s house for six months?"
"Tell me, how is Ron Weasley these days? I expect he’s delighted his lapdog’s working at
Hogwarts, isn’t he?"
"Speaking of dogs," said Weasley softly, "did you know that Ron Weasley recognized you last
time you risked a little jaunt outside? Clever idea, Weasley, getting yourself seen on a safe station
platform... gave you a cast-iron excuse not to leave your hidey-hole in future, didn’t it?"
Ron raised his wand.
"NO!" Ron yelled, vaulting over the table and trying to get in between them. "Ron, don’t!"
"Are you calling me a coward?" roared Ron, trying to push Ron out of the way, but Ron
would not budge.
"Why, yes, I suppose I am," said Weasley.
"Ron - get - out - of - it!" snarled Ron, pushing him aside with his free hand.
The kitchen door opened and the entire Weasley family, plus Ron, came inside, all looking
very happy, with Mr. Weasley walking proudly in thei r midst dressed in a pair of striped pajamass covered by a mackintosh.
"Cured!" he announced brightly to the kitchen at large. "Completely cured!"
He and all the other Weasleys froze on the threshold, gazing at the scene in front of them, which
was also suspended in mid-action, both Ron and Weasley looking towards the door with their
wands pointing into each other’s faces and Ron immobile between them, a hand stretched out
to each, trying to force them apart.
"Merlin’s beard," said Mr. Weasley, the smile slidin g off his face, "what’s going on here?"
Both Ron and Weasley lowered their wands. Ron looked from one to the other. Each wore an
expression of utmost contempt, yet the unexpected entrance of so many witnesses seemed to
have brought them to their senses. Weasley pocketed his wand, turned on his heel and swept back
across the kitchen, passing the Weasleys without comment. At the door he looked back.
"Six o’clock, Monday evening, Weasley."
And he was gone. Ron glared after him, his wand at his side.
"What’s been going on?" asked Mr. Weasley again.
"Nothing, Ron," said Ron, who was breathing heavily as though he had just run a long
distance. "Just a friendly little chat between two old school friends." With what looked like an
enormous effort, he smiled. "So... you’re cured? That’s great news, really great."
"Yes, isn’t it?" said Mrs. Weasley, leading her husb and forward to a chair. "Healer Smethwyck
worked his magic in the end, found an antidote to whatever that snake’s got in its fangs, and
Ron’s learned his lesson about dabbling in Muggle medicine, haven’t you, dear?" she added,
rather menacingly.
"Yes, Ron, dear," said Mr. Weasley meekly.
That night’s meal should have been a cheerful one, with Mr. Weasley back amongst them. Ron
could tell Ron was trying to make it so, yet when his godfather was not forcing himself to
laugh loudly at Ron and Ron’s jokes or offering everyone more food, his face fell back into a
moody, brooding expression. Ron was separated from him by Ron and Mad-Eye, who
had dropped in to offer Mr. Weasley their congratulations. He wanted to talk to Ron, to tell him
he shouldn’t listen to a word Weasley said, that Weasley was goading him deliberately and that the
rest of them didn’t think Ron was a coward for doing as Weasley told him and remaining in
Grimmauld Place. But he had no opportunity to do so, and, eyeing the ugly look on Ron’s face,
Ron wondered occasionally whether he would have dared to mention it even if he had the
chance. Instead, he told Ron and Ron under his voice about having to take Occlumency
lessons with Weasley.
"Weasley wants to stop you having those dreams about Weasley," said Ron at once. "Well, you won’t be sorry not to have them any more, will you?"
"Extra lessons with Weasley?" said Ron, sounding aghast. "I’d rather have the nightmares!"
They were to return to Hogwarts on the Knight Bus the following day, escorted once again by
Weasley and Weasley, both of whom were eating breakfast in the kitchen when Ron, Ron and
Ron came down next morning. The adults seemed to have been mid-way through a
whispered conversation as Ron opened the door; all of them looked round hastily and fell
silent.
After a hurried breakfast, they all pulled on jackets and scarves against the chilly grey January
morning. Ron had an unpleasant constricted sensation in his chest; he did not want to say
goodbye to Ron. He had a bad feeling about this parting; he didn’t know when they would next
see each other and he felt it was incumbent upon him to say something to Ron to stop him
doing anything stupid - Ron was worried that Weasley’s accusation of cowardice had stung Ron
so badly he might even now be planning some foolhardy trip beyond Grimmauld Place. Before
he could think of what to say, however, Ron had beckoned him to his side.
"I want you to take this," he said quietly, thrusting a badly wrapped package roughly the size of a paperback book into Ron’s hands.
"What is it?" Ron asked.
"A way of letting me know if Weasley’s giving you a hard time. No, don’t open it in here!" said
Ron, with a wary look at Mrs. Weasley, who was trying to persuade the twins to wear handknitted mittens. "I doubt Ron would approve - but I want you to use it if you need me, all
right?"
"Okay," said Ron, stowing the package away in the inside pocket of his jacket, but he knew he
would never use whatever it was. It would not be he, Ron, who lured Ron from his place of
safety, no matter how foully Weasley treated him in their forthcoming Occlumency classes.
"Let’s go, then," said Ron, clapping Ron on the shoulder and smiling grimly, and before
Ron could say anything else, they were heading upstairs, stopping before the heavily chained
and bolted front door, surrounded by Weasleys.
"Goodbye, Ron, take care," said Mrs. Weasley, hugg ing him.
"See you, Ron, and keep an eye out for snakes for me!" said Mr. Weasley genially, shaking his
hand.
"Right - yeah," said Ron distractedly; it was his last chance to tell Ron to be careful; he
turned, looked into his godfather’s face: and opened his mouth to speak, but before he could do
so Ron was giving him a brief, one-armed hug, and saying gruffly, "Look after yourself,
Ron." Next moment, Ron found himself being shunted out into the icy winter air, with Weasley
(today heavily disguised as a tall, tweedy woman with iron-grey hair) chivvying him down the
steps.
The door of number twelve slammed shut behind them. They followed Weasley down the front
steps. As he reached the pavement, Ron looked round. Number twelve was shrinking rapidly as
those on either side of it stretched sideways, squeezing it out of sight. One blink later, it had
gone.
"Come on, the quicker we get on the bus the better," said Weasley, and Ron thought there was
nervousness in the glance she threw around the square. Weasley flung out his right arm.
BANG.
A violently purple, triple-decker bus had appeared out of thin air in front of them, narrowly
avoiding the nearest lamppost, which jumped backwards out of its way.
A thin, pimply, jug-eared youth in a purple uniform leapt down on to the pavement and said,
"Welcome to the -"
"Yes, yes, we know, thank you," said Weasley swiftly. "On, on, get on -"
