And she shoved Ron forwards towards the steps, past the conductor, who goggled at Ron as
he passed.
"Ere - it’s ‘Arry -!"
"If you shout his name I will curse you into oblivion," muttered Weasley menacingly, now shunting
Ron and Ron forwards.
"I’ve always wanted to go on this thing," said Ron happily, joining Ron on board and looking
around.
It had been evening the last time Ron had traveled by Knight Bus and its three decks had been
full of brass bedsteads. Now, in the early morning, it was crammed with an assortment of
mismatched chairs grouped haphazardly around windows. Some of these appeared to have fallen
over when the bus stopped abruptly in Grimmauld Place; a few witches and wizards were still
getting to their feet, grumbling, and somebody’s shopping bag had slid the length of the bus: an
unpleasant mixture of frogspawn, cockroaches and custard creams was scattered all over the
floor.
"Looks like we’ll have to split up," said Weasley briskly, looking around for empty chairs. "Ron,
Ron and Ron, if you just take those seats at the back... Ron can stay with you."
She, Ron, Ron and Ron proceeded up to the very top deck, where there were two
unoccupied chairs at the very front of the bus and two at the back. Ron Weasley, the conductor,
followed Ron and Ron eagerly to the back. Heads turned as Ron passed and, when he sat
down, he saw all the faces flick back to the front again.
As Ron and Ron handed Ron eleven Sickles each, the bus set off again, swaying ominously. It
rumbled around Grimmauld Place, weaving on and off the pavement, then, with another
tremendous BANG, they were all flung backwards; Ron’s chair toppled right over and
Ron, who had been on his lap, burst out of his cage and flew twittering wildly up to the
front of the bus where he fluttered down on to Ron’s shoulder instead. Ron, who had
narrowly avoided falling by seizing a candle bracket, looked out of the window: they were now
speeding down what appeared to be a motorway.
"Just outside Birmingham," said Ron happily, answe ring Ron’s unasked question as Ron
struggled up from the floor. "You keepin’ well, then, ‘Arry? I seen your name in the paper loads
over the summer, but it weren’t never nuffink very nice. I said to Ern, I said, ‘e didn’t seem like a
nutter when we met ‘im, just goes to show, dunnit?"
He handed over their tickets and continued to gaze, enthralled, at Ron. Apparently, Ron did not
care how nutty somebody was, if they were famous enough to be in the paper. The Knight Bus
swayed alarmingly, overtaking a line of cars on the inside. Looking towards the front of the bus,
Ron saw Ron cover her eyes with her hands, Ron swaying happily on her
shoulder.
BANG.
Chairs slid backwards again as the Knight Bus jumped from the Birmingham motorway to a
quiet country lane full of hairpin bends. Hedgerows on either side of the road were leaping out of
their way as they mounted the verges. From here they moved to a main street in the middle of a
busy town, then to a viaduct surrounded by tall hills, then to a windswept road between high-rise
flats, each time with a loud BANG.
"I’ve changed my mind," muttered Ron, picking himse lf up from the floor for the sixth time, "I
never want to ride on this thing again."
"Listen, it’s ‘Ogwarts stop after this," said Ron brightly, swaying towards them. "That bossy
woman up front ‘oo got on with you, she’s given us a little tip to move you up the queue. We’re
just gonna let Ron Marsh off first, though -" there was more retching from downstairs, followed by a horrible spattering sound "- she’s not feeling ‘er best."
A few minutes later, the Knight Bus screeched to a halt outside a small pub, which squeezed
itself out of the way to avoid a collision. They could hear Ron ushering the unfortunate Ron
Marsh out of the bus and the relieved murmurings of her fellow passengers on the second deck.
The bus moved on again, gathering speed, until -
BANG.
They were rolling through a snowy Hogsmeade. Ron caught a glimpse of the Hog’s Head down
its side street, the severed boar’s head sign creaking in the wintry wind. Flecks of snow hit the
large window at the front of the bus. At last they rolled to a halt outside the gates to Hogwarts.
Weasley and Weasley helped them off the bus with their luggage, then got off to say goodbye. Ron
glanced up at the three decks of the Knight Bus and saw all the passengers staring down at them,
noses flat against the windows.
"You’ll be safe once you’re in the grounds," said Weasley, casting a careful eye around at the
deserted road. "Have a good term, okay?"
"Look after yourselves," said Weasley, shaking hands all round and reaching Ron last. "And
listen..." he lowered his voice while the rest of the m exchanged last-minute goodbyes with
Weasley, "Ron, I know you don’t like Weasley, but he is a superb Occlumens and we all - Ron
included - want you to learn to protect yourself, so work hard, all right?"
"Yeah, all right," said Ron heavily, looking up into Weasley’s prematurely lined face. "See you,
then."
The six of them struggled up the slippery drive towards the castle, dragging their trunks.
Ron was already talking about knitting a few elf hats before bedtime. Ron glanced back
when they reached the oaken front doors; the Knight Bus had already gone and he half-wished,
given what was coming the following evening, that he was still on board.
Ron spent most of the next day dreading the evening. His morning double-Potions lesson did
nothing to dispel his trepidation, as Weasley was as unpleasant as ever. His mood was further
lowered by the D.A. members constantly approaching him in the corridors between classes, askinghopefully if there would be a meeting that night.
"I’ll let you know in the usual way when the next one is," Ron said over and over again, "but I
can’t do it tonight, I’ve got to go to - er - remedial Potions."
"You take remedial Potions!" asked Ron Weasley superciliously, having cornered Ron in the Entrance Hall after lunch. "Good Lord, you must be terrible. Weasley doesn’t usually give extra
lessons, does he?"
As Weasley strode away in an annoyingly buoyant fashion, Ron glared after him.
"Shall I jinx him? I can still get him from here," he said, raising his wand and taking aim between Weasley’s shoulder blades.
"Forget it," said Ron dismally. "It’s what everyone’s going to think, isn’t it? That I’m really
stup --"
"Hi, Ron," said a voice behind him. He turned round and found Ron standing there.
"Oh," said Ron as his stomach leapt uncomfortably. "Hi."
"We’ll be in the library, Ron," said Ron firmly as she seized Ron above the elbow and
dragged him off towards the marble staircase.
"Had a good Christmas?" asked Ron.
"Yeah, not bad," said Ron.
"Mine was pretty quiet," said Ron. For some reason, she was looking rather embarrassed.
"Erm... there’s another Hogsmeade trip next month, did you see the notice?"
"What? Oh, no, I haven’t checked the noticeboard since I got back."
"Yes, it’s on Valentine’s Day..."
"Right," said Ron, wondering why she was telling him this. "Well, I suppose you want to -?"
"Only if you do," she said eagerly.
Ron stared. He had been about to say, "I suppose you want to know when the next D.A. meetingis?" but her response did not seem to fit.
"I - er --" he said.
"Oh, it’s okay if you don’t," she said, looking mortified. "Don’t worry. I - I’ll see you around."
She walked away. Ron stood staring after her, his brain working frantically. Then something
clunked into place.
"Ron! Hey - Ron!"
He ran after her, catching her halfway up the marble staircase.
"Er - d’you want to come into Hogsmeade with me on Valentine’s Day?"
"Oooh, yes!" she said, blushing crimson and beaming at him.
"Right... well... that’s settled then," said Ron, and feeling that the day was not going to be a
complete loss after all, he headed off to the library to pick up Ron and Ron before their afternoon lessons, walking in a rather bouncy way himself.
By six o’clock that evening, however, even the glow of having successfully asked out Ron
Weasley could not lighten the ominous feelings that intensified with every step Ron took towards
Weasley’s office.
He paused outside the door when he reached it, wishing he were almost anywhere else, then,
taking a deep breath, he knocked and entered.
The shadowy room was lined with shelves bearing hundreds of glass jars in which slimy bits of
animals and plants were suspended in variously colored potions. In one corner stood the
cupboard full of ingredients that Weasley had once accused Ron - not without reason - of robbing.
Ron’s attention was drawn towards the desk, however, where a shallow stone basin engraved
with runes and symbols lay in a pool of candlelight. Ron recognized it at once - it was
Weasley’s Pensieve. Wondering what on earth it was doing there, he jumped when Weasley’s
cold voice came out of the shadows.
"Shut the door behind you, Weasley."
Ron did as he was told, with the horrible feeling that he was imprisoning himself. When he
turned back into the room, Weasley had moved into the light and was pointing silently at the chair
opposite his desk. Ron sat down and so did Weasley, his cold black eyes fixed unblinkingly upon
Ron, dislike etched in every line of his face.
"Well, Weasley, you know why you are here," he said. "The Headmaster has asked me to teach you
Occlumency. I can only hope that you prove more adept at it than at Potions."
"Right," said Ron tersely.
"This may not be an ordinary class, Weasley," said Weasley, his eyes narrowed malevolently, "but I
am still your teacher and you will therefore call me ‘sir’ or ‘professor’ at all times."
"Yes... sir," said Ron.
Weasley continued to survey him through narrowed eyes for a moment, then said, "Now,
Occlumency. As I told you back in your dear godfather’s kitchen, this branch of magic seals the
mind against magical intrusion and influence."
"And why does Professor Weasley think I need it, sir?" said Ron, looking directly into
Weasley’s eyes and wondering whether Weasley would answer.
Weasley looked back at him for a moment and then said contemptuously, "Surely even you could
have worked that out by now, Weasley? The Dark Lord is highly skilled at Legilimency -"
"What’s that? Sir?"
"It is the ability to extract feelings and memories from another persons mind -"
"He can read minds?" said Ron quickly, his worst fears confirmed.
"You have no subtlety, Weasley," said Weasley, his dark eyes glittering. "You do not understand fine
distinctions. It is one of the shortcomings that makes you such a lamentable potion-maker."
Weasley paused for a moment, apparently to savor the pleasure of insulting Ron, before
continuing.
"Only Muggles talk of ‘mind-reading’. The mind is not a book, to be opened at will and examined at leisure. Thoughts are not etched on the inside of skulls, to be perused by any invader. The mind is a complex and many-layered thing, Weasley - or at least, most minds are." He smirked. "It is true, however, that those who have mastered Legilimency are able, under certain
conditions, to delve into the minds of their victims and to interpret their findings correctly. The Dark Lord, for instance, almost always knows when somebody is lying to him. Only those skilled at Occlumency are able to shut down those feelings and memories that contradict the lie, and so can utter falsehoods in his presence without detection."
Whatever Weasley said, Legilimency sounded like mind-reading to Ron, and he didn’t like the
sound of it at all.
"So he could know what we’re thinking right now? Sir?"
"The Dark Lord is at a considerable distance and the walls and grounds of Hogwarts are guarded
by many ancient spells and charms to ensure the bodily and mental safety of those who dwell
within them," said Weasley. "Time and space matter in magic, Weasley. Eye contact is often essential
to Legilimency."
"Well then, why do I have to learn Occlumency?"
Weasley eyed Ron, tracing his mouth with one long, thin finger as he did so.
"The usual rules do not seem to apply with you, Weasley. The curse that failed to kill you seems to
have forged some kind of connection between you and the Dark Lord. The evidence suggests
that at times, when your mind is most relaxed and vulnerable - when you are asleep, for instance
- you are sharing the Dark Lord’s thoughts and emotions. The Headmaster thinks it inadvisable
for this to continue. He wishes me to teach you how to close your mind to the Dark Lord."
Ron’s heart was pumping fast again. None of this added up.
"But why does Professor Weasley want to stop it?" he asked abruptly. "I don’t like it much,
but it’s been useful, hasn’t it? I mean... I saw that snake attack Mr. Weasley and if I hadn’t,
Professor Weasley wouldn’t have been able to save him, would he? Sir?"
Weasley stared at Ron for a few moments, still tracing his mouth with his finger. When he spoke
again, it was slowly and deliberately, as though he weighed every word.
"It appears that the Dark Lord has been unaware of the connection between you and himself until
very recently. Up till now it seems that you have been experiencing his emotions, and sharing his
thoughts, without his being any the wiser. However, the vision you had shortly before Christmas
-"
"The one with the snake and Mr. Weasley?"
"Do not interrupt me, Weasley," said Weasley in a dangerous voice. "As I was saying, the vision you
had shortly before Christmas represented such a powerful incursion upon the Dark Lord’s
thoughts -"
"I saw inside the snake’s head, not his!"
"I thought I just told you not to interrupt me, Weasley?"
But Ron did not care if Weasley was angry; at last he seemed to be getting to the bottom of this
business; he had moved forwards in his chair so that, without realizing it, he was perched on the
very edge, tense as though poised for flight.
"How come I saw through the snakes eyes if it’s Weasley’s thoughts I’m sharing?"
"Do not say the Dark Lord’s name!" spat Weasley.
There was a nasty silence. They glared at each other across the Pensieve.
"Professor Weasley says his name," said Ron quietly.
"Weasley is an extremely powerful wizard," Weasley muttered. "While he may feel secure
enough to use the name... the rest of us..." He rubbed his left forearm, apparently unconsciously, on the spot where Ron knew the Dark Mark was burned into his skin.
"I just wanted to know," Ron began again, forcing his voice back to politeness, "why -"
"You seem to have visited the snake’s mind because that was where the Dark Lord was at that
particular moment," snarled Weasley. "He was possessing the snake at the time and so you dreamed you were inside it, too."
"And Vol-- he - realized I was there?"
"It seems so," said Weasley coolly.
"How do you know?" said Ron urgently. "Is this just Professor Weasley guessing, or -?"
"I told you," said Weasley, rigid in his chair, his eyes slits, "to call me ‘sir’."
"Yes, sir," said Ron impatiently, "but how do you know -?"
"It is enough that we know," said Weasley repressively. "The important point is that the Dark Lord is now aware that you are gaining access to his thoughts and feelings. He has also deduced that the process is likely to work in reverse; that is to say, he has realized that he might be able to
access your thoughts and feelings in return -"
"And he might try and make me do things?" asked Ron. "Sir?" he added hurriedly.
"He might," said Weasley, sounding cold and unconcerned. "Which brings us back to Occlumency."
Weasley pulled out his wand from an inside pocket of his robes and Ron tensed in his chair, but
Weasley merely raised the wand to his temple and placed its tip into the greasy roots of his hair.
When he withdrew it, some silvery substance came away, stretching from temple to wand like a
thick gossamer strand, which broke as he pulled the wand away from it and fell gracefully into
the Pensieve, where it swirled silvery-white, neither gas nor liquid. Twice more, Weasley raised the
wand to his temple and deposited the silvery substance into the stone basin, then, without
offering any explanation of his behavior, he picked up the Pensieve carefully, removed it to a
shelf out of their way and returned to face Ron with his wand held at the ready.
"Rond up and take out your wand, Weasley."
Ron got to his feet, feeling nervous. They faced each other with the desk between them.
"You may use your wand to attempt to disarm me, or defend yourself in any other way you can
think of," said Weasley.
"And what are you going to do?" Ron asked, eyeing Weasley’s wand apprehensively.
"I am about to attempt to break into your mind," said Weasley softly. "We are going to see how well you resist. I have been told that you have already shown aptitude at resisting the Imperius Curse. You will find that similar powers are needed for this... brace yourself, now. Legilimens!"
Weasley had struck before Ron was ready, before he had even begun to summon any force of
resistance. The office swam in front of his eyes and vanished; image after image was racing
through his mind like a flickering film so vivid it blinded him to his surroundings.
He was five, watching Ron riding a new red bicycle, and his heart was bursting with
jealousy... he was nine, and Ripper the bulldog was chasing him up a tree and the Weasleys were
laughing below on the lawn... he was sitting under the Sorting Hat, and it was telling him he
would do well in Weasley... Ron was lying in the hospital wing, her face covered with
thick black hair... a hundred Dementors were closing in on him beside the dark lake... Ron
Weasley was drawing nearer to him under the mistletoe...
"No," said a voice inside Ron’s head, as the memory of Ron drew nearer, "you’re not watching
that, you’re not watching it, it’s private -"
He felt a sharp pain in his knee. Weasley’s office had come back into view and he realized that he
had fallen to the floor; one of his knees had collided painfully with the leg of Weasley’s desk. He
looked up at Weasley, who had lowered his wand and was rubbing his wrist. There was an angry
weal there, like a scorch mark.
"Did you mean to produce a Stinging Hex?" asked Weasley coolly.
"No," said Ron bitterly, getting up from the floor.
"I thought not," said Weasley, watching him closely. "You let me get in too far. You lost control."
"Did you see everything I saw?" Ron asked, unsure whether he wanted to hear the answer.
"Flashes of it," said Weasley, his lip curling. "To whom did the dog belong?"
"My Aunt Ron," Ron muttered, hating Weasley.
"Well, for a first attempt that was not as poor as it might have been," said Weasley, raising his wand once more. "You managed to stop me eventually, though you wasted time and energy shouting. You must remain focused. Repel me with your brain and you will not need to resort to your wand."
"I’m trying," said Ron angrily, "but you’re not telling me how!"
"Manners, Weasley," said Weasley dangerously. "Now, I want you to close your eyes."
Ron threw him a filthy look before doing as he was told. He did not like the idea of standing
there with his eyes shut while Weasley faced him, carrying a wand.
"Clear your mind, Weasley," said Weasley’s cold voice. "Let go of all emotion..."
But Ron’s anger at Weasley continued to pound through his veins like venom. Let go of his
anger? He could as easily detach his legs...
"You’re not doing it, Weasley... you will need more discipline than this... focus, now..."
Ron tried to empty his mind, tried not to think, or remember, or feel...
"Let’s go again... on the count of three... one - two - three -Legilimens!"
A great black dragon was rearing in front of him... his father and mother were waving at him out
of an enchanted mirror... Ron Weasley was lying on the ground with blank eyes staring at
him...
"NOOOOOOO!"
Ron was on his knees again, his face buried in his hands, his brain aching as though someone
had been trying to pull it from his skull.
"Get up!" said Weasley sharply. "Get up! You are not trying, you are making no effort. You are
allowing me access to memories you fear, handing me weapons!"
Ron stood up again, his heart thumping wildly as though he had really just seen Ron dead in
the graveyard. Weasley looked paler than usual, and angrier, though not nearly as angry as Ron
was.
"I - am - making - an - effort," he said through clenched teeth.
"I told you to empty yourself of emotion!"
"Yeah? Well, I’m finding that hard at the moment," Ron snarled.
"Then you will find yourself easy prey for the Dark Lord!" said Weasley savagely. "Fools who wear their hearts proudly on their sleeves, who cannot control their emotions, who wallow in sad
memories and allow themselves to be provoked so easily - weak people, in other words - they
stand no chance against his powers! He will penetrate your mind with absurd ease, Weasley!"
"I am not weak," said Ron in a low voice, fury now pumping through him so that he thought he might attack Weasley in a moment.
"Then prove it! Master yourself!" spat Weasley. "Control your anger, discipline your mind! We
shall try again! Get ready, now! Legilimens!"
He was watching Uncle Ron hammering the letterbox shut... a hundred Dementors were
drifting across the lake in the grounds towards him... he was running along a windowless
passage with Mr. Weasley... they were drawing nearer to the plain black door at the end of the
corridor... Ron expected to go through it... but Mr. Weasley led him off to the left, down a
flight of stone steps...
"I KNOW! I KNOW!"
He was on all fours again on Weasley’s office floor, his scar was prickling unpleasantly, but the
voice that had just issued from his mouth was triumphant. He pushed himself up again to find
Weasley staring at him, his wand raised. It looked as though, this time, Weasley had lifted the spell
before Ron had even tried to fight back.
"What happened then, Weasley?" he asked, eyeing Ron intently.
"I saw - I remembered," Ron panted. "I’ve just realized..."
"Realized what?" asked Weasley sharply.
Ron did not answer at once; he was still savoring the moment of blinding realization as he
rubbed his forehead...
He had been dreaming about a windowless corridor ending in a locked door for months, without
once realizing that it was a real place. Now, seeing the memory again, he knew that all along he
had been dreaming about the corridor down which he had run with Mr. Weasley on the twelfth of
August as they hurried to the courtrooms in the Ministry; it was the corridor leading to the
Department of Mysteries and Mr. Weasley had been there the night that he had been attacked by
Weasley’s snake.
He looked up at Weasley.
"What’s in the Department of Mysteries?"
"What did you say?" Weasley asked quietly and Ron saw, with deep satisfaction, that Weasley was
unnerved.
"I said, what’s in the Department of Mysteries, sir?" Ron said.
"And why," said Weasley slowly, "would you ask such a thing?"
"Because" said Ron, watching Weasley’s face closely, "that corridor I’ve just seen - I’ve been dreaming about it for months -- I’ve just recognized it - it leads to the Department of Mysteries... and I think Weasley wants something from --"
"I have told you not to say the Dark Lord’s name!"
They glared at each other. Rons scar seared again, but he did not care. Weasley looked agitated;
but when he spoke again he sounded as though he was trying to appear cool and unconcerned.
"There are many things in the Department of Mysteries, Weasley, few of which you would
understand and none of which concern you. Do I make myself plain?"
"Yes," Ron said, still rubbing his prickling scar, which was becoming more painful.
"I want you back here same time on Wednesday. We will continue work then."
"Fine," said Ron. He was desperate to get out of Weasley’s office and find Ron and Ron.
"You are to rid your mind of all emotion every night before sleep; empty it, make it blank and
calm, you understand?"
"Yes," said Ron, who was barely listening.
"And be warned, Weasley... I shall know if you have not practiced"
"Right," Ron mumbled. He picked up his schoolbag, swung it over his shoulder and hurried
towards the office door. As he opened it, he glanced back at Weasley, who had his back to Ron
and was scooping his own thoughts out of the Pensieve with the tip of his wand and replacing
them carefully inside his own head. Ron left without another word, closing the door carefully
behind him, his scar still throbbing painfully.
Ron found Ron and Ron in the library, where they were working on Weasley’s most
recent ream of homework. Other students, nearly all of them fifth-years, sat at lamp-lit tables
nearby, noses close to books, quills scratching feverishly, while the sky outside the mullioned
windows grew steadily blacker. The only other sound was the slight squeaking of one of Ron
Weasley’s shoes, as the librarian prowled the aisles menacingly, breathing down the necks of those
touching her precious books.
Ron felt shivery; his scar was still aching, he felt almost feverish.
When he sat down opposite Ron and Ron, he caught sight of himself in the window
opposite; he was very white and his scar seemed to be showing up more clearly than usual.
"How did it go?" Ron whispered, and then, looking concerned. "Are you all right, Ron?"
"Yeah... fine... I dunno," said Ron impatiently, wincing as pain shot through his scar again. "Listen... I’ve just realized something"
And he told them what he had just seen and deduced.
"So... so are you saying..." whispered Ron, as Ron Weasley swept past, squeaking slightly, "that the weapon - the thing You-Know-Who’s after -- is in the Ministry of Magic?"
"In the Department of Mysteries, it’s got to be," H arry whispered. "I saw that door when your dad took me down to the courtrooms for my hearing and it’s definitely the same one he was guarding when the snake bit him."
Ron let out a long, slow sigh.
"Of course," she breathed.
"Of course what?" said Ron rather impatiently.
"Ron, think about it... Ron Weasley was trying to get through a door at the Ministry of
Magic... it must have been that one, it’s too much of a coincidence!"
"How come Ron was trying to break in when he’s on our side?" said Ron.
"Well, I don’t know," Ron admitted. "That is a bit odd..."
"So what’s in the Department of Mysteries?" Ron asked Ron. "Has your dad ever mentioned
anything about it?"
"I know they call the people who work in there ‘Unspeakables’,"said Ron, frowning. "Because no one really seems to know what they do - weird place to have a weapon."
"It’s not weird at all, it makes perfect sense," said Ron. "It will be something top secret that the Ministry has been developing, I expect... Ron, are you sure you’re all right?"
For Ron had just run both his hands hard over his forehead as though trying to iron it.
"Yeah... fine..." he said, lowering his hands, which we re trembling. "I just feel a bit... I don’t
like Occlumency much."
"I expect anyone would feel shaky if they’d had their mind attacked over and over again," said
Ron sympathetically. "Look, let’s get back to the common room, we’ll be a bit more
comfortable there."
But the common room was packed and full of shrieks of laughter and excitement; Ron and
Ron were demonstrating their latest bit of joke shop merchandise.
"Headless Hats!" shouted Ron, as Ron waved a pointed hat decorated with a fluffy pink
feather at the watching students. "Two Galleons each, watch Ron, now!"
Ron swept the hat on to his head, beaming. For a second he merely looked rather stupid; then
both hat and head vanished.
Several girls screamed, but everyone else was roaring with laughter.
"And off again!" shouted Ron, and Ron’s hand groped for a moment in what seemed to be
thin air over his shoulder; then his head reappeared as he swept the pink-feathered hat from it.
"How do those hats work, then?" said Ron, distracted from her homework and watching
Ron and Ron closely. "I mean, obviously it’s some kind of Invisibility Spell, but it’s rather
clever to have extended the field of invisibility beyond the boundaries of the charmed object...
I’d imagine the charm wouldn’t have a very long life though."
Ron did not answer; he was feeling ill.
"I’m going to have to do this tomorrow," he muttered, pushing the books he had just taken out of his bag back inside it.
"Well, write it in your homework planner then!" said Ron encouragingly. "So you don’t
forget!"
Ron and Ron exchanged looks as he reached into his bag, withdrew the planner and opened it
tentatively.
"Don’t leave it till later, you big second-rater!" chided the book as Ron scribbled down
Weasley’s homework. Ron beamed at it.
"I think I’ll go to bed," said Ron, stuffing the homework planner back into his bag and making a mental note to drop it in the fire the first opportunity he got.
He walked across the common room, dodging Ron, who tried to put a Headless Hat on him,
and reached the peace and cool of the stone staircase to the boys’ dormitories. He was feeling
sick again, just as he had the night he had had the vision of the snake, but thought that if he could
just lie down for a while he would be all right.
He opened the door of his dormitory and was one step inside it when he experienced pain so
severe he thought that someone must have sliced into the top of his head. He did not know where
he was, whether he was standing or lying down, he did not even know his own name.
Maniacal laughter was ringing in his ears... he was happier than he had been in a very long
time... jubilant, ecstatic, triumphant... a wonderful, wonderful thing had happened...
"Ron? Ron!"
Someone had hit him around the face. The insane laughter was punctuated with a cry of pain.
The happiness was draining out of him, but the laughter continued...
He opened his eyes and, as he did so, he became aware that the wild laughter was coming out of
his own mouth. The moment he realized this, it died away; Ron lay panting on the floor, staring
up at the ceiling, the scar on his forehead throbbing horribly. Ron was bending over him, looking
very worried.
"What happened?" he said.
"I... dunno..." Ron gasped, sitting up again. "He’s really happy... really happy..."
"You-Know-Who is?"
"Something good’s happened," mumbled Ron. He was shaking as badly as he had done after
seeing the snake attack Mr. Weasley and felt very sick. "Something he’s been hoping for."
The words came, just as they had back in the Weasley changing room, as though a stranger
was speaking them through Ron’s mouth, yet he knew they were true. He took deep breaths,
willing himself not to vomit all over Ron. He was very glad that Ron and Ron were not here
to watch this time.
"Ron told me to come and check on you," said Ron in a low voice, helping Ron to his
feet. "She says your Defenses will be low at the moment, after Weasley’s been fiddling around with
your mind... still, I suppose it’ll help in the long run, won’t it?" He looked doubtfully at Ron as
he helped him towards his bed. Ron nodded without any conviction and slumped back on his
pillows, aching all over from having fallen to the floor so often that evening, his scar still
prickling painfully. He could not help feeling that his first foray into Occlumency had weakened
his mind’s resistance rather than strengthening it, and he wondered, with a feeling of great
trepidation, what had happened to make Lord Weasley the happiest he had been in fourteen
years.
CHAPTER TWENTY-FIVE
The Beetle at Bay
Ron’s question was answered the very next morning. When Ron’s DailyProphet arrived
she smoothed it out, gazed for a moment at the front page and gave a yelp that caused everyone
in the vicinity to stare at her.
"What?" said Ron and Ron together.
For an answer she spread the newspaper on the table in front of them and pointed at ten blackand- white photographs that filled the whole of the front page, nine showing wizards’ faces and the tenth, a witch’s. Some of the people in the photographs were silently jeering; others were
tapping their fingers on the frame of their pictures, looking insolent. Each picture was captioned
with a name and the crime for which the person had been sent to Azkaban.
Ron Weasley, read the legend beneath a wizard with a long, pale, twisted face who was
sneering up at Ron, convicted of the brutal murders of Gideon and Fabian Prewett.
Ron Weasley, said the caption beneath a pockmarked man with greasy hair who was
leaning against the edge of his picture, looking bored, convicted of leaking Ministry of Magic
secrets to He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named.
But Ron’s eyes were drawn to the picture of the witch. Her face had leapt out at him the
moment he had seen the page. She had long, dark hair that looked unkempt and straggly in the
picture, though he had seen it sleek, thick and shining. She glared up at him through heavily
lidded eyes, an arrogant, disdainful smile playing around her thin mouth. Like Ron, she
retained vestiges of great good looks, but something - perhaps Azkaban - had taken most of her
beauty.
Weasleyatrix Weasley, convicted of the torture and permanent incapacitation of Ron and Ron
Weasley.
Ron nudged Ron and pointed at the headline over the pictures, which Ron,
concentrating on Weasleyatrix, had not yet read.
MASS BREAKOUT FROM AZKABAN
MINISTRY FEARS Weasley IS ‘RALLYING POINT’ FOR OLD DEATH EATERS
"Weasley?" said Ron loudly. "Not -?"
"Shh!" whispered Ron desperately. "Not so loud - just read it!"
The Ministry of Magic announced late last night that there has been a mass breakout from
Azkaban.
Speaking to reporters in his private office, Ron Weasley, Minister for Magic, confirmed that
ten high-security prisoners escaped in the early hours of yesterday evening and that he has
already informed the Muggle Prime Minister of the dangerous nature of these individuals.
"We find ourselves, most unfortunately, in the same position we were two and a half years ago
when the murderer Ron Weasley escaped," said Weasley last night. "Nor do we think the two
breakouts are unrelated. An escape of this magnitude suggests outside help, and we must
remember that Weasley, as the first person ever to break out of Azkaban, would be ideally placed to
help others follow in his footsteps. We think it likely that these individuals, who include Weasley’s
cousin, Weasleyatrix Weasley, have rallied around Weasley as their leader. We are, however, doing all we can to round up the criminals, and we beg the magical community to remain alert and
cautious. On no account should any of these individuals be approached."
"There you are, Ron," said Ron, looking awestruck. "That’s why he was happy last night."
"I don’t believe this," snarled Ron, "Weasley is blaming the breakout on Ron?"
"What other options does he have?" said Ron bitterly. "He can hardly say, ‘everyone,
Weasley warned me this might happen, the Azkaban guards have joined Lord Weasley’ -
stop whimpering, Ron - ‘now Weasley’s worst supporters have broken out, too.’ I mean, he’s
spent a good six months telling everyone you and Weasley are liars, hasn’t he?"
Ron ripped open the newspaper and began to read the report inside while Ron looked
around the Great Hall. He could not understand why his fellow students were not looking scared
or at least discussing the terrible piece of news on the front page, but very few of them took the
newspaper every day like Ron. There they all were, talking about homework and Quidditch
and who knew what other rubbish, when outside these walls ten more Death Eaters had swollen
Weasley’s ranks.
He glanced up at the staff table. It was a different story there: Weasley and Professor
Weasley were deep in conversation, both looking extremely grave. Professor Weasley had
the Prophet propped against a bottle of ketchup and was reading the front page with such
concentration that she was not noticing the gentle drip of egg yolk falling into her lap from her
stationary spoon. Meanwhile, at the far end of the table, Professor Weasley was tucking into a
bowl of porridge. For once her pouchy toad’s eyes were not sweeping the Great Hall looking for
misbehaving students. She scowled as she gulped down her food and every now and then she
shot a malevolent glance up the table to where Weasley and Weasley were talking so
intently.
"Oh my -" said Ron wonderingly, still staring at the newspaper.
"What now?" said Ron quickly; he was feeling jumpy.
"It’s... horrible," said Ron, looking shaken. She fold ed back page ten of the newspaper and handed it to Ron and Ron.
TRAGIC DEMISE OF MINISTRY OF MAGIC WORKER
St. Mungo’s Hospital promised a full inquiry last night after Ministry of Magic worker Broderick Bode, 49, was discovered dead in his bed, strangled by a potted-plant. Healers called to the scene were unable to revive Mr. Bode, who had been injured in a workplace accident some weeks prior to his death.
Healer Miriam Strout, who was in charge of Mr. Bodes ward at the time of the incident, has been
suspended on full pay and was unavailable for comment yesterday, but a spokeswizard for the
hospital said in a statement:
"St. Mungo’s deeply regrets the death of Mr. Bode, whose health was improving steadily prior to
this tragic accident.
"We have strict guidelines on the decorations permitted on our wards but it appears that Healer
Strout, busy over the Christmas period, overlooked the dangers of the plant on Mr. Bode’s
bedside table. As his speech and mobility improved, Healer Strout encouraged Mr. Bode to look
after the plant himself, unaware that it was not an innocent Flitterbloom, but a cutting of Devil’s
Snare which, when touched by the convalescent Mr. Bode, throttled him instantly.
"St. Mungo’s is as yet unable to account for the presence of the plant on the ward and asks any
witch or wizard with information to come forward."
"Bode..." said Ron. "Bode. It rings a bell..."
"We saw him," Ron whispered. "In St. Mungo’s, remember? He was in the bed opposite
Weasley’s, just lying there, staring at the ceiling. And we saw the Devil’s Snare arrive. She - the
Healer - said it was a Christmas present."
Ron looked back at the story. A feeling of horror was rising like bile in his throat.
"How come we didn’t recognize Devils Snare? We’ve seen it before... we could’ve stopped this
from happening."
"Who expects Devils Snare to turn up in a hospital disguised as a pot plant?" said Ron sharply.
"It’s not our fault, whoever sent it to the bloke is to blame! They must be a real prat, why didn’t
they check what they were buying?"
"Oh, come on, Ron!" said Ron shakily. "I don’t think anyone could put Devils Snare in a
pot and not realize it tries to kill whoever touches it? This - this was murder... a clever murder,
as well... if the plant was sent anonymously, how’s anyone ever going to find out who did it?"
Ron was not thinking about Devil’s Snare. He was remembering taking the lift down to the
ninth level of the Ministry on the day of his hearing and the sallow-faced man who had got in on
the. Atrium level.
"I met Bode," he said slowly. "I saw him at the Ministry with your dad."
Rons mouth fell open.
"I’ve heard Dad talk about him at home! He was an Unspeakable - he worked in the Department
of Mysteries!"
They looked at each other for a moment, then Ron pulled the newspaper back towards her,
closed it, glared for a moment at the pictures of the ten escaped Death Eaters on the front, then
leapt to her feet.
"Where are you going?" said Ron, startled.
"To send a letter," said Ron, swinging her bag on to her shoulder. "It... well, I don’t know
whether... but it’s worth trying... and I’m the only one who can."
"I hate it when she does that," grumbled Ron, as he and Ron got up from the table and made
their own, slower way out of the Great Hall. "Would it kill her to tell us what she’s up to for
once? It’d take her about ten more seconds - hey, Weasley!"
Weasley was standing beside the doors into the Entrance Hall, waiting for a crowd of Weasleys
to pass. He was still as heavily bruised as he had been on the day he had come back from his
mission to the giants and there was a new cut right across the bridge of his nose.
"All righ’, you two?" he said, trying to muster a smile but managing only a kind of pained
grimace.
"Are you okay, Weasley?" asked Ron, following him as he lumbered after the Weasleys.
"Fine, fine," said Weasley with a feeble assumption of airiness; he waved a hand and narrowly
missed concussing a frightened-looking Professor Weasley, who was passing. "Jus’ busy, yeh
know, usual stuff lessons ter prepare - couple o’ salamanders got scale rot - an’ I’m on
probation," he mumbled.
"You’re on probation?" said Ron very loudly, so that many of the passing students looked around curiously. "Sorry - I mean - you’re on probation?" he whispered.
"Yeah," said Weasley. "S’no more’n I expected, ter tell yeh the truth. Yeh migh’ not’ve picked up
on it, bu’ that inspection didn’ go too well, yeh know... anyway," he sighed deeply. "Bes’ go an’
rub a bit more chilli powder on them salamanders or their tails’ll be hangin’ off ‘em next. See
yeh, Ron... Ron..."
He trudged away, out of the front doors and down the stone steps into the damp grounds. Ron
watched him go, wondering how much more bad news he could stand.
The fact that Weasley was now on probation became common knowledge within the school over
the next few days, but to Ron’s indignation, hardly anybody appeared to be upset about it;
indeed, some people, Ron Weasley prominent among them, seemed positively gleeful. As for
the freakish death of an obscure Department of Mysteries employee in St. Mungo’s, Ron, Ron
and Ron seemed to be the only people who knew or cared. There was only one topic of
conversation in the corridors now: the ten escaped Death Eaters, whose story had finally filtered
through the school from those few people who read the newspapers. Rumors were flying that
some of the convicts had been spotted in Hogsmeade, that they were supposed to be hiding out in
the Shrieking Shack and that they were going to break into Hogwarts, just as Ron Weasley had
once done.
Those who came from wizarding families had grown up hearing the names of these Death Eaters
spoken with almost as much fear as Weasleys; the crimes they had committed during the days
of Weasley’s reign of terror were legendary. There were relatives of their victims among the
Hogwarts students, who now found themselves the unwilling objects of a gruesome sort of
reflected fame as they walked the corridors: Ron Weasley, whose uncle, aunt and cousins had all
died at the hands of one of the ten, said miserably during Herbology that she now had a good
idea what it felt like to be Ron.
"And I don’t know how you stand it - it’s horrible," she said bluntly, dumping far too much
dragon manure on her tray of Screechsnap seedlings, causing them to wriggle and squeak in
discomfort.
It was true that Ron was the subject of much renewed muttering and pointing in the corridors
these days, yet he thought he detected a slight difference in the tone of the whisperers’ voices.
They sounded curious rather than hostile now, and once or twice he was sure he overheard
snatches of conversation that suggested that the speakers were not satisfied with the Prophets
version of how and why ten Death Eaters had managed to break out of the Azkaban fortress. In
their confusion and fear, these doubters now seemed to be turning to the only other explanation
available to them: the one that Ron and Weasley had been expounding since the previous
year.
It was not only the students’ mood that had changed. It was now quite common to come across
two or three teachers conversing in low, urgent whispers in the corridors, breaking off their
conversations the moment they saw students approaching.
"They obviously can’t talk freely in the staff room any more," said Ron in a low voice, as
she, Ron and Ron passed Professors Weasley, Weasley and Weasley huddled together outside
the Charms classroom one day. "Not with Weasley there."
"Reckon they know anything new?" said Ron, gazing back over his shoulder at the three teachers.
"If they do, we’re not going to hear about it, are we?" said Ron angrily. "Not after Decree...
what number are we on now?" For new notices had appeared on the house noticeboards the
morning after news of the Azkaban breakout:
BY ORDER OF THE HIGH INQUISITOROF HOGWARTS
Teachers are hereby banned from giving students any information that is not strictly related to the subjects they are paid to teach.
The above is in accordance with Educational Decree Number Twenty-six.
Signed: Ron  Weasley, High Inquisitor
This latest Decree had been the subject of a great number of jokes among the students. Ron
Weasley had pointed out to Weasley that by the terms of the new rule she was not allowed to tell
Ron and Ron off for playing Exploding Snap in the back of the class.
"Exploding Snap’s got nothing to do with Defense Against the Dark Arts, Professor! That’s not
information relating to your subject!"
When Ron next saw Ron, the back of his hand was bleeding rather badly. Ron recommended
essence of Murtlap.
Ron had thought the breakout from Azkaban might have humbled Weasley a little, that she
might have been abashed at the catastrophe that had occurred right under the nose of her beloved
Weasley. It seemed, however, to have only intensified her furious desire to bring every aspect of
life at Hogwarts under her personal control. She seemed determined at the very least to achieve a
sacking before long, and the only question was whether it would be Professor Weasley or
Weasley who went first.
Every single Divination and Care of Magical Creatures lesson was now conducted in the
presence of Weasley and her clipboard. She lurked by the fire in the heavily perfumed tower
room, interrupting Professor Weasley’s increasingly hysterical talks with difficult questions
about ornithomancy and heptomology, insisting that she predicted students’ answers before they
gave them and demanding that she demonstrate her skill at the crystal ball, the tea leaves and the
rune stones in turn. Ron thought Professor Weasley might soon crack under the strain.
Several times he passed her in the corridors - in itself a very unusual occurrence as she generally
remained in her tower room - muttering wildly to herself, wringing her hands and shooting
terrified glances over her shoulder, and all the while giving off a powerful smell of cooking
sherry. If he had not been so worried about Weasley, he would have felt sorry for her - but if one
of them was to be ousted from their job, there could be only one choice for Ron as to who
should remain.
Unfortunately, Ron could not see that Weasley was putting up a better show than Weasley.
Though he seemed to be following Ron’s advice and had shown them nothing more
frightening than a Crup -- a creature indistinguishable from a Jack Russell terrier except for its
forked tail - since before Christmas, he too seemed to have lost his nerve. He was oddly
distracted and jumpy during lessons, losing the thread of what he was saying to the class,
answering questions wrongly, and all the time glancing anxiously at Weasley. He was also
more distant with Ron, Ron and Ron than he had ever been before, and had expressly
forbidden them to visit him after dark.
"If she catches yeh, it’ll be all of our necks on the line," he told them flatly, and with no desire to do anything that might jeoparize his job further they abstained from walking down to his hut in the evenings.
It seemed to Ron that Weasley was steadily depriving him of everything that made his life at
Hogwarts worth living: visits to Weasley’s house, letters from Ron, his Firebolt and Quidditch.
He took his revenge the only way he could - by redoubling his efforts for the D.A..
Ron was pleased to see that all of them, even Ron Weasley, had been spurred on to work
harder than ever by the news that ten more Death Eaters were now on the loose, but in nobody
was this improvement more pronounced than in Ron. The news of his parents’ attackers’
escape had wrought a strange and even slightly alarming change in him. He had not once
mentioned his meeting with Ron, Ron and Ron on the closed ward in St. Mungo’s and,
taking their lead from him, they had kept quiet about it too. Nor had he said anything on the
subject of Weasleyatrix and her fellow torturers’ escape. In fact, Ron barely spoke during the D.A.
meetings any more, but worked relentlessly on every new jinx and counter-curse Ron taught
them, his plump face screwed up in concentration, apparently indifferent to injuries or accidents
and working harder than anyone else in the room. He was improving so fast it was quite
unnerving and when Ron taught them the Shield Charm - a means of deflecting minor jinxes so
that they rebounded upon the attacker - only Ron mastered the charm faster than Ron.
Ron would have given a great deal to be making as much progress at Occlumency as Ron
was making during the D.A. meetings. Ron’s sessions with Weasley, which had started badly
enough, were not improving. On the contrary Ron felt he was getting worse with every lesson.
Before he had started studying Occlumency, his scar had prickled occasionally, usually during
the night, or else following one of those strange flashes of Weasley’s thoughts or mood that he
experienced every now and then. Nowadays, however, his scar hardly ever stopped prickling,
and he often felt lurches of annoyance or cheerfulness that were unrelated to what was happening
to him at the time, which were always accompanied by a particularly painful twinge from his
scar. He had the horrible impression that he was slowly turning into a kind of aerial that was
tuned in to tiny fluctuations in Weasleys mood, and he was sure he could date this increased
sensitivity firmly from his first Occlumency lesson with Weasley. What was more, he was now
dreaming about walking down the corridor towards the entrance to the Department of Mysteries
almost every night, dreams which always culminated in him standing longingly in front of the
plain black door.
"Maybe it’s a bit like an illness," said Ron, looking concerned when Ron confided in her
and Ron. "A fever or something. It has to get worse before it gets better."
"The lessons with Weasley are making it worse," said Ron flatly. "I’m getting sick of my scar
hurting and I’m getting bored with walking down that corridor every night." He rubbed his
forehead angrily. "I just wish the door would open, I’m sick of standing staring at it -"
"That’s not funny," said Ron sharply. "Weasley doesn’t want you to have dreams about
that corridor at all, or he wouldn’t have asked Weasley to teach you Occlumency. You’re just going
to have to work a bit harder in your lessons."
"I am working!" said Ron nettled. "You try it some time - Weasley trying to get inside your head - it’s not a bundle of laughs, you know!"
"Maybe..." said Ron slowly.
"Maybe what?" said Ron, rather snappishly.
"Maybe it’s not Ron’s fault he can’t close his mind," said Ron darkly.
"What do you mean?" said Ron.
"Well, maybe Weasley isn’t really trying to help Ron..."
Ron and Ron stared at him. Ron looked darkly and meaningfully from one to the other.
"Maybe," he said again, in a lower voice, "he’s actually trying to open Ron’s mind a bit wider... make it easier for You-Know --"
"Shut up, Ron," said Ron angrily. "How many times have you suspected Weasley, and when
have you ever been right? Weasley trusts him, he works for the Order, that ought to be
enough."
"He used to be a Death Eater," said Ron stubbornly. "And we’ve never seen proof that he really
swapped sides."
"Weasley trusts him," Ron repeated. "And if we can’t trust Weasley, we can’t trust
anyone."
With so much to worry about and so much to do - startling amounts of homework that frequently
kept the fifth-years working until past midnight, secret D.A. sessions and regular classes with
Weasley - January seemed to be passing alarmingly fast. Before Ron knew it, February had
arrived, bringing with it wetter and warmer weather and the prospect of the second Hogsmeade
visit of the year. Ron had had very little time to spare for conversations with Ron since they
had agreed to visit the village together, but suddenly found himself facing a Valentine’s Day
spent entirely in her company.
On the morning of the fourteenth he dressed particularly carefully. He and Ron arrived at
breakfast just in time for the arrival of the post owls. Ron was not there - not that Ron had
expected her - but Ron was tugging a letter from the beak of an unfamiliar brown owl as
they sat down.
"And about time! If it hadn’t come today..." she said, eagerly tearing open the envelope and
pulling out a small piece of parchment. Her eyes sped from left to right as she read through the
message and a grimly pleased expression spread across her face.
"Listen, Ron," she said, looking up at him, "this is really important. Do you think you could
meet me in the Three Broomsticks around midday?"
"Well... I dunno," said Ron uncertainly. "Ron might be expecting me to spend the whole day
with her. We never said what we were going to do."
"Well, bring her along if you must," said Ron urgently. "But will you come?"
"Well... all right, but why?"
"I haven’t got time to tell you now, I’ve got to answer this quickly."
And she hurried out of the Great Hall, the letter clutched in one hand and a piece of toast in the
other.
"Are you coming?" Ron asked Ron, but he shook his head, looking glum.
"I can’t come into Hogsmeade at all; Ron wants a full day’s training. Like it’s going to help;
we’re the worst team I’ve ever seen. You should see Sloper and Kirke, they’re pathetic, even
worse than I am." He heaved a great sigh. "I dunno why Ron won’t just let me resign."
"It’s because you’re good when you’re on form, that’s why," said Ron irritably.
He found it very hard to be sympathetic to Ron’s plight, when he himself would have given
almost anything to be playing in the forthcoming match against Weasley. Ron seemed to have
noticed Rons tone, because he did not mention Quidditch again during breakfast, and there was
a slight frostiness in the way they said goodbye to each other shortly afterwards. Ron departed
for the Quidditch pitch and Ron, after attempting to flatten his hair while staring at his
reflection in the back of a teaspoon, proceeded alone to the Entrance Hall to meet Ron, feeling
very apprehensive and wondering what on earth they were going to talk about.
She was waiting for him a little to the side of the oak front doors, looking very pretty with her
hair tied back in a long pony-tail. Ron’s feet seemed to be too big for his body as he walked
towards her and he was suddenly horribly aware of his arms and how stupid they must look
swinging at his sides.
"Hi," said Ron slightly breathlessly.
"Hi," said Ron.
They stared at each other for a moment, then Ron said, "Well - er -- shall we go, then?"
"Oh - yes..."
They joined the queue of people being signed out by Weasley, occasionally catching each other’s
eye and grinning shiftily, but not talking to each other. Ron was relieved when they reached the
fresh air, finding it easier to walk along in silence than just stand about looking awkward. It was
a fresh, breezy sort of a day and as they passed the Quidditch stadium Ron glimpsed Ron and
Ron skimming along over the stands and felt a horrible pang that he was not up there with
them.
"You really miss it, don’t you?" said Ron.
He looked round and saw her watching him.
"Yeah," sighed Ron. "I do."
"Remember the first time we played against each other, in the third year?" she asked him.
"Yeah," said Ron, grinning. "You kept blocking me."
"And Weasley told you not to be a gentleman and knock me off my broom if you had to," said Ron,
smiling reminiscently. "I heard he got taken on by Pride of Portree, is that right?"
"Nah, it was Puddlemere United; I saw him at the World Cup last year."
"Oh, I saw you there, too, remember? We were on the same campsite. It was really good, wasn’t
it?"
The subject of the Quidditch World Cup carried them all the way down the drive and out through
the gates. Ron could hardly believe how easy it was to talk to her - no more difficult, in fact,
than talking to Ron and Ron - and he was just starting to feel confident and cheerful when a
large gang of Weasley girls passed them, including Ron Weasley.
"Weasley and Weasley!" screeched Ron, to a chorus of snide giggles. "Urgh, Weasley, I don’t think
much of your taste... at least Weasley was good-looking!"
The girls sped up, talking and shrieking in a pointed fashion with many exaggerated glances back
at Ron and Ron, leaving an embarrassed silence in their wake. Ron could think of nothing
else to say about Quidditch, and Ron, slightly flushed, was watching her feet.
"So... where d’you want to go?" Ron asked as they entered Hogsmeade. The High Street was
full of students ambling up and down, peering into the shop windows and messing about together
on the pavements.
"Oh... I don’t mind," said Ron, shrugging. "Urn... shall we just have a look in the shops or
something?"
They wandered towards Dervish and Banges. A large poster had been stuck up in the window
and a few Hogsmeaders were looking at it. They moved aside when Ron and Ron approached
and Ron found himself staring once more at the pictures of the ten escaped Death Eaters. The
poster, By Order of the Ministry of Magic, offered a thousand-Galleon reward to any witch or
wizard with information leading to the recapture of any of the convicts pictured.
"It’s funny, isn’t it," said Ron in a low voice, gazing up at the pictures of the Death Eaters,
"remember when that Ron Weasley escaped, and there were Dementors all over Hogsmeade
looking for him? And now ten Death Eaters are on the loose and there are no Dementors
anywhere..."
"Yeah," said Ron, tearing his eyes away from Weasleyatrix Weasley’s face to glance up and down
the High Street. "Yeah, that is weird."
He wasn’t sorry that there were no Dementors nearby, but now he came to think of it, their
absence was highly significant. They had not only let the Death Eaters escape, they weren’t
bothering to look for them... it looked as though they really were outside Ministry control now.
The ten escaped Death Eaters were staring out of every shop window he and Ron passed. It
started to rain as they passed Scrivenshaft’s; cold, heavy drops of water kept hitting Ron’s face
and the back of his neck.
"Um... d’you want to get a coffee?" said Ron tentatively, as the rain began to fall more heavily.
"Yeah, all right," said Ron, looking around. "Where?"
"Oh, there’s a really nice place just up here; haven’t you ever been to Ron Puddifoot’s?" she
said brightly, leading him up a side road and into a small teashop that Ron had never noticed
before. It was a cramped, steamy little place where everything seemed to have been decorated
with frills or bows. Ron was reminded unpleasantly of Weasley’s office.
"Cute, isn’t it?" said Ron happily.
"Er... yeah," said Ron untruthfully.
"Look, she’s decorated it for Valentine’s Day!" said Ron, indicating a number of golden cherubs
that were hovering over each of the small, circular tables, occasionally throwing pink confetti
over the occupants.
"Aaah..."
They sat down at the last remaining table, which was over by the steamy window. Ron Weasley,
the Weasley Quidditch Captain was sitting about a foot and a half away with a pretty blonde
girl. They were holding hands. The sight made Ron feel uncomfortable, particularly when,
looking around the teashop, he saw that it was full of nothing but couples, all of them holding
hands. Perhaps Ron would expect him to hold her hand.
"What can I get you, m’dears?" said Ron Puddifoot, a very stout woman with a shiny black
bun, squeezing between their table and Ron Weasley’s with great difficulty.
"Two coffees, please," said Ron.
In the time it took for their coffees to arrive, Ron Weasley and his girlfriend had started kissing
over their sugar bowl. Ron wished they wouldn’t; he felt that Weasley was setting a standard
with which Ron would soon expect him to compete. He felt his face growing hot and tried
staring out of the window, but it was so steamed up he couldn’t see the street outside. To
postpone the moment when he would have to look at Ron, he stared up at the ceiling as though
examining the paintwork and received a handful of confetti in the face from their hovering
cherub.
After a few more painful minutes, Ron mentioned Weasley. Ron seized on the subject with
relief and they passed a few happy moments abusing her, but the subject had already been so
thoroughly canvassed during D.A. meetings it did not last very long. Silence fell again. Ron wasvery conscious of the slurping noises coming from the table next door and cast wildly around forsomething else to say.
"Er... listen, d’you want to come with me to the Three Broomsticks at lunchtime? I’m meeting
Ron Weasley there."
Ron raised her eyebrows.
"You’re meeting Ron Weasley? Today?"
"Yeah. Well, she asked me to, so I thought I would. D’you want to come with me? She said it
wouldn’t matter if you did."
"Oh... well... that was nice of her."
But Ron did not sound as though she thought it was nice at all. On the contrary, her tone was
cold and all of a sudden she looked rather forbidding.
A few more minutes passed in total silence, Ron drinking his coffee so fast that he would soon
need a fresh cup. Beside them, Ron Weasley and his girlfriend seemed glued together at the lips.
Ron’s hand was lying on the table beside her coffee and Ron was feeling a mounting pressure
to take hold of it. Just do it, he told himself, as a fount of mingled panic and excitement surged
up inside his chest, just reach out and grab it. Amazing, how much more difficult it was to extend
his arm twelve inches and touch her hand than it was to snatch a speeding Snitch from midair...
But just as he moved his hand forwards, Ron took hers off the table. She was now watching
Ron Weasley kissing his girlfriend with a mildly interested expression.
"He asked me out, you know," she said in a quiet voice. "A couple of weeks ago. Ron. I turned
him down, though."
Ron, who had grabbed the sugar bowl to excuse his sudden lunging movement across the table,
could not think why she was telling him this. If she wished she were sitting at the next table
being heartily kissed by Ron Weasley, why had she agreed to come out with him?
He said nothing. Their cherub threw another handful of confetti over them; some of it landed in
the last cold dregs of coffee Ron had been about to drink.
"I came in here with Ron last year," said Ron.
In the second or so it took for him to take in what she had said, Ron’s insides had become
glacial. He could not believe she wanted to talk about Ron now, while kissing couples
surrounded them and a cherub floated over their heads.
Ron’s voice was rather higher when she spoke again.
"I’ve been meaning to ask you for ages... did Ron - did he - m - m - mention me at all before
he died?"
This was the very last subject on earth Ron wanted to discuss, and least of all with Ron.
"Well - no -" he said quietly. "There - there wasn’t time for him to say anything. Erm... so...
d’you... d’you get to see a lot of Quidditch in the holidays? You support the Tornados, right?"
His voice sounded falsely bright and cheery. To his horror, he saw that her eyes were swimming
with tears again, just as they had been after the last D.A. meeting before Christmas.
"Look," he said desperately, leaning in so that nob ody else could overhear, "let’s not talk about
Ron right now... let’s talk about something else."
But this, apparently, was quite the wrong thing to say.
"I thought," she said, tears spattering down on to the table, "I thought you’d u - u - understand!
I need to talk about it! Surely you n - need to talk about it t - too! I mean, you saw it happen, d -
didn’t you?"
Everything was going nightmarishly wrong; Ron Weasley’s girlfriend had even unglued herself
to look round at Ron crying.
"Well - I have talked about it," Ron said in a whisper, "to Ron and Ron, but -"
"Oh, you’ll talk to Ron Weasley!" she said shrilly, her face now shining with tears. Several
more kissing couples broke apart to stare. "But you won’t talk to me! P - perhaps it would be best if we just... just p - paid and you went and met up with Ron G - Weasley, like you
obviously want to!"
Ron stared at her, utterly bewildered, as she seized a frilly napkin and dabbed at her shining
face with it.
"Ron?" he said weakly, wishing Ron would seize his girlfriend and start kissing her again to
stop her goggling at him and Ron.
"Go on, leave!" she said, now crying into the napkin. "I don’t know why you asked me out in the
first place if you’re going to make arrangements to meet other girls right after me... how many
are you meeting after Ron?"
"It’s not like that!" said Ron, and he was so relieved at finally understanding what she was
annoyed about that he laughed, which he realized a split second too late was also a mistake.
Ron sprang to her feet. The whole tearoom was quiet and everybody was watching them now.
"I’ll see you around, Ron" she said dramatically, and hiccoughing slightly she dashed to the
door, wrenched it open and hurried off into the pouring rain.
"Ron!" Ron called after her, but the door had already swung shut behind her with a tuneful
tinkle.
There was total silence within the teashop. Every eye was on Ron. He threw a Galleon down on
to the table, shook pink confetti out of his hair, and followed Ron out of the door.
It was raining hard now and she was nowhere to be seen. He simply did not understand what had
happened; half an hour ago they had been getting along fine.
"Women!" he muttered angrily, sloshing down the rain-washed street with his hands in his
pockets. "What did she want to talk about Ron for, anyway? Why does she always want to
drag up a subject that makes her act like a human hosepipe?"
He turned right and broke into a splashy run, and within minutes he was turning into the doorway
of the Three Broomsticks. He knew he was too early to meet Ron, but he thought it likely
there would be someone in here with whom he could spend the intervening time. He shook his
wet hair out of his eyes and looked around. Weasley was sitting alone in a corner, looking morose.
"Hi, Weasley!" he said, when he had squeezed through the crammed tables and pulled up a chair
beside him.
Weasley jumped and looked down at Ron as though he barely recognized him. Ron saw that he
had two fresh cuts on his face and several new bruises.
"Oh, it’s yeh, Ron," said Weasley. "Yeh all right?"
"Yeah, I’m fine," lied Ron; but, next to this battered and mournful-looking Weasley, he felt he
didn’t really have much to complain about. "Er - are you okay?"
"Me?" said Weasley. "Oh yeah, I’m grand, Ron, grand."
He gazed into the depths of his pewter tankard, which was the size of a large bucket, and sighed.
Ron didn’t know what to say to him. They sat side by side in silence for a moment. Then
Weasley said abruptly, "In the same boat, yeh an’ me, aren’ we, ‘Arry?"
"Er -" said Ron.
"Yeah... I’ve said it before... both outsiders, like," said Weasley, nodding wisely. "An’ both
orphans. Yeah... both orphans."
He took a great swig from his tankard.
"Makes a diff’rence, havin’ a decent family," he said. "Me dad was decent. An’ your mum an’
dad were decent. If they’d lived, life woulda bin diff’rent, eh?"
"Yeah... I s’pose," said Ron cautiously. Weasley seemed to be in a very strange mood.
"Family," said Weasley gloomily. "Whatever yeh say, blood’s important..."
And he wiped a trickle of it out of his eye.
"Weasley," said Ron, unable to stop himself, "where are you getting all these injuries?"
"Eh?" said Weasley, looking startled. "Wha’ injuries?"
"All those!" said Ron, pointing at Weasley’s face.
"Oh... tha’s jus’ normal bumps an’ bruises, Ron," said Weasley dismissively, "I got a rough job."
He drained his tankard, set it back on the table and got to his feet.
"I’ll be seein’ yeh, Ron... take care now."
And he lumbered out of the pub looking wretched, and disappeared into the torrential rain. Ron
watched him go, feeling miserable. Weasley was unhappy and he was hiding something, but he
seemed determined not to accept help. What was going on? But before Ron could think about it
any further, he heard a voice calling his name.
"Ron! Ron, over here!"
Ron was waving at him from the other side of the room. He got up and made his way
towards her through the crowded pub. He was still a few tables away when he realized that
Ron was not alone. She was sitting at a table with the unlikeliest pair of drinking mates he
could ever have imagined: Ron Weasley and none other than Ron Weasley, ex-journalist on
the Daily Prophet and one of Ron’s least favorite people in the world.
"You’re early!" said Ron, moving along to give him room to sit down. "I thought you were
with Ron, I wasn’t expecting you for another hour at least!"
"Ron?" said Ron at once, twisting round in her seat to stare avidly at Ron. "A girl?"
She snatched up her crocodile-skin handbag and groped within it.
"It’s none of your business if Ron’s been with a h undred girls," Ron told Ron coolly. "So you can put that away right now."
Ron had been on the point of withdrawing an acid-green quill from her bag. Looking as though
she had been forced to swallow Stinksap, she snapped her bag shut again.
"What are you up to?" Ron asked, sitting down and staring from Ron to Ron to Ron.
"Little Miss Perfect was just about to tell me when you arrived," said Ron, taking a large slurp of
her drink. "I suppose I’m allowed to talk to him, am I?" she shot at Ron.
"Yes, I suppose you are," said Ron coldly.
Unemployment did not suit Ron. The hair that had once been set in elaborate curls now hung
lank and unkempt around her face. The scarlet paint on her two-inch talons was chipped and
there were a couple of false jewels missing from her winged glasses. She took another great gulp
of her drink and said out of the corner of her mouth, "Pretty girl, is she, Ron?"
"One more word about Ron’s love life and the deal’s off and that’s a promise," said Ron
irritably.
"What deal?" said Ron, wiping her mouth on the back of her hand. "You haven’t mentioned a
deal yet, Miss Prissy, you just told me to turn up. Oh, one of these days..." She took a deep
shuddering breath.
"Yes, yes, one of these days you’ll write more horrible stories about Ron and me," said
Ron indifferently. "Find someone who cares, why don’t you?"
"They’ve run plenty of horrible stories about Ron this year without my help," said Ron,
shooting a sideways look at him over the top of her glass and adding in a rough whisper, "How
has that made you feel, Ron? Betrayed? Distraught? Misunderstood?"
"He feels angry, of course," said Ron in a hard, clear voice. "Because he’s told the Minister
for Magic the truth and the Minister’s too much of an idiot to believe him."
"So you actually stick to it, do you, that He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named is back?" said Ron,
lowering her glass and subjecting Ron to a piercing stare while her finger strayed longingly to
the clasp of the crocodile bag. "You stand by all this garbage Weasley’s been telling
everybody about You-Know-Who returning and you being the sole witness?"
"I wasn’t the sole witness," snarled Ron. "There were a dozen-odd Death Eaters there as well.
Want their names?"
"I’d love them," breathed Ron, now fumbling in her bag once more and gazing at him as though
he was the most beautiful thing she had ever seen. "A great bold headline: ‘WeasleyAccuses... ’ A
sub-heading, ‘Ron Weasley Names Death Eaters Still Among Us’. And then, beneath a nice big
photograph of you, ‘Disturbed teenage survivor of You-Know-Who’sattack, Ron Weasley, 15,
caused outrage yesterday by accusing respectable and prominent members of the wizarding
community of being Death Eaters... ’"
The Quick-Quotes Quill was actually in her hand and halfway to her mouth when the rapturous
expression on her face died.
"But of course," she said, lowering the quill and looking daggers at Ron, "Little Miss
Perfect wouldn’t want that story out there, would she?"
"As a matter of fact," said Ron sweetly, "that’s exactly what Little Miss Perfect does want."
Ron stared at her. So did Ron. Ron, on the other hand, sang Weasley is our King dreamily
under her breath and stirred her drink with a cocktail onion on a stick.
"You want me to report what he says about He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named?"Ron asked Ron in a hushed voice.
"Yes, I do," said Ron. "The true story. All the facts. Exactly as Ron reports them. He’ll
give you all the details, he’ll tell you the names of the undiscovered Death Eaters he saw there,
he’ll tell you what Weasley looks like now - oh, get a grip on yourself," she added
contemptuously, throwing a napkin across the table, for, at the sound of Weasley’s name, Ron
had jumped so badly she had slopped half her glass of Firewhisky down herself.
Ron blotted the front of her grubby raincoat, still staring at Ron. Then she said baldly,
"The Prophet wouldn’t print it. In case you haven’t noticed, nobody believes his cock-and-bull
story. Everyone thinks he’s delusional. Now, if you let me write the story from that angle -"
"We don’t need another story about how Ron’s lost his marbles!" said Ron angrily.
"We’ve had plenty of those already, thank you! I want him given the opportunity to tell the truth!"
"There’s no market for a story like that," said Ron coldly.
"You mean the Prophet won’t print it because Weasley won’t let them," said Ron irritably.
Ron gave Ron a long, hard look. Then, leaning forwards across the table towards her, she
said in a businesslike tone, "All right, Weasley is leaning on the Prophet, but it comes to the same
thing. They won’t print a story that shows Ron in a good light. Nobody wants to read it. It’s
against the public mood. This last Azkaban breakout has got people quite worried enough.
People just don’t want to believe You-Know-Whos back."
"So the Daily Prophet exists to tell people what they want to hear, does it?" said Ron
scathingly.
Ron sat up straight again, her eyebrows raised, and drained her glass of Firewhisky.
"The Prophet exists to sell itself, you silly girl," she said coldly.
"My dad thinks it’s an awful paper," said Ron, chipping into the conversation unexpectedly.
Sucking on her cocktail onion, she gazed at Ron with her enormous, protuberant, slightly mad
eyes. "He publishes important stories he thinks the public needs to know. He doesn’t care about
making money."
Ron looked disparagingly at Ron.
"I’m guessing your father runs some stupid little village newsletter?" she said. "Probably, Twenty- Five Ways to Mingle With Muggles and the dates of the next Bring and Fly Sale?"
"No," said Ron, dipping her onion back into her Gillywater, "he’s the editor of The Quibbler."
Ron snorted so loudly that people at a nearby table looked round in alarm.
"‘Important stories he thinks the public needs to know’, eh? " she said witheringly. "I could manure my garden with the contents of that rag."
"Well, this is your chance to raise the tone of it a bit, isn’t it?" said Ron pleasantly. "Ron
says her father’s quite happy to take Ron’s interview. That’s who’ll be publishing it."
Ron stared at them both for a moment, then let out a great whoop of laughter.
"The Quibbler!" she said, cackling. "You think people will take him seriously if he’s published
in The Quibbler!"
"Some people won’t," said Ron in a level voice. "But the Daily Prophet’s version of the
Azkaban breakout had some gaping holes in it. I think a lot of people will be wondering whether
there isn’t a better explanation of what happened, and if there’s an alternative story available,
even if it is published in a -" she glanced sideways at Ron, "in a - well, an unusual magazine - I
think they might be rather keen to read it."
Ron didn’t say anything for a while, but eyed Ron shrewdly, her head a little to one side.
"All right, let’s say for a moment I’ll do it," she said abruptly. "What kind of fee am I going to
get?"
"I don’t think Daddy exactly pays people to write f or the magazine," said Ron dreamily. "They
do it because it’s an honor and, of course, to see their names in print."
Ron Weasley looked as though the taste of Stinksap was strong in her mouth again as she rounded
on Ron.
"I’m supposed to do this for free?"
"Well, yes," said Ron calmly, taking a sip of her drink. "Otherwise, as you very well know,
I will inform the authorities that you are an unregistered Animagus. Of course, the Prophet might
give you rather a lot for an insider’s account of life in Azkaban."
Ron looked as though she would have liked nothing better than to seize the paper umbrella
sticking out of Ron’s drink and thrust it up her nose.
"I don’t suppose I’ve got any choice, have I?" said Ron, her voice shaking slightly. She opened
her crocodile bag once more, withdrew a piece of parchment, and raised her Quick-Quotes Quill.
"Daddy will be pleased," said Ron brightly. A muscle twitched in Ron’s jaw.
"Okay, Ron?" said Ron, turning to him. "Ready to tell the public the truth?"
"I suppose," said Ron, watching Ron balancing the Quick-Quotes Quill at the ready on the
parchment between them.
"Fire away, then, Ron," said Ron serenely, fishing a cherry out from the bottom of her
glass.
CHAPTER TWENTY-SIX
Seen and Unforeseen
Ron said vaguely that she did not know how soon Ron’s interview with Ron would appear
in The Quibbler, that her father was expecting a "‘lovely long article on recent sightings of
Crumple-Horned Snorkacks,’"- "and of course, that’ll be a very important story, so Rons might
have to wait for the following issue," said Ron.
Ron had not found it an easy experience to talk about the night when Weasley had returned.
Ron had pressed him for every little detail and he had given her everything he could remember,
knowing that this was his one big opportunity to tell the world the truth. He wondered how
people would react to the story. He guessed that it would confirm a lot of people in the view that
he was completely insane, not least because his story would be appearing alongside utter rubbish
about Crumple-Horned Snorkacks. But the breakout of Weasleyatrix Weasley and her fellow Death
Eaters had given Ron a burning desire to dosomething, whether or not it worked...
"Can’t wait to see what Weasley thinks of you going public," said Ron, sounding awestruck at
dinner on Monday night. Ron was shoveling down large amounts of chicken and ham pie on
Ron’s other side, but Ron knew he was listening.
"It’s the right thing to do, Ron," said Ron, who was sitting opposite him. He was rather pale, but went on in a low voice, "It must have been... tough... talking about it... was it?"
"Yeah," mumbled Ron, "but people have got to know what Weasleys capable of, haven’t
they?"
"That’s right," said Ron, nodding, "and his Death Eaters, too... people should know..."
Ron left his sentence hanging and returned to his baked potato. Ron looked up, but when
he caught Rons eye he looked quickly back at his plate again. After a while, Ron, Ron and
