Ron departed for the common room, leaving Ron and Ron at the table waiting for
Ron, who had not yet had dinner because of Quidditch practice.
Ron Weasley walked into the Hall with her friend Ron. Ron’s stomach gave an unpleasant
lurch, but she did not look over at the Weasley table, and sat down with her back to him.
"Oh, I forgot to ask you," said Ron brightly, glancing over at the Weasley table, "what
happened on your date with Ron? How come you were back so early?"
"Er... well, it was..." said Ron, pulling a dish of rhubarb crumble towards him and helping
himself to seconds, "a complete fiasco, now you mention it."
And he told her what had happened in Ron Puddifoot’s teashop.
"... so then," he finished several minutes later, as the final bit of crumble disappeared, "she jumps up, right, and says, ‘I’ll see you around, Ron,’ an d runs out of the place!" He put down his spoon and looked at Ron. "I mean, what was all that about? What was going on?"
Ron glanced over at the back of Ron’s head and sighed.
"Oh, Ron" she said sadly. "Well, I’m sorry, but you were a bit tactless."
"Me, tactless?" said Ron, outraged. "One minute we were getting on fine, next minute she was
telling me that Ron Weasley asked her out and how she used to go and snog Ron in that stupid
teashop - how was I supposed to feel about that?"
"Well, you see," said Ron, with the patient air of someone explaining that one plus one
equals two to an over-emotional toddler, "you shouldn’t have told her that you wanted to meet
me halfway through your date."
"But, but," spluttered Ron, "but - you told me to meet you at twelve and to bring her along, how was I supposed to do that without telling her?"
"You should have told her differently," said Ron, still with that maddeningly patient air.
"You should have said it was really annoying, but I’d made you promise to come along to the
Three Broomsticks, and you really didn’t want to go, you’d much rather spend the whole day
with her, but unfortunately you thought you really ought to meet me and would she please,
please come along with you and hopefully you’d be able to get away more quickly. And it might
have been a good idea to mention how ugly you think I am, too," Ron added as an
afterthought.
"But I don’t think you’re ugly," said Ron, bemused.
Ron laughed.
"Ron you’re worse than Ron... well, no, you’re not, " she sighed, as Ron himself came
stumping into the Hall splattered with mud and looking grumpy. "Look - you upset Ron when
you said you were going to meet me, so she tried to make you jealous. It was her way of trying to
find out how much you liked her."
"Is that what she was doing?" said Ron, as Ron dropped on to the bench opposite them and
pulled every dish within reach towards him. "Well, wouldn’t it have been easier if she’d just
asked me whether I liked her better than you?"
"Girls don’t often ask questions like that," said Ron.
"Well, they should!" said Ron forcefully. "Then I could’ve just told her I fancy her, and she
wouldn’t have had to get herself all worked up again about Ron dying!"
"I’m not saying what she did was sensible," said Ron, as Ron joined them, just as muddy as Ron and looking equally disgruntled. "I’m just trying to make you see how she was feeling at the time."
"You should write a book," Ron told Ron as he cut up his potatoes, "translating mad things
girls do so boys can understand them."
"Yeah," said Ron fervently, looking over at the Weasley table. Ron had just got up, and, still
not looking at him, she left the Great Hall. Feeling rather depressed, he looked back at Ron and
Ron. "So, how was Quidditch practice?"
"It was a nightmare," said Ron in a surly voice.
"Oh come on," said Ron, looking at Ron, "I’m sure it wasn’t that -"
"Yes, it was," said Ron. "It was appalling. Ron was nearly in tears by the end of it."
Ron and Ron went off for baths after dinner; Ron and Ron returned to the busy
Weasley common room and their usual pile of homework. Ron had been struggling with a
new star-chart for Astronomy for half an hour when Ron and Ron turned up.
"Ron and Ron not here?" asked Ron, looking around as he pulled up a chair, and when Ron
shook his head, he said, "Good. We were watching their practice. They’re going to be
slaughtered. They’re complete rubbish without us."
"Come on, Ron’s not bad," said Ron fairly, sitting down next to Ron. "Actually, I dunno
how she got so good, seeing how we never let her play with us."
"She’s been breaking into your broom shed in the garden since the age of six and taking each of
your brooms out in turn when you weren’t looking," said Ron from behind her tottering
pile of Ancient Rune books.
"Oh," said Ron, looking mildly impressed. "Well - that’d explain it."
"Has Ron saved a goal yet?" asked Ron, peering over the top of Magical Hieroglyphs and
Logograms.
"Well, he can do it if he doesn’t think anyone’s watching him," said Ron, rolling his eyes. "So all we have to do is ask the crowd to turn their backs and talk among themselves every time the
Quaffle goes up his end on Saturday."
He got up again and moved restlessly to the window, staring out across the dark grounds.
"You know, Quidditch was about the only thing in this place worth staying for."
Ron cast him a stern look.
"You’ve got exams coming!"
"Told you already, we’re not fussed about Rons," said Ron. "The Snackboxes are ready to
roll, we found out how to get rid of those boils, just a couple of drops of Murtlap essence sorts
them, Ron put us on to it."
Ron yawned widely and looked out disconsolately at the cloudy night sky.
"I dunno if I even want to watch this match. If Ron Weasley beats us I might have to kill
myself."
"Kill him, more like," said Ron firmly.
"That’s the trouble with Quidditch," said Ron absent-mindedly, once again bent over her
Runes translation, "it creates all this bad feeling and tension between the houses."
She looked up to find her copy of Spellman’s Syllabary, and caught Ron, Ron and Ron all
staring at her with expressions of mingled disgust and incredulity on their faces.
"Well, it does!" she said impatiently. "It’s only a game, isn’t it?"
"Ron," said Ron, shaking his head, "you’re good on feelings and stuff, but you just don’t
understand about Quidditch."
"Maybe not," she said darkly, returning to her translation, "but at least my happiness doesn’t
depend on Ron’s goalkeeping ability."
And though Ron would rather have jumped off the Astronomy Tower than admit it to her, by
the time he had watched the game the following Saturday he would have given any number of
Galleons not to care about Quidditch either.
The very best thing you could say about the match was that it was short; the Weasley
spectators had to endure only twenty-two minutes of agony. It was hard to say what the worst
thing was: Ron thought it was a close-run contest between Ron’s fourteenth failed save, Sloper
missing the Bludger but hitting Ron in the mouth with his bat, and Kirke shrieking and
falling backwards off his broom when Ron Weasley zoomed at him carrying the Quaffle. The
miracle was that Weasley only lost by ten points: Ron managed to snatch the Snitch from
right under Weasley Seeker Summerby’s nose, so that the final score was two hundred and
forty versus two hundred and thirty.
"Good catch," Ron told Ron back in the common room, where the atmosphere resembled that
of a particularly dismal funeral.
"I was lucky," she shrugged. "It wasn’t a very fast Snitch and Summerby’s got a cold, he sneezed and closed his eyes at exactly the wrong moment. Anyway, once you’re back on the team -"
"Ron, I’ve got a lifelong ban."
"You’re banned as long as Weasley is in the school," Ron corrected him. "There’s a difference. Anyway, once you’re back, I think I’ll try out for Chaser. Ron and Ron are both leaving next year and I prefer goal-scoring to Seeking anyway."
Ron looked over at Ron, who was hunched in a corner, staring at his knees, a bottle of
Butterbeer clutched in his hand.
"Ron still won’t let him resign," Ron said, as though reading Ron’s mind. "She says she
knows he’s got it in him."
Ron liked Ron for the faith she was showing in Ron, but at the same time thought it would
really be kinder to let him leave the team. Ron had left the pitch to another booming chorus of
Weasley is our King sung with great gusto by the Weasleys, who were now favorites to win
the Quidditch Cup.
Ron and Ron wandered over.
"I haven’t even got the heart to take the mickey out of him," said Ron, looking over at Ron’s
crumpled figure. "Mind you... when he missed the fourteenth -"
He made wild motions with his arms as though doing an upright doggy-paddle.
"- well, I’ll save it for parties, eh?"
Ron dragged himself up to bed shortly after this. Out of respect for his feelings, Ron waited a
while before going up to the dormitory himself, so that Ron could pretend to be asleep if he
wanted to. Sure enough, when Ron finally entered the room Ron was snoring a little too loudly
to be entirely plausible.
Ron got into bed, thinking about the match. It had been immensely frustrating watching from
the sidelines. He was quite impressed by Ron’s performance but he knew if he had been
playing he could have caught the Snitch sooner... there had been a moment when it had been
fluttering near Kirke’s ankle; if Ron hadn’t hesitated, she might have been able to scrape a win
for Weasley.
Weasley had been sitting a few rows below Ron and Ron. Once or twice she had turned
squatly in her seat to look at him, her wide toad’s mouth stretched in what he thought had been a
gloating smile. The memory of it made him feel hot with anger as he lay there in the dark. After
a few minutes, however, he remembered that he was supposed to be emptying his mind of all
emotion before he slept, as Weasley kept instructing him at the end of every Occlumency lesson.
He tried for a moment or two, but the thought of Weasley on top of memories of Weasley merely
increased his sense of grumbling resentment and he found himself focusing instead on how much
he loathed the pair of them. Slowly, Ron’s snores died away, to be replaced by the sound of
deep, slow breathing. It took Ron much longer to get to sleep; his body was tired, but it took his
brain a long time to close down.
He dreamed that Ron and Professor Weasley were waltzing around the Room of Requirement
while Professor Weasley played the bagpipes. He watched them happily for a while, then
decided to go and find the other members of the D.A..
But when he left the room he found himself facing, not the tapestry of Barnabas the Barmy, but a
torch burning in its bracket on a stone wall. He turned his head slowly to the left. There, at the
far end of the windowless passage, was a plain, black door.
He walked towards it with a sense of mounting excitement. He had the strangest feeling that this
time he was going to get lucky at last, and find the way to open it... he was feet from it, and saw
with a leap of excitement that there was a glowing strip of faint blue light down the right-hand
side... the door was ajar... he stretched out his hand to push it wide and -
Ron gave a loud, rasping, genuine snore and Ron awoke abruptly with his right hand stretched
in front of him in the darkness, to open a door that was hundreds of miles away. He let it fall
with a feeling of mingled disappointment and guilt. He knew he should not have seen the door,
but at the same time felt so consumed with curiosity about what was behind it that he could not
help feeling annoyed with Ron... if only he could have saved his snore for just another minute.
They entered the Great Hall for breakfast at exactly the same moment as the post owls on
Monday morning. Ron was not the only person eagerly awaiting her Daily Prophet: nearly
everyone was eager for more news about the escaped Death Eaters, who, despite many reported
sightings, had still not been caught. She gave the delivery owl a Knut and unfolded the
newspaper eagerly while Ron helped himself to orange juice; as he had only received one note
during the entire year, he was sure, when the first owl landed with a thud in front of him, that it
had made a mistake.
"Who’re you after?" he asked it, languidly removing his orange juice from underneath its beak
and leaning forwards to see the recipient’s name and address:
Ron Weasley, Great Hall, Hogwarts School
Frowning, he made to take the letter from the owl, but before he could do so, three, four, five
more owls had fluttered down beside it and were jockeying for position, treading in the butter
and knocking over the salt as each one attempted to give him their letter first.
"What’s going on?" Ron asked in amazement, as the whole of Weasley table leaned forwards
to watch and another seven owls landed amongst the first ones, screeching, hooting and flapping
their wings.
"Ron!" said Ron breathlessly, plunging her hands into the feathery mass and pulling out a
screech owl bearing a long, cylindrical package. "I think I know what this means - open this one
first!"
Ron ripped off the brown packaging. Out rolled a tightly furled copy of the March edition
of The Quibbler. He unrolled it to see his own face grinning sheepishly at him from the front
cover. In large red letters across this picture were the words:
SPEAKS OUT AT LAST: THE TRUTH ABOUT HE-WHO-MUST-NOT-BE-NAMED AND
THE NIGHT I SAW HIM RETURN
"It’s good, isn’t it?" said Ron, who had drifted o ver to the Weasley table and now squeezed
herself on to the bench between Ron and Ron. "It came out yesterday, I asked Dad to send you a
free copy. I expect all these," she waved a hand at the assembled owls still scrabbling around on
the table in front of Ron, "are letters from readers."
"That’s what I thought," said Ron eagerly. "Ron, d’you mind if we -?"
"Help yourself," said Ron, feeling slightly bemused.
Ron and Ron both started ripping open envelopes.
"This one’s from a bloke who thinks you’re off your rocker," said Ron, glancing down his letter.
"Ah well..."
"This woman recommends you try a good course of Shock Spells at St. Mungo’s," said Ron, looking disappointed and crumpling up a second.
"This one looks okay, though," said Ron slowly, scanning a long letter from a witch in Paisley.
"Hey, she says she believes me!"
"This one’s in two minds," said Ron, who had joined in the letter-opening with enthusiasm.
"Says you don’t come across as a mad person, but he really doesn’t want to believe You-Know-
Who’s back so he doesn’t know what to think now. Blimey, what a waste of parchment."
"Here’s another one you’ve convinced, Ron!" said Ron excitedly. "Having read your side
of the story, I am forced to the conclusion that the Daily Prophet has treated you very unfairly...
little though I want to think that He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named has returned, I am forced to accept that you are telling the truth... Oh, this is wonderful!"
"Another one who thinks you’re barking," said Ron, throwing a crumpled letter over his shoulder
"... but this one says you’ve got her converted and she now thinks you’re a real hero - she’s put
in a photograph, too - wow!"
"What is going on here?" said a falsely sweet, girlish voice.
Ron looked up with his hands full of envelopes. Professor Weasley was standing behind Ron
and Ron, her bulging toad’s eyes scanning the mess of owls and letters on the table in front of
Ron. Behind her he saw many of the students watching them avidly.
"Why have you got all these letters, Mr. Weasley?" she asked slowly.
"Is that a crime now?" said Ron loudly. "Getting mail?"
"Be careful, Mr. Weasley, or I shall have to put you in detention," said Weasley. "Well, Mr.
Weasley?"
Ron hesitated, but he did not see how he could keep what he had done quiet; it was surely only
a matter of time before a copy of The Quibbler came to Weasleys attention.
"People have written to me because I gave an interview," said Ron. "About what happened to
me last June."
For some reason he glanced up at the staff table as he said this. Ron had the strangest feeling
that Weasley had been watching him a second before, but when he looked towards the
Headmaster he seemed to be absorbed in conversation with Professor Weasley.
"An interview?" repeated Weasley, her voice thinner and higher than ever. "What do you
mean?"
"I mean a reporter asked me questions and I answered them," said Ron. "Here -"
And he threw the copy of The Quibbler to her. She caught it and stared down at the cover. Her
pale, doughy face turned an ugly, patchy violet.
"When did you do this?" she asked, her voice trembling slightly.
"Last Hogsmeade weekend," said Ron.
She looked up at him, incandescent with rage, the magazine shaking in her stubby fingers.
"There will be no more Hogsmeade trips for you, Mr. Weasley," she whispered. "How you dare...
how you could..." She took a deep breath. "I have tried again and again to teach you not to tell
lies. The message, apparently, has still not sunk in. Fifty points from Weasley and another
week’s worth of detentions."
She stalked away, clutching The Quibbler to her chest, the eyes of many students following her.
By mid-morning enormous signs had been put up all over the school, not just on house
noticeboards, but in the corridors and classrooms too.
BY ORDER OF THE HIGH INQUISITOR OF HOGWARTS
Any student found in possession of the magazine The Quibbler will be expelled.
The above is in accordance with Educational Decree Number Twenty-seven.
Signed: Ron  Weasley, High Inquisitor
For some reason, every time Ron caught sight of one of these signs she beamed with
pleasure.
"What exactly are you so happy about?" Ron asked her.
"Oh, Ron, don’t you see?" Ron breathed. "If she could have done one thing to make
absolutely sure that every single person in this school will read your interview, it was banning
it!"
And it seemed that Ron was quite right. By the end of the day, though Ron had not seen
so much as a corner of The Quibbler anywhere in the school, the whole place seemed to be
quoting the interview to each other. Ron heard them whispering about it as they queued up
outside classes, discussing it over lunch and in the back of lessons, while Ron even
reported that every occupant of the cubicles in the girls’ toilets had been talking about it when
she nipped in there before Ancient Runes. "Then they spotted me, and obviously they know I
know you, so they bombarded me with questions," Ron told Ron, her eyes shining, "and
Ron, I think they believe you, I really do, I think you’ve finally got them convinced!"
Meanwhile, Professor Weasley was stalking the school, stopping students at random and
demanding that they turn out their books and pockets: Ron knew she was looking for copies
of The Quibbler, but the students were several steps ahead of her. The pages carrying Rons
interview had been bewitched to resemble extracts from textbooks if anyone but themselves read
it, or else wiped magically blank until they wanted to peruse it again. Soon it seemed that every
single person in the school had read it.
The teachers were of course forbidden from mentioning the interview by Educational Decree
Number Twenty-six, but they found ways to express their feelings about it all the same.
Professor Weasley awarded Weasley twenty points when Ron passed her a watering can; a
beaming Professor Weasley pressed a box of squeaking sugar mice on him at the end of Charms,
said, "Shh!" and hurried away; and Professor Weasley broke into hysterical sobs during
Divination and announced to the startled class, and a very disapproving Weasley, that Ron
was not going to suffer an early death after all, but would live to a ripe old age, become Minister
for Magic and have twelve children.
But what made Ron happiest was Ron catching up with him as he was hurrying along to
Transfiguration the next day. Before he knew what had happened, her hand was in his and she
was breathing in his ear, "I’m really, really sorry. That interview was so brave... it made me cry."
He was sorry to hear she had shed even more tears over it, but very glad they were on speaking
terms again, and even more pleased when she gave him a swift kiss on the cheek and hurried off
again. And unbelievably, no sooner had he arrived outside Transfiguration than something just as
good happened: Ron stepped out of the queue to face him.
"I just wanted to say," he mumbled, squinting at Ron’s left knee, "I believe you. And I’ve sent a copy of that magazine to me mam."
If anything more was needed to complete Ron’s happiness, it was the reaction he got from
Weasley, Weasley and Weasley. He saw them with their heads together later that afternoon in the
library; they were with a weedy-looking boy Ron whispered was called Ron Weasley.
They looked round at Ron as he browsed the shelves for the book he needed on Partial
Vanishment: Weasley cracked his knuckles threateningly and Weasley whispered something
undoubtedly malevolent to Weasley. Ron knew perfectly well why they were acting like this: he
had named all of their fathers as Death Eaters.
"And the best bit," whispered Ron gleefully, as they left the library, "is they can’t contradict you, because they can’t admit they’ve read the article!"
To cap it all, Ron told him over dinner that no issue of The Quibbler had ever sold out faster.
"Dad’s reprinting!" she told Ron, her eyes popping excitedly. "He can’t believe it, he says
people seem even more interested in this than the Crumple-Horned Snorkacks!"
Ron was a hero in the Weasley common room that night. Daringly, Ron and Ron had put
an Enlargement Charm on the front cover of The Quibbler and hung it on the wall, so that Ron’s giant head gazed down upon the proceedings, occasionally saying things like ‘THE MINISTRY ARE MORONS’ and ‘EAT DUNG, Weasley’ in a booming voice. Ron did not find this very amusing; she said it interfered with her concentration, and she ended up going to bed early out of irritation. Ron had to admit that the poster was not quite as funny after an hour or two, especially when the talking spell had started to wear off, so that it merely shouted
disconnected words like ‘DUNG’ and ‘Weasley’ at more and more frequent intervals in a
progressively higher voice. In fact, it started to make his head ache and his scar began prickling
uncomfortably again. To disappointed moans from the many people who were sitting around
him, asking him to relive his interview for the umpteenth time, he announced that he too needed
an early night.
The dormitory was empty when he reached it. He rested his forehead for a moment against the
cool glass of the window beside his bed; it felt soothing against his scar. Then he undressed and
got into bed, wishing his headache would go away. He also felt slightly sick. He rolled over on to
his side, closed his eyes, and fell asleep almost at once...
He was standing in a dark, curtained room lit by a single branch of candles. His hands were
clenched on the back of a chair in front of him. They were long-fingered and white as though
they had not seen sunlight for years and looked like large, pale spiders against the dark velvet of
the chair.
Beyond the chair, in a pool of light cast upon the floor by the candles, knelt a man in black robes.
"I have been badly advised, it seems," said Ron, in a high, cold voice that pulsed with anger.
"Master, I crave your pardon," croaked the man kneeling on the floor. The back of his head
glimmered in the candlelight. He seemed to be trembling.
"I do not blame you, Weasley," said Ron in that cold, cruel voice.
He relinquished his grip on the chair and walked around it, closer to the man cowering on the
floor, until he stood directly over him in the darkness, looking down from a far greater height
than usual.
"You are sure of your facts, Weasley?" asked Ron.
"Yes, My Lord, yes... I used to work in the Department after - after all..."
"Avery told me Bode would be able to remove it."
"Bode could never have taken it, Master... Bode would have known he could not... undoubtedly, that is why he fought so hard against Weasley’s Imperius Curse..."
"Rond up, Weasley," whispered Ron.
The kneeling man almost fell over in his haste to obey. His face was pockmarked; the scars were
thrown into relief by the candlelight. He remained a little stooped when standing, as though
halfway through a bow, and he darted terrified looks up at Ron’s face.
"You have done well to tell me this," said Ron. "Very well... I have wasted months on fruitless
schemes, it seems... but no matter... we begin again, from now. You have Lord Weasley’s
gratitude, Weasley..."
"My Lord... yes, My Lord," gasped Weasley, his voice hoarse with relief.
"I shall need your help. I shall need all the information you can give me."
"Of course, My Lord, of course... anything..."
"Very well... you may go. Send Avery to me."
Weasley scurried backwards, bowing, and disappeared through a door.
Left alone in the dark room, Ron turned towards the wall. A cracked, age-spotted mirror hung
on the wall in the shadows. Ron moved towards it. His reflection grew larger and clearer in the
darkness... a face whiter than a skull... red eyes with slits for pupils...
"NOOOOOOOOO!"
"What?" yelled a voice nearby.
Ron flailed around madly, became entangled in the hangings and fell out of his bed. For a few
seconds he did not know where he was; he was convinced he was about to see the white, skulllike face looming at him out of the dark again, then very near to him Ron’s voice spoke.
"Will you stop acting like a maniac so I can get you out of here!"
Ron wrenched the hangings apart and Ron stared up at him in the moonlight, flat on his back,
his scar searing with pain. Ron looked as though he had just been getting ready for bed; one arm
was out of his robes.
"Has someone been attacked again?" asked Ron, pulling Ron roughly to his feet. "Is it Dad? Is it that snake?"
"No - everyone’s fine -" gasped Ron, whose forehead felt as though it were on fire. "Well...
Avery isn’t... he’s in trouble... he gave him the wrong information... Weasley’s really angry"
Ron groaned and sank, shaking, on to his bed, rubbing his scar.
"But Weasley’s going to help him now... he’s on the right track again..."
"What are you talking about?" said Ron, sounding scared. "D’you mean... did you just see You-
Know-Who?"
"I was You-Know-Who," said Ron, and he stretched out his hands in the darkness and held
them up to his face, to check that they were no longer deathly white and long-fingered. "He was
with Weasley, he’s one of the Death Eaters who escaped from Azkaban, remember? Weasley’s just told him Bode couldn’t have done it."
"Done what?"
"Remove something... he said Bode would have known he couldn’t have done it... Bode was
under the Imperius Curse... I think he said Weasley’s dad put it on him."
"Bode was bewitched to remove something?" Ron said. "But -Ron, that’s got to be -"
"The weapon," Ron finished the sentence for him. "I know"
The dormitory door opened; Ron and Ron came in. Ron swung his legs back into bed. He
did not want to look as though anything odd had just happened, seeing as Ron had only just
stopped thinking Ron was a nutter.
"Did you say," murmured Ron, putting his head close to Ron’s on the pretence of helping
himself to water from the jug on his bedside table, "that you were You-Know-Who?"
"Yeah," said Ron quietly.
Ron took an unnecessarily large gulp of water; Ron saw it spill over his chin on to his chest.
"Ron," he said, as Ron and Ron clattered around noisily, pulling off their robes and talking, "you’ve got to tell -"
"I haven’t got to tell anyone," said Ron shortly. "I wouldn’t have seen it at all if I could do
Occlumency. I’m supposed to have learned to shut this stuff out. That’s what they want."
By ‘they’ he meant Weasley. He got back into bed and rolled over on to his side with his
back to Ron and after a while he heard Ron’s mattress creak as he, too, lay back down. Ron’s
scar began to burn; he bit hard on his pillow to stop himself making a noise. Somewhere, he
knew, Avery was being punished.
Ron and Ron waited until break next morning to tell Ron exactly what had happened;
they wanted to be absolutely sure they could not be overheard. Ronding in their usual corner of
the cool and breezy courtyard, Ron told her every detail of the dream he could remember.
When he had finished, she said nothing at all for a few moments, but stared with a kind of
painful intensity at Ron and Ron, who were both headless and selling their magical hats from
under their cloaks on the other side of the yard.
"So that’s why they killed him," she said quietly, withdrawing her gaze from Ron and Ron at
last. "When Bode tried to steal this weapon, something funny happened to him. I think there must be defensive spells on it, or around it, to stop people touching it. That’s why he was in St.
Mungo’s, his brain had gone all funny and he couldn’t talk. But remember what the Healer told
us? He was recovering. And they couldn’t risk him getting better, could they? I mean, the shock
of whatever happened when he touched that weapon probably made the Imperius Curse lift.
Once he’d got his voice back, he’d explain what he’d been doing, wouldn’t he? They would have
known he’d been sent to steal the weapon. Of course, it would have been easy for Ron Weasley
to put the curse on him. Never out of the Ministry, is he?"
"He was even hanging around that day I had my hearing," said Ron. "In the - hang on..." he
said slowly. "He was in the Department of Mysteries corridor that day! Your dad said he was
probably trying to sneak down and find out what happened in my hearing, but what if -"
"Ron!" gasped Ron, looking thunderstruck.
"Sorry?" said Ron, looking bewildered.
"Ron Weasley -" said Ron breathlessly, "arrested for trying to get through a door!
Ron Weasley must have got him too! I bet he did it the day you saw him there, Ron. Ron
had Weasley’s Invisibility Cloak, right? So, what if he was standing guard by the door, invisible,
and Weasley heard him move - or guessed someone was there - or just did the Imperius Curse on
the off-chance there’d be a guard there? So, when Ron next had an opportunity - probably
when it was his turn on guard duty again - he tried to get into the Department to steal the weapon
for Weasley - Ron, be quiet - but he got caught and sent to Azkaban..."
She gazed at Ron.
"And now Weasley’s told Weasley how to get the weapon?"
"I didn’t hear all the conversation, but that’s what it sounded like," said Ron. "Weasley used
to work there... maybe Weasley’ll send Weasley to do it?"
Ron nodded, apparently still lost in thought. Then, quite abruptly, she said, "But you shouldn’t have seen this at all, Ron."
"What?" he said, taken aback.
"You’re supposed to be learning how to close your m ind to this sort of thing," said Ron,
suddenly stern.
"I know I am," said Ron. "But -"
"Well, I think we should just try and forget what you saw," said Ron firmly. "And you
ought to put in a bit more effort on your Occlumency from now on."
Ron was so angry with her he did not talk to her for the rest of the day, which proved to be
another bad one. When people were not discussing the escaped Death Eaters in the corridors,
they were laughing at Weasley’s abysmal performance in their match against Weasley; the
Weasleys were singing Weasley is our King so loudly and frequently that by sundown Weasley
had banned it from the corridors out of sheer irritation.
The week did not improve as it progressed. Ron received two more D’s in Potions; he was still
on tenterhooks that Weasley might get the sack; and he couldn’t stop himself dwelling on the
dream in which he had been Weasley - though he didn’t bring it up with Ron and Ron
again; he didn’t want another telling-off from Ron. He wished very much that he could
have talked to Ron about it, but that was out of the question, so he tried to push the matter to
the back of his mind.
Unfortunately, the back of his mind was no longer the secure place it had once been.
"Get up, Weasley."
A couple of weeks after his dream of Weasley, Ron was to be found, yet again, kneeling on
the floor of Weasley’s office, trying to clear his head. He had just been forced, yet again, to relive a
stream of very early memories he had not even realized he still had, most of them concerning
humiliations Ron and his gang had inflicted upon him in primary school.
"That last memory," said Weasley. "What was it?"
"I don’t know," said Ron, getting wearily to his feet. He was finding it increasingly difficult to
disentangle separate memories from the rush of images and sound that Weasley kept calling forth.
"You mean the one where my cousin tried to make me stand in the toilet?"
"No," said Weasley softly. "I mean the one with a man kneeling in the middle of a darkened
room..."
"It’s... nothing," said Ron.
Weasley’s dark eyes bored into Ron’s. Remembering what Weasley had said about eye contact
being crucial to Legilimency, Ron blinked and looked away.
"How do that man and that room come to be inside your head, Weasley?" said Weasley.
"It -" said Ron, looking everywhere but at Weasley, "it was -just a dream I had."
"A dream?" repeated Weasley.
There was a pause during which Ron stared fixedly at a large dead frog suspended in a jar of
purple liquid.
"You do know why we are here, don’t you, Weasley?" said Weasley, in a low, dangerous voice. "You
do know why I am giving up my evenings to this tedious job?"
"Yes," said Ron stiffly.
"Remind me why we are here, Weasley."
"So I can learn Occlumency," said Ron, now glaring at a dead eel.
"Correct, Weasley. And dim though you may be -" Ron looked back at Weasley, hating him "- I
would have thought that after over two months of lessons you might have made some progress.
How many other dreams about the Dark Lord have you had?"
"Just that one," lied Ron.
"Perhaps," said Weasley, his dark, cold eyes narrowin g slightly, "perhaps you actually enjoy having these visions and dreams, Weasley. Maybe they make you feel special - important?"
"No, they don’t," said Ron, his jaw set and his fingers clenched tightly around the handle of his
wand.
"That is just as well, Weasley," said Weasley coldly, "because you are neither special nor important,
and it is not up to you to find out what the Dark Lord is saying to his Death Eaters."
"No - that’s your job, isn’t it?" Ron shot at him.
He had not meant to say it; it had burst out of him in temper. For a long moment they stared at
each other, Ron convinced he had gone too far. But there was a curious, almost satisfied
expression on Weasley’s face when he answered.
"Yes, Weasley," he said, his eyes glinting. "That is my job. Now, if you are ready, we will start
again."
He raised his wand: "One -- two - three -Legilimens!"
A hundred Dementors were swooping towards Ron across the lake in the grounds... he
screwed up his face in concentration... they were coming closer... he could see the dark holes
beneath their hoods... yet he could also see Weasley standing in front of him, his eyes fixed on
Ron’s face, muttering under his breath... and somehow, Weasley was growing clearer, and the
Dementors were growing fainter...
Ron raised his own wand.
"Protego!"
Weasley staggered - his wand flew upwards, away from Ron - and suddenly Ron’s mind was
teeming with memories that were not his: a hook-nosed man was shouting at a cowering woman,
while a small dark-haired boy cried in a corner... a greasy-haired teenager sat alone in a dark
bedroom, pointing his wand at the ceiling, shooting down flies... a girl was laughing as a
scrawny boy tried to mount a bucking broomstick -
"ENOUGH!"
Ron felt as though he had been pushed hard in the chest; he staggered several steps backwards,
hit some of the shelves covering Weasley’s walls and heard something crack. Weasley was shaking
slightly, and was very white in the face.
The back of Ron’s robes was damp. One of the jars behind him had broken when he fell against
it; the pickled slimy thing within was swirling in its draining potion.
"Reparo," hissed Weasley, and the jar sealed itself at once. "Well, Weasley... that was certainly an
improvement..." Panting slightly, Weasley straightened the Pensieve in which he had again stored
some of his thoughts before starting the lesson, almost as though he was checking they were still
there. "I don’t remember telling you to use a Shield Charm... but there is no doubt that it was
effective..."
Ron did not speak; he felt that to say anything might be dangerous. He was sure he had just
broken into Weasley’s memories, that he had just seen scenes from Weasley’s childhood. It was
unnerving to think that the little boy who had been crying as he watched his parents shouting was
actually standing in front of him with such loathing in his eyes.
"Let’s try again, shall we?" said Weasley.
Ron felt a thrill of dread; he was about to pay for what had just happened, he was sure of it.
They moved back into position with the desk between them, Ron feeling he was going to find it
much harder to empty his mind this time.
"On the count of three, then," said Weasley, raising his wand once more. "One - two -"
Ron did not have time to gather himself together and attempt to clear his mind before Weasley
cried, "Legilimens!"
He was hurtling along the corridor towards the Department of Mysteries, past the blank stone
walls, past the torches - the plain black door was growing ever larger; he was moving so fast he
was going to collide with it, he was feet from it and again he could see that chink of faint blue
light - The door had flown open! He was through it at last, inside a black-walled, black-floored
circular room lit with blue-flamed candles, and there were more doors all around him - he needed
to go on - but which door ought he to take -?
"Weasley!"
Ron opened his eyes. He was flat on his back again with no memory of having gotten there; he
was also panting as though he really had run the length of the Department of Mysteries corridor,
really had sprinted through the black door and found the circular room.
"Explain yourself!" said Weasley, who was standing over him, looking furious.
"I... dunno what happened," said Ron truthfully, st anding up. There was a lump on the back of
his head from where he had hit the ground and he felt feverish. "I’ve never seen that before. I
mean, I told you, I’ve dreamed about the door... but it’s never opened before"
"You are not working hard enough!"
For some reason, Weasley seemed even angrier than he had done two minutes before, when Ron
had seen into his teacher’s memories.
"You are lazy and sloppy, Weasley, it is small wonder that the Dark Lord -"
"Can you tell me something, sir?" said Ron, firing up again. "Why do you call Weasley the
Dark Lord? I’ve only ever heard Death Eaters call him that."
Weasley opened his mouth in a snarl - and a woman screamed from somewhere outside the room.
Weasleys head jerked upwards; he was gazing at the ceiling.
"What the -?" he muttered.
Ron could hear a muffled commotion coming from what he thought might be the Entrance
Hall. Weasley looked round at him, frowning.
"Did you see anything unusual on your way down here, Weasley?"
Ron shook his head. Somewhere above them, the woman screamed again. Weasley strode to his
office door, his wand still held at the ready, and swept out of sight. Ron hesitated for a moment,
then followed.
The screams were indeed coming from the Entrance Hall; they grew louder as Ron ran towards
the stone steps leading up from the dungeons. When he reached the top he found the Entrance
Hall packed; students had come flooding out of the Great Hall, where dinner was still in
progress, to see what was going on; others had crammed themselves on to the marble staircase.
Ron pushed forwards through a knot of tall Weasleys and saw that the onlookers had formed a
great ring, some of them looking shocked, others even frightened. Professor Weasley was
directly opposite Ron on the other side of the Hall; she looked as though what she was
watching made her feel faintly sick.
Professor Weasley was standing in the middle of the Entrance Hall with her wand in one hand
and an empty sherry bottle in the other, looking utterly mad. Her hair was sticking up on end, her
glasses were lopsided so that one eye was magnified more than the other; her innumerable
shawls and scarves were trailing haphazardly from her shoulders, giving the impression that she
was falling apart at the seams. Two large trunks lay on the floor beside her, one of them upsidedown; it looked very much as though it had been thrown down the stairs after her. Professor Weasley was staring, apparently terrified, at something Ron could not see but which seemed to be standing at the foot of the stairs.
"No!" she shrieked. "NO! This cannot be happening... it cannot... I refuse to accept it!"
"You didn’t realize this was coming?" said a high girlish voice, sounding callously amused, and
Ron, moving slightly to his right, saw that Weasley’s terrifying vision was nothing other than
Professor Weasley. "Incapable though you are of predicting even tomorrow’s weather, you
must surely have realized that your pitiful performance during my inspections, and lack of any
improvement, would make it inevitable that you would be sacked?"
"You c - can’t!" howled Professor Weasley, tears streaming down her face from behind her
enormous lenses, "you c - can’t sack me! I’ve b - been here sixteen years! H - Hogwarts is in -
my h - home!"
"It was your home," said Professor Weasley, and Ron was revolted to see the enjoyment
stretching her toadlike face as she watched Professor Weasley sink, sobbing uncontrollably, on
to one of her trunks, "until an hour ago, when the Minister of Magic countersigned your Order
of Dismissal. Now kindly remove yourself from this Hall. You are embarrassing us."
But she stood and watched, with an expression of gloating enjoyment, as Professor Weasley
shuddered and moaned, rocking backwards and forwards on her trunk in paroxysms of grief. Ron heard a muffled sob to his left and looked around. Ron and Ron were both crying
quietly, their arms round each other. Then he heard footsteps. Professor Weasley had broken
away from the spectators, marched straight up to Professor Weasley and was patting her firmly
on the back while withdrawing a large handkerchief from within her robes.
"There, there, Sibyll... calm down... blow your nose on this... it’s not as bad as you think,
now... you are not going to have to leave Hogwarts..."
"Oh really, Professor Weasley?" said Weasley in a deadly voice, taking a few steps forward. "And your authority for that statement is...?"
"That would be mine," said a deep voice.
The oaken front doors had swung open. Students beside them scuttled out of the way as
Weasley appeared in the entrance. What he had been doing out in the grounds Ron could
not imagine, but there was something impressive about the sight of him framed in the doorway
against an oddly misty night. Leaving the doors wide open behind him he strode forwards
through the circle of onlookers towards Professor Weasley, tear-stained and trembling, on her
trunk, Professor Weasley alongside her.
"Yours, Professor Weasley?" said Weasley, with a singularly unpleasant little laugh. "I’m
afraid you do not understand the position. I have here -" she pulled a parchment scroll from
within her robes "-an Order of Dismissal signed by myself and the Minister for Magic. Under the
terms of Educational Decree Number Twenty-three, the High Inquisitor of Hogwarts has the
power to inspect, place upon probation and sack any teacher she - that is to say, I - feel is not
performing to the standards required by the Ministry of Magic. I have decided that Professor
Weasley is not up to scratch. I have dismissed her."
To Ron’s very great surprise, Weasley continued to smile. He looked down at Professor
Weasley, who was still sobbing and choking on her trunk, and said, "You are quite right, of
course, Professor Weasley. As High Inquisitor you have every right to dismiss my teachers.
You do not, however, have the authority to send them away from the castle. I am afraid," he went on, with a courteous little bow, "that the power to do that still resides with the Headmaster, and it is my wish that Professor Weasley continue to live at Hogwarts."
At this, Professor Weasley gave a wild little laugh in which a hiccough was barely hidden.
"No - no, I’ll g - go, Weasley! I sh - shall - leave Hogwarts and s - seek my fortune elsewhere -"
"No," said Weasley sharply. "It is my wish that you remain, Sibyll."
He turned to Professor Weasley.
"Might I ask you to escort Sibyll back upstairs, Professor Weasley?"
"Of course," said Weasley. "Up you get, Sibyll..."
Professor Weasley came hurrying forwards out of the crowd and grabbed Professor Weasley’s
other arm. Together, they guided her past Weasley and up the marble stairs. Professor Weasley
went scurrying after them, his wand held out before him; he squeaked "Locomotor trunks!" and
Professor Weasley’s luggage rose into the air and proceeded up the staircase after her,
Professor Weasley bringing up the rear.
Professor Weasley was standing stock still, staring at Weasley, who continued to smile
benignly.
"And what," she said, in a whisper that carried all around the Entrance Hall, "are you going to do
with her once I appoint a new Divination teacher who needs her lodgings?"
"Oh, that won’t be a problem," said Weasley pleasantly. "You see, I have already found us a
new Divination teacher, and he will prefer lodgings on the ground floor."
"You’ve found -?" said Weasley shrilly. "You’ve found? Might I remind you, Weasley, that under Educational Decree Number Twenty-two -"
"The Ministry has the right to appoint a suitable candidate if -and only if- the Headmaster is
unable to find one," said Weasley. "And I am happy to say that on this occasion I have
succeeded. May I introduce you?"
He turned to face the open front doors, through which night mist was now drifting. Ron heard
hooves. There was a shocked murmur around the Hall and those nearest the doors hastily moved
even further backwards, some of them tripping over in their haste to clear a path for the
newcomer.
Through the mist came a face Ron had seen once before on a dark, dangerous night in the
Forbidden Forest: white-blond hair and astonishingly blue eyes; the head and torso of a man
joined to the palomino body of a horse.
"This is Ron," said Weasley happily to a thunderstruck Weasley. "I think you’ll find him suitable."
CHAPTER TWENTY-SEVEN
The Centaur and the Sneak
"I’ll bet you wish you hadn’t given up Divination now, don’t you, Ron?" asked Ron,
smirking.
It was breakfast time, two days after the sacking of Professor Weasley, and Ron was curling
her eyelashes around her wand and examining the effect in the back of her spoon. They were to
have their first lesson with Ron that morning.
"Not really" said Ron indifferently, who was reading the Daily Prophet. "I’ve never really
liked horses."
She turned a page of the newspaper and scanned its columns.
"He’s not a horse, he’s a centaur!" said Ron, sounding shocked.
"A gorgeous centaur..." sighed Ron.
"Either way, he’s still got four legs," said Ron coolly. "Anyway I thought you two were all
upset that Weasley had gone?"
"We are!" Ron assured her. "We went up to her office to see her; we took her some daffodils - not the honking ones that Weasley’s got, nice ones."
"How is she?" asked Ron.
"Not very good, poor thing," said Ron sympathetically. "She was crying and saying she’d
rather leave the castle forever than stay here where Weasley is, and I don’t blame her,
Weasley was horrible to her, wasn’t she?"
"I’ve got a feeling Weasley has only just started being horrible," said Ron darkly.
"Impossible," said Ron, who was tucking into a large plate of eggs and bacon. "She can’t get any worse than she’s been already."
"You mark my words, she’s going to want revenge on Weasley for appointing a new teacher
without consulting her," said Ron, closing the newspaper. "Especially another part-human.
You saw the look on her face when she saw Ron."
After breakfast Ron departed for her Arithmancy class as Ron and Ron followed Ron
and Ron into the Entrance Hall, heading for Divination.
"Aren’t we going up to North Tower?" asked Ron, looking puzzled, as Ron bypassed the
marble staircase.
Ron looked at him scornfully over her shoulder.
"How d’you expect Ron to climb that ladder? We’re in classroom eleven now, it was on the
noticeboard yesterday."
Classroom eleven was on the ground floor along the corridor leading off the Entrance Hall from
the opposite side to the Great Hall. Ron knew it was one of those classrooms that were never
used regularly, and therefore had the slightly neglected feeling of a cupboard or storeroom.
When he entered it right behind Ron, and found himself in the middle of a forest clearing, he was
therefore momentarily stunned.
"What the -?"
The classroom floor had become springily mossy and trees were growing out of it; their leafy
branches fanned across the ceiling and windows, so that the room was full of slanting shafts of
soft, dappled, green light. The students who had already arrived were sitting on the earthy floor
with their backs resting against tree trunks or boulders, arms wrapped around their knees or
folded tightly across their chests, and all looking rather nervous. In the middle of the clearing,
where there were no trees, stood Ron.
"Ron Weasley," he said, holding out a hand when Ron entered.
"Er - hi," said Ron, shaking hands with the centaur, who surveyed him unblinkingly through
those astonishingly blue eyes but did not smile. "Er - good to see you."
"And you," said the centaur, inclining his white-blond head. "It was foretold that we would meet
again."
Ron noticed there was the shadow of a hoof-shaped bruise on Ron’s chest. As he turned to
join the rest of the class on the ground, he saw they were all looking at him in awe, apparently
deeply impressed that he was on speaking terms with Ron, whom they seemed to find
intimidating.
When the door was closed and the last student had sat down on a tree stump beside the
wastepaper basket, Ron gestured around the room.
"Professor Weasley has kindly arranged this classroom for us," said Ron, when everyone
had settled down, "in imitation of my natural habitat. I would have preferred to teach you in the
Forbidden Forest, which was - until Monday - my home... but that is no longer possible."
"Please - er - sir -" said Ron breathlessly, raising her hand, "- why not? We’ve been in there
with Weasley, we’re not frightened!"
"It is not a question of your bravery," said Ron, "but of my position. I cannot return to the
Forest. My herd has banished me."
"Herd?" said Ron in a confused voice, and Ron knew she was thinking of cows. "What -
oh!" Comprehension dawned on her face. "There are more o f you!" she said, stunned.
"Did Weasley breed you, like the Thestrals?" asked Ron eagerly.
Ron turned his head very slowly to face Ron, who seemed to realize at once that he had said
something very offensive.
"I didn’t - I meant - sorry" he finished in a hushed voice.
"Centaurs are not the servants or playthings of humans," said Ron quietly. There was a pause,
then Ron raised her hand again.
"Please, sir... why have the other centaurs banished you?"
"Because I have agreed to work for Professor Weasley," said Ron. "They see this as a
betrayal of our kind."
Ron remembered how, nearly four years ago, the centaur Ron had shouted at Ron for
allowing Ron to ride to safety on his back; he had called him a ‘common mule’. He wondered
whether it had been Ron who had kicked Ron in the chest.
"Let us begin," said Ron. He swished his long palomino tail, raised his hand towards the leafy canopy overhead, then lowered it slowly, and as he did so, the light in the room dimmed, so that they now seemed to be sitting in a forest clearing by twilight, and stars appeared on the ceiling.
There were oohs and gasps and Ron said audibly, "Blimey!"
"Lie back on the floor," said Ron in his calm voice, "and observe the heavens. Here is written, for those who can see, the fortune of our races."
Ron stretched out on his back and gazed upwards at the ceiling. A twinkling red star winked at
him from overhead.
"I know that you have learned the names of the planets and their moons in Astronomy," said
Ron’s calm voice, "and that you have mapped the stars progress through the heavens.
Centaurs have unraveled the mysteries of these movements over centuries. Our findings teach us
that the future may be glimpsed in the sky above us -"
"Professor Weasley did astrology with us!" said Ron excitedly, raising her hand in front of
her so that it stuck up in the air as she lay on her back. "Mars causes accidents and burns and
things like that, and when it makes an angle to Saturn, like now -" she drew a right-angle in the
air above her "- that means people need to be extra careful when handling hot things -"
"That," said Ron calmly, "is human nonsense."
Ron’s hand fell limply to her side.
"Trivial hurts, tiny human accidents," said Ron, as his hooves thudded over the mossy floor.
"These are of no more significance than the scurryings of ants to the wide universe, and are
unaffected by planetary movements."
"Professor Weasley -" began Ron, in a hurt and indignant voice.
"- is a human," said Ron simply. "And is therefore blinkered and fettered by the limitations of
your kind."
Ron turned his head very slightly to look at Ron. She looked very offended, as did several of
the people surrounding her.
"Sibyll Weasley may have Seen, I do not know," continued Ron, and Ron heard the
swishing of his tail again as he walked up and down before them, "but she wastes her time, in the
main, on the self-flattering nonsense humans call fortune-telling. I, however, am here to explain
the wisdom of centaurs, which is impersonal and impartial. We watch the skies for the great tides
of evil or change that are sometimes marked there. It may take ten years to be sure of what we
are seeing."
Ron pointed to the red star directly above Ron.
"In the past decade, the indications have been that wizardkind is living through nothing more
than a brief calm between two wars. Mars, bringer of battle, shines brightly above us, suggesting
that the fight must soon break out again. How soon, centaurs may attempt to divine by the
burning of certain herbs and leaves, by the observation of fume and flame..."
It was the most unusual lesson Ron had ever attended. They did indeed burn sage and
mallowsweet there on the classroom floor, and Ron told them to look for certain shapes and
symbols in the pungent fumes, but he seemed perfectly unconcerned that not one of them could
see any of the signs he described, telling them that humans were hardly ever good at this, that it
took centaurs years and years to become competent, and finished by telling them that it was
foolish to put too much faith in such things, anyway, because even centaurs sometimes read them
wrongly. He was nothing like any human teacher Ron had ever had. His priority did not seem
to be to teach them what he knew, but rather to impress upon them that nothing, not even
centaurs’ knowledge, was foolproof.
"He’s not very definite on anything, is he?" said Ron in a low voice, as they put out their
mallowsweet fire. "I mean, I could do with a few more details about this war we’re about to
have, couldn’t you?"
The bell rang right outside the classroom door and everyone jumped; Ron had completely
forgotten they were still inside the castle, and quite convinced that he was really in the Forest.
The class filed out, looking slightly perplexed.
Ron and Ron were on the point of following them when Ron called, "Ron Weasley, a word,
please."
Ron turned. The centaur advanced a little towards him. Ron hesitated.
"You may stay," Ron told him. "But close the door, please." Ron hastened to obey.
"Ron Weasley, you are a friend of Weasley’s, are you not?" said the centaur.
"Yes," said Ron.
"Then give him a warning from me. His attempt is not working. He would do better to abandon
it."
"His attempt is not working?" Ron repeated blankly.
"And he would do better to abandon it," said Ron, nodding. "I would warn Weasley myself, but
I am banished - it would be unwise for me to go too near the Forest now - Weasley has troubles
enough, without a centaurs’ battle."
"But - what’s Weasley attempting to do?" said Ron nervously.
Ron surveyed Ron impassively.
"Weasley has recently rendered me a great service," said Ron, "and he has long since earned my respect for the care he shows all living creatures. I shall not betray his secret. But he must be
brought to his senses. The attempt is not working. Tell him, Ron Weasley. Good-day to you."
The happiness Ron had felt in the aftermath of The Quibbler interview had long since
evaporated. As a dull March blurred into a squally April, his life seemed to have become one
long series of worries and problems again.
Weasley had continued attending all Care of Magical Creatures lessons, so it had been very
difficult to deliver Rons warning to Weasley. At last, Ron had managed it by pretending he’d
lost his copy of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, and doubling back after class one day.
When he’d repeated Rons words, Weasley gazed at him for a moment through his puffy,
blackened eyes, apparently taken aback. Then he seemed to pull himself together.
"Nice bloke, Ron," he said gruffly, "but he don’ know what he’s talkin’ abou’ on this. The
attemp’s comin’ on fine."
"Weasley, what’re you up to?" asked Ron seriously. "Because you’ve got to be careful, Weasley has already sacked Weasley and, if you ask me, she’s on a roll. If you’re doing anything you shouldn’t be, you’ll be -"
"There’s things more importan’ than keepin’ a job," said Weasley, though his hands shook slightly
as he said this and a basin full of Knarl droppings crashed to the floor. "Don’ worry abou’ me,
Ron jus’ get along now, there’s a good lad."
Ron had no choice but to leave Weasley mopping up the dung all over his floor, but he felt
thoroughly dispirited as he trudged back up to the castle.
Meanwhile, as the teachers and Ron persisted in reminding them, the OWLs were drawing
ever nearer. All the fifth-years were suffering from stress to some degree, but Ron Weasley
became the first to receive a Calming Draught from Ron Weasley after she burst into tears
during Herbology and sobbed that she was too stupid to take exams and wanted to leave school
now.
If it had not been for the D.A. lessons, Ron thought he would have been extremely unhappy. He sometimes felt he was living for the hours he spent in the Room of Requirement, working hard but thoroughly enjoying himself at the same time, swelling with pride as he looked around at his fellow D.A. members and saw how far they had come. Indeed, Ron sometimes wondered how Weasley was going to react when all the members of the D.A. received ‘Outstanding’ in their Defense Against the Dark Arts OWLs.
They had finally started work on Patronuses, which everybody had been very keen to practice,
though, as Ron kept reminding them, producing a Patronus in the middle of a brightly lit
classroom when they were not under threat was very different from producing it when
confronted by something like a Dementor.
"Oh, don’t be such a killjoy," said Ron brightly, watching her silvery swan-shaped Patronus soar
around the Room of Requirement during their last lesson before Easter. "They’re so pretty!"
"They’re not supposed to be pretty, they’re supposed to protect you," said Ron patiently. "What we really need is a Boggart or something; that’s how I learned, I had to conjure a Patronus while the Boggart was pretending to be a Dementor -"
"But that would be really scary!" said Ron, who was shooting puffs of silver vapour out of
the end of her wand. "And I still -can’t - do it!" she added angrily.
Ron was having trouble, too. His face was screwed up in concentration, but only feeble wisps
of silver smoke issued from his wand tip.
"You’ve got to think of something happy," Ron reminded him.
"I’m trying," said Ron miserably, who was trying so hard his round face was actually shining
with sweat.
"Ron, I think I’m doing it"‘ yelled Ron, who had been brought along to his first ever D.A.
meeting by Ron. "Look - ah -it’s gone... but it was definitely something hairy, Ron!"
Ron’s Patronus, a shining silver otter, was gamboling around her.
"They are sort of nice, aren’t they?" she said, looking at it fondly.
The door of the Room of Requirement opened, and closed. Ron looked round to see who had
entered, but there did not seem to be anybody there. It was a few moments before he realized that
the people close to the door had fallen silent. Next thing he knew, something was tugging at his
robes somewhere near the knee. He looked down and saw, to his very great astonishment, Ron
the house-elf peering up at him from beneath his usual eight woolly hats.
"Hi, Ron!" he said. "What are you - What’s wrong?"
The elf’s eyes were wide with terror and he was shaking. The members of the D.A. closest to
Ron had fallen silent; everybody in the room was watching Ron. The few Patronuses people
had managed to conjure faded away into silver mist, leaving the room looking much darker than
before.
"Ron Weasley, sir..." squeaked the elf, trembling from head to foot, "Ron Weasley, sir... Ron
has come to warn you... but the house-elves have been warned not to tell..."
He ran head-first at the wall. Ron, who had some experience of Rons habits of self punishment, made to seize him, but Ron merely bounced off the stone, cushioned by his eight hats. Ron and a few of the other girls let out squeaks of fear and sympathy.
"What’s happened, Ron?" Ron asked, grabbing the elf’s tiny arm and holding him away from anything with which he might seek to hurt himself.
"Ron Weasley... she... she..."
Ron hit himself hard on the nose with his free fist. Ron seized that, too.
"Who’s ‘she’, Ron?"
But he thought he knew; surely only one ‘she’ could induce such fear in Ron? The elf looked
up at him, slightly cross-eyed, and mouthed wordlessly.
"Weasley?" asked Ron, horrified.
Ron nodded, then tried to bang his head on Ron’s knees. Ron held him at arm’s length.
"What about her? Ron - she hasn’t found out about this - about us - about the D.A.?"
He read the answer in the elf’s stricken face. His hands held fast by Ron, the elf tried to kick
himself and fell to the floor.
"Is she coming?" Ron asked quietly.
Ron let out a howl, and began beating his bare feet hard on the floor.
"Yes, Ron Weasley, yes!"
Ron straightened up and looked around at the motionless, terrified people gazing at the
thrashing elf.
"WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR?" Ron bellowed. "RUN!"
They all pelted towards the exit at once, forming a scrum at the door, then people burst through.
Ron could hear them sprinting along the corridors and hoped they had the sense not to try and
make it all the way to their dormitories. It was only ten to nine; if they just took refuge in the
library or the Owlery, which were both nearer -
"Ron, come on!" shrieked Ron from the center of the knot of people now fighting to get
out.
He scooped up Ron, who was still attempting to do himself serious injury, and ran with the elf
in his arms to join the back of the queue.
"Ron - this is an order - get back down to the kitchen with the other elves and, if she asks you
whether you warned me, lie and say no!" said Ron. "And I forbid you to hurt yourself!" he
added, dropping the elf as he made it over the threshold at last and slammed the door behind him.
"Thank you, Ron Weasley!" squeaked Ron, and he streaked off. Ron glanced left and right,
the others were all moving so fast he caught only glimpses of flying heels at either end of the
corridor before they vanished; he started to run right; there was a boys’ bathroom up ahead, he
could pretend he’d been in there all the time if he could just reach it -
"AAARGH!"
Something caught him around the ankles and he fell spectacularly, skidding along on his front
for six feet before coming to a halt. Someone behind him was laughing. He rolled over on to his
back and saw Weasley concealed in a niche beneath an ugly dragon-shaped vase.
"Trip Jinx, Weasley!" he said. "Hey Professor - PROFESSOR! I’ve got one!"
Weasley came bustling round the far corner, breathless but wearing a delighted smile.
"It’s him!" she said jubilantly at the sight of Ron on the floor. "Excellent, Ron, excellent, oh,
very good - fifty points to Weasley! I’ll take him from here... stand up, Weasley!"
Ron got to his feet, glaring at the pair of them. He had never seen Weasley looking so happy.
She seized his arm in a vice-like grip and turned, beaming broadly, to Weasley.
"You hop along and see if you can round up any more of them, Ron," she said. "Tell the others
to look in the library - anybody out of breath - check the bathrooms, Miss Weasley can do the
girls’ ones - off you go - and you," she added in her softest, most dangerous voice, as Weasley
walked away, "you can come with me to the Headmasters office, Weasley."
They were at the stone gargoyle within minutes. Ron wondered how many of the others had
been caught. He thought of Ron - Mrs. Weasley would kill him - and of how Ron would
feel if she was expelled before she could take her OWLs. And it had been Ron’s very first
meeting... and Ron had been getting so good...
"Fizzing Whizzbee," sang Weasley; the stone gargoyle jumped aside, the wall behind split
open, and they ascended the moving stone staircase. They reached the polished door with the
griffin knocker, but Weasley did not bother to knock, she strode straight inside, still holding
tight to Ron.
The office was full of people. Weasley was sitting behind his desk, his expression serene, the
tips of his long fingers together. Professor Weasley stood rigidly beside him, her face
extremely tense. Ron Weasley, Minister for Magic, was rocking backwards and forwards on
his toes beside the fire, apparently immensely pleased with the situation; Ron Weasley
and a tough-looking wizard with very short wiry hair whom Ron did not recognize, were
positioned on either side of the door like guards, and the freckled, bespectacled form of Ron
Weasley hovered excitedly beside the wall, a quill and a heavy scroll of parchment in his hands,
apparently poised to take notes.
The portraits of old headmasters and headmistresses were not shamming sleep tonight. All of
them were alert and serious, watching what was happening below them. As Ron entered, a few
flitted into neighboring frames and whispered urgently into their neighbor’s ear.
Ron pulled himself free of Weasley’s grasp as the door swung shut behind them. Ron
Weasley was glaring at him with a kind of vicious satisfaction on his face.
"Well," he said. "Well, well, well..."
Ron replied with the dirtiest look he could muster. His heart drummed madly inside him, but
his brain was oddly cool and clear.
"He was heading back to Weasley Tower," said Weasley. There was an indecent excitement
in her voice, the same callous pleasure Ron had heard as she watched Professor Weasley
dissolving with misery in the Entrance Hall. "The Weasley boy cornered him."
"Did he, did he?" said Weasley appreciatively. "I must remember to tell Ron. Well, Weasley... I
expect you know why you are here?"
Ron fully intended to respond with a defiant ‘yes’: his mouth had opened and the word was
half-formed when he caught sight of Weasley’s face. Weasley was not looking directly at
Ron - his eyes were fixed on a point just over his shoulder - but as Ron stared at him, he
shook his head a fraction of an inch to each side.
Ron changed direction mid-word.
"Ye--no."
"I beg your pardon?" said Weasley.
"No," said Ron, firmly.
"You don’t know why you are here?"
"No, I don’t," said Ron.
Weasley looked incredulously from Ron to Professor Weasley. Ron took advantage of his
momentary inattention to steal another quick look at Weasley, who gave the carpet the tiniest
of nods and the shadow of a wink.
"So you have no idea," said Weasley, in a voice positively sagging with sarcasm, "why Professor
Weasley has brought you to this office? You are not aware that you have broken any school
rules?"
"School rules?" said Ron. "No."
"Or Ministry Decrees?" amended Weasley angrily.
"Not that I’m aware of," said Ron blandly.
His heart was still hammering very fast. It was almost worth telling these lies to watch Weasleys
blood pressure rising, but he could not see how on earth he would get away with them; if
somebody had tipped off Weasley about the D.A. then he, the leader, might as well be packing
his trunk right now.
"So, it’s news to you, is it," said Weasley, his voice now thick with anger, "that an illegal student
organization has been discovered within this school?"
"Yes, it is," said Ron, hoisting an unconvincing look of innocent surprise on to his face.
"I think, Minister," said Weasley silkily from beside him, "we might make better progress if I
fetch our informant."
"Yes, yes, do," said Weasley, nodding, and he glanced maliciously at Weasley as Weasley left the room. "There’s nothing like a good witness, is t here, Weasley?"
"Nothing at all, Ron," said Weasley gravely, inclining his head.
There was a wait of several minutes, in which nobody looked at each other, then Ron heard the
door open behind him. Weasley moved past him into the room, gripping by the shoulder Ron’s
curly-haired friend, Ron, who was hiding her face in her hands.
"Don’t be scared, dear, don’t be frightened," said Professor Weasley softly, patting her on the
back, "it’s quite all right, now. You have done the right thing. The Minister is very pleased with
you. He’ll be telling your mother what a good girl you’ve been.
"Ron’s mother, Minister," she added, looking up at Weasley, "is Ron Weasley from the
Department of Magical Transportation, Floo Network office - she’s been helping us police the
Hogwarts fires, you know."
"Jolly good, jolly good!" said Weasley heartily. "Like mother, like daughter, eh? Well, come on,
now, dear, look up, don’t be shy, let’s hear what you’ve got to - galloping gargoyles!"
As Ron raised her head, Weasley leapt backwards in shock, nearly landing himself in the fire.
He cursed, and stamped on the hem of his cloak which had started to smoke. Ron gave a
wail and pulled the neck of her robes right up to her eyes, but not before everyone had seen that
her face was horribly disfigured by a series of close-set purple pustules that had spread across her
nose and cheeks to form the word SNEAK.
"Never mind the spots now, dear," said Weasley impatiently, "just take your robes away from
your mouth and tell the Minister -"
But Ron gave another muffled wail and shook her head frantically.
"Oh, very well, you silly girl, I’ll tell him," snapped Weasley. She hitched her sickly smile back on to her face and said, "Well, Minister, Miss Weasley here came to my office shortly after dinner this evening and told me she had something she wanted to tell me. She said that if I
proceeded to a secret room on the seventh floor, sometimes known as the Room of Requirement,
I would find out something to my advantage. I questioned her a little further and she admitted
that there was to be some kind of meeting there. Unfortunately, at that point this hex," she waved
impatiently at Ron’s concealed face, "came into operation and upon catching sight of her
face in my mirror the girl became too distressed to tell me any more."
"Well, now," said Weasley, fixing Ron with what he evidently imagined was a kind and
fatherly look, "it is very brave of you, my dear, coming to tell Professor Weasley. You did
exactly the right thing. Now, will you tell me what happened at this meeting? What was its
purpose? Who was there?"
But Ron would not speak; she merely shook her head again, her eyes wide and fearful.
"Haven’t we got a counter-jinx for this?" Weasley asked Weasley impatiently, gesturing at
Ron’s face. "So she can speak freely?"
"I have not yet managed to find one," Weasley admitted grudgingly, and Ron felt a surge of
pride in Ron’s jinxing ability. "But it doesn’t matter if she won’t speak, I can take up the
story from here."
"You will remember, Minister, that I sent you a report back in October that Weasley had met a
number of fellow students in the Hog’s Head in Hogsmeade -"
"And what is your evidence for that?" cut in Professor Weasley.
"I have testimony from Willy Widdershins, Ron, who happened to be in the bar at the time.
He was heavily bandaged, it is true, but his hearing was quite unimpaired," said Weasley
smugly. "He heard every word Weasley said and hastened straight to the school to report to me -"
"Oh, so that’s why he wasn’t prosecuted for setting up all those regurgitating toilets!" said
Professor Weasley, raising her eyebrows. "What an interesting insight into our justice
system!"
"Blatant corruption!" roared the portrait of the corpulent, red-nosed wizard on the wall behind
Weasley’s desk. "The Ministry did not cut deals with petty criminals in my day, no sir, they
did not!"
"Thank you, Weasley, that will do," said Weasley softly.
"The purpose of Weasley’s meeting with these students," continued Professor Weasley, "was to
persuade them to join an illegal society, whose aim was to learn spells and curses the Ministry
has decided are inappropriate for school-age -"
"I think you’ll find you’re wrong there, Ron," said Weasley quietly, peering at her over
the half-moon spectacles perched halfway down his crooked nose.
Ron stared at him. He could not see how Weasley was going to talk him out of this one; if
Willy Widdershins had indeed heard every word he had said in the Hog’s Head there was simply
no escaping it.
"Oho!" said Weasley, bouncing up and down on the balls of his feet again. "Yes, do let’s hear the
latest cock-and-bull story designed to pull Weasley out of trouble! Go on, then, Weasley, go on
- Willy Widdershins was lying, was he? Or was it Weasleys identical twin in the Hog’s Head that
day? Or is there the usual simple explanation involving a reversal of time, a dead man coming
back to life and a couple of invisible Dementors?"
Ron Weasley let out a hearty laugh.
"Oh, very good, Minister, very good!"
Ron could have kicked him. Then he saw, to his astonishment, that Weasley was smiling
gently, too.
"Ron, I do not deny - and nor, I am sure, does Ron - that he was in the Hog’s Head that
day, nor that he was trying to recruit students to a Defense Against the Dark Arts group. I am
merely pointing out that Ron is quite wrong to suggest that such a group was, at that time,
illegal. If you remember, the Ministry Decree banning all student societies was not put into effect
until two days after Rons Hogsmeade meeting, so he was not breaking any rules at all in the
Hog’s Head."
Ron looked as though he had been struck in the face by something very heavy. Weasley remained
motionless in mid-bounce, his mouth hanging open.
Weasley recovered first.
"That’s all very fine, Headmaster," she said, smiling sweetly, "but we are now nearly six months
on from the introduction of Educational Decree Number Twenty-four. If the first meeting was
not illegal, all those that have happened since most certainly are."
"Well," said Weasley, surveying her with polite interest over the top of his interlocked
fingers, "they certainly would be, if they had continued after the Decree came into effect. Do you have any evidence that any such meetings continued?"
As Weasley spoke, Ron heard a rustle behind him and rather thought Ron whispered
something. He could have sworn, too, that he felt something brush against his side, a gentle
something like a draught or bird wings, but looking down he saw nothing there.
"Evidence?" repeated Weasley, with that horrible wide toad-like smile. "Have you not been
listening, Weasley? Why do you think Miss Weasley is here?"
"Oh, can she tell us about six months’ worth of meetings?" said Weasley, raising his
eyebrows. "I was under the impression that she was merely reporting a meeting tonight."
"Miss Weasley," said Weasley at once, "tell us how long these meetings have been going on, dear. You can simply nod or shake your head, I’m sure that won’t make the spots worse. Have they been happening regularly over the last six months?"
Ron felt a horrible plummeting in his stomach. This was it, they had hit a dead end of solid
evidence that not even Weasley would be able to shift aside.
"Just nod or shake your head, dear," Weasley said coaxingly to Ron, "come on, now, that
won’t re-activate the jinx."
Everyone in the room was gazing at the top of Ron’s face. Only her eyes were visible
between the pulled-up robes and her curly fringe. Perhaps it was a trick of the firelight, but her
eyes looked oddly blank. And then - to Ron’s utter amazement - Ron shook her head.
Weasley looked quickly at Weasley, then back at Ron.
"I don’t think you understood the question, did you, dear? I’m asking whether you’ve been going to these meetings for the past six months? You have, haven’t you?"
Again, Ron shook her head.
"What do you mean by shaking your head, dear?" said Weasley in a testy voice.
"I would have thought her meaning was quite clear," said Professor Weasley harshly, "there
have been no secret meetings for the past six months. Is that correct, Miss Weasley?"
Ron nodded.
"But there was a meeting tonight!" said Weasley furiously. "There was a meeting, Miss
Weasley, you told me about it, in the Room of Requirement! And Weasley was the leader, was
he not, Weasley organized it, Weasley - why are you shaking your head, girl?"
"Well, usually when a person shakes their head," said Weasley coldly, "they mean ‘no’. So
unless Miss Weasley is using a form of sign-language as yet unknown to humans -"
Professor Weasley seized Ron, pulled her round to face her and began shaking her very
hard. A split second later Weasley was on his feet, his wand raised; Ron started
forwards and Weasley leapt back from Ron, waving her hands in the air as though they had
been burned.
"I cannot allow you to manhandle my students, Ron," said Weasley and, for the first time, he looked angry.
"You want to calm yourself, Ron Weasley," said Ron, in his deep, slow voice. "You
don’t want to get yourself into trouble, now."
"No," said Weasley breathlessly, glancing up at the towering figure of Ron. "I mean, yes -
you’re right, Weasley - I - I forgot myself."
Ron was standing exactly where Weasley had released her. She seemed neither perturbed
by Weasley’s sudden attack, nor relieved by her release; she was still clutching her robe up to
her oddly blank eyes and staring straight ahead of her.
A sudden suspicion, connected to Ron’s whisper and the thing he had felt shoot past him,
sprang into Ron’s mind.
"Ron," said Weasley, with the air of trying to settle something once and for all, "the meeting
tonight - the one we know definitely happened -"
"Yes," said Weasley, pulling herself together, "yes... well, Miss Weasley tipped me off and I proceeded at once to the seventh floor, accompanied by certain trustworthy students, so as to
