catch those in the meeting red-handed. It appears that they were forewarned of my arrival,
however, because when we reached the seventh floor they were running in every direction. It
does not matter, however. I have all their names here, Miss Weasley ran into the Room of
Requirement for me to see if they had left anything behind. We needed evidence and the room
provided."
And to Ron’s horror, she withdrew from her pocket the list of names that had been pinned upon
the Room of Requirement’s wall and handed it to Weasley.
"The moment I saw Weasley’s name on the list, I knew what we were dealing with," she said softly.
"Excellent," said Weasley, a smile spreading across his face, "excellent, Ron. And... by
thunder..."
He looked up at Weasley, who was still standing beside Ron, his wand held loosely in
his hand.
"See what they’ve named themselves?" said Weasley quietly. "Weasley’s Army."
Weasley reached out and took the piece of parchment from Weasley. He gazed at the heading
scribbled by Ron months before and for a moment seemed unable to speak. Then he looked
up, smiling.
"Well, the game is up," he said simply. "Would you like a written confession from me, Ron
- or will a statement before these witnesses suffice?"
Ron saw Weasley and Ron look at each other. There was fear in both faces. He did not
understand what was going on, and nor, apparently, did Weasley.
"Statement?" said Weasley slowly. "What - I don’t -?"
"Weasley’s Army, Ron," said Weasley, still smiling as he waved the list of names
before Weasley’s face. "Not Weasley’s Army. Weasley’s Army."
"But - but -"
Understanding blazed suddenly in Weasleys face. He took a horrified step backwards, yelped, and
jumped out of the fire again.
"You?" he whispered, stamping again on his smouldering cloak.
"That’s right," said Weasley pleasantly.
"You organized this?"
"I did," said Weasley.
"You recruited these students for - for your army?"
"Tonight was supposed to be the first meeting," said Weasley, nodding. "Merely to see
whether they would be interested in joining me. I see now that it was a mistake to invite Miss
Weasley, of course."
Ron nodded. Weasley looked from her to Weasley, his chest swelling.
"Then you have been plotting against me!" he yelled.
"That’s right," said Weasley cheerfully.
"NO!" shouted Ron.
Ron flashed a look of warning at him, Weasley widened her eyes threateningly, but it
had suddenly dawned on Ron what Weasley was about to do, and he could not let it
happen.
"No -- Professor Weasley -!"
"Be quiet, Ron, or I am afraid you will have to leave my office," said Weasley calmly.
"Yes, shut up, Weasley!" barked Weasley, who was still ogling Weasley with a kind of horrified
delight. "Well, well, well - I came here tonight expecting to expel Weasley and instead -"
"Instead you get to arrest me," said Weasley, smiling. "It’s like losing a Knut and finding a
Galleon, isn’t it?"
"Weasley!" cried Weasley, now positively quivering with delight, "Weasley, have you written it all
down, everything he’s said, his confession, have you got it?"
"Yes, sir, I think so, sir!" said Ron eagerly, whose nose was splattered with ink from the speed
of his note-taking.
"The bit about how he’s been trying to build up an army against the Ministry, how he’s been
working to destabilize me?"
"Yes, sir, I’ve got it, yes!" said Ron, scanning his notes joyfully.
"Very well, then," said Weasley, now radiant with glee, "duplicate your notes, Weasley, and send a
copy to the Daily Prophet at once. If we send a fast owl we should make the morning edition!"
Ron dashed from the room, slamming the door behind him, and Weasley turned back to
Weasley. "You will now be escorted back to the Ministry, where you will be formally
charged, then sent to Azkaban to await trial!"
"Ah," said Weasley gently, "yes. Yes, I thought we might hit that little snag."
"Snag?" said Weasley, his voice still vibrating with joy. "I see no snag, Weasley!"
"Well," said Weasley apologetically, "I’m afraid I do."
"Oh, really?"
"Well - it’s just that you seem to be laboring under the delusion that I am going to - what is the
phrase? - come quietly. I am afraid I am not going to come quietly at all, Ron. I have
absolutely no intention of being sent to Azkaban. I could break out, of course - but what a waste
of time, and frankly, I can think of a whole host of things I would rather be doing."
Weasley’s face was growing steadily redder; she looked as though she was being filled with
boiling water. Weasley stared at Weasley with a very silly expression on his face, as though he
had just been stunned by a sudden blow and could not quite believe it had happened. He made a
small choking noise, then looked round at Ron and the man with short grey hair, who alone
of everyone in the room had remained entirely silent so far. The latter gave Weasley a reassuring
nod and moved forwards a little, away from the wall. Ron saw his hand drift, almost casually,
towards his pocket.
"Don’t be silly, Weasley," said Weasley kindly. "I’m sure you are an excellent Auror - I seem to remember that you achieved ‘Outstanding’ in all your Ron s -- but if you attempt to -- er -- bring me in by force, I will have to hurt you."
The man called Weasley blinked rather foolishly. He looked towards Weasley again, but this time
seemed to be hoping for a clue as to what to do next.
"So," sneered Weasley, recovering himself, "you intend to take on Weasley, Weasley, Ron
and myself single-handed, do you, Weasley?"
"Merlin’s beard, no," said Weasley, smiling, "not unless you are foolish enough to force me
to."
"He will not be single-handed!" said Professor Weasley loudly, plunging her hand inside her
robes.
"Oh yes he will, Ron!" said Weasley sharply. "Hogwarts needs you!"
"Enough of this rubbish!" said Weasley, pulling out his own wand. "Weasley! Weasley! Take
him!"
A streak of silver light flashed around the room; there was a bang like a gunshot and the floor
trembled; a hand grabbed the scruff of Ron’s neck and forced him down on the floor as a
second silver flash went off; several of the portraits yelled, Ron screeched and a cloud of dust
filled the air. Coughing in the dust, Ron saw a dark figure fall to the ground with a crash in
front of him; there was a shriek and a thud and somebody cried, "No!"; then there was the sound
of breaking glass, frantically scuffling footsteps, a groan... and silence.
Ron struggled around to see who was half-strangling him and saw Professor Weasley
crouched beside him; she had forced both him and Ron out of harm’s way. Dust was still
floating gently down through the air on to them. Panting slightly, Ron saw a very tall figure
moving towards them.
"Are you all right?" Weasley asked.
"Yes!" said Professor Weasley, getting up and dragging Ron and Ron with her.
The dust was clearing. The wreckage of the office loomed into view: Weasley’s desk had
been overturned, all of the spindly tables had been knocked to the floor, their silver instruments
in pieces. Weasley, Weasley, Ron and Weasley lay motionless on the floor. Ron the
phoenix soared in wide circles above them, singing softly.
"Unfortunately, I had to hex Ron too, or it would have looked very suspicious," said
Weasley in a low voice. "He was remarkably quick on the uptake, modifying Miss
Weasley’s memory like that while everyone was looking the other way - thank him, for me,
won’t you, Ron?
"Now, they will all awake very soon and it will be best if they do not know that we had time to
communicate - you must act as though no time has passed, as though they were merely knocked
to the ground, they will not remember -"
"Where will you go, Weasley?" whispered Professor Weasley. "Grimmauld Place?"
"Oh no," said Weasley, with a grim smile, "I am not leaving to go into hiding. Weasley will
soon wish he’d never dislodged me from Hogwarts, I promise you."
"Professor Weasley..." Ron began.
He did not know what to say first: how sorry he was that he had started the D.A. in the first place
and caused all this trouble, or how terrible he felt that Weasley was leaving to save him from
expulsion? But Weasley cut him off before he could say another word.
"Listen to me, Ron," he said urgently. "You must study Occlumency as hard as you can, do you understand me? Do everything Professor Weasley tells you and practice it particularly every night before sleeping so that you can close your mind to bad dreams - you will understand why soon enough, but you must promise me -"
The man called Weasley was stirring. Weasley seized Ron’s wrist.
"Remember - close your mind -"
But as Weasley’s fingers closed over Rons skin, a pain shot through the scar on his
forehead and he felt again that terrible, snakelike longing to strike Weasley, to bite him, to
hurt him -
"- you will understand," whispered Weasley.
Ron circled the office and swooped low over him. Weasley released Ron, raised his
hand and grasped the phoenix’s long golden tail. There was a flash of fire and the pair of them
were gone.
"Where is he?" yelled Weasley, pushing himself up from the floor. "Where is he?"
"I don’t know!" shouted Ron, also leaping to his feet.
"Well, he can’t have Disapparated!" cried Weasley. "You can’t do it from inside this school -"
"The stairs!" cried Weasley, and he flung himself upon the door, wrenched it open and
disappeared, followed closely by Ron and Weasley. Weasley hesitated, then got slowly to his
feet, brushing dust from his front. There was a long and painful silence.
"Well, Ron," said Weasley nastily, straightening his torn shirtsleeve, "I’m afraid this is the end
of your friend Weasley."
"You think so, do you?" said Professor Weasley scornfully.
Weasley seemed not to hear her. He was looking around at the wrecked office. A few of the
portraits hissed at him; one or two even made rude hand gestures.
"You’d better get those two off to bed," said Weasley, looking back at Professor Weasley with a dismissive nod towards Ron and Ron.
Professor Weasley said nothing, but marched Ron and Ron to the door. As it swung
closed behind them, Ron heard Phineas ’s voice.
"You know, Minister, I disagree with Weasley on many counts... but you cannot deny he’s
got style..."
CHAPTER TWENTY-EIGHT
Weasley’s Worst Memory
BY ORDER OF THE MINISTRY OF MAGIC
Ron  Weasley (High Inquisitor) has replaced Ron Weasley as Head of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
The above is in accordance with Educational Decree Number Twenty-eight.
Signed: Ron Oswald Weasley, Minister for Magic
The notices had gone up all around the school overnight, but they did not explain how every
single person within the castle seemed to know that Weasley had overcome two Aurors, the
High Inquisitor, the Minister for Magic and his Junior Assistant to escape. No matter where
Ron went within the castle, the sole topic of conversation was Weasley’s flight, and though
some of the details may have gone awry in the retelling (Ron overheard one second-year girl
assuring another that Weasley was now lying in St. Mungo’s with a pumpkin for a head) it was
surprising how accurate the rest of their information was. Everybody knew, for instance, that
Ron and Ron were the only students to have witnessed the scene in Weasley’s office
and, as Ron was now in the hospital wing, Ron found himself besieged with requests to
give a first-hand account.
"Weasley will be back before long," said Ron Weasley confidently on the way back from
Herbology, after listening intently to Ron’s story. "They couldn’t keep him away in our second
year and they won’t be able to this time. The Ron Weasley told me -" he dropped his voice
conspiratorially, so that Ron, Ron and Ron had to lean closer to him to hear "- that
Weasley tried to get back into his office last night after they’d searched the castle and grounds
for him. Couldn’t get past the gargoyle. The Head’s office has sealed itself against her." Ron
smirked. "Apparently, she had a right little tantrum."
"Oh, I expect she really fancied herself sitting up there in the Heads office," said Ron
viciously, as they walked up the stone steps into the Entrance Hall. "Lording it over all the other
teachers, the stupid puffed-up, power-crazy old -"
"Now, do you really want to finish that sentence, Weasley?"
Ron Weasley had slid out from behind the door, closely followed by Weasley and Weasley. His
pale, pointed face was alight with malice.
"Afraid I’m going to have to dock a few points from Weasley and Weasley," he drawled.
"It’s only teachers who can dock points from houses, Weasley," said Ron at once.
"Yeah, we’re prefects, too, remember?" snarled Ron.
"I know prefects can’t dock points, Weasel King," sneered Weasley. Weasley and Weasley sniggered.
"But members of the Inquisitorial Squad -"
"The what!" said Ron sharply.
"The Inquisitorial Squad, Weasley," said Weasley, pointing towards a tiny silver ‘I’ on his robes just beneath his prefect’s badge. "A select group of students who are supportive of the Ministry of Magic, hand-picked by Professor Weasley. Anyway, members of the Inquisitorial Squad do
have the power to dock points... so, Weasley, I’ll have five from you for being rude about our
new Headmistress. Weasley, five for contradicting me. Five because I don’t like you, Weasley.
Weasley, your shirts untucked, so I’ll have another five for that. Oh yeah, I forgot, you’re a
Mudblood, Weasley, so ten off for that."
Ron pulled out his wand, but Ron pushed it away, whispering, "Don’t!"
"Wise move, Weasley," breathed Weasley. "New Head, new times... be good now, Potty... Weasel King..."
Laughing heartily, he strode away with Weasley and Weasley.
"He was bluffing," said Ron, looking appalled. "He can’t be allowed to dock points... that
would be ridiculous... it would completely undermine the prefect system."
But Ron, Ron and Ron had turned automatically towards the giant hour-glasses set in
niches along the wall behind them, which recorded the house-points. Weasley and Weasley
had been neck and neck in the lead that morning. Even as they watched, stones flew upwards,
reducing the amounts in the lower bulbs. In fact, the only glass that seemed unchanged was the
emerald-filled one of Weasley.
"Noticed, have you?" said Ron’s voice.
He and Ron had just come down the marble staircase and joined Ron, Ron, Ron and
Ron in front of the hour-glasses.
"Weasley just docked us all about fifty points," said Ron furiously, as they watched several more stones fly upwards from the Weasley hour-glass.
"Yeah, Weasley tried to do us during break," said Ron.
"What do you mean, ‘tried’?" said Ron quickly.
"He never managed to get all the words out," said Ron, "due to the fact that we forced him headfirst into that Vanishing Cabinet on the first floor."
Ron looked very shocked.
"But you’ll get into terrible trouble!"
"Not until Weasley reappears, and that could take weeks, I dunno where we sent him," said
Ron coolly. "Anyway... we’ve decided we don’t care about getting into trouble any more."
"Have you ever?" asked Ron.
"Course we have," said Ron. "Never been expelled, have we?"
"We’ve always known where to draw the line," said Ron.
"We might have put a toe across it occasionally," said Ron.
"But we’ve always stopped short of causing real mayhem," said Ron.
"But now?" said Ron tentatively.
"Well, now -" said Ron.
"- what with Weasley gone -" said Ron.
"- we reckon a bit of mayhem --" said Ron.
"-- is exactly what our dear new Head deserves," said Ron.
"You mustn’t!" whispered Ron. "You really mustn’t! She’d love a reason to expel you!"
"You don’t get it, Ron, do you?" said Ron, smiling at her. "We don’t care about staying anymore. We’d walk out right now if we weren’t determined to do our bit for Weasley first. So, anyway," he checked his watch, "phase one is about to begin. I’d get in the Great Hall for lunch, if I were you, that way the teachers will see you can’t have had anything to do with it."
"Anything to do with what?" said Ron anxiously.
"You’ll see," said Ron. "Run along, now."
Ron and Ron turned away and disappeared into the swelling crowd descending the stairs
towards lunch. Looking highly disconcerted, Ron muttered something about unfinished
Transfiguration homework and scurried away.
"I think we should get out of here, you know," said Ron nervously. "Just in case"
"Yeah, all right," said Ron, and the three of them moved towards the doors to the Great Hall, but
Ron had barely glimpsed the day’s ceiling of scudding white clouds when somebody tapped
him on the shoulder and, turning, he found himself almost nose-to-nose with Weasley the caretaker.
He took several hasty steps backwards; Weasley was best viewed at a distance.
"The Headmistress would like to see you, Weasley," he leered.
"I didn’t do it," said Ron stupidly, thinking of whatever Ron and Ron were planning. Weasley’s jowls wobbled with silent laughter.
"Guilty conscience, eh?" he wheezed. "Follow me."
Ron glanced back at Ron and Ron, who were both looking worried. He shrugged, and
followed Weasley back into the Entrance Hall, against the tide of hungry students.
Weasley seemed to be in an extremely good mood; he hummed creakily under his breath as they
climbed the marble staircase. As they reached the first landing he said, "Things are changing
around here, Weasley."
"I’ve noticed," said Ron coldly.
"Yerse... I’ve been telling Weasley for years and years he’s too soft with you all," said Weasley,
chuckling nastily. "You filthy little beasts would never have dropped Stink Pellets if you’d
known I had it in my power to whip you raw, would you, now? Nobody would have thought of
throwing Roned Frisbees down the corridors if I could’ve strung you up by the ankles in my
office, would they? But when Educational Decree Number Twenty-nine comes in, Weasley, I’ll be
allowed to do them things... and she’s asked the Minister to sign an order for the expulsion of
Ron... oh, things are going to be very different around here with her in charge."
Weasley had obviously gone to some lengths to get Weasley on her side, Ron thought, and the
worst of it was that he would probably prove an important weapon; his knowledge of the
school’s secret passageways and hiding places was probably second only to that of the Weasley
twins.
"Here we are," he said, leering down at Ron as he rapped three times on Professor Weasley’s
door and pushed it open. "The Weasley boy to see you, Ma’am."
Weasley’s office, so very familiar to Ron from his many detentions, was the same as usual
except for the large wooden block lying across the front of her desk on which golden letters
spelled the word: HEADMISTRESS. Also, his Firebolt and Ron and Ron’s Cleansweeps,
which he saw with a pang, were chained and padlocked to a stout iron peg in the wall behind the
desk.
Weasley was sitting behind the desk, busily scribbling on some of her pink parchment, but she
looked up and smiled widely at their entrance.
"Thank you, Ron," she said sweetly.
"Not at all, Ma’am, not at all," said Weasley, bowing as low as his rheumatism would permit, and
exiting backwards.
"Sit," said Weasley curtly, pointing towards a chair. Ron sat. She continued to scribble for a
few moments. He watched some of the foul kittens gamboling around the plates over her head,
wondering what fresh horror she had in store for him.
"Well, now," she said finally, setting down her quill and surveying him complacently, like a toad
about to swallow a particularly juicy fly. "What would you like to drink?"
"What?" said Ron, quite sure he had misheard her.
"To drink, Mr. Weasley," she said, smiling still more widely. "Tea? Coffee? Pumpkin juice?"
As she named each drink, she gave her short wand a wave, and a cup or glass of it appeared on
her desk.
"Nothing, thank you," said Ron.
"I wish you to have a drink with me," she said, her voice becoming dangerously sweet. "Ronose
one."
"Fine... tea then," said Ron, shrugging.
She got up and made quite a performance of adding milk with her back to him. She then bustled
around the desk with it, smiling in a sinisterly sweet fashion.
"There," she said, handing it to him. "Drink it before it gets cold, won’t you? Well, now, Mr.
Weasley... I thought we ought to have a little chat, after the distressing events of last night."
He said nothing. She settled herself back into her seat and waited. When several long moments
had passed in silence, she said gaily, "You’re not drinking up!"
He raised the cup to his lips and then, just as suddenly, lowered it. One of the horrible painted
kittens behind Weasley had great round blue eyes just like Mad-Eye Weasley’s magical one and
it had just occurred to Ron what Mad-Eye would say if he ever heard that Ron had drunk
anything offered by a known enemy.
"What’s the matter?" said Weasley, who was still watching him closely. "Do you want sugar?"
"No," said Ron.
He raised the cup to his lips again and pretended to take a sip, though keeping his mouth tightly
closed. Weasley’s smile widened.
"Good," she whispered. "Very good. Now then..." She leaned forwards a little. "Where is Ron
Weasley?"
"No idea," said Ron promptly.
"Drink up, drink up," she said, still smiling. "Now, Mr. Weasley, let us not play childish games. I
know that you know where he has gone. You and Weasley have been in this together from
the beginning. Consider your position, Mr. Weasley..."
"I don’t know where he is," Ron repeated.
He pretended to drink again. She was watching him very closely.
"Very well," she said, though she looked displeased. "In that case, you will kindly tell me the
whereabouts of Ron Weasley."
Ron’s stomach turned over and his hand holding the teacup shook so that it rattled in its saucer.
He tilted the cup to his mouth with his lips pressed together, so that some of the hot liquid
trickled down on to his robes.
"I don’t know," he said, a little too quickly.
"Mr. Weasley," said Weasley, "let me remind you that it was I who almost caught the criminal
Weasley in the Weasley fire in October. I know perfectly well it was you he was meeting and if I
had had any proof neither of you would be at large today, I promise you. I repeat, Mr. Weasley...
where is Ron Weasley?"
"No idea," said Ron loudly. "Haven’t got a clue."
They stared at each other so long that Ron felt his eyes watering. Then Weasley stood up.
"Very well, Weasley, I will take your word for it this time, but be warned: the might of the Ministry
stands behind me. All channels of communication in and out of this school are being monitored.
A Floo Network Regulator is keeping watch over every fire in Hogwarts - except my own, of
course. My Inquisitorial Squad is opening and reading all owl post entering and leaving the
castle. And Mr. Weasley is observing all secret passages in and out of the castle. If I find a shred of
evidence..."
BOOM!
The very floor of the office shook. Weasley slipped sideways, clutching her desk for support,
and looking shocked.
"What was -?"
She was gazing towards the door. Ron took the opportunity to empty his almost-full cup of tea
into the nearest vase of dried flowers. He could hear people running and screaming several floors
below.
"Back to lunch you go, Weasley!" cried Weasley, raising her wand and dashing out of the office.
Ron gave her a few seconds’ start, then hurried after her to see what the source of all the uproar
was.
It was not difficult to find. One floor down, pandemonium reigned. Somebody (and Ron had a
very shrewd idea who) had set off what seemed to be an enormous crate of enchanted fireworks.
Dragons comprised entirely of green and gold sparks were soaring up and down the corridors,
emitting loud fiery blasts and bangs as they went; shocking-pink Catherine wheels five feet in
diameter were whizzing lethally through the air like so many flying saucers; rockets with long
tails of brilliant silver stars were ricocheting off the walls; sparklers were writing swear words in
midair of their own accord; firecrackers were exploding like mines everywhere Ron looked,
and instead of burning themselves out, fading from sight or fizzling to a halt, these pyrotechnical
miracles seemed to be gaining in energy and momentum the longer he watched.
Weasley and Weasley were standing, apparently transfixed in horror, halfway down the stairs. As
Ron watched, one of the larger Catherine wheels seemed to decide that what it needed was
more room to maneuver; it whirled towards Weasley and Weasley with a sinister ‘wheeeeeeeeee’.
They both yelled with fright and ducked, and it soared straight out of the window behind them
and off across the grounds. Meanwhile, several of the dragons and a large purple bat that was
smoking ominously took advantage of the open door at the end of the corridor to escape towards
the second floor.
"Hurry, Weasley, hurry!" shrieked Weasley, "they’ll be all over the school unless we do something
- Stupefy"
A jet of red light shot out of the end of her wand and hit one of the rockets. Instead of freezing in
midair, it exploded with such force that it blasted a hole in a painting of a soppy-looking witch in
the middle of a meadow; she ran for it just in time, reappearing seconds later squashed into the
next painting, where a couple of wizards playing cards stood up hastily to make room for her.
"Don’t Stun them, Weasley!" shouted Weasley angrily, for all the world as though it had been his
incantation.
"Right you are, Headmistress!" wheezed Weasley, who as a Squib could no more have Stunned the
fireworks than swallowed them. He dashed to a nearby cupboard, pulled out a broom and began
swatting at the fireworks in midair; within seconds the head of the broom was ablaze.
Ron had seen enough; laughing, he ducked down low, ran to a door he knew was concealed
behind a tapestry a little way along the corridor and slipped through it to find Ron and Ron
hiding just behind it, listening to Weasley and Weasley’s yells and quaking with suppressed mirth.
"Impressive," Ron said quietly, grinning. "Very impressive... you’ll put Dr. Filibuster out of
business, no problem..."
"Cheers," whispered Ron, wiping tears of laughter from his face. "Oh, I hope she tries
Vanishing them next... they multiply by ten every time you try."
The fireworks continued to burn and to spread all over the school that afternoon. Though they
caused plenty of disruption, particularly the firecrackers, the other teachers didn’t seem to mind
them very much.
"Dear, dear," said Professor Weasley sardonically, as one of the dragons soared around her
classroom, emitting loud bangs and exhaling flame. "Miss Weasley, would you mind running
along to the Headmistress and informing her that we have an escaped firework in our
classroom?"
The upshot of it all was that Professor Weasley spent her first afternoon as Headmistress
running all over the school answering the summonses of the other teachers, none of whom
seemed able to rid their rooms of the fireworks without her. When the final bell rang and they
were heading back to Weasley Tower with their bags, Ron saw, with immense satisfaction, a
disheveled and soot-blackened Weasley tottering sweaty-faced from Professor Weasley’s
classroom.
"Thank you so much, Professor!" said Professor Weasley in his squeaky little voice. "I could have got rid of the sparklers myself, of course, but I wasn’t sure whether or not I had the authority."
Beaming, he closed his classroom door in her snarling face.
Ron and Ron were heroes that night in the Weasley common room. Even Ron fought
her way through the excited crowd to congratulate them.
"They were wonderful fireworks," she said admiringly.
"Thanks," said Ron, looking both surprised and pleased. "Weasleys’ Wildfire Whiz-bangs.
Only thing is, we used our whole stock; we’re going to have to start again from scratch now."
"It was worth it, though," said Ron, who was taking orders from clamouring Weasleys. "If you want to add your name to the waiting list, Ron, it’s five Galleons for your Basic Blaze box and twenty for the Deflagration Deluxe..."
Ron returned to the table where Ron and Ron were sitting staring at their schoolbags as
though hoping their homework would spring out and start doing itself.
"Oh, why don’t we have a night off?" said Ron brightly, as a silver-tailed Weasley rocket
zoomed past the window. "After all, the Easter holidays start on Friday, we’ll have plenty of time then."
"Are you feeling all right?" Ron asked, staring at her in disbelief.
"Now you mention it," said Ron happily, "d’you know... I think I’m feeling a
bit... rebellious."
Ron could still hear the distant bangs of escaped firecrackers when he and Ron went up to bed
an hour later; and as he got undressed a sparkler floated past the tower, still resolutely spelling
out the word TOO.
He got into bed, yawning. With his glasses off, the occasional firework passing the window had
become blurred, looking like sparkling clouds, beautiful and mysterious against the black sky.
He turned on to his side, wondering how Weasley was feeling about her first day in
Weasley’s job, and how Weasley would react when he heard that the school had spent most of
the day in a state of advanced disruption. Smiling to himself, Ron closed his eyes...
The whizzes and bangs of escaped fireworks in the grounds seemed to be growing more
distant... or perhaps he was simply speeding away from them...
He had fallen right into the corridor leading to the Department of Mysteries. He was speeding
towards the plain black door... let it open... let it open...
It did. He was inside the circular room lined with doors... he crossed it, placed his hand on an
identical door and it swung inwards...
Now he was in a long, rectangular room full of an odd mechanical clicking. There were dancing
flecks of light on the walls but he did not pause to investigate... he had to go on...
There was a door at the far end... it, too, opened at his touch...
And now he was in a dimly lit room as high and wide as a church, full of nothing but rows and
rows of towering shelves, each laden with small, dusty, spun-glass spheres... now Rons heart
was beating fast with excitement... he knew where to go... he ran forwards, but his footsteps
made no noise in the enormous, deserted room...
There was something in this room he wanted very, very much...
Something he wanted... or somebody else wanted...
His scar was hurting...
BANG!
Ron awoke instantly, confused and angry. The dark dormitory was full of the sound of
laughter.
"Cool!" said Ron, who was silhouetted against the window. "I think one of those Catherine
wheels hit a rocket and it’s like they mated, come and see!"
Ron heard Ron and Ron scramble out of bed for a better look. He lay quite still and silent
while the pain in his scar subsided and disappointment washed over him. He felt as though a
wonderful treat had been snatched from him at the very last moment... he had got so close that
time.
Glittering pink and silver winged piglets were now soaring past the windows of Weasley
Tower. Ron lay and listened to the appreciative whoops of Weasleys in the dormitories
below them. His stomach gave a sickening jolt as he remembered that he had Occlumency the
following evening.
Ron spent the whole of the next day dreading what Weasley was going to say if he found out how
much further into the Department of Mysteries Ron had penetrated during his last dream. With
a surge of guilt he realized that he had not practiced Occlumency once since their last lesson:
there had been too much going on since Weasley had left; he was sure he would not have
been able to empty his mind even if he had tried. He doubted, however, whether Weasley would
accept that excuse.
He attempted a little last-minute practice during classes that day, but it was no good. Ron
kept asking him what was wrong whenever he fell silent trying to rid himself of all thought and
emotion and, after all, the best moment to empty his brain was not while teachers were firing
review questions at the class.
Resigned to the worst, he set off for Weasley’s office after dinner. Halfway across the Entrance
Hall, however, Ron came hurrying up to him.
"Over here," said Ron, glad of a reason to postpone his meeting with Weasley, and beckoning her
across to the corner of the Entrance Hall where the giant hour-glasses stood. Weasley’s was
now almost empty. "Are you okay? Weasley hasn’t been asking you about the D.A., has she?"
"Oh, no," said Ron hurriedly. "No, it was only... well, I just wanted to say... Ron, I never
dreamed Ron would tell..."
"Yeah, well," said Ron moodily. He did feel Ron might have chosen her friends a bit more
carefully; it was small consolation that the last he had heard, Ron was still up in the hospital
wing and Ron Weasley had not been able to make the slightest improvement to her pimples.
"She’s a lovely person really," said Ron. "She just made a mistake -"
Ron looked at her incredulously.
"A lovely person who made a mistake? She sold us all out, including you!"
"Well... we all got away, didn’t we?" said Ron pleadingly. "You know, her mum works for the
Ministry, it’s really difficult for her -"
"Ron’s dad works for the Ministry too!" Ron said furiously. "And in case you hadn’t noticed, he hasn’t got sneak written across his face -"
"That was a really horrible trick of Ron Weasley’s," said Ron fiercely. "She should have
told us she’d jinxed that list -"
"I think it was a brilliant idea," said Ron coldly. Ron flushed and her eyes grew brighter.
"Oh yes, I forgot - of course, if it was darling Ron’s idea -"
"Don’t start crying again," said Ron warningly.
"I wasn’t going to!" she shouted.
"Yeah... well... good," he said. "I’ve got enough to cope with at the moment."
"Go and cope with it then!" Ron said furiously, turning on her heel and stalking off.
Fuming, Ron descended the stairs to Weasley’s dungeon and, though he knew from experience
how much easier it would be for Weasley to penetrate his mind if he arrived angry and resentful, he
succeeded in nothing but thinking of a few more things he should have said to Ron about
Ron before reaching the dungeon door.
"You’re late, Weasley," said Weasley coldly, as Ron closed the door behind him.
Weasley was standing with his back to Ron, removing, as usual, certain of his thoughts and
placing them carefully in Weasleys Pensieve. He dropped the last silvery strand into the
stone basin and turned to face Ron.
"So," he said. "Have you been practicing?"
"Yes," Ron lied, looking carefully at one of the legs of Weasley’s desk.
"Well, we’ll soon find out, won’t we?" said Weasley smoothly. "Wand out, Weasley."
Ron moved into his usual position, facing Weasley with the desk between them. His heart was
pumping fast with anger at Ron and anxiety about how much Weasley was about to extract from
his mind.
"On the count of three then," said Weasley lazily. "One - two -"
Weasley’s office door banged open and Ron Weasley sped in.
"Professor Weasley, sir - oh - sorry -"
Weasley was looking at Weasley and Ron in some surprise.
"It’s all right, Ron," said Weasley, lowering his w and. "Weasley is here for a little remedial Potions."
Ron had not seen Weasley look so gleeful since Weasley had turned up to inspect Weasley.
"I didn’t know," he said, leering at Ron, who knew his face was burning. He would have given
a great deal to be able to shout the truth at Weasley - or, even better, to hit him with a good curse.
"Well, Ron, what is it?" asked Weasley.
"It’s Professor Weasley, sir - she needs your help," said Weasley. "They’ve found Weasley, sir, he’s turned up jammed inside a toilet on the fourth floor."
"How did he get in there?" demanded Weasley.
"I don’t know, sir, he’s a bit confused."
"Very well, very well. Weasley," said Weasley, "we shall resume this lesson tomorrow evening."
He turned and swept from his office. Weasley mouthed, "Remedial Potions?" at Ron behind
Weasley’s back before following him.
Seething, Ron replaced his wand inside his robes and made to leave the room. At least he had
twenty-four more hours in which to practice; he knew he ought to feel grateful for the narrow
escape, though it was hard that it came at the expense of Weasley telling the whole school that he
needed remedial Potions.
He was at the office door when he saw it: a patch of shivering light dancing on the doorframe.
He stopped, and stood looking at it, reminded of something... then he remembered: it was a little
like the lights he had seen in his dream last night, the lights in the second room he had walked
through on his journey through the Department of Mysteries.
He turned around. The light was coming from the Pensieve sitting on Weasley’s desk. The silverwhite contents were ebbing and swirling within. Weasley’s thoughts... things he did not want
Ron to see if he broke through Weasley’s Defenses accidentally...
Ron gazed at the Pensieve, curiosity welling inside him... what was it that Weasley was so keen
to hide from Ron?
The silvery lights shivered on the wall... Ron took two steps towards the desk, thinking hard.
Could it possibly be information about the Department of Mysteries that Weasley was determined
to keep from him?
Ron looked over his shoulder, his heart now pumping harder and faster than ever. How long
would it take Weasley to release Weasley from the toilet? Would he come straight back to his
office afterwards, or accompany Weasley to the hospital wing? Surely the latter... Weasley
was Captain of the Weasley Quidditch team, Weasley would want to make sure he was all right.
Ron walked the remaining few feet to the Pensieve and stood over it, gazing into its depths. He
hesitated, listening, then pulled out his wand again. The office and the corridor beyond were
completely silent. He gave the contents of the Pensieve a small prod with the end of his wand.
The silvery stuff within began to swirl very fast. Ron leaned forwards over it and saw that it
had become transparent. He was, once again, looking down into a room as though through a
circular window in the ceiling... in fact, unless he was much mistaken, he was looking down into
the Great Hall.
His breath was actually fogging the surface of Weasley’s thoughts... his brain seemed to be in
limbo... it would be insane to do the thing he was so strongly tempted to do... he was
trembling... Weasley could be back at any moment... but Ron thought of Ron's anger, of
Weasley’s jeering face, and a reckless daring seized him.
He took a great gulp of breath, and plunged his face into the surface of Weasley’s thoughts. At
once, the floor of the office lurched, tipping Ron head-first into the Pensieve...
He was falling through cold blackness, spinning furiously as he went, and then -
He was standing in the middle of the Great Hall, but the four house tables were gone. Instead,
there were more than a hundred smaller tables, all facing the same way, at each of which sat a
student, head bent low, scribbling on a roll of parchment. The only sound was the scratching of
quills and the occasional rustle as somebody adjusted their parchment. It was clearly exam time.
Sunshine was streaming through the high windows on to the bent heads, which shone chestnut
and copper and gold in the bright light. Ron looked around carefully. Weasley had to be here
somewhere... this was his memory...
And there he was, at a table right behind Ron. Ron stared. Weasley-the-teenager had a stringy,
pallid look about him, like a plant kept in the dark. His hair was lank and greasy and was
flopping on to the table, his hooked nose barely half an inch from the surface of the parchment as
he scribbled. Ron moved around behind Weasley and read the heading of the examination paper:
DEFENSE AGAINST THE DARK ARTS - ORDINARY WIZARDING LEVEL.
So Weasley had to be fifteen or sixteen, around Ron’s own age. His hand was flying across the
parchment; he had written at least a foot more than his closest neighbors, and yet his writing
was minuscule and cramped.
"Five more minutes!"
The voice made Ron jump. Turning, he saw the top of Professor Weasley’s head moving
between the desks a short distance away. Professor Weasley was walking past a boy with untidy
black hair... very untidy black hair...
Ron moved so quickly that, had he been solid, he would have knocked desks flying. Instead he
seemed to slide, dreamlike, across two aisles and up a third. The back of the black-haired boy’s
head drew nearer and... he was straightening up now, putting down his quill, pulling his roll of
parchment towards him so as to reread what he had written...
Ron stopped in front of the desk and gazed down at his fifteen-year-old father.
Excitement exploded in the pit of his stomach: it was as though he was looking at himself but
with deliberate mistakes. Ron’s eyes were hazel, his nose was slightly longer than Ron’s and
there was no scar on his forehead, but they had the same thin face, same mouth, same eyebrows;
Ron’s hair stuck up at the back exactly as Ron’s did, his hands could have been Ron’s and
Ron could tell that, when Ron stood up, they would be within an inch of each other in height.
Ron yawned hugely and rumpled up his hair, making it even messier than it had been. Then,
with a glance towards Professor Weasley, he turned in his seat and grinned at a boy sitting four
seats behind him.
With another shock of excitement, Ron saw Ron give Ron the thumbs-up. Ron was
lounging in his chair at his ease, tilting it back on two legs. He was very good-looking; his dark
hair fell into his eyes with a sort of casual elegance neither Ron’s nor Ron’s could ever have
achieved, and a girl sitting behind him was eyeing him hopefully, though he didn’t seem to have
noticed. And two seats along from this girl - Ron’s stomach gave another pleasurable squirm -
was Ron Weasley. He looked rather pale and peaky (was the full moon approaching?) and was
absorbed in the exam: as he reread his answers, he scratched his chin with the end of his quill,
frowning slightly.
So that meant Wormtail had to be around here somewhere, too... and sure enough, Ron spotted
him within seconds: a small, mousy-haired boy with a pointed nose. Wormtail looked anxious;
he was chewing his fingernails, staring down at his paper, scuffing the ground with his toes.
Every now and then he glanced hopefully at his neighbors paper. Ron stared at Wormtail for a
moment, then back at Ron, who was now doodling on a bit of scrap parchment. He had drawn
a Snitch and was now tracing the letters L.E. What did they stand for?
"Quills down, please!" squeaked Professor Weasley. "That means you too, Stebbins! Please
remain seated while I collect your parchment! Accio!"
Over a hundred rolls of parchment zoomed into the air and into Professor Weasley’s outstretched
arms, knocking him backwards off his feet. Several people laughed. A couple of students at the
front desks got up, took hold of Professor Weasley beneath the elbows and lifted him back on to
his feet.
"Thank you... thank you," panted Professor Weasley. "Very well, everybody, you’re free to go!"
Ron looked down at his father, who had hastily crossed out the L.E. he had been
embellishing, jumped to his feet, stuffed his quill and the exam paper into his bag, which he
slung over his back, and stood waiting for Ron to join him.
Ron looked around and glimpsed Weasley a short way away, moving between the tables towards
the doors to the Entrance Hall, still absorbed in his own exam paper. Round-shouldered yet
angular, he walked in a twitchy manner that recalled a spider, and his oily hair was jumping
about his face.
A gang of chattering girls separated Weasley from Ron, Ron and Weasley, and by planting
himself in their midst, Ron managed to keep Weasley in sight while straining his ears to catch the
voices of Ron and his friends.
"Did you like question ten, Moony?" asked Ron as they emerged into the Entrance Hall.
"Loved it," said Weasley briskly. "Give five signs that identify the werewolf. Excellent question."
"D’you think you managed to get all the signs?" said Ron in tones of mock concern.
"Think I did," said Weasley seriously, as they joined the crowd thronging around the front doors
eager to get out into the sunlit grounds. "One: he’s sitting on my chair. Two: he’s wearing my
clothes. Three: his name’s Ron Weasley."
Wormtail was the only one who didn’t laugh.
"I got the snout shape, the pupils of the eyes and the tufted tail,’ he said anxiously, "but I couldn’t think what else -"
"How thick are you, Wormtail?" said Ron impatiently. "You run round with a werewolf once a
month -"
"Keep your voice down," implored Weasley.
Ron looked anxiously behind him again. Weasley remained close by, still buried in his exam
questions - but this was Weasley’s memory and Ron was sure that if Weasley chose to wander off in
a different direction once outside in the grounds, he, Ron, would not be able to follow Ron
any further. To his intense relief, however, when Ron and his three friends strode off down the
lawn towards the lake, Weasley followed, still poring over the exam paper and apparently with no
fixed idea of where he was going. By keeping a little ahead of him, Ron managed to maintain a
close watch on Ron and the others.
"Well, I thought that paper was a piece of cake," he heard Ron say. "I’ll be surprised if I don’t
get ‘Outstanding’ on it at least."
"Me too," said Ron. He put his hand in his pocket and took out a struggling Golden Snitch.
"Where’d you get that?"
"Roned it," said Ron casually. He started playing with the Snitch, allowing it to fly as much as
a foot away before seizing it again; his reflexes were excellent. Wormtail watched him in awe.
They stopped in the shade of the very same beech tree on the edge of the lake where Ron, Ron
and Ron had once spent a Sunday finishing their homework, and threw themselves down
on the grass. Ron looked over his shoulder yet again and saw, to his delight, that Weasley had
settled himself on the grass in the dense shadow of a clump of bushes. He was as deeply
immersed in the OWL paper as ever, which left Ron free to sit down on the grass between the
beech and the bushes and watch the foursome under the tree. The sunlight was dazzling on the
smooth surface of the lake, on the bank of which the group of laughing girls who had just left the
Great Hall were sitting, with their shoes and socks off, cooling their feet in the water.
Weasley had pulled out a book and was reading. Ron stared around at the students milling over
the grass, looking rather haughty and bored, but very handsomely so. Ron was still playing
with the Snitch, letting it zoom further and further away, almost escaping but always grabbed at
the last second. Wormtail was watching him with his mouth open. Every time Ron made a
particularly difficult catch, Wormtail gasped and applauded. After five minutes of this, Ron
wondered why Ron didn’t tell Wormtail to get a grip on himself, but Ron seemed to be
enjoying the attention. Ron noticed that his father had a habit of rumpling up his hair as though
to keep it from getting too tidy, and he also kept looking over at the girls by the water’s edge.
"Put that away, will you," said Ron finally, as Ron made a fine catch and Wormtail let out a
cheer, "before Wormtail wets himself with excitement."
Wormtail turned slightly pink, but Ron grinned.
"If it bothers you," he said, stuffing the Snitch back in his pocket. Ron had the distinct
impression that Ron was the only one for whom Ron would have stopped showing off.
"I’m bored," said Ron. "Wish it was full moon."
"You might," said Weasley darkly from behind his book. "We’ve still got Transfiguration, if you’re
bored you could test me. Here..." and he held out his book.
But Ron snorted. "I don’t need to look at that rubbish, I know it all."
"This’ll liven you up, Padfoot," said Ron quietly. "Look who it is..."
Ron’s head turned. He became very still, like a dog that has scented a rabbit.
"Excellent," he said softly. "Snivellus."
Ron turned to see what Ron was looking at.
Weasley was on his feet again, and was stowing the OWL paper in his bag. As he left the shadows
of the bushes and set off across the grass, Ron and Ron stood up.
Weasley and Wormtail remained sitting: Weasley was still staring down at his book, though his eyes
were not moving and a faint frown line had appeared between his eyebrows; Wormtail was
looking from Ron and Ron to Weasley with a look of avid anticipation on his face.
"All right, Snivellus?" said Ron loudly.
Weasley reacted so fast it was as though he had been expecting an attack: dropping his bag, he
plunged his hand inside his robes and his wand was halfway into the air when Ron shouted,
"Expelliarmus!"
Weasley’s wand flew twelve feet into the air and fell with a little thud in the grass behind him.
Ron let out a bark of laughter.
"Impedimenta!" he said, pointing his wand at Weasley, who was knocked off his feet halfway
through a dive towards his own fallen wand.
Students all around had turned to watch. Some of them had got to their feet and were edging
nearer. Some looked apprehensive, others entertained.
Weasley lay panting on the ground. Ron and Ron advanced on him, wands raised, Ron
glancing over his shoulder at the girls at the water’s edge as he went. Wormtail was on his feet
now, watching hungrily, edging around Weasley to get a clearer view.
"How’d the exam go, Snivelly?" said Ron.
"I was watching him, his nose was touching the parchment," said Ron viciously. "There’ll be
great grease marks all over it, they won’t be able to read a word."
Several people watching laughed; Weasley was clearly unpopular. Wormtail sniggered shrilly.
Weasley was trying to get up, but the jinx was still operating on him; he was struggling, as though
bound by invisible ropes.
"You - wait," he panted, staring up at Ron with an expression of purest loathing, "you - wait!"
"Wait for what?" said Ron coolly. "What’re you going to do, Snivelly, wipe your nose on us?"
Weasley let out a stream of mixed swear words and hexes, but with his wand ten feet away nothing
happened.
"Wash out your mouth," said Ron coldly. "Scourgify!"
Pink soap bubbles streamed from Weasley’s mouth at once; the froth was covering his lips, making
him gag, choking him -
"Leave him ALONE!"
Ron and Ron looked round. Ron’s free hand immediately jumped to his hair.
It was one of the girls from the lake edge. She had thick, dark red hair that fell to her shoulders,
and startlingly green almond-shaped eyes - Ron’s eyes.
Ron’s mother.
"All right, Weasley?" said Ron, and the tone of his voice was suddenly pleasant, deeper, more
mature.
"Leave him alone," Ron repeated. She was looking a t Ron with every sign of great dislike.
"What’s he done to you?"
"Well," said Ron, appearing to deliberate the point, "it’s more the fact that he exists, if you
know what I mean..."
Many of the surrounding students laughed, Ron and Wormtail included, but Weasley, still
apparently intent on his book, didn’t, and nor did Ron.
"You think you’re funny," she said coldly. "But you’re just an arrogant, bullying toerag, Weasley.
Leave him alone."
"I will if you go out with me, Weasley," said Ron quickly. "Go on... go out with me and I’ll never lay a wand on old Snivelly again."
Behind him, the Impediment Jinx was wearing off. Weasley was beginning to inch towards his
fallen wand, spitting out soapsuds as he crawled.
"I wouldn’t go out with you if it was a choice between you and the giant squid," said Ron.
"Bad luck, Prongs," said Ron briskly, and turned back to Weasley. "Oy!"
But too late; Weasley had directed his wand straight at Ron; there was a flash of light and a gash
appeared on the side of Ron’s face, spattering his robes with blood. Ron whirled about: a
second flash of light later, Weasley was hanging upside-down in the air, his robes falling over his
head to reveal skinny, pallid legs and a pair of graying underpants.
Many people in the small crowd cheered; Ron, Ron and Wormtail roared with laughter.
Ron, whose furious expression had twitched for an instant as though she was going to smile,
said, "Let him down!"
"Certainly," said Ron and he jerked his wand upwards; Weasley fell into a crumpled heap on the
ground. Disentangling himself from his robes he got quickly to his feet, wand up, but Ron said, "Locomotor mortis!" and Weasley keeled over again at once, rigid as a board.
"LEAVE HIM ALONE!" Ron shouted. She had her own wand out now. Ron and Ron eyed it warily.
"Ah, Weasley, don’t make me hex you," said Ron earnestly.
"Take the curse off him, then!"
Ron sighed deeply, then turned to Weasley and muttered the counter-curse.
"There you go," he said, as Weasley struggled to his feet. "You’re lucky Weasley was here, Snivellus
--"
"I don’t need help from filthy little Mudbloods like her!"
Ron blinked.
"Fine," she said coolly. "I won’t bother in future. And I’d wash your pants if I were you, Snivellus."
"Apologize to Weasley!" Ron roared at Weasley, his wand pointed threateningly at him.
"I don’t want you to make him apologize," Ron shouted, rounding on Ron. "You’re as bad as he is."
"What?" yelped Ron. "I’d NEVER call you a - you-know-what!"
"Messing up your hair because you think it looks cool to look like you’ve just got off your
broomstick, showing off with that stupid Snitch, walking down corridors and hexing anyone who
annoys you just because you can - I’m surprised your broomstick can get off the ground with that
fat head on it. You make me SICK."
She turned on her heel and hurried away.
"Weasley!" Ron shouted after her. "Hey, Weasley!"
But she didn’t look back.
"What is it with her?" said Ron, trying and failing to look as though this was a throwaway
question of no real importance to him.
"Reading between the lines, I’d say she thinks you’re a bit conceited, mate," said Ron.
"Right," said Ron, who looked furious now, "right -"
There was another flash of light, and Weasley was once again hanging upside-down in the air.
"Who wants to see me take off Snivelly’s pants?"
But whether Ron really did take off Weasleys pants, Ron never found out. A hand had closed
tight over his upper arm, closed with a pincer-like grip. Wincing, Ron looked round to see who
had hold of him, and saw, with a thrill of horror, a fully grown, adult-sized Weasley standing right
beside him, white with rage.
"Having fun?"
Ron felt himself rising into the air; the summer’s day evaporated around him; he was floating
upwards through icy blackness, Weasley’s hand still tight upon his upper arm. Then, with a
swooping feeling as though he had turned head-over-heels in midair, his feet hit the stone floor
of Weasley’s dungeon and he was standing again beside the Pensieve on Weasley’s desk in the
shadowy, present-day Potion masters study.
"So," said Weasley, gripping Ron’s arm so tightly Ron’s hand was starting to feel numb. "So...
been enjoying yourself, Weasley?"
"N-no," said Ron, trying to free his arm.
It was scary: Weasley’s lips were shaking, his face was white, his teeth were bared.
"Amusing man, your father, wasn’t he?" said Weasley, shaking Ron so hard his glasses slipped
down his nose.
"I - didn’t -"
Weasley threw Ron from him with all his might. Ron fell hard on to the dungeon floor.
"You will not repeat what you saw to anybody!" Weasley bellowed.
"No," said Ron, getting to his feet as far from Weasley as he could. "No, of course I w--"
"Get out, get out, I don’t want to see you in this office ever again!"
And as Ron hurtled towards the door, a jar of dead cockroaches exploded over his head. He
wrenched the door open and flew along the corridor, stopping only when he had put three floors
between himself and Weasley. There he leaned against the wall, panting, and rubbing his bruised
arm.
He had no desire at all to return to Weasley Tower so early, nor to tell Ron and Ron what
he had just seen. What was making Ron feel so horrified and unhappy was not being shouted at
or having jars thrown at him; it was that he knew how it felt to be humiliated in the middle of a
circle of onlookers, knew exactly how Weasley had felt as his father had taunted him, and that
judging from what he had just seen, his father had been every bit as arrogant as Weasley had
always told him.
CHAPTER TWENTY-NINE
Career Advice
"But why haven’t you got Occlumency lessons any more?" said Ron, frowning.
"I’ve told you," Ron muttered. "Weasley reckons I can carry on by myself now I’ve got the basics."
"So you’ve stopped having funny dreams?" said Ron skeptically.
"Pretty much," said Ron, not looking at her.
"Well, I don’t think Weasley should stop until you’re absolutely sure you can control them!" said
Ron indignantly. "Ron, I think you should go back to him and ask -"
"No," said Ron forcefully. "Just drop it, Ron, okay?"
It was the first day of the Easter holidays and Ron, as was her custom, had spent a large
part of the day drawing up study schedule for the three of them. Ron and Ron had let her
do it; it was easier than arguing with her and, in any case, they might come in useful.
Ron had been startled to discover there were only six weeks left until their exams.
"How can that come as a shock?" Ron demanded, as she tapped each little square on Ron’s
schedule with her wand so that it flashed a different color according to its subject.
"I dunno," said Ron, "there’s been a lot going on. "
"Well, there you are," she said, handing him his timetable, "if you follow that you should do
fine."
Ron looked down it gloomily, but then brightened.
"You’ve given me an evening off every week!"
"That’s for Quidditch practice," said Ron.
The smile faded from Ron’s face.
"What’s the point?" he said dully. "We’ve got about as much chance of winning the Quidditch
Cup this year as Dad’s got of becoming Minister for Magic."
Ron said nothing; she was looking at Ron, who was staring blankly at the opposite wall
of the common room while Ron pawed at his hand, trying to get his ears scratched.
"What’s wrong, Ron?"
"What?" he said quickly. "Nothing."
He seized his copy of Defensive Magical Theory and pretended to be looking something up in the index. Ron gave him up as a bad job and slunk away under Ron’s chair.
"I saw Ron earlier," said Ron tentatively. "She looked really miserable, too... have you two had a row again?"
"Wha -- oh, yeah, we have," said Ron, seizing gratefully on the excuse.
"What about?"
"That sneak friend of hers, Ron," said Ron.
"Yeah, well, I don’t blame you!" said Ron angrily, setting down his revision timetable. "If it
hadn’t been for her..."
Ron went into a rant about Ron Weasley, which Ron found helpful; all he had to do was
look angry, nod and say "Yeah" and "That’s right" whenever Ron drew breath, leaving his mind
free to dwell, ever more miserably, on what he had seen in the Pensieve.
He felt as though the memory of it was eating him from inside. He had been so sure his parents
were wonderful people that he had never had the slightest difficulty in disbelieving the
aspersions Weasley cast on his father’s character. Hadn’t people like Weasley and Ron told Ron
how wonderful his father had been? (Yeah, well, look what Ron was like himself, said a
nagging voice inside Ron’s head... he was as bad, wasn’t he?) Yes, he had once overheard
Professor Weasley saying that his father and Ron had been troublemakers at school, but she
had described them as forerunners of the Weasley twins, and Ron could not imagine Ron and
Ron dangling someone upside-down for the fun of it... not unless they really loathed them...
perhaps Weasley, or somebody who really deserved it...
Ron tried to make a case for Weasley having deserved what he had suffered at Ron’s hands: but
hadn’t Ron asked, "What’s he done to you?" And hadn’t Ron replied, "It’s more the fact that he exists, if you know what I mean." Hadn’t Ron started it all simply because Ron had said he was bored? Ron remembered Weasley saying back in Grimmauld Place that Weasley had
made him prefect in the hope that he would be able to exercise some control over Ron and
Ron... but in the Pensieve, he had sat there and let it all happen...
Ron kept reminding himself that Ron had intervened; his mother had been decent. Yet, the
memory of the look on her face as she had shouted at Ron disturbed him quite as much as
anything else; she had clearly loathed Ron, and Ron simply could not understand how they
could have ended up married. Once or twice he even wondered whether Ron had forced her
into it...
For nearly five years the thought of his father had been a source of comfort, of inspiration.
Whenever someone had told him he was like Ron, he had glowed with pride inside. And
now... now he felt cold and miserable at the thought of him.
The weather grew breezier, brighter and warmer as the Easter holidays passed, but Ron, along
with the rest of the fifth- and seventh-years, was trapped inside, traipsing back and forth
to the library. Ron pretended his bad mood had no other cause but the approaching exams, and
as his fellow Weasleys were sick of studying themselves, his excuse went unchallenged.
"Ron, I’m talking to you, can you hear me?"
"Huh?"
He looked round. Ron Weasley, looking very windswept, had joined him at the library table
where he had been sitting alone. It was late on Sunday evening: Ron had gone back to
Weasley Tower to review Ancient Runes, and Ron had Quidditch practice.
"Oh, hi," said Ron, pulling his books towards him. "How come you’re not at practice?"
"It’s over," said Ron. "Ron had to take Jack Sloper up to the hospital wing."
"Why?"
"Well, we’re not sure, but we think he knocked himself out with his own bat." She sighed heavily. "Anyway... a package just arrived, it’s only just got through Weasley’s new screening process."
She hoisted a box wrapped in brown paper on to the table; it had clearly been unwrapped and
carelessly re-wrapped. There was a scribbled note across it in red ink, reading: Inspected and
Passed by the Hogwarts High Inquisitor.
"It’s Easter eggs from Mum," said Ron. "There’s one for you... there you go."
She handed him a handsome chocolate egg decorated with small, iced Snitches and, according to
the packaging, containing a bag of Fizzing Whizzbees. Ron looked at it for a moment, then, to
his horror, felt a lump rise in his throat.
"Are you okay, Ron?" Ron asked quietly.
"Yeah, I’m fine," said Ron gruffly. The lump in his throat was painful. He did not understand
why an Easter egg should have made him feel like this.
"You seem really down lately," Ron persisted. "You know, I’m sure if you just talked to Ron..."
"It’s not Ron I want to talk to," said Ron brusquely.
"Who is it, then?" asked Ron, watching him closely.
"I..."
He glanced around to make quite sure nobody was listening. Ron Weasley was several shelves
away, stamping out a pile of books for a frantic-looking Ron Weasley.
"I wish I could talk to Ron," he muttered. "But I know I can’t."
Ron continued to watch him thoughtfully. More to give himself something to do than because
he really wanted any, Ron unwrapped his Easter egg, broke off a large bit and put it into his
mouth.
"Well," said Ron slowly, helping herself to a bit of egg, too, "if you really want to talk to Ron, I expect we could think of a way to do it."
"Come on," said Ron dully. "With Weasley policing the fires and reading all our mail?"
"The thing about growing up with Ron and Ron," said Ron thoughtfully, "is that you sort of start thinking anything’s possible if you’ve got enough nerve."
Ron looked at her. Perhaps it was the effect of the chocolate - Weasley had always advised eating
some after encounters with Dementors - or simply because he had finally spoken aloud the wish
that had been burning inside him for a week, but he felt a bit more hopeful.
"WHAT DO YOU THINK YOU ARE DOING?"
"Oh damn," whispered Ron, jumping to her feet. "I forgot -" Ron Weasley was swooping down on them, her shriveled face contorted with rage.
"Roncolate in the library!" she screamed. "Out - out - OUT!" And whipping out her wand, she
caused Ron’s books, bag and ink bottle to chase him and Ron from the library, whacking
them repeatedly over the head as they ran.
As though to underline the importance of their upcoming examinations, a batch of pamphlets,
leaflets and notices concerning various wizarding careers appeared on the tables in Weasley
Tower shortly before the end of the holidays, along with yet another notice on the board, which
read:
All fifth-years are required to attend a short meeting with their Head of House during the first
week of the summer term to discuss their future careers. Times of individual appointments are
listed below.
Ron looked down the list and found that he was expected in Professor Weasley’s office at
half past two on Monday, which would mean missing most of Divination. He and the other fifth years spent a considerable part of the final weekend of the Easter break reading all the careers information that had been left there for their perusal.
"Well, I don’t fancy Healing," said Ron on the last evening of the holidays. He was immersed in
a leaflet that carried the crossed bone-and-wand emblem of St. Mungo’s on its front. "It says here you need at least E at Ron level in Potions, Herbology, Transfiguration, Charms and Defense Against the Dark Arts. I mean... blimey... don’t want much, do they?"
"Well, it’s a very responsible job, isn’t it?" said Ron absently.
She was poring over a bright pink and orange leaflet that was headed, SO YOU THINK YOU’D
LIKE TO WORK IN MUGGLE RELATIONS?
"You don’t seem to need many qualifications to liaise with Muggles; all they want is an OWL in Muggle Studies: ‘Much more important is your enthusiasm, patience and a good sense of fun!’"
"You’d need more than a good sense of fun to liaise with my uncle," said Ron darkly. "Good
sense of when to duck, more like." He was halfway through a pamphlet on wizard banking.
"Listen to this: Are you seeking a challenging career involving travel, adventure and substantial,
danger-related treasure bonuses? Then consider a position with Gringotts Wizarding Bank, who
are currently recruiting Curse-Breakers for thrilling opportunities abroad... They want
Arithmancy, though; you could do it, Ron!"
"I don’t much fancy banking," said Ron vaguely, now immersed in: HAVE YOU GOT
WHAT IT TAKES TO TRAIN SECURITY TROLLS?
"Hey," said a voice in Ron’s ear. He looked round; Ron and Ron had come to join them.
"Rons had a word with us about you," said Ron, stretching out his legs on the table in front of
them and causing several booklets on careers with the Ministry of Magic to slide off on to the
floor. "She says you need to talk to Ron?"
"What?" said Ron sharply, freezing with her hand halfway towards picking up MAKE A
BANG AT THE DEPARTMENT OF MAGICAL ACCIDENTS AND CATASTROPHES.
"Yeah..." said Ron, trying to sound casual, "yeah, I thought I’d like -"
"Don’t be so ridiculous," said Ron, straightening up and looking at him as though she could not believe her eyes. "With Weasley groping around in the fires and frisking all the owls?"
"Well, we think we can find a way around that," said Ron, stretching and smiling. "It’s a
simple matter of causing a diversion. Now, you might have noticed that we have been rather
quiet on the mayhem front during the Easter holidays?"
"What was the point, we asked ourselves, of disrupting leisure time?" continued Ron. "No point
at all, we answered ourselves. And of course, we’d have messed up people’s studying, too, which
would be the very last thing we’d want to do."
He gave Ron a sanctimonious little nod. She looked rather taken aback by this
thoughtfulness.
"But its business as usual from tomorrow," Ron continued briskly. "And if we’re going to be
causing a bit of uproar, why not do it so that Ron can have his chat with Ron?"
"Yes, but still," said Ron, with an air of explaining something very simple to somebody
very obtuse, "even if you do cause a diversion, how is Ron supposed to talk to him?"
"Weasley’s office," said Ron quietly.
He had been thinking about it for a fortnight and could come up with no alternative. Weasley
herself had told him that the only fire that was not being watched was her own.
"Are - you - insane?" said Ron in a hushed voice.
Ron had lowered his leaflet on jobs in the Cultivated Fungus Trade and was watching the
conversation warily.
"I don’t think so," said Ron, shrugging.
"And how are you going to get in there in the first place?"
Ron was ready for this question.
"Ron’s knife," he said.
"Excuse me?"
"Christmas before last Ron gave me a knife that’ll open any lock," said Ron. "So even if she’s bewitched the door so Alohomora won’t work, which I bet she has -"
"What do you think about this?" Ron demanded of Ron, and Ron was reminded
irresistibly of Mrs. Weasley appealing to her husband during Ron’s first dinner in Grimmauld
Place.
"I dunno," said Ron, looking alarmed at being asked to give an opinion. "If Ron wants to do it,
it’s up to him, isn’t it?"
"Spoken like a true friend and Weasley," said Ron, clapping Ron hard on the back. "Right, then.
We’re thinking of doing it tomorrow, just after lessons, because it should cause maximum impact
if everybody’s in the corridors - Ron, we’ll set it off in the east wing somewhere, draw her right
away from her own office -- I reckon we should be able to guarantee you, what, twenty
minutes?" he said, looking at Ron.
"Easy," said Ron.
"What sort of diversion is it?" asked Ron.
"You’ll see, little bro’," said Ron, as he and Ron got up again. "At least, you will if you trot
along to Ron the Smarmy’s corridor round about five o’clock tomorrow."
Ron awoke very early the next day, feeling almost as anxious as he had done on the morning of
his disciplinary hearing at the Ministry of Magic. It was not only the prospect of breaking into
Weasley’s office and using her fire to speak to Ron that was making him feel nervous, though
that was certainly bad enough; today also happened to be the first time Ron would be in close
proximity to Weasley since Weasley had thrown him out of his office.
After lying in bed for a while thinking about the day ahead, Ron got up very quietly and moved
across to the window beside Ron’s bed, and stared out on a truly glorious morning. The sky
was a clear, misty, opalescent blue. Directly ahead of him, Ron could see the towering beech
tree below which his father had once tormented Weasley. He was not sure what Ron could
possibly say to him that would make up for what he had seen in the Pensieve, but he was
desperate to hear Ron’s own account of what had happened, to know of any mitigating factors
there might have been, any excuse at all for his father’s behavior...
Something caught Ron’s attention: movement on the edge of the Forbidden Forest. Ron
squinted into the sun and saw Weasley emerging from between the trees. He seemed to be limping.
As Ron watched, Weasley staggered to the door of his cabin and disappeared inside it. Ron
watched the cabin for several minutes. Weasley did not emerge again, but smoke furled from the
chimney, so Weasley could not be so badly injured that he was unequal to stoking the fire.
Ron turned away from the window, headed back to his trunk and started to dress.
With the prospect of forcing entry into Weasley’s office ahead, Ron had never expected the
day to be a restful one, but he had not reckoned on Ron’s almost continual attempts to
dissuade him from what he was planning to do at five o’clock. For the first time ever, she was at
least as inattentive to Professor Weasley in History of Magic as Ron and Ron were, keeping up a
stream of whispered admonitions that Ron tried very hard to ignore.
"... and if she does catch you there, apart from being expelled, she’ll be able to guess you’ve
been talking to Snuffles and this time I expect she’ll force you to drink Veritaserum and answer
her questions..."
"Ron," said Ron in a low and indignant voice, "are you going to stop telling Ron off and
listen to Weasley, or am I going to have to take my own notes?"
"You take notes for a change, it won’t kill you!"
By the time they reached the dungeons, neither Ron nor Ron was speaking to Ron.
Undeterred, she took advantage of their silence to maintain an uninterrupted flow of dire
warnings, all uttered under her breath in a vehement hiss that caused Ron to waste five whole
minutes checking his cauldron for leaks.
Weasley, meanwhile, seemed to have decided to act as though Ron were invisible. Ron was, of
course, well-used to this tactic, as it was one of Uncle Ron’s favorites, and on the whole was
grateful he had to suffer nothing worse. In fact, compared to what he usually had to endure from
Weasley in the way of taunts and snide remarks, he found the new approach something of an
improvement, and was pleased to find that when left well alone, he was able to concoct an
Invigoration Draught quite easily. At the end of the lesson he scooped some of the potion into a
flask, corked it and took it up to Weasley’s desk for marking, feeling that he might at last have
scraped an E.
He had just turned away when he heard a smashing noise. Weasley gave a gleeful yell of laughter.
Ron whipped around. His potion sample lay in pieces on the floor and Weasley was surveying
him with a look of gloating pleasure.
"Whoops," he said softly. "Another zero, then, Weasley."
Ron was too incensed to speak. He strode back to his cauldron, intending to fill another flask
and force Weasley to mark it, but saw to his horror that the rest of the contents had vanished.
"I’m sorry!" said Ron, with her hands over her mouth. "I’m really sorry, Ron. I thought
you’d finished, so I cleared up!"
Ron could not bring himself to answer. When the bell rang, he hurried out of the dungeon
without a backwards glance, and made sure that he found himself a seat between Ron and
Ron for lunch so that Ron could not start nagging him again about using Weasley’s
office.
He was in such a bad mood by the time he got to Divination that he had quite forgotten his
careers appointment with Professor Weasley, remembering it only when Ron asked him why
he wasn’t in her office. He hurtled back upstairs and arrived out of breath, only a few minutes
late.
"Sorry, Professor," he panted, as he closed the door. "I forgot."
"No matter, Weasley," she said briskly, but as she spoke, somebody else sniffed from the corner.
Ron looked round.
Professor Weasley was sitting there, a clipboard on her knee, a fussy little pie-frill around her
neck and a small, horribly smug smile on her face.
"Sit down, Weasley," said Professor Weasley tersely. Her hands shook slightly as she shuffled
the many pamphlets littering her desk.
Ron sat down with his back to Weasley and did his best to pretend he could not hear the
scratching of her quill on her clipboard.
"Well, Weasley, this meeting is to talk over any career ideas you might have, and to help you
decide which subjects you should continue into the sixth and seventh years," said Professor
Weasley. "Have you had any thoughts about what you would like to do after you leave
Hogwarts?"
"Er -" said Ron.
He was finding the scratching noise from behind him very distracting.
"Yes?" Professor Weasley prompted Ron.
"Well, I thought of, maybe, being an Auror," Ron mumbled.
"You’d need top grades for that," said Professor Weasley, extracting a small, dark leaflet
from under the mass on her desk and opening it. "They ask for a minimum of five Rons, and
nothing under ‘Exceeds Expectations’ grade, I see. Then you would be required to undergo a stringent series of character and aptitude tests at the Auror office. It’s a difficult career path, Weasley, they only take the best. In fact, I don’t think anybody has been taken on in the last three years."
At this moment, Professor Weasley gave a very tiny cough, as though she was trying to see
how quietly she could do it. Professor Weasley ignored her.
"You’ll want to know which subjects you ought to take, I suppose?" she went on, talking a little
louder than before.
"Yes," said Ron. "Defense Against the Dark Arts, I suppose?"
"Naturally," said Professor Weasley crisply. "I would also advise -"
Professor Weasley gave another cough, a little more audible this time. Professor Weasley
closed her eyes for a moment, opened them again, and continued as though nothing had
happened.
"I would also advise Transfiguration, because Aurors frequently need to Transfigure or
Untransfigure in their work. And I ought to tell you now, Weasley, that I do not accept students into
my Ron classes unless they have achieved ‘Exceeds Expectations’ or higher at Ordinary Wizarding Level. I’d say you’re averaging ‘Acceptable’ at the moment, so you’ll need to put in some good hard work before the exams to stand a chance of continuing. Then you ought to do Charms, always useful, and Potions. Yes, Weasley, Potions," she added, with the merest flicker of a smile. "Poisons and antidotes are essential study for Aurors. And I must tell you that Professor Weasley absolutely refuses to take students who get anything other than ‘Outstanding’ in their OWLs, so -"
Professor Weasley gave her most pronounced cough yet.
"May I offer you a cough drop, Ron?" Professor Weasley asked curtly, without looking at Professor Weasley.
"Oh, no, thank you very much," said Weasley, with that simpering laugh Ron hated so much.
"I just wondered whether I could make the teensiest interruption, Ron?"
"I daresay you’ll find you can," said Professor Weasley through tightly gritted teeth.
"I was just wondering whether Mr. Weasley has quite the temperament for an Auror?" said Professor Weasley sweetly.
"Were you?" said Professor Weasley haughtily. "Well, Weasley," she continued, as though there had been no interruption, "if you are serious in this ambition, I would advise you to concentrate hard on bringing your Transfiguration and Potions up to scratch. I see Professor Weasley has graded you between ‘Acceptable’ and ‘Exceeds Expectations’ for the last two years, so your Charmwork seems satisfactory. As for Defense Against the Dark Arts, your marks have been generally high, Professor Weasley in particular thought you - are you quite sure you wouldn’t like a cough drop, Ron!"
"Oh, no need, thank you, Ron" simpered Professor Weasley, who had just coughed her
loudest yet. "I was just concerned that you might not have Rons most recent Defense Against
the Dark Arts marks in front of you. I’m quite sure I slipped in a note."
"What, this thing?" said Professor Weasley in a tone of revulsion, as she pulled a sheet of
pink parchment from between the leaves of Ron’s folder. She glanced down it, her eyebrows
slightly raised, then placed it back into the folder without comment.
"Yes, as I was saying, Weasley, Professor Weasley thought you showed a pronounced aptitude for the
subject, and obviously for an Auror -"
"Did you not understand my note, Ron?" asked Professor Weasley in honeyed tones, quite
forgetting to cough.
"Of course I understood it," said Professor Weasley, her teeth clenched so tightly the words
came out a little muffled.
"Well, then, I am confused... I’m afraid I don’t quite understand how you can give Mr. Weasley
false hope that -"
"False hope?" repeated Professor Weasley, still refusing to look round at Professor
