Weasley. "He has achieved high marks in all his Defense Against the Dark Arts tests -"
"I’m terribly sorry to have to contradict you, Ron, but as you will see from my note, Ron
has been achieving very poor results in his classes with me -"
"I should have made my meaning plainer," said Professor Weasley, turning at last to look
Weasley directly in the eyes. "He has achieved high marks in all Defense Against the Dark Arts
tests set by a competent teacher."
Professor Weasley’s smile vanished as suddenly as a light bulb blowing. She sat back in her
chair, turned a sheet on her clipboard and began scribbling very fast indeed, her bulging eyes
rolling from side to side. Professor Weasley turned back to Ron, her thin nostrils flared, her
eyes burning.
"Any questions, Weasley?"
"Yes," said Ron. "What sort of character and aptitude tests do the Ministry do on you, if you get enough Rons?"
"Well, you’ll need to demonstrate the ability to react well to pressure and so forth," said
Professor Weasley, "perseverance and dedication, because Auror training takes a further
three years, not to mention very high skills in practical Defense. It will mean a lot more study
even after you’ve left school, so unless you’re prepared to -"
"I think you’ll also find," said Weasley, her voice very cold now, "that the Ministry looks into
the records of those applying to be Aurors. Their criminal records."
"- unless you’re prepared to take even more exams after Hogwarts, you should really look at
another -"
"Which means that this boy has as much chance of becoming an Auror as Weasley has of
ever returning to this school."
"A very good chance, then," said Professor Weasley.
"Weasley has a criminal record," said Weasley loudly.
"Weasley has been cleared of all charges," said Weasley, even more loudly.
Professor Weasley stood up. She was so short that this did not make a great deal of difference,
but her fussy, simpering demeanour had given place to a hard fury that made her broad, flabby
face look oddly sinister.
"Weasley has no chance whatsoever of becoming an Auror!"
Professor Weasley got to her feet, too, and in her case this was a much more impressive
move; she towered over Professor Weasley.
"Weasley," she said in ringing tones, "I will assist you to become an Auror if it is the last thing I do! If I have to coach you nightly, I will make sure you achieve the required results!"
"The Minister for Magic will never employ Ron Weasley!" said Weasley, her voice rising
furiously.
"There may well be a new Minister for Magic by the time Weasley is ready to join!" shouted
Professor Weasley.
"Aha!" shrieked Professor Weasley, pointing a stubby finger at Weasley. "Yes! Yes, yes,
yes! Of course! That’s what you want, isn’t it, Ron Weasley? You want Ron Weasley
replaced by Ron Weasley! You think you’ll be where I am, don’t you: Senior
Undersecretary to the Minister and Headmistress to boot!"
"You are raving," said Professor Weasley, superbly disdainful. "Weasley, that concludes our
careers consultation."
Ron swung his bag over his shoulder and hurried out of the room, not daring to look at
Professor Weasley. He could hear her and Professor Weasley continuing to shout at each
other all the way back along the corridor.
Professor Weasley was still breathing as though she had just run a race when she strode into
their Defense Against the Dark Arts lesson that afternoon.
"I hope you’ve thought better of what you were planning to do, Ron," Ron whispered, the moment they had opened their books to ‘Chapter Thirty-four, Non-Retaliation and Negotiation’.
"Weasley looks like she’s in a really bad mood already..."
Every now and then Weasley shot glowering looks at Ron, who kept his head down, staring
at Defensive Magical Theory, his eyes unfocused, thinking...
He could just imagine Professor Weasley’s reaction if he was caught trespassing in Professor
Weasley’s office mere hours after she had vouched for him... there was nothing to stop him
simply going back to Weasley Tower and hoping that some time during the next summer
holidays he would have a chance to ask Ron about the scene he had witnessed in the
Pensieve... nothing, except that the thought of taking this sensible course of action made him
feel as though a lead weight had dropped into his stomach... and then there was the matter of
Ron and Ron, whose diversion was already planned, not to mention the knife Ron had
given him, which was currently residing in his schoolbag along with his father’s old Invisibility
Cloak.
But the fact remained that if he was caught...
"Weasley sacrificed himself to keep you in school, Ron!" whispered Ron, raising her
book to hide her face from Weasley. "And if you get thrown out today it will all have been for
nothing!"
He could abandon the plan and simply learn to live with the memory of what his father had done
on a summer’s day more than twenty years ago...
And then he remembered Ron in the fire upstairs in the Weasley common room...
You’re less like your father than I thought... the risk would’ve been what made it fun for
Ron...
But did he want to be like his father any more?
"Ron, don’t do it, please don’t do it!" Ron said in anguished tones as the bell rang at the
end of the class.
He did not answer; he did not know what to do.
Ron seemed determined to give neither his opinion nor his advice; he would not look at Ron,
though when Ron opened her mouth to try dissuading Ron some more, he said in a low
voice, "Give it a rest, okay? He can make up his own mind."
Rons heart beat very fast as he left the classroom. He was halfway along the corridor outside
when he heard the unmistakable sounds of a diversion going off in the distance. There were
screams and yells reverberating from somewhere above them; people exiting the classrooms all
around Ron were stopping in their tracks and looking up at the ceiling fearfully -
Weasley came pelting out of her classroom as fast as her short legs would carry her. Pulling out
her wand, she hurried off in the opposite direction: it was now or never.
"Ron - please!" Ron pleaded weakly.
But he had made up his mind; hitching his bag more securely on to his shoulder, he set off at a
run, weaving in and out of students now hurrying in the opposite direction to see what all the
fuss was about in the east wing.
Ron reached the corridor to Weasley’s office and found it deserted. Dashing behind a large
suit of armor whose helmet creaked around to watch him, he pulled open his bag, seized Ron’s knife and donned the Invisibility Cloak. He then crept slowly and carefully back out from behind the suit of armor and along the corridor until he reached Weasley’s door.
He inserted the blade of the magical knife into the crack around it and moved it gently up and
down, then withdrew it. There was a tiny click, and the door swung open. He ducked inside the
office, closed the door quickly behind him and looked around.
Nothing was moving except the horrible kittens that were still frolicking on the wall plates above
the confiscated broomsticks.
Ron pulled off his Cloak and, striding over to the fireplace, found what he was looking for
within seconds: a small box containing glittering Floo powder.
He crouched down in front of the empty grate, his hands shaking. He had never done this before,
though he thought he knew how it must work. Sticking his head into the fireplace, he took a large
pinch of powder and dropped it on to the logs stacked neatly beneath him. They exploded at once
into emerald green flames.
"Number twelve, Grimmauld Place!" Ron said loudly and clearly.
It was one of the most curious sensations he had ever experienced. He had traveled by Floo
powder before, of course, but then it had been his entire body that had spun around and around in
the flames through the network of wizarding fireplaces that stretched over the country. This time,
his knees remained firm upon the cold floor of Weasley’s office, and only his head hurtled
through the emerald fire...
And then, as abruptly as it had begun, the spinning stopped. Feeling rather sick and as though he
were wearing an exceptionally hot muffler around his head, Ron opened his eyes to find that he
was looking up out of the kitchen fireplace at the long, wooden table, where a man sat poring
over a piece of parchment.
"Ron?"
The man jumped and looked around. It was not Ron, but Weasley.
"Ron!" he said, looking thoroughly shocked. "What are you - what’s happened, is everything all right?"
"Yeah," said Ron. "I just wondered -- I mean, I just fancied a - a chat with Ron."
"I’ll call him," said Weasley, getting to his feet, still looking perplexed, "he went upstairs to look for Ron, he seems to be hiding in the attic again..."
And Ron saw Weasley hurry out of the kitchen. Now he was left with nothing to look at but the
chair and table legs. He wondered why Ron had never mentioned how very uncomfortable it
was to speak out of the fire; his knees were already objecting painfully to their prolonged contact
with Weasley’s hard stone floor.
Weasley returned with Ron at his heels moments later.
"What is it?" said Ron urgently, sweeping his long dark hair out of his eyes and dropping to the
ground in front of the fire, so that he and Ron were on a level. Weasley knelt down too, looking
very concerned. "Are you all right? Do you need help?"
"No," said Ron, "it’s nothing like that... I just wanted to talk... about my dad."
They exchanged a look of great surprise, but Ron did not have time to feel awkward or
embarrassed; his knees were becoming sorer by the second and he guessed five minutes had
already passed from the start of the diversion; Ron had only guaranteed him twenty. He
therefore plunged immediately into the story of what he had seen in the Pensieve.
When he had finished, neither Ron nor Weasley spoke for a moment. Then Weasley said quietly, "I
wouldn’t like you to judge your father on what you saw there, Ron. He was only fifteen -"
"I’m fifteen!" said Ron heatedly.
"Look, Ron" said Ron placatingly, "Ron and Weasley hated each other from the moment they
set eyes on each other, it was just one of those things, you can understand that, can’t you? I think
Ron was everything Weasley wanted to be - he was popular, he was good at Quidditch - good at
pretty much everything. And Weasley was just this little oddball who was up to his eyes in the
Dark Arts, and Ron - whatever else he may have appeared to you, Ron - always hated the
Dark Arts."
"Yeah," said Ron, "but he just attacked Weasley for no good reason, just because - well, just
because you said you were bored," he finished, with a slightly apologetic note in his voice.
"I’m not proud of it," said Ron quickly.
Weasley looked sideways at Ron, then said, "Look, Ron, what you’ve got to understand is that
your father and Ron were the best in the school at whatever they did - everyone thought they
were the height of cool - if they sometimes got a bit carried away -"
"If we were sometimes arrogant little berks, you mean," said Ron.
Weasley smiled.
"He kept messing up his hair," said Ron in a pained voice.
Ron and Weasley laughed.
"I’d forgotten he used to do that," said Ron affectionately.
"Was he playing with the Snitch?" said Weasley eagerly.
"Yeah," said Ron, watching uncomprehendingly as Ron and Weasley beamed reminiscently.
"Well... I thought he was a bit of an idiot."
"Of course he was a bit of an idiot!" said Ron bracingly, "we were all idiots! Well - not Moony
so much," he said fairly, looking at Weasley.
But Weasley shook his head. "Did I ever tell you to lay off Weasley?" he said. "Did I ever have the
guts to tell you I thought you were out of order?"
"Yeah, well," said Ron, "you made us feel ashamed of ourselves sometimes... that was
something..."
"And," said Ron doggedly, determined to say everything that was on his mind now he was here, "he kept looking over at the girls by the lake, hoping they were watching him!"
"Oh, well, he always made a fool of himself whenever Ron was around," said Ron, shrugging,
"he couldn’t stop himself showing off whenever he got near her."
"How come she married him?" Ron asked miserably. "She hated him!"
"Nah, she didn’t," said Ron.
"She started going out with him in seventh year," said Weasley.
"Once Ron had deflated his head a bit," said Ron.
"And stopped hexing people just for the fun of it," said Weasley.
"Even Weasley?" said Ron.
"Well," said Weasley slowly, "Weasley was a special case I mean, he never lost an opportunity to
curse Ron so you couldn’t really expect Ron to take that lying down, could you?"
"And my mum was okay with that?"
"She didn’t know too much about it, to tell you the truth," said Ron. "I mean, Ron didn’t take
Weasley on dates with her and jinx him in front of her, did he?"
Ron frowned at Ron, who was still looking unconvinced.
"Look," he said, "your father was the best friend I ever had and he was a good person. A lot of
people are idiots at the age of fifteen. He grew out of it."
"Yeah, okay," said Ron heavily. "I just never thought I’d feel sorry for Weasley."
"Now you mention it," said Weasley, a faint crease between his eyebrows, "how did Weasley react
when he found you’d seen all this?"
"He told me he’d never teach me Occlumency again," said Ron indifferently, "like that’s a big
disappoint--"
"He WHAT?" shouted Ron, causing Ron to jump and inhale a mouthful of ashes.
"Are you serious, Ron?" said Weasley quickly. "He’s stopped giving you lessons?"
"Yeah," said Ron, surprised at what he considered a great over-reaction. "But it’s okay, I don’t
care, it’s a bit of a relief to tell you the -"
"I’m coming up there to have a word with Weasley!" said Ron forcefully, and he actually made to stand up, but Weasley wrenched him back down again.
"If anyone’s going to tell Weasley it will be me!" he said firmly. "But Ron, first of all, you’re to
go back to Weasley and tell him that on no account is he to stop giving you lessons -- when
Weasley hears -"
"I can’t tell him that, he’d kill me!" said Ron, outraged. "You didn’t see him when we got out of the Pensieve."
"Ron there is nothing so important as you learning Occlumency!" said Weasley sternly. "Do you
understand me? Nothing!"
"Okay, okay," said Ron, thoroughly discomposed, not to mention annoyed. "I’ll... I’ll try and say something to him... but it won’t be-"
He fell silent. He could hear distant footsteps.
"Is that Ron coming downstairs?"
"No," said Ron, glancing behind him. "It must be somebody your end." Rons heart skipped
several beats.
"I’d better go!" he said hastily and pulled his head backwards out of the Grimmauld Place fire. For a moment his head seemed to be revolving on his shoulders, then he found himself kneeling in front of Weasley’s fire with it firmly back on and watching the emerald flames flicker and die.
"Quickly, quickly!" he heard a wheezy voice mutter right outside the office door. "Ah, she’s left
it open -"
Ron dived for the Invisibility Cloak and had just managed to pull it back over himself when
Weasley burst into the office. He looked absolutely delighted about something and was talking to
himself feverishly as he crossed the room, pulled open a drawer in Weasley’s desk and began
rifling through the papers inside it.
"Approval for Whipping... Approval for Whipping... I can do it at last... they’ve had it coming
to them for years..."
He pulled out a piece of parchment, kissed it, then shuffled rapidly back out of the door,
clutching it to his chest.
Ron leapt to his feet and, making sure he had his bag and that the Invisibility Cloak was
completely covering him, he wrenched open the door and hurried out of the office after Weasley,
who was hobbling along faster than Ron had ever seen him go.
One landing down from Weasley’s office, Ron thought it was safe to become visible again.
He pulled off the Cloak, shoved it in his bag and hurried onwards. There was a great deal of
shouting and movement coming from the Entrance Hall. He ran down the marble staircase and
found what looked like most of the school assembled there.
It was just like the night when Weasley had been sacked. Students were standing all around the
walls in a great ring (some of them, Ron noticed, covered in a substance that looked very like
Stinksap); teachers and ghosts were also in the crowd. Prominent among the onlookers were
members of the Inquisitorial Squad, who were all looking exceptionally pleased with themselves,
and Ron, who was bobbing overhead, gazed down at Ron and Ron who stood in the
middle of the floor with the unmistakable look of two people who had just been cornered.
"So!" said Weasley triumphantly. Ron realized she was standing just a few stairs in front of
him, once more looking down upon her prey. "So - you think it amusing to turn a school corridor
into a swamp, do you?"
"Pretty amusing, yeah," said Ron, looking up at her without the slightest sign of fear.
Weasley elbowed his way closer to Weasley, almost crying with happiness.
"I’ve got the form, Headmistress," he said hoarsely, waving the piece of parchment Ron had
just seen him take from her desk. "I’ve got the form and I’ve got the whips waiting... oh, let me
do it now..."
"Very good, Ron," she said. "You two," she went on, gazing down at Ron and Ron, "are
about to learn what happens to wrongdoers in my school."
"You know what?" said Ron. "I don’t think we are."
He turned to his twin.
"Ron," said Ron, "I think we’ve outgrown full-time education."
"Yeah, I’ve been feeling that way myself," said Ron lightly.
"Time to test our talents in the real world, d’you reckon?" asked Ron.
"Definitely," said Ron.
And before Weasley could say a word, they raised their wands and said together:
"Accio brooms!"
Ron heard a loud crash somewhere in the distance. Looking to his left, he ducked just in time.
Ron and Ron’s broomsticks, one still trailing the heavy chain and iron peg with which
Weasley had fastened them to the wall, were hurtling along the corridor towards their owners;
they turned left, streaked down the stairs and stopped sharply in front of the twins, the chain
clattering loudly on the flagged stone floor.
"We won’t be seeing you," Ron told Professor Weasley, swinging his leg over his broomstick.
"Yeah, don’t bother to keep in touch," said Ron, mounting his own.
Ron looked around at the assembled students, at the silent, watchful crowd.
"If anyone fancies buying a Portable Swamp, as demonstrated upstairs, come to number ninety-three, Diagon Alley - Weasleys’ Wizarding Wheezes," he said in a loud voice. "Our new
premises!"
"Special discounts to Hogwarts students who swear they’re going to use our products to get rid of this old bat," added Ron, pointing at Professor Weasley.
"STOP THEM!" shrieked Weasley, but it was too late. As the Inquisitorial Squad closed in,
Ron and Ron kicked off from the floor, shooting fifteen feet into the air, the iron peg
swinging dangerously below. Ron looked across the hall at the poltergeist bobbing on his level
above the crowd.
"Give her hell from us, Ron."
And Ron, who Ron had never seen take an order from a student before, swept his belled hat
from his head and sprang to a salute as Ron and Ron wheeled about to tumultuous applause
from the students below and sped out of the open front doors into the glorious sunset.
CHAPTER THIRTY
Ron
The story of Ron and Ron’s flight to freedom was retold so often over the next few days that
Ron could tell it would soon become the stuff of Hogwarts legend: within a week, even those
who had been eye-witnesses were half-convinced they had seen the twins dive-bomb Weasley
on their brooms and pelt her with Dungbombs before zooming out of the doors. In the immediate
aftermath of their departure there was a great wave of talk about copying them. Ron frequently
heard students saying things like, "Honestly some days I just feel like jumping on my broom and
leaving this place," or else, "One more lesson like that and I might just do a Weasley."
Ron and Ron had made sure nobody was likely to forget them too soon. For one thing, they
had not left instructions on how to remove the swamp that now filled the corridor on the fifth
floor of the east wing. Weasley and Weasley had been observed trying different means of
removing it but without success. Eventually the area was roped off and Weasley, gnashing his teeth
furiously, was given the task of punting students across it to their classrooms. Ron was certain
that teachers like Weasley or Weasley could have removed the swamp in an instant but, just
as in the case of Ron and Rons Wildfire Whiz-bangs, they seemed to prefer to watch
Weasley struggle.
Then there were the two large broom-shaped holes in Weasley’s office door, through which
Ron and Ron’s Cleansweeps had smashed to rejoin their masters. Weasley fitted a new door and
removed Ron’s Firebolt to the dungeons where, it was rumored, Weasley had set an armed
security troll to guard it. However, her troubles were far from over.
Inspired by Ron and Ron’s example, a great number of students were now vying for the
newly vacant positions of Troublemakers-in-Chief. In spite of the new door, somebody managed
to slip a hairy-snouted Niffler into Weasley’s office, which promptly tore the place apart in its
search for shiny objects, leapt on Weasley when she entered and tried to gnaw the rings off her
stubby fingers. Dungbombs and Stink Pellets were dropped so frequently in the corridors that it
became the new fashion for students to perform Bubble-Head Charms on themselves before
leaving lessons, which ensured them a supply of fresh air, even though it gave them all the
peculiar appearance of wearing upside-down goldfish bowls on their heads.
Weasley prowled the corridors with a horsewhip ready in his hands, desperate to catch miscreants,
but the problem was that there were now so many of them he never knew which way to turn. The
Inquisitorial Squad was attempting to help him, but odd things kept happening to its members.
Warrington of the Weasley Quidditch team reported to the hospital wing with a horrible skin
complaint that made him look as though he had been coated in cornflakes; Ron Weasley, to
Rons delight, missed all her lessons the following day as she had sprouted antlers.
Meanwhile, it became clear just how many Skiving Snackboxes Ron and Ron had managed
to sell before leaving Hogwarts. Weasley only had to enter her classroom for the students
assembled there to faint, vomit, develop dangerous fevers or else spout blood from both nostrils.
Shrieking with rage and frustration, she attempted to trace the mysterious symptoms to their
source, but the students told her stubbornly they were suffering from ‘Weasley -itis’. After
putting four successive classes in detention and failing to discover their secret, she was forced to
give up and allow the bleeding, swooning, sweating and vomiting students to leave her classes in
droves.
But not even the users of the Snackboxes could compete with that master of chaos, Ron, who
seemed to have taken Ron’s parting words deeply to heart. Cackling madly, he soared through
the school, upending tables, bursting out of blackboards, toppling statues and vases; twice he
shut Mrs. Norris inside a suit of armor, from which she was rescued, yowling loudly, by the
furious caretaker. Ron smashed lanterns and snuffed out candles, juggled burning torches over
the heads of screaming students, caused neatly stacked piles of parchment to topple into fires or
out of windows; flooded the second floor when he pulled off all the taps in the bathrooms,
dropped a bag of tarantulas in the middle of the Great Hall during breakfast and, whenever he
fancied a break, spent hours at a time floating along after Weasley and blowing loud raspberries
every time she spoke.
None of the staff but Weasley seemed to be stirring themselves to help her. Indeed, a week after
Ron and Ron’s departure Ron witnessed Professor Weasley walking right past Ron,
who was determinedly loosening a crystal chandelier, and could have sworn he heard her tell the
poltergeist out of the corner of her mouth, "It unscrews the other way."
To cap matters, Weasley had still not recovered from his sojourn in the toilet; he remained
confused and disorientated and his parents were to be observed one Tuesday morning striding up
the front drive, looking extremely angry.
"Should we say something?" said Ron in a worried voice, pressing her cheek against the
Charms window so that she could see Mr. and Mrs. Weasley marching inside. "About what
happened to him? In case it helps Ron Weasley cure him?"
"Course not, he’ll recover," said Ron indifferently.
"Anyway, more trouble for Weasley, isn’t it?" said Ron in a satisfied voice.
He and Ron both tapped the teacups they were supposed to be charming with their wands.
Ron’s spouted four very short legs that could not reach the desk and wriggled pointlessly in
midair. Ron’s grew four very thin spindly legs that hoisted the cup off the desk with great
difficulty, trembled for a few seconds, then folded, causing the cup to crack into two.
"Reparo," said Ron quickly, mending Ron’s cup with a wave of her wand. "That’s all very
well, but what if Weasley’s permanently injured?"
"Who cares?" said Ron irritably, while his teacup stood up drunkenly again, trembling violently
at the knees. "Weasley shouldn’t have tried to take all those points from Weasley, should he?
If you want to worry about anyone, Ron, worry about me!"
"You?" she said, catching her teacup as it scampered happily away across the desk on four sturdy little willow-patterned legs, and replacing it in front of her. "Why should I be worried about you?"
"When Mum’s next letter finally gets through Weasley’s screening process," said Ron bitterly,
now holding his cup up while its frail legs tried feebly to support its weight, "I’m going to be in
deep trouble. I wouldn’t be surprised if she’s sent another Howler."
"But -"
"It’ll be my fault Ron and Ron left, you wait, " said Ron darkly. "She’ll say I should’ve
stopped them leaving, I should’ve grabbed the ends of their brooms and hung on or something...
yeah, it’ll be all my fault."
"Well, if she does say that it’ll be very unfair, you couldn’t have done anything! But I’m sure she won’t, I mean, if it’s really true they’ve got premises in Diagon Alley, they must have been
planning this for ages."
"Yeah, but that’s another thing, how did they get premises?" said Ron, hitting his teacup so hard
with his wand that its legs collapsed again and it lay twitching before him. "It’s a bit dodgy isn’t
it? They’ll need loads of Galleons to afford the rent on a place in Diagon Alley. She’ll want to
know what they’ve been up to, to get their hands on that sort of gold."
"Well, yes, that occurred to me, too," said Ron, allowing her teacup to jog in neat little
circles around Ron’s, whose stubby little legs were still unable to touch the desktop, "I’ve been
wondering whether Ron has persuaded them to sell stolen goods or something awful."
"He hasn’t," said Ron curtly.
"How do you know?" said Ron and Ron together.
"Because -" Ron hesitated, but the moment to confess finally seemed to have come. There was
no good to be gained in keeping silent if it meant anyone suspected that Ron and Ron were
criminals. "Because they got the gold from me. I gave them my Triwizard winnings last June."
There was a shocked silence, then Ron’s teacup jogged right over the edge of the desk and
smashed on the floor.
"Oh, Ron, you didn’t!" she said.
"Yes, I did," said Ron mutinously. "And I don’t regret it, either. I didn’t need the gold and
they’ll be great at running a joke shop."
"But this is excellent!" said Ron, looking thrilled. "It’s all your fault, Ron - Mum can’t blame
me at all! Can I tell her?"
"Yeah, I suppose you’d better," said Ron dully, "specially if she thinks they’re receiving stolen
cauldrons or something."
Ron said nothing at all for the rest of the lesson, but Ron had a shrewd suspicion that her
self-restraint was bound to crack before long. Sure enough, once they had left the castle for break
and were standing around in the weak May sunshine, she fixed Ron with a beady eye and
opened her mouth with a determined air.
Ron interrupted her before she had even started.
"It’s no good nagging me, it’s done," he said firmly. "Ron and Ron have got the gold - spent a good bit of it, too, by the sounds of it - and I can’t get it back from them and I don’t want to. So
save your breath, Ron."
"I wasn’t going to say anything about Ron and Ron!" she said in an injured voice.
Ron snorted disbelievingly and Ron threw him a very dirty look.
"No, I wasn’t!" she said angrily. "As a matter of fact, I was going to ask Ron when he’s going
to go back to Weasley and ask for more Occlumency lessons!"
Ron’s heart sank. Once they had exhausted the subject of Ron and Ron’s dramatic
departure, which admittedly had taken many hours, Ron and Ron had wanted to hear news
of Ron. As Ron had not confided in them the reason he had wanted to talk to Ron in the first
place, it had been hard to think of what to tell them; he had ended up saying, truthfully, that
Ron wanted Ron to resume Occlumency lessons. He had been regretting this ever since;
Ron would not let the subject drop and kept reverting to it when Ron least expected it.
"You can’t tell me you’ve stopped having funny dreams," Ron said now, "because Ron told me you were muttering in your sleep again last night."
Ron threw Ron a furious look. Ron had the grace to look ashamed of himself.
"You were only muttering a bit," he mumbled apologetically. "Something about ‘just a bit
further’."
"I dreamed I was watching you lot play Quidditch," Ron lied brutally. "I was trying to get you
to stretch out a bit further to grab the Quaffle."
Ron’s ears went red. Ron felt a kind of vindictive pleasure; he had not, of course, dreamed
anything of the sort.
Last night, he had once again made the journey along the Department of Mysteries corridor. He
had passed through the circular room, then the room full of clicking and dancing light, until he
found himself again inside that cavernous room full of shelves on which were ranged dusty glass
spheres.
He had hurried straight towards row number ninety-seven, turned left, and ran along it... it had
probably been then that he had spoken aloud... just a bit further... for he felt his conscious self
struggling to wake... and before he had reached the end of the row, he had found himself lying
in bed again, gazing up at the canopy of his four-poster.
"You are trying to block your mind, aren’t you?" said Ron, looking beadily at Ron. "You
are keeping going with your Occlumency?"
"Of course I am," said Ron, trying to sound as though this question was insulting, but not quite
meeting her eye. The truth was he was so intensely curious about what was hidden in that room
full of dusty orbs, that he was quite keen for the dreams to continue.
The problem was that with just under a month to go until the exams and every free moment
devoted to revision, his mind seemed so saturated with information when he went to bed he
found it very difficult to get to sleep at all; and when he did, his overwrought brain presented
him most nights with stupid dreams about the exams. He also suspected that part of his mind -
the part that often spoke in Ron’s voice -- now felt guilty on the occasions it strayed down
that corridor ending in the black door, and sought to wake him before he could reach the
journeys end.
"You know," said Ron, whose ears were still flaming red, "if Weasley doesn’t recover before
Weasley play Weasley, we might be in with a chance of winning the Cup."
"Yeah, I s’pose so," said Ron, glad of a change of subject.
"I mean, we’ve won one, lost one - if Weasley lose to Weasley next Saturday -"
"Yeah, that’s right," said Ron, losing track of what he was agreeing to. Ron Weasley had just
walked across the courtyard, determinedly not looking at him.
The final match of the Quidditch season, Weasley versus Weasley, was to take place on the
last weekend of May. Although Weasley had been narrowly defeated by Weasley in their last
match, Weasley were not daring to hope for victory, due mainly (though of course nobody said
it to him) to Ron’s abysmal goal-keeping record. He, however, seemed to have found a new
optimism.
"I mean, I can’t get any worse, can I?" he told Ron and Ron grimly over breakfast on the
morning of the match. "Nothing to lose now, is there?"
"You know," said Ron, as she and Ron walked down to the pitch a little later in the midst
of a very excitable crowd, "I think Ron might do better without Ron and Ron around. They
never exactly gave him a lot of confidence."
Ron Weasley overtook them with what appeared to be a live eagle perched on top of her head.
"Oh, gosh, I forgot!" said Ron, watching the eagle flapping its wings as Ron walked
serenely past a group of cackling and pointing Weasleys. "Ron will be playing, won’t she?"
Ron, who had not forgotten this, merely grunted.
They found seats in the topmost row of the stands. It was a fine, clear day; Ron could not wish
for better, and Ron found himself hoping against hope that Ron would not give the Weasleys
cause for more rousing choruses of ‘Weasley is our King’.
Ron Weasley, who had been very dispirited since Ron and Ron had left, was commentating as
usual. As the teams zoomed out on to the pitch he named the players with something less than
his usual gusto.
"... Bradley... Weasley... Weasley," he said, and Ron felt his stomach perform, less of a back flip,
more a feeble lurch as Ron walked out on to the pitch, her shiny black hair rippling in the slight
breeze. He was not sure what he wanted to happen any more, except that he could not stand any
more rows. Even the sight of her chatting animatedly to Ron Weasley as they prepared to mount
their brooms caused him only a slight twinge of jealousy.
"And they’re off!" said Ron. "And Weasley takes the Quaffle immediately, Weasley Captain
Weasley with the Quaffle, he dodges Ronson, he dodges Weasley, he dodges Weasley as well... he’s
going straight for goal! He’s going to shoot - and - and -" Ron swore very loudly. "And he’s
scored."
Ron and Ron groaned with the rest of the Weasleys. Predictably, horribly, the
Weasleys on the other side of the stands began to sing: "Weasley cannot save a thing He cannot block a single ring..."
"Ron" said a hoarse voice in Rons ear. "Ron..."
Ron looked round and saw Weasley’s enormous bearded face sticking between the seats.
Apparently, he had squeezed his way all along the row behind, for the first- and second-years he
had just passed had a ruffled, flattened look about them. For some reason, Weasley was bent
double as though anxious not to be seen, though he was still at least four feet taller than
everybody else.
"Listen," he whispered, "can yeh come with me? Now? While ev’ryone’s watchin’ the match?"
"Er... can’t it wait, Weasley?" asked Ron. "Till the match is over?"
"No," said Weasley. "No, Ron, it’s gotta be now... while ev’ryone’s lookin’ the other way...
please?"
Weasley’s nose was gently dripping blood. His eyes were both blackened. Ron had not seen him
this close-up since his return to the school; he looked utterly woebegone.
"Course," said Ron at once, "course we’ll come."
He and Ron edged back along their row of seats, causing much grumbling among the
students who had to stand up for them. The people in Weasley’s row were not complaining,
merely attempting to make themselves as small as possible.
"I ‘ppreciate this, you two, I really do," said Hag rid as they reached the stairs. He kept looking
around nervously as they descended towards the lawn below. "I jus’ hope she doesn’ notice us
goin’."
"You mean Weasley?" said Ron. "She won’t, she’s got her whole Inquisitorial Squad sitting
with her, didn’t you see? She must be expecting trouble at the match."
"Yeah, well, a bit o’ trouble wouldn’ hurt," said Weasley, pausing to peer around the edge of the
stands to make sure the stretch of lawn between there and his cabin was deserted. "Give us more
time."
"What is it, Weasley?" said Ron, looking up at him with a concerned expression on her face
as they hurried across the grass towards the edge of the Forest.
"Yeh - yeh’ll see in a mo’," said Weasley, looking over his shoulder as a great roar rose from the
stands behind them. "Hey - did someone jus’ score?"
"It’ll be Weasley," said Ron heavily.
"Good... good..." said Weasley distractedly. "Tha’s good..."
They had to jog to keep up with him as he strode across the lawn, looking around with every
other step. When they reached his cabin, Ron turned automatically left towards the front
door. Weasley, however, walked straight past it into the shade of the trees on the outermost edge
of the Forest, where he picked up a crossbow that was leaning against a tree. When he realized
they were no longer with him, he turned.
"We’re goin’ in here," he said, jerking his shaggy head behind him.
"Into the Forest?" said Ron, perplexed.
"Yeah," said Weasley. "C’mon now, quick, before we’re spotted!"
Ron and Ron looked at each other, then ducked into the cover of the trees behind Weasley,
who was already striding away from them into the green gloom, his crossbow over his arm.
Ron and Ron ran to catch up with him.
"Weasley, why are you armed?" said Ron.
"Jus’ a precaution," said Weasley, shrugging his massive shoulders.
"You didn’t bring your crossbow the day you showed us the Thestrals," said Ron timidly.
"Nah, well, we weren’ goin’ in so far then," said Weasley. "An’ anyway, tha’ was before Ron
left the Forest, wasn’ it?"
"Why does Ron leaving make a difference?" asked Ron curiously.
"Cause the other centaurs are good an’ riled at me, tha’s why," said Weasley quietly, glancing
around. "They used ter be - well, yeh couldn’ call ‘em friendly -- but we got on all righ’. Kept
‘emselves to ‘emselves, bu’ always turned up if I wanted a word. Not any more."
He sighed deeply.
"Ron said they’re angry because he went to work for Weasley," Ron said, tripping on a
protruding root because he was busy watching Weasley’s profile.
"Yeah," said Weasley heavily. "Well, angry doesn’ cover it. Ruddy livid. If I hadn’ stepped in, I
reckon they’d’ve kicked Ron ter death -"
"They attacked him?" said Ron, sounding shocked.
"Yep," said Weasley gruffly, forcing his way through several low-hanging branches. "He had half
the herd on to him."
"And you stopped it?" said Ron, amazed and impressed. "By yourself?"
"Course I did, couldn’t stand by an’ watch ‘em kill ‘im, could I?" said Weasley. "Lucky I was
passin’, really... an’ I’d’ve thought Ron mighta remembered tha’ before he started sendin’
me stupid warnin’s!" he added hotly and unexpectedly.
Ron and Ron looked at each other, startled, but Weasley, scowling, did not elaborate.
"Anyway," he said, breathing a little more heavily than -usual, "since then the other centaurs’ve
bin livid with me, an’ the trouble is they’ve got a lot of influence in the Forest... cleverest
creatures in here."
"Is that why we’re here, Weasley?" asked Ron. "The centaurs?"
"Ah, no," said Weasley, shaking his head dismissively, "no, it’s not them. Well, o’ course, they
could complicate the problem, yeah... but yeh’ll see what I mean in a bit."
On this incomprehensible note he fell silent and forged a little ahead, taking one stride for every
three of theirs, so that they had great trouble keeping up with him.
The path was becoming increasingly overgrown and the trees grew so closely together as they
walked further and further into the Forest that it was as dark as dusk. They were soon a long way
past the clearing where Weasley had shown them the Thestrals, but Ron felt no sense of unease
until Weasley stepped unexpectedly off the path and began wending his way in and out of trees
towards the dark heart of the Forest.
"Weasley!" said Ron, fighting his way through thickly knotted brambles, over which Weasley had
stepped with ease, and remembering very vividly what had happened to him on the other
occasion he had stepped off the Forest path. "Where are we going?"
"Bit further," said Weasley over his shoulder. "C’mon, Ron... we need ter keep together now."
It was a great struggle to keep up with Weasley, what with branches and thickets of thorn through
which Weasley marched as easily as if they were cobwebs, but which snagged Ron and
Ron’s robes, frequently entangling them so severely that they had to stop for minutes at a
time to free themselves. Ron’s arms and legs were soon covered in small cuts and scratches.
They were so deep in the Forest now that sometimes all Ron could see of Weasley in the gloom
was a massive dark shape ahead of him. Any sound seemed threatening in the muffled silence.
The breaking of a twig echoed loudly and the tiniest rustle of movement, even though it might
have been made by an innocent sparrow, caused Ron to peer through the gloom for a culprit. It
occurred to him that he had never managed to get this far into the Forest without meeting some
kind of creature; their absence struck him as rather ominous.
"Weasley, would it be all right if we lit our wands?" said Ron quietly.
"Er... all righ’," Weasley whispered back. "In fact -"
He stopped suddenly and turned around; Ron walked right into him and was knocked over
backwards. Ron caught her just before she hit the Forest floor.
"Maybe we bes’ jus’ stop fer a momen’, so I can... fill yeh in," said Weasley. "Before we ge’ there, like."
"Good!" said Ron, as Ron set her back on her feet. They both murmured "Lumos!" and
their wand-tips ignited. Weasley’s face swam through the gloom by the light of the two wavering
beams and Ron saw again that he looked nervous and sad.
"Righ’," said Weasley. "Well... see... the thing is..."
He took a great breath.
"Well, there’s a good chance I’m goin’ ter be gettin’ the sack any day now," he said.
Ron and Ron looked at each other, then back at him.
"But you’ve lasted this long -" Ron said tentatively. "What makes you think -"
"Weasley reckons it was me that put tha’ Niffler in her office."
"And was it?" said Ron, before he could stop himself.
"No, it ruddy well wasn’!" said Weasley indignantly. "On’y any-thin’ ter do with magical creatures an’ she thinks it’s got somethin’ ter do with me. Yeh know she’s bin lookin’ fer a chance ter get rid of me ever since I got back. I don’ wan’ ter go, o’ course, but if it wasn’ fer... well... the special circumstances I’m abou’ ter explain to yeh, I’d leave righ’ now, before she’s go’ the chance ter do it in front o’ the whole school, like she did with Weasley."
Ron and Ron both made noises of protest, but Weasley overrode them with a wave of one
of his enormous hands.
"It’s not the end o’ the world, I’ll be able ter help Weasley once I’m outta here, I can be
useful ter the Order. An’ you lot’ll have Weasley, yeh’ll - yeh’ll get through yer exams
fine..."
His voice trembled and broke.
"Don’ worry abou’ me," he said hastily, as Ron made to pat his arm. He pulled his
enormous spotted handkerchief from the pocket of his waistcoat and mopped his eyes with it.
"Look, I wouldn’ be tellin’ yer this at all if I didn’ have ter. See, if I go... well, I can’ leave
withou’... withou’ tellin’ someone... because I’ll - I’ll need yeh two ter help me. An’ Ron, if
he’s willin’."
"Of course we’ll help you," said Ron at once. "What do you want us to do?"
Weasley gave a great sniff and patted Ron wordlessly on the shoulder with such force Ron was
knocked sideways into a tree.
"I knew yeh’d say yes," said Weasley into his handkerchief, "but I won’... never... forget...
well... c’mon... jus’ a little bit further through here... watch yerselves, now, there’s nettles..."
They walked on in silence for another fifteen minutes; Ron had opened his mouth to ask how
much further they had to go when Weasley threw out his right arm to signal that they should stop.
"Really easy" he said softly. "Very quiet, now..."
They crept forwards and Ron saw that they were facing a large, smooth mound of earth nearly
as tall as Weasley that he thought, with a jolt of dread, was sure to be the lair of some enormous
animal. Trees had been ripped up at the roots all around the mound, so that it stood on a bare
patch of ground surrounded by heaps of trunks and boughs that formed a kind of fence or
barricade, behind which Ron, Ron and Weasley now stood.
"Sleepin’," breathed Weasley.
Sure enough, Ron could hear a distant, rhythmic rumbling that sounded like a pair of enormous
lungs at work. He glanced sideways at Ron, who was gazing at the mound with her mouth
slightly open. She looked utterly terrified.
"Weasley," she said in a whisper barely audible over the sound of the sleeping creature, "who is
he?"
Ron found this an odd question..."What is it?" was the one he had been planning on asking.
"Weasley, you told us -" said Ron, her wand now shaking in her hand, "you told us none of
them wanted to come!"
Ron looked from her to Weasley and then, as realization hit him, he looked back at the mound
with a small gasp of horror.
The great mound of earth, on which he, Ron and Weasley could easily have stood, was
moving slowly up and down in time with the deep, grunting breathing. It was not a mound at all.
It was the curved back of what was clearly --
"Well - no - he didn’ want ter come," said Weasley, sounding desperate. "But I had ter bring him,
Ron, I had ter!"
"But why?" asked Ron, who sounded as though she wanted to cry. "Why - what -
oh, Weasley!"
"I knew if I jus’ got him back," said Weasley, sounding close to tears himself, "an’ - an’ taught him a few manners - I’d be able ter take him outside an’ show ev’ryone he’s harmless!"
"Harmless!" said Ron shrilly, and Weasley made frantic hushing noises with his hands as the
enormous creature before them grunted loudly and shifted in its sleep. "He’s been hurting you all
this time, hasn’t he? That’s why you’ve had all these injuries!"
"He don’ know his own strength!" said Weasley earnestly. "An’ he’s gettin’ better, he’s not fightin’ so much any more --"
"So, this is why it took you two months to get home!" said Ron distractedly. "Oh, Weasley,
why did you bring him back if he didn’t want to come? Wouldn’t he have been happier with his
own people?"
"They were all bullyin’ him, Ron, ‘cause he’s so small!" said Weasley.
"Small?" said Ron. "Small?"
"Ron, I couldn’ leave him," said Weasley, tears now trickling down his bruised face into his
beard. "See - he’s my brother!"
Ron simply stared at him, her mouth open.
"Weasley, when you say ‘brother’," said Ron slowly, "d o you mean --?"
"Well - half-brother," amended Weasley. "Turns out me mother took up with another giant when
she left me dad, an’ she went an’ had Ron here -"
"Ron?" said Ron.
"Yeah... well, tha’s what it sounds like when he says his name," said Weasley anxiously. "He don’ speak a lot of English... I’ve bin tryin’ ter teach him... anyway, she don’ seem ter have liked him much more’n she liked me. See, with giantesses, what counts is producin’ good big kids, and he’s always been a bit on the runty side fer a giant - on’y sixteen foot -"
"Oh, yes, tiny!" said Ron, with a kind of hysterical sarcasm. "Absolutely minuscule!"
"He was bein’ kicked aroun’ by all o’ them - I jus’ couldn’ leave him -"
"Did Rone Weasley want to bring him back?" asked Ron.
"She - well, she could see it was right importan’ ter me," said Weasley, twisting his enormous
hands. "Bu’ - bu’ she got a bit tired o’ him after a while, I must admit... so we split up on the
journey home... she promised not ter tell anyone, though..."
"How on earth did you get him back without anyone noticing?" said Ron.
"Well, tha’s why it took so long, see," said Weasley. "Could on’y travel by nigh’ an’ through wild
country an’ stuff. Course, he covers the ground pretty well when he wants ter, but he kep’
wantin’ ter go back."
"Oh, Weasley, why on earth didn’t you let him!" said Ron, flopping down on to a ripped up
tree and burying her face in her hands. "What do you think you’re going to do with a violent
giant who doesn’t even want to be here!"
"Well, now - ‘violent’ - tha’s a bit harsh," said Weasley, still twisting his hands agitatedly. "I’ll admit he mighta taken a couple o’ swings at me when he’s bin in a bad mood, but he’s gettin’ better, loads better, settlin’ down well."
"What are those ropes for, then?" Ron asked.
He had just noticed ropes thick as saplings stretching from around the trunks of the largest
nearby trees towards the place where Ron lay curled on the ground with his back to them.
"You have to keep him tied up?" said Ron faintly.
"Well... yeah..." said Weasley, looking anxious. "See - it’s like I say - he doesn’ really know ‘is
own strength."
Ron understood now why there had been such a suspicious lack of any other living creature in
this part of the Forest.
"So, what is it you want Ron and Ron and me to do?" Ron asked apprehensively.
"Look after him," said Weasley croakily. "After I’m gone."
Ron and Ron exchanged miserable looks, Ron uncomfortably aware that he had already
promised Weasley that he would do whatever he asked.
"What - what does that involve, exactly?" Ron enquired.
"Not food or anythin’!" said Weasley eagerly. "He can get his own food, no problem. Birds an’
deer an’ stuff... no, it’s company he needs. If I jus’ knew someone was carryin’ on tryin’ ter help
him a bit... teachin’ him, yeh know."
Ron said nothing, but turned to look back at the gigantic form lying asleep on the ground in
front of them. Unlike Weasley, who simply looked like an oversized human, Ron looked
strangely misshapen. What Ron had taken to be a vast mossy boulder to the left of the great
earthen mound he now recognized as Ron’s head. It was much larger in proportion to the body
than a human head, and was almost perfectly round and covered with tightly curling, close-growing hair the color of bracken. The rim of a single large, fleshy ear was visible on top of the head, which seemed to sit, rather like Uncle Ron’s, directly upon the shoulders with little or no neck in between. The back, under what looked like a dirty brownish smock comprised of animal skins sewn roughly together, was very broad; and as Ron slept, it seemed to strain a
little at the rough seams of the skins. The legs were curled up under the body. Ron could see
the soles of enormous, filthy, bare feet, large as sledges, resting one on top of the other on the
earthy Forest floor.
"You want us to teach him," Ron said in a hollow voice. He now understood what Ron’s
warning had meant. His attempt is not working. He would do better to abandon it. Of course, the
other creatures who lived in the Forest would have heard Weasleys fruitless attempts to teach
Ron English.
"Yeah - even if yeh jus’ talk ter him a bit," said Weasley hopefully. "Cause I reckon, if he can talk
ter people, he’ll understand more that we all like ‘im really, an’ want ‘im ter stay."
Ron looked at Ron, who peered back at him from between the fingers over her face.
"Kind of makes you wish we had Ron back, doesn’t it?" he said, and she gave a very shaky
laugh.
"Yeh’ll do it, then?" said Weasley, who did not seem to have caught what Ron had just said.
"We’ll..." said Ron, already bound by his promise. "We’ll try, Weasley."
"I knew I could count on yeh, Ron," Weasley said, beaming in a very watery way and dabbing at
his face with his handkerchief again. "An’ I don’ want yeh ter put yerself out too much, like... I
know yeh’ve got exams... if yeh could jus’ nip down here in yer Invisibility Cloak maybe once a
week an’ have a little chat with ‘im. I’ll wake ‘im up, then - introduce yeh -"
"Wha-- no!" said Ron, jumping up. "Weasley, no, don’t wake him, really, we don’t need -"
But Weasley had already stepped over the great tree trunk in front of them and was proceeding
towards Ron. When he was about ten feet away, he lifted a long, broken bough from the
ground, smiled reassuringly over his shoulder at Ron and Ron, then poked Ron hard in
the middle of the back with the end of the bough.
The giant gave a roar that echoed around the silent Forest; birds in the treetops overhead rose
twittering from their perches and soared away. In front of Ron and Ron, meanwhile, the
gigantic Ron was rising from the ground, which shuddered as he placed an enormous hand
upon it to push himself on to his knees. He turned his head to see who and what had disturbed
him.
"All righ’, Rony?" said Weasley, in a would-be cheery voice, backing away with the long bough raised, ready to poke Ron again. "Had a nice sleep, eh?"
Ron and Ron retreated as far as they could while still keeping the giant within their
sights. Ron knelt between two trees he had not yet uprooted. They looked up into his
startlingly huge face that resembled a grey full moon swimming in the gloom of the clearing. It
was as though the features had been hewn on to a great stone ball. The nose was stubby and
shapeless, the mouth lopsided and full of misshapen yellow teeth the size of half-bricks; the eyes,
small by giant standards, were a muddy greenish-brown and just now were half-gummed
together with sleep. Ron raised dirty knuckles, each as big as a cricket ball, to his eyes, rubbed
vigorously, then, without warning, pushed himself to his feet with surprising speed and agility.
"Oh my!" Ron heard Ron squeal, terrified, beside him.
The trees to which the other ends of the ropes around Ron’s wrists and ankles were attached
creaked ominously. He was, as Weasley had said, at least sixteen feet tall. Gazing blearily around,
Ron reached out a hand the size of a beach umbrella, seized a bird’s nest from the upper
branches of a towering pine and turned it upside-down with a roar of apparent displeasure that
there was no bird in it; eggs fell like grenades towards the ground and Weasley threw his arms
over his head to protect himself.
"Anyway, Rony," shouted Weasley, looking up apprehensively in case of further falling eggs,
"I’ve brought some friends ter meet yeh. Remember, I told yeh I might? Remember, when I said
I might have ter go on a little trip an’ leave them ter look after yeh fer a bit? Remember that,
Rony?"
But Ron merely gave another low roar; it was hard to say whether he was listening to Weasley
or whether he even recognized the sounds Weasley was making as speech. He had now seized the
top of the pine tree and was pulling it towards him, evidently for the simple pleasure of seeing
how far it would spring back when he let go.
"Now, Rony, don’ do that!" shouted Weasley. "Tha’s how you ended up pullin’ up the others -"
And sure enough, Ron could see the earth around the tree’s roots beginning to crack.
"I got company for yeh!" Weasley shouted. "Company, see! Look down, yeh big buffoon, I
brought yeh some friends!"
"Oh, Weasley, don’t," moaned Ron, but Weasley had already raised the bough again and gave
Ron’s knee a sharp poke.
The giant let go of the top of the tree, which swayed alarmingly and deluged Weasley with a rain
of pine needles, and looked down.
"This," said Weasley, hastening over to where Ron and Ron stood, "is Ron, Ron! Ron Weasley! He migh’ be comin’ ter visit yeh if I have ter go away, understand?"
The giant had only just realized that Ron and Ron were there. They watched, in great
trepidation, as he lowered his huge boulder of a head so that he could peer blearily at them.
"An’ this is Ron, see? Her--" Weasley hesitated. Turning to Ron, he said, "Would yeh
mind if he called yeh Hermy, Ron? On’y it’s a difficult name fer him ter remember."
"No, not at all," squeaked Ron.
"This is Hermy, Ron! An’ she’s gonna be comin’ an’ all! Is’n’ tha’ nice? Eh? Two friends fer
yeh ter - RonY, NO!"
Ron’s hand had shot out of nowhere towards Ron; Ron seized her and pulled her
backwards behind the tree, so that Ron’s fist scraped the trunk but closed on thin air.
"BAD BOY, RonY!" they heard Weasley yelling, as Ron clung to Ron behind the tree, shaking and whimpering. "VERY BAD BOY! YEH DON’ GRAB - OUCH!"
Ron poked his head out from around the trunk and saw Weasley lying on his back, his hand over
his nose. Ron, apparently losing interest, had straightened up and was again engaged in
pulling back the pine as far as it would go.
"Righ’," said Weasley thickly, getting up with one hand pinching his bleeding nose and the other
grasping his crossbow, "well... there yeh are... yeh’ve met him an’ - an’ now he’ll know yeh
when yeh come back. Yeah... well..."
He looked up at Ron, who was now pulling back the pine with an expression of detached
pleasure on his boulderish face; the roots were creaking as he ripped them away from the ground.
"Well, I reckon tha’s enough fer one day," said Weasley. "We’ll -er - we’ll go back now, shall we?"
Ron and Ron nodded. Weasley shouldered his crossbow again and, still pinching his nose,
led the way back into the trees.
Nobody spoke for a while, not even when they heard the distant crash that meant Ron had
pulled over the pine tree at last. Ron’s face was pale and set. Ron could not think of a
single thing to say. What on earth was going to happen when somebody found out that Weasley
had hidden Ron in the Forbidden Forest? And he had promised that he, Ron and Ron
would continue Weasley’s totally pointless attempts to civilize the giant. How could Weasley, even
with his immense capacity to delude himself that fanged monsters were loveably harmless, fool
himself that Ron would ever be fit to mix with humans?
"Hold it," said Weasley abruptly, just as Ron and Ron were struggling through a patch of
thick knotgrass behind him. He pulled an arrow out of the quiver over his shoulder and fitted it
into the crossbow. Ron and Ron raised their wands; now that they had stopped walking,
they, too, could hear movement close by.
"Oh, blimey" said Weasley quietly.
"I thought we told you, Weasley," said a deep male voice, "that you are no longer welcome here?"
A man’s naked torso seemed for an instant to be floating towards them through the dappled
green half-light; then they saw that his waist joined smoothly into a horse’s chestnut body. This
centaur had a proud, high-cheekboned face and long black hair. Like Weasley, he was armed; a
quiverful of arrows and a longbow were slung over his shoulders.
"How are yeh, Ron?" said Weasley warily.
The trees behind the centaur rustled and four or five more centaurs emerged behind him. Ron
recognized the black-bodied and bearded Ron, whom he had met nearly four years ago on the
same night he had met Ron. Ron gave no sign that he had ever seen Ron before.
"So," he said, with a nasty inflection in his voice, before turning immediately to Ron. "We
agreed, I think, what we would do if this human ever showed his face in the Forest again?"
"‘This human’ now, am I?" said Weasley testily. "Jus ‘ fer stoppin’ all of yeh committin’ murder?"
"You ought not to have meddled, Weasley," said Ron. "Our ways are not yours, nor are our
laws. Ron has betrayed and dishonored us."
"I dunno how yeh’work that out," said Weasley impatiently. "He’s done nothin’ except help Ron Weasley -"
"Ron has entered into servitude to humans," said a grey centaur with a hard, deeply lined face.
"Servitude!" said Weasley scathingly. "He’s doin’ Weasley a favor is all -"
"He is peddling our knowledge and secrets among humans," said Ron quietly. "There can be no return from such disgrace."
"If yeh say so," said Weasley, shrugging, "but personally I think yeh’re makin’ a big mistake -"
"As are you, human," said Ron, "coming back into our Forest when we warned you -"
"Now, yeh listen ter me," said Weasley angrily. "I’ll have less of the ‘our’ Forest, if it’s all the
same ter yeh. It’s not up ter yeh who comes an’ goes in here -"
"No more is it up to you, Weasley," said Ron smoothly. "I shall let you pass today because
you are accompanied by your young --"
"They’re not his!" interrupted Ron contemptuously. "Students, Ron, from up at the school! They have probably already profited from the traitor Ron’s teachings."
"Nevertheless," said Ron calmly, "the slaughter of foals is a terrible crime - we do not touch the innocent. Today, Weasley, you pass. Henceforth, stay away from this place. You forfeited the friendship of the centaurs when you helped the traitor Ron escape us."
"I won’ be kept outta the Fores’ by a bunch o’ old mules like yeh!" said Weasley loudly.
"Weasley," said Ron in a high-pitched and terrified voice, as both Ron and the grey centaur
pawed at the ground, "let’s go, please let’s go!"
Weasley moved forwards, but his crossbow was still raised and his eyes were still fixed
threateningly upon Ron.
"We know what you are keeping in the Forest, Weasley!" Ron called after them, as the
centaurs slipped out of sight. "And our tolerance is waning!"
Weasley turned and gave every appearance of wanting to walk straight back to Ron.
"Yeh’ll tolerate ‘im as long as he’s here, it’s as much his Forest as yours!" he yelled, as Ron
and Ron both pushed with all their might against Weasley’s moleskin waistcoat in an effort
to keep him moving forwards. Still scowling, he looked down; his expression changed to mild
surprise at the sight of them both pushing him; he seemed not to have felt it.
"Calm down, you two," he said, turning to walk on while they panted along behind him. "Ruddy
old mules, though, eh?"
"Weasley," said Ron breathlessly, skirting the patch of nettles they had passed on their way
there, "if the centaurs don’t want humans in the Forest, it doesn’t really look as though Ron and
I will be able -"
"Ah, you heard what they said," said Weasley dismissively, "they wouldn’t hurt foals - I mean,
kids. Anyway, we can’ let ourselves be pushed aroun’ by that lot."
"Nice try," Ron murmured to Ron, who looked crestfallen.
At last they rejoined the path and, after another ten minutes, the trees began to thin; they were
able to see patches of clear blue sky again and, in the distance, the definite sounds of cheering
and shouting.
"Was that another goal?" asked Weasley, pausing in the shelter of the trees as the Quidditch
stadium came into view. "Or d’yeh reckon the match is over?"
"I don’t know," said Ron miserably. Ron saw that she looked much the worse for wear;
her hair was full of twigs and leaves, her robes were ripped in several places and there were
numerous scratches on her face and arms. He knew he must look little better.
"I reckon it’s over, yeh know!" said Weasley, still squinting towards the stadium. "Look - there’s
people comin’ out already - if yeh two hurry yeh’ll be able ter blend in with the crowd an’ no
one’ll know yeh weren’t there!"
"Good idea," said Ron. "Well... see you later, then, Weasley."
"I don’t believe him," said Ron in a very unsteady voice, the moment they were out of
earshot of Weasley. "I don’t believe him. I really don’t believe him."
"Calm down," said Ron.
"Calm down!" she said feverishly. "A giant! A giant in the Forest! And we’re supposed to give
him English lessons! Always assuming, of course, we can get past the herd of murderous
centaurs on the way in and out! I - don’t -believe - him!"
"We haven’t got to do anything yet!" Ron tried to reassure her in a quiet voice, as they joined a
stream of jabbering Weasleys heading back towards the castle. "He’s not asking us to do
anything unless he gets chucked out and that might not even happen."
"Oh, come off it, Ron!" said Ron angrily, stopping dead in her tracks so that the people
behind had to swerve to avoid her. "Of course he’s going to be chucked out and, to be perfectly
honest, after what we’ve just seen, who can blame Weasley?"
There was a pause in which Ron glared at her, and her eyes filled slowly with tears.
"You didn’t mean that," said Ron quietly.
"No... well... all right... I didn’t," she said, wiping her eyes angrily. "But why does he have to
make life so difficult for himself - for us?’
"I dunno -"
"Weasley is our King, Weasley is our King, He didn’t let the Quaffle in, Weasley is our King..."
"And I wish they’d stop singing that stupid song," said Ron miserably, "haven’t they
gloated enough?"
A great tide of students was moving up the sloping lawns from the pitch.
"Oh, let’s get in before we have to meet the Weasleys," said Ron.
"Weasley can save anything, He never leaves a single ring, That’s why Weasleys all sing,
Weasley is our King."
"Ron..." said Ron slowly.
The song was growing louder, but it was issuing not from a crowd of green-and-silver-clad
Weasleys, but from a mass of red and gold moving slowly towards the castle, bearing a solitary
figure upon its many shoulders.
"Weasley is our King, Weasley is our King, He didn’t let the Quaffle in, Weasley is our King..."
"No?" said Ron in a hushed voice.
"YES!" said Ron loudly.
"Ron! Ron!" yelled Ron, waving the silver Quidditch cup in the air and looking
quite beside himself. "WE DID IT! WE WON!"
They beamed up at him as he passed. There was a scrum at the door of the castle and Ron’s head
got rather badly bumped on the lintel, but nobody seemed to want to put him down. Still singing,
the crowd squeezed itself into the Entrance Hall and out of sight. Ron and Ron watched
them go, beaming, until the last echoing strains of ‘Weasley is our King’ died away. Then they
turned to each other, their smiles fading.
"We’ll save our news till tomorrow, shall we?" said Ron.
"Yes, all right," said Ron wearily. "I’m not in any hurry."
They climbed the steps together. At the front doors both instinctively looked back at the
Forbidden Forest. Ron was not sure whether or not it was his imagination, but he rather thought
he saw a small cloud of birds erupting into the air over the tree tops in the distance, almost as
though the tree in which they had been nesting had just been pulled up by the roots.
CHAPTER THIRTY-ONE
O.W.L.s
Ron’s euphoria at helping Weasley scrape the Quidditch cup was such that he couldn’t settle to
anything next day. All he wanted to do was talk over the match, so Ron and Ron found it
very difficult to find an opening in which to mention Ron. Not that either of them tried very
hard; neither was keen to be the one to bring Ron back to reality in quite such a brutal fashion.
As it was another fine, warm day, they persuaded him to join them in revising under the beech
tree at the edge of the lake, where they had less chance of being overheard than in the common
room. Ron was not particularly keen on this idea at first - he was thoroughly enjoying being
patted on the back by every Weasley who walked past his chair, not to mention the occasional
outbursts of ‘Weasley is our King’ - but after a while he agreed that some fresh air might do him
good.
They spread their books out in the shade of the beech tree and sat down while Ron talked them
through his first save of the match for what felt like the dozenth time.
"Well, I mean, I’d already let in that one of Weasley’s, so I wasn’t feeling all that confident, but I
dunno, when Bradley came towards me, just out of nowhere, I thought - you can do this! And I
had about a second to decide which way to fly, you know, because he looked like he was aiming
for the right goalhoop - my right, obviously, his left - but I had a funny feeling that he was
feinting, and so I took the chance and flew left - his right, I mean - and - well - you saw what
happened," he concluded modestly, sweeping his hair back quite unnecessarily so that it looked
interestingly windswept and glancing around to see whether the people nearest to them -- a
bunch of gossiping third-year Weasleys -- had heard him. "And then, when Chambers came at
me about five minutes later - What?" Ron asked, having stopped mid-sentence at the look on
Ron’s face. "Why are you grinning?"
"I’m not," said Ron quickly, and looked down at his Transfiguration notes, attempting to
straighten his face. The truth was that Ron had just reminded Ron forcibly of another
Weasley Quidditch player who had once sat rumpling his hair under this very tree. "I’m just
glad we won, that’s all."
"Yeah," said Ron slowly, savoring the words, "we won. Did you see the look on Weasleys face
when Ron got the Snitch right out from under her nose?"
"I suppose she cried, did she?" said Ron bitterly.
"Well, yeah - more out of temper than anything, though..." Ron frowned slightly. "But you saw
her chuck her broom away when she got back to the ground, didn’t you?"
"Er -" said Ron.
"Well, actually... no, Ron," said Ron with a heavy sigh, putting down her book and looking at him apologetically. "As a matter of fact, the only bit of the match Ron and I saw was
Weasley’s first goal."
Ron’s carefully ruffled hair seemed to wilt with disappointment. "You didn’t watch?" he said
faintly, looking from one to the other. "You didn’t see me make any of those saves?"
"Well - no," said Ron, stretching out a placatory hand towards him. "But Ron, we didn’t
want to leave -- we had to!"
"Yeah?" said Ron, whose face was growing rather red. "How come?"
"It was Weasley," said Ron. "He decided to tell us why he’s been covered in injuries ever since
he got back from the giants. He wanted us to go into the Forest with him, we had no choice, you
know how he gets. Anyway..."
The story was told in five minutes, by the end of which Ron’s indignation had been replaced by a
look of total incredulity.
"He brought one back and hid it in the Forest?"
"Yep," said Ron grimly.
"No," said Ron, as though by saying this he could make it untrue. "No, he can’t have."
"Well, he has," said Ron firmly. "Ron’s about sixteen feet tall, enjoys ripping up twenty-foot pine trees, and knows me," she snorted, "as Hermy."
Ron gave a nervous laugh.
"And Weasley wants us to...?"
"Teach him English, yeah," said Ron.
"He’s lost his mind," said Ron in an almost awed voice.
"Yes," said Ron irritably, turning a page of Intermediate Transfiguration and glaring at a
series of diagrams showing an owl turning into a pair of opera glasses. "Yes, I’m starting to think
he has. But, unfortunately, he made Ron and me promise."
"Well, you’re just going to have to break your promise, that’s all," said Ron firmly. "I mean,
come on... we’ve got exams and we’re about that far -" he held up his hand to show thumb and
forefinger almost touching "- from being chucked out as it is. And anyway... remember Ron?
Remember Ron? Have we ever come off better for mixing with any of Weasley’s monster
mates?"
"I know, it’s just that - we promised," said Ron in a small voice.
Ron smoothed his hair flat again, looking preoccupied.
"Well," he sighed, "Weasley hasn’t been sacked yet, has he? He’s hung on this long, maybe he’ll
hang on till the end of term and we won’t have to go near Ron at all."
The castle grounds were gleaming in the sunlight as though freshly painted; the cloudless sky
smiled at itself in the smoothly sparkling lake; the satin green lawns rippled occasionally in a
gentle breeze. June had arrived, but to the fifth-years this meant only one thing: their OWLs were
upon them at last.
Their teachers were no longer setting them homework; lessons were devoted to revising those
topics the teachers thought most likely to come up in the exams. The purposeful, feverish
atmosphere drove nearly everything but the OWLs from Ron’s mind, though he did wonder
occasionally during Potions lessons whether Weasley had ever told Weasley that he must continue
giving Ron Occlumency tuition. If he had, then Weasley had ignored Weasley as thoroughly as he
was now ignoring Ron. This suited Ron very well; he was quite busy and tense enough
without extra classes with Weasley, and to his relief Ron was much too preoccupied these
days to badger him about Occlumency; she was spending a lot of time muttering to herself, and
had not laid out any elf clothes for days.
She was not the only person acting oddly as the OWLs drew steadily nearer. Ron Weasley
had developed an irritating habit of interrogating people about their study habits.
"How many hours d’you think you’re doing a day?" he demanded of Ron and Ron as they
queued outside Herbology, a manic gleam in his eyes.
"I dunno," said Ron. "A few."
"More or less than eight?"
"Less, I s’pose," said Ron, looking slightly alarmed.
"I’m doing eight," said Ron, puffing out his chest. "Eight or nine. I’m getting an hour in before
breakfast every day. Eights my average. I can do ten on a good weekend day. I did nine and a
half on Monday. Not so good on Tuesday - only seven and a quarter. Then on Wednesday -"
Ron was deeply thankful that Professor Weasley ushered them into greenhouse three at that
point, forcing Ron to abandon his recital.
Meanwhile, Ron Weasley had found a different way to induce panic.
"Of course, it’s not what you know," he was heard to tell Weasley and Weasley loudly outside
Potions a few days before the exams were to start, "it’s who you know. Now, Ronher’s been
friendly with the head of the Wizarding Examinations Authority for years -- old Ron
Weasley - we’ve had her round for dinner and everything..."
"Do you think that’s true?" Ron whispered in alarm to Ron and Ron.
"Nothing we can do about it if it is," said Ron gloomily.
"I don’t think it’s true," said Ron quietly from behind them. "Because Ron Weasley is
a friend of my gran’s, and she’s never mentioned the Weasleys."
"What’s she like, Ron?" asked Ron at once. "Is she strict?"
"Bit like Gran, really," said Ron in a subdued voice.
"Knowing her won’t hurt your chances, though, will it?" Ron told him encouragingly.
"Oh, I don’t think it will make any difference," said Ron, still more miserably. "Grans always
telling Professor Weasley I’m not as good as my dad... well... you saw what she’s like at St
Mungo’s" Ron looked fixedly at the floor. Ron, Ron and Ron glanced at each other, but didn’t know what to say. It was the first time Ron had acknowledged that they had met at the wizarding hospital.
Meanwhile, a flourishing black-market trade in aids to concentration, mental agility and
wakefulness had sprung up among the fifth- and seventh-years. Ron and Ron were much
tempted by the bottle of Baruffio’s Brain Elixir offered to them by Weasley sixth-year Eddie
Carmichael, who swore it was solely responsible for the nine ‘Outstanding’ OWLs he had gained
the previous summer and was offering a whole pint for a mere twelve Galleons. Ron assured
Ron he would reimburse him for his half the moment he left Hogwarts and got a job, but before
they could close the deal, Ron had confiscated the bottle from Carmichael and poured the
contents down a toilet.
"Ron, we wanted to buy that!" shouted Ron.
"Don’t be stupid," she snarled. "You might as well take Harold Dingle’s powdered dragon claw
and have done with it."
"Dingle’s got powdered dragon claw?" said Ron eagerly.
"Not any more," said Ron. "I confiscated that, too. None of these things actually work, you
know."
"Dragon claw does work!" said Ron. "It’s supposed to be incredible, really gives your brain a
boost, you come over all cunning for a few hours - Ron, let me have a pinch, go on, it can’t
hurt -"
"This stuff can," said Ron grimly. "I’ve had a look at it, and it’s actually dried Doxy
droppings."
This information took the edge off Ron and Rons desire for brain stimulants.
They received their examination timetables and details of the procedure for OWLs during their
next Transfiguration lesson.
"As you can see," Professor Weasley told the class as they copied down the dates and times
of their exams from the blackboard, "your OWLs are spread over two successive weeks. You
will sit the theory exams in the mornings and the practice in the afternoons. Your practical
Astronomy examination will, of course, take place at night.
"Now, I must warn you that the most stringent anti-cheating charms have been applied to your
examination papers. Auto-Answer Quills are banned from the examination hall, as are
Remembralls, Detachable Cribbing Cuffs and Self-Correcting Ink. Every year, I am afraid to say,
seems to harbor at least one student who thinks that he or she can get around the Wizarding
Examinations Authority’s rules. I can only hope that it is nobody in Weasley. Our new -
Headmistress --" Professor Weasley pronounced the word with the same look on her face
that Aunt Ron had whenever she was contemplating a particularly stubborn bit of dirt "- has
asked the Heads of House to tell their students that cheating will be punished most severely -
because, of course, your examination results will reflect upon the Headmistress’s new regime at
the school -"
Professor Weasley gave a tiny sigh; Ron saw the nostrils of her sharp nose flare.
"- however, that is no reason not to do your very best. You have your own futures to think about."
"Please, Professor," said Ron, her hand in the air, "when will we find out our results?"
"An owl will be sent to you some time in July" said Professor Weasley.
"Excellent," said Ron Ron in an audible whisper, "so we don’t have to worry about it till the holidays."
Ron imagined sitting in his bedroom in Privet Drive in six weeks’ time, waiting for his OWL
results. Well, he thought dully, at least he would be sure of one bit of post next summer.
Their first examination, Theory of Charms, was scheduled for Monday morning. Ron agreed to
test Ron after lunch on Sunday, but regretted it almost at once; she was very agitated and
kept snatching the book back from him to check that she had got the answer completely right,
finally hitting him hard on the nose with the sharp edge of Achievements in Charming.
"Why don’t you just do it yourself?" he said firmly, handing the book back to her, his eyes
watering.
Meanwhile, Ron was reading two years’ worth of Charms notes with his fingers in his ears, his
lips moving soundlessly; Ron Weasley was lying flat on his back on the floor, reciting the
definition of a Substantive Charm while Ron checked it against The Rondard Book of Spells,
Grade 5; and Ron and Ron, who were practicing basic Locomotion Charms, were
making their pencil-cases race each other around the edge of the table.
Dinner was a subdued affair that night. Ron and Ron did not talk much, but ate with gusto,
having studied hard all day. Ron, on the other hand, kept putting down her knife and fork
and diving under the table for her bag, from which she would seize a book to check some fact or
figure. Ron was just telling her that she ought to eat a decent meal or she would not sleep that
night, when her fork slid from her limp fingers and landed with a loud tinkle on her plate.
"Oh, my goodness," she said faintly, staring into the Entrance Hall. "Is that them? Is that the
examiners?"
Ron and Ron whipped around on their bench. Through the doors to the Great Hall they could
see Weasley standing with a small group of ancient-looking witches and wizards. Weasley,
Ron was pleased to see, looked rather nervous.
"Shall we go and have a closer look?" said Ron.
Ron and Ron nodded and they hastened towards the double doors into the Entrance Hall,
slowing down as they stepped over the threshold to walk sedately past the examiners. Ron
thought Professor Weasley must be the tiny, stooped witch with a face so lined it looked as
though it had been draped in cobwebs; Weasley was speaking to her deferentially. Professor
