Weasley seemed to be a little deaf; she was answering Professor Weasley very loudly
considering they were only a foot apart.
"Journey was fine, journey was fine, we’ve made it plenty of times before!" she said impatiently. "Now, I haven’t heard from Weasley lately!" she added, peering around the Hall as though
hopeful he might suddenly emerge from a broom cupboard. "No idea where he is, I suppose?"
"None at all," said Weasley, shooting a malevolent look at Ron, Ron and Ron, who were now dawdling around the foot of the stairs as Ron pretended to do up his shoelace. "But I daresay the Ministry of Magic will track him down soon enough."
"I doubt it," shouted tiny Professor Weasley, "not if Weasley doesn’t want to be found! I
should know... examined him personally in Transfiguration and Charms when he did Rons...
did things with a wand I’d never seen before."
"Yes... well..." said Professor Weasley as Ron, Ron and Ron dragged their feet up the
marble staircase as slowly as they dared, "let me show you to the staff room. I daresay you’d like a cup of tea after your journey."
It was an uncomfortable sort of an evening. Everyone was trying to do some last-minute revising
but nobody seemed to be getting very far. Ron went to bed early but then lay awake for what
felt like hours. He remembered his careers consultation and Weasley’s furious declaration
that she would help him become an Auror if it was the last thing she did. He wished he had
expressed a more achievable ambition now that exam time was here. He knew he was not the
only one lying awake, but none of the others in the dormitory spoke and finally, one by one, they
fell asleep.
None of the fifth-years talked very much at breakfast next day, either: Ron was practicing
incantations under her breath while the salt cellar in front of her twitched; Ron was
rereading Achievements in Charming so fast that her eyes appeared blurred; and Ron kept
dropping his knife and fork and knocking over the marmalade.
Once breakfast was over, the fifth- and seventh-years milled around in the Entrance Hall while
the other students went off to lessons; then, at half past nine, they were called forwards class by
class to re-enter the Great Hall, which had been rearranged exactly as Ron had seen it in the
Pensieve when his father, Ron and Weasley had been taking their OWLs; the four house tables
had been removed and replaced instead with many tables for one, all facing the staff-table end of
the Hall where Professor Weasley stood facing them. When they were all seated and quiet,
she said, "You may begin," and turned over an enormous hour-glass on the desk beside her, on
which there were also spare quills, ink bottles and rolls of parchment.
Ron turned over his paper, his heart thumping hard - three rows to his right and four seats
ahead Ron was already scribbling - and lowered his eyes to the first question: a) Give the
incantation and b) describe the wand movement required to make objects fly.
Ron had a fleeting memory of a club soaring high into the air and landing loudly on the thick
skull of a troll... smiling slightly, he bent over the paper and began to write.
"Well, it wasn’t too bad, was it?" asked Ron anxiously in the Entrance Hall two hours later, still clutching the exam paper. "I’m not sure I did myself justice on Cheering Charms, I just ran out of time. Did you put in the counter-charm for hiccoughs? I wasn’t, sure whether I ought to, it felt like too much - and on question twenty-three -"
"Ron," said Ron sternly, "we’ve been through this before... we’re not going through every
exam afterwards, it’s bad enough doing them once."
The fifth-years ate lunch with the rest of the school (the four house tables had reappeared for the
lunch hour), then they trooped off into the small chamber beside the Great Hall, where they were
to wait until called for their practical examination. As small groups of students were called
forwards in alphabetical order, those left behind muttered incantations and practiced wand
movements, occasionally poking each other in the back or eye by mistake.
Ron’s name was called. Trembling, she left the chamber with Ron Weasley, Ron
Weasley and Daphne Greengrass. Students who had already been tested did not return afterwards,
so Ron and Ron had no idea how Ron had done.
"She’ll be fine, remember she got a hundred and twelve percent on one of our Charms tests?"
said Ron.
Ten minutes later, Professor Weasley called, "Weasley, Ron - Weasley, Ron - Weasley, Ron -
Weasley, Ron."
"Good luck," said Ron quietly. Ron walked into the Great Hall, clutching his wand so tightly
his hand shook.
"Professor Tofty is free, Weasley," squeaked Professor Weasley, who was standing just inside the
door. He pointed Ron towards what looked like the very oldest and baldest examiner who was
sitting behind a small table in a far corner, a short distance from Professor Weasley, who was
halfway through testing Ron Weasley.
"Weasley, is it?" said Professor Tofty, consulting his notes and peering over his pince-nez at Ron
as he approached. "The famous Weasley?"
Out of the corner of his eye, Ron distinctly saw Weasley throw a scathing look over at him; the
wine-glass Weasley had been levitating fell to the floor and smashed. Ron could not suppress a
grin; Professor Tofty smiled back at him encouragingly.
"That’s it," he said in his quavery old voice, "no need to be nervous. Now, if I could ask you to
take this egg cup and make it do some cartwheels for me."
On the whole, Ron thought it went rather well. His Levitation Charm was certainly much better
than Weasley’s had been, though he wished he had not mixed up the incantations for Color
Weasleye and Growth Charms, so that the rat he was supposed to be turning orange swelled
shockingly and was the size of a badger before Ron could rectify his mistake. He was glad
Ron had not been in the Hall at the time and neglected to mention it to her afterwards. He
could tell Ron, though; Ron had caused a dinner plate to mutate into a large mushroom and had
no idea how it had happened.
There was no time to relax that night; they went straight to the common room after dinner and
submerged themselves in revision for Transfiguration next day; Ron went to bed with his head
buzzing with complex spell models and theories.
He forgot the definition of a Switching Spell during his written paper next morning but thought
his practical could have been a lot worse. At least he managed to Vanish the whole of his iguana,
whereas poor Ron Weasley lost her head completely at the next table and somehow managed
to multiply her ferret into a flock of flamingos, causing the examination to be halted for ten
minutes while the birds were captured and carried out of the Hall.
They had their Herbology exam on Wednesday (other than a small bite from a Roned Geranium,
Ron felt he had done reasonably well); and then, on Thursday, Defense Against the Dark Arts.
Here, for the first time, Ron felt sure he had passed. He had no problem with any of the written
questions and took particular pleasure, during the practical examination, in performing all the
counter-jinxes and defensive spells right in front of Weasley, who was watching coolly from
near the doors into the Entrance Hall.
"Oh, bravo!" cried Professor Tofty, who was examining Ron again, when Ron demonstrated a perfect Boggart banishing spell. "Very good indeed! Well, I think that’s all, Weasley... unless..."
He leaned forwards a little.
"I heard, from my dear friend Tiberius Weasley, that you can produce a Patronus? For a bonus
point...?"
Ron raised his wand, looked directly at Weasley and imagined her being sacked.
"Expecto patronum!"
His silver stag erupted from the end of his wand and cantered the length of the Hall. All of the
examiners looked around to watch its progress and when it dissolved into silver mist Professor
Tofty clapped his veined and knotted hands enthusiastically.
"Excellent!" he said. "Very well, Weasley, you may go!"
As Ron passed Weasley beside the door, their eyes met. There was a nasty smile playing
around her wide, slack mouth, but he did not care. Unless he was very much mistaken (and he
was not planning on telling anybody, in case he was), he had just achieved an ‘Outstanding’
OWL.
On Friday, Ron and Ron had a day off while Ron sat her Ancient Runes exam, and as
they had the whole weekend in front of them they permitted themselves a break from revision.
They stretched and yawned beside the open window, through which warm summer air was
wafting as they played wizard chess. Ron could see Weasley in the distance, teaching a class on
the edge of the Forest. He was trying to guess what creatures they were examining - he thought it
must be unicorns, because the boys seemed to be standing back a little - when the portrait hole
opened and Ron clambered in, looking thoroughly bad-tempered.
"How were the Runes?" said Ron, yawning and stretching.
"I mistranslated ehwaz," said Ron furiously. "It means partnership, not Defense; I mixed it
up with eihwaz."
"Ah well," said Ron lazily, "that’s only one mistake, isn’t it, you’ll still get -"
"Oh, shut up!" said Ron angrily. "It could be the one mistake that makes the difference
between a pass and a fail. And what’s more, someone’s put another Niffler in Weasley’s office.
I don’t know how they got it through that new door, but I just walked past there and Weasley is
shrieking her head off - by the sound of it, it tried to take a chunk out of her leg -"
"Good," said Ron and Ron together.
"It is not good!" said Ron hotly. "She thinks it’s Weasley doing it, remember? And we do not want Weasley chucked out!"
"He’s teaching at the moment; she can’t blame him," said Ron, gesturing out of the window.
"Oh, you’re so naive sometimes, Ron.You really think Weasley will wait for proof?" said
Ron, who seemed determined to be in a towering temper, and she swept off towards the
girls’ dormitories, banging the door behind her.
"Such a lovely, sweet-tempered girl," said Ron, very quietly, prodding his queen forward to beat
up one of Ron’s knights.
Ron’s bad mood persisted for most of the weekend, though Ron and Ron found it quite
easy to ignore as they spent most of Saturday and Sunday revising for Potions on Monday, the
exam which Ron had been looking forward to least - and which he was sure would be the
downfall of his ambitions to become an Auror. Sure enough, he found the written paper difficult,
though he thought he might have got full marks on the question about Polyjuice Potion; he could
describe its effects accurately, having taken it illegally in his second year.
The afternoon practical was not as dreadful as he had expected it to be. With Weasley absent from
the proceedings, he found that he was much more relaxed than he usually was while making
potions. Ron, who was sitting very near Ron, also looked happier than Ron had ever seen
him during a Potions class. When Professor Weasley said, "Step away from your cauldrons,
please, the examination is over," Ron corked his sample flask feeling that he might not have
achieved a good grade but he had, with luck, avoided a fail.
"Only four exams left," said Ron Weasley wearily as they headed back to Weasley common
room.
"Only!" said Ron snappishly. "I’ve got Arithmancy and it’s probably the toughest subject
there is!"
Nobody was foolish enough to snap back, so she was unable to vent her spleen on any of them
and was reduced to telling off some first-years for giggling too loudly in the common room.
Ron was determined to perform well in Tuesdays Care of Magical Creatures exam so as not to
let Weasley down. The practical examination took place in the afternoon on the lawn on the edge
of the Forbidden Forest, where students were required to correctly identify the Knarl hidden
among a dozen hedgehogs (the trick was to offer them all milk in turn: Knarls, highly suspicious
creatures whose quills had many magical properties, generally went berserk at what they saw as
an attempt to poison them); then demonstrate correct handling of a Bowtruckle; feed and clean
out a Fire Crab without sustaining serious burns; and choose, from a wide selection of food, the
diet they would give a sick unicorn.
Ron could see Weasley watching anxiously out of his cabin window. When Ron’s examiner, a
plump little witch this time, smiled at him and told him he could leave, Ron gave Weasley a
fleeting thumbs-up before heading back to the castle.
The Astronomy theory paper on Wednesday morning went well enough. Ron was not
convinced he had got the names of all Jupiter’s moons right, but was at least confident that none
of them was inhabited by mice. They had to wait until evening for their practical Astronomy; the
afternoon was devoted instead to Divination.
Even by Ron’s low standards in Divination, the exam went very badly. He might as well have
tried to see moving pictures on the desktop as in the stubbornly blank crystal ball; he lost his
head completely during tea-leaf reading, saying it looked to him as though Professor Weasley
would shortly be meeting a round, dark, soggy stranger, and rounded off the whole fiasco by
mixing up the life and head lines on her palm and informing her that she ought to have died the
previous Tuesday.
"Well, we were always going to fail that one," said Ron gloomily as they ascended the marble
staircase. He had just made Ron feel rather better by telling him how he had told the examiner
in detail about the ugly man with a wart on his nose in his crystal ball, only to look up and realize
he had been describing his examiner’s reflection.
"We shouldn’t have taken the stupid subject in the first place," said Ron.
"Still, at least we can give it up now."
"Yeah," said Ron. "No more pretending we care what happens when Jupiter and Uranus get too
friendly."
"And from now on, I don’t care if my tea-leaves spell die, Ron, die - I’m just chucking them in
the bin where they belong."
Ron laughed just as Ron came running up behind them. He stopped laughing at once, in
case it annoyed her.
"Well, I think I’ve done all right in Arithmancy" she said, and Ron and Ron both sighed with
relief. "Just time for a quick look over our star-charts before dinner, then..."
When they reached the top of the Astronomy Tower at eleven o’clock, they found a perfect night
for stargazing, cloudless and still. The grounds were bathed in silvery moonlight and there was a
slight chill in the air. Each of them set up his or her telescope and, when Professor Weasley
gave the word, proceeded to fill in the blank star-chart they had been given.
Professors Weasley and Tofty strolled among them, watching as they entered the precise
positions of the stars and planets they were observing. All was quiet except for the rustle of
parchment, the occasional creak of a telescope as it was adjusted on its stand, and the scribbling
of many quills. Half an hour passed, then an hour; the little squares of reflected gold light
flickering on the ground below started to vanish as lights in the castle windows were
extinguished.
As Ron completed the constellation Orion on his chart, however, the front doors of the castle
opened directly below the parapet where he was standing, so that light spilled down the stone
steps a little way across the lawn. Ron glanced down as he made a slight adjustment to the
position of his telescope and saw five or six elongated shadows moving over the brightly lit grass
before the doors swung shut and the lawn became a sea of darkness once more.
Ron put his eye back to his telescope and refocused it, now examining Venus. He looked down
at his chart to enter the planet there, but something distracted him; pausing with his quill
suspended over the parchment, he squinted down into the shadowy grounds and saw half a dozen
figures walking over the lawn. If they had not been moving, and the moonlight had not been
gilding the tops of their heads, they would have been indistinguishable from the dark ground on
which they walked. Even at this distance, Ron had a funny feeling he recognized the walk of
the squattest of them, who seemed to be leading the group.
He could not think why Weasley would be taking a stroll outside after midnight, much less
accompanied by five others. Then somebody coughed behind him, and he remembered that he
was halfway through an exam. He had quite forgotten Venus’s position. Jamming his eye to his
telescope, he found it again and was once more about to enter it on his chart when, alert for any
odd sound, he heard a distant knock which echoed through the deserted grounds, followed
immediately by the muffled barking of a large dog.
He looked up, his heart hammering. There were lights on in Weasley’s windows and the people he
had observed crossing the lawn were now silhouetted against them. The door opened and he
distinctly saw six sharply defined figures walk over the threshold. The door closed again and
there was silence.
Ron felt very uneasy. He glanced around to see whether Ron or Ron had noticed what he
had, but Professor Weasley came walking behind him at that moment and, not wanting to
look as though he was sneaking looks at anyone else’s work, Ron hastily bent over his starchart
and pretended to be adding notes to it while really peering over the top of the parapet
towards Weasley’s cabin. Figures were now moving across the cabin windows, temporarily
blocking the light.
He could feel Professor Weasley’s eyes on the back of his neck and pressed his eye again to
his telescope, staring up at the moon though he had marked its position an hour ago, but as
Professor Weasley moved on he heard a roar from the distant cabin that echoed through the
darkness right to the top of the Astronomy Tower. Several of the people around Ron ducked
out from behind their telescopes and peered instead in the direction of Weasley’s cabin.
Professor Tofty gave another dry little cough.
"Try and concentrate, now, boys and girls," he said softly.
Most people returned to their telescopes. Ron looked to his left. Ron was gazing
transfixed at Weasley’s cabin.
"Ahem - twenty minutes to go," said Professor Tofty.
Ron jumped and returned at once to her star-chart; Ron looked down at his own and
noticed that he had mislabelled Venus as Mars. He bent to correct it.
There was a loud BANG from the grounds. Several people cried ‘Ouch!’ when they poked
themselves in the face with the ends of their telescopes as they hastened to see what was going
on below.
Weasley’s door had burst open and by the light flooding out of the cabin they saw him quite
clearly a massive figure roaring and brandishing his fists, surrounded by six people, all of whom,
judging by the tiny threads of red light they were casting in his direction, seemed to be
attempting to Stun him.
"No!" cried Ron.
"My dear!" said Professor Tofty in a scandalised voice. "This is an examination!"
But nobody was paying the slightest attention to their star-charts any more. Jets of red light were
still flying about beside Weasley’s cabin, yet somehow they seemed to be bouncing off him; he
was still upright and still, as far as Ron could see, fighting. Cries and yells echoed across the
grounds; a man yelled, "Be reasonable, Weasley!"
Weasley roared, "Reasonable be damned, yeh won’ take me like this, Weasley!"
Ron could see the tiny outline of Ron, attempting to defend Weasley, leaping repeatedly at the
wizards surrounding him until a Stunning Spell caught him and he fell to the ground. Weasley
gave a howl of fury, lifted the culprit bodily from the ground and threw him; the man flew what
looked like ten feet and did not get up again. Ron gasped, both hands over her mouth;
Ron looked round at Ron and saw that he, too, was looking scared. None of them had ever seen
Weasley in a real temper before.
"Look!" squealed Ron, who was leaning over the parapet and pointing to the foot of the castle
where the front doors had opened again; more light was spilling out on to the dark lawn and a
single long black shadow was now rippling across the lawn.
"Now, really!" said Professor Tofty anxiously. "Only sixteen minutes left, you know!"
But nobody paid him the slightest attention: they were watching the person now sprinting
towards the battle beside Weasley’s cabin.
"How dare you!" the figure shouted as she ran. "How dare you!"
"It’s Weasley!" whispered Ron.
"Leave him alone! Alone, I say!" said Professor Weasley’s voice through the darkness. "On
what grounds are you attacking him? He has done nothing, nothing to warrant such -"
Ron, Ron and Ron all screamed. No fewer than four Stunners had shot from the figures around the cabin toward Professor Weasley. Halfway between cabin and castle the red beams collided with her; for a moment she looked luminous, illuminated by an eerie red glow, then was lifted right off her feet, landed hard on her back, and moved no more.
"Galloping gargoyles!" shouted Professor Tofty, who seemed to have forgotten the exam
completely. "Not so much as a warning! Outrageous behavior!"
"COWARDS!" bellowed Weasley, his voice carring clearly to the top of the tower, and several
lights flickered back on inside the castle. "RUDDY COWARDS! HAVE SOME O’ THAT - AN’ THAT -"
"Oh my --" gasped Ron.
Weasley took two massive swipes at his closest attackers; judging by their immediate collapse,
they had been knocked cold. Ron saw Weasley double over, and thought he had finally been
overcome by a spell. But, on the contrary, next moment Weasley was standing again with what
appeared to be a sack on his back - then Ron realized that Ron’s limp body was draped around
his shoulders.
"Get him, get him!" screamed Weasley, but her remaining helper seemed highly reluctant to go
within reach of Weasley’s fists; indeed, he was backing away so fast he tripped over one of his
unconscious colleagues and fell over. Weasley had turned and begun to run with Ron still hung
around his neck. Weasley sent one last Stunning Spell after him but it missed; and Weasley,
running full-pelt towards the distant gates, disappeared into the darkness.
There was a long minutes quivering silence as everybody gazed open-mouthed into the grounds.
Then Professor Tofty’s voice said feebly, "Um... five minutes to go, everybody."
Though he had only filled in two-thirds of his chart, Ron was desperate for the exam to end.
When it came at last he, Ron and Ron forced their telescopes haphazardly back into their
holders and dashed back down the spiral staircase. None of the students were going to bed; they
were all talking loudly and excitedly at the foot of the stairs about what they had witnessed.
"That evil woman!" gasped Ron, who seemed to be having difficulty talking due to rage.
"Trying to sneak up on Weasley in the dead of night!"
"She clearly wanted to avoid another scene like Weasley’s," said Ron Weasley sagely,
squeezing over to join them.
"Weasley did well, didn’t he?" said Ron, who looked more alarmed than impressed. "How come all the spells bounced off him?"
"It’ll be his giant blood," said Ron shakily. "Its very hard to Stun a giant, they’re like trolls,
really tough... but poor Professor Weasley... four Stunners straight in the chest and she’s not
exactly young, is she?"
"Dreadful, dreadful," said Ron, shaking his head pompously. "Well, I’m off to bed. Night, all."
People around them were drifting away, still talking excitedly about what they had just seen.
"At least they didn’t get to take Weasley off to Azkaban," said Ron. "I ‘spect he’s gone to join
Weasley, hasn’t he?"
"I suppose so," said Ron, who looked tearful. "Oh, this is awful, I really thought
Weasley would be back before long, but now we’ve lost Weasley too."
They traipsed back to the Weasley common room to find it full. The commotion out in the
grounds had woken several people, who had hastened to rouse their friends. Ron and Ron,
who had arrived ahead of Ron, Ron and Ron, were now telling everyone what they had
seen and heard from the top of the Astronomy Tower.
"But why sack Weasley now?" asked Ron Ronson, shaking her head. "It’s not like
Weasley; he’s been teaching much better than usual this year!"
"Weasley hates part-humans," said Ron bitterly, flopping down into an armchair. "She
was always going to try and get Weasley out."
"And she thought Weasley was putting Nifflers in her office," piped up Ron Weasley.
"Oh, blimey," said Ron Weasley, covering his mouth. "It’s me who’s been putting the Nifflers in
her office. Ron and Ron left me a couple; I’ve been levitating them in through her window."
"She’d have sacked him anyway" said Ron. "He was too close to Weasley."
"That’s true," said Ron, sinking into an armchair beside Ron’s.
"I just hope Professor Weasley’s all right," said Ron tearfully.
"They carried her back up to the castle, we watched through the dormitory window," said Ron
Weasley "She didn’t look very well."
"Ron Weasley will sort her out," said Ron Weasley firmly. "She’s never failed yet."
It was nearly four in the morning before the common room cleared. Ron felt wide awake; the
image of Weasley sprinting away into the dark was haunting him; he was so angry with Weasley
he could not think of a punishment bad enough for her, though Ron’s suggestion of having her
fed to a box of starving Blast-Ended Skrewts had its merits. He fell asleep contemplating hideous
revenges and arose from bed three hours later feeling distinctly unrested.
Their final exam, History of Magic, was not to take place until that afternoon. Ron would very
much have liked to go back to bed after breakfast, but he had been counting on the morning for a
spot of last-minute revision, so instead he sat with his head in his hands by the common-room
window, trying hard not to doze off as he read through some of the notes stacked three-and-a-half feet high that Ron had lent him.
The fifth-years entered the Great Hall at two o’clock and took their places in front of their facedown examination papers. Ron felt exhausted. He just wanted this to be over, so that he could go and sleep; then tomorrow, he and Ron were going to go down to the Quidditch pitch - he was going to have a fly on Rons broom - and savor their freedom from revision.
"Turn over your papers," said Professor Weasley from the front of the Hall, flicking over the
giant hour-glass. "You may begin."
Ron stared fixedly at the first question. It was several seconds before it occurred to him that he
had not taken in a word of it; there was a wasp buzzing distractingly against one of the high
windows. Slowly, tortuously, he at last began to write an answer.
He was finding it very difficult to remember names and kept confusing dates. He simply skipped
question four (In your opinion, did wand legislation contribute to, or lead to better control of,
goblin riots of the eighteenth century?), thinking that he would go back to it if he had time at the
end. He had a stab at question five (How wasthe Statute of Secrecy breached in 1749 and what
measures were introduced to prevent a recurrence?) but had a nagging suspicion that he had
missed several important points; he had a feeling vampires had come into the story somewhere.
He looked ahead for a question he could definitely answer and his eyes alighted upon number
ten: Describe the circumstances that led to the form ation of the International Confederation of
Wizards and explain why the warlocks of Liechtenstein refused to join.
I know this, Ron thought, though his brain felt torpid and slack. He could visualize a heading,
in Ron’s handwriting: The formation of the International Confederation of Wizards... he
had read those notes only this morning.
He began to write, looking up now and again to check the large hour-glass on the desk beside
Professor Weasley. He was sitting right behind Ron Weasley, whose long dark hair fell below
the back of her chair. Once or twice he found himself staring at the tiny golden lights that
glistened in it when she moved her head slightly, and had to give his own head a little shake to
clear it.
... the first Supreme Mugwump of the International Confederation of Wizards was Pierre
Bonaccord, but his appointment was contested by the wizarding community of Liechtenstein,
because -
All around Ron quills were scratching on parchment like scurrying, burrowing rats. The sun
was very hot on the back of his head. What was it that Bonaccord had done to offend the wizards
of Liechtenstein? Ron had a feeling it had something to do with trolls... he gazed blankly at the
back of Ron’s head again. If he could only perform Legilimency and open a window in the
back of her head and see what it was about trolls that had caused the breach between Pierre
Bonaccord and Liechtenstein...
Ron closed his eyes and buried his face in his hands, so that the glowing red of his eyelids grew
dark and cool. Bonaccord had wanted to stop troll-hunting and give the trolls rights... but
Liechtenstein was having problems with a tribe of particularly vicious mountain trolls... that was
it.
He opened his eyes; they stung and watered at the sight of the blazing white parchment. Slowly,
he wrote two lines about the trolls, then read through what he had done so far. It did not seem
very informative or detailed, yet he was sure Ron’s notes on the Confederation had gone on
for pages and pages.
He closed his eyes again, trying to see them, trying to remember... the Confederation had met
for the first time in France, yes, he had written that already...
Goblins had tried to attend and been ousted... he had written that, too...
And nobody from Liechtenstein had wanted to come...
Think, he told himself, his face in his hands, while all around him quills scratched out neverending answers and the sand trickled through the hour-glass at the front...
He was walking along the cool, dark corridor to the Department of Mysteries again, walking
with a firm and purposeful tread, breaking occasionally into a run, determined to reach his
destination at last... the black door swung open for him as usual, and here he was in the circular
room with its many doors...
Straight across the stone floor and through the second door... patches of dancing light on the
walls and floor and that odd mechanical clicking, but no time to explore, he must hurry...
He jogged the last few feet to the third door, which swung open just like the others...
Once again he was in the cathedral-sized room full of shelves and glass spheres... his heart was
beating very fast now... he was going to get there this time... when he reached number ninety-seven he turned left and hurried along the aisle between two rows...
But there was a shape on the floor at the very end, a black shape moving on the floor like a
wounded animal... Ron’s stomach contracted with fear... with excitement...
A voice issued from his own mouth, a high, cold voice empty of any human kindness...
"Take it for me... lift it down, now... I cannot touch it... but you can"
The black shape on the floor shifted a little. Ron saw a long-fingered white hand clutching a
wand rise at the end of his own arm... heard the high, cold voice say "Crucio!"
The man on the floor let out a scream of pain, attempted to stand but fell back, writhing. Ron
was laughing. He raised his wand, the curse lifted and the figure groaned and became motionless.
"Lord Weasley is waiting"
Very slowly, his arms trembling, the man on the ground raised his shoulders a few inches and
lifted his head. His face was bloodstained and gaunt, twisted in pain yet rigid with defiance...
"You’ll have to kill me," whispered Ron.
"Undoubtedly I shall in the end," said the cold voice. "But you will fetch it for me first, Weasley...
you think you have felt pain thus far? Think again... we have hours ahead of us and nobody to
hear you scream..."
But somebody screamed as Weasley lowered his wand again; somebody yelled and fell
sideways off a hot desk on to the cold stone floor; Ron awoke as he hit the ground, still yelling,
his scar on fire, as the Great Hall erupted all around him.
CHAPTER THIRTY-TWO
Out of the Fire
"I’m not going... I don’t need the hospital wing... I don’t want"
He was gibbering as he tried to pull away from Professor Tofty, who was looking at Ron with
much concern after helping him out into the Entrance Hall with the students all around them
staring.
"I’m - I’m fine, sir," Ron stammered, wiping the sweat from his face. "Really... I just fell
asleep... had a nightmare..."
"Pressure of examinations!" said the old wizard sympathetically, patting Ron shakily on the
shoulder. "It happens, young man, it happens! Now, a cooling drink of water, and perhaps you
will be ready to return to the Great Hall? The examination is nearly over, but you may be able to
round off your last answer nicely?"
"Yes," said Ron wildly. "I mean... no... I’ve done - done as much as I can, I think..."
"Very well, very well," said the old wizard gently. "I shall go and collect your examination paper
and I suggest that you go and have a nice lie down."
"I’ll do that," said Ron, nodding vigorously. "Thanks very much."
The second that the old man’s heels disappeared over the threshold into the Great Hall, Ron ran
up the marble staircase, hurtled along the corridors so fast the portraits he passed muttered
reproaches, up more flights of stairs, and finally burst like a hurricane through the double doors
of the hospital wing, causing Ron Weasley - who had been spooning some bright blue liquid
into Weasley’s open mouth - to shriek in alarm.
"Weasley, what do you think you’re doing?"
"I need to see Professor Weasley," gasped Ron, the breath tearing his lungs. "Now... it’s
urgent!"
"She’s not here, Weasley," said Ron Weasley sadly. "She was transferred to St. Mungo’s this
morning. Four Stunning Spells straight to the chest at her age? It’s a wonder they didn’t kill her."
"She’s... gone?" said Ron, shocked.
The bell rang just outside the dormitory and he heard the usual distant rumbling of students
starting to flood out into the corridors above and below him. He remained quite still, looking at
Ron Weasley. Terror was rising inside him.
There was nobody left to tell. Weasley had gone, Weasley had gone, but he had always
expected Professor Weasley to be there, irascible and inflexible, perhaps, but always
dependably, solidly present...
"I don’t wonder you’re shocked, Weasley," said Ron Weasley, with a kind of fierce approval in
her face. "As if one of them could have Stunned Ron Weasley face-on by daylight!
Cowardice, that’s what it was... despicable cowardice... if I wasn’t worried what would happen
to you students without me, I’d resign in protest."
"Yes," said Ron blankly.
He wheeled around and strode blindly from the hospital wing into the teeming corridor where he
stood, buffeted by the crowd, panic expanding inside him like poison gas so that his head swam
and he could not think what to do...
Ron and Ron, said a voice in his head.
He was running again, pushing students out of the way, oblivious to their angry protests. He
sprinted back down two floors and was at the top of the marble staircase when he saw them
hurrying towards him.
"Ron!" said Ron at once, looking very frightened. "What happened? Are you all right?
Are you ill?"
"Where have you been?" demanded Ron.
"Come with me," Ron said quickly. "Come on, I’ve got to tell you something."
He led them along the first-floor corridor, peering through doorways, and at last found an empty
classroom into which he dived, closing the door behind Ron and Ron the moment they
were inside, and leaned against it, facing them.
"Weasley’s got Ron."
"What?"
"How d’you -?"
"Saw it. Just now. When I fell asleep in the exam."
"But - but where? How?" said Ron, whose face was white.
"I dunno how," said Ron. "But I know exactly where. There’s a room in the Department of
Mysteries full of shelves covered in these little glass balls and they’re at the end of row ninety-seven... he’s trying to use Ron to get whatever it is he wants from in there... he’s torturing him... says he’ll end by killing him!"
Ron found his voice was shaking, as were his knees. He moved over to a desk and sat down on
it, trying to master himself.
"How’re we going to get there?" he asked them.
There was a moment’s silence. Then Ron said, "G-get there?"
"Get to the Department of Mysteries, so we can rescue Ron!" Ron said loudly.
"But - Ron..." said Ron weakly.
"What? What?" said Ron.
He could not understand why they were both gaping at him as though he was asking them
something unreasonable.
"Ron," said Ron in a rather frightened voice, "er... how... how did Weasley get into the Ministry of Magic without anybody realizing he was there?"
"How do I know?" bellowed Ron. "The question is how we’re going to get in there!"
"But... Ron, think about this," said Ron, taking a step towards him, "it’s five o’clock in
the afternoon... the Ministry of Magic must be full of workers... how would Weasley and
Ron have got in without being seen? Ron... they’re probably the two most wanted wizards in
the world... you think they could get into a building full of Aurors undetected?"
"I dunno, Weasley used an Invisibility Cloak or something!" Ron shouted. "Anyway, the
Department of Mysteries has always been completely empty whenever I’ve been -"
"You’ve never been there, Ron," said Ron quietly. "You’ve dreamed about the place,
that’s all."
"They’re not normal dreams!" Ron shouted in her face, standing up and taking a step closer to
her in turn. He wanted to shake her. "How d’you explain Ron’s dad then, what was all that about,
how come I knew what had happened to him?"
"He’s got a point," said Ron quietly, looking at Ron.
"But this is just -- just sounds unlikely." said Ron desperately. "Ron, how on earth could Weasley have got hold of Ron when he’s been in Grimmauld Place all the time?"
"Ron might’ve cracked and just wanted some fresh air," said Ron, sounding worried. "He’s
been desperate to get out of that house for ages -"
"But why," Ron persisted, "why on earth would Weasley want to use Ron to get the
weapon, or whatever the thing is?"
"I dunno, there could be loads of reasons!" Ron yelled at her. "Maybe Ron is just someone
Weasley doesn’t care about seeing hurt -"
"You know what, I’ve just thought of something," said Ron in a hushed voice. "Ron’s brother
was a Death Eater, wasn’t he? Maybe he told Ron the secret of how to get the weapon!"
"Yeah - and that’s why Weasley’s been so keen to keep Ron locked up all the time!" said
Ron.
"Look, I’m sorry," cried Ron, "but neither of you is making sense, and we’ve got no proof
for any of this, no proof Weasley and Ron are even there -"
"Ron, Rons seen them!" said Ron, rounding on her.
"Okay," she said, looking frightened yet determined, "I’ve just got to say this -"
"What?"
"You... this isn’t a criticism, Ron! But you do... sort of... I mean - don’t you think you’ve got
a bit of a - a -saving-people thing!" she said.
He glared at her.
"And what’s that supposed to mean, ‘a -saving-people thing’?"
"Well... you..." she looked more apprehensive than ever. "I mean... last year, for instance... in
the lake... during the Tournament... you shouldn’t have... I mean, you didn’t need to save that
little Weasley girl... you got a bit... carried away..."
A wave of hot, prickly anger swept through Rons body; how could she remind him of that
blunder now?
"I mean, it was really great of you and everything," said Ron quickly, looking positively
petrified at the look on Rons face, "everyone thought it was a wonderful thing to do -"
"That’s funny," said Ron through gritted teeth, "because I definitely remember Ron saying I’d
wasted time acting the hero... is that what you think this is? You reckon I want to act the hero
again?"
"No, no, no!" said Ron, looking aghast. "That’s not what I mean at all!"
"Well, spit out what you’ve got to say, because we’re wasting time here!" Ron shouted.
"I’m trying to say - Weasley knows you, Ron! He took Ron down into the Chamber of
Secrets to lure you there, it’s the kind of thing he does, he knows you’re the - the sort of person
who’d go to Ron’s aid! What if he’s just trying to get you into the Department of Myst--?"
"Ron, it doesn’t matter if he’s done it to get me there or not - they’ve taken Weasley to
St. Mungo’s, there isn’t anyone from the Order left at Hogwarts who we can tell, and if we don’t
go, Ron is dead!"
"But Ron - what if your dream was - was just that, a dream?"
Ron let out a roar of frustration. Ron actually stepped back from him, looking alarmed.
"You don’t get it!" Ron shouted at her, "I’m not having nightmares, I’m not just dreaming!
What d’you think all the Occlumency was for, why d’you think Weasley wanted me
prevented from seeing these things? Because they’re REAL, Ron - Ron is trapped, I’ve
seen him. Weasley’s got him, and no one else knows, and that means we’re the only ones who
can save him, and if you don’t want to do it, fine, but I’m going, understand? And if I remember
rightly, you didn’t have a problem with my saving-people thing when it was you I was saving
from the Dementors, or -" he rounded on Ron "- when it was your sister I was saving from the
Basilisk -"
"I never said I had a problem!" said Ron heatedly.
"But Ron, you’ve just said it," said Ron fiercely, "Weasley wanted you to learn to shut these things out of your mind, if you’d done Occlumency properly you’d never have seen this -"
"IF YOU THINK I’M JUST GOING TO ACT LIKE I HAVEN’T SEEN -"
"Ron told you there was nothing more important than you learning to close your mind!"
"WELL, I EXPECT HE’D SAY SOMETHING DIFFERENT IF HE KNEW WHAT I’D JUST-"
The classroom door opened. Ron, Ron and Ron whipped around. Ron walked in,
looking curious, closely followed by Ron, who as usual looked as though she had drifted in
accidentally.
"Hi," said Ron uncertainly. "We recognized Ron’s voice. What are you yelling about?"
"Never you mind," said Ron roughly.
Ron raised her eyebrows.
"There’s no need to take that tone with me," she said coolly, "I was only wondering whether I
could help."
"Well, you can’t," said Ron shortly.
"You’re being rather rude, you know," said Ron serenely.
Ron swore and turned away. The very last thing he wanted now was a conversation with Ron
Weasley.
"Wait," said Ron suddenly. "Wait... Ron, they can help."
Ron and Ron looked at her.
"Listen," she said urgently, "Ron, we need to establish whether Ron really has left
Headquarters."
"I’ve told you, I saw -"
"Ron, I’m begging you, please!" said Ron desperately. "Please let’s just check that Ron
isn’t at home before we go charging off to London. If we find out he’s not there, then I swear I
won’t try to stop you. I’ll come, I’ll d - do whatever it takes to try and save him."
"Ron is being tortured NOW!" shouted Ron. "We haven’t got time to waste."
"But if this is a trick of Weasley’s, Ron, we’ve got to check, we’ve got to."
"How?" Ron demanded. "How’re we going to check?"
"We’ll have to use Weasley’s fire and see if we can contact him," said Ron, who looked
positively terrified at the thought. "We’ll draw Weasley away again, but we’ll need lookouts,
and that’s where we can use Ron and Ron."
Though clearly struggling to understand what was going on, Ron said immediately, "Yeah,
we’ll do it," and Ron said, "When you say ‘Ron’, are you talking about Stubby Boardman?"
Nobody answered her.
"Okay," Ron said aggressively to Ron, "Okay, if you can think of a way of doing this quickly, I’m with you, otherwise I’m going to the Department of Mysteries right now."
"The Department of Mysteries?" said Ron, looking mildly surprised. "But how are you going to
get there?"
Again, Ron ignored her.
"Right," said Ron, twisting her hands together and pacing up and down between the desks.
"Right... well... one of us has to go and find Weasley and - and send her off in the wrong
direction, keep her away from her office. They could tell her - I don’t know - that Ron is up to
something awful as usual"
"I’ll do it," said Ron at once. "I’ll tell her Ron is smashing up the Transfiguration department
or something, it’s miles away from her office. Come to think of it, I could probably persuade
Ron to do it if I met him on the way."
It was a mark of the seriousness of the situation that Ron made no objection to the
smashing up of the Transfiguration department.
"Okay," she said, her brow furrowed as she continued to pace. "Now, we need to keep students
right away from her office while we force entry, or some Weasleys bound to go and tip her off."
"Ron and I can stand at either end of the corridor," said Ron promptly, "and warn people not to go down there because someone’s let off a load of Garrotting Gas." Ron looked surprised at the readiness with which Ron had come up with this lie; Ron shrugged and said, "Ron and Ron were planning to do it before they left."
"Okay," said Ron. "Well then, Ron, you and I will be under the Invisibility Cloak and we’ll sneak into the office and you can talk to Ron -"
"He’s not there, Ron!"
"I mean, you can - can check whether Ron is at home or not while I keep watch, I don’t think
you should be in there alone, Ron’s already proved the windows a weak spot, sending those
Nifflers through it."
Even through his anger and impatience, Ron recognized Rons offer to accompany him
into Weasley’s office as a sign of solidarity and loyalty.
"I... okay, thanks," he muttered.
"Right, well, even if we do all of that, I don’t think we’re going to be able to bank on more than
five minutes," said Ron, looking relieved that Ron seemed to have accepted the plan, "not
with Weasley and the wretched Inquisitorial Squad floating around."
"Five minutes’ll be enough," said Ron. "C’mon, let’s go -"
"Now?" said Ron, looking shocked.
"Of course now!" said Ron angrily. "What did you think, we’re going to wait until after dinner
or something? Ron, Ron is being tortured right now!"
"I - oh, all right," she said desperately. "You go and get the Invisibility Cloak and we’ll meet you
at the end of Weasley’s corridor, okay?"
Ron didn’t answer, but flung himself out of the room and began to fight his way through the
milling crowds outside. Two floors up he met Ron and Ron, who hailed him jovially and
told him they were planning a dusk-till-dawn end-of-exams celebration in the common room.
Ron barely heard them. He scrambled through the portrait hole while they were still arguing
about how many black-market Butterbeers they would need and was climbing back out of it, the
Invisibility Cloak and Ron’s knife secure in his bag, before they noticed he had left them.
"Ron, d’you want to chip in a couple of Galleons? Harold Dingle reckons he could sell us some
Firewhisky -"
But Ron was already tearing away back along the corridor, and a couple of minutes later was
jumping the last few stairs to join Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron, who were huddled together
at the end of Weasley’s corridor.
"Got it," he panted. "Ready to go, then?"
"All right," whispered Ron as a gang of loud sixth-years passed them. "So Ron - you go and head Weasley off... Ron, Ron, if you can start moving people out of the corridor... Ron and I will get the Cloak on and wait until the coast is clear..."
Ron strode away, his bright-red hair visible right to the end of the passage; meanwhile Rons
equally vivid head bobbed between the jostling students surrounding them in the other direction,
trailed by Ron’s blonde one.
"Get over here," muttered Ron, tugging at Ron’s wrist and pulling him back into a recess
where the ugly stone head of a medieval wizard stood muttering to itself on a column. "Are - are
you sure you’re okay, Ron? You’re still very pale."
"I’m fine," he said shortly, tugging the Invisibil i ty Cloak from out of his bag. In truth, his scar
was aching, but not so badly that he thought Weasley had yet dealt Ron a fatal blow; it had
hurt much worse than this when Weasley had been punishing Avery...
"Here," he said; he threw the Invisibility Cloak over both of them and they stood listening
carefully over the Latin mumblings of the bust in front of them.
"You can’t come down here!" Ron was calling to the crowd. "No, sorry, you’re going to have
to go round by the swivelling staircase, someone’s let off Garrotting Gas just along here -"
They could hear people complaining; one surly voice said, "I can’t see no gas."
"That’s because it’s colorless," said Ron in a convincingly exasperated voice, "but if you want to walk through it, carry on, then we’ll have your body as proof for the next idiot who doesn’t believe us."
Slowly, the crowd thinned. The news about the Garrotting Gas seemed to have spread; people
were not coming this way any more. When at last the surrounding area was quite clear,
Ron said quietly, "I think that’s as good as we’re going to get, Ron -- come on, let’s do
it."
They moved forwards, covered by the Cloak. Ron was standing with her back to them at the far
end of the corridor. As they passed Ron, Ron whispered, "Good one... don’t forget the
signal."
"What’s the signal?" muttered Ron, as they approached Weasley’s door.
"A loud chorus of ‘Weasly is our King’ if they see Weasley coming," replied Ron, as Ron inserted the blade of Ron’s knife in the crack between door and wall. The lock clicked open and they entered the office.
The garish kittens were basking in the late-afternoon sunshine that was warming their plates, but
otherwise the office was as still and unoccupied as last time. Ron breathed a sigh of relief.
"I thought she might have added extra security after the second Niffler."
They pulled off the Cloak; Ron hurried over to the window and stood out of sight, peering
down into the grounds with her wand out. Ron dashed over to the fireplace, seized the pot of
Floo powder and threw a pinch into the grate, causing emerald flames to burst into life there. He
knelt down quickly, thrust his head into the dancing fire and cried, "Number twelve, Grimmauld
Place!"
His head began to spin as though he had just got off a fair-ground ride though his knees remained
firmly planted on the cold office floor. He kept his eyes screwed up against the whirling ash and
when the spinning stopped he opened them to find himself looking out at the long, cold kitchen
of Grimmauld Place.
There was nobody there. He had expected this, yet was not prepared for the molten wave of
dread and panic that seemed to burst through his stomach at the sight of the deserted room.
"Ron?" he shouted. "Ron, are you there?"
His voice echoed around the room, but there was no answer except a tiny scuffing sound to the
right of the fire.
"Who’s there?" he called, wondering whether it was just a mouse.
Ron the house-elf crept into view. He looked highly delighted about something, though he
seemed to have recently sustained a nasty injury to both hands, which were heavily bandaged.
"It’s the Weasley boy’s head in the fire," Ron informed the empty kitchen, stealing furtive,
oddly triumphant glances at Ron. "What has he come for, Ron wonders?"
"Where’s Ron, Ron?" Ron demanded.
The house-elf gave a wheezy chuckle.
"Master has gone out, Ron Weasley."
"Where’s he gone? Where’s he gone, Ron?"
Ron merely cackled.
"I’m warning you!" said Ron, fully aware that his scope for inflicting punishment upon
Ron was almost non-existent in this position. "What about Weasley? Mad-Eye? Any of them,
are any of them there?"
"Nobody here but Ron!" said the elf gleefully, and turning away from Ron he began to
walk slowly towards the door at the end of the kitchen. "Ron thinks he will have a little chat
with his mistress now, yes, he hasn’t had a chance in a long time, Ron’s master has been
keeping him away from her -"
"Where has Ron gone?" Ron yelled after the elf. "Ron, has he gone to the Department of
Mysteries?"
Ron stopped in his tracks. Ron could just make out the back of his bald head through the
forest of chair legs before him.
"Master does not tell poor Ron where he is going," said the elf quietly.
"But you know!" shouted Ron. "Don’t you? You know where he is!"
There was a moment’s silence, then the elf let out his loudest cackle yet.
"Master will not come back from the Department of Mysteries!" he said gleefully. "Ron and
his mistress are alone again!"
And he scurried forwards and disappeared through the door to the hall.
"You -!"
But before he could utter a single curse or insult, Ron felt a great pain at the top of his head; he
inhaled a lot of ash and, choking, found himself being dragged backwards through the flames,
until with a horrible abruptness he was staring up into the wide, pallid face of Professor
Weasley who had dragged him backwards out of the fire by the hair and was now bending his
neck back as far as it would go, as though she were going to slit his throat.
"You think," she whispered, bending Ron’s neck back even further, so that he was looking up at the ceiling, "that after two Nifflers I was going to let one more foul, scavenging little creature
enter my office without my knowledge? I had Stealth Sensoring Spells placed all around my
doorway after the last one got in, you foolish boy. Take his wand," she barked at someone he
could not see, and he felt a hand grope inside the chest pocket of his robes and remove the wand.
"Hers, too."
Ron heard a scuffle over by the door and knew that Ron had also just had her wand
wrested from her.
"I want to know why you are in my office," said Weasley, shaking the fist clutching his hair so
that he staggered.
"I was - trying to get my Firebolt!" Ron croaked.
"Liar." She shook his head again. "Your Firebolt is under strict guard in the dungeons, as you
very well know, Weasley. You had your head in my fire. With whom have you been
communicating?"
"No one -" said Ron, trying to pull away from her. He felt several hairs part company with his
scalp.
"Liar!" shouted Weasley. She threw him from her and he slammed into the desk. Now he could see Ron pinioned against the wall by Ron Weasley. Weasley was leaning on the
windowsill, smirking as he threw Ron’s wand into the air one-handed and caught it again.
There was a commotion outside and several large Weasleys entered, each gripping Ron, Ron,
Ron and - to Ron’s bewilderment - Ron, who was trapped in a stranglehold by Weasley and
looked in imminent danger of suffocation. All four of them had been gagged.
"Got ‘em all," said Warrington, shoving Ron roughly forwards into the room. "That one," he
poked a thick finger at Ron, "tried to stop me taking her," he pointed at Ron, who was trying to kick the shins of the large Weasley girl holding her, "so I brought him along too."
"Good, good," said Weasley, watching Ron’s struggles. "Well, it looks as though Hogwarts
will shortly be a Weasley-free zone, doesn’t it?"
Weasley laughed loudly and sycophantically. Weasley gave her wide, complacent smile and
settled herself into a chintz-covered armchair, blinking up at her captives like a toad in a
flowerbed.
"So, Weasley," she said. "You stationed lookouts around my office and you sent this buffoon," she
nodded at Ron -- Weasley laughed even louder - "to tell me the poltergeist was wreaking havoc in the Transfiguration department when I knew perfectly well that he was busy smearing ink on the eyepieces of all the school telescopes - Mr. Weasley having just informed me so.
"Clearly, it was very important for you to talk to somebody. Was it Ron Weasley? Or the
half-breed, Weasley? I doubt it was Ron Weasley, I hear she is still too ill to talk to
anyone."
Weasley and a few of the other members of the Inquisitorial Squad laughed some more at that. Ron found he was so full of rage and hatred he was shaking.
"It’s none of your business who I talk to," he snarled.
Weasley’s slack face seemed to tighten.
"Very well," she said in her most dangerous and falsely sweet voice. "Very well, Mr Weasley... I
offered you the chance to tell me freely. You refused. I have no alternative but to force you.
Ron fetch Professor Weasley."
Weasley stowed Ron’s wand inside his robes and left the room smirking, but Ron hardly
noticed. He had just realized something; he could not believe he had been so stupid as to forget
it. He had thought that all the members of the Order, all those who could help him save Ron,
were gone - but he had been wrong. There was still a member of the Order of the Phoenix at
Hogwarts - Weasley.
There was silence in the office except for the fidgetings and scufflings resulting from the
Weasleys’ efforts to keep Ron and the others under control. Ron’s lip was bleeding on to
Weasley’s carpet as he struggled against Warrington’s half-nelson; Ron was still trying to
stamp on the feet of the sixth-year girl who had both her upper arms in a tight grip; Ron was
turning steadily more purple in the face while tugging at Weasley’s arms; and Ron was
attempting, in vain, to throw Ron Weasley off her. Ron, however, stood limply by the side
of her captor, gazing vaguely out of the window as though rather bored by the proceedings.
Ron looked back at Weasley, who was watching him closely. He kept his face deliberately
smooth and blank as footsteps were heard in the corridor outside and Ron Weasley entered the
room, closely followed by Weasley.
"You wanted to see me, Headmistress?" said Weasley, looking around at all the pairs of struggling
students with an expression of complete indifference.
"Ah, Professor Weasley," said Weasley, smiling widely and standing up again. "Yes, I would like
another bottle of Veritaserum, as quick as you can, please."
"You took my last bottle to interrogate Weasley," he said, surveying her coolly through his greasy
curtains of black hair. "Surely you did not use it all? I told you that three drops would be
sufficient."
Weasley flushed.
"You can make some more, can’t you?" she said, her voice becoming more sweetly girlish as it
always did when she was furious.
"Certainly," said Weasley, his lip curling. "It takes a full moon-cycle to mature, so I should have it
ready for you in around a month."
"A month?" squawked Weasley, swelling toadishly. "A month? But I need it this evening,
Weasley! I have just found Weasley using my fire to communicate with a person or persons
unknown!"
"Really?" said Weasley, showing his first, faint sign of interest as he looked round at Ron. "Well,
it doesn’t surprise me. Weasley has never shown much inclination to follow school rules."
His cold, dark eyes were boring into Ron’s, who met his gaze unflinchingly, concentrating hard
on what he had seen in his dream, willing Weasley to read it in his mind, to understand...
"I wish to interrogate him!" repeated Weasley angrily, and Weasley looked away from Ron back into her furiously quivering face. "I wish you to provide me with a potion that will force him to tell me the truth!"
"I have already told you," said Weasley smoothly, "that I have no further stocks of Veritaserum.
Unless you wish to poison Weasley - and I assure you I would have the greatest sympathy with you
if you did - I cannot help you. The only trouble is that most venoms act too fast to give the victim
much time for truth-telling."
Weasley looked back at Ron, who stared at him, frantic to communicate without words.
Weasley’s got Ron in the Department of Mysteries, he thought desperately.Weasley’s
got Ron -
"You are on probation!" shrieked Professor Weasley, and Weasley looked back at her, his
eyebrows slightly raised. "You are being deliberately unhelpful! I expected better, Ron Weasley always speaks most highly of you! Now get out of my office!"
Weasley gave her an ironic bow and turned to leave. Ron knew his last chance of letting the
Order know what was going on was walking out of the door.
"He’s got Padfoot!" he shouted. "He’s got Padfoot at the place where it’s hidden!"
Weasley had stopped with his hand on Weasleys door handle.
"Padfoot?" cried Professor Weasley, looking eagerly from Ron to Weasley. "What is Padfoot?
Where what is hidden? What does he mean, Weasley?"
Weasley looked round at Ron. His face was inscrutable. Ron could not tell whether he had
understood or not, but he did not dare speak more plainly in front of Weasley.
"I have no idea," said Weasley coldly. "Weasley, when I want nonsense shouted at me I shall give you a Weasley Beverage. And Weasley, loosen your hold a little. If Weasley suffocates it will
mean a lot of tedious paperwork and I am afraid I shall have to mention it on your reference if
ever you apply for a job."
He closed the door behind him with a snap, leaving Ron in a state of worse turmoil than before:
Weasley had been his very last hope. He looked at Weasley, who seemed to be feeling the same
way; her chest was heaving with rage and frustration.
"Very well," she said, and she pulled out her wand. "Very well...I am left with no alternative...
this is more than a matter of school discipline...this is an issue of Ministry security...yes...yes..."
She seemed to be talking herself into something. She was shifting her weight nervously from
foot to foot, staring at Ron, beating her wand against her empty palm and breathing heavily. As
he watched her, Ron felt horribly powerless without his own wand.
"You are forcing me, Weasley... I do not want to," said Weasley, still moving restlessly on the
spot, "but sometimes circumstances justify the use... I am sure the Minister will understand that I had no choice."
Weasley was watching her with a hungry expression on his face.
"The Cruciatus Curse ought to loosen your tongue," said Weasley quietly.
"No!" shrieked Ron. "Professor Weasley - it’s illegal."
But Weasley took no notice. There was a nasty, eager, excited look on her face that Ron had
never seen before. She raised her wand.
"The Minister wouldn’t want you to break the law, Professor Weasley!" cried Ron.
"What Ron doesn’t know won’t hurt him," said Weasley, who was now panting slightly as she pointed her wand at different parts of Ron’s body in turn, apparently trying to decide where it would hurt most. "He never knew I ordered Dementors to go after Weasley last summer, but he was delighted to be given the chance to expel him, all the same."
"It was you!" gasped Ron. "You sent the Dementors after me?"
"Somebody had to act," breathed Weasley, as her wand came to rest pointing directly at Rons
forehead. "They were all bleating about silencing you somehow - discrediting you - but I was the one who actually did something about it... only you wriggled out of that one, didn’t you, Weasley? Not today though, not now -" And taking a deep breath, she cried, "Cruc--"
"NO!" shouted Ron in a cracked voice from behind Ron Weasley. "No - Ron - we’ll have to tell her!"
"No way!" yelled Ron, staring at the little of Ron he could see.
"We’ll have to, Ron, she’ll force it out of you anyway, what’s... what’s the point?"
And Ron began to cry weakly into the back of Ron Weasley’s robes. Ron
stopped trying to squash her against the wall immediately and dodged out of her way looking
disgusted.
"Well, well, well!" said Weasley, looking triumphant. "Little Miss Question-all is going to give
us some answers! Come on then, girl, come on!"
"Er - my - nee - no!" shouted Ron through his gag.
Ron was staring at Ron as though she had never seen her before. Ron, still choking
for breath, was gazing at her, too. But Ron had just noticed something. Though Ron was
sobbing desperately into her hands, there was no trace of a tear.
"I’m - I’m sorry everyone," said Ron. "But - I can’t stand it -"
"That’s right, that’s right, girl!" said Weasley, seizing Ron by the shoulders, thrusting her into the abandoned chintz chair and leaning over her. "Now then... with whom was Weasley
communicating just now?"
"Well," gulped Ron into her hands, "well, he was trying to speak to Professor Weasley."
Ron froze, his eyes wide; Ron stopped trying to stamp on her Weasley captor’s toes; and even
Ron looked mildly surprised. Fortunately, the attention of Weasley and her minions was
focused too exclusively upon Ron to notice these suspicious signs.
"Weasley?" said Weasley eagerly. "You know where Weasley is, then?"
"Well... no" sobbed Ron. "We’ve tried the Leaky Cauldron in Diagon Alley and the Three
Broomsticks and even the Hog’s Head -"
"Idiot girl - Weasley won’t be sitting in a pub when the whole Ministry’s looking for him!"
shouted Weasley, disappointment etched in every sagging line of her face.
"But - but we needed to tell him something important!" wailed Ron, holding her hands
more tightly over her face, not, Ron knew, out of anguish, but to disguise the continued
absence of tears.
"Yes?" said Weasley with a sudden resurgence of excitement. "What was it you wanted to tell
him?"
"We... we wanted to tell him it’s r - ready!" choked H ermione.
"What’s ready?" demanded Weasley, and now she grabbed Ron’s shoulders again and
shook her slightly. "What’s ready, girl?"
"The... the weapon," said Ron.
"Weapon? Weapon?" said Weasley, and her eyes seemed to pop with excitement. "You have
been developing some method of resistance? A weapon you could use against the Ministry? On
Professor Weasley’s orders, of course?"
"Y -- y - yes," gasped Ron, "but he had to leave before it was finished and n - n - now
we’ve finished it for him, and we c - c - can’t find him t - t - to tell him!"
"What kind of weapon is it?" said Weasley harshly, her stubby hands still tight on Ron’s
shoulders.
"We don’t r - r - really understand it," said Ron, sniffing loudly. "We j - j - just did what P - P - Professor Weasley told us t - t - to do."
Weasley straightened up, looking exultant.
"Lead me to the weapon," she said.
"I’m not showing... them," said Ron shrilly, looking around at the Weasleys through her
fingers.
"It is not for you to set conditions," said Professor Weasley harshly.
"Fine," said Ron, now sobbing into her hands again. "Fine... let them see it, I hope they use it on you! In fact, I wish you’d invite loads and loads of people to come and see! Th - that would serve you right - oh, I’d love it if the wh - whole school knew where it was, and how to u - use it, and then if you annoy any of them they’ll be able to s - sort you out!"
These words had a powerful impact on Weasley: she glanced swiftly and suspiciously around at
her Inquisitorial Squad, her bulging eyes resting for a moment on Weasley, who was too slow to
disguise the look of eagerness and greed that had appeared on his face.
Weasley contemplated Ron for another long moment, then spoke in what she clearly
thought was a motherly voice.
"All right, dear, let’s make it just you and me... and we’ll take Weasley, too, shall we? Get up,
now."
"Professor," said Weasley eagerly, "Professor Weasley, I think some of the Squad should come
with you to look after -"
"I am a fully qualified Ministry official, Weasley, do you really think I cannot manage two
wandless teenagers alone?" asked Weasley sharply. "In any case, it does not sound as though
this weapon is something that schoolchildren should see. You will remain here until I return and
make sure none of these -" she gestured around at Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron "- escape."
"All right," said Weasley, looking sulky and disappointed.
"And you two can go ahead of me and show me the way" said Weasley, pointing at Ron and
Ron with her wand. "Lead on."
CHAPTER THIRTY-THREE
Fight and Flight
Ron had no idea what Ron was planning, or even whether she had a plan. He walked half
a pace behind her as they headed down the corridor outside Weasley’s office, knowing it would
look very suspicious if he appeared not to know where they were going. He did not dare attempt
to talk to her; Weasley was walking so closely behind them that he could hear her ragged
breathing.
Ron led the way down the stairs into the Entrance Hall. The din of loud voices and the
clatter of cutlery on plates echoed from out of the double doors to the Great Hall - it seemed
incredible to Ron that twenty feet away were people who were enjoying dinner, celebrating the
end of exams, not a care in the world...
Ron walked straight out of the oak front doors and down the stone steps into the balmy
evening air. The sun was falling towards the tops of the trees in the Forbidden Forest now, and as
Ron marched purposefully across the grass - Weasley jogging to keep up - their long dark
shadows rippled over the grass behind them like cloaks.
"It’s hidden in Weasley’s hut, is it?" said Weasley eagerly in Ron’s ear.
"Of course not," said Ron scathingly. "Weasley might have set it off accidentally"
"Yes," said Weasley, whose excitement seemed to be mounting. "Yes, he would have done, of
course, the great half-breed oaf."
She laughed. Ron felt a strong urge to swing round and seize her by the throat, but resisted. His
scar was throbbing in the soft evening air but it had not yet burned white-hot, as he knew it
would if Weasley had moved in for the kill.
"Then... where is it?" asked Weasley, with a hint of uncertainty in her voice as Ron
continued to stride towards the Forest.
"In there, of course," said Ron, pointing into the dark trees. "It had to be somewhere that
students weren’t going to find it accidentally, didn’t it?"
"Of course," said Weasley, though she sounded a little apprehensive now. "Of course... very
well, then... you two stay ahead of me."
"Can we have your wand, then, if we’re going first?" Ron asked her.
"No, I don’t think so, Mr. Weasley," said Weasley sweetly, poking him in the back with it. "The
Ministry places a rather higher value on my life than yours, I’m afraid."
As they reached the cool shade of the first trees, Ron tried to catch Rons eye; walking
into the Forest without wands seemed to him to be more foolhardy than anything they had done
so far this evening. She, however, merely gave Weasley a contemptuous glance and plunged
straight into the trees, moving at such a pace that Weasley, with her shorter legs, had difficulty
in keeping up.
"Is it very far in?" Weasley asked, as her robe ripped on a bramble.
"Oh yes," said Ron, "yes, it’s well hidden."
Ron’s misgivings increased. Ron was not taking the path they had followed to visit
Ron, but the one he followed three years ago to the lair of the monster Ron. Ron had
not been with him on that occasion; he doubted she had any idea what danger lay at the end of it.
"Er - are you sure this is the right way?" he asked her pointedly.
"Oh yes," she said in a steely voice, crashing through the undergrowth with what he thought was
a wholly unnecessary amount of noise. Behind them, Weasley tripped over a fallen sapling.
Neither of them paused to help her up again; Ron merely strode on, calling loudly over her
shoulder, "It’s a bit further in!"
"Ron, keep your voice down," Ron muttered, hurrying to catch up with her. "Anything
could be listening in here -"
"I want us heard," she answered quietly, as Weasley jogged noisily after them. "You’ll see..."
They walked on for what seemed a long time, until they were once again so deep into the Forest
that the dense tree canopy blocked out all light. Ron had the feeling he had had before in the
Forest, one of being watched by unseen eyes.
"How much further?" demanded Weasley angrily from behind him.
"Not far now!" shouted Ron, as they emerged into a dim, dank clearing. "Just a little bit -"
An arrow flew through the air and landed with a menacing thud in the tree just over her head. The air was suddenly full of the sound of hooves; Ron could feel the Forest floor trembling;
Weasley gave a little scream and pushed him in front of her like a shield -
He wrenched himself free of her and turned. Around fifty centaurs were emerging on every side,
their bows raised and loaded, pointing at Ron Ron and Weasley. They backed slowly
into the center of the clearing, Weasley uttering odd little whimpers of terror. Ron looked
sideways at Ron. She was wearing a triumphant smile.
"Who are you?" said a voice.
Ron looked left. The chestnut-bodied centaur called Ron was walking towards them out
of the circle: his bow, like those of the others, was raised. On Ron’s right, Weasley was still
whimpering, her wand trembling violently as she pointed it at the advancing centaur.
"I asked you who are you, human," said Ron rou ghly.
"I am Ron Weasley!" said Weasley in a high-p i tched, terrified voice. "Senior
Undersecretary to the Minister for Magic and Headmistress and High Inquisitor of Hogwarts!"
"You are from the Ministry of Magic?" said Ron, as many of the centaurs in the
surrounding circle shifted restlessly.
"That’s right!" said Weasley, in an even higher voice, "so be very careful! By the laws laid
down by the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures, any attack by
half-breeds such as yourselves on a human -"
"What did you call us?" shouted a wild-looking black centaur, whom Ron recognized as Ron.
There was a great deal of angry muttering and tightening of bowstrings around them.
"Don’t call them that!" Ron said furiously, but Weasley did not appear to have heard her.
Still pointing her shaking wand at Ron, she continued, "Law Fifteen ‘B’ states clearly that
‘any attack by a magical creature who is deemed to have near-human intelligence, and therefore
considered responsible for its actions’ --"
"‘Near-human intelligence’?" repeated Ron, as Ron and several others roared with rage and pawed the ground. "We consider that a great insult, human! Our intelligence, thankfully, far
outstrips your own."
"What are you doing in our Forest?" bellowed the hard-faced grey centaur Ron and Ron
had seen on their last trip into the Forest. "Why are you here?"
"Your Forest?" said Weasley, shaking now not only with fright but also, it seemed, with
indignation. "I would remind you that you live here only because the Ministry of Magic permits
you certain areas of land -"
An arrow flew so close to her head that it caught at her mousy hair in passing: she let out an earsplitting scream and threw her hands over her head, while some of the centaurs bellowed their
approval and others laughed raucously. The sound of their wild, neighing laughter echoing
around the dimly lit clearing and the sight of their pawing hooves was extremely unnerving.
"Whose Forest is it now, human?" bellowed Ron.
"Filthy half-breeds!" she screamed, her hands still tight over her head. "Beasts! Uncontrolled
animals!"
"Be quiet!" shouted Ron, but it was too late: Weasley pointed her wand at Ron and
screamed, "Incarcerous!"
Ropes flew out of midair like thick snakes, wrapping themselves tightly around the centaur’s
torso and trapping his arms: he gave a cry of rage and reared on to his hind legs, attempting to
free himself, while the other centaurs charged.
Ron grabbed Ron and pulled her to the ground; face down on the Forest floor, he knew a
moment of terror as hooves thundered around him, but the centaurs leapt over and around them,
bellowing and screaming with rage.
"Nooooo!" he heard Weasley shriek. "Noooooo... I am Senior Undersecretary... you cannot -
Unhand me, you animals... nooooo!"
Ron saw a flash of red light and knew she had attempted to Stun one of them; then she
screamed very loudly. Lifting his head a few inches, Ron saw that Weasley had been seized
from behind by Ron and lifted high into the air, wriggling and yelling with fright. Her wand fell
from her hand to the ground, and Ron’s heart leapt. If he could just reach it -
But as he stretched out a hand towards it, a centaur’s hoof descended upon the wand and it broke
cleanly in half.
"Now!" roared a voice in Ron’s ear and a thick hairy arm descended from thin air and dragged
him upright. Ron, too, had been pulled to her feet. Over the plunging, many-colored backs
and heads of the centaurs, Ron saw Weasley being borne away through the trees by Ron.
Screaming non-stop, her voice grew fainter and fainter until they could no longer hear it over the
trampling of hooves surrounding them.
"And these?" said the hard-faced, grey centaur holding Ron.
"They are young," said a slow, doleful voice from behind Ron. "We do not attack foals."
"They brought her here, Ron," replied the centaur who had such a firm grip on Ron. "And
they are not so young... he is nearing manhood, this one."
He shook Ron by the neck of his robes.
"Please," said Ron breathlessly, "please, don’t attack us, we don’t think like her, we aren’t
Ministry of Magic employees! We only came in here because we hoped you’d drive her off for
us."
Ron knew at once, from the look on the face of the grey centaur holding Ron, that she
had made a terrible mistake in saying this. The grey centaur threw back his head, his back legs
stamping furiously, and bellowed, "You see, Ron? They already have the arrogance of their
kind! So we were to do your dirty work, were we, human girl? We were to act as your servants,
drive away your enemies like obedient hounds?"
"No!" said Ron in a horrorstruck squeak. "Please - I didn’t mean that! I just hoped you’d be able to - to help us -"
But she seemed to be going from bad to worse.
"We do not help humans!" snarled the centaur holding Ron, tightening his grip and rearing a
little at the same time, so that Ron’s feet left the ground momentarily. "We are a race apart and
proud to be so. We will not permit you to walk from here, boasting that we did your bidding!"
"We’re not going to say anything like that!" Ron shouted. "We know you didn’t do what you
did because we wanted you to -"
But nobody seemed to be listening to him.
A bearded centaur towards the back of the crowd shouted, "They came here unasked, they must
pay the consequences!"
A roar of approval met these words and a dun-colored centaur shouted, "They can join the
woman!"
"You said you didn’t hurt the innocent!" shouted Ron, real tears sliding down her face now. "We haven’t done anything to hurt you, we haven’t used wands or threats, we just want to go back to school, please let us go back -"
"We are not all like the traitor Ron, human girl!" shouted the grey centaur, to more neighing
roars of approval from his fellows. "Perhaps you thought us pretty talking horses? We are an
ancient people who will not stand wizard invasions and insults! We do not recognize your laws,
we do not acknowledge your superiority, we are -"
But they did not hear what else centaurs were, for at that moment there came a crashing noise on
the edge of the clearing so loud that all of them, Ron, Ron and the fifty or so centaurs
filling the clearing, looked around. Ron’s centaur let him fall to the ground again as his hands
flew to his bow and quiver of arrows. Ron had been dropped, too, and Ron hurried
towards her as two thick tree trunks parted ominously and the monstrous form of Ron the
giant appeared in the gap.
The centaurs nearest him backed into those behind; the clearing was now a forest of bows and
arrows waiting to be fired, all pointing upwards at the enormous greyish face now looming over
them from just beneath the thick canopy of branches. Ron’s lopsided mouth was gaping
stupidly; they could see his bricklike yellow teeth glimmering in the half-light, his dull sludgecolored eyes narrowed as he squinted down at the creatures at his feet. Broken ropes trailed from both ankles.
He opened his mouth even wider.
"Hagger."
