Ron did not know what ‘hagger’ meant, or what language it was from, nor did he much care; he
was watching Ron’s feet, which were almost as long as Ron’s whole body. Ron
gripped his arm tightly; the centaurs were quite silent, staring up at the giant, whose huge, round
head moved from side to side as he continued to peer amongst them as though looking for
something he had dropped.
"Hagger!" he said again, more insistently.
"Get away from here, giant!" called Ron. "You are not welcome among us!"
These words seemed to make no impression whatsoever on Ron. He stooped a little (the
centaurs’ arms tensed on their bows), then bellowed, "HAGGER!"
A few of the centaurs looked worried now. Ron, however, gave a gasp.
"Ron!" she whispered. "I think he’s trying to say ‘Weasley’!"
At this precise moment Ron caught sight of them, the only two humans in a sea of centaurs.
He lowered his head another foot or so, staring intently at them. Ron could feel Ron
shaking as Ron opened his mouth wide again and said, in a deep, rumbling voice, "Hermy."
"Goodness," said Ron, gripping Ron’s arm so tightly it was growing numb and looking as
though she was about to faint, "he - he remembered!"
"HERMY!" roared Ron. "WHERE HAGGER?"
"I don’t know!" squealed Ron, terrified. "I’m sorry, Ron, I don’t know!"
"Ron WANT HAGGER!"
One of the giant’s massive hands reached down. Ron let out a real scream, ran a few steps
backwards and fell over. Devoid of a wand, Ron braced himself to punch, kick, bite or
whatever else it took as the hand swooped towards him and knocked a snow-white centaur off
his legs.
It was what the centaurs had been waiting for -- Ron’s outstretched fingers were a foot from
Ron when fifty arrows soared through the air at the giant, peppering his enormous face, causing
him to howl with pain and rage and straighten up, rubbing his face with his enormous hands,
breaking off the arrow shafts but forcing the arrowheads in still deeper.
He yelled and stamped his enormous feet and the centaurs scattered out of the way; pebble-sized
droplets of Ron’s blood showered Ron as he pulled Ron to her feet and the pair of
them ran as fast as they could for the shelter of the trees. Once there they looked back; Ron
was snatching blindly at the centaurs as blood ran down his face; they were retreating in
disorder, galloping away through the trees on the other side of the clearing. Ron and Ron
watched Ron give another roar of fury and plunge after them, smashing more trees aside as he
went.
"Oh no," said Ron, quaking so badly that her knees gave way. "Oh, that was horrible. And
he might kill them all."
"I’m not that fussed, to be honest," said Ron bitterly.
The sounds of the galloping centaurs and the blundering giant grew fainter and fainter. As Ron
listened to them, his scar gave another great throb and a wave of terror swept over him.
They had wasted so much time - they were even further from rescuing Ron than they had been
when he had had the vision. Not only had Ron managed to lose his wand but they were stuck in
the middle of the Forbidden Forest with no means of transport whatsoever.
"Smart plan," he spat at Ron, having to release some of his fury. "Really smart plan. Where
do we go from here?"
"We need to get back up to the castle," said Ron faintly.
"By the time we’ve done that, Ron’ll probably be dead!" said Ron, kicking a nearby tree in
temper. A high-pitched chattering started up overhead and he looked up to see an angry
Bowtruckle flexing its long twiglike fingers at him.
"Well, we can’t do anything without wands," said Ron hopelessly, dragging herself up
again. "Anyway, Ron, how exactly were you planning to get all the way to London?"
"Yeah, we were just wondering that," said a familiar voice from behind her.
Ron and Ron moved together instinctively and peered through the trees.
Ron came into sight, closely followed by Ron, Ron and Ron. All of them looked a little the
worse for wear - there were several long scratches running the length of Ron’s cheek; a large
purple lump was swelling above Ron’s right eye; Ron’s lip was bleeding worse than ever -
but all were looking rather pleased with themselves.
"So," said Ron, pushing aside a low-hanging branch and holding out Ron’s wand, "had any
ideas?"
"How did you get away?" asked Ron in amazement, taking his wand from Ron.
"Couple of Stunners, a Disarming Charm, Ron brought off a really nice little Impediment
Jinx," said Ron airily, now handing back Ron’s wand, too. "But Ron was best, she got
Weasley - Bat Bogey Hex - it was superb, his whole face was covered in the great flapping things.
Anyway, we saw you out of the window heading into the Forest and followed. What’ve you done
with Weasley?"
"She got carried away," said Ron. "By a herd of centaurs."
"And they left you behind?" asked Ron, looking astonished.
"No, they got chased off by Ron," said Ron
"Who’s Ron?" Ron asked interestedly.
"Weasley’s little brother," said Ron promptly. "Anyway, never mind that now. Ron, what did you find out in the fire? Has You-Know-Who got Ron or -?"
"Yes," said Ron, as his scar gave another painful prickle, "and I’m sure Ron is still alive, but I can’t see how we’re going to get there to help him."
They all fell silent, looking rather scared; the problem facing them seemed insurmountable.
"Well, we’ll have to fly, won’t we?" said Ron, in the closest thing to a matter-of-fact voice
Ron had ever heard her use.
"Okay," said Ron irritably, rounding on her. "First of all, ‘we’ aren’t doing anything if you’re
including yourself in that, and second of all, Ron’s the only one with a broomstick that isn’t
being guarded by a security troll, so -"
"I’ve got a broom!" said Ron.
"Yeah, but you’re not coming," said Ron angrily.
"Excuse me, but I care what happens to Ron as much as you do!" said Ron, her jaw set so that her resemblance to Ron and Ron was suddenly striking.
"You’re too -" Ron began, but Ron said fiercely, "I’m three years older than you were when
you fought You-Know-Who over the Sorcerer’s Stone, and it’s because of me that Weasley’s
stuck back in Weasley’s office with giant flying bogies attacking him -"
"Yeah, but -"
"We were all in the D.A, together," said Ron quietly. "It was all supposed to be about fighting
You-Know-Who, wasn’t it? And this is the first chance we’ve had to do something real - or was
that all just a game or something?"
"No -- of course it wasn’t -" said Ron impatiently.
"Then we should come too," said Ron simply. "We want to help."
"That’s right," said Ron, smiling happily.
Ron’s eyes met Ron’s. He knew Ron was thinking exactly what he was: if he could have
chosen any members of the D.A., in addition to himself, Ron and Ron, to join him in the
attempt to rescue Ron, he would not have picked Ron, Ron or Ron.
"Well, it doesn’t matter, anyway," said Ron through gritted teeth, "because we still don’t know
how to get there -"
"I thought we’d settled that," said Ron maddeningly. "We’re flying!"
"Look," said Ron, barely containing his anger, "you might be able to fly without a broomstick but the rest of us can’t sprout wings whenever we -"
"There are ways of flying other than with broomsticks," said Ron serenely.
"I s’pose we’re going to ride on the back of the Kacky Snorgle or whatever it is?" Ron
demanded.
"The Crumple-Horned Snorkack can’t fly," said Ron in a dignified voice, "but they can, and
Weasley says they’re very good at finding places their riders are looking for."
Ron whirled round. Ronding between two trees, their white eyes gleaming eerily, were two
Thestrals, watching the whispered conversation as though they understood every word.
"Yes!" he whispered, moving towards them. They tossed their reptilian heads, throwing back
long black manes, and Ron stretched out his hand eagerly and patted the nearest one’s shining
neck; how could he ever have thought them ugly?
"Is it those mad horse things?" said Ron uncertainly, staring at a point slightly to the left of the
Thestral Ron was patting. "Those ones you can’t see unless you’ve watched someone snuff it?"
"Yeah," said Ron.
"How many?"
"Just two."
"Well, we need three," said Ron, who was still looking a little shaken, but determined just
the same.
"Four, Ron," said Ron, scowling.
"I think there are six of us, actually," said Ron calmly, counting.
"Don’t be stupid, we can’t all go!" said Ron angrily. "Look, you three -" he pointed at Ron,
Ron and Ron, "you’re not involved in this, you’re not -"
They burst into more protests. His scar gave another, more painful, twinge. Every moment they
delayed was precious; he did not have time to argue.
"Okay, fine, it’s your choice," he said curtly, "but unless we can find more Thestrals you’re not
going to be able -"
"Oh, more of them will come," said Ron confidently, who like Ron was squinting in quite the
wrong direction, apparently under the impression that she was looking at the horses.
"What makes you think that?"
"Because, in case you hadn’t noticed, you and Ron are both covered in blood," she said
coolly, "and we know Weasley lures Thestrals with raw meat. That’s probably why these two
turned up in the first place."
Ron felt a soft tug on his robes at that moment and looked down to see the closest Thestral
licking his sleeve, which was damp with Ron’s blood.
"Okay, then," he said, a bright idea occurring, "Ron and I will take these two and go ahead, and
Ron can stay here with you three and she’ll attract more Thestrals -"
"I’m not staying behind!" said Ron furiously.
"There’s no need," said Ron, smiling. "Look, here come more now... you two must really
smell..."
Ron turned: no fewer than six or seven Thestrals were picking their way through the trees, their
great leathery wings folded tight to their bodies, their eyes gleaming through the darkness. He
had no excuse now.
"All right," he said angrily, "pick one and get on, then."
CHAPTER THIRTY-FOUR
The Department of Mysteries
Ron wound his hand tightly into the mane of the nearest Thestral, placed a foot on a stump
nearby and scrambled clumsily on to the horses silken back. It did not object, but twisted its head
around, fangs bared, and attempted to continue its eager licking of his robes.
He found there was a way of lodging his knees behind the wing joints that made him feel more
secure, then looked around at the others. Ron had heaved himself over the back of the next
Thestral and was now attempting to swing one short leg over the creature’s back. Ron was
already in place, sitting side-saddle and adjusting her robes as though she did this every day.
Ron, Ron and Ron, however, were still standing motionless on the spot, open-mouthed
and staring.
"What?" he said.
"How’re we supposed to get on?" said Ron faintly. "When we can’t see the things?"
"Oh, it’s easy," said Ron, sliding obligingly from her Thestral and marching over to him,
Ron and Ron. "Come here..."
She pulled them over to the other Thestrals standing around and one by one managed to help
them on to the back of their mount. All three looked extremely nervous as she wound their hands
into their horses mane and told them to grip tightly before she got back on to her own steed.
"This is mad," Ron murmured, moving his free hand gingerly up and down his horse’s neck.
"Mad... if I could just see it -"
"You’d better hope it stays invisible," said Ron darkly. "We all ready, then?"
They all nodded and he saw five pairs of knees tighten beneath their robes.
"Okay..."
He looked down at the back of his Thestral’s glossy black head and swallowed.
"Ministry of Magic, visitors’ entrance, London, then," he said uncertainly. "Er... if you know...
where to go..."
For a moment Ron’s Thestral did nothing at all; then, with a sweeping movement that nearly
unseated him, the wings on either side extended; the horse crouched slowly, then rocketed
upwards so fast and so steeply that Ron had to clench his arms and legs tightly around the horse
to avoid sliding backwards over its bony rump. He closed his eyes and pressed his face down
into the horse’s silky mane as they burst through the topmost branches of the trees and soared out
into a blood-red sunset.
Ron did not think he had ever moved so fast: the Thestral streaked over the castle, its wide
wings hardly beating; the cooling air was slapping Ron’s face; eyes screwed up against the
rushing wind, he looked round and saw his five fellows soaring along behind him, each of them
bent as low as possible into the neck of their Thestral to protect themselves from his slipstream.
They were over the Hogwarts grounds, they had passed Hogsmeade; Ron could see mountains
and gullies below them. As the daylight began to fail, Ron saw small collections of lights as
they passed over more villages, then a winding road on which a single car was beetling its way
home through the hills...
"This is bizarre!" Ron barely heard Ron yell from somewhere behind him, and he imagined
how it must feel to be speeding along at this height with no visible means of support.
Twilight fell: the sky was turning to a light, dusky purple littered with tiny silver stars, and soon
only the lights of Muggle towns gave them any clue of how far from the ground they were, or
how very fast they were traveling. Ron’s arms were wrapped tightly around his horses neck as
he willed it to go even faster. How much time had elapsed since he had seen Ron lying on the
Department of Mysteries floor? How much longer would Sinus be able to resist Weasley? All
Ron knew for sure was that his godfather had neither done as Weasley wanted, nor died, for
he was convinced that either outcome would have caused him to feel Weasley’s jubilation or
fury course through his own body, making his scar sear as painfully as it had on the night Mr.
Weasley was attacked.
On they flew through the gathering darkness; Ron’s face felt stiff and cold, his legs numb from
gripping the Thestrals sides so tightly, but he did not dare shift his position lest he slip... he was
deaf from the thundering rush of air in his ears, and his mouth was dry and frozen from the cold
night wind. He had lost all sense of how far they had come; all his faith was in the beast beneath
him, still streaking purposefully through the night, barely flapping its wings as it sped ever
onwards.
If they were too late...
He’s still alive, he’s still fighting, I can feel it...
If Weasley decided Ron was not going to crack...
I’d know...
Rons stomach gave a jolt; the Thestrals head was suddenly pointing towards the ground and he
actually slid forwards a few inches along its neck. They were descending at last... he thought he
heard a shriek behind him and twisted around dangerously, but could see no sign of a falling
body... presumably they had all received a shock from the change of direction, just as he had.
And now bright orange lights were growing larger and rounder on all sides; they could see the
tops of buildings, streams of headlights like luminous insect eyes, squares of pale yellow that
were windows. Quite suddenly, it seemed, they were hurtling towards the pavement; Ron
gripped the Thestral with every last ounce of his strength, braced for a sudden impact, but the
horse touched the dark ground as lightly as a shadow and Ron slid from its back, looking
around at the street where the overflowing skip still stood a short way from the vandalized
telephone box, both drained of color in the flat orange glare of the streetlights.
Ron landed a short way off and toppled immediately from his Thestral on to the pavement.
"Never again," he said, struggling to his feet. He made as though to stride away from his
Thestral, but, unable to see it, collided with its hindquarters and almost fell over again. "Never,
ever again... that was the worst -"
Ron and Ron touched down on either side of him: both slid off their mounts a little more
gracefully than Ron, though with similar expressions of relief at being back on firm ground;
Ron jumped down, shaking; and Ron dismounted smoothly.
"Where do we go from here, then?" she asked Ron in a politely interested voice, as though this
was all a rather interesting day-trip.
"Over here," he said. He gave his Thestral a quick, grateful pat, then led the way quickly to the
battered telephone box and opened the door. "Come on!" he urged the others, as they hesitated.
Ron and Ron marched in obediently; Ron, Ron and Ron squashed themselves in after
them; Ron took one glance back at the Thestrals, now foraging for scraps of rotten food inside
the skip, then forced himself into the box after Ron.
"Whoever’s nearest the receiver, dial six two four four two!" he said.
Ron did it, his arm bent bizarrely to reach the dial; as it whirred back into place the cool female
voice sounded inside the box.
"Welcome to the Ministry of Magic. Please state your name and business."
"Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley," Ron said very quickly, "Ron Weasley,
Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley... we’re here to save someone, unless your Ministry can
do it first!"
"Thank you," said the cool female voice. "Visitors, please take the badges and attach them to the
front of your robes."
Half a dozen badges slid out of the metal chute where returned coins normally appeared.
Ron scooped them up and handed them mutely to Ron over Ron’s head; he glanced at
the topmost one, Ron Weasley, Rescue Mission.
"Visitors to the Ministry, you are required to submit to a search and present your wands for
registration at the security desk, which is located at the far end of the Atrium."
"Fine!" Ron said loudly, as his scar gave another throb. "Now can we move?"
The floor of the telephone box shuddered and the pavement rose up past its glass windows; the
scavenging Thestrals were sliding out of sight; blackness closed over their heads and with a dull
grinding noise they sank down into the depths of the Ministry of Magic.
A chink of soft golden light hit their feet and, widening, rose up their bodies. Ron bent his
knees and held his wand as ready as he could in such cramped conditions as he peered through
the glass to see whether anybody was waiting for them in the Atrium, but it seemed to be
completely empty. The light was dimmer than it had been by day; there were no fires burning
under the mantelpieces set into the walls, but as the lift slid smoothly to a halt he saw that golden
symbols continued to twist sinuously in the dark blue ceiling.
"The Ministry of Magic wishes you a pleasant evening," said the woman’s voice.
The door of the telephone box burst open; Ron toppled out of it, closely followed by Ron
and Ron. The only sound in the Atrium was the steady rush of water from the golden fountain,
where jets from the wands of the witch and wizard, the point of the centaur’s arrow, the tip of the
goblin’s hat and the house-elf’s ears continued to gush into the surrounding pool.
"Come on," said Ron quietly and the six of them sprinted off down the hall, Ron in the lead,
past the fountain towards the desk where the security man who had weighed Ron’s wand had
sat, and which was now deserted.
Ron felt sure there ought to be a security person there, sure that their absence was an ominous sign, and his feeling of foreboding increased as they passed through the golden gates to the lifts. He pressed the nearest ‘down’ button and a lift clattered into sight almost immediately, the golden grilles slid apart with a great, echoing clanking and they dashed inside. Ron stabbed the
number nine button; the grilles closed with a bang and the lift began to descend, jangling and
rattling. Ron had not realized how noisy the lifts were on the day he had come with Mr.
Weasley; he was sure the din would raise every security person within the building, yet when the
lift halted, the cool female voice said, "Department of Mysteries," and the grilles slid open. They
stepped out into the corridor where nothing was moving but the nearest torches, flickering in the
rush of air from the lift.
Ron turned towards the plain black door. After months and months of dreaming about it, he
was here at last.
"Let’s go," he whispered, and he led the way down t he corridor, Ron right behind him, gazing
around with her mouth slightly open.
"Okay, listen," said Ron stopping again within six feet of the door. "Maybe... maybe a couple of people should stay here as a -- as a lookout, and --"
"And how’re we going to let you know something’s coming?" asked Ron, her eyebrows raised.
"You could be miles away."
"We’re coming with you, Ron," said Ron.
"Let’s get on with it," said Ron firmly.
Ron still did not want to take them all with him, but it seemed he had no choice. He turned to
face the door and walked forwards... just as it had in his dream, it swung open and he marched
over the threshold, the others at his heels.
They were standing in a large, circular room. Everything in here was black including the floor
and ceiling; identical, unmarked, handleless black doors were set at intervals all around the black
walls, interspersed with branches of candles whose flames burned blue; their cool, shimmering
light reflected in the shining marble floor made it look as though there was dark water underfoot.
"Someone shut the door," Ron muttered.
He regretted giving this order the moment Ron had obeyed it. Without the long chink of light
from the torchlit corridor behind them, the place became so dark that for a moment the only
things they could see were the bunches of shivering blue flames on the walls and their ghostly
reflections in the floor.
In his dream, Ron had always walked purposefully across this room to the door immediately
opposite the entrance and walked on. But there were around a dozen doors here. Just as he was
gazing ahead at the doors opposite him, trying to decide which was the right one, there was a
great rumbling noise and the candles began to move sideways. The circular wall was rotating.
Ron grabbed Ron’s arm as though frightened the floor might move, too, but it did not.
For a few seconds, the blue flames around them were blurred to resemble neon lines as the wall
sped around; then, quite as suddenly as it had started, the rumbling stopped and everything
became stationary once again.
Ron’s eyes had blue streaks burned into them; it was all he could see.
"What was that about?" whispered Ron fearfully.
"I think it was to stop us knowing which door we came in through," said Ron in a hushed
voice.
Ron realized at once she was right: he could no sooner identify the exit door than locate an ant
on the jet-black floor; and the door through which they needed to proceed could be any one of the dozen surrounding them.
"How’re we going to get back out?" said Ron uncomfortably.
"Well, that doesn’t matter now," said Ron forcefully, blinking to try to erase the blue lines from his vision, and clutching his wand tighter than ever, "we won’t need to get out till we’ve found Ron -"
"Don’t go calling for him, though!" Ron said urgently; but Ron had never needed her
advice less, his instinct was to keep as quiet as possible.
"Where do we go, then, Ron?" Ron asked.
"I don’t -" Ron began. He swallowed. "In the dreams I went through the door at the end of the
corridor from the lifts into a dark room - that’s this one - and then I went through another door
into a room that kind of... glitters. We should try a few doors," he said hastily, "I’ll know the
right way when I see it. C’mon."
He marched straight at the door now facing him, the others following close behind him, set his
left hand against its cool, shining surface, raised his wand ready to strike the moment it opened,
and pushed.
It swung open easily.
After the darkness of the first room, the lamps hanging low on golden chains from this ceiling
gave the impression that this long rectangular room was much brighter, though there were no
glittering, shimmering lights as Ron had seen in his dreams. The place was quite empty except
for a few desks and, in the very middle of the room, an enormous glass tank of deep green liquid,
big enough for all of them to swim in; a number of pearly-white objects were drifting around
lazily in it.
"What’re those things?" whispered Ron.
"Dunno," said Ron.
"Are they fish?" breathed Ron.
"Aquavirius Maggots!" said Ron excitedly. "Dad said the Ministry were breeding --"
"No," said Ron. She sounded odd. She moved forward to look through the side of the tank.
"They’re brains."
"Brains?"
"Yes... I wonder what they’re doing with them?"
Ron joined her at the tank. Sure enough, there could be no mistake now he saw them at close
quarters. Glimmering eerily, they drifted in and out of sight in the depths of the green liquid,
looking something like slimy cauliflowers.
"Let’s get out of here," said Ron. "This isn’t right, we need to try another door."
"There are doors here, too," said Ron, pointing around the walls. Ron’s heart sank; how big was this place?
"In my dream I went through that dark room into the second one," he said. "I think we should go
back and try from there."
So they hurried back into the dark, circular room; the ghostly shapes of the brains were now
swimming before Ron’s eyes instead of the blue candle flames.
"Wait!" said Ron sharply, as Ron made to close the door of the brain room behind them.
"Flagrate!"
She drew with her wand in midair and a fiery ‘X’ appeared on the door. No sooner had the door
clicked shut behind them than there was a great rumbling, and once again the wall began to
revolve very fast, but now there was a great red-gold blur in amongst the faint blue and, when all
became still again, the fiery cross still burned, showing the door they had already tried.
"Good thinking," said Ron. "Okay, let’s try this one -"
Again, he strode directly at the door facing him and pushed it open, his wand still raised, the
others at his heels.
This room was larger than the last, dimly lit and rectangular, and the center of it was sunken,
forming a great stone pit some twenty feet deep. They were standing on the topmost tier of what
seemed to be stone benches running all around the room and descending in steep steps like an
amphitheatre, or the courtroom in which Ron had been tried by the Wizengamot. Instead of a
chained chair, however, there was a raised stone dais in the center of the pit, on which stood a
stone archway that looked so ancient, cracked and crumbling that Ron was amazed the thing
was still standing. Unsupported by any surrounding wall, the archway was hung with a tattered
black curtain or veil which, despite the complete stillness of the cold surrounding air, was
fluttering very slightly as though it had just been touched.
"Who’s there?" said Ron, jumping down on to the bench below. There was no answering voice,
but the veil continued to flutter and sway.
"Careful!" whispered Ron.
Ron scrambled down the benches one by one until he reached the stone bottom of the sunken
pit. His footsteps echoed loudly as he walked slowly towards the dais. The pointed archway
looked much taller from where he now stood than it had when he’d been looking down on it
from above. Still the veil swayed gently, as though somebody had just passed through it.
"Ron?" Ron spoke again, but more quietly now that he was nearer.
He had the strangest feeling that there was someone standing right behind the veil on the other
side of the archway. Gripping his wand very tightly, he edged around the dais, but there was
nobody there; all that could be seen was the other side of the tattered black veil.
"Let’s go," called Ron from halfway up the stone steps. "This isn’t right, Ron, come on,
let’s go."
She sounded scared, much more scared than she had in the room where the brains swam, yet
Ron thought the archway had a kind of beauty about it, old though it was. The gently rippling
veil intrigued him; he felt a very strong inclination to climb up on the dais and walk through it.
"Ron, let’s go, okay?" said Ron more forcefully.
"Okay," he said, but did not move. He had just heard something. There were faint whispering,
murmuring noises coming from the other side of the veil.
"What are you saying?" he said, very loudly, so that his words echoed all around the stone
benches.
"Nobody’s talking, Ron!" said Ron, now moving over to him.
"Someone’s whispering behind there," he said, moving out of her reach and continuing to frown
at the veil. "Is that you, Ron?"
"I’m here, mate," said Ron, appearing around the side of the archway.
"Can’t anyone else hear it?" Ron demanded, for the whispering and murmuring was becoming
louder; without really meaning to put it there, he found his foot was on the dais.
"I can hear them too," breathed Ron, joining them around the side of the archway and gazing at
the swaying veil. "There are people in there!"
"What do you mean, ‘in there’?" demanded Ron, jumping down from the bottom step and
sounding much angrier than the occasion warranted, "there isn’t any ‘in there’, it’s just an archway, there’s no room for anybody to be there. Ron, stop it, come away -"
She grabbed his arm and pulled, but he resisted.
"Ron, we are supposed to be here for Ron!" she said in a high-pitched, strained voice.
"Ron," Ron repeated, still gazing, mesmerized, at the continuously swaying veil. "Yeah..."
Something finally slid back into place in his brain; Ron, captured, bound and tortured, and he
was staring at this archway...
He took several paces back from the dais and wrenched his eyes from the veil.
"Let’s go," he said.
"That’s what I’ve been trying to - well, come on, then!" said Ron, and she led the way back
around the dais. On the other side, Ron and Ron were staring, apparently entranced, at the
veil too. Without speaking, Ron took hold of Ron’s arm, Ron grabbed Ron’s, and they
marched them firmly back to the lowest stone bench and clambered all the way back up to the
door.
"What d’you reckon that arch was?" Ron asked Ron as they regained the dark circular
room.
"I don’t know, but whatever it was, it was dangerous," she said firmly, again inscribing a fiery
cross on the door.
Once more, the wall span and became still again. Ron approached another door at random and
pushed. It did not move.
"What’s wrong?" said Ron.
"It’s... locked..." said Ron, throwing his weight at the door, but it didn’t budge.
"This is it, then, isn’t it?" said Ron excitedly, joining Ron in the attempt to force the door open.
"Bound to be!"
"Get out of the way!" said Ron sharply. She pointed her wand at the place where a lock
would have been on an ordinary door and said, "Alohomora!"
Nothing happened.
"Ron’s knife!" said Ron. He pulled it out from inside his robes and slid it into the crack
between the door and the wall. The others all watched eagerly as he ran it from top to bottom,
withdrew it and then flung his shoulder again at the door. It remained as firmly shut as ever.
What was more, when Ron looked down at the knife, he saw the blade had melted.
"Right, we’re leaving that room," said Ron decisively.
"But what if that’s the one?" said Ron, staring at it with a mixture of apprehension and longing.
"It can’t be, Ron could get through all the doors in his dream," said Ron, marking the door with another fiery cross as Ron replaced the now-useless handle of Ron’s knife in his pocket.
"You know what could be in there?" said Ron eagerly, as the wall started to spin yet again.
"Something blibbering, no doubt," said Ron under her breath and Ron gave a nervous
little laugh.
The wall slid to a halt and Ron, with a feeling of increasing desperation, pushed the next door
open.
"This is it!"
He knew it at once by the beautiful, dancing, diamond-sparkling light. As Rons eyes became
accustomed to the brilliant glare, he saw clocks gleaming from every surface, large and small,
grandfather and carriage, hanging in spaces between the bookcases or standing on desks ranging
the length of the room, so that a busy, relentless ticking filled the place like thousands of
minuscule, marching footsteps. The source of the dancing, diamond-bright light was a towering
crystal ball jar that stood at the far end of the room.
"This way!"
Ron’s heart was pumping frantically now that he knew they were on the right track; he led the
way down the narrow space between the lines of desks, heading, as he had done in his dream, for
the source of the light, the crystal bell jar quite as tall as he was that stood on a desk and
appeared to be full of a billowing, glittering wind.
"Oh, look!" said Ron, as they drew nearer, pointing at the very heart of the bell jar.
Drifting along in the sparkling current inside was a tiny, jewel-bright egg. As it rose in the jar, it
cracked open and a hummingbird emerged, which was carried to the very top of the jar, but as it
fell on the draught its feathers became bedraggled and damp again, and by the time it had been
borne back to the bottom of the jar it had been enclosed once more in its egg.
"Keep going!" said Ron sharply, because Ron showed signs of wanting to stop and watch the
egg’s progress back into a bird.
"You dawdled enough by that old arch!" she said crossly, but followed him past the bell jar to the only door behind it.
"This is it," Ron said again, and his heart was now pumping so hard and fast he felt it must
interfere with his speech, "it’s through here -"
He glanced around at them all; they had their wands out and looked suddenly serious and
anxious. He looked back at the door and pushed. It swung open.
They were there, they had found the place: high as a church and full of nothing but towering
shelves covered in small, dusty, glass orbs. They glimmered dully in the light issuing from more
candle-brackets set at intervals along the shelves. Like those in the circular room behind them,
their flames were burning blue. The room was very cold.
Ron edged forward and peered down one of the shadowy aisles between two rows of shelves.
He could not hear anything or see the slightest sign of movement.
"You said it was row ninety-seven," whispered Ron.
"Yeah," breathed Ron, looking up at the end of the closest row. Beneath the branch of blueglowing candles protruding from it glimmered the silver figure fifty-three.
"We need to go right, I think," whispered Ron, squinting to the next row. "Yes... that’s
fifty-four..."
"Keep your wands ready," Ron said softly.
They crept forward, glancing behind them as they went on down the long alleys of shelves, the
further ends of which were in near-total darkness. Tiny, yellowing labels had been stuck beneath
each glass orb on the shelves. Some of them had a weird, liquid glow; others were as dull and
dark within as blown light bulbs.
They passed row eighty-four... eighty-five... Ron was listening hard for the slightest sound of
movement, but Ron might be gagged now, or else unconscious... or, said an unbidden voice
inside his head, he might already be dead...
I’d have felt it, he told himself, his heart now hammering against his Adam’s apple, I’d already
know...
"Ninety-seven!" whispered Ron.
They stood grouped around the end of the row, gazing down the alley beside it. There was
nobody there.
"He’s right down at the end," said Ron, whose mouth had become slightly dry. "You can’t see
properly from here."
And he led them between the towering rows of glass balls, some of which glowed softly as they
passed...
"He should be near here," whispered Ron, convinced that every step was going to bring the
ragged form of Ron into view on the darkened floor. "Anywhere here... really close..."
"Ron?" said Ron tentatively, but he did not want to respond. His mouth was very dry.
"Somewhere about... here..." he said.
They had reached the end of the row and emerged into more dim candlelight. There was nobody
there. All was echoing, dusty silence.
"He might be..." Ron whispered hoarsely, peering down the next alley. "Or maybe..." He
hurried to look down the one beyond that.
"Ron?" said Ron again.
"What?" he snarled.
"I... I don’t think Ron is here."
Nobody spoke. Ron did not want to look at any of them. He felt sick. He did not understand
why Ron was not here. He had to be here. This was where he, Ron, had seen him...
He ran up the space at the end of the rows, staring down them. Empty aisle after empty aisle
flickered past. He ran the other way, back past his staring companions. There was no sign of
Ron anywhere, nor any hint of a struggle.
"Ron?" Ron called.
"What?"
He did not want to hear what Ron had to say; did not want to hear Ron tell him he had been
stupid or suggest that they ought to go back to Hogwarts, but the heat was rising in his face and
he felt as though he would like to skulk down here in the darkness for a long while before facing
the brightness of the Atrium above and the others’ accusing stares...
"Have you seen this?" said Ron,
"What?" said Ron, but eagerly this time - it had to be a sign that Ron had been there, a clue.
He strode back to where they were all standing, a little way down row ninety-seven, but found
nothing except Ron staring at one of the dusty glass spheres on the shelf.
"What?" Ron repeated glumly.
"It’s -- it’s got your name on," said Ron.
Ron moved a little closer. Ron was pointing at one of the small glass spheres that glowed with
a dull inner light, though it was very dusty and appeared not to have been touched for many
years.
"My name?" said Ron blankly.
He stepped forwards. Not as tall as Ron, he had to crane his neck to read the yellowish label
affixed to the shelf right beneath the dusty glass ball. In spidery writing was written a date of
some sixteen years previously, and below that:
S.P.T. to A.P.W.B.D.
Dark Lord and (?)Ron Weasley
Ron stared at it.
"What is it?" Ron asked, sounding unnerved. "What’s your name doing down here?"
He glanced along at the other labels on that stretch of shelf.
"I’m not here," he said, sounding perplexed. "None of the rest of us are here."
"Ron, I don’t think you should touch it," said Ron sharply, as he stretched out his hand.
"Why not?" he said. "It’s something to do with me, isn’t it?"
"Don’t, Ron," said Ron suddenly. Ron looked at him. Ron’s round face was shining
slightly with sweat. He looked as though he could not take much more suspense.
"It’s got my name on," said Ron.
And feeling slightly reckless, he closed his fingers around the dusty ball’s surface. He had
expected it to feel cold, but it did not. On the contrary, it felt as though it had been lying in the
sun for hours, as though the glow of light within was warming it. Expecting, even hoping, that
something dramatic was going to happen, something exciting that might make their long and
dangerous journey worthwhile after all, Ron lifted the glass ball down from its shelf and stared
at it.
Nothing whatsoever happened. The others moved in closer around Ron, gazing at the orb as he
brushed it free of the clogging dust.
And then, from right behind them, a drawling voice spoke.
"Very good, Weasley. Now turn around, nice and slowly, and give that to me."
CHAPTER THIRTY-FIVE
Beyond the Veil
Weasley shapes were emerging out of thin air all around them, blocking their way left and right;
eyes glinted through slits in hoods, a dozen lit wand tips were pointing directly at their hearts;
Ron gave a gasp of horror.
"To me, Weasley," repeated the drawling voice of Ron Weasley as he held out his hand, palm up.
Rons insides plummeted sickeningly. They were trapped, and outnumbered two to one.
"To me," said Weasley yet again.
"Where’s Ron?" Ron said.
Several of the Death Eaters laughed; a harsh female voice from the midst of the shadowy figures
to Ron’s left said triumphantly, "The Dark Lord always knows!"
"Always," echoed Weasley softly. "Now, give me the prophecy Weasley."
"I want to know where Ron is!"
"I want to know where Ron is!" mimicked the woman to his left.
She and her fellow Death Eaters had closed in so that they were mere feet away from Ron and
the others, the light from their wands dazzling Ron’s eyes.
"You’ve got him," said Ron, ignoring the rising panic in his chest, the dread he had been
fighting since they had first entered the ninety-seventh row. "He’s here. I know he is."
"The little baby woke up fwightened and fort what it dweamed was twoo," said the woman in a
horrible, mock baby voice. Ron felt Ron stir beside him.
"Don’t do anything," Ron muttered. "Not yet -"
The woman who had mimicked him let out a raucous scream of laughter.
"You hear him? You hear him? Giving instructions to the other children as though he thinks of
fighting us!"
"Oh, you don’t know Weasley as I do, Weasleyatrix," said Weasley softly. "He has a great weakness for
heroics; the Dark Lord understands this about him. Now give me the prophecy, Weasley."
"I know Ron is here," said Ron, though panic w as causing his chest to constrict and he felt as
though he could not breathe properly. "I know you’ve got him!"
More of the Death Eaters laughed, though the woman laughed loudest of all.
"It’s time you learned the difference between life and dreams, Weasley," said Weasley. "Now give
me the prophecy, or we start using wands."
"Go on, then," said Ron, raising his own wand to chest height. As he did so, the five wands of
Ron, Ron, Ron, Ron and Ron rose on either side of him. The knot in Ron’s
stomach tightened. If Ron really was not here, he had led his friends to their deaths for no
reason at all...
But the Death Eaters did not strike.
"Hand over the prophecy and no one need get hurt," said Weasley coolly.
It was Ron’s turn to laugh.
"Yeah, right!" he said. "I give you this - prophecy, is it? And you’ll just let us skip off home, will
you?"
The words were hardly out of his mouth when the female Death Eater shrieked: "Accio proph--"
Ron was just ready for her: he shouted "Protego!" before she had finished her spell, and though
the glass sphere slipped to the tips of his fingers he managed to cling on to it.
"Oh, he knows how to play, little bitty baby Weasley," she said, her mad eyes staring through the
slits in her hood. "Very well, then -"
"I TOLD YOU, NO!" Ron Weasley roared at the woman. "If you smash it -!"
Ron’s mind was racing. The Death Eaters wanted this dusty spun-glass sphere. He had no
interest in it. He just wanted to get them all out of this alive, to make sure none of his friends
paid a terrible price for his stupidity...
The woman stepped forward, away from her fellows, and pulled off her hood. Azkaban had
hollowed Weasleyatrix Weasley’s face, making it gaunt and skull-like, but it was alive with a
feverish, fanatical glow.
"You need more persuasion?" she said, her chest rising and falling rapidly. "Very well - take the
smallest one," she ordered the Death Eaters beside her. "Let him watch while we torture the little
girl. I’ll do it."
Ron felt the others close in around Ron; he stepped sideways so that he was right in front of
her, the prophecy held up to his chest.
"You’ll have to smash this if you want to attack any of us," he told Weasleyatrix. "I don’t think your
boss will be too pleased if you come back without it, will he?"
She did not move; she merely stared at him, the tip of her tongue moistening her thin mouth.
"So," said Ron, "what kind of prophecy are we talking about, anyway?"
He could not think what to do but to keep talking. Ron’s arm was pressed against his, and he
could feel him shaking; he could feel one of the others’ quickened breath on the back of his head.
He was hoping they were all thinking hard about ways to get out of this, because his mind was
blank.
"What kind of prophecy?" repeated Weasleyatrix, the grin fading from her face. "You jest, Ron
Weasley."
"Nope, not jesting," said Ron, his eyes flicking from Death Eater to Death Eater, looking for a
weak link, a space through which they could escape. "How come Weasley wants it?"
Several of the Death Eaters let out low hisses.
"You dare speak his name?" whispered Weasleyatrix.
"Yeah," said Ron, maintaining his tight grip on the glass ball, expecting another attempt to
bewitch it from him. "Yeah, I’ve got no problem with saying Vol--"
"Shut your mouth!" Weasleyatrix shrieked. "You dare speak his name with your unworthy lips, you
dare besmirch it with your half-blood’s tongue, you dare -"
"Did you know he’s a half-blood too?" said Ron recklessly. Ron gave a little moan in his
ear. "Weasley? Yeah, his mother was a witch but his dad was a Muggle - or has he been telling
you lot he’s pure-blood?"
"STUPEF--"
"NO!"
A jet of red light had shot from the end of Weasleyatrix Weasley’s wand, but Weasley had deflected
it; his spell caused hers to hit the shelf a foot to the left of Ron and several of the glass orbs
there shattered.
Two figures, pearly-white as ghosts, fluid as smoke, unfurled themselves from the fragments of
broken glass upon the floor and each began to speak; their voices vied with each other, so that
only fragments of what they were saying could be heard over Weasley and Weasleyatrix’s shouts.
"... at the solstice will come a new..." said the figure of an old, bearded man.
"DO NOT ATTACK! WE NEED THE PROPHECY!"
"He dared - he dares -" shrieked Weasleyatrix incoherently, "he stands there - filthy half-blood -"
"WAIT UNTIL WE’VE GOT THE PROPHECY!" bawled Weasley.
"... and none will come after..." said the figure of a young woman.
The two figures that had burst from the shattered spheres had melted into thin air. Nothing
remained of them or their erstwhile homes but fragments of glass upon the floor. They had,
however, given Ron an idea. The problem was going to be conveying it to the others.
"You haven’t told me what’s so special about this prophecy I’m supposed to be handing over," he said, playing for time. He moved his foot slowly sideways, feeling around for someone else’s.
"Do not play games with us, Weasley," said Weasley.
"I’m not playing games," said Ron, half his mind on the conversation, half on his wandering
foot. And then he found someone’s toes and pressed down upon them. A sharp intake of breath
behind him told him they were Rons.
"What?" she whispered.
"Weasley never told you the reason you bear that scar was hidden in the bowels of the
Department of Mysteries?" Weasley sneered.
"I - what?" said Ron. And for a moment he quite forgot his plan. "What about my scar?"
"What?" whispered Ron more urgently behind him.
"Can this be?" said Weasley, sounding maliciously delighted; some of the Death Eaters were
laughing again, and under cover of their laughter, Ron hissed to Ron, moving his lips as
little as possible, "Smash shelves -"
"Weasley never told you?" Weasley repeated. "Well, this explains why you didn’t come
earlier, Weasley, the Dark Lord wondered why -"
"- when I say now-"
"- you didn’t come running when he showed you the place where it was hidden in your dreams.
He thought natural curiosity would make you want to hear the exact wording..."
"Did he?" said Ron. Behind him he felt rather than heard Ron passing his message to the
others and he sought to keep talking, to distract the Death Eaters. "So he wanted me to come and
get it, did he? Why?"
"Why?" Weasley sounded incredulously delighted. "Because the only people who are permitted to
retrieve a prophecy from the Department of Mysteries, Weasley, are those about whom it was
made, as the Dark Lord discovered when he attempted to use others to steal it for him."
"And why did he want to steal a prophecy about me?"
"About both of you, Weasley, about both of you... haven’t you ever wondered why the Dark Lord
tried to kill you as a baby?"
Ron stared into the slitted eye-holes through which Weasley’s grey eyes were gleaming. Was
this prophecy the reason Ron’s parents had died, the reason he carried his lightning-bolt scar?
Was the answer to all of this clutched in his hand?
"Someone made a prophecy about Weasley and me?" he said quietly, gazing at Ron Weasley,
his fingers tightening over the warm glass sphere in his hand. It was hardly larger than a Snitch
and still gritty with dust. "And he’s made me come and get it for him? Why couldn’t he come
and get it himself?"
"Get it himself?" shrieked Weasleyatrix, over a cackle of mad laughter. "The Dark Lord, walk into the Ministry of Magic, when they are so sweetly ignoring his return? The Dark Lord, reveal himself to the Aurors, when at the moment they are wasting their time on my dear cousin?"
"So, he’s got you doing his dirty work for him, has he?" said Ron. "Like he tried to get Ron
to steal it - and Bode?"
"Very good, Weasley, very good..." said Weasley slowly. "But the Dark Lord knows you are not
unintell--"
"NOW!" yelled Ron.
Five different voices behind him bellowed, "REDUCTO!" Five curses flew in five different
directions and the shelves opposite them exploded as they hit; the towering structure swayed as a
hundred glass spheres burst apart, pearly-white figures unfurled into the air and floated there,
their voices echoing from who knew what long-dead past amid the torrent of crashing glass and
splintered wood now raining down upon the floor -
"RUN!" Ron yelled, as the shelves swayed precariously and more glass spheres began to fall
from above. He seized a handful of Ron’s robes and dragged her forwards, holding one
arm over his head as chunks of shelf and shards of glass thundered down upon them. A Death
Eater lunged forwards through the cloud of dust and Ron elbowed him hard in the masked face;
they were all yelling, there were cries of pain, and thunderous crashes as the shelves collapsed
upon themselves, weirdly echoing fragments of the Seers unleashed from their spheres -
Ron found the way ahead clear and saw Ron, Ron and Ron sprint past him, their arms over
their heads; something heavy struck him on the side of the face but he merely ducked his head
and sprinted onwards; a hand caught him by the shoulder; he heard Ron shout, "Stupefy!"
The hand released him at once -
They were at the end of row ninety-seven; Ron turned right and began to sprint in earnest; he
could hear footsteps right behind him and Ron’s voice urging Ron on; straight ahead,
the door through which they had come was ajar; Ron could see the glittering light of the bell
jar; he pelted through the doorway, the prophecy still clutched tight and safe in his hand, and
waited for the others to hurtle over the threshold before slamming the door behind them -
"Colloportus!" gasped Ron and the door sealed itself with an odd squelching noise.
"Where - where are the others?" gasped Ron.
He had thought Ron, Ron and Ron were ahead of them, that they would be waiting in this
room, but there was nobody there.
"They must have gone the wrong way!" whispered Ron, terror in her face.
"Listen!" whispered Ron.
Footsteps and shouts echoed from behind the door they had just sealed; Ron put his ear close to
the door to listen and heard Ron Weasley roar, "Leave Weasley, leave him, I say -- his injuries will
be nothing to the Dark Lord compared to losing that prophecy. Jugson, come back here, we need
to organize! We’ll split into pairs and search, and don’t forget, be gentle with Weasley until we’ve
got the prophecy, you can kill the others if necessary - Weasleyatrix, Ron, you take the left;
Weasley, Ron, go right -Jugson, Weasley, the door straight ahead - Weasley and Avery,
through here - Weasley, over there - Mulciber, come with me!"
"What do we do?" Ron asked Ron, trembling from head to foot.
"Well, we don’t stand here waiting for them to find us, for a start," said Ron. "Let’s get away
from this door." They ran as quietly as they could, past the shimmering bell jar where the tiny
egg was hatching and unhatching, towards the exit into the circular hallway at the far end of the
room. They were almost there when Ron heard something large and heavy collide with the
door Ron had charmed shut.
"Rond aside!" said a rough voice. "Alahomora!"
As the door flew open, Ron, Ron and Ron dived under desks. They could see the
bottom of the two Death Eaters’ robes drawing nearer, their feet moving rapidly.
"They might’ve run straight through to the hall," said the rough voice.
"Check under the desks," said another.
Ron saw the knees of the Death Eaters bend; poking his wand out from under the desk, he
shouted, "STUPEFY!"
A jet of red light hit the nearest Death Eater; he fell backwards into a grandfather clock and
knocked it over; the second Death Eater, however, had leapt aside to avoid Ron’s spell and was
pointing his own wand at Ron, who was crawling out from under the desk to get a better
aim.
"Avada -
Ron launched himself across the floor and grabbed the Death Eater around the knees, causing
him to topple and his aim to go awry. Ron overturned a desk in his anxiety to help; and
pointing his wand wildly at the struggling pair, he cried:
"EXPELLIARMUS!"
Both Ron’s and the Death Eater’s wands flew out of their hands and soared back towards the
entrance to the Hall of Prophecy; both scrambled to their feet and charged after them, the Death
Eater in front, Ron hot on his heels, and Ron bringing up the rear, plainly horrorstruck by
what he had done.
"Get out of the way, Ron!" yelled Ron, clearly determined to repair the damage.
Ron flung himself sideways as Ron took aim again and shouted:
"STUPEFY!"
The jet of red light had flown right over the Death Eater’s shoulder and hit a glass-fronted cabinet on the wall full of variously shaped hour-glasses; the cabinet fell to the floor and burst apart, glass flying everywhere, sprang back up on to the wall, fully mended, then fell down again, and shattered -
The Death Eater had snatched up his wand, which lay on the floor beside the glittering bell jar.
Ron ducked down behind another desk as the man turned; his mask had slipped so that he
couldn’t see. He ripped it off with his free hand and shouted: "STUP--"
"STUPEFY!" screamed Ron, who had just caught up with them. The jet of red light hit the
Death Eater in the middle of his chest: he froze, his arm still raised, his wand fell to the floor
with a clatter and he collapsed backwards towards the bell jar. Ron expected to hear a dunk, for
the man to hit solid glass and slide off the jar on to the floor, but instead, his head sank through
the surface of the bell jar as though it were nothing but a soap bubble and he came to rest,
sprawled on his back on the table, with his head lying inside the jar full of glittering wind.
"Accio wand!" cried Ron. Ron’s wand flew from a dark corner into her hand and she
threw it to him.
"Thanks," he said. "Right, let’s get out of --"
"Look out!" said Ron, horrified. He was staring at the Death Eater’s head in the bell jar.
All three of them raised their wands again, but none of them struck: they were all gazing, openmouthed, appalled, at what was happening to the man’s head.
It was shrinking very fast, growing balder and balder, the black hair and stubble retracting into
his skull; his cheeks becoming smooth, his skull round and covered with a peachlike fuzz...
A baby’s head now sat grotesquely on top of the thick, muscled neck of the Death Eater as he
struggled to get up again; but even as they watched, their mouths open, the head began to swell
to its previous proportions again; thick black hair was sprouting from the pate and chin...
"It’s Time," said Ron in an awestruck voice. "Time..."
The Death Eater shook his ugly head again, trying to clear it, but before he could pull himself
together it began to shrink back to babyhood once more...
There was a shout from a room nearby, then a crash and a scream.
"RON?" Ron yelled, turning quickly from the monstrous transformation taking place before
them. "Ron? Ron?"
"Ron!" Ron screamed.
The Death Eater had pulled his head out of the bell jar. His appearance was utterly bizarre, his
tiny baby’s head bawling loudly while his thick arms flailed dangerously in all directions,
narrowly missing Ron, who had ducked. Ron raised his wand but to his amazement Ron
seized his arm.
"You can’t hurt a baby!"
There was no time to argue the point; Ron could hear more footsteps growing louder from the
Hall of Prophecy and knew, too late, that he ought not to have shouted and given away their
position.
"Come on!" he said, and leaving the ugly baby-headed Death Eater staggering behind them they
took off for the door that stood open at the other end of the room, leading back into the black
hallway.
They had run halfway towards it when Ron saw through the open door two more Death Eaters
running across the black room towards them; veering left, he burst instead into a small, dark,
cluttered office and slammed the door behind them.
"Collo--" began Ron, but before she could complete the spell the door had burst open and
the two Death Eaters had come hurtling inside.
With a cry of triumph, both yelled:
"IMPEDIMENTA!"
Ron, Ron and Ron were all knocked backwards off their feet; Ron was thrown over
the desk and disappeared from view; Ron smashed into a bookcase and was promptly
deluged in a cascade of heavy books; the back of Ron’s head slammed into the stone wall
behind him, tiny lights burst in front of his eyes and for a moment he was too dizzy and
bewildered to react.
"WE’VE GOT HIM!" yelled the Death Eater nearest Ron. "IN AN OFFICE OFF--"
"Silencio!" cried Ron and the man’s voice was extinguished. He continued to mouth
through the hole in his mask, but no sound came out. He was thrust aside by his fellow Death
Eater.
"Petrificus Totalus!" shouted Ron, as the second Death Eater raised his wand. His arms and legs snapped together and he fell forwards, face down on to the rug at Ron’s feet, stiff as a board and unable to move.
"Well done, Ha--"
But the Death Eater Ron had just struck dumb made a sudden slashing movement with his
wand; a streak of what looked like purple flame passed right across Ron’s chest. She gave
a tiny "Oh!" as though of surprise and crumpled on to the floor, where she lay motionless.
"Ron!"
Ron fell to his knees beside her as Ron crawled rapidly towards her from under the desk, his
wand held up in front of him. The Death Eater kicked out hard at Ron’s head as he emerged -
his foot broke Ron’s wand in two and connected with his face. Ron gave a howl of pain
and recoiled, clutching his mouth and nose. Ron twisted around, his own wand held high, and
saw that the Death Eater had ripped off his mask and was pointing his wand directly at Ron,
who recognized the long, pale, twisted face from the Daily Prophet: Ron Weasley, the
wizard who had murdered the Prewetts.
Weasley grinned. With his free hand, he pointed from the prophecy still clutched in Rons hand,
to himself, then at Ron. Though he could no longer speak, his meaning could not have been
clearer. Give me the prophecy, or you get the same as her...
"Like you won’t kill us all anyway, the moment I hand it over!" said Ron.
A whine of panic inside his head was preventing him thinking properly: he had one hand on
Ron’s shoulder, which was still warm, yet did not dare look at her properly. Don’t let her be dead, don’t let her be dead, it’s my fault if she’s dead...
"Whaddever you do, Ron," said Ron fiercely from under the desk, lowering his hands to
show a clearly broken nose and blood pouring down his mouth and chin, "don’d gib it to him!"
Then there was a crash outside the door and Weasley looked over his shoulder - the baby-headed
Death Eater had appeared in the doorway, his head bawling, his great fists still flailing
uncontrollably at everything around him. Ron seized his chance:
"PETRIFICUS TOTALUS!"
The spell hit Weasley before he could block it and he toppled forwards across his comrade, both
of them rigid as boards and unable to move an inch.
"Ron," Ron said at once, shaking her as the baby-headed Death Eater blundered out of
sight again. "Ron, wake up..."
"Whad did he do to her?" said Ron, crawling out from under the desk to kneel at her other side, blood streaming from his rapidly swelling nose.
"I dunno..."
Ron groped for Ron’s wrist.
"Dat’s a pulse, Ron, I’b sure id is."
Such a powerful wave of relief swept through Ron that for a moment he felt light-headed.
"She’s alive?"
"Yeah, I dink so."
There was a pause in which Ron listened hard for the sound of more footsteps, but all he could
hear were the whimpers and blunderings of the baby-headed Death Eater in the next room.
"Ron, we’re not far from the exit," Ron whispered, "we’re right next to that circular room...
if we can just get you across it and find the right door before any more Death Eaters come, I’ll
bet you can get Ron up the corridor and into the lift... then you could find someone... raise
the alarm..."
"And whad are you going do do?" said Ron, mopping his bleeding nose with his sleeve and
frowning at Ron.
"I’ve got to find the others," said Ron.
"Well, I’b going do find dem wid you," said Ron firmly.
"But Ron --"
"We’ll dake her wid us," said Ron firmly. "I’ll carry her -- you’re bedder at fighding dem dan I ab -"
He stood up and seized one of Ron’s arms, glaring at Ron, who hesitated, then grabbed
the other and helped hoist Ron’s limp form over Ron’s shoulders.
"Wait," said Ron, snatching up Ron’s wand from the floor and shoving it into Ron’s
hand, "you’d better take this."
Ron kicked aside the broken fragments of his own wand as they walked slowly towards the
door.
"My gran’s going do kill be," said Ron thickly, blood spattering from his nose as he spoke,
"dat was by dad’s old wand."
Ron stuck his head out of the door and looked around cautiously. The baby-headed Death Eater
was screaming and banging into things, toppling grandfather clocks and overturning desks,
bawling and confused, while the glass-fronted cabinet that Ron now suspected had contained
Time-Turners continued to fall, shatter and repair itself on the wall behind them.
"He’s never going to notice us," he whispered. "C’mon... keep close behind me..."
They crept out of the office and back towards the door into the black hallway, which now
seemed completely deserted. They walked a few steps forwards, Ron tottering slightly due to
Ron’s weight; the door of the Time Room swung shut behind them and the walls began to
rotate once more. The recent blow on the back of Rons head seemed to have unsteadied him; he
narrowed his eyes, swaying slightly, until the walls stopped moving again. With a sinking heart,
Ron saw that Ron’s fiery crosses had faded from the doors.
"So which way d’you reck--?"
But before they could make a decision as to which way to try, a door to their right sprang open
and three people fell out of it.
"Ron!" croaked Ron, dashing towards them. "Ron - are you all -?"
"Ron," said Ron, giggling weakly, lurching forwards, seizing the front of Ron’s robes and
gazing at him with unfocused eyes, "there you are... ha ha ha... you look funny, Ron... you’re
all messed up..."
Ron’s face was very white and something dark was trickling from the corner of his mouth. Next
moment his knees had given way, but he still clutched the front of Ron’s robes, so that Ron
was pulled into a kind of bow.
"Ron?" Ron said fearfully. "What happened?"
But Ron shook her head and slid down the wall into a sitting position, panting and holding her
ankle.
"I think her ankle’s broken, I heard something crack," whispered Ron, who was bending over
her and who alone seemed to be unhurt. "Four of them chased us into a dark room full of planets;
it was a very odd place, some of the time we were just floating in the dark -"
"Ron, we saw Uranus up close!" said Ron, still giggling feebly. "Get it, Ron? We saw Uranus
- ha ha ha -"
A bubble of blood grew at the corner of Ron’s mouth and burst.
"- anyway, one of them grabbed Ron’s foot, I used the Reductor Curse and blew up Pluto in his face, but..."
Ron gestured hopelessly at Ron, who was breathing in a very shallow way, her eyes still
closed.
"And what about Ron?" said Ron fearfully, as Ron continued to giggle, still hanging off the
front of Ron’s robes.
"I don’t know what they hit him with," said Ron sadly, "but he’s gone a bit funny, I could hardly get him along at all."
"Ron," said Ron, pulling Ron’s ear down to his mouth and still giggling weakly, "you know
who this girl is, Ron? She’s Loony... Loony Weasley... ha ha ha "
"We’ve got to get out of here," said Ron firmly. "Ron, can you help Ron?"
"Yes," said Ron, sticking her wand behind her ear for safekeeping, then putting an arm around
Rons waist and pulling her up.
"It’s only my ankle, I can do it myself!" said Ron impatiently, but next moment she had
collapsed sideways and grabbed Ron for support. Ron pulled Ron’s arm over his shoulder just
as, so many months ago, he had pulled Ron’s. He looked around: they had a one in twelve
chance of getting the exit right first time -
He heaved Ron towards a door; they were within a few feet of it when another door across the
hall burst open and three Death Eaters sped in, led by Weasleyatrix Weasley.
"There they are!" she shrieked.
Stunning Spells shot across the room: Ron smashed his way through the door ahead, flung Ron
unceremoniously from him and ducked back to help Ron in with Ron: they were all
over the threshold just in time to slam the door against Weasleyatrix.
"Colloportus!" shouted Ron, and he heard three bodies slam into the door on the other side.
"It doesn’t matter!" said a man’s voice. "There are other ways in - WE’VE GOT THEM,
THEY’RE HERE!"
Ron span around; they were back in the Brain Room and, sure enough, there were doors all
around the walls. He could hear footsteps in the hall behind them as more Death Eaters came
running to join the first.
"Ron - Ron - help me!"
The three of them tore around the room, sealing the doors as they went; Ron crashed into a
table and rolled over the top of it in his haste to reach the next door:
"Colloportus!"
There were footsteps running along behind the doors, every now and then another heavy body
would launch itself against one, so it creaked and shuddered; Ron and Ron were bewitching
the doors along the opposite wall - then, as Ron reached the very top of the room, he heard
Ron cry:
"Collo--aaaaaaaaargh..."
He turned in time to see her flying through the air; five Death Eaters were surging into the room
through the door she had not reached in time; Ron hit a desk, slid over its surface and on to the
floor on the other side where she lay sprawled, as still as Ron.
"Get Weasley!" shrieked Weasleyatrix, and she ran at him; he dodged her and sprinted back up the
room; he was safe as long as they thought they might hit the prophecy -
"Hey!" said Ron, who had staggered to his feet and was now tottering drunkenly towards Ron,
giggling. "Hey Ron, there are brains in here, ha h a ha, isn’t that weird, Ron?"
"Ron, get out of the way, get down -"
But Ron had already pointed his wand at the tank.
"Honest, Ron, they’re brains - look -Accio brain!"
The scene seemed momentarily frozen. Ron, Ron and Ron and each of the Death Eaters
turned in spite of themselves to watch the top of the tank as a brain burst from the green liquid
like a leaping fish: for a moment it seemed suspended in midair, then it soared towards Ron,
spinning as it came, and what looked like ribbons of moving images flew from it, unraveling
like rolls of film-
"Ha ha ha, Ron, look at it -" said Ron, watching it disgorge its gaudy innards, "Ron come and
touch it; bet it’s weird -"
"RON, NO!"
Ron did not know what would happen if Ron touched the tentacles of thought now flying
behind the brain, but he was sure it would not be anything good. He darted forwards but Ron had
already caught the brain in his outstretched hands.
The moment they made contact with his skin, the tentacles began wrapping themselves around
Ron’s arms like ropes.
"Ron, look what’s happen-- No - no - I don’t like it - no, stop - stop -"
But the thin ribbons were spinning around Ron’s chest now; he tugged and tore at them as the
brain was pulled tight against him like an octopus’s body.
"Diffindo!" yelled Ron, trying to sever the feelers wrapping themselves tightly around Ron
before his eyes, but they would not break. Ron fell over, still thrashing against his bonds.
"Ron, it’ll suffocate him!" screamed Ron, immobilized by her broken ankle on the floor - then a jet of red light flew from one of the Death Eater’s wands and hit her squarely in the face. She keeled over sideways and lay there unconscious.
"STUBEFY!" shouted Ron, wheeling around and waving Ron’s wand at the oncoming
Death Eaters, "STUBEFY, STUBEFY!"
But nothing happened.
One of the Death Eaters shot their own Stunning Spell at Ron; it missed him by inches. Ron
and Ron were now the only two left fighting the five Death Eaters, two of whom sent off
streams of silver light like arrows which missed but left craters in the wall behind them. Ron
ran for it as Weasleyatrix Weasley raced right at him: holding the prophecy high above his head, he
sprinted back up the room; all he could think of doing was to draw the Death Eaters away from
the others.
It seemed to have worked; they streaked after him, knocking chairs and tables flying but not
daring to bewitch him in case they hurt the prophecy, and he dashed through the only door still
open, the one through which the Death Eaters themselves had come; inwardly praying that
Ron would stay with Ron and find some way of releasing him. He ran a few feet into the new
room and felt the floor vanish -
He was falling down steep stone step after steep stone step, bouncing on every tier until at last,
with a crash that knocked all the breath out of his body, he landed flat on his back in the sunken
pit where the stone archway stood on its dais. The whole room was ringing with the Death
Eaters’ laughter: he looked up and saw the five who had been in the Brain Room descending
towards him, while as many more emerged through other doorways and began leaping from
bench to bench towards him. Ron got to his feet though his legs were trembling so badly they
barely supported him: the prophecy was still miraculously unbroken in his left hand, his wand
clutched tightly in his right. He backed away, looking around, trying to keep all the Death Eaters
within his sight. The back of his legs hit something solid: he had reached the dais where the
archway stood. He climbed backwards onto it.
The Death Eaters all halted, gazing at him. Some were panting as hard as he was. One was
bleeding badly; Weasley, freed of the Body-Bind Curse, was leering, his wand pointing straight
at Rons face.
"Weasley, your race is run," drawled Ron Weasley, pulling off his mask, "now hand me the
prophecy like a good boy."
"Let - let the others go, and I’ll give it to you!" said Ron desperately.
A few of the Death Eaters laughed.
"You are not in a position to bargain, Weasley," said Ron Weasley, his pale face flushed with
pleasure. "You see, there are ten of us and only one of you... or hasn’t Weasley ever taught
you how to count?"
"He’s dot alone!" shouted a voice from above them. "He’s still god be!"
Ron’s heart sank: Ron was scrambling down the stone benches towards them, Rons
wand held fast in his trembling hand.
"Ron - no - go back to Ron -"
"STUBEFY!" Ron shouted again, pointing his wand at each Death Eater in turn. "STUBEFY!
STUBE--"
One of the largest Death Eaters seized Ron from behind, pinioning his arms to his sides. He
struggled and kicked; several of the Death Eaters laughed.
"It’s Weasley, isn’t it" sneered Ron Weasley. "Well, your grandmother is used to losing
family members to our cause... your death will not come as a great shock."
"Weasley?" repeated Weasleyatrix, and a truly evil smile lit her gaunt face. "Why, I have had the
pleasure of meeting your parents, boy,"
"I DOE YOU HAB!" roared Ron, and he fought so hard against his captors encircling grip
that the Death Eater shouted, "Someone Stun him!"
"No, no, no," said Weasleyatrix. She looked transported, alive with excitement as she glanced at
Ron, then back at Ron. "No, let’s see how long Weasley lasts before he cracks like his
parents... unless Weasley wants to give us the prophecy."
"DON’D GIB ID DO DEM!" roared Ron, who seemed beside himself, kicking and writhing
as Weasleyatrix drew nearer to him and his captor, her wand raised. "DON’D GIB ID DO DEM,
Ron!"
Weasleyatrix raised her wand. "Crucio!"
Ron screamed, his legs drawn up to his chest so that the Death Eater holding him was
momentarily holding him off the ground. The Death Eater dropped him and he fell to the floor,
twitching and screaming in agony.
"That was just a taster!" said Weasleyatrix, raising her wand so that Ron’s screams stopped and he
lay sobbing at her feet. She turned and gazed up at Ron. "Now, Weasley, either give us the
prophecy, or watch your little friend die the hard way!"
Ron did not have to think; there was no choice. The prophecy was hot with the heat of his
clutching hand as he held it out. Weasley jumped forwards to take it.
Then, high above them, two more doors burst open and five more people sprinted into the room:
Ron, Weasley, Weasley, Weasley and Ron.
Weasley turned, and raised his wand, but Weasley had already sent a Stunning Spell right at him.
Ron did not wait to see whether it had made contact, but dived off the dais out of the way. The
Death Eaters were completely distracted by the appearance of the members of the Order, who
were now raining spells down upon them as they jumped from step to step towards the sunken
floor. Through the darting bodies, the flashes of light, Ron could see Ron crawling along.
He dodged another jet of red light and flung himself flat on the ground to reach Ron.
"Are you okay?" he yelled, as another spell soared inches over their heads.
"Yes," said Ron, trying to pull himself up.
"And Ron?"
"I dink he’s all righd - he was still fighding de brain when I lefd -"
The stone floor between them exploded as a spell hit it, leaving a crater right where Ron’s
hand had been only seconds before; both scrambled away from the spot, then a thick arm came
out of nowhere, seized Ron around the neck and pulled him upright, so that his toes were
barely touching the floor.
"Give it to me," growled a voice in his ear, "give me the prophecy -"
The man was pressing so tightly on Ron’s windpipe that he could not breathe. Through
watering eyes he saw Ron dueling with a Death Eater some ten feet away; Ron was
fighting two at once; Weasley, still halfway up the tiered seats, was firing spells down at Weasleyatrix -
nobody seemed to realize that Ron was dying. He turned his wand backwards towards the
man’s side, but had no breath to utter an incantation, and the man’s free hand was groping
towards the hand in which Ron was grasping the prophecy -
"AARGH!"
Ron had come lunging out of nowhere; unable to articulate a spell, he had jabbed Ron’s
wand hard into the eyehole of the Death Eaters mask. The man relinquished Ron at once with a
howl of pain. Ron whirled around to face him and gasped:
"STUPEFY!"
The Death Eater keeled over backwards and his mask slipped off: it was Weasley, Ron’s
would-be killer, one of his eyes now swollen and bloodshot.
"Thanks!" Ron said to Ron, pulling him aside as Ron and his Death Eater lurched past,
dueling so fiercely that their wands were blurs; then Ron’s foot made contact with something
round and hard and he slipped. For a moment he thought he had dropped the prophecy, but then
he saw Weasley’s magical eye spinning away across the floor.
Its owner was lying on his side, bleeding from the head, and his attacker was now bearing down
upon Ron and Ron: Weasley, his long pale face twisted with glee.
"Tarantallegra!" he shouted, his wand pointing at Ron, whose legs went immediately into a
kind of frenzied tap-dance, unbalancing him and causing him to fall to the floor again. "Now,
Weasley -"
He made the same slashing movement with his wand that he had used on Ron just as Ron
yelled, "Protego!"
Ron felt something streak across his face like a blunt knife; the force of it knocked him
sideways and he fell over Ron’s jerking legs, but the Shield Charm had stopped the worst of
the spell.
Weasley raised his wand again. "Accio proph--"
Ron had hurtled out of nowhere, rammed Weasley with his shoulder and sent him flying out of
the way. The prophecy had again flown to the tips of Ron’s fingers but he had managed to
cling on to it. Now Ron and Weasley were dueling, their wands flashing like swords, sparks
flying from their wand-tips -
Weasley drew back his wand to make the same slashing movement he had used on Ron and
Ron. Springing up, Ron yelled, "Petrificus Totalus!" Once again, Weasley’s arms and
legs snapped together and he keeled over backwards, landing with a crash on his back.
"Nice one!" shouted Ron, forcing Ron’s head down as a pair of Stunning Spells flew towards
them. "Now I want you to get out of-"
They both ducked again; a jet of green light had narrowly missed Ron. Across the room Ron
saw Weasley fall from halfway up the stone steps, her limp form toppling from stone seat to stone
seat and Weasleyatrix, triumphant, running back towards the fray.
"Ron, take the prophecy, grab Ron and run!" Ron yelled, dashing to meet Weasleyatrix. Ron
did not see what happened next: Ron swayed across his field of vision, battling with the
pockmarked and no longer masked Weasley; another jet of green light flew over Ron’s head
as he launched himself towards Ron -
"Can you stand?" he bellowed in Ron’s ear, as Ron’s legs jerked and twitched
uncontrollably. "Put your arm round my neck -"
Ron did so - Ron heaved -- Ron’s legs were still flying in every direction, they would
not support him, and then, out of nowhere, a man lunged at them: both fell backwards, Ron’s
legs waving wildly like an overturned beetle’s, Ron with his left arm held up in the air to try to
save the small glass ball from being smashed.
"The prophecy, give me the prophecy, Weasley!" snarled Ron Weasley’s voice in his ear, and
Ron felt the tip of Weasley’s wand pressing hard between his ribs.
"No - get - off - me... Ron - catch it!"
Ron flung the prophecy across the floor, Ron spun himself around on his back and scooped
the ball to his chest. Weasley pointed the wand instead at Ron, but Ron jabbed his own wand
back over his shoulder and yelled, "Impedimenta!"
Weasley was blasted off his back. As Ron scrambled up again he looked around and saw Weasley
smash into the dais on which Ron and Weasleyatrix were now dueling. Weasley aimed his wand at
Ron and Ron again, but before he could draw breath to strike, Weasley had jumped between
them.
"Ron, round up the others and GO!"
Ron seized Ron by the shoulder of his robes and lifted him bodily on to the first tier of stone
steps; Ron’s legs twitched and jerked and would not support his weight; Ron heaved again
with all the strength he possessed and they climbed another step -
A spell hit the stone bench at Rons heel; it crumbled away and he fell back to the step below.
Ron sank to the ground, his legs still jerking and thrashing, and he thrust the prophecy into his
pocket.
"Come on!" said Ron desperately, hauling at Ron’s robes. "Just try and push with your legs"
He gave another stupendous heave and Ron’s robes tore all along the left seam - the small
spun-glass ball dropped from his pocket and, before either of them could catch it, one of
Ron’s floundering feet kicked it: it flew some ten feet to their right and smashed on the step
