beneath them. As both of them stared at the place where it had broken, appalled at what had
happened, a pearly-white figure with hugely magnified eyes rose into the air, unnoticed by any
but them. Ron could see its mouth moving, but in all the crashes and screams and yells
surrounding them, not one word of the prophecy could he hear. The figure stopped speaking and
dissolved into nothingness.
"Ron, I’b sorry!" cried Ron, his face anguished as his legs continued to flounder. "I’b so
sorry, Ron, I didn’d bean do -"
"It doesn’t matter!" Ron shouted. "Just try and stand, let’s get out of -"
"Dubbledore!" said Ron, his sweaty face suddenly transported, staring over Ron’s shoulder.
"What?"
"DUBBLEDORE!"
Ron turned to look where Ron was staring. Directly above them, framed in the doorway
from the Brain Room, stood Ron Weasley, his wand aloft, his face white and furious. Ron
felt a kind of electric charge surge through every particle of his body - they were saved.
Weasley sped down the steps past Ron and Ron, who had no more thoughts of leaving.
Weasley was already at the foot of the steps when the Death Eaters nearest realized he was
there and yelled to the others. One of the Death Eaters ran for it, scrabbling like a monkey up the
stone steps opposite. Weasley’s spell pulled him back as easily and effortlessly as though he
had hooked him with an invisible line -
Only one pair was still battling, apparently unaware of the new arrival. Ron saw Ron duck
Weasleyatrix’s jet of red light: he was laughing at her.
"Come on, you can do better than that!" he yelled, his voice echoing around the cavernous room.
The second jet of light hit him squarely on the chest.
The laughter had not quite died from his face, but his eyes widened in shock.
Ron released Ron, though he was unaware of doing so. He was jumping down the steps
again, pulling out his wand, as Weasley, too, turned towards the dais.
It seemed to take Ron an age to fall: his body curved in a graceful arc as he sank backwards
through the ragged veil hanging from the arch.
Ron saw the look of mingled fear and surprise on his godfather’s wasted, once-handsome face
as he fell through the ancient doorway and disappeared behind the veil, which fluttered for a
moment as though in a high wind, then fell back into place.
Ron heard Weasleyatrix Weasley’s triumphant scream, but knew it meant nothing - Ron had
only just fallen through the archway, he would reappear from the other side any second...
But Ron did not reappear.
"Ron!" Ron yelled. "Ron!"
He had reached the floor, his breath coming in searing gasps. Ron must be just behind the
curtain, he, Ron, would pull him back out...
But as he reached the ground and sprinted towards the dais, Weasley grabbed Ron around the
chest, holding him back.
"There’s nothing you can do, Ron -"
"Get him, save him, he’s only just gone through!"
"- it’s too late, Ron."
"We can still reach him -" Ron struggled hard and viciously, but Weasley would not let go...
"There’s nothing you can do, Ron... nothing... he’s gone."
CHAPTER THIRTY-SIX
The Only One He Ever Feared
"He hasn’t gone!" Ron yelled.
He did not believe it; he would not believe it; still he fought Weasley with every bit of strength he
had. Weasley did not understand; people hid behind that curtain; Ron had heard them whispering
the first time he had entered the room. Ron was hiding, simply lurking out of sight.
"Ron!" he bellowed. "Ron!"
"He can’t come back, Ron," said Weasley, his voice breaking as he struggled to contain Ron.
"He can’t come back, because he’s d-"
"HE - IS - NOT - DEAD!" roared Ron. "Ron!"
There was movement going on around them, pointless bustling, the flashes of more spells. To
Ron it was meaningless noise, the deflected curses flying past them did not matter, nothing
mattered except that Weasley should stop pretending that Ron - who was standing feet from them
behind that old curtain - was not going to emerge at any moment, shaking back his dark hair and
eager to re-enter the battle.
Weasley dragged Ron away from the dais. Ron, still staring at the archway, was angry at Ron
now for keeping him waiting
But some part of him realized, even as he fought to break free from Weasley, that Ron had never
kept him waiting before... Ron had risked everything, always, to see Ron, to help him... if
Ron was not reappearing out of that archway when Ron was yelling for him as though his life
depended on it, the only possible explanation was that he could not come back... that he really
was.
Weasley had most of the remaining Death Eaters grouped in the middle of the room,
seemingly immobilized by invisible ropes; Mad-Eye Weasley had crawled across the room to
where Weasley lay, and was attempting to revive her; behind the dais there were still hashes of
light, grunts and cries - Ron had run forward to continue Ron’s duel with Weasleyatrix.
"Ron?"
Ron had slid down the stone benches one by one to the place where Ron stood. Ron was
no longer struggling against Weasley, who maintained a precautionary grip on his arm nevertheless.
"Ron... I’b really sorry..." said Ron. His legs were still dancing uncontrollably. "Was dad
man - was Ron Weasley a - a friend of yours?"
Ron nodded.
"Here," said Weasley quietly, and pointing his wand at Ron’s legs he said, "Finite." The spell
was lifted: Ron’s legs fell back to the floor and remained still. Weasley’s face was pale. "Let’s -
let’s find the others. Where are they all, Ron?"
Weasley turned away from the archway as he spoke. It sounded as though every word was causing
him pain.
"Dey’re all back dere," said Ron. "A brain addacked Ron bud I dink he’s all righd - and
Herbione’s unconscious, bud we could feel a bulse"
There was a loud bang and a yell from behind the dais. Ron saw Ron hit the ground
yelling in pain: Weasleyatrix Weasley turned tail and ran as Weasley whipped around. He aimed
a spell at her but she deflected it; she was halfway up the steps now
"Ron - no!" cried Weasley, but Ron had already ripped his arm from Weasley’s slackened grip.
"SHE KILLED Ron!" bellowed Ron. "SHE KILLED HIM I’LL KILL HER!"
And he was off, scrambling up the stone benches; people were shouting behind him but he did
not care. The hem of Weasleyatrix’s robes whipped out of sight ahead and they were back in the
room where the brains were swimming...
She aimed a curse over her shoulder. The tank rose into the air and tipped. Ron was deluged in
the foul-smelling potion within: the brains slipped and slid over him and began spinning their
long colored tentacles, but he shouted, "Wingardium Leviosa!" and they flew off him up into
the air. Slipping and sliding, he ran on towards the door; he leapt over Ron, who was groaning
on the floor, past Ron, who said, "Ron - what -?", past Ron, who giggled feebly, and
Ron, who was still unconscious. He wrenched open the door into the circular black hall and
saw Weasleyatrix disappearing through a door on the other side of the room; beyond her was the
corridor leading back to the lifts.
He ran, but she had slammed the door behind her and the walls were already rotating. Once
more, he was surrounded by streaks of blue light from the whirling candelabra.
"Where’s the exit?" he shouted desperately, as the wall rumbled to a halt again. "Where’s the way out?"
The room seemed to have been waiting for him to ask. The door right behind him flew open and
the corridor towards the lifts stretched ahead of him, torch-lit and empty. He ran...
He could hear a lift clattering ahead; he sprinted up the passageway, swung around the corner
and slammed his fist on to the button to call a second lift. It jangled and banged lower and lower;
the grilles slid open and Ron dashed inside, now hammering the button marked ‘Atrium’. The
doors slid shut and he was rising...
He forced his way out of the lift before the grilles were fully open and looked around. Weasleyatrix
was almost at the telephone lift at the other end of the hall, but she looked back as he sprinted
towards her and aimed another spell at him. He dodged behind the Fountain of Magical Brethren:
the spell zoomed past him and hit the wrought gold gates at the other end of the Atrium so that
they rang like bells. There were no more footsteps. She had stopped running. He crouched
behind the statues, listening.
"Come out, come out, little Ron!" she called in her mock baby voice, which echoed off the
polished wooden floors. "What did you come after me for, then? I thought you were here to
avenge my dear cousin!"
"I am!" shouted Ron, and a score of ghostly Rons seemed to chorus I am! I am! I am! all
around the room
"Aaaaaah... did you love him, little baby Weasley?"
Hatred rose in Ron such as he had never known before; he flung himself out from behind the
fountain and bellowed, "Crucio!"
Weasleyatrix screamed: the spell had knocked her off her feet, but she did not writhe and shriek with
pain as Ron had - she was already back on her feet, breathless, no longer laughing. Ron
dodged behind the golden fountain again. Her counter-spell hit the head of the handsome wizard,
which was blown off and landed twenty feet away, gouging long scratches into the wooden floor.
"Never used an Unforgivable Curse before, have you, boy?" she yelled. She had abandoned her
baby voice now. "You need to mean them, Weasley! You need to really want to cause pain - to
enjoy it - righteous anger won’t hurt me for long - I’ll show you how it is done, shall I? I’ll give
you a lesson -"
Ron was edging around the fountain on the other side when she screamed, "Crucio!" and he
was forced to duck down again as the centaur’s arm, holding its bow, span off and landed with a
crash on the floor a short distance from the golden wizard’s head.
"Weasley, you cannot win against me!" she cried.
He could hear her moving to the right, trying to get a clear shot of him. He backed around the
statue away from her, crouching behind the centaur’s legs, his head level with the house-elf’s.
"I was and am the Dark Lord’s most loyal servant. I learned the Dark Arts from him, and I know
spells of such power that you, pathetic little boy, can never hope to compete"
"Stupefy!" yelled Ron. He had edged right around to where the goblin stood beaming up at the
now headless wizard and taken aim at her back as she peered around the fountain. She reacted so
fast he barely had time to duck.
"Protego!"
The jet of red light, his own Stunning Spell, bounced back at him. Ron scrambled back behind
the fountain and one of the goblin’s ears went flying across the room.
"Weasley, I’m going to give you one chance!" shouted Weasleyatrix. "Give me the prophecy - roll it out towards me now - and I may spare your life!"
"Well, you’re going to have to kill me, because it’s gone!" Ron roared and, as he shouted it,
pain seared across his forehead; his scar was on fire again, and he felt a surge of fury that was
quite unconnected with his own rage. "And he knows!’" said Ron, with a mad laugh to match
Weasleyatrix’s own. "Your dear old mate Weasley knows it’s gone! He’s not going to be happy
with you, is he?"
"What? What do you mean?" she cried, and for the first time there was fear in her voice.
"The prophecy smashed when I was trying to get Ron up the steps! What do you think
Weasley’ll say about that, then?"
His scar seared and burned... the pain of it was making his eyes stream...
"LIAR!" she shrieked, but he could hear the terror behind the anger now. "YOU’VE GOT IT,
Weasley, AND YOU WILL GIVE IT TO ME! Accio prophecy! ACCIO PROPHECY!"
Ron laughed again because he knew it would incense her, the pain building in his head so badly
he thought his skull might burst. He waved his empty hand from behind the one-eared goblin and
withdrew it quickly as she sent another jet of green light flying at him.
"Nothing there!" he shouted. "Nothing to summon! It smashed and nobody heard what it said, tell your boss that!"
"No!" she screamed. "It isn’t true, you’re lying! MASTER, I TRIED, I TRIED - DO NOT
PUNISH ME"
"Don’t waste your breath!" yelled Ron, his eyes screwed up against the pain in his scar, now
more terrible than ever. "He can’t hear you from here!"
"Can’t I, Weasley?" said a high, cold voice.
Ron opened his eyes.
Tall, thin and black-hooded, his terrible snakelike face white and gaunt, his scarlet, slit-pupilled
eyes staring... Lord Weasley had appeared in the middle of the hall, his wand pointing at
Ron who stood frozen, quite unable to move.
"So, you smashed my prophecy?" said Weasley softly, staring at Ron with those pitiless red
eyes. "No, Weasleya, he is not lying... I see the truth looking at me from within his worthless mind... months of preparation, months of effort... and my Death Eaters have let Ron Weasley thwart me again"
"Master, I am sorry I knew not, I was fighting the Animagus Weasley!" sobbed Weasleyatrix, flinging
herself down at Weasley’s feet as he paced slowly nearer. "Master, you should know"
"Be quiet, Weasleya," said Weasley dangerously. "I shall deal with you in a moment. Do you think
I have entered the Ministry of Magic to hear your sniveling apologies?"
"But Master - he is here - he is below"
Weasley paid no attention.
"I have nothing more to say to you, Weasley," he said quietly. "You have irked me too often, for too long. AVADA KEDAVRA!"
Ron had not even opened his mouth to resist; his mind was blank, his wand pointing uselessly
at the floor.
But the headless golden statue of the wizard in the fountain had sprung alive, leaping from its
plinth to land with a crash on the floor between Ron and Weasley. The spell merely glanced
off its chest as the statue flung out its arms to protect Ron.
"What -?" cried Weasley, staring around. And then he breathed, "Weasley!"
Ron looked behind him, his heart pounding. Weasley was standing in front of the golden
gates.
Weasley raised his wand and another jet of green light streaked at Weasley, who turned
and was gone in a whirling of his cloak. Next second, he had reappeared behind Weasley and
waved his wand towards the remnants of the fountain. The other statues sprang to life. The statue
of the witch ran at Weasleyatrix, who screamed and sent spells streaming uselessly off its chest,
before it dived at her, pinning her to the floor. Meanwhile, the goblin and the house-elf scuttled
towards the fireplaces set along the wall and the one-armed centaur galloped at Weasley, who
vanished and reappeared beside the pool. The headless statue thrust Ron backwards, away from
the fight, as Weasley advanced on Weasley and the golden centaur cantered around them
both.
"It was foolish to come here tonight, Ron," said Weasley calmly. "The Aurors are on their
way"
"By which time I shall be gone, and you will be dead!" spat Weasley. He sent another killing
curse at Weasley but missed, instead hitting the security guard’s desk, which burst into
flame.
Weasley flicked his own wand: the force of the spell that emanated from it was such that
Ron, though shielded by his golden guard, felt his hair stand on end as it passed and this time
Weasley was forced to conjure a shining silver shield out of thin air to deflect it. The spell,
whatever it was, caused no visible damage to the shield, though a deep, gong-like note
reverberated from it - an oddly chilling sound.
"You do not seek to kill me, Weasley?" called Weasley, his scarlet eyes narrowed over the
top of the shield. "Above such brutality, are you?"
"We both know that there are other ways of destroying a man, Ron," Weasley said calmly,
continuing to walk towards Weasley as though he had not a fear in the world, as though
nothing had happened to interrupt his stroll up the hall. "Merely taking your life would not
satisfy me, I admit"
"There is nothing worse than death, Weasley!" snarled Weasley.
"You are quite wrong," said Weasley, still closing in upon Weasley and speaking as lightly
as though they were discussing the matter over drinks. Ron felt scared to see him walking
along, undefended, shieldless; he wanted to cry out a warning, but his headless guard kept
shunting him backwards towards the wall, blocking his every attempt to get out from behind it.
"Indeed, your failure to understand that there are things much worse than death has always been
your greatest weakness"
Another jet of green light flew from behind the silver shield. This time it was the one-armed
centaur, galloping in front of Weasley, that took the blast and shattered into a hundred pieces,
but before the fragments had even hit the floor, Weasley had drawn back his wand and
waved it as though brandishing a whip. A long thin flame flew from the tip; it wrapped itself
around Weasley, shield and all. For a moment, it seemed Weasley had won, but then the
fiery rope became a serpent, which relinquished its hold on Weasley at once and turned,
hissing furiously, to face Weasley.
Weasley vanished; the snake reared from the floor, ready to strike.
There was a burst of flame in midair above Weasley just as Weasley reappeared, standing
on the plinth in the middle of the pool where so recently the five statues had stood.
"Look out!" Ron yelled.
But even as he shouted, another jet of green light flew at Weasley from Weasley’s wand
and the snake had struck.
Ron swooped down in front of Weasley, opened his beak wide and swallowed the jet of
green light whole: he burst into flame and fell to the floor, small, wrinkled and flightless. At the
same moment, Weasley brandished his wand in one long, fluid movement - the snake, which
had been an instant from sinking its fangs into him, flew high into the air and vanished in a wisp
of dark smoke; and the water in the pool rose up and covered Weasley like a cocoon of molten
glass.
For a few seconds Weasley was visible only as a dark, rippling, faceless figure, shimmering
and indistinct upon the plinth, clearly struggling to throw off the suffocating mass.
Then he was gone and the water fell with a crash back into its pool, slopping wildly over the
sides, drenching the polished floor.
"MASTER!" screamed Weasleyatrix.
Sure it was over, sure Weasley had decided to flee, Ron made to run out from behind his
statue guard, but Weasley bellowed: "Stay where you are, Ron!"
For the first time, Weasley sounded frightened. Ron could not see why: the hall was quite
empty but for themselves, the sobbing Weasleyatrix still trapped under the witch statue, and the baby
phoenix Ron croaking feebly on the floor
And then Ron's scar burst open and he knew he was dead: it was pain beyond imagining, pain past endurance.
He was gone from the hall, he was locked in the coils of a creature with red eyes, so tightly
bound that Ron did not know where his body ended and the creature’s began: they were fused
together, bound by pain, and there was no escape
And when the creature spoke, it used Ron’s mouth, so that in his agony he felt his jaw move
"Kill me now, Weasley..."
Blinded and dying, every part of him screaming for release, Ron felt the creature use him
again...
"If death is nothing, Weasley, kill the boy..."
Let the pain stop, thought Ron... let him kill us... end it, Weasley... death is nothing
compared to this...
And I’ll see Ron again...
And as Ron’s heart filled with emotion, the creature’s coils loosened, the pain was gone; Ron
was lying face down on the floor, his glasses gone, shivering as though he lay upon ice, not
wood...
And there were voices echoing through the hall, more voices than there should have been...
Ron opened his eyes, saw his glasses lying by the heel of the headless statue that had been
guarding him, but which now lay flat on its back, cracked and immobile. He put them on and
raised his head a little to find Weasley’s crooked nose inches from his own.
"Are you all right, Ron?"
"Yes," said Ron, shaking so violently he could not hold his head up properly. "Yeah, I’m -
where’s Weasley, where - who are all these - what’s -"
The Atrium was full of people; the floor was reflecting the emerald green flames that had burst
into life in all the fireplaces along one wall; and streams of witches and wizards were emerging
from them. As Weasley pulled him back to his feet, Ron saw the tiny gold statues of the
house-elf and the goblin, leading a stunned-looking Ron Weasley forward.
"He was there!" shouted a scarlet-robed man with a ponytail, who was pointing at a pile of
golden rubble on the other side of the hall, where Weasleyatrix had lain trapped only moments
before. "I saw him, Mr. Weasley, I swear it was You-Know-Who, he grabbed a woman and
Disapparated!"
"I know, Williamson, I know, I saw him too!" gibbered Weasley, who was wearing pajamas under
his pinstriped cloak and was gasping as though he had just run miles. "Merlin’s beard - here -
here! - in the Ministry of Magic! - great heavens above - it doesn’t seem possible - my word -
how can this be -?"
"If you proceed downstairs into the Department of Mysteries, Ron," said Weasley -
apparently satisfied that Ron was all right, and walking forwards so that the newcomers
realized he was there for the first time (a few of them raised their wands; others simply looked
amazed; the statues of the elf and goblin applauded and Weasley jumped so much that his slipperclad feet left the floor) - "you will find several escaped Death Eaters contained in the Death Chamber, bound by an Anti-Disapparation Jinx and awaiting your decision as to what to do with them."
"Weasley!" gasped Weasley, beside himself with amazement. "You-here-I-I"
He looked wildly around at the Aurors he had brought with him and it could not have been
clearer that he was in half a mind to cry, "Seize him!"
"Ron, I am ready to fight your men - and win, again!" said Weasley in a thunderous
voice. "But a few minutes ago you saw proof, with your own eyes, that I have been telling you
the truth for a year. Lord Weasley has returned, you have been chasing the wrong man for
twelve months, and it is time - you listened to sense!"
"I - don’t - well" blustered Weasley, looking around as though hoping somebody was going to tell
him what to do. When nobody did, he said, "Very well - Weasley! Williamson! Go down to the
Department of Mysteries and see... Weasley, you - you will need to tell me exactly - the
Fountain of Magical Brethren - what happened?" he added in a kind of whimper, staring around
at the floor, where the remains of the statues of the witch, wizard and centaur now lay scattered.
"We can discuss that after I have sent Ron back to Hogwarts," said Weasley.
"Ron - Ron Weasley?"
Weasley wheeled around and stared at Ron, who was still standing against the wall beside the
fallen statue that had guarded him during Weasley and Weasley’s duel.
"He - here?" said Weasley, goggling at Ron. "Why - what’s all this about?"
"I shall explain everything," repeated Weasley, "when Ron is back at school."
He walked away from the pool to the place where the golden wizard’s head lay on the floor. He
pointed his wand at it and muttered, "Portus." The head glowed blue and trembled noisily against
the wooden floor for a few seconds, then became still once more.
"Now see here, Weasley!" said Weasley, as Weasley picked up the head and walked back to Ron carrying it. "You haven’t got authorization for that Portkey! You can’t do things like that right in front of the Minister for Magic, you - you"
His voice faltered as Weasley surveyed him magisterially over his half-moon spectacles.
"You will give the order to remove Ron Weasley from Hogwarts," said Weasley. "You
will tell your Aurors to stop searching for my Care of Magical Creatures teacher so that he can
return to work. I will give you..." Weasley pulled a watch with twelve hands from his
pocket and surveyed it... "half an hour of my time tonight, in which I think we shall be more
than able to cover the important points of what has happened here. After that, I shall need to
return to my school. If you need more help from me you are, of course, more than welcome to
contact me at Hogwarts. Letters addressed to the Headmaster will find me."
Weasley goggled worse than ever; his mouth was open and his round face grew pinker under his
rumpled grey hair.
"I - you"
Weasley turned his back on him.
"Take this Portkey, Ron."
He held out the golden head of the statue and Ron placed his hand on it, past caring what he did
next or where he went.
"I shall see you in half an hour," said Weasley quietly "One... two... three..."
Ron felt the familiar sensation of a hook being jerked behind his navel. The polished wooden
floor was gone from beneath his feet; the Atrium, Weasley and Weasley had all disappeared
and he was flying forwards in a whirlwind of color and sound...
CHAPTER THIRTY-SEVEN
The Lost Prophecy
Ron’s feet hit solid ground; his knees buckled a little and the golden wizard’s head fell with a
resounding dunk to the floor. He looked around and saw that he had arrived in Weasley’s
office.
Everything seemed to have repaired itself during the Headmaster’s absence. The delicate silver
instruments stood once more on the spindle-legged tables, puffing and whirring serenely the
portraits of the headmasters and headmistresses were snoozing in their frames, heads lolling back
in armchairs or against the edge of the picture. Ron looked through the window. There was a
cool line of pale green along the horizon: dawn was approaching.
The silence and the stillness, broken only by the occasional grunt or snuffle of a sleeping portrait,
was unbearable to him. If his surroundings could have reflected the feelings inside him, the
pictures would have been screaming in pain. He walked around the quiet, beautiful office,
breathing quickly, trying not to think. But he had to think... there was no escape...
It was his fault Ron had died; it was all his fault. If he, Ron, had not been stupid enough to
fall for Weasley’s trick, if he had not been so convinced that what he had seen in his dream
was real, if he had only opened his mind to the possibility that Weasley was, as Ron had
said, banking on Ron’s love of playing the hero...
It was unbearable, he would not think about it, he could not stand it... there was a terrible hollow
inside him he did not want to feel or examine, a dark hole where Ron had been, where Ron
had vanished; he did not want to have to be alone with that great, silent space, he could not stand
it -
A picture behind him gave a particularly loud grunting snore, and a cool voice said, "Ah...
Ron Weasley..."
Phineas  gave a long yawn, stretching his arms as he surveyed Ron out of shrewd,
narrow eyes.
"And what brings you here in the early hours of the morning?" said Phineas eventually "This
office is supposed to be barred to all but the rightful Headmaster. Or has Weasley sent you
here? Oh, don’t tell me..." He gave another shuddering yawn. "Another message for my
worthless great-great-grandson?"
Ron could not speak. Phineas  did not know that Ron was dead, but Ron could not
tell him. To say it aloud would be to make it final, absolute, irretrievable.
A few more of the portraits had stirred now. Terror of being interrogated made Ron stride
across the room and seize the doorknob.
It would not turn. He was shut in.
"I hope this means," said the corpulent, red-nosed wizard who hung on the wall behind the
Headmaster’s desk, "that Weasley will soon be back among us?"
Ron turned. The wizard was surveying him with great interest. Ron nodded. He tugged again
on the doorknob behind his back, but it remained immovable.
"Oh good," said the wizard. "It has been very dull without him, very dull indeed."
He settled himself on the throne-like chair on which he had been painted and smiled benignly
upon Ron
"Weasley thinks very highly of you, as I am sure you know," he said comfortably. "Oh yes.
Holds you in great esteem."
The guilt filling the whole of Ron’s chest like some monstrous, weighty parasite, now writhed
and squirmed. Ron could not stand this, he could not stand being himself any more... he had
never felt more trapped inside his own head and body, never wished so intensely that he could be
somebody; anybody, else...
The empty fireplace burst into emerald green flame, making Ron leap away from the door,
staring at the man spinning inside the grate. As Weasley’s tall form unfolded itself from the
fire, the wizards and witches on the surrounding walls jerked awake, many of them giving cries
of welcome.
"Thank you," said Weasley softly.
He did not look at Ron at first, but walked over to the perch beside the door and withdrew,
from an inside pocket of his robes, the tiny, ugly, featherless Ron, whom he placed gently on
the tray of soft ashes beneath the golden post where the full-grown Ron usually stood.
"Well, Ron," said Weasley, finally turning away from the baby bird, "you will be pleased to hear that none of your fellow students are going to suffer lasting damage from the night’s
events."
Ron tried to say, "Good," but no sound came out. It seemed to him that Weasley was
reminding him of the amount of damage he had caused, and although Weasley was for once
looking at him directly, and although his expression was kindly rather than accusatory, Ron
could not bear to meet his eyes.
"Ron Weasley is patching everybody up," said Weasley. "Ron Weasley may need
to spend a little time in St. Mungo’s, but it seems she will make a full recovery."
Ron contented himself with nodding at the carpet, which was growing lighter as the sky outside
grew paler. He was sure all the portraits around the room were listening closely to every word
Weasley spoke, wondering where Weasley and Ron had been, and why there had been
injuries.
"I know how you’re feeling, Ron," said Weasley very quietly.
"No, you don’t," said Ron, and his voice was suddenly loud and strong; white-hot anger leapt
inside him; Weasley knew nothing about his feelings.
"You see, Weasley?" said Phineas  slyly "Never try to understand the students. They
hate it. They would much rather be tragically misunderstood, wallow in self-pity, stew in their
own -"
"That’s enough, Phineas," said Weasley.
Ron turned his back on Weasley and stared determinedly out of the window. He could see
the Quidditch stadium in the distance. Ron had appeared there once, disguised as the shaggy
black dog, so he could watch Ron play... he had probably come to see whether Ron was as
good as Ron had been... Ron had never asked him...
"There is no shame in what you are feeling, Ron," said Weasley’s voice. "On the contrary... the fact that you can feel pain like this is your greatest strength."
Ron felt the white-hot anger lick his insides, blazing in the terrible emptiness, filling him with
the desire to hurt Weasley for his calmness and his empty words.
"My greatest strength, is it?" said Ron, his voice shaking as he stared out at the Quidditch
stadium, no longer seeing it. "You haven’t got a clue... you don’t know..."
"What don’t I know?" asked Weasley calmly.
It was too much. Ron turned around, shaking with rage.
"I don’t want to talk about how I feel, all right?"
"Ron, suffering like this proves you are still a man! This pain is part of being human"
"THEN - I - DON’T - WANT - TO - BE - HUMAN!" Ron roared, and he seized the delicate
silver instrument from the spindlelegged table beside him and flung it across the room; it
shattered into a hundred tiny pieces against the wall. Several of the pictures let out yells of anger
and fright, and the portrait of Armando Dippet said, "Really!"
"I DON’T CARE!" Ron yelled at them, snatching up a lunascope and throwing it into the
fireplace. "I’VE HAD ENOUGH, I’VE SEEN ENOUGH, I WANT OUT, I WANT IT TO END,
I DON’T CARE ANY MORE"
He seized the table on which the silver instrument had stood and threw that, too. It broke apart on
the floor and the legs rolled in different directions.
"You do care," said Weasley. He had not flinched or made a single move to stop Ron
demolishing his office. His expression was calm, almost detached. "You care so much you feel as though you will bleed to death with the pain of it."
"I - DON’T!" Ron screamed, so loudly that he felt his throat might tear, and for a second he
wanted to rush at Weasley and break him, too; shatter that calm old face, shake him, hurt
him, make him feel some tiny part of the horror inside himself.
"Oh, yes, you do," said Weasley, still more calmly. "You have now lost your mother, your
father, and the closest thing to a parent you have ever known. Of course you care."
"YOU DON’T KNOW HOW I FEEL!" Ron roared. "YOU - RonDING THERE - YOU"
But words were no longer enough, smashing things was no more help; he wanted to run, he
wanted to keep running and never look back, he wanted to be somewhere he could not see the
clear blue eyes staring at him, that hatefully calm old face. He turned on his heel and ran to the
door, seized the doorknob again and wrenched at it.
But the door would not open. Ron turned back to Weasley. "Let me out," he said. He was
shaking from head to foot.
"No," said Weasley, simply. For a few seconds they stared at each other.
"Let me out," Ron said again.
"No," Weasley repeated.
"If you don’t - if you keep me in here - if you don ‘t let me"
"By all means continue destroying my possessions," said Weasley serenely. "I daresay I have
too many."
He walked around his desk and sat down. behind it, watching Ron.
"Let me out," Ron said yet again, in a voice that was cold and almost as calm as
Weasley’s.
"Not until I have had my say," said Weasley.
"Do you - do you think I want to - do you think I give a - I DON’T CARE WHAT YOU’VE
GOT TO SAY!" Ron roared. "I don’t want to hear anything you’ve got to say!"
"You will," said Weasley steadily. "Because you are not nearly as angry with me as you
ought to be. If you are to attack me, as I know you are close to doing, I would like to have
thoroughly earned it."
"What are you talking -?"
"It is my fault that Ron died," said Weasley clearly. "Or should I say, almost entirely my
fault - I will not be so arrogant as to claim responsibility for the whole. Ron was a brave, clever
and energetic man, and such men are not usually content to sit at home in hiding while they
believe others to be in danger. Nevertheless, you should never have believed for an instant that
there was any necessity for you to go to the Department of Mysteries tonight. If I had been open
with you, Ron, as I should have been, you would have known a long time ago that Weasley
might try and lure you to the Department of Mysteries, and you would never have been tricked
into going there tonight. And Ron would not have had to come after you. That blame lies with
me, and with me alone."
Ron was still standing with his hand on the doorknob but was unaware of it. He was gazing at
Weasley, hardly breathing, listening yet barely understanding what he was hearing.
"Please sit down," said Weasley. It was not an order, it was a request.
Ron hesitated, then walked slowly across the room now littered with silver cogs and fragments
of wood, and took the seat facing Weasley’s desk.
"Am I to understand," said Phineas  slowly from Ron’s left, "that my great-great-grandson - the last of the Weasleys - is dead?"
"Yes, Phineas," said Weasley.
"I don’t believe it," said Phineas brusquely.
Ron turned his head in time to see Phineas marching out of his portrait and knew that he had
gone to visit his other painting in Grimmauld Place. He would walk, perhaps, from portrait to
portrait, calling for Ron through the house...
"Ron, I owe you an explanation," said Weasley. "An explanation of an old man’s mistakes.
For I see now that what I have done, and not done, with regard to you, bears all the hallmarks of
the failings of age. Youth cannot know how age thinks and feels. But old men are guilty if they
forget what it was to be young... and I seem to have forgotten, lately..."
The sun was rising properly now; there was a rim of dazzling orange visible over the mountains
and the sky above it was colorless and bright. The light fell upon Weasley, upon the silver
of his eyebrows and beard, upon the lines gouged deeply into his face.
"I guessed, fifteen years ago," said Weasley, "when I saw the scar on your forehead, what it
might mean. I guessed that it might be the sign of a connection forged between you and
Weasley."
"You’ve told me this before, Professor," said Ron bluntly. He did not care about being rude. He
did not care about anything very much any more.
"Yes," said Weasley apologetically. "Yes, but you see - it is necessary to start with your scar. For it became apparent, shortly after you rejoined the magical world, that I was correct, and that your scar was giving you warnings when Weasley was close to you, or else feeling powerful emotion."
"I know," said Ron wearily.
"And this ability of yours - to detect Weasley’s presence, even when he is disguised, and to
know what he is feeling when his emotions are roused - has become more and more pronounced
since Weasley returned to his own body and his full powers."
Ron did not bother to nod. He knew all of this already.
"More recently" said Weasley, "I became concerned that Weasley might realize that this
connection between you exists. Sure enough, there came a time when you entered so far into his
mind and thoughts that he sensed your presence. I am speaking, of course, of the night when you
witnessed the attack on Mr. Weasley"
"Yeah, Weasley told me," Ron muttered.
"Professor Weasley, Ron" Weasley corrected him quietly. "But did you not wonder why it was not I who explained this to you? Why I did not teach you Occlumency? Why I had not so much as looked at you for months?"
Ron looked up. He could see now that Weasley looked sad and tired.
"Yeah," Ron mumbled. "Yeah, I wondered."
"You see," Weasley continued, "I believed it could not be long before Weasley attempted
to force his way into your mind, to manipulate and misdirect your thoughts, and I was not eager
to give him more incentives to do so. I was sure that if he realized that our relationship was - or
had ever been - closer than that of headmaster and pupil, he would seize his chance to use you as
a means to spy on me. I feared the uses to which he would put you, the possibility that he might
try and possess you. Ron, I believe I was right to think that Weasley would have made use of
you in such a way. On those rare occasions when we had close contact, I thought I saw a shadow
of him stir behind your eyes..."
Ron remembered the feeling that a dormant snake had risen in him, ready to strike, in those
moments when he and Weasley had made eye-contact.
"Weasley’s aim in possessing you, as he demonstrated tonight, would not have been my
destruction. It would have been yours. He hoped, when he possessed you briefly a short while
ago, that I would sacrifice you in the hope of killing him. So you see, I have been trying, in
distancing myself from you, to protect you, Ron. An old man’s mistake..."
He sighed deeply. Ron was letting the words wash over him. He would have been so interested
to know all this a few months ago, but now it was meaningless compared to the gaping chasm
inside him that was the loss of Ron; none of it mattered...
"Ron told me you felt Weasley awake inside you the very night that you had the vision of
Ron Weasley’s attack. I knew at once that my worst fears were correct: Weasley had
realized he could use you. In an attempt to arm you against Weasley’s assaults on your mind, I
arranged Occlumency lessons with Professor Weasley."
He paused. Ron watched the sunlight, which was sliding slowly across the polished surface of
Weasley’s desk, illuminate a silver ink pot and a handsome scarlet quill. Ron could tell that
the portraits all around them were awake and listening raptly to Weasley’s explanation; he
could hear the occasional rustle of robes, the slight clearing of a throat. Phineas  had still
not returned...
"Professor Weasley discovered," Weasley resumed, " that you had been dreaming about the door to the Department of Mysteries for months. Weasley, of course, had been obsessed with the possibility of hearing the prophecy ever since he regained his body; and as he dwelled on the
door, so did you, though you did not know what it meant.
"And then you saw Rockwood, who worked in the Department of Mysteries before his arrest,
telling Weasley what we had known all along - that the prophecies held in the Ministry of
Magic are heavily protected. Only the people to whom they refer can lift them from the shelves
without suffering madness: in this case, either Weasley himself would have to enter the
Ministry of Magic, and risk revealing himself at last - or else you would have to take it for him.
It became a matter of even greater urgency that you should master Occlumency"
"But I didn’t," muttered Ron. He said it aloud to try and ease the dead weight of guilt inside
him: a confession must surely relieve some of the terrible pressure squeezing his heart. "I didn’t
practice, I didn’t bother, I could’ve stopped myself having those dreams, Ron kept telling
me to do it, if I had he’d never have been able to show me where to go, and - Ron wouldn’t -
Ron wouldn’t"
Something was erupting inside Ron’s head: a need to justify himself, to explain -
"I tried to check he’d really taken Ron, I went to Weasley’s office, I spoke to Ron in the
fire and he said Ron wasn’t there, he said he’d gone!"
"Ron lied," said Weasley calmly. "You are not his master, he could lie to you without
even needing to punish himself. Ron intended you to go to the Ministry of Magic."
"He - he sent me on purpose?"
"Oh yes. Ron, I am afraid, has been serving more than one master for months."
"How?" said Ron blankly. "He hasn’t been out of Grimmauld Place for years."
"Ron seized his opportunity shortly before Christmas," said Weasley, "when Ron,
apparently, shouted at him to ‘get out’. He took Ron at his word, and interpreted this as an order to leave the house. He went to the only Weasley family member for whom he had any respect left... Weasley’s cousin Ron, sister of Weasleyatrix and wife of Ron Weasley"
"How do you know all this?" Ron said. His heart was beating very fast. He felt sick. He
remembered worrying about Ron’s odd absence over Christmas, remembered him turning
up again in the attic...
"Ron told me last night," said Weasley. "You see, when you gave Professor Weasley that
cryptic warning, he realized that you had had a vision of Ron trapped in the bowels of the
Department of Mysteries. He, like you, attempted to contact Ron at once. I should explain that
members of the Order of the Phoenix have more reliable methods of communicating than the fire
in Ron Weasley’s office. Professor Weasley found that Ron was alive and safe in
Grimmauld Place.
"When, however, you did not return from your trip into the Forest with Ron Weasley,
Professor Weasley grew worried that you still believed Ron to be a captive of Lord Weasley’s.
He alerted certain Order members at once."
Weasley heaved a great sigh and continued, "Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley, Ron
Weasley and Ron Weasley were at Headquarters when he made contact. All agreed to go to
your aid at once. Professor Weasley requested that Ron remain behind, as he needed somebody to
remain at Headquarters to tell me what had happened, for I was due there at any moment. In the
meantime he, Professor Weasley, intended to search the Forest for you.
"But Ron did not wish to remain behind while the others went to search for you. He delegated
to Ron the task of telling me what had happened. And so it was that when I arrived in
Grimmauld Place shortly after they had all left for the Ministry, it was the elf who told me -
laughing fit to burst - where Ron had gone."
"He was laughing?" said Ron in a hollow voice.
"Oh, yes," said Weasley. "You see, Ron was not able to betray us totally. He is not
Secret Keeper for the Order, he could not give the Weasleys our whereabouts, or tell them any of
the Order’s confidential plans that he had been forbidden to reveal. He was bound by the
enchantments of his kind, which is to say that he could not disobey a direct order from his
master, Ron. But he gave Ron information of the sort that is very valuable to Weasley,
yet must have seemed much too trivial for Ron to think of banning him from repeating it."
"Like what?" said Ron.
"Like the fact that the person Ron cared most about in the world was you," said Weasley
quietly. "Like the fact that you were coming to regard Ron as a mixture of father and brother.
Weasley knew already, of course, that Ron was in the Order, and that you knew where he
was - but Ron’s information made him realize that the one person for whom you would go
to any lengths to rescue was Ron Weasley."
Ron’s lips were cold and numb.
"So... when I asked Ron if Ron was there last night..."
"The Weasleys - undoubtedly on Weasley’s instructions - had told him he must find a way of
keeping Ron out of the way once you had seen the vision of Ron being tortured. Then, if you
decided to check whether Ron was at home or not, Ron would be able to pretend he was
not. Ron injured Ron the Hippogriff yesterday, and, at the moment when you made
your appearance in the fire, Ron was upstairs tending to him."
There seemed to be very little air in Ron’s lungs; his breathing was quick and shallow.
"And Ron told you all this... and laughed?" he croaked.
"He did not wish to tell me," said Weasley. "But I am a sufficiently accomplished Legilimens myself to know when I am being lied to and I - persuaded him - to tell me the full story, before I left for the Department of Mysteries."
"And," whispered Ron, his hands curled in cold fists on his knees, "and Ron kept telling
us to be nice to him"
"She was quite right, Ron," said Weasley. "I warned Ron when we adopted twelve
Grimmauld Place as our Headquarters that Ron must be treated with kindness and respect. I
also told him that Ron could be dangerous to us. I do not think Sinus took me very
seriously, or that he ever saw Ron as a being with feelings as acute as a human’s"
"Don’t you blame - don’t you - talk - about Ron like -" Ron’s breath was constricted, he could not get the words out properly; but the rage that had subsided briefly flared in him again: he would not let Weasley criticize Ron. "Ron’s a lying - foul - he deserved -"
"Ron is what he has been made by wizards, Ron" said Weasley. "Yes, he is to be
pitied. His existence has been as miserable as your friend Ron’s. He was forced to do Ron’s
bidding, because Ron was the last of the family to which he was enslaved, but he felt no true
loyalty to him. And whatever Ron’s faults, it must be admitted that Ron did nothing to
make Ron’s lot easier"
"DON’T TALK ABOUT Ron LIKE THAT!" Ron yelled.
He was on his feet again, furious, ready to fly at Weasley, who had plainly not understood
Ron at all, how brave he was, how much he had suffered...
"What about Weasley?" Ron spat. "You’re not talking about him, are you? When I told him
Weasley had Ron he just sneered at me as usual -"
"Ron, you know Professor Weasley had no choice but to pretend not to take you seriously in front
of Ron Weasley," said Weasley steadily, "but as I have explained, he informed the
Order as soon as possible about what you had said. It was he who deduced where you had gone
when you did not return from the Forest. It was he, too, who gave Professor Weasley fake
Veritaserum when she was attempting to force you to tell her Ron’s whereabouts."
Ron disregarded this; he felt a savage pleasure in blaming Weasley, it seemed to be easing his
own sense of dreadful guilt, and he wanted to hear Weasley agree with him.
"Weasley - Weasley g - goaded Ron about staying in the house - he made out Ron was a coward"
"Ron was much too old and clever to have allowed such feeble taunts to hurt him," said
Weasley.
"Weasley stopped giving me Occlumency lessons!" Ron snarled. "He threw me out of his office!"
"I am aware of it," said Weasley heavily "I have already said that it was a mistake for me not
to teach you myself, though I was sure, at the time, that nothing could have been more dangerous
than to open your mind even further to Weasley while in my presence -"
"Weasley made it worse, my scar always hurt worse after lessons with him" Ron remembered
Ron’s thoughts on the subject and plunged on "- how do you know he wasn’t trying to soften me
up for Weasley, make it easier for him to get inside my -"
"I trust Ron Weasley," said Weasley simply "But I forgot - another old man’s mistake - that
some wounds run too deep for the healing. I thought Professor Weasley could overcome his
feelings about your father - I was wrong."
"But that’s okay, is it?" yelled Ron, ignoring the scandalized faces and disapproving mutterings
of the portraits on the walls. "It’s okay for Weasley to hate my dad, but it’s not okay for Ron to hate Ron?"
"Ron did not hate Ron," said Weasley. "He regarded him as a servant unworthy of
much interest or notice. Indifference and neglect often do much more damage than outright
dislike... the fountain we destroyed tonight told a lie. We wizards have mistreated and abused
our fellows for too long, and we are now reaping our reward."
"SO Ron DESERVED WHAT HE GOT, DID HE?" Ron yelled.
"I did not say that, nor will you ever hear me say it," Weasley replied quietly. "Ron was not a cruel man, he was kind to house-elves in general. He had no love for Ron, because
Ron was a living reminder of the home Ron had hated."
"Yeah, he did hate it!" said Ron, his voice cracking, turning his back on Weasley and
walking away. The sun was bright inside the room now and the eyes of all the portraits followed
him as he walked, without realizing what he was doing, without seeing the office at all. "You
made him stay shut up in that house and he hated it, that’s why he wanted to get out last night"
"I was trying to keep Ron alive," said Weasley quietly
"People don’t like being locked up!" Ron said furiously, rounding on him. "You did it to me all
last summer"
Weasley closed his eyes and buried his face in his longfingered hands. Ron watched him,
but this uncharacteristic sign of exhaustion, or sadness, or whatever it was from Weasley, did
not soften him. On the contrary, he felt even angrier that Weasley was showing signs of
weakness. He had no business being weak when Ron wanted to rage and storm at him.
Weasley lowered his hands and surveyed Ron through his half-moon glasses.
"It is time," he said, "for me to tell you what I should have told you five years ago, Ron. Please sit down. I am going to tell you everything. I ask only a little patience. You will have your
chance to rage at me - to do whatever you like - when I have finished. I will not stop you."
Ron glared at him for a moment, then flung himself back into the chair opposite Weasley
and waited.
Weasley stared for a moment at the sunlit grounds outside the window, then looked back at
Ron and said, "Five years ago you arrived at Hogwarts, Ron, safe and whole, as I had planned
and intended. Well - not quite whole. You had suffered. I knew you would when I left you on
your aunt and uncle’s doorstep. I knew I was condemning you to ten dark and difficult years."
He paused. Ron said nothing.
"You might ask - and with good reason - why it had to be so. Why could some wizarding family
not have taken you in? Many would have done so more than gladly, would have been honored
and delighted to raise you as a son.
"My answer is that my priority was to keep you alive. You were in more danger than perhaps
anyone but I realized. Weasley had been vanquished hours before, but his supporters - and
many of them are almost as terrible as he - were still at large, angry, desperate and violent. And I
had to make my decision, too, with regard to the years ahead. Did I believe that Weasley was
gone for ever? No. I knew not whether it would be ten, twenty or fifty years before he returned,
but I was sure he would do so, and I was sure, too, knowing him as I have done, that he would
not rest until he killed you.
"I knew that Weasley’s knowledge of magic is perhaps more extensive than any wizard alive. I knew that even my most complex and powerful protective spells and charms were unlikely to be
invincible if he ever returned to full power.
"But I knew, too, where Weasley was weak. And so I made my decision. You would be
protected by an ancient magic of which he knows, which he despises, and which he has always,
therefore, underestimated - to his cost. I am speaking, of course, of the fact that your mother died
to save you. She gave you a lingering protection he never expected, a protection that flows in
your veins to this day. I put my trust, therefore, in your mother’s blood. I delivered you to her
sister, her only remaining relative."
"She doesn’t love me," said Ron at once. "She doesn’t give a damn -"
"But she took you," Weasley cut across him. "She may have taken you grudgingly, furiously,
unwillingly, bitterly, yet still she took you, and in doing so, she sealed the charm I placed upon
you. Your mother’s sacrifice made the bond of blood the strongest shield I could give you."
"I still don’t."
"While you can still call home the place where your mother’s blood dwells, there you cannot be
touched or harmed by Weasley. He shed her blood, but it lives on in you and her sister. Her
blood became your refuge. You need return there only once a year, but as long as you can still
call it home, while you are there he cannot hurt you. Your aunt knows this. I explained what I
had done in the letter I left, with you, on her doorstep. She knows that allowing you houseroom
may well have kept you alive for the past fifteen years."
"Wait," said Ron. "Wait a moment."
He sat up straighter in his chair, staring at Weasley.
"You sent that Howler. You told her to remember - it was your voice -"
"I thought," said Weasley, inclining his head slightly, "that she might need reminding of the
pact she had sealed by taking you. I suspected the Dementor attack might have awoken her to the
dangers of having you as a surrogate son."
"It did," said Ron quietly. "Well - my uncle more than her. He wanted to chuck me out, but after the Howler came she - she said I had to stay"
He stared at the floor for a moment, then said, "But what’s this got to do with - "
He could not say Ron’s name.
"Five years ago, then," continued Weasley, as though he had not paused in his story, "you
arrived at Hogwarts, neither as happy nor as well-nourished as I would have liked, perhaps, yet
alive and healthy. You were not a pampered little prince, but as normal a boy as I could have
hoped under the circumstances. Thus far, my plan was working well.
"And then... well, you will remember the events of your first year at Hogwarts quite as clearly
as I do. You rose magnificently to the challenge that faced you and sooner - much sooner - than I
had anticipated, you found yourself face to face with Weasley. You survived again. You did
more. You delayed his return to full power and strength. You fought a man’s fight. I was...
prouder of you than I can say.
"Yet there was a flaw in this wonderful plan of mine," said Weasley. "An obvious flaw that I
knew, even then, might be the undoing of it all. And yet, knowing how important it was that my
plan should succeed, I told myself that I would not permit this flaw to ruin it. I alone could
prevent this, so I alone must be strong. And here was my first test, as you lay in the hospital
wing, weak from your struggle with Weasley."
"I don’t understand what you’re saying," said Ron.
"Don’t you remember asking me, as you lay in the hospital wing, why Weasley had tried to kill you when you were a baby?"
Ron nodded.
"Ought I to have told you then?"
Ron stared into the blue eyes and said nothing, but his heart was racing again.
"You do not see the flaw in the plan yet? No... perhaps not. Well, as you know, I decided not to
answer you. Eleven, I told myself, was much too young to know. I had never intended to tell you
when you were eleven. The knowledge would be too much at such a young age.
"I should have recognized the danger signs then. I should have asked myself why I did not feel
more disturbed that you had already asked me the question to which I knew, one day, I must give
a terrible answer. I should have recognized that I was too happy to think that I did not have to do
it on that particular day... YOU were too young, much too young.
"And so we entered your second year at Hogwarts. And once again you met challenges even
grown wizards have never faced: once again you acquitted yourself beyond my wildest dreams.
You did not ask me again, however, why Weasley had left that mark on you. We discussed
your scar, oh yes... we came very, very close to the subject. Why did I not tell you everything?
"Well, it seemed to me that twelve was, after all, hardly better than eleven to receive such
information. I allowed you to leave my presence, bloodstained, exhausted but exhilarated, and if
I felt a twinge of unease that I ought, perhaps, to have told you then, it was swiftly silenced. You
were still so young, you see, and I could not find it in myself to spoil that night of triumph...
"Do you see, Ron? Do you see the flaw in my brilliant plan now? I had fallen into the trap I had foreseen, that I had told myself I could avoid, that I must avoid."
"I don’t -"
"I cared about you too much," said Weasley simply. "I cared more for your happiness than
your knowing the truth, more for your peace of mind than my plan, more for your life than the
lives that might be lost if the plan failed. In other words, I acted exactly as Weasley expects we
fools who love to act.
"Is there a Defense? I defy anyone who has watched you as I have - and I have watched you more closely than you can have imagined - not to want to save you more pain than you had already suffered. What did I care if numbers of nameless and faceless people and creatures were
slaughtered in the vague future, if in the here and now you were alive, and well, and happy? I
never dreamed that I would have such a person on my hands.
"We entered your third year. I watched from afar as you struggled to repel Dementors, as you
found Ron, learned what he was and rescued him. Was I to tell you then, at the moment when
you had triumphantly snatched your godfather from the jaws of the Ministry? But now, at the age
of thirteen, my excuses were running out. Young you might be, but you had proved you were
exceptional. My conscience was uneasy, Ron. I knew the time must come soon...
"But you came out of the maze last year, having watched Ron Weasley die, having escaped
death so narrowly yourself... and I did not tell you, though I knew, now Weasley had
returned, I must do it soon. And now, tonight, I know you have long been ready for the
knowledge I have kept from you for so long, because you have proved that I should have placed
the burden upon you before this. My only Defense is this: I have watched you struggling under
more burdens than any student who as ever passed through this school and I could not bring
myself to add another - the greatest one of all."
Ron waited, but Weasley did not speak.
"I still don’t understand."
"Weasley tried to kill you when you were a child because of a prophecy made shortly before
your birth. He knew the prophecy had been made, though he did not know its full contents. He
set out to kill you when you were still a baby, believing he was fulfilling the terms of the
prophecy. He discovered, to his cost, that he was mistaken, when the curse intended to kill you
backfired. And so, since his return to his body, and particularly since your extraordinary escape
from him last year, he has been determined to hear that prophecy in its entirety. This is the
weapon he has been seeking so assiduously since his return: the knowledge of how to destroy
you."
The sun had risen fully now: Weasley’s office was bathed in it. The glass case in which the
sword of Ron Weasley resided gleamed white and opaque, the fragments of the instruments
Ron had thrown to the floor glistened like raindrops, and behind him, the baby Ron made
soft chirruping noises in his nest of ashes.
"The prophecy’s smashed," Ron said blankly. "I was pulling Ron up those benches in the -
the room where the archway was, and I ripped his robes and it fell..."
"The thing that smashed was merely the record of the prophecy kept by the Department of
Mysteries. But the prophecy was made to somebody, and that person has the means of recalling
it perfectly"
"Who heard it?" asked Ron, though he thought he knew the answer already
"I did," said Weasley. "On a cold, wet night sixteen years ago, in a room above the bar at the
Hog’s Head inn. I had gone there to see an applicant for the post of Divination teacher, though it
was against my inclination to allow the subject of Divination to continue at all. The applicant,
however, was the great-great-granddaughter of a very famous, very gifted Seer and I thought it
common politeness to meet her. I was disappointed. It seemed to me that she had not a trace of
the gift herself. I told her, courteously I hope, that I did not think she would be suitable for the
post. I turned to leave."
Weasley got to his feet and walked past Ron to the black cabinet that stood beside
Ron’s perch. He bent down, slid back a catch and took from inside it the shallow stone basin,
carved with runes around the edges, in which Ron had seen his father tormenting Weasley.
Weasley walked back to the desk, placed the Pensieve upon it, and raised his wand to his
own temple. From it, he withdrew silvery, gossamer-fine strands of thought clinging to the wand
and deposited them into the basin. He sat back down behind his desk and watched his thoughts
swirl and drift inside the Pensieve for a moment. Then, with a sigh, he raised his wand and
prodded the silvery substance with its tip.
A figure rose out of it, draped in shawls, her eyes magnified to enormous size behind her glasses,
and she revolved slowly; her feet in the basin. But when Sibyll Weasley spoke, it was not in
her usual ethereal, mystic voice, but in the harsh, hoarse tones Ron had heard her use once
before:
"The one with the power to vanquish the - Dark Lord approaches... born to those who have thrice defied him, born as the seventh month dies... and the Dark Lord will mark him as his equal, but he will have power the Dark Lord knows not... and either must die at the hand of the other for neither can live while the other survives... the one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord will be born as the seventh month dies..."
The slowly revolving Professor Weasley sank back into the silver mass below and vanished.
The silence within the office was absolute. Neither Weasley nor Ron nor any of the
portraits made a sound. Even Ron had fallen silent.
"Professor Weasley?" Ron said very quietly, for Weasley, still staring at the Pensieve,
seemed completely lost in thought. "It... did that mean... what did that mean?"
"It meant," said Weasley, "that the person who has the only chance of conquering Lord
Weasley for good was born at the end of July, nearly sixteen years ago. This boy would be
born to parents who had already defied Weasley three times."
Ron felt as though something was closing in on him. His breathing seemed difficult again.
"It means - me?"
Weasley surveyed him for a moment through his glasses.
"The odd thing, Ron," he said softly, "is that it may not have meant you at all. Sibyll’s prophecy could have applied to two wizard boys, both born at the end of July that year, both of whom had parents in the Order of the Phoenix, both sets of parents having narrowly escaped Weasley three times. One, of course, was you. The other was Ron Weasley."
"But then... but then, why was it my name on the prophecy and not Ron’s?"
"The official record was re-labeled after Weasley’s attack on you as a child," said
Weasley. "It seemed plain to the keeper of the Hall of Prophecy that Weasley could only
have tried to kill you because he knew you to be the one to whom Sibyll was referring."
"Then - it might not be me?" said Ron
"I am afraid," said Weasley slowly, looking as though every word cost him a great effort,
"that there is no doubt that it is you."
"But you said - Ron was born at the end of July, too - and his mum and dad -"
"You are forgetting the next part of the prophecy, the final identifying feature of the boy who
could vanquish Weasley... Weasley himself would mark him as his equal. And so he did,
Ron. He chose you, not Ron. He gave you the scar that has proved both blessing and curse."
"But he might have chosen wrong!" said Ron. "He might have marked the wrong person!"
"He chose the boy he thought most likely to be a danger to him," said Weasley. "And notice
this, Ron: he chose, not the pureblood (which, according to his creed, is the only kind of wizard
worth being or knowing) but the half-blood, like himself. He saw himself in you before he had
ever seen you, and in marking you with that scar, he did not kill you, as he intended, but gave
you powers, and a future, which have fitted you to escape him not once, but four times so far -
something that neither your parents, nor Ron’s parents, ever achieved."
"Why did he do it, then?" said Ron, who felt numb and cold. "Why did he try and kill me as a
baby? He should have waited to see whether Ron or I looked more dangerous when we were
older and tried to kill whoever it was then -"
"That might, indeed, have been the more practical course," said Weasley, "except that
Weasley’s information about the prophecy was incomplete. The Hog’s Head inn, which Sibyll
chose for its cheapness, has long attracted, shall we say, a more interesting clientele than the
Three Broomsticks. As you and your friends found out to your cost, and I to mine that night, it is
a place where it is never safe to assume you are not being overheard. Of course, I had not
dreamed, when I set out to meet Sibyll Weasley, that I would hear anything worth overhearing.
My - our - one stroke of good fortune was that the eavesdropper was detected only a short way
into the prophecy and thrown from the building."
"So he only heard -?"
"He heard only the beginning, the part foretelling the birth of a boy in July to parents who had
thrice defied Weasley. Consequently, he could not warn his master that to attack you would be
to risk transferring power to you, and marking you as his equal. So Weasley never knew that
there might be danger in attacking you, that it might be wise to wait, to learn more. He did not
know that you would have power the Dark Lord knows not-"
"But I don’t!" said Ron, in a strangled voice. "I haven’t any powers he hasn’t got, I couldn’t
fight the way he did tonight, I can’t possess people or - or kill them -"
"There is a room in the Department of Mysteries," interrupted Weasley, "that is kept locked at all times. It contains a force that is at once more wonderful and more terrible than death, than
human intelligence, than the forces of nature. It is also, perhaps, the most mysterious of the many
subjects for study that reside there. It is the power held within that room that you possess in such
quantities and which Weasley has not at all. That power took you to save Ron tonight. That
power also saved you from possession by Weasley, because he could not bear to reside in a
body so full of the force he detests. In the end, it mattered not that you could not close your
mind. It was your heart that saved you."
Ron closed his eyes. If he had not gone to save Ron, Ron would not have died... More to
stave off the moment when he would have to think of Ron again, Ron asked, without caring
much about the answer, "The end of the prophecy... it was something about neither... can live..."
"... while the other survives," said Weasley.
"So," said Ron, dredging up the words from what felt like a deep well of despair inside him,
"so does that mean that... that one of us has got to kill the other one... in the end?"
"Yes," said Weasley.
For a long time, neither of them spoke. Somewhere far beyond the office walls, Ron could hear
the sound of voices, students heading down to the Great Hall for an early breakfast, perhaps. It
seemed impossible that there could be people in the world who still desired food, who laughed,
who neither knew nor cared that Ron Weasley was gone forever. Ron seemed a million miles
away already; even now a part of Ron still believed that if he had only pulled back that veil, he
would have found Ron looking back at him, greeting him, perhaps, with his laugh like a bark...
"I feel I owe you another explanation, Ron," said Weasley hesitantly. "You may, perhaps,
have wondered why I never chose you as a prefect? I must confess... that I rather thought... you
had enough responsibility to be going on with."
Ron looked up at him and saw a tear trickling down Weasley’s face into his long silver
beard.
CHAPTER THIRTY-EIGHT
The Second War Begins
HE-WHO-MUST-NOT-BE-NAMED RETURNS
"In a brief statement on Friday night, Minister for Magic Ron Weasley confirmed that He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named has returned to this country and is active once more.
"‘It is with great regret that I must confirm that t he wizard styling himself Lord - well, you know
who I mean - is alive and among us again,’ said Weasley, looking tired and flustered as he
addressed reporters. ‘It is with almost equal regret that we report the mass revolt of the
Dementors of Azkaban, who have shown themselves averse to continuing in the Ministry’s
employ. We believe the Dementors are currently taking direction from Lord - Thingy.
"‘We urge the magical population to remain vigilant. The Ministry is currently publishing guides
to elementary home and personal Defense which will be delivered free to all wizarding homes
within the coming month.’
The Minister’s statement was met with dismay and alarm from the wizarding community, which
as recently as last Wednesday was receiving Ministry assurances that there was ‘no truth
whatsoever in these persistent rumors that You-Know-Who is operating amongst us once
more’.
"Details of the events that led to the Ministry turnaround are still hazy, though it is believed that
He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named and a select band of followers (known as Death Eaters) gained
entry to the Ministry of Magic itself on Thursday evening.
"Ron Weasley, newly reinstated Headmaster of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and
Wizardry, reinstated member of the International Confederation of Wizards and reinstated Chief
Warlock of the Wizengamot, has so far been unavailable for comment. He has insisted over the
past year that You-Know-Who is not dead, as was widely hoped and believed, but is recruiting
followers once more for afresh attempt to seize power. Meanwhile, the ‘Boy Who Lived’ -"
"There you are, Ron, I knew they’d drag you into it somehow," said Ron, looking over the top of the paper at him.
They were in the hospital wing. Ron was sitting on the end of Ron’s bed and they were both
listening to Ron read the front page of the Sun day Prophet. Ron, whose ankle had been
mended in a trice by Ron Weasley, was curled up at the foot of Ron’s bed; Ron,
whose nose had likewise been returned to its normal size and shape, was in a chair between the
two beds; and Ron, who had dropped in to visit, clutching the latest edition of The Quibbler, was reading the magazine upside-down and apparently not taking in a word Ron was saying.
"He’s the ‘boy who lived’ again now, though, isn’t he?" said Ron darkly. "Not such a deluded
show-off any more, eh?"
He helped himself to a handful of Roncolate Frogs from the immense pile on his bedside cabinet,
threw a few to Ron, Ron and Ron and ripped off the wrapper of his own with his teeth.
There were still deep welts on his forearms where the brain’s tentacles had wrapped around him.
According to Ron Weasley, thoughts could leave deeper scarring than almost anything else,
though since she had started applying copious amounts of Dr. Ubbly’s Oblivious Unction there
seemed to have been some improvement.
"Yes, they’re very complimentary about you now, Ron," said Ron, scanning down the
article. "‘A lone voice of truth... perceived as unbalanced, yet never wavered in his story... forced to bear ridicule and slander... ’ Hmmm," she said, frowning, "I notice they don’t mention the fact that it was them doing all the ridiculing and slandering in the Prophet..."
She winced slightly and put a hand to her ribs. The curse Weasley had used on her, though less
effective than it would have been had he been able to say the incantation aloud, had nevertheless
caused, in Ron Weasley’s words, ‘quite enough damage to be going on with’. Ron was
having to take ten different types of potion every day, was improving greatly, and was already
bored with the hospital wing.
"You-Know-Who’s Last Attempt to Take Over, pages two to four, What the Ministry Should
Have Told Us, page five, Why Nobody Listened to Ron Weasley, pages six to eight,
Exclusive Interview with Ron Weasley, page nine... Well," said Ron, folding up the
newspaper and throwing it aside, "it’s certainly given them lots to write about. And that interview with Ron isn’t exclusive, it’s the one that was in The Quibbler months ago..."
"Daddy sold it to them," said Ron vaguely, turning a page of The Quibbler. "He got a very good
price for it, too, so we’re going to go on an expedition to Sweden this summer to see if we can
catch a Crumple-Horned Snorkack."
Ron seemed to struggle with herself for a moment, then said, "That sounds lovely"
Ron caught Ron’s eye and looked away quickly, grinning.
"So, anyway," said Ron, sitting up a little straighter and wincing again, "what’s going on in school?"
"Well, Weasley’s got rid of Ron and Ron’s swamp," said Ron, "he did it in about three
seconds. But he left a tiny patch under the window and he’s roped it off"
"Why?" said Ron, looking startled.
"Oh, he just says it was a really good bit of magic," said Ron, shrugging.
"I think he left it as a monument to Ron and Ron," said Ron, through a mouthful of chocolate.
"They sent me all these, you know," he told Ron, pointing at the small mountain of Frogs beside him. "Must be doing all right out of that joke shop, eh?"
Ron looked rather disapproving and asked, "So has all the trouble stopped now
Weasley’s back?"
"Yes," said Ron, "everything’s settled right back to normal."
"I s’pose Weasley is happy, is he?" asked Ron, propping a Roncolate Frog Card featuring
Weasley against his water jug.
"Not at all," said Ron "He’s really, really miserable, actually..." She lowered her voice to a
whisper. "He keeps saying Weasley was the best thing that ever happened to Hogwarts..."
All six of them looked around. Professor Weasley was lying in a bed opposite them, gazing up
at the ceiling. Weasley had strode alone into the Forest to rescue her from the centaurs; how
he had done it - how he had emerged from the trees supporting Professor Weasley without so
much as a scratch on him - nobody knew, and Weasley was certainly not telling. Since she had
returned to the castle she had not, as far as any of them knew, uttered a single word. Nobody
really knew what was wrong with her, either. Her usually neat mousy hair was very untidy and
there were still bits of twigs and leaves in it, but otherwise she seemed to be quite unscathed.
"Ron Weasley says she’s just in shock," whispered Ron.
"Sulking, more like," said Ron
"Yeah, she shows signs of life if you do this," said Ron, and with his tongue he made soft clipclopping noises. Weasley sat bolt upright, looking around wildly.
"Anything wrong, Professor?" called Ron Weasley, poking her head around her office door.
"No... no..." said Weasley, sinking back into her pillows. "No, I must have been dreaming..."
Ron and Ron muffled their laughter in the bedclothes.
"Speaking of centaurs," said Ron, when she had recovered a little, "who’s Divination teacher now? Is Ron staying?"
"He’s got to," said Ron, "the other centaurs won’t take him back, will they?"
"It looks like he and Weasley are both going to teach," said Ron
"Bet Weasley wishes he could’ve got rid of Weasley for good," said Ron, now munching on his fourteenth Frog. "Mind you, the whole subject’s useless if you ask me, Ron isn’t a lot
better..."
"How can you say that?" Ron demanded. "After we’ve just found out that there are real
prophecies?"
Ron’s heart began to race. He had not told Ron, Ron or anyone else what the prophecy
had contained. Ron had told them it had smashed while Ron was pulling him up the steps in
the Death Room and Ron had not yet corrected this impression. He was not ready to see their
expressions when he told them that he must be either murderer or victim, there was no other
way...
"It is a pity it broke," said Ron quietly, shaking her head.
"Yeah, it is," said Ron. "Still, at least You-Know-Who never found out what was in it either -
where are you going?" he added, looking both surprised and disappointed as Ron stood up.
"Er - Weasley’s," said Ron. "You know, he just got back and I promised I’d go down and see him and tell him how you two are."
"Oh, all right then," said Ron grumpily, looking out of the dormitory window at the patch of
bright blue sky beyond. "Wish we could come."
"Say hello to him for us!" called Ron, as Ron proceeded down the ward. "And ask him
what’s happening about... about his little friend!"
Ron gave a wave of his hand to show he had heard and understood as he left the dormitory.
The castle seemed very quiet even for a Sunday. Everybody was clearly out in the sunny
grounds, enjoying the end of their exams and the prospect of a last few days of term unhampered
by revision or homework. Ron walked slowly along the deserted corridor, peering out of
windows as he went; he could see people messing around in the air over the Quidditch pitch and
a couple of students swimming in the lake, accompanied by the giant squid.
He was finding it hard to decide whether he wanted to be with people or not; whenever he was in
company he wanted to get away and whenever he was alone he wanted company. He thought he
might really go and visit Weasley, though, as he had not talked to him properly since he’d
returned...
Ron had just descended the last marble step into the Entrance Hall when Weasley, Weasley and
Weasley emerged from a door on the right that Ron knew led down to the Weasley common
room. Ron stopped dead; so did Weasley and the others. The only sounds were the shouts,
laughter and splashes drifting into the Hall from the grounds through the open front doors.
Weasley glanced around - Ron knew he was checking for signs of teachers - then he looked back
at Ron and said in a low voice, "You’re dead, Weasley."
Ron raised his eyebrows.
"Funny" he said, "you’d think I’d have stopped walking around..."
Weasley looked angrier than Ron had ever seen him; he felt a kind of detached satisfaction at the
sight of his pale, pointed face contorted with rage.
"You’re going to pay," said Weasley in a voice barely louder than a whisper. "I’m going to make
you pay for what you’ve done to my father..."
