"Well, I’m terrified now," said Ron sarcastically. "I s’pose Lord Weasley’s just a warm-up act compared to you three - what’s the matter?" he added, for Weasley, Weasley and Weasley had all
looked stricken at the sound of the name. "He’s your dad’s mate, isn’t he? Not scared of him,
are you?"
"You think you’re such a big man, Weasley," said Weasley, advancing now, Weasley and Weasley
flanking him. "You wait. I’ll have you. You can’t land my father in prison"
"I thought I just had," said Ron.
"The Dementors have left Azkaban," said Weasley quietly. "Dad and the others’ll be out in no
time..."
"Yeah, I expect they will," said Ron "Still, at least everyone knows what scumbags they are
now"
Weasley’s hand flew towards his wand, but Ron was too quick for him; he had drawn his own
wand before Weasley’s fingers had even entered the pocket of his robes.
"Weasley!"
The voice rang across the Entrance Hall. Weasley had emerged from the staircase leading down to
his office and at the sight of him Ron felt a great rush of hatred beyond anything he felt
towards Weasley... whatever Weasley said, he would never forgive Weasley... never...
"What are you doing, Weasley?" said Weasley, as coldly as ever, as he strode over to the four of them.
"I’m trying to decide what curse to use on Weasley, sir," said Ron fiercely.
Weasley stared at him.
"Put that wand away at once," he said curtly. "Ten points from Gryff-"
Weasley looked towards the giant hour-glasses on the walls and gave a sneering smile.
"Ah. I see there are no longer any points left in the Weasley hour-glass to take away. In that
case, Weasley, we will simply have to -"
"Add some more?"
Professor Weasley had just stumped up the stone steps into the castle; she was carrying a
tartan carpetbag in one hand and leaning heavily on a walking stick with her other, but otherwise
looked quite well.
"Professor Weasley!" said Weasley, striding forwards. "Out of St. Mungo’s, I see!"
"Yes, Professor Weasley," said Professor Weasley, shrugging off her traveling cloak, "I’m quite as good as new. You two - Weasley - Weasley"
She beckoned them forwards imperiously and they came, shuffling their large feet and looking
awkward.
"Here," said Professor Weasley, thrusting her carpetbag into Weasley’s chest and her cloak into Weasley’s; "take these up to my office for me."
They turned and stumped away up the marble staircase.
"Right then," said Professor Weasley, looking up at the hourglasses on the wall. "Well, I think Weasley and his friends ought to have fifty points apiece for alerting the world to the return of You-Know-Who! What say you, Professor Weasley?"
"What?" snapped Weasley, though Ron knew he had heard perfectly well. "Oh - well - I
suppose..."
"So that’s fifty each for Weasley, the two Weasleys, Weasley and Miss Weasley," said Professor Weasley, and a shower of rubies fell down into the bottom bulb of Weasley’s hour-glass as she spoke. "Oh - and fifty for Miss Weasley, I suppose," she added, and a number of sapphires fell into Weasley’s glass. "Now, you wanted to take ten from Mr. Weasley, I think, Professor Weasley - so there we are..."
A few rubies retreated into the upper bulb, leaving a respectable amount below nevertheless.
"Well, Weasley, Weasley I think you ought to be outside on a glorious day like this," Professor
Weasley continued briskly.
Ron did not need telling twice- he thrust his wand back inside his robes and headed straight for
the front doors without another glance at Weasley and Weasley.
The hot sun hit him with a blast as he walked across the lawns towards Weasley’s cabin. Students
lying around on the grass sunbathing, talking, reading the Sunday Prophet and eating sweets,
looked up at him as he passed; some called out to him, or else waved, clearly eager to show that
they, like the Prophet, had decided he was something of a hero. Ron said nothing to any of
them. He had no idea how much they knew of what had happened three days ago, but he had so
far avoided being questioned and preferred to keep it that way.
He thought at first when he knocked on Weasley’s cabin door that he was out, but then Ron came
charging around the corner and almost bowled him over with the enthusiasm of his welcome.
Weasley, it transpired, was picking runner beans in his back garden.
"All righ’, Ron!" he said, beaming, when Ron approached the fence. "Come in, come in, we’ll have a cup o’ dandelion juice..."
"How’s things?" Weasley asked him, as they settled d own at his wooden table with a glass apiece
of iced juice. "Yeh - er - feelin’ all righ’, are yeh?"
Ron knew from the look of concern on Weasley’s face that he was not referring to Ron’s
physical well-being.
"I’m fine," Ron said quickly, because he could no t bear to discuss the thing that he knew was in Weasley’s mind. "So, where’re you been?"
"Bin hidin’ out in the mountains," said Weasley. "Up in a cave, like Ron did when he -"
Weasley broke off, cleared his throat gruffly, looked at Ron, and took a long draught of juice.
"Anyway, back now," he said feebly.
"You - you look better," said Ron, who was determined to keep the conversation moving away
from Ron.
"Wha’?" said Weasley, raising a massive hand and feeling his face. "Oh - oh yeah. Well, Rony’s loads better behaved now, loads. Seemed right pleased ter see me when I got back, ter tell yeh the truth. He’s a good lad, really... I’ve bin thinkin’ abou’ tryin’ ter find him a lady friend, actually..."
Ron would normally have tried to persuade Weasley out of this idea at once; the prospect of a
second giant taking up residence in the Forest, possibly even wilder and more brutal than Ron,
was positively alarming, but somehow Ron could not muster the energy necessary to argue the
point. He was starting to wish he was alone again, and with the idea of hastening his departure he
took several large gulps of his dandelion juice, half-emptying his glass.
"Ev’ryone knows yeh’ve bin tellin’ the truth now, Ron," said Weasley softly and unexpectedly. He was watching Ron closely. "Tha’s gotta be better, hasn’ it?"
Ron shrugged.
"Look..." Weasley leaned towards him across the table, "I knew Ron longer ‘n yeh did... he died in battle, an’ tha’s the way he’d’ve wanted ter go -"
"He didn’t want to go at all!" said Ron angrily.
Weasley bowed his great shaggy head...
"Nah, I don’ reckon he did," he said quietly. "But s till, Ron... he was never one ter sit aroun’ at home an’ let other people do the fightin’. He couldn’ve lived with himself if he hadn’ gone ter
help -"
Ron leapt up.
"I’ve got to go and visit Ron and Ron in the hospital wing," he said mechanically.
"Oh," said Weasley, looking rather upset. "Oh... all righ’ then, Ron... take care o’ yerself then, an’ drop back in if yeh’ve got a -"
"Yeah... right..."
Ron crossed to the door as fast as he could and pulled it open; he was out in the sunshine again
before Weasley had finished saying goodbye, and walking away across the lawn. Once again,
people called out to him as he passed. He closed his eyes for a few moments, wishing they would
all vanish, that he could open his eyes and find himself alone in the grounds...
A few days ago, before his exams had finished and he had seen the vision Weasley had planted in his mind, he would have given almost anything for the wizarding world to know he had been telling the truth, for them to believe that Weasley was back, and to know that he was neither a liar nor mad. Now, however...
He walked a short way around the lake, sat down on its bank, sheltered from the gaze of passersby behind a tangle of shrubs, and stared out over the gleaming water, thinking...
Perhaps the reason he wanted to be alone was because he had felt isolated from everybody since
his talk with Weasley. An invisible barrier separated him from the rest of the world. He was -
he had always been - a marked man. It was just that he had never really understood what that
meant...
And yet sitting here on the edge of the lake, with the terrible weight of grief dragging at him,
with the loss of Ron so raw and fresh inside, he could not muster any great sense of fear. It was
sunny, and the grounds around him were full of laughing people, and even though he felt as
distant from them as though he belonged to a different race, it was still very hard to believe as he
sat here that his life must include, or end in, murder...
He sat there for a long time, gazing out at the water, trying not to think about his godfather or to
remember that it was directly across from here, on the opposite bank, that Ron had once
collapsed trying to fend off a hundred Dementors...
The sun had set before he realized he was cold. He got up and returned to the castle, wiping his
face on his sleeve as he went.
Ron and Ron left the hospital wing completely cured three days before the end of term.
Ron kept showing signs of wanting to talk about Ron, but Ron tended to make `hushing
noises every time she mentioned his name. Ron was still not sure whether or not he wanted to
talk about his godfather yet; his wishes varied with his mood. He knew one thing, though:
unhappy as he felt at the moment, he would greatly miss Hogwarts in a few days’ time when he
was back at number four, Privet Drive. Even though he now understood exactly why he had to
return there every summer, he did not feel any better about it. Indeed, he had never dreaded his
return more.
Professor Weasley left Hogwarts the day before the end of term. It seemed she had crept out of
the hospital wing during dinnertime, evidently hoping to depart undetected, but unfortunately for
her, she met Ron on the way, who seized his last chance to do as Ron had instructed, and
chased her gleefully from the premises whacking her alternately with a walking stick and a sock
full of chalk. Many students ran out into the Entrance Hall to watch her running away down the
path and the Heads of Houses tried only half-heartedly to restrain them. Indeed, Professor
Weasley sank back into her chair at the staff table after a few feeble remonstrances and was
clearly heard to express a regret that she could not run cheering after Weasley herself, because
Ron had borrowed her walking stick.
Their last evening at school arrived; most people had finished packing and were already heading
down to the end-of-term feast, but Ron had not even started.
"Just do it tomorrow!" said Ron, who was waiting by the door of their dormitory. "Come on, I’m
starving."
"I won’t be long... look, you go ahead..."
But when the dormitory door closed behind Ron, Ron made no effort to speed up his packing.
The very last thing he wanted to do was to attend the Leaving Feast. He was worried that
Weasley would make some reference to him in his speech. He was sure to mention
Weasley’s return; he had talked to them about it last year, after all...
Ron pulled some crumpled robes out of the very bottom of his trunk to make way for folded
ones and, as he did so, noticed a badly wrapped package lying in a corner of it. He could not
think what it was doing there. He bent down, pulled it out from underneath his trainers and
examined it.
He realized what it was within seconds. Ron had given it to him just inside the front door of
number twelve Grimmauld Place. ‘Use it if you need me, all right?’
Ron sank down on to his bed and unwrapped the package. Out fell a small, square mirror. It
looked old; it was certainly dirty. Ron held it up to his face and saw his own reflection looking
back at him.
He turned the mirror over. There on the reverse side was a scribbled note from Ron.
This is a two-way mirror, I’ve got the other. If you need to speak to me, just say my name into it; you’ll appear in my mirror and I‘ll be able to talk in yours. Ron and I used to use them when we were in separate detentions.
Ron’s heart began to race. He remembered seeing his dead parents in the Mirror of Erised four
years ago. He was going to be able to talk to Ron again, right now, he knew it -
He looked around to make sure there was nobody else there; the dormitory was quite empty. He
looked back at the mirror, raised it in front of his face with trembling hands and said, loudly and
clearly, "Ron."
His breath misted the surface of the glass. He held the mirror even closer, excitement flooding
through him, but the eyes blinking back at him through the fog were definitely his own.
He wiped the mirror clear again and said, so that every syllable rang clearly through the room:
"Ron Weasley!"
Nothing happened. The frustrated face looking back out of the mirror was still, definitely, his
own...
Ron didn’t have his mirror on him when he went through the archway, said a small voice in
Ron’s head. That’s why it’s not working...
Ron remained quite still for a moment, then hurled the mirror back into the trunk where it
shattered. He had been convinced, for a whole, shining minute, that he was going to see Ron,
talk to him again...
Disappointment was burning in his throat; he got up and began throwing his things pell-mell into
the trunk on top of the broken mirror -
But then an idea struck him... a better idea than a mirror... a much bigger, more important
idea... how had he never thought of it before - why had he never asked?
He was sprinting out of the dormitory and down the spiral staircase hitting the walls as he ran
and barely noticing; he hurtled across the empty common room, through the portrait hole and off
along the corridor, ignoring the Ron Weasley, who called after him: "The feast is about to start, you
know, you’re cutting it very fine!"
But Ron had no intention of going to the feast...
How could it be that the place was full of ghosts whenever you didn’t need one, yet now...
He ran down staircases and along corridors and met nobody either alive or dead. They were all,
clearly, in the Great Hall. Outside his Charms classroom he came to a halt, panting and thinking
disconsolately that he would have to wait until later, until after the end of the feast...
But just as he had given up hope, he saw it - a translucent somebody drifting across the end of
the corridor.
"Hey - hey Ron! Ron!"
The ghost stuck its head back out of the wall, revealing the extravagantly plumed hat and
dangerously wobbling head of Sir Nicholas de Mimsy-Porpington.
"Good evening," he said, withdrawing the rest of his body from the solid stone and smiling at
Ron "I am not the only one who is late, then? Though," he sighed, "in a rather different sense, of course..."
"Ron, can I ask you something?"
A most peculiar expression stole over Nearly Headless Ron’s face as he inserted a finger in the
stiff ruff at his neck and tugged it a little straighter, apparently to give himself thinking time. He
desisted only when his partially severed neck seemed about to give way completely.
"Er - now, Ron?" said Ron, looking discomfited. "Can’t it wait until after the feast?"
"No - Ron - please," said Ron, "I really need to talk to you. Can we go in here?"
Ron opened the door of the nearest classroom and Nearly Headless Ron sighed.
"Oh, very well," he said, looking resigned. "I can’t pretend I haven’t been expecting it."
Ron was holding the door open for him, but he drifted through the wall instead.
"Expecting what?" Ron asked, as he closed the door.
"You to come and find me," said Ron, now gliding over to the window and looking out at the
darkening grounds. "It happens, sometimes... when somebody has suffered a... loss."
"Well," said Ron, refusing to be deflected. "You were right, I’ve - I’ve come to find you."
Ron said nothing.
"It’s -" said Ron, who was finding this more awkward than he had anticipated, "it’s just - you’re dead. But you’re still here, aren’t you?"
Ron sighed and continued to gaze out at the grounds.
"That’s right, isn’t it?" Ron urged him. "You died, but I’m talking to you... you can walk around Hogwarts and everything, can’t you?"
"Yes," said Nearly Headless Ron quietly, "I walk and talk, yes."
"So, you came back, didn’t you?" said Ron urgently. "People can come back, right? As ghosts.
They don’t have to disappear completely. Well?" he added impatiently, when Ron continued to
say nothing.
Nearly Headless Ron hesitated, then said, "Not everyone can come back as a ghost."
"What d’you mean?" said Ron quickly
"Only... only wizards."
"Oh," said Ron, and he almost laughed with relief. "Well, that’s okay then, the person I’m asking about is a wizard. So he can come back, right?"
Ron turned away from the window and looked mournfully at Ron.
"He won’t come back."
"Who?"
"Ron Weasley," said Ron.
"But you did!" said Ron angrily. "You came back - you’re dead and you didn’t disappear -"
"Wizards can leave an imprint of themselves upon the earth, to walk palely where their living
selves once trod," said Ron miserably. "But very few wizards choose that path."
"Why not?" said Ron. "Anyway - it doesn’t matter - Ron won’t care if it’s unusual, he’ll come back, I know he will!"
And so strong was his belief, Ron actually turned his head to check the door, sure, for a split
second, that he was going to see Ron, pearly-white and transparent but beaming, walking
through it towards him.
"He will not come back," repeated Ron. "He will have... gone on."
"What d’you mean, ‘gone on’?" said Ron quickly "Gone on where? Listen - what happens when you die, anyway? Where do you go? Why doesn’t everyone come back? Why isn’t this place full of ghosts? Why -?"
"I cannot answer," said Ron.
"You’re dead, aren’t you?" said Ron exasperatedly. "Who can answer better than you?"
"I was afraid of death," said Ron softly. "I chose to remain behind. I sometimes wonder whether I oughtn’t to have... well, that is neither here nor there... in fact, I am neither here nor there..."
He gave a small sad chuckle. "I know nothing of the secrets of death, Ron, for I chose my feeble imitation of life instead. I believe learned wizards study the matter in the Department of
Mysteries -"
"Don’t talk to me about that place!" said Ron fiercely.
"I am sorry not to have been more help," said Ron gently "Well... well, do excuse me... the
feast, you know..."
And he left the room, leaving Ron there alone, gazing blankly at the wall through which Ron
had disappeared.
Ron felt almost as though he had lost his godfather all over again in losing the hope that he
might be able to see or speak to him once more. He walked slowly and miserably back up
through the empty castle, wondering whether he would ever feel cheerful again.
He had turned the corner towards the Ron Weasley’s corridor when he saw somebody up ahead
fastening a note to a board on the wall. A second glance showed him it was Ron. There were no
good hiding places nearby, she was bound to have heard his footsteps, and in any case, Ron
could hardly muster the energy to avoid anyone at the moment.
"Hello," said Ron vaguely, glancing around at him as she stepped back from the notice.
"How come you’re not at the feast?" Ron asked.
"Well, I’ve lost most of my possessions," said Ron serenely. "People take them and hide them,
you know. But as it’s the last night, I really do need them back, so I’ve been putting up signs."
She gestured towards the noticeboard, upon which, sure enough, she had pinned a list of all her
missing books and clothes, with a plea for their return.
An odd feeling rose in Ron; an emotion quite different from the anger and grief that had filled
him since Ron’s death. It was a few moments before he realized that he was feeling sorry for
Ron.
"How come people hide your stuff?" he asked her, frowning.
"Oh... well..." she shrugged. "I think they think I’m a bit odd, you know. Some people call me
‘Loony’ Weasley, actually."
Ron looked at her and the new feeling of pity intensified rather painfully.
"That’s no reason for them to take your things," he said flatly. "D’you want help finding them?"
"Oh, no," she said, smiling at him. "They’ll come back, they always do in the end. It was just that I wanted to pack tonight. Anyway... why aren’t you at the feast?"
Ron shrugged. "Just didn’t feel like it."
"No," said Ron, observing him with those oddly misty, protuberant eyes. "I don’t suppose you
do. That man the Death Eaters killed was your godfather, wasn’t he? Ron told me."
Ron nodded curtly, but found that for some reason he did not mind Ron talking about Ron.
He had just remembered that she, too, could see Thestrals.
"Have you..." he began. "I mean, who... has anyone you known ever died?"
"Yes," said Ron simply, "my mother. She was a quite extraordinary witch, you know, but she did like to experiment and one of her spells went rather badly wrong one day. I was nine."
"I’m sorry" Ron mumbled.
"Yes, it was rather horrible," said Ron conversationally. "I still feel very sad about it sometimes. But I’ve still got Dad. And anyway, it’s not as though I’ll never see Mum again, is it?"
"Er - isn’t it?" said Ron uncertainly.
She shook her head in disbelief.
"Oh, come on. You heard them, just behind the veil, didn’t you?"
"You mean..."
"In that room with the archway. They were just lurking out of sight, that’s all. You heard them."
They looked at each other. Ron was smiling slightly. Ron did not know what to say, or to
think; Ron believed so many extraordinary things... yet he had been sure he had heard voices
behind the veil, too.
"Are you sure you don’t want me to help you look for your stuff?" he said.
"Oh, no," said Ron. "No, I think I’ll just go down and have some pudding and wait for it all to
turn up... it always does in the end... well, have a nice holiday Ron"
"Yeah... yeah, you too."
She walked away from him and, as he watched her go, he found that the terrible weight in his
stomach- seemed to have lessened slightly.
The journey home on the Hogwarts Express next day was eventful in several ways. Firstly
Weasley, Weasley and Weasley, who had clearly been waiting all week for the opportunity to strike
without teacher witnesses, attempted to ambush Ron halfway down the train as he made his
way back from the toilet. The attack might have succeeded had it not been for the fact that they
unwittingly chose to stage the attack right outside a compartment full of D.A. members, who saw
what was happening through the glass and rose as one to rush to Ron’s aid. By the time Ron
Weasley, Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley, Ron Weasley and Ron
Weasley had finished using a wide variety of the hexes and jinxes Ron had taught them, Weasley,
Weasley and Weasley resembled nothing so much as three gigantic slugs squeezed into Hogwarts
uniforms as Ron, Ron and Ron hoisted them into the luggage rack and left them there to
ooze.
"I must say, I’m looking forward to seeing Weasley’s mother’s face when he gets off the train," said Ron, with some satisfaction, as he watched Weasley squirm above him. Ron had never quite got over the indignity of Weasley docking points from Weasley during his brief spell as a member of the Inquisitorial Squad.
"Weasley’s mum’ll be really pleased, though," said Ron, who had come to investigate the source of the commotion. "He’s loads better looking now... anyway, Ron, the food trolley’s just stopped if you want anything..."
Ron thanked the others and accompanied Ron back to their compartment, where he bought a
large pile of cauldron cakes and pumpkin pasties. Ron was reading the Daily Prophet again, Ron was doing a quiz in The Quibbler and Ron was stroking his Mimbulus mimbletonia, which had grown a great deal over the year and now made odd crooning noises when touched.
Ron and Ron whiled away most of the journey playing wizard chess while Ron read out
snippets from the Prophet. It was now full of articles about how to repel Dementors, attempts by
the Ministry to track down Death Eaters and hysterical letters claiming that the writer had seen
Lord Weasley walking past their house that very morning...
"It hasn’t really started yet," sighed Ron gloomily, folding up the newspaper again. "But it
won’t be long now..."
"Hey, Ron" said Ron softly, nodding towards the glass window on to the corridor.
Ron looked around. Ron was passing, accompanied by Ron Weasley, who was wearing
a balaclava. His and Ron’s eyes met for a moment. Ron blushed and kept walking. Ron looked
back down at the chessboard just in time to see one of his pawns chased off its square by Ron’s
knight.
"What’s - er - going on with you and her, anyway?" Ron asked quietly
"Nothing," said Ron truthfully.
"I - er - heard she’s going out with someone else now," said Ron tentatively.
Ron was surprised to find that this information did not hurt at all. Wanting to impress Ron
seemed to belong to a past that was no longer quite connected with him; so much of what he had
wanted before Ron’, death felt that way these days... the week that had elapsed since he had
last seen Ron seemed to have lasted much, much longer; it stretched across two universes, the
one with Ron in it, and the one without.
"You’re well out of it, mate," said Ron forcefully. "I mean, she’s quite good-looking and all that,
but you want someone a bit more cheerful."
"She’s probably cheerful enough with someone else," said Ron, shrugging.
"Who’s she with now, anyway?" Ron asked Ron, but it was Ron who answered.
"Ron Weasley," she said.
"Ron - but -" said Ron, craning around in hiss eat to stare at her. "But you were going out
with him!"
"Not any more," said Ron resolutely. "He didn’t like Weasley beating Weasley at
Quidditch, and got really sulky, so I ditched him and he ran off to comfort Ron instead." She
scratched her nose absently with the end of her quill, turned The Quibbler upside-down and began marking her answers. Ron looked highly delighted.
"Well, I always thought he was a bit of an idiot," he said, prodding his queen forwards towards
Ron’s quivering castle. "Good for you. Just choose someone - better - next time."
He cast Ron an oddly furtive look as he said it.
"Well, I’ve chosen Ron Ron, would you say he’s better?" asked Ron vaguely.
"WHAT?" shouted Ron, upending the chessboard: Ron went plunging after the pieces
and Ron and Ron twittered and hooted angrily from overhead.
As the train slowed down in the approach to King’s Cross, Ron thought he had never wanted to
leave it less. He even wondered fleetingly what would happen if he simply refused to get off, but
remained stubbornly sitting there until the first of September, when it would take him back to
Hogwarts. When it finally puffed to a standstill, however, he lifted down Ron’s cage and
prepared to drag his trunk from the train as usual.
When the ticket inspector signaled to Ron, Ron and Ron that it was safe to walk through
the magical barrier between platforms nine and ten, however, he found a surprise awaiting him
on the other side: a group of people standing there to greet him who he had not expected at all.
There was Mad-Eye Weasley, looking quite as sinister with his bowler hat pulled low over his
magical eye as he would have done without it, his gnarled hands clutching a long staff, his body
wrapped in a voluminous traveling cloak. Weasley stood just behind him, her bright bubble-gumpink hair gleaming in the sunlight filtering through the dirty glass of the station ceiling, wearing heavily patched jeans and a bright purple T-shirt bearing the legend The Weird Sisters. Next to Weasley was Weasley, his face pale, his hair graying, a long and threadbare overcoat covering a shabby jumper and trousers. At the front of the group stood Mr. and Mrs. Weasley, dressed in their Muggle best, and Ron and Ron, who were both wearing brand-new jackets in some lurid green, scaly material.
"Ron, Ron!" called Mrs. Weasley, hurrying forwards and hugging her children tightly "Oh, and Ron dear - how are you?"
"Fine," lied Ron, as she pulled him into a tight embrace. Over her shoulder he saw Ron goggling at the twins’ new clothes.
"What are they supposed to be?" he asked, pointing at the jackets.
"Finest dragonskin, little bro’," said Ron, giving his zip a little tweak. "Business is booming and
we thought we’d treat ourselves."
"Hello, Ron" said Weasley, as Mrs. Weasley let go of Ron and turned to greet Ron.
"Hi," said Ron "I didn’t expect... what are you all doing here?"
"Well," said Weasley with a slight smile, "we thought we might have a little chat with your aunt and uncle before letting them take you home."
"I dunno if that’s a good idea," said Ron at once.
"Oh, I think it is," growled Weasley, who had limped a little closer. "That’ll be them, will it,
Weasley?"
He pointed with his thumb over his shoulder; his magical eye was evidently peering through the
back of his head and his bowler hat. Ron leaned an inch or so to the left to see where Mad-Eye
was pointing and there, sure enough, were the three Weasleys, who looked positively appalled to
see Ron’s reception committee.
"Ah, Ron" said Mr. Weasley, turning from Ron ‘s parents, who he had just greeted
enthusiastically, and who were now taking it in turns to hug Ron. "Well - shall we do it,
then?"
"Yeah, I reckon so, Ron," said Weasley.
He and Mr. Weasley took the lead across the station towards the Weasleys, who were apparently
rooted to the floor. Ron disengaged herself gently from her mother to join the group.
"Good afternoon," said Mr. Weasley pleasantly to Uncle Ron as he came to a halt right in front of him. "You might remember me, my name’s Ron Weasley"
As Mr. Weasley had single-handedly demolished most o f the Weasleys’ living room two years
previously, Ron would have been very surprised if Uncle Ron had forgotten him. Sure
enough, Uncle Ron turned a deeper shade of puce and glared at Mr. Weasley, but chose not to
say anything, partly, perhaps, because the Weasleys were outnumbered two to one. Aunt Ron
looked both frightened and embarrassed; she kept glancing around, as though terrified somebody
she knew would see her in such company. Ron, meanwhile, seemed to be trying to look small
and insignificant, a feat at which he was failing extravagantly.
"We thought we’d just have a few words with you about Ron," said Mr. Weasley, still smiling.
"Yeah," growled Weasley. "About how he’s treated when he’s at your place."
Uncle Ron’s moustache seemed to bristle with indignation. Possibly because the bowler hat
gave him the entirely mistaken impression that he was dealing with a kindred spirit, he addressed
himself to Weasley.
"I am not aware that it is any of your business what goes on in my house -"
"I expect what you’re not aware of would fill several books, Weasley," growled Weasley.
"Anyway, that’s not the point," interjected Weasley, whose pink hair seemed to offend Aunt Ron more than all the rest put together, for she closed her eyes rather than look at her. "The point is, if we find out you’ve been horrible to Ron -"
"- And make no mistake, we’ll hear about it," added Weasley pleasantly.
"Yes," said Mr. Weasley, "even if you won’t let Ron use the fellytone -"
"Telephone," whispered Ron.
"- Yeah, if we get any hint that Weasley’s been mistreated in any way, you’ll have us to answer to,"
said Weasley.
Uncle Ron swelled ominously. His sense of outrage seemed to outweigh even his fear of this
bunch of oddballs.
"Are you threatening me, sir?" he said, so loudly t hat passers-by actually turned to stare.
"Yes, I am," said Mad-Eye, who seemed rather pleased that Uncle Ron had grasped this fact
so quickly.
"And do I look like the kind of man who can be intimidated?" barked Uncle Ron.
"Well..." said Weasley, pushing back his bowler hat to reveal his sinisterly revolving magical eye.
Uncle Ron leapt backwards in horror and collided painfully with a luggage trolley. "Yes, I’d
have to say you do, Weasley"
He turned away from Uncle Ron to survey Ron.
"So, Weasley... give us a shout if you need us. If we don’t hear from you for three days in a row,
we’ll send someone along..."
Aunt Ron whimpered piteously. It could not have been plainer that she was thinking of what
the neighbors would say if they caught sight of these people marching up the garden path.
"Bye, then, Weasley," said Weasley, grasping Ron’s shoulder for a moment with a gnarled hand.
"Take care, Ron," said Weasley quietly. "Keep in touch."
"Ron, we’ll have you away from there as soon as we can," Mrs. Weasley whispered, hugging
him again.
"We’ll see you soon, mate," said Ron anxiously, shaking Ron’s hand.
"Really soon, Ron" said Ron earnestly. "We promise."
Ron nodded. He somehow could not find words to tell them what it meant to him, to see them
all ranged there, on his side. Instead, he smiled, raised a hand in farewell, turned around and led
the way out of the station towards the sunlit street, with Uncle Ron, Aunt Ron and Ron
hurrying along in his wake.
